Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 17:10:59 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Head gasket?...

>
>Recently I turned my 1980 928 over to a kind mechanic to do a pre-track
>inspection.  To my surprise he told me that the car had no major
>problems, only a slightly leaky head gasket.  He said that it would be
>fine for a while and only $150 to fix it when I wanted to.  Not having
>$150 to spare, I told him I'd do it later.  This weekend I went to the
>track and had a great time- I am amazed at the 928's performance (I
>can't believe it's 15 years old!).  However, I had one very scary
>experience:  On the straight I was passing another car and had the tach.
>needle just up into the red before I was going to shift.  I looked into
>the rear view mirror to see if it was clear to get back over and saw a
>BIG cloud of smoke!  It was coming from my tailpipe!  I have seen this
>in my rear view mirror before, but not smoke this dense and abundant.
>As I let offthe gas it slowly tapered off and,to make a long story
>short, was fine for the rest of the day (I did not take it to red ever
>again!)  My instructor said that it was the leak in the head gasket
>letting a little bit of oil into the combustion chamber.  He said that
>when oil ignites it creates a big cloud like my car did.  Does this
>sound right?  If I fix the head gasket should that take care of the
>puffs of smoke I see in the rear view mirror when accelerating hard?  Or
>does this have nothing to do with a leaking head gasket?  This is
>probably the most important post I have ever put to the list(for me!),
>so could I get more than a 2 replies even though I'm a 928?  :)
>Thanks in advance, Sean
>
>

As a water-cooled porschephile, I would suggest that you get it fixed.
Now, before you have a warped head to go along with the gasket.

Also, these things never fail completely at the most opportune time.
Now is the time to fix it...

(Reply #1)
Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 17:20:21 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: RE: Problems with changing gears

>Asad Husain wrote: Is there a secret to changing from 1st to second gear on
a
>911SC? When I change gears from 1st to second, I hear this horrible grinding
.

One thing that you may want to try is double clutching on the upshift.  You
won't win any stoplight drag races shifting this way but the 915 sure seems
to like it.  I gotten into the habit of doing a little abbreviated
double-clutch
on most of my upshifts and have no trouble shifting into any gear at any
speed.  BTW, my 915 gearbox also has about 100k miles on it, has never
been opened up (to the best of my knowledge) and I think it shifts rather
nicely.  (big "FWIW" there...)

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Wed, 31 May 95 23:10:30 edt
From: Craig <pp002619@interramp.com>
Subject: 1988 911 Cab

Well I have found an 88 Cabriolet (it's even black!) that I am interested in, following everyone advice I had it 
checked by a dealer.  Even had the compression and leak-down tests done.

The results were:
165 lbs	.25%
175 	.20
170	.20
170	.20
175	.20
175	.30

According to the dealer these are OK.

They did find LOTS of small stuff that needed attention:
*Top needs adjustment (it is new) and possibly needs seals on window  $280.00 plus parts if needed
*Exhaust leak, needs gasket				        350.00
Cam oil lines "seeping" (not leaking yet)			        265.00
*4 wheel alignment (new tires but wearing inconsistantly)	        120.00  
Deck shocks will need replacment			        120.00
Belts will need replacement				          80.00
Check vlave on windshield washer needs replaced		          43.00
Drivers side mirror does not go up and down ( left right ok)	          85.00 plus parts if needed

* should be done now according to dealer

All told about $1,350.00 plus parts.

Sort of seems like a lot of stuff has not been attended to!  Supposedly they do have records for oil changes 
and other maintenance.

Should I overlook all these items that have been neglected, just use them to get a better price (asking price is 
$27,500), or does this seem like a danger signal?  The car has about 47,000 miles on it.

Thanks for any advice.

Craig

Date: Wed, 31 May 95 14:45:53 -0700
From: keith_watson@MENTORG.COM (Keith Watson)
Subject: Re: Seen on Kansas Turnpike

> This last Friday I found myself sitting behind a pickup pulling a
> trailor while waiting at the west bound ticket booth for I-70 at
> Kansas City.  On the trailor was a VW race car.  In bright yellow
> letters across the hatch it said, "Wabbit Wacing".  I found it
> fairly humorous...

Us wabbit wacers have a *lot* of fun in those cars.
Set up right they are great handling cars.  OK, mines
a Golf not a Wabbit.  Racing Rabbits are popular out
here in Portland, OR.  I've had mine at a Porsche track
day and none of the modified street Porsches could pull
away from me in the turns.  Quite a few held me up.  Of
course they all blew by me on the straight.  The only
thing which could corner faster was a race 911RS.

At last month's track day I took my stock 911 out
in the rain so the car would point out all of my bad
habits.  A 911 *demands* to be driven correctly.  My
Golf is so easy to drive it covers up bad habits.
Boy, did I start out driving bad!  It took half an hour
before I was driving the car well.  The next hour was
spent giggling every time the car skated over the slick
part of the racing line.  Then the line started drying
out. :-(  I credit that time in the rain helping me
get my first win in the Golf a week later.

Keith Watson
'81 Porsche 911 SC Targa (dark green)
'85 VW race Golf (white, bright yellow, bright orange)
The Golf is 4 seconds faster than my Targa.

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 14:58:38 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: 1988 911 Cab

>Well I have found an 88 Cabriolet (it's even black!) that I am interested in,
>following everyone advice I had it checked by a dealer.  Even had the
>compression and leak-down tests done.
>
>The results were:
>165 lbs .25%
>175     .20
>170     .20
>170     .20
>175     .20
>175     .30
>
>According to the dealer these are OK.

Are the leak-down numbers between 20% and 30% or do you really mean all are
less than 1%?

If the leak-down numbers are really between 20% and 30%, I would run away
from the car. If the number are really less than 1% the dealer is lying to
you and you should run away from the car or have an independant shop check
it out. Leak-down numbers between 2% and 10% are what you should look for.
I would prefer closer to the 2% but this is not likely to be what you will
find out there.



Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 18:02:12 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: What's SCCA?

> How does SCCA differ from Club Racing?  Which is easier to get into?  I
> know that you have to do a lot of driving schools to do Club Racing, but
> I heard that it's relatively easy to do SCCA racing.  How do people feel
> about it?  What are the reqirements for your car?  It it cut-throat or
> do people have fun with it?  Thanks for any replies, Sean  '80 928

All racing takes two things (1) more money that sense and (2) a car that
you don't mind seeing get wadded up into a little ball of smoking metal,
because that's what you *CAN* get at any event, at any time, through no
fault of your own.

SCCA is also Club Racing, but it's a different club. Alas, they have little
to no place for most Porsches, since all Porsches are really race cars that
hang out on the street. The rules make it difficult to compete effectively
in any of the club classes in any Porsche (but lots of us do so anyway).

As to requirements, it depends entirely on the class, ranging from Showroom
Stock (bolt in roll cage, window net, harness, driver safety gear) to
GT ("all cars are assumed to be of a tubular frame construction...")

There is no class in which the 928 is legal other than in PCA Club Racing.
Sorry.

Stan 
(ex SCCA and IMSA 911 and 914 pusher, future SVRA competitor)

that person who started the myth that toyotas run forever?

rush into anything.  However, my hands been forced.  I am willing to rent 
a car for a couple of weeks to keep from buying the next car I see.  But 
I will have to buy one within the next month.

true.  A 1983 911SC with 68,000 miles, asking 13,500  Second owner (for 
only 4 months, divorce forces sale), the original owner was a mechanic 
and did all the tune ups and oil changes.  The owner, who imports Porsches 
told me that nothing

expect?  Isn't there a major 60K service that should be done?  Of course 
I will take it to a trusted Porsche mechanic to check it out completely, 
but I just wanted to pick the collective minds of porschephiles before 
looking at it.

of the paint color.  He said it was the original paint and was a cross 
between Platnium and Bronze.  Any idea what color?  Will it offend?
Thanks,

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 17:22:20 -0700
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: Re:      Head gasket?...

Yo Sean!

Regarding your smoking 928, the first thing to do is find out where the oil is
being ingested.  Pop off the airbox right after this happens (it will happen
again) and see if there is oil in the airbox.  If there is oil there, it's 
coming from a pressurized crankcase which is forcing the oil up through the
oil supply tube in the pan, past the breather and into the airbox, throttle body
and engine.  You'll need to make sure the breather tube from the "V" of the
engine to the oil cap is clear.  Mine wasn't.  It had collapsed inside and
was blocking the flow of air, pressurizing the case and pumping oil into the
airbox.  Makes for a great misquito-killer (and birds) but not much else.
Mine only did this when I was under full-throttle for several seconds and then
a sharp turn; the autocross guys were not impressed.

If your airbox is clean and has no oil residue, then a damaged or weak head
gasket is likely.  Is there oil in the water?  How does your mechanic know the
head gasket is "seeping"?  Oil leaks?  Water leaks?

later,
bill
'79 928 



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 31 May 95 17:46:01 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: What's SCCA?

} From: "Sean P. Simmen"  <SEAN@american.edu>
}
} How does SCCA differ from Club Racing?  Which is easier to get into?  I
} know that you have to do a lot of driving schools to do Club Racing, but
} I heard that it's relatively easy to do SCCA racing.  How do people feel
} about it?  What are the reqirements for your car?  It it cut-throat or
} do people have fun with it?  Thanks for any replies, Sean  '80 928

The local SCCA folks here in the Pacific Northwest have agreed to
a Porsche-only grid at their road race events. The big difference,
as I understand it, is that PCA club racing and the p-car grid both
abide by the 13-13 rule. I don't think SCCA uses the 13-13 rule (but
I could be wrong, which is why I am asking for correction if so!).

The 13-13 rule says that if the race steward finds you as the cause
of an "incident" you go on a 13 month probation. If you cause an
incident during the probation, you are bared from competing for
13 months. Not sure if an incident would be limited to bent sheetmetal
or if merely running someone off the course would be an infraction.
The idea is to encourage participants to respect the lives and
property (cars) of the other participants.

BTW, I am not yet a racer. I have just started attending driver's ed events
so I can develop my meager skills. Sure is a lot of fun, though!

    Eric

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 20:26:56 -0500
From: jeffk914@groucho.roc.servtech.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Smoking 914 all better now. :)

Katarina is feeling MUCH better now... The problem was basically a bad fuel
injector. It was contantly spraying fuel into the cylinder, which is a
LITTLE more than it's supposed to. :)

Thank goodness for problems that aren't quite as bad as they seem!

Jeff Kyle

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 22:59:24 EDT
From: AWJK94A@prodigy.com (MR DREW A SPENCER)
Subject: Unsticking stuck heat exchanger bolts.


When I was stripping all the misc bits off the motor
on my SC, I found this really nasty smelling stuff called
PB Blaster at Pep Boys. I sprayed all the nuts and waited
a couple days, went back and sprayed them again.  Not
one of them stuck, and they WERE rusted.  Granted, this
is little solace for you now that one has broken off, but
this penetrant may help you get the others off without
breaking...
Re: Hex ends...
I have two options for the hex nuts.  One is a set of
T-handle hex wrenches from Sears.  Another option that
works is 3/8's hex end sockets with a long extension.

Good luck,
Drew
Drew Spencer (aka awjk94A@prodigy.com)
'93 RS America
'82 911 SC (track car waiting for me to finish it...)

Subject: 911 Bump Steer Kit

RR DONNELLEY & SONS COMPANY
 
          TO:        OAS     -00000001 *porschephiles@tta.com
 
          FROM:      TODD.COHEN
 
          DATE:      05/31/95
          TIME:      22:57:00
 
          SUBJECT:   911 Bump Steer Kit
 
 
After installing the 1/2" bump steer spacers under the steering rack of my
'72 911, the steering binds during certain steering wheel positions.
Since I loosened the U-bracket under the access cover in the trunk to
allow the steering rack to move up, I know the binding is caused by the
U-joint under this access cover.  I can loosen the U-bracket that holds
the shaft under the cover and release the tension on the steering column,
but I can't drive the car like this.  To fix this, do I need to loosen all
the U-Joints in the steering column to release the tension, then tighten
everything back?  This requires removing the plastic cover in the trunk,
and the passanger compartment fan.
 
Todd Cohen
1972 911T (Leaf Green)

Date: Thu, 01 Jun 1995 02:46:06 -0400 (EDT)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: Re: Wax Residue

Be careful with the PreKleano (sp?).  It's great for prepping cars
for paint.  It also *softens* the paint (to give the surface better
"tooth").  I would recommend trying a less agressive product.


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 01 Jun 1995 02:46:19 -0400 (EDT)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: 914 Axle Nut + VW Engine Rebuild Book C

Did anyone suggest using the old gas hatchet?  An oxy acetylene 
torch with a fair size rosebud (about as big as your thumb).  Heat
until cherry red.  If that doesn't loosen it heat again and cool
immeadiately with ice water.  I've found very few fasteners
will stand up to this kind of abuse.  (a new nut is HIGHLY 
recommended)  Use fireblanket and water soaked rags around
non-target parts.  And a firewatch!  Have someone standing
around for firewatch with an extinguisher.  After all, you really
don't want to set your car on fire, do you?

(don't ask me how I know)

Wilson's book, "How to Rebuild Your VOLKSWAGEN Air-Cooled Engine"
ISBN 0-89586-225-5, should be required reading for all flat four 
wrench benders.  The guy has ALOT of good ideas (did anyone mention
the flywheel saddle for your floorjack?  I just caught this thread.)
I don't agree with *everything* he says.  This comes from being
experienced and/or highly opinionated.  It's the kind of book that
Larry Reynolds will ultimately write about car care (given a few more
probing, insightful posts!)


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1445                         Thu Jun 1 14:21:46 CDT 1995
Date: Thu, 1 Jun 1995 05:27:23 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Early 944 Seat Removal


>Now for something that is P-car related. Does anyone know how to remove 
>the seats from the floorboard of a 84' 944. There are rails that the seat 
>ride on, and the heads of the bolts are so close to the sides of the 
>rails, that I can't get a socket on them. Again thanks for any help.
>

Hi Rich,

The seat bolts are standard 10 mm heads. They can be removed by
a 10 mm thinwall socket (try snapon or sears craftsman) on a 1/4 inch
drive extension with a universal joint.

The 3/8 inch drive is too large to get in there, I agree...
Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology
Suppliers of Used 944 Parts to Her Majesty
Orders: 800-all-p944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
83 944, 97 944S, 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 80 GMC Pickup

Date: Thu, 01 Jun 95 10:02:00 PDT
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: 928 belt warning


>Date: Wed, 31 May 95 10:30:48 EDT
>From: "Chuck Olson PKO3-2/Q21; DTN: 223-4816  31-May-1995 1002"\
> <olson@lando.ENET.dec.com>
>RE: 928 belt tension

Chuck,
Like Clint Eastwood/Dirty Harry  would say, "Do you feel lucky?"  Being an 
S4, allot of expensive head work will need to be done If it breaks.  Mine 
broke once, luckily I have the 16 valve US motor, so no damage other than a 
belt.  Replacing it is pretty routine, but time consuming.  It took me about 
9-10 hours at a leisurely rate, breaking for coffee often and cleaning 
everything really well as I went.  I didn't want to rush it my first time 
through. <g>

Hardest part was torquing the bolt down on the Harmonic Balancer, it takes 
some effort.  You will need to lock your flywheel down to do this or you'll 
just turn the engine.  I think Automotion sells a flywheel lock for the 928 
for around $20-30.

The belt tensioning tool is needed to adjust an S4 belt correctly.  Bruce 
Anderson advised that on the older 16 valve motors you can usually get away 
with adjusting the tension by hand (if you have the feel for it), but not on 
the S4 motor he advised.  The tool runs about $400.

As for replacing the water pump, it's probably a good idea.  I replaced mine 
while I had it all apart.  If the pump goes bad, you will have to do all 
this work over again.  Of course you could get a bad new pump too, but 
chances of that are less likely.

I've heard horror stories of bolts breaking off in the aluminum block, so 
you may wish to use some penetrating oil like PB Blaster (my favorite) or 
Liquid Wrench.  Don't forget to use anti-seize where appropriate when 
putting it all back together for the next time.

Even after you buy the parts and the expensive special tools, you'll still 
be ahead of what a dealer would charge you for this service.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 31 May 1995 15:42:58 -0400 (EDT)
From: Mark Krieger <msk@unipress.com>
Subject: Re: happy 914 shifting & rocker/valance resto ?'s

Dennis,

Hi. About your rocker panels: I took mine off (rather Stan took mine off, 
they were so glued to the car that it took all of his considerable power!).
Then I took off all the decals, etc. (with WD-40 helping), banged them 
straight with a good old trusty hammer, sanded the rough spots, and then 
primed and painted them flat black. 3 coats, took no time at all. They 
look new. Used new hardware to put them back on. I then put the 
new little rubber pieces over the jack inserts and it looks real good.

Mark

914-2.0 1973 -- oh what fun today, 80 outside, top off.

Mark Krieger          
UniPress Software     http://www.unipress.com 
msk@unipress.com      (908)287-2100 x937

Date: 1 Jun 95 11:32:00 EST
From: "LOGISX::GIBBS" <GIBBS%LOGISX.decnet@vaxa.acdnj.itt.com>
Subject: 944 Clutch is Toast?

Just got back from a few days off, so I'm late responding to this, but
didn't the original post sound just like the infamous 944 Stuck Clutch
Syndrome (the one that goes away if you CAREFULLY brake and accelerate
in 1st gear on a clear stretch of road?  This was discussed here several
months ago, and I remember it because I had it happen to me a couple 
years ago.  I fixed it by jamming the car into reverse as it was rolling
backwards down my driveway, and it has been fine ever since.

Ed Gibbs
gibbs@avionics.itt.com
'84 944, Guards Red, All Mine!

Date: Thu, 1 Jun 1995 11:00:03 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: 944 Production Numbers

Barry Lenoble writes:

>Am I the only one who finds it very interesting that each post gives a very
>different number of cars produced? Does anyone know the reason why the
>publications used for the numbers list such different numbers? Is one list
>for just the US and the others for the rest of the world?

The original list was US sales figures.  The list from Peter Morgan's
book is world wide production figures (not necesarily sales).

>I also thought that the 944 Turbo was not produced until 86, and that the
>924S was not sold until 87.

The 944 Turbo was only sold in the US from '86 to '89.  It was sold in
the rest of the world from '85 to '91.  The 924S was only sold in the 
US in '87 and '88.  I assume like the Turbo it was sold in the rest
of the world longer.

Ross Stites
'87 951

>---------------------------------------------------------------------------  
 ---
>
>Recently I turned my 1980 928 over to a kind mechanic to do a pre-track
>inspection.  To my surprise he told me that the car had no major
>problems, only a slightly leaky head gasket.  He said that it would be
>fine for a while and only $150 to fix it when I wanted to.  Not having
>$150 to spare, I told him I'd do it later.  This weekend I went to the
>track and had a great time- I am amazed at the 928's performance (I
>can't believe it's 15 years old!).  However, I had one very scary
>experience:  On the straight I was passing another car and had the tach.
>needle just up into the red before I was going to shift.  I looked into
>the rear view mirror to see if it was clear to get back over and saw a
>BIG cloud of smoke!  It was coming from my tailpipe!  I have seen this
>in my rear view mirror before, but not smoke this dense and abundant.
>As I let offthe gas it slowly tapered off and,to make a long story
>short, was fine for the rest of the day (I did not take it to red ever
>again!)  My instructor said that it was the leak in the head gasket
>letting a little bit of oil into the combustion chamber.  He said that
>when oil ignites it creates a big cloud like my car did.  Does this
>sound right?  If I fix the head gasket should that take care of the
>puffs of smoke I see in the rear view mirror when accelerating hard?  Or
>does this have nothing to do with a leaking head gasket?  This is
>probably the most important post I have ever put to the list(for me!),
>so could I get more than a 2 replies even though I'm a 928?  :)
>Thanks in advance, Sean
>

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 1 Jun 95 10:09:13 -0700
From: keith_watson@MENTORG.COM (Keith Watson)
Subject: Re: What's SCCA?

> How does SCCA differ from Club Racing?  Which is easier to get into?  I
> know that you have to do a lot of driving schools to do Club Racing, but
> I heard that it's relatively easy to do SCCA racing.  How do people feel
> about it?  What are the reqirements for your car?  It it cut-throat or
> do people have fun with it?  Thanks for any replies, Sean  '80 928

Go out and watch a weekend of SCCA racing and a weekend of PCA racing.
At the SCCA weekend watch how many cars come off the track broke or
bent.  There *will* be more than one.  As Stan already mentioned you
have to be willing to accept the fact that if you take the car out
on track for *any* event it may come back rolled up in a ball.
Been there, done that.  SCCA racing is very aggressive.  From what
I read PCA racing is much more low keyed but I haven't seen one yet.

As far as "easier to get into", the requirements are on the driver
and both forms have similar requirements.

Keith Watson - licensed ICSCC driver
'81 Porsche 911 - street and driver ed events
'85 VW race Golf - because of this car a body man is now a
   good friend of mine

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 01 Jun 95 10:13:00 PDT
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: RE: 928 belt tension


Wise move.

As a former (sniff :( ) 86.5 928S owner, I'm always interested in the 32 
valve engines.  I had an opportunity to see one out of the car the other day 
at my favorite shop.  Seems the owner had neglected to change the belt @ 
60K, and, stopped at a stop light, the engine died.  That was it.  7 bent 
valves  (ONLY EARLY 928s HAVE ENOUGHT CLEARANCE!)  $7000 later, (had other 
stuff done while it was out) he's back on the road, a wiser and poorer P-car 
owner.

$5000 will cover the cost of the head work, but not a rebuild.

I would spend an extra $40 and have the car moved via flatbed towtruck to 
the shop.  It's an expensive risk to drive it.

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu

Date: Thu, 1 Jun 95 11:05:20 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Porsche Motorsport Control Arms.


Thought the 944/951/968 track persons would like to know this:

The price for the 951.341.027.32 and 951.341.028.32 control arms
is $747.32 each.

They are only available, at this time, from Porsche Motorsports North 
America. Terms are Certified or Cashier's check to PMNA for the full 
amount + $50.00 shipping. Upon receipt of funds parts will be ordered 
from Germany. Parts are shipped withing 24 hours of receipt from Germany.
Generally, orders are taking 4 weeks. If you have a Fed-Ex account, you 
can deduct the  $50.00 shipping. Thanks, Mark Popov-Dadani and staff.


Rear stub axle nut. There is no Loctite or other similar compound used 
with the nut. The nut is a ONE-TIME use only. Use a new nut if the stub 
axle is serviced in any way. The torque is 362ft-lbs for the ALLOY stub
axle nut only.

The steel arm stub axle nut torque is 268ft-lbs +52ft-lbs (the extra is to 
allow for alignment of the castle for the cotter key).

We tend to use some "adapted" tools for tightening these nuts. Porsche 
makes a special tool that adapts a normal torque wrench to these nuts for 
achieving the proper torque. If you have an accurate tool that 
accomplishes the same thing, use it. This is one area you do not want to 
guess on. Thanks to Mark Doan at PCNA for the clairification.

Jim Pasha

Date: Thu, 01 Jun 95 12:21:00 PDT
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: RE: rattling 914 rear window


>        And lastly, my rear window is getting really loose now and rattles
>and slaps in the wind. A rolled up newspaper behind my harness bar is doing
>an ok job for now, but is there an easy way to repair this myself? If
>anyone out there is familiar with this, a step-by-step would be really
>appreciated.

Mine was the same many years ago....here's what I did:

 - Go to your local automobile windshield supply
place and buy some "black windshield adhesive
stuff for a Porsche 914".  They will look it up in
their book and give you a roll of stuff which has
the correct dimensions (I can't remember the
size).
 - Remove the interior trim around the window
 - Remove the rear defroster wires (if equipped)
 - Remove the window with a SHARP utility knife.
Don't pry the window or force it in any way - it'll
break.  Simply cut away the old "goo" so the window
can be separated from the car.  This may take
a while.  It took me about an hour to remove
a front windshield without breaking it.
 - Carefully clean the window and frame mating
surface to remove all traces of old "goo".
 - Unroll the new "goo" on the frame in the same
place the old stuff was - don't squash it, just gently
press it in place.  It's sticky stuff, so it'll stay
in place.
 - Using a heat gun (paint stripper), heat the
"goo" and the window where it'll touch the "goo".
 - Wearing gloves, and with a friend helping you,
press the window into place by applying a fair
amount of pressure over each inch of the "goo".
 - Enjoy your rattle-free window for many more
years.

I've done this with both the front and rear windows
on my car.

Good luck!

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>
'75 914-6  3.0 SC

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 1 Jun 1995 15:55:50 -0400
From: cbt@eduplus.ca (Stephen Davies)
Subject: 944 vibration

> Date: Tue, 30 May 1995 17:38:02 EDT

>3000 RPM and stops at 3200 RPM. It can be felt throught the shifter and it
>causes the shifter to rattle..... etc

I have exactly the same symptoms at exactly the same rpm. I found that the
vibration was only prevalent when engaged. It disappeared as soon as I put
the clutch in. It has been diagnossed as a likely problem with the clutch.
It is being repaired as we speak. If your symptoms are the same let me know
and I will let you know if the clutch repair fixed it.

Stephen Davies
1988 944 Turbo S

Date: Thu, 1 Jun 1995 16:03:29 -0400 (EDT)
From: Rick Shimkets <quartz@minerva.cis.yale.edu>
Subject: Replacing the motor mounts... 914

but the engine mounts are gone.  Thanks in advance!  Rick

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 1 Jun 1995 15:36:42 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: Replacing the motor mounts... 914

>What's involved in replacing the motor mounts for my '72 914-4 and how
>much effort and/or tools will I need to muster, my tranny mounts are fine
>but the engine mounts are gone.

        1)  Jack the rear of the car (or the whole thing) up into the air
and support it.
        2)  Put a jack under the engine and take up the weight of the
engine on the jack.  It is a good idea to put a solid support under the
engine as well as the jack.  One place to put the jack (esp. with either the
special VW jack support or a wooden facsimile) is at the engine/tranny seam.
        3)  If the clutch and speedo drive cables run underneath or through
the engine support bar, diconnect them from the tranny end and get them out
of the way.

        I'm told that early cars have rubber mounts on the ends of the bar
and solid mounts from the bar to the engine.  73+ cars are the other way
around--and are the only ones I've done.  The next few steps may need to
be changed a bit to fit your installation.

        4)  Undo the two 10mm nuts holding the rubber engine mounts to the
middle of the bar.
        5)  Undo the two nuts and bolts holding the bar onto the solid
outboard motor mounts.  At some point in this procedure, the bar will fall
on you--be prepared to catch it.
        6)  Undo the two 10mm nuts holding the rubber engine mounts to the
engine.  It helps to be limber for this one!

        Ummm...  "Installation is the reverse of removal."  (TM Haynes).
(Well, it's true, *this* time!)

        You'll want to check the clutch pedal adjustment after you get the
clutch cable hooked back up.  Also be careful when you take the jack out
from under the engine--you want to make sure that the outboard nuts and bolts
are not still loose!
        Remember that you are removing the part of the car that supports the
weight of your engine, and then putting parts of your body underneath that
engine!  Be very very careful because not many people can bench-press the
weight of the engine, and fewer still can do it in the split-second that it
takes for the engine to fall on their head!

        Good luck!

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"

Date: Thu, 1 Jun 95 15:01:35 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  Replacing the motor mounts... 914

Rick,

Tail shift or side shift trany?  It makes a difference.

On the tail shifter, it's easy!  The mounts are at the outboard ends
of the engine mounting cross bar.  The other thing to look for here
is that the bracket where the bar attaches to the engine is on securely.

On the side shifter, you'll need to get to the mounts, which, when
I did mine, required removing the fan and fan housing (but, I did
it with the engine in the car).  This is considerable work, but
not unreasonable.

Pat
pat@ixi.saic.com

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 1 Jun 1995 18:00:49 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re:  Replacing the motor mounts... 914

>On the side shifter, you'll need to get to the mounts, which, when
>I did mine, required removing the fan and fan housing (but, I did
>it with the engine in the car).  This is considerable work, but
>not unreasonable.

        I did it with the blower and housing (shroud) in place--but
out of the car.  Not sure how much difference it makes.  It was
indeed a b*tch getting the open-ended wrench and/or 1/4" drive
socket on the nut--but it worked for me.
        If you *do* have to remove the fan and shrouding, you'll
need extra tools:  A BIG honkin' slot-head screwdriver to take the
sheet-metal off the front of the shroud, a "CV Joint wrench" (check
your local VW Bug specialty shop, or find an 8mm triple-box socket)
and a 13mm socket and extension.
        Unscrew the slot-head screws holding the sheetmetal on the
front.  Use the CV Joint socket to undo the three fan bolts, then
pull the fan off the hub.  This will expose four 13mm nuts that you
can remove.  Use a phillips-head screwdriver to loosen up the clamp
that holds the rubber air duct from the fan housing to the alternator,
and remove the duct from the alternator.  Then pull the housing for-
ward.  You may be able to get enough space by tilting it outward at
the bottom.
        When you put it back together, follow the torque spec on the
fan bolts.  It would be a *very* bad thing to have them come loose
out on the freeway somewhere.

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 1 Jun 95 16:11:19 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  Replacing the motor mounts... 914

>> >On the side shifter, you'll need to get to the mounts, which, when
>> >I did mine, required removing the fan and fan housing (but, I did
>> >it with the engine in the car).  This is considerable work, but
>> >not unreasonable.
>> 
>>         I did it with the blower and housing (shroud) in place--but
>> out of the car.  Not sure how much difference it makes.  It was
>> indeed a b*tch getting the open-ended wrench and/or 1/4" drive
>> socket on the nut--but it worked for me.


Opps.  Dave is correct.  I forgot that the big reason that I took 
the cooling stuff off was because of the solid mounts I made/installed
with the grade 8 hardware going through.  (Also, the mounts were
torn in two, but that's another story...)

>>         If you *do* have to remove the fan and shrouding, you'll
>> need extra tools:  A BIG honkin' slot-head screwdriver to take the
>> sheet-metal off the front of the shroud, a "CV Joint wrench" (check
>> your local VW Bug specialty shop, or find an 8mm triple-box socket)
>> and a 13mm socket and extension.

Take a look before you do this.  Some of the motors don't have the
same type of bolts holding the fan onto the hub anymore.  I've seen
some that all you will need is a 13mm socket with an extension.


Pat Norris
pat@ixi.saic.com

Date: Thu, 01 Jun 1995 22:07:30 GMT
From: kam@sandwell.demon.co.uk (Keith A Matthews)
Subject: Porsche Model Range

As a recent P-car convert I have been avidly reading about current
and future developments at Porsche. Unless I have misunderstood it 
seems that the future model range will consist of only the Boxster
and the 911 replacement. Two two-seater sports cars sharing a lot of 
components but with different drivetrain configurations. At the risk
of stirring up a hornets nest at best, and being excommunicated at 
worst it seem to me that if the Boxster is as good as it should be
then it should be a 'better' car than it's rear engined stablemate.

I would be interested to know if Porsche ever seriously considered 
continuing with a front engined car, and perhaps making a 2-door
4-seater. This might of course have meant *dropping* the rear engined
concept retaining only the Boxster if a two car range is all that 
could be accomodated. The world is changing and high performance cars
may not always be as socially acceptable in the future as there are at 
present. The future might better accomodate cars with a 'family' image
and a 4 seater P might be better than no P. An old English proverb 
states 'half a loaf is better than no bread!' It seems to me that 
there will be a lot of Stuttgart eggs in a single basket going into
the twenty-first century.

Apologies if this has been discussed previously and to anyone upset
by the heretical ramblings above.  

- -- 
Keith A Matthews
1986 944 (Great white tadpole)
          to be replaced in the year 2001 by a 1996 Boxster!

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 1 Jun 1995 21:07:32 -0400
From: Phyl346@aol.com
Subject: Distilled or Non-Distilled H2O?

Greetings All,

Most know to use only distilled water in their batteries and steam irons but
what about the radiator?

Seems to me if you eliminate the ions and minerals from the coolant, you
eliminate corrosion and the precipitation of minerals that reduce radiator
efficiency.

Anyone have any ideas on this subject, or am I just being an anal retentive
engineer .... again?

TIA


Phil Carr
Austin, Tx

'83 944
'65 M.G. Midget
'70 BMW R60/5

Date: 1 Jun 95 14:29:00 +1700
From: MIFSUD_BRIAN@Tandem.COM
Subject: 914 Seat Upgrades/Throttle Switch

will fit into a 914 (bolt in)?  "Dee" makes seats for VW's, does anyone know if
they build them for 914s?  Any other brands I don't know of?  Used is dandy for
me as long as they work.  If need be, I can do any machining to adapt a set.
  914 Throttle Switch- had "bucking" problem (random and infrequent) at constan
t speed, PORSCHEPHILES to RESCUE with advice to clean and re (dielectric)grease
the offending switch (really just fancy potentiometer)  PRESTO, "bucking" gone.
HOORAY, this People-Base REALLY WORKS!!!!  Thanks for the GREAT ADVICE!  Any
recommendations on Hot Stocks Out There?????  O.K.  O.K.
  Non Porsche Seat Issue- My MB 240D (1979) has seats that died and went to
heaven (horsehair totally gone, springs in my decrepit backbones).  I need my
driver's seat rebuilt with springs repaired, new horsehair pads, and new
Mercedes Textile Upholstery ('cause all are dead).  Any recommendations for a
trustworthy San Francisco Bay Area Seat/Repair Joint?  My only quote right now
is $500/seat. After I got up off the floor, I started eyeing the Lumbar Adjust-
able seats (new @$850+).  I'm not sure that the totally restored (stock) seat
will help my back out, but never sat in a young 123 Chassis seat (since last
123 was built in '85).  Any help out there? Has anyone tried putting a late
model MB seat into a 123 chassis? (123 is the 240D, 300D, 300CD etc. chassis
from 1977 to 1985)
thanks all brian

Date: Thu, 1 Jun 1995 20:32:16 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Unsticking stuck heat exchanger bolts.

Hi Barry,

Heat them cherry red with as much of the flame on the side of the nut as 
possible.  I prefer to use a #0 tip with 5-7lbs of acetylene and 7-12 lbs 
Oxygen.

As for the special tool I use a long metric allen wrench that was cut 
with a cut off saw.  I hold the long piece of the wrench with the 
appropriate 3/8 drive socket.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974

Date: Mon, 29 May 1995 23:22:36 -0400
From: HHeath3@aol.com
Subject: A mountain drive in a Porsche

Well, Memorial Day dawned moderate and sunny, after weeks of
drizzly/stormy/snowy spring here in Salt Lake City.  I ran in to the office
early and crashed through a project that just had to be ready for tomorrow,
came home for lunch, and persuaded my spouse to ride along in the 944 for a
few hours of mountain touring.  She's an artist, and the cumuli were building
over the Wasatch mountains; she thought there might be subjects to paint, so
agreed enthusiastically.

First, we cruised up Emigration Canyon, route of the infamous Donner party on
their way to an appointment with tragedy, and of the Mormon pioneers first
entering the valley in 1847.  Climbing steadily, past historic Ruth's Diner,
the Santa Fe Restaurant (try the rack of lamb and don't forget a margarita or
two, with salt), past Crompton's Roadside Attraction (best hamburgers in a
log cabin yet), we crested the front rank of the mountains slowed a bit by
the hardy mountain bikers climbing the 3,000 feet or so in their colorful
spandex.  Then it was down the smooth, twisty switchbacks to the edge of the
Mountain Dell reservoir.  Then we turned left, and began climbing again, up
to the saddle of Big Mountain, where Brigham Young last camped before
descending into the valley.  (The ascent that took us 30 minutes for them was
a descent of six days!)  We drove to the edge of the parking area, looking
southwest with snowy mountains ahead and to the left, the valley in view
below us, and the Oquirrh Mountains clearly visible across the valley, maybe
30 miles away.

The Porsche was humming, temp in the middle of the band, oil pressure right
where it ought to be, the sunroof tipped up so we could smell the breezes as
we started down the mountain switchbacks headed north.  We ran down the
valley past East Canyon Lake all the way to the Interstate, took a run down
toward Ogden on a lumpy, barricaded single lane, pursued by a hostile moving
van, until we pulled off at Peterson for a soda and enjoyment of the scenery.
 Behind the snack shop, we found a shady spot for my platinum baby, and
sipped our drinks while watching horses munch grass in a lush green pasture,
with snowcapped mountains spread behind.  Here was one of the paintings my
wife sought; photos were taken.

Then we headed easterly down a curvy two-lane, through several tiny burgs,
huge lilac hedges in full bloom, the hillsides teeming with brilliant yellow
flowers amongst the sagebrush.  Soon we were back to East Canyon lake, then
retracing our miles over Big Mountain and down Emigration Canyon.  

Back in our garage, Heinrich II cooled, clicking and clacking and making its
settling-in-for-the-night noises.  I cleaned off the brake dust, closed the
sunroof, and stepped out onto the deck to enjoy the late afternoon beauty of
the valley.  Yes, a lovely afternoon, in a lovely little car.  This was the
kind of day, the kind of road, the kind of loving companion this *sports car*
was made for.  I can't wait for the next time; maybe out to Cedar Valley for
a long fast run where you can see the sheriff coming 20 miles away!

I hope you all had experiences at least half as pleasant with your Porsches
this weekend.  Vroom!

Hunter Heath


------------------------------

Date:      Mon, 29 May 1995 23:41:54 -0500
From: "Chris Alexander" <chris@smaug.synapse.net>
Subject:   Re: 911 Tunes

A solution that worked for me was to get a 
portable CD player that plugs into the cassette
player.   You'll want to get one of the better 
ones though, they skip quite a bit in a firm car
like a 911.   I managed to work around it by 
using a foam insert that ethernet card 5 packs
are sometimes packed in (what a geek!).   Stuck
the CD player in one of the slots and shoved the 
whole thing in the glove box.   Not 100% but
usable.

I couldn't bear the thought of pulling my
CD changer out of my (dreaded) 4x4 and drilling
holes in my 911 to mount it.   Don't care 
about the truck, the drilling holes part is
like nails on a chalk board.

I agree with Uncle Bart, there's lots of other
"music" to listen to and things to observe
but I find that pulling out of the laneway with
something like Sugar's Copper Blue playing puts
me in a good driving mood to start off.

Funny thing though, when driving for enjoyment
the disk replay is rarely pressed...

Go figure.

- --

1497 Michaelsem St.   chris@smaug.synapse.net
Gloucester, ON      voice: 613.834.0696
K1C 7C4               fax: 613.834.1461      25th Ann. 911 Carrera
CANADA

Date: Thu, 01 Jun 95 12:41:00 -0600
From: jack.criswell@the-matrix.com (JACK CRISWELL)
Subject: porsche wins & reasons

According to a USA Today ad Porsche purchased (full page) after the 1994
LeMans, they have won that race outright 13 times in "the last 25 races"
held there.  Of course they've had numerous class wins there since the
550 Coupe in 1953.
        I hope this helps the guy with the trivia bet.
        Porsche has won Daytona's 24 hour 19 times, too.
        This also satisfies "why we like Porsche" queries.  Just attend
one of these 24 hour grueling races and you'll see why real racers
choose Porsche.  I enjoy seeing 25-plus year old 911s (with chrome
window moldings) competing against and winning against the latest Fords
and Jap cars.
jack.criswell@the-matrix.com
silver 993
silver 911s targa 3.2 (for sale)

Porschephiles #1447                         Thu Jun 1 22:11:29 CDT 1995
Date: Thu, 01 Jun 1995 22:55:20 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Distilled or Non-Distilled H2O?

>Most know to use only distilled water in their batteries and steam irons but
>what about the radiator?

Yes, this is what I do.  I don't remember why I started doing it, but
probably something I was told or read.  It's cheap enough, and I figured
that if Porsche wanted us to use phosphate-free antifreeze to keep sediment
and calcification to a minimum, then using distilled water would be a
pretty good idea too.

Kevin Gross
