Date: Thu, 1 Jun 1995 08:47:46 -0700
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Porschephiles FAQ for June '95


+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
+             PORSCHEPHILES - FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS              +
+                   (last revised May 23, 1995)                       +
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

This is the FAQ for the Porschephiles list.  It is posted regularly,
once a month at or near the start of the month.  There are undoubtedly
additions, changes, etc., needed.  Your input is solicited in improving
the FAQ.  Send any comments to the address at the end of the FAQ.

Changes this month include changes to the WWW references section, and
revised information about how to join PCA. 

=======================================================================

Questions answered in this FAQ:
  What is Porschephiles?
  How does Porschephiles work?
  Who is the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?
  What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?
  Are there any suggestions on how I should submit to the list?
  How do I submit administrative requests?
  Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?
  What else is available in the tta.com archives?
  Is there WWW access to the Porschephiles archives?
  What about other Porsche-related WWW links?
  What about other automotive WWW links?
  What about splitting the list?
  What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?
  What is the Porschephiles Fund?
  Which clubs are there for Porsche owners?
  I want to join the Porsche Club of America; what do I have to do?
  How can I find out more about the car I own?
  What are the model numbers of cars related to the Porsche name?
  What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
  What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?
  What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?
  What are the major Porsche periodicals besides Porsche Panorama?
  What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?
  What references are available for information about Porsches?
  Should I use an oil additive in my Porsche engine?
  Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other renowned Porsche people) here?
  Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?
  Who maintains this FAQ?

=======================================================================

What is Porschephiles?

     Porschephiles is an Internet mailing list centering on the Porsche
automobile in all of its incarnations.

=======================================================================

How does Porschephiles work?

     This list is being run as a mail reflector, which sends incoming 
mail to the whole list at once.  The participants include people with a 
variety of backgrounds, some technical, some race/autocross/performance 
drivers, some owners, some just admirers.  To send a message to the 
whole list, mail to

                porschephiles@tta.com

     To send mail regarding distribution problems, or other 
administrative issues, send mail to

                porschephiles-request@tta.com

     If you have a friend who would like to get on this list, or if you
feel moved to tell other people about it, ONLY GIVE OUT THE "-request"
address.  The list is also available as a digest, where you get a
compilation of the day's messages once per day, rather than getting all
of the individual messages. This seems to be a win for people with slow
mail links or who are just too busy to stay current. If you want to
convert to (or from) the digest, send mail to the "porschephiles-
request" address above.

=======================================================================

Who is the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?

     The moderator is:
          Stanley P. Hanks
          Principal, 
          Technology Tranfer Associates
          P.O. Box 2087
          Bellaire TX 77402-2087

          e-mail: stan@tta.com, 
          voice:  1-713-661-2084 

     His Porsches currently include:  
          '64 356 SC (daily driver)

=======================================================================

What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?

     There are a lot of members on the list.  It's small enough to be 
effective, and large enough to have a number of diverse opinions and
sets of experience.  You ought to be able to ask any question you like,
although it's probably a good idea to look it up yourself if you can and
save the net bandwidth.  Keep the diversity of the list in mind before 
you decide to not ask a question, or if you get flamed for asking an 
"obvious" question.  Diversity -- it's a *feature*...

=======================================================================

Are there any suggestions on how I should submit to the list?

     Beyond using normal good sense and discretion, you can submit
whatever you like that is relevant to Porsches.  You might want to use
descriptive "Subject" lines, including the model number when it is
relevant (e.g., "944 S2 Fuel leak query").  Your submissions would be 
easier for others to read if you make sure that your mailer wraps 
lines of text at 80 characters or less.

=======================================================================

How do I submit administrative requests?

     Send them, and ONLY them, to the "porschephiles-request" address 
(porschephiles-request@tta.com), or to Stan directly.  

=======================================================================

Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?

     Archives are available at ftp://tta.com/pub/porschephiles/archives.
Archives in six subdirectories (90, 91, 92, 93, 94, 95) each of which 
has the archives for that year, in UNIX compress format.  There are no
older archives available.  While it might seem like a good idea when
you're first starting out on the list to know what has gone on before,
there are OVER 13 MEG of archives.  DO NOT TRY TO FTP THEM ALL AT ONE
TIME.  And PLEASE DO NOT FTP between 8:00 AM and 7:00 PM CST, or Stan
may have to take access away.  Also, DO NOT ask Stan to mail you
archives.  To FTP the compressed archives, you will have to use BINARY
mode in FTP.  On receipt you need to use the UNIX "uncompress" program,
or equivalent, to restore to textual format.  Mac and Windows versions
of "uncompress" are available via FTP from /pub/porschephiles/programs.

=======================================================================

What else is available in the tta.com archives?

     FAQs: The FAQs directory contains the following FAQs:

          NAME                    LAST UPDATED
          911.faq                 Apr 19, 1995 
          914.faq                 May  9, 1994 
          924.faq                 link to 944.faq
          944.faq                 ???
          968.faq                 link to 944.faq
          carrera.faq             ???
          general.faq             (monthly) 

Feel free to contribute one on YOUR favorite Porsche or to suggest
revisions to those that exist).  These are available at
ftp://tta.com/pub/porschephiles/FAQs.  (Note: Each FAQ was developed by
a different volunteer or volunteers, and none of us who worked on a
specific FAQ knows much about the FAQs developed by others.)

     Images: All sorts of Porsche images for your viewing pleasure,
mostly in .gif format.  There's also a directory called "UPLOAD" where
you can deposit your own images for inclusion in the collection.  If
you add any images, please include a file called "from.<username>",
where <username> is your login ID, that describes the files if
possible.

     PCA racing info: The PCA Club Racing Newsletter is now on-line,
thanks to the tireless efforts of the editor.  This is available by FTP 
in the directory tta.com:/pub/porschephiles/PCA/ClubRacing.  The 
newsletters are available both in PostScript and in Windows Write 
format.  If this is useful to you, send your thanks to the editor, Tom,
at "tt911@ibm.net".
 
     MiscInfo: Various other interesting bits of information potentially
useful to Porschephiles.
 
     Survey: The questionaire and results (when compiled) of the 
membership survey.

     Logo contest: Several Porschephiles logos have been submitted;
check them out and choose one you like, or develop your own candidate.
Someday maybe we'll decide on a winner, and then we can have T-shirts,
coffee mugs, stationery, etc., made up.

     And as usual, Monthly-Update, RULES, and Whos-Who, which get 
updated on a monthly basis.

=======================================================================
 
Is there WWW access to the Porschephiles archives?
 
     Yes, WWW access is through http://tta.com/porschephiles.  The 
FTP restriction above applies to major downloading of stuff from the
archives, not WWW access.  Suggestions for improving the WWW pages
would be welcomed, as well as experienced help in doing so.

=======================================================================

What about other Porsche-related WWW links?

     There are several WWW home pages related to Porsches.  Stan has 
created an unofficial PCA home page, and has offered to make room for 
additional PCA region home pages.  Contact him if you're interested.  
The PCA home page, listed first below, contains references to all of
the known PCA region home pages.  Here are some other interesting
links:

     http://tta.com/PCA/home.html -- Porsche Club of America Home Page

     http://192.253.114.31/Stuttgart/Porsche/Porsche_contents.html -- 
     Porsche Museum (courtesy of an American High School in Stuttgart)

     http://www.indirect.com/www/timjones/porsche/ -- described by Tim
     Jones <timjones@indirect.com> as a "914-centric web page."

     http://akebono.stanford.edu/yahoo/Entertainment/Automobiles/
     Porsche -- the Yahoo Porsche page

In case you missed it and haven't met Stan, you can find a picture of 
him at http://tta.com/~stan/home.html; check it out.

     If you know of any other links that should be mentioned here, 
please submit them.  

=======================================================================

What about other automotive WWW links?

     There are many references to other home pages in the links noted
above.  Here is a list of a few that might be of interest to the
readership; suggestions for more are welcomed: 

     http://ram.chem.tulane.edu:8080/f-body/trivia/gasoline.html --
     "FAQ: Automotive Gasoline"

     http://www.eng.hawaii.edu/Contribs/carina/ra.home.page.html -- 
     "The Racer Archive"

     http://ganglion.anes.med.umich.edu/NSX/other.html -- "Other
     Automotive Resources"

     http://www.dealernet.com/index.html -- "Dealernet"

     http://www.valvoline.com/ -- Valvoline's Indy 500 Home Page

     http://www.nashville.net/speedtrap/ -- The Speed Trap Registry

     http://espnet.sportszone.com/car/ -- ESPNET SportsZone Auto Racing

     http://www.motorsport.com/Series/Index.html -- Motorsports
     News International Index

     http://reality.sgi.com/employees/rck/PhOR/ -- Physics of Racing
     Series

=======================================================================

What about splitting the list? 

     Various proposals surface now and then about splitting the list 
into components based on car model, activity types, or other divisions.  
Stan's reply to these suggestions is as follows:  

     "I just want all you Faithful Readers to understand: there are only 
two votes that count. Mine, and anyone who's willing to pay me to change 
my mind or operation or whatever.
 
     "Posted rates around here are $75/hr for automotive engineering 
projects, $125/hr for information technology consulting, and $2k/day for 
expert witness engagements.  Just so you know where the bidding starts...

     "In other words, the list *WILL* **NOT** be split."

=======================================================================

What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?

     The Who's Who is a listing of those who receive Porschephiles and 
who have responded to the offer to be listed.  It lists the owners, 
their state/country of residence, their car's year and model, and
their net address.  The list is updated when people send Stan the
information, and when he has time to update the list.  He sends it out
on a monthly basis to the list.  Only Porsches are listed, so don't
send your Alfa Zagato or your Buick GN in to be included.  Send
submissions or changes to "porschephiles-request@tta.com."

=======================================================================

What is the Porschephiles Fund?

     From Bart Chambers, the custodian of the fund: "Here, gentle 
reader and Porschephile, is *The Problem*!  Porschephiles has over 1200
members and generates so much traffic and creates such a demand for
computer and bandwidth resources, that its future is in jeopardy if it
remains dependent upon the *ability* and willingness of any individual
to *donate* them.  In order to ensure the continued survival of
'Philes, we, like PBS, are asking members to donate to a non-profit
fund to be used to acquire the required resources, to be *owned* by
Porschephiles.  This will reduce the load on our beloved Listmeister to
merely backbreaking.  We are asking everyone for a *VOLUNTARY* Donation
for the survival of Porschephiles.  Send your check, made out to
`Porschephiles Acct# 3933150532' to Porschephiles Custodian, c/o Bart
Chambers, 1270 Lavall Drive, Davidsonville, MD 21035.  We suggest $50
for members, $15 for Students and $100 for Patrons.  Thanks."

=======================================================================

Which clubs are there for Porsche owners?

     Several different clubs are available, depending on your interests
and location:

          Porsche Club of America.
          P.O. Box 10402
          Alexandria VA 22310
          Telephone: 1-703 922-9300

The main US Porsche club; see below for more information.

          Porsche Club Great Britain
          Ayton House
          West End, Northleach
          Gloucestershire GL54 3HG
          Telephone: 44-451-860-792
          FAX: 44-451-860-011

The Porsche club in Great Britain, obviously.

          Porsche Owners Club
          P.O. Box 9000-277
          Seal Beach, CA  90740
          1-310-784-5653

Based in Southern California, the focus of POC is time trialing and 
racing.

          356 Registry Inc.
          27244 Ryan Rd.
          Warren, MI, 48092
          Telephone: 1-313-558-3692

For 356 enthusiasts around the world.  $20 per year and cheap at twice
the price (The 356 Registry Magazine with Vic Skirmants' racing column 
is worth that, as are the classifieds).  5000 happy members can't be 
wrong!

          914 Owner's Association
          100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
          Palm Springs CA 92262
          Telephone: 1-619-325-6583

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries.  Dennis Deeds published the 
club newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly.  Membership is $22 a 
year.

          Early 911S Registry
          PO Box 363
          West Point, PA 19486
          Telephone: 1-215-652-701 (day), 1-215-287-5083 (evening)

Contact Vern Lyle.  Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter.  
Dedicated to all early 911S models.

     A more complete list of Porsche US regional and other special 
interest groups, from the January 1994 Porsche Panorama, is on tta.com,
in /pub/MiscInfo/sigs.

=======================================================================

I want to join the Porsche Club of America; what do I have to do?

     The following comes from Judy Hendrickson, Chairman, PCA National
Membership Committee (DH993@aol.com):

     "PCA membership is unique among car clubs in that the criteria to
become an Active Member includes ownership of a Porsche.  This is
apparent when you see a membership application and there is a blank to
fill in the VIN.  I know for a fact that "speculation in VINs" for
acquiring membership in PCA is not new.  We have a 35-year member who 
admits his original membership was based on a 10% share in a car! 
Innovation I have witnessed includes "loaning" a VIN number to a 
friend who wants to join so he can do his first Porsche shopping.  
Using a VIN from a car acquired by a PCA member who joined with 
another, earlier car's VIN, and I'm sure some people have just made 
up a number!  Also, once you have joined PCA and are in between 
Porsches, you can remain an Associate Member, as long as you continue 
paying the $36 dues each year.  Application for Associate Membership 
can also be made by "...any person, employed by a Porsche-oriented 
business, interested in the Club and its objectives, having paid Club 
dues and fees as required."  Associate Members cannot, however, vote 
in National PCA Elections or hold National Office.  Requests for 
Associate Membership must be done through a local Region's Membership
chairperson, to verify their relationship to a business.  If you need
to be put in contact with your local Region's Membership Chairperson,
send me a note including your ZIP code.
     "The $36 annual dues (Active or Associate) not only includes your
monthly subscription to *Panorama*, but an annual payment of $12 per
member to your local Region.  Other subsidy payments to the Regions 
may also be voted by the National organization."

     Additional PCA membership information (courtesy of Stan):

     The Club affiliates you with a local region based on where your
ZIP code falls on their territory map.  You *CAN* request to join a
specific region, and you can specify an affilate region or dual
membership in another region.  The local regions put on many different
events, some social, some educational, some driving or compeition
oriented.  The annual gathering of the whole membership, the Porsche
Parade, features competition for the national championships in many
events, seminars, a GREAT goodie store, and one of the most fun weeks
you'll experience.

     Once you have a VIN number, there are four ways to join:

     1) Send a letter to the national office saying that you want to 
join, with your name, address, car info and a check for $36 to:

	Porsche Club of Americia.
	P.O. Box 10402
	Alexandria VA 22310

     2) Call them up at 1-703-922-9300, roughly between 9:00 to 5:00
EST (GMT - 6).  If you have your Visa/MC number *AND* your VIN number
handy, you can do it over the phone.  (Otherwise, they'll send you an
application which you can mail in with your check.)  This is the FASTEST
way, and if you need to be a member *RIGHT NOW* to go to an event that
is members only, this is your best bet.  Don't count on using this
method the week of or before Parade...

     3) find someone active in your local region.  *MANY* of the regions
are represented on the Porschephiles list, so that's a good place to
start.  Once you have found someone, get them to put you in touch with
the local region membership chair, they can give you the form, and off 
you go.

     4) National membership chair Judy Hendrickson is reachable as 
DH993@aol.com (see above).  She'd be happy to help you out, as would
Nann Weissenberger (NannW@aol.com).

=======================================================================

How can I find out more about the car I own?

     If you own a North American Porsche, Porsche Cars North America 
will, for a fee of $20, research the original bill of sale for your car
and give you a Certificate of Authenticity stating the facts and 
figures for the car as it was delivered to the dealer.  If you're 
interested, contact: 
          Howard Adams
          PCNA
          P.O. Box 30911
          Reno Nevada 89520-3911
Include a copy of your title or registration as proof of ownership.
It takes 2-3 weeks depending on backlog.  A similar service is
available in Great Britain from Porsche Cars Great Britain, for about
30 pounds Sterling.  Porsche AG can also perform a similar search.

     It's also possible to get dealers to run a search for warranty and
other repairs for your car.  Some authorized dealers will search PCNA 
files for warranty and other maintenance records on specific cars.  
This data base apparently only goes back to sometime in the mid-1980s.  
It's not known how widespread this practice is among dealers; some will 
search only for warranty work done, while others also provide 
information about routine maintenance and repairs.  Ask your dealer.

=======================================================================

What are the model numbers of cars related to the Porsche name?

     The following list was extracted from _Illustrated_Porsche_Buyers_
Guide_, _Porsche_Specials_, _Cars_Are_My_Life_, _We_At_Porsche_, and
the article "Project Porsche, The Early Years" in the June '83 issue of
_Thoroughbred_&_Classic_Car_.  It includes only more or less complete 
automobiles designed by Ferdinand Porsche or by the Porsche factory.  
Components (engines, transmissions, etc.) have not been included.  
The list is incomplete, in part because there has apparently been 
imperfect record keeping at the factory.  In addition, the nature of the
list has changed over the years from an in-house listing of project 
numbers to a market-driven listing.  Additions and corrections are 
welcomed:

      "1" - Lohner-Porsche electric car, 1900; Ferdinand's first design,
            but not part of the "official" model sequence.
       7  - Wanderer passenger car, 1.7-liter, 6-cylinder engine, 1930; 
            the first official model, chosen to convey impression of 
            prior experience.
       8  - Wanderer 8-cylinder saloon design, 3.5-liter engine, 1931.
       9  - Second Wanderer 8-cylinder prototype, supercharged, 1931.
      12  - Zundapp small car, 5-cylinder radial rear-engined, 3 built.
      22  - Auto Union P-Wagen Grand Prix car, 4.3-liter, V16 engine, 
            1932-1937.
      24  - Zundapp three-wheel vehicle.
      27  - Mathis-Ford Saloon.
      32  - NSU prototype (Volkswagen forerunner).
      52  - Auto Union sports car based on P-Wagen GP car, 1934.
      60  - Original Volkswagen prototype, renamed KdF (Kraft durch 
            Freude, or strength through joy, by Adolf Hitler), basis 
            for the postwar Volkswagen, 1934-1941; the 60K10, a variation 
            of the 60, was a sports coupe built for the later cancelled 
            Berlin-Rome race, 1939. 
      61  - Another Volkswagen prototype, a narrower version of the 60.
      62  - Volkswagen-Kubelwagen (bucket car) cross-country prototype.
      64  - KdF-based sports car, 3 built, 1937-1938.
      65  - Volkswagen for driving schools.
      66  - Volkswagen for export, right-hand drive.
      67  - Volkswagen for invalids with steering column gear change.
      68  - Volkswagen Post office delivery van, model A, 1939.
      80  - Mercedes-Benz land speed record car, 44.7-liter V12
            Daimler-Benz engine, 1938-1939.
      81  - Volkswagen Medium Van, 1939.
      82  - KdF-based military Kubelwagen, 1939-1940.
      86  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen with 4wd, 6 built.
      87  - 4-wheel-drive version of Kubelwagen, 1939-1941.
      88  - Volkswagen delivery van on Kubelwagen chassis, model B, 1939.
      90 -  V12 rear-engined racing car for Daimler-Benz, 1937.
      94 -  V12 rear-engined racing car for Daimler-Benz, 1937.
      97  - Daimler-Benz heavy lorry.
      98  - Volkswagen amphibious car.
     100  - Panzer Leopard tank, 2 prototypes, 1939.
     110  - Volkspflug Small Tractor.
     111  - Small Tractor (2-cylinder engine).
     112  - Further development of 111 above.
     113  - Further development of 111 above.
     114  - F-wagen, 1.5-liter sports car prototype, 1.5-liter V10
            twin-ohc water cooled mid-engined coupe, 1938-9.
     115 -  1.1-liter supercharged Volkswagen mid-engined coupe, 1938.
     116 -  1.5-liter Volkswagen mid-engined coupe.
     128  - KdF-based amphibian Schwimmwagen, 1940-1941.
     130  - Tiger Tank (Jagpanzer) "Ferdinand".
     138  - Volkswagen Amphibious Car (version 2).
     155  - Half Track version of Kubelwagen.
     164  - Six-wheel lorry.
     166  - Volkswagen amphibious car (production version).
     182  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen (production version).
     187  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen 4wd (production version).
     205  - 180-ton Maus tank, 1942; two built, never saw action.
     245  - 18-ton multipurpose tank, 1942.
     293  - Caterpillar tractor.
     312  - Tractor with petrol engine.
     323  - 11-hp diesel tractor, 1946.
     328  - Tractor, 28 hp. engine.
     340  - Wheelbarrow.
     355  - Volkswagen delivery van.
     356  - The original Porsche sports car, the first to wear the
            Porsche name, 1948-1965; various engine and drivetrain 
            components and numerous styling variations existed.
     360  - Cisitalia 4-wheel-drive Grand Prix car, 1947-1948.
     370  - Cisitalia 1.5-liter sports/touring car, 1947.
     425  - 20 bhp diesel tractor.
     514  - LeMans car, also called 356SL, 1951.
     524  - Improved 356 prototype with mechanical injection, 1951;
            not economically feasible to take to production.
     530  - Experimental 4-passenger Porsche, 1951-1952.
     534  - Volkswagen Small sports car.
     540  - Porsche America Roadster.
     541  - Special sports version of 356.
     542  - Studebaker Saloon 1952-1954.
     550  - Mid-engine, 2-seat sports/racing car, the car that James 
            Dean died in, 1954; the 550A was a redesigned 550 with a
            tubular space frame, 1956.
     597  - Jagdwagen (Hunter) 4-wheel-drive vehicle, 1954-1955.
     621  - Porsche single-cylinder tractor (allgaier).
     622  - 2-cylinder tractor.
     623  - 3-cylinder tractor.
     624  - 4-cylinder tractor.
     633  - Studebaker saloon prototype.
     645  - Sports/racing car, "Mickey Mouse," 1956.
     675  - Small Volkswagen 1955-1959.
     691  - Porsche 550 RS (1956)
     695  - Porsche predevelopment (T7) for 911.
     702  - One man Helicopter.
     718  - Bergspyder sports/racing car (RSK), 1957; the 718/2 was a 
            1.5-liter single-seat racing car (F-2), 1959.
     726  - Volkswagen Saloon 1958.
     728  - Small Volkswagen 1957-1961.
     737  - Porsche outboard motor.
     753  - Porsche 1.5-liter 8-cylinder Formula 1.
     764  - Volkswagen 6-cylinder saloon.
     787  - Grand Prix car, 1961.
     804  - Grand Prix car, 1962.
     806  - Leopard Tank.
     814  - Leopard Tank.
     901  - Prototype 6-cylinder sports car, basis for 911, 1963; 
            changed to 911 for production because of conflict with 
            Peugeot numbering scheme.  6 prototypes built.
     904  - Mid-engine competition GT coupe, with various engines in 
            1963-1964, 100+ built, some for street use. 
     906  - Competition sports coupe (space frame), 1966-1967.
     907  - Sports/racing coupe, various iterations, 1967-1968.
     908  - 3-liter, 8-cylinder competition car, various bodies,
            1968-1970.
     909  - 2-liter hill climb spyder, 1968.
     910  - Sports racing coupe, different configurations, 1966-1968.
     911  - Porsche's flagship.  Built from 1964 (excluding the '63
            901 prototype) in numerous variations through the 993.  
            Rear-engined, air-cooled, boxer six-cylinder engine.
            Many engine variations have existed through its long life, 
            from the original 2-liter car to the 3.8-liter RS.
     912  - The 911 with the four-cylinder engine from the 356 inserted
            in place of the flat six-cylinder.  Built from 1966 through
            1969; 912E in '76 was a revival with engine from the 914.
     914  - The mid-engined car co-developed with Volkswagen between
            1970 and 1976; a popular autocross/slalom car.  The 914/6
            was a Porsche-built variant with a two-liter 911 engine
            inserted in place of the four-cylinder engine and other
            refinements.
     916  - Projected 2.4-liter version of 914/6, 1971.  Was apparently
            used in competition by the factory.  Also, a few examples 
            of an 8-cylinder (908-based) version supposedly exist.
     917  - 12-cylinder competition car, famous for Le Mans and CanAm
            victories; various iterations, 1969-1973.
     924  - The first of the water-cooled front-engine cars, built from
            1976 to 1988.  Originally with a four-cylinder, Audi-derived
            engine; updated in mid-86 as the 924S with the 944 drivetrain;
            has the best aerodynamic shape of any street Porsche.
     928  - The high-end car produced from 1978 to present, V8 in the
            front, water-cooled, has grown from an original 4.5-liter
            to 5.4 today.
     930  - Turbocharged 911, homologation and street version of the
            racing 934.
     931  - Turbocharged 924, sold in 1980-1982.
     934  - Group 4 racing 930 turbo coupe, 1975-1976.
     935  - Group 5 racing 930 turbo coupe, 1976.
     936  - Group 6 turbocharged spyder, 1976.
     937  - 924 Carrera GT.
     939  - 924 Carrera GT Le Mans.
     944  - Front-engined, water-cooled inline four-cylinder car, with
            nearly perfect 50/50 weight bias.  Sixteen-valve and
            turbocharged versions were produced.  Produced from 1982
            through 1991. 2.5-liter displacement, except for a 2.7-liter
            eight-valve 944 model in 1989 and the 3-liter 944S2.
     951  - The turbo version of the 944.  Built from 1985 to 1991.
     956  - GT racing car, loosely based on 911; 1982-1983.
     959  - Supercar 911 derivative; 2.85-liter, four-valve, twin cam,
            dual turbochargers, all-wheel drive; not street-legal in US.
     961  - Racing version of the 959.
     962  - GT racing car based loosely on 911; used in endurance racing 
            and IMSA GTP; 1984.
     964  - The 911 Carrera 2 and Carrera 4, introduced in 1989.
     968  - Rebirth of the 944 series in 1992 with revised styling.  A 
            noteworthy feature is variable valve timing.
     986  - The Boxster, due in Sept. '96, the newest hope for Porsche's 
            future.
     993  - The latest iteration of the 911, introduced in 1994.

    1764  - Volkswagen vehicle.
    1834  - Volkswagen vehicle.
    1866  - Volkswagen successor.
    1906  - Leopard tank.
    1966  - Volkswagen small car prototype.
    2539  - "Save" ambulance.
    2567  - "Orbit" fire fighting system.
    2708  - Cart.

=======================================================================

What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
 
     General answer:  Buy the latest one you can afford of the model you
like.  Within models, there are certain years that are generally thought
of as more reliable or otherwise desirable, and others that have proved
troublesome over the years.  If you have questions about a particular
model, ask the list.  (We are looking for contributors to write about 
specific models.  Contributions, which may be too lengthy to include 
here, will be stored at tta.com and available via FTP.  Dave Darling has
gotten the ball rolling with a summary for the 914.  Feel free to 
contribute regarding your favorite model.)

=======================================================================

What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?

     There are several kinds of events organized and run by Porsche
clubs and organizations:

     Autocrosses.  These normally occur in a large parking lot or other 
relatively flat, open area.  The lot is filled with traffic cones that 
define a course.  Only 2 or 3 cars are on the course at the same time, 
and never at the same location on the course.  You race against the 
clock, and your times are compared to others in your class.  Classes 
are organized so that you compete against similarly-configured cars of 
about equal capability, ranging from box-stock to extensively modified.
Autocrossing is probably the safest and cheapest way to go fast in your 
Porsche (or any other car for that matter).  In some parts of the 
country, autocrosses are called slaloms.

     Time Trials.  These are also timed events, but they usually take
place on an actual race course.  They are often held in conjunction
with Track Events.  The time trial, like the autocross, is not against
other cars at the same time but against a clock.

     Driver's Education.  These events are held at a race track (but not
during a formal race meeting).  Multiple cars are on the track at the 
same time.  Instructors ride with the students, who are taught to drive 
at speed safely.  The US PCA has a basic set of rules and various PCA 
regions have their own rules which don't differ much from each other.  
Usually, the only modification to the car is a fire extinguisher that is
mounted metal to metal.  Students and instructors must wear an approved 
helmet.  

     PCA Club Racing.  This is racing in the traditional sense, in that
there's a full complement of cars, a definite start and finish, and
head-to-head racing.  The concept is similar to the various vintage
racing events that are becoming so popular; the idea is to preserve your
car and those of others while racing against each other.  If you don't 
race responsibly, you are not allowed to race.  There's a policy
governing this that is referred to as the 13/13 rule.  Under this rule,
if a driver is judged to be at fault in an incident that results in
damage to his car or another (no matter how small), he's out of that
particular event  and on probation for the next 13 months.  If in that
probation period that driver is again determined to be at fault in
another incident with damage, he's out of club racing for the next 13
months.  Equipment requirements include the fire extinguisher, a cut
off switch, an approved roll bar, and a five point seat belt harness.
There are several of these around the country.  You should have 
experience with autocross and driver's education events under your 
belt before you jump into this kind of racing.  Contact your local
club racing officials to get copies of rules, needed equipment, etc.

=======================================================================

What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?

     BTDT = Been there, done that
      BTW = By the way
      EFI = Electronic fuel injection
      FAQ = Frequently asked questions (but you knew that)
      FTP = File transfer program
     FWIW = For what it's worth
     IMHO = In my humble opinion
      IMO = In my opinion
      IOW = In other words
      LWB = Long wheelbase
      MFI = Mechanical fuel injection
      PAG = Porsche AG, the mother company back in Stuttgart; "AG"
            stands for "Aktiengesselschaft," which means that the 
            company has publicly traded stock
     PANO = Not an acronym; this stands for Porsche Panorama, the PCA 
            national monthly magazine
      PCA = Porsche Club of America, the major US/Canada Porsche
            enthusiasts organization
     PCGB = Porsche Club Great Britain OR Porsche Cars, Great Britain
     PCNA = Porsche Cars North America (Reno, NV), the US importer
     PMJI = Pardon me for jumping in
      POC = Porsche Owner's Club, the *other* US Porsche owner's group;
            in the past they have been more competition-oriented than 
            PCA, which has many interest groups participating
     ROFL = Rolling on the floor laughing
  ROFL,PP = Rolling on the floor laughing, peeing in my pants (!)
     RTFM = Read the f**king manual (for some, "read the Ford manual")
      SWB = Short wheelbase
      TIA = Thanks in advance
     TTFN = Tata for now
     TTYL = Talk to you later
      WWW = World Wide Web
     YMMV = Your mileage may vary
      <g> = Grin
     <bg> = Big grin
    <vbg> = Very big grin
      :-) = Smiley face (turn your head 90 degrees to the left to 
            "read" it); various iterations exist using different ASCII 
            characters
    
=======================================================================

What are the major Porsche periodicals besides Porsche Panorama?


     Excellence -
       Independent magazine devoted to Porsches.  Many of the same
       authors you see in Panorama, less jingoistic in their praise
       for everything PCNA brings to market.

       US rates: $20 one year, $35 two years, $49 three years
       foreign (incl. Canada): US$27 one, $49 two, $69 three years

       Excellence
       Circulation Dept.
       P.O. Box 1529
       Ross, CA  94957
       Telephone: 1-415-382-0580


     Christophorus -
       Porsche AG's official magazine.  Very good source of some
       technical information about their cars and technology.
       Beautiful magazine.

       US rates: US$28 surface mail, US$40 air mail

       Porsche AG
       Editors, Christophorus
       Porschestrasse 42
       D-70435 Stuttgart
       Germany
       FAX: D-711/827-6245


     European Car -
       Formerly "VW & Porsche", now devotes some bandwidth to other
       European cars, esp. BMW.  Lots of technical how-to's, but
       biased by "placed" articles from advertisers - beware!

       US rates: $18.80 one year, $28.20 two years
       Canada: $26.80 one year, $44.20 two years, includes GST
       foreign: $28.80 one year, $48.20 two years

       Argus Publishers Corp.
       P.O. Box 454
       Mt. Morris, IL  61054-0454
       Telephone: 1-800-877-5602


     911 and Porsche World -
       British independent magazine devoted to Porsches.  Coverage
       of UK club racing, tech Q&A, owner's reports, and so forth.

       US, Canada, Mexico:
         US rates: $37 one year, $72 two years
         Canada, Mexico: US$43 one year, US$83 two years

         Eric Waiter Associates

       historical pricing information.

       1 year subscription $55 for 12 issues includes Dean Batchelor's
         book, "Illustrated Porsche Buyers Guide,"  6 month subscripton

What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?

     Be aware when buying a part in the aftermarket that it may or may
not be the same part you would get from Porsche.  This holds true even
when the part carries the "correct" Porsche part number, and when it
carries Porsche's parts trademark.  The following suppliers, listed
alphabetically, have been praised by various Porschephiles:


     Andial
     3203-3207 S. Shannon St.
     Santa Ana, CA  92704
     Telephone: 1-714-957-3900
     FAX:       1-714-957-9332

     Porsche's official agent for competition parts and products in 
     the US.  Catalog $6.00.


     Automobile Atlanta
     505A South Marietta Highway
     Marietta, GA 30060
     Telephone: 1-404-427-2844
 
     The most comprehensive catalog of 914 parts.  Higher-than-average
     prices.  Catalog $5.00.  (Also a 924 catalog?)

 
     Automotion
     193 Commercial St.
     Sunnyvale, CA 94086
     Telephone: 1-800-777-8881
                1-408-736-9020
     FAX:       1-408-736-9013

     Wide selection of maintenance and replacement parts and products;
     sister company to Weltmeister, whose suspension kits they carry.
     Free catalog.


     Autothority Performance Engineering
     3769-B Pickett Road
     Fairfax, VA  22031
     Telephone: 1-703-323-0919
     FAX:       1-703-323-7325

     Performance chips for Porsches ECU's; also other performance 
     products.


     Baum Tools Unlimited, Inc. 
     4000 S. Tamiami Trail
     Sarasota FL 34231
     Telephone: 1-813-927-1414 Office
     Telephone: 1-800-848-6657 Orders (US & Canada)
     FAX:       1-813-927-1612
     
     Baum Tools Unlimited, Inc. 
     1523 38th Avenue
     San Francisco CA 94122-3011
     Telephone: 1-415-566-9229
     FAX:       1-415-566-0694
     Mobile:    1-415-298-7831

     Manufacturers, importers and distributors of Porsche special tools.
     They specialize in all tools for Porsches from 356 to 968, and also
     carry an extensive line of German automotive hand tools (Hazet, 
     Stahlwille, Usag, Matra and Peisler).  Catalogs available ($10, 
     which is refunded with the first order).  $35 minimum order 
     required from their main warehouse but smaller orders accepted 
     at their West Coast warehouse.  They also have an extensive 
     technical library covering all German makes and models.


     FAT Performance
     1558 No. Case
     Orange, CA 92667

                1-805-549-8525

     selection, excellent prices.  Also some 911 and other Porsche 
     parts. No catalog.

=======================================================================

What references are available for information about Porsches?

     There are many books and manuals available, and the right one for 
you depends a lot on your interests and your particular car.  Porsche
publishes a Workshop Manual for all late model cars, as well as
various Technical Specification booklets.  Your local dealership's
parts manager can show you a catalog of technical literature
available from PCNA.

     The Porsche Club of America periodically assembles all of the 
technical articles which have appeared in Panorama into a new volume of 
their Upfixin der Porsche series.  These are available from PCA's 
executive office.

     What follows is a list of some of the more popular and often-cited
books.  This list is not exhaustive, but provides a starting point.  If 
you want information about other books, ask the list.  (Note: there's 
not much information about water-cooled cars; those with favorites 
should submit them to the name at the end of this FAQ.)

     Aichele, Tobias
     Porsche 911, Forever Young
     (translated by Pete Albrecht)
       ISBN 0-92975811-0
     Beeman Jorgensen, Inc.

     Anderson, Bruce
     Porsche 911 Performance Handbook
       ISBN 0-87938-269-4
     Motorbooks International

     Automobile Quarterly, Volume 9, Number 2 (Porsche is featured 
     marque, with 58 pages devoted to the man, the car, and racing)
       Library of Congress Card Catalog No. 62-4005
     Automobile Quarterly, Inc.
 
     Automobile Year, Number 41

     Barrett, Frank (ed.)
     Porsche Panorama, The First 25 Years
       ISBN ?
     Porsche Club of America, Inc.

     Batchelor, Dean
     Illustrated Porsche Buyer's Guide
       ISBN 0-87938-239-2
     Motorbooks International

     Boschen, Lothar & Barth, Jurgen
     The Porsche Book, A Definitive Illustrated History
       ISBN 0-668-06003-4
     Arco Publishing, Inc.

     Conradt, Dirk-Michael
     Porsche 356, Driving in its Purest Form
     (translated by Pete Albrecht)
       ISBN 0-929758-09-9
     Beeman Jorgensen, Inc. 

     Elfrink, Henry
     Porsche Technical Manual
       ISBN ?
     Henry Elfrink Automotive

     Fujimoto, Akira (ed.)
     Famous Automobile Museums: Volume 3, Porsche Museum
       ISBN ?
     Car Styling Publishing Co.

     Johnson, Brett
     The 356 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-08-0
     The 911 and 912 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-00-5
     The 914 and 914/6 Porsche: A Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
       ISBN 0-929758-01-3
     Beeman Jorgensen Inc.

     Ludvigsen, Karl
     Porsche, Excellence Was Expected
       ISBN 0-525-10117-9
     E.P. Dutton & Co.

     Maltby, Gordon
     Porsche 356 & RS Spyders
       ISBN 0879385510
     Motorbooks International
 
     Merritt, Richard E. Merritt & Miller, Susann C.
     Porsche, Brochures and Sales Literature, 1948-1965
       ISBN 0-914822-15-2
     John W. Barnes, Jr., Publishing, Inc.

     Morgan, Peter
     The Porsche 924/944 Book
       ISBN 0-85429-764-2
     Haynes Publishing Group

     Porsche, Dr. Ing. h.c. Ferry, & Bentley, John
     We At Porsche
       ISBN 0-385-05309-6
     Doubleday & Co.

     Probst, Charles O.
     Bosch Fuel Injection & Engine Management
       ISBN 0-8376-0300-5
     Robert Bentley, Inc.

     Pellow, Harry 
     The ABC's (and 912's) of Porsche Engines
       ISBN 0-941210-04-9
     HCP Research (408) 727-1864
     (The "Maestro" has several other books available as well)

     Puhn, Fred
     How To Make Your Car Handle
       ISBN 0-912656-46-8
     HP Books

     Rasmussen, ?
     Porsche 356 & 550
       ISBN 1879301032
     Top Ten Publications
 
     Sloniger, Jerry
     Porsche, the 4-Cyclinder, 4-Cam Sports & Racing Cars
       ISBN 0-914792-03-2
     Dean Batchelor Publications

     Spencer, Duane
     Porsche 356 Performance Handbook  
       ISBN 0-87938-417-4

     356 Porsche Technical and Restoration Guide
       ISBN 0-929758-10-2
     Beeman Jorgensen, Inc. 

     There are also Haynes manuals available for most models.  While 
the Haynes manuals tend to be very weak on specifics having to do with
different model years and variations, they are good at teaching how-to
procedures for different maintenance and repair tasks.

     The following sources for books and publications were provided by 
Bob Joyce (Bob356@aol.com):

     Toad Hall Motorbooks
     1235 Pierce Street
     Lakewood, CO 80214, USA
     Telephone 1-303-237-0911, FAX 1-303-237-6080
 
     Block's Books, the Fanatic's Choice
     c/o MetPath
     4444 Giddings Road
     Auburn Hills, MI 48326, USA
     Telephone 1-313-678-3017
 
     Classic Motorbooks
     729 Prospect Avenue
     Osceola, WI 54020, USA
     Telephone 1-800-826-6600 (24 hours)
 
     TPR, Inc.
     7510 Allisonville Road
     Indianapolis, IN 46250, USA
     Telephone 1-317-841-7677, 1-800-553-5319, FAX 317-849-2001
 
     Motor Books
     33 & 36 St. Martin's Court
     London WC2, ENGLAND, UK 

=======================================================================

Should I use an oil additive in my Porsche engine?

     This is Stan's response:  "Duralube, Slick-50, and *EVERYTHING ELSE 
THAT ISN'T JUST PLAIN OIL* is, to be blunt, snake oil.  Or as Bruce 
Anderson commented about something else, "a cash flow device."  Slick-50
is *evil* if you have an engine with an aluminium case.  Guess what we 
all have, eh?  There is a bit of info on it via anonymous FTP in tta.com
in /pub/porschephiles/MiscInfo.  Additionally, many of these additives 
use teflon.  DuPont (the inventors of Teflon) have stated categorically 
that teflon is useless in such applications."
 
=======================================================================

Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other renowned Porsche people) here?
 
     Yes. There are many luminaries in the Porsche world on this list.
If something is relevant to them, they'll typically respond to you
privately.  Their participation is greatly valued, so respect their
privacy and don't try to draw them out in the open.  If they want to
say something to the list as a whole, they'll do so.

=======================================================================

Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?

     The FAQ is stored on tta.com in the /pub/porschephiles/FAQs 
directory, filename general-FAQ.  The version stored there will be 
the same one sent out monthly.  (There's also a FAQ that's specific to
the 914; other specific FAQs are welcomed, if anyone wants to contribute
to the archives.)

=======================================================================

Who maintains this FAQ?

     The FAQ is maintained by Walt Thode (thode@nprdc.navy.mil).  I have
a 1972 911T as my daily driver.  Anyone who wants to contribute should 
do so.  Contributions, revisions, and suggestions for new items are 
always welcomed.  I peruse the list for potential additions, but I don't
promise to find everything you might want in the FAQ.  Don't be shy 
about sending suggestions directly to me, or to the maintainers of the
model-specific FAQs in the tta.com archives.  Also, don't expect me to 
know anything about those model-specific FAQs -- this one is my only
vice.

=======================================================================

Date: Thu, 1 Jun 1995 20:19:26 -0700 (PDT)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: Re: Distilled or Non-Distilled H2O?

On Thu, 1 Jun 1995 Phyl346@aol.com wrote:

> Most know to use only distilled water in their batteries and steam irons but
> what about the radiator?
> 
> Seems to me if you eliminate the ions and minerals from the coolant, you
> eliminate corrosion and the precipitation of minerals that reduce radiator
> efficiency.
> 
> Anyone have any ideas on this subject, or am I just being an anal retentive
> engineer .... again?

How timely you should ask this. After recently refilling my '86 944 rad
with 50% regular (aluminum compatible) Prestone and 50% distilled water, I
wondered about corrosion.  Would using this cheapo (phosphate loaded?)
antifreeze really make a difference? And what about using distilled water? 

I decided to do a little experiment. I polished a small sheet of 
aluminum, washed it with a solvent, and cut off 4 strips. I placed each 
strip in identical jars which had been cleaned in a laboratory. I filled 
each jar as follows:

1. 100% distilled water
2. 100% tap water
3. 100% Prestone
4. 50% Prestone, 50% distilled water 

That was May 19th. Today, here are the results so far:

1. White precipitate (flakes) coating the top surface of the aluminum.
   (looks almost like 1 mm specs of dandruff) There are also flakes settled
   at the bottom of the jar.
 
2. About 1/4 the precipitate of jar 1. The flakes are much smaller, almost
   making the water look cloudy rather looking like they are in suspension.
   Also visible are small gray specs of corrosion on the aluminum (not 
   visible in jar 1 perhaps due to the thick coating of flakes).
 
3 & 4. No discernable precipitate or cloudiness. Aluminum surface still as
   satiny as when first polished.

So jars 3 & 4 proves what we all know already, that antifreeze prevents 
corrosion. Only time will tell whether my use of an antifreeze which 
probably has phosphates will make any difference. Unfortunately, I don't 
have phosphate-free antifreeze to use for a 5th jar.

However, jars 1 and 2 behave the opposite as I would have expected. Any 
chemists out there to explain why using distilled water produced more 
precipitate than tap water?
 
Joe '86 944

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 1 Jun 1995 22:09:17 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Rev Limiter

Hello Folks,

Those of you that depend on your electronic rev limiters beware.

I recently repaired a set of 911 heads from an '82 euro.  I replaced the 
exhaust valves and guides.  Intakes were fine.

The car was recently purchased from one of our local (Springfield MO) used 
exotic dealers.  (They advertise in Autoweek & Hemmings)  The new owner 
took it to Branson MO at a high rate of speed.  He steered onto the off 
ramp and shoved it into a lower gear 1st or 2nd I'm told.  His complaint 
was the engine stopped running and would not restart.  The mechanic 
called me asking why this engine would not have any compression.  I told 
him to put air pressure into the spark plug hole and listen for the 
escaping air.  

The engine continued to rev even though the ignition cut out.  All of the 
exhaust valves hit the pistons and bell shaped the ends of the guides.
The engine would not restart because it had no compression.

Don't depend on your rev-limiter to replace common sense.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 1 Jun 1995 23:14:02 -0500
From: pfile@tta.com (Porschephiles Mailer)
Subject: Monthly Update, June 1995

June 1995

Monthly Notices for the Porschephiles mailing list. 
PLEASE READ THIS WHOLE MESSAGE!!

There are five sections: UPDATE, COPYRIGHT, FTP-INFO, CLUB-INFO, RULES. Be sure
that you are current on RULES...

UPDATE

Wow. The last two months have dwarfed anything I've had in a LONG while, all 
the way back to when I was hitting consulting gigs in 4 different cities a 
week... *BUT* things are looking up. I can't say more just yet, but there's
a very major change coming that I've worked a long LONG time for...

Don't worry, this will be one of the first places to get the announcement.
If you miss it, don't worry, it'll make the WSJ, etc...

Bart Chambers continues to fight for truth, the American Way, and the
establishment of the Porschephiles Foundation. If you haven't sent
him a check and can, please do so. If you have no idea what I'm
talking about, stick around, Uncle Bart will be around shortly with
the collection plate...

List membership continues to climb, hovering in the zone between 1500 and
2000. Speaking of such things, I've been VERY busy, so requests are no
longer guaranteed to be handled on a daily basis. I'm doing good right 
now to get to it every other day. So if you want an add/move/change,
don't get all upset if it's not happening in real time. *NOTHING* is
happening in real time right now...

COPYRIGHT AND FAIR USAGE STATEMENT

The messages sent to this list constitute private correspondence by and between
members of a closed community. As such, the copyright for EVERYTHING that 
ANYONE posts lies with them. PERIOD. This is *NOT* a bulletin board system,
where consent for further redistribution is implied by nature of the the
system; it's PRIVATE.

If you wish to use something written by someone on the list, you must first
seek their permission unless they specifically grant the right in that
specific posting to reprint it at will. And, in general, it is a VERY GOOD
idea to *CREDIT* someone if you use something by permission "copyright xxxx
Joe Gearhead, used by permission" to keep *SOMEONE ELSE* from screwing up
down the line.

You may also solicit articles, comments, notes and expansions of previous
notes. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't.

Remember, when you read something on this list: what you are reading belongs
to whoever wrote it. They may have plans to publish it further themselves.
They may want to keep it "private" (i.e. just for list member use). They 
may not care what gets done with it. It's still theirs, and before re-use,
permission must be obtained.

Please respect people's rights, even if they don't make a big deal about it.
I mean it.

FTP-INFO

Archives are available via FTP, compressed, since 4/90. There are no
older archives available. Remember, while it seems like a good idea when 
you're first starting out on the list to know what has gone on before, 
there are OVER 18 MEG of archives. DO NOT TRY TO FTP THEM ALL AT ONE TIME. 
Period!!! And PLEASE DO NOT FTP between 8:00 AM and 7:00 PM CST, or I'll 
have to take access away. We do have to get *SOME* work done around here, 
you know...  Also DO NOT ask me to mail you archives, since it's just too 
much work. Thank you.

Images from a variety of sources are available as well, in /pub/images.
There is an UPLOAD directory there as well, if you have images that you'd
like to upload. Please include a file called "from.<username>", where
<username> is your logon ID that describes the files if possible.

NOTE: To FTP the compressed archives, you will have to use BINARY mode in FTP. 
Then on receipt, you need to use the UNIX "uncompress" program, or equivalent,
to restore to textual format.

SECOND NOTE: if you really, really need to get a full set of archives, 
we have a business services group which could write you a tape for a fee.
Let me know if you really, really need that.

FINAL NOTE: As I noted in a prior mailing, the FTP restriction above applies 
to major downloading of stuff from the archives, not WWW access. Suggestions 
for improving the WWW pages would be welcomed, as well as experienced help
in doing so.

CLUB-INFO

Some Porsche Club info follows. IF you're not a member, PLEASE join!! 
This info is also on-line in /pub/pca/info, in case you forget to save
this message!

Porsche Club of Americia.
P.O. Box 10402
Alexandria VA 22310

Does take non-US membership. You *MUST* have a Porsche VIN number to join.
+1 703 922-9300, roughly 9:00 to 5:00 EST (GMT - 6).  Dues are $36/year.
Have your Visa/MC number *AND* your VIN number handy.
Or they'll send you an application which you can mail in with your check.

National membership chairman is Nann Weissenberger who is reachable via
e-mail at nannw@aol.com.   You can ask her for info or get her to send 
you an application as well. 


Porsche Club of Great Britain
Ayton House
West End
Northleach
Gloucestershire
England GL54 3HG
Telephone : +44 451 860792
Fax	    +44 451 860011

Specialty clubs:

356 Registry Inc.
27244 Ryan Rd. 
Warren, MI, 48092

For 356 enthusiasts around the world. $20 per year for US members, $35 for
world-wide members -- and cheap at twice the price!!! (Vic Skirmants' racing 
column is worth that, as are the classifieds...) 
5000 happy members can't be wrong! 

P.S. You *DON'T* have to own a 356 to join, and if you think you want to
own one, this is the best place to buy. No one seems to expect concours
prices for their cars unless they have a real concours car.

914 Owner's Association
100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
Palm Springs CA 92262

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries. Dennis Deeds publishes the club
newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly. Membership is $22 a year.
Again, they don't require you own an 914 to join, but they are interested
in the lowest and highest serial numbers known for each year model.

"S" Registry

Contact Vern Lyle, Box 363,
West Point, PA 19486 (tele (215) 652-7011 (day), (215) 287-5083 (eve). 
Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter. Dedicated to all early
911S models.

RULES

This list is still being run as a mail reflector, which sends incoming
mail to the whole list at once. The participants include people with a 
variety of backgrounds, some technical, some race/autocross/performance 
drivers, some owners, some just admirers.  

To send a message to the whole list, mail to

		porschephiles@tta.com

To send mail regarding distribution problems, or other administrative issues,
send mail to

		porschephiles-request@tta.com

If you have a friend who would like to get on this list, or if you feel
moved to tell other people about it, ONLY GIVE OUT THE "-request" address.

The list is also available as a digest, where you get a compilataion of
the day's messages once per day, rather than getting all of the individual
messages. This seems to be a win for people with slow mail links or who
are just too busy to stay current. If you want to convert to (or from)
the digest, send mail to the porschephiles-request address above.

PLEASE NOTE A FEW ITEMS:

1) There are a lot of  members on the list. It's small enough to be effective,
   and large enough to have a number of diverse opinions and sets of
   experience. Remember that before you decide to not ask a question, or
   if you get flamed for asking an "obvious" question. Diversity -- it's
   a *feature*....

2) The list is maintained more regularly than it used to be. I have
   routine access and try to handle changes at least once every other
   day.

3) ONLY send administrative mail to the "porschephiles-request"
   address, or to me directly. And, you can also reach me by phone 
   at (713) 661-2084 if you have to.

4) In the same vein, if you use a "pure" System V mail system, please pay
   attention to your replies. The default will send the reply to 
   the "porschephiles-request" address, as it is the UUCP "From "
   address (first actual line of the mail header). 

   PLEASE BE AWARE THAT I ROUTINELY TRASH SUCH MIS-ROUTED MAIL!!!

5) If your mailer starts screwing up *you will be dropped from the list*
   Should you notice that you aren't getting the list any more, send me
   mail and I'll figure out why not...

Enjoy the list! If I can be of assistance, please don't hesitate to drop
me a note.

Regards From Your Moderator,

Stanley P. Hanks
Principal, OMNInet Communications
P.O. Box 2087, Bellaire Texas 77402-2087
e-mail: stan@tta.com    direct voice: (713) 661-2084

'64 356 SC  		(Daily Driver)

Date: Fri, 2 Jun 1995 00:55:18 -0400
From: "Daniel G. Pouzzner" <douzzer@prez.mit.edu>
Subject: Re: Rev Limiter


Hmm. It's my understanding that Porsche's "under load" qualification
for the rev limiter's behavior actually means simply that you can't
get it to go past an RPM brick wall _using the throttle_. On the other
hand, downshifting can't possibly be guarded against without a very
large piece of extra machinery, essentially a brake on the engine
itself. Common sense, indeed!

 -douzzer

Date: Fri, 2 Jun 1995 01:55:12 -0400
From: "Paul F. Lyman" <lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov>
Subject: Subject: name that Boxster


Hi, all,

   I believe the commonly acknowledged designation number
for the Boxster is the 986.  At least, I seem to remember
seeing that in some auto mags, and that is what is in Walt
Thode's FAQ.  However, during my recent visit to the factory,
I could have SWORN the number used on the various Boxster
parts was 886.  I know that seems weird, but that is 
what I remember.  I even double-checked it with my SO, 
who doesn't share my praeternatural bias for numbers
that have the form "9xy".  She said, unprompted, that she thought
it was "886 or something."  When pressed for the "8xy" vs. "9xy"
she said that she was pretty sure it was an "800" number."  What
gives here?  Did Porsche go back to the future, or did the missus
and me have a few too many Stuttgarter Pilsners??

 TIA,
 Paul Lyman    lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov
 '82 911SC Targa  (but would consider a 886, 986, 914, 356, 9x4, 9x8, whatever!)

Porschephiles #1449                         Fri Jun 2 13:45:40 CDT 1995
Date: Fri, 2 Jun 1995 00:29:18 -0700
From: paulm@kestrel.engr.sgi.com (Paul Mielke)
Subject: torque wrenches

I'm gonna get myself a torque wrench (manual variety) to
work on my 911SC (there's the only Porsche content).  I
haven't been to the h/w store yet, but I checked a coupla
catalogs I happened to have lying around and was stunned
by the variation in price.  Griot's has a FACOM wrench for
more than $300 and an Amurrican one for $165.  Performance
Products has only one, but it's $32.95.  Hmm.  That's about
an order of magnitude difference.  I know you get what
you pay for, generally speaking, so I'd be willing to bet
that the $32.95 one is pretty cheesy.  But is it worth paying
more than $300?  I don't plan to put it to very hard use.

Before I go down to Sears or OSH, does anyone have any
opinions or advice to offer on what a good quality manual
(as opposed to compressed air powered) torque wrench should
cost?  Any testimonials or caveats?

Thanks for any suggestions (besides "get a life" 8^))!


Paul Mielke (paulm@sgi.com)
Silicon Graphics, Inc.

Paul F. Lyman said:

Date: Fri, 2 Jun 1995 02:31:46 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: torque wrenches

Dear Paul,

I bought a torque wrench from Imparts which probably compares with the
PP one.  The price when I bought it was lower.  Don't see it
advertised in the Imparts ad any more, but they probably still have
it.  With PP you pay both shipping and tax if you're in CA; Imparts
used to be free of shipping charges if your order was over $45, but
now it's a flat $3 on every order, no tax.  My only complaint about the
Imparts wrench is that the case (the only thing cheesy about it)
doesn't have room for the soft socket I bought for my lug nuts.
Otherwise it does the job.  The other wrenches are most likely better,
but five to ten times better?  I doubt it.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Fri, 2 Jun 1995 9:05:39 -0400 (EDT)
From: Darrin <LUCAS001@WCSUB.CTSTATEU.EDU>
Subject: 914 - Some people should be better salesmen!!


	Made the hour and a half trip to check out a '76 914 2.0 last night.
The seller (who shall remain nameless - he is a car salesman) told me the car
was perfect except for one small surface rust spot - I should have known better.
	The body was beautiful - the interior was perfect - it looked awesome
until I saw the "surface rust" right below the sail panel (what are the odds
of finding rust there??!!  :)    )  Further inspection revealed more bubbles
along the rocker panels.  

	A quick drive down the hiway revealed a spongy suspension and horrible
brakes (even compared to my 1,000,000,000,000 pound Audi Quattro).

	The worst was the seller's list of receipts.  The engine was supposedly
rebuilt 8,000 miles ago.  A lot of white and blue smoke for a new rebuild.
The famous Porsche "leaky engine tubes" were also shot.....  see oil covered
heater boxes for further proof.

	Asking price was about $8,000 - he'll probably get from someone who
has no 914 experience - the car looked and sounded great.

	Oh well, the hunt for another 914 or 911 Targa continues.

	BTW, if anyone wants a fair warning on the above car, mail me.  I don't
think the guy really thought anything was wrong with the car;  but aren't those
people always the best car salesmen??!!  :)


	It's in the northeast US, by the way.

	Darrin Lucas

	73  914 2.0     (In search of another 914  or 911 Targa)

Paul Mielke (paulm@sgi.com)

  Hey Paul,

  I just bought a micrometer-type torque wrench from Home Depot for about
  $50.
  The brand name was Husky, and upon comparison to the t wrench in Griot's
  (the non-Facom one) I am certain that they are one in the same. The
  picture
  in the catalog was an exact match, down to the dimples in the plastic
  case, and
  the text was nearly exactly the same in the catalog as it was in the
  wrench literature
  (OK, the manual said it was 'Made in the USA' while the catalog said
  'Finely made
  in the USA). The only significant difference was the price, which was
  more than
  double in the catalog, and close to triple. They had both 10-100 ft-lbs
  and 25-250
  ft-lbs at Home Depot.This wrench seems to be a pretty good one, and is
  far better
  than the beam-type wrench I have used for years. Hope this helps.

  Regards,

Date: Fri,  2 Jun 95 09:03:53 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; $150 head gasket


>From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>

>OK, this "928 leaky head gasket" thread has been running for a few days
>now, with lots of cogent advice being offered, but nobody has questioned
>what I was sure was a typo in the original post:

>HOW do you have a 928 head gasket replaced [I assume] for $150?????
>Doesn't it cost about $150 just to open the hood of a 928?

>No flame intended.  Just curious...

> -Ed Mellinger

    Sean, I agree with Ed; this is too cheap ! Forgetting the cost of the
 parts, removing the head on a 928 is a nightmate job (well, actually getting
 the head off is easy; its getting the cam towers off thats hard). Unless your
 mechanic has done a 928 head before, and if you value whatever relationship 
 you have with him, to be really decent you may leave your final price "open" 
 and rely on his generousity in billing....or by the time its over your 
 mechanic will shudder at the sight of you and your car when he is done.

      I don't know which year the change was made, but at some time the 928
  changed from "hidden" allen head bolts mounting the cam towers to ones
  that come flush to the outside of the towers. If its possible, I'd 
  definitely change the fasteners to the newer style so that its easy to get
  your head off in the future. Getting any of these off (upper or lower) is
  -THE- pain of the head job.

     Parts costs are going to run higher; a head gasket is about $40
 (I can't remember if the cam tower gasket is reusable), but then you'll need 
 about 8 rubber plugs to refill the access holes that in the cam towers (I  
 think about 8 at $5 each). If you are lucky, you will only need need 4
 intake/exhaust gaskets more, but likely you will break those custom
 German plastic hoses (gee, I think new cars use rubber instead of that
 brittle plastic :> ). Likely you will also have problems with frozen or
 broken allen-head bolts on the way out.

     All this is a mess and will probably cost closer to $500 than $150.
 But if you have anything marginal, fixing it quickly (and treating your
 mechanic fairly) is by far your cheapest alternative...

      - Lee A, ooh meenya nyet  '79 928



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 2 Jun 1995 10:22:20 -0500
From: sarsfld@tiac.net (Steve Sarsfield)
Subject: Update - 944 Puzzler Solved

Since I only got one response to my previous post (thanks, Trevor), I post
this message with some reservations.  However, we have found a solution to
the surging/anti-surging 1983 944 with a whining fuel pump.  Perhaps this
message will save you folks a few bucks.

I thought for sure I needed a new fuel pump.  The engine was obviously
burning extremely rich.  The pump was whining like Holly Hunter and pumping
at about 140 lbs of pressure.  In fact, I was just about to ask my mechanic
to order one, when he suggested trying the fuel pressure regulator first.
It worked.  The car runs better than ever now with a relatively cheap part.

The mechanic shared a story with me of a similar problem that he
encountered.  The owner of a '84 944 pulled in his car and asked the shop
to replace the fuel pump.  He told them that it was whining and that he
needed a new one.  Well, I'm sure you know how it turned out - he broke
down about 20 minutes after leaving the shop. Fuel pressure regulator.

I'm told, however, that this is not a typical malfunction.  In the 15 or so
years this guy's worked on Porsche's, it's only the 2nd fuel pressure
regulator he's done.

Moral of the story:
1) Look at the whole picture when you're dealing with Bosch FI System.  (ie
a whining fuel pump may not necessarily be a bad fuel pump.)
2) Get yourself a mechanic who's seen a few Porsches.  On the atypical
problems, there's no substitute for experience.

............................................................
.                                                          .
.  Steve Sarsfield          http://www.digvis.com/digvis/  .
.  Digital Vision, Inc.     Digital Vision's WWW Home Page .
.  sarsfld@tiac.net                                        .

.                                                          .

Date: Fri, 2 Jun 1995 08:28:48 -0700

Phil, I've always used a mixture of distilled water, ShellZone antifreeze
and RedLine Watterwetter in all my water-cooled cars. After 45,000 miles I
had to pull an aluminum head (worn cam) and there was absolutely no
evidence of corrosion. The above mixture certainly works for me ...

volatile, and one bottle of the stuff goes a long way.

Date: Fri, 2 Jun 1995 11:53:12 -0400
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: Distilled or Non-Distille...

No, you are not being AR, I believe it is officially recommended that you use
distilled water. Not so much from a corrosion standpoint, you will still need
corrosion inhibitors, but to prevent scaling from hard water impurities. 

I run distilled water with Red Line "Water Wetter" which improves heat
conductivity and also (recently added) has corrosion inhibiters in it. A
little anti freeze is also useful as it will raise the boiling point as well
as lower the freezing point of the mixture.

If you plan to run on the track, you will be loved by all if you eliminate
anti-freeze from your system and replalce it with distilled water only. Anti
freeze is worse than oil on the track surface and can cause long delays for
mop up in the event of a spillage.

Note also, that anti-freeze does just that, by adding glycol to water you
raise the boiling point (which is why we still use it in summer) and lowers
the freezing point. But it also LOWERS the heat dissipation capabilities of
your system .

------------------------------

Date: Fri,  2 Jun 95 08:16:20 PDT
From: Scott=D=Berry%MfgEng%GPID@banyan.BV.TEK.COM
Subject: 66 912 fume problem solved!!!!

I would like to thank Reid Zeigler and Jim Mali and Ron Jay De Lange and 
everyone else that gave advice about where the the fumes in my 66 912.  The 
winner was.........  Ron!  I feel really stupid that I hadn't tried this months 
ago but the crankcase breather hose (the one about an inch in diameter that 
comes out of the oil filler can) has been inserted into this perfectly matched 
metal pipe on the right side of the engine compartment.  I believe this pipe use 
to connect to the carbs (My car now has webers now though).  I pulled the 
crankcase ventilation hose out of the metal pipe and just rested it on the rear 
engine cover.  NO MORE FUMES IN THE CAR!!!!!!  I now have to figure out where I 
should put the crankcase breather hose.  I assume it use to go into the right 
carb air cleaner - but my K&N aircleaners won't allow that (I wouldn't want to 
do that anyway).  But thanks to everyone and my car is now much more enjoyable 
to drive now.  Now if I can just make that 022 distributor work.......

Scott

66 912

Date: Fri, 2 Jun 95 09:10:44 PDT
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: distilled water

>Date: Thu, 1 Jun 1995 20:19:26 -0700 (PDT)
>From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
>Subject: Re: Distilled or Non-Distilled H2O?

<< big snip>>

>However, jars 1 and 2 behave the opposite as I would have expected. Any 
>chemists out there to explain why using distilled water produced more 
>precipitate than tap water?
> 
>Joe '86 944
>

It has to do with a thing called the KSP.  What is happening is that
the Al is dissolving in the water.  The reason that the tap water
looks better is that there is already a lot of metal dissolved in
it; it can't dissolve that much more.

One of the reasons for distilled water is so that YOU have control
of what metals are dissolved in the water.  Certain metals are less
soluible than others, and will be exchanged for the more soluible
metal in your engine.

Then again, what is water doing in your motor anyway?  <flinch>

Gary.


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 2 Jun 1995 13:01:12 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>

etc. etc.

Date: Fri, 2 Jun 1995 14:53:12 -0400 (EDT)
From: Michell Feig <mitchsf@shadow.net>
Subject: Re: 914 down in FLA

Dear Darrin:
I stopped at Specialized Motorcars this afternoon to look at the 1976 914 
you're interested in.  Here's what I found:

BODY

Original lime green, now red.  Paint job is below average.  I don't 
believe that they used primer between colors (I could be wrong about 
this).  I didn't find any major accident repair.  Car never had A/C.

Front Trunk - Front torsion bar mounts badly rusted.  Entire front trunk 
coated with black undercoat.  Otherwise OK

Rear Trunk - Painted red (including wiring harness).  No rust detected.

Bottom - Outer rockers seem to be OK, inner probably OK, but you must 
remove the outers to be sure.  No rust or other damage noted.

Engine Compartment - Also coated with black undercoat.  Battery bracket 
badly rusted.  What I could see under the bracket seemed to be OK, but 
the salesman didn't have a flashlight handy (of course), and we couldn't 
move the battery.  The battery was held in place with a U-shaped bracket 
screwed to the sidewall, pushing down on it.  There didn't seem to be any 
other rust in the engine compartment.

Passenger Compartment - No rust under seats or on floorboards.  Otherwise 
average interior.  Plastic dash cover glued to dash. Alpine stereo and 
speaker upgrade with door speakers.


ENGINE & TRANS

2.0 litre with original fuel injection - smog pump removed with a lot of 
loose plumbing left over.  Probably could use some new vacuum hoses.  

Shifter is very sloppy.  I'm sure that new bushings would help a lot.  
Third gear synchro is probably shot, but it could be a linkage problem.  
Maybe someone else can comment on this. Other shifts were OK, so it's 
probably the synchro.  

DRIVE

Car runs fine.  Engine has power and doesn't smoke (of course this 
observation is no substitute for a mechanic's inspection).  It sure is 
hot down here without AC.  Salesman said that he has been driving it 
every day to his home in Miami (about 30 or 40 miles).

CONCLUSION

I certainly would not be happy with this car for 6K plus $800 shipping to CT.

Any questions, call me at the office - I'll be here Saturday morning 
305-755-1993 extension 600

or at home tonight before 11:30PM 305-345-8089.

Mitch Feig
1976 911S Minerva Blue
formerly about 5 914's including a 6

from two p-filers that just toured the factory that one- the last 968 has been

word if known?  We should have a nation minute of silence in respect for the
passing of such an important part of our auto heritage or better yet maybe
Porsche will realize it's mistake and find a way to continue it's water cooler
line.  I personally can't see the big deal of having a new line of 2.0 liter
rag tops starting at $40,000.  My first two cars were rag tops a Sunbeam
Alpine and  a Fiat  124 Spyder (which I still have) so I know the fun of such
cars but for a Porsche I love the 968 (which I also still have) looks/feel etc
etc.  I don't think Porsche's problem is the 968 cars themselves and I fear
that the 986 isn't going to solve it either.  

I guess I'm a little p#ssed off because I took my 968 into the shop today to
get the AC fixed-bad switch and have the valve cover gasket replaced-all under
warranty and I was told after I got there that I would have to leave the car
for the whole day.  This is the second time I took the car in and they knew I
was going to be waiting for the car while the repair was done.  I should have
at least been told beforehand that I would need to leave the car for the day. 
It turns out I had to rent a car or wait 8 hours till they finished.  I live
an hour and a half away so it's a real pain having service done.  Since it was
warranty work I guess I should be  happy that I did not have to pay for the
fix but a lot of car dealers give you a loaner car since you are deprived of
the use of your car for the day due to "their" fault.  If Saturn can do it why
can't Porsche?  A nice new Turbo would have made my day and think of the good
will they would create.  I might just have my car serviced weekly?  Enough
bandwidth.
Thanks for the vent.
Andy Chrisman
