Date: Fri, 02 Jun 95 13:06:00 PDT
From: Thomas Pindelski <ThomasP@nacm.com>
Subject: Torque wrenches


My first one came from Imparts about seven years ago; after a couple of 
years of decent service, it would suddenly slip at 90+ft.lbs, just when 
tightening those lug nuts on the wheels, with the result that the air would 
turn blue from the foul language, the latter resulting from the smashed 
knuckles on your right hand. After about three vituperative outbreaks over a 
span of one year, at which point I was contemplating driving with loose nuts 
in preference to smashed knuckles, I got an Armstrong from a San Fernando 
Valley tool store (General Industrial) model 64-066, cost $135.31 (in 1992) 
and have been delighted with it, as well I should be at that price.

Like the Imparts one, it's a clicker type and goes up to 120 ft.lbs.  It 
includes metric calibration, albeit on a non-linear scale, the primary scale 
unfortunately (at least for P cars) being US.  the only problem has been 
that the rubber handle started to slip off a few months back, easily 
remedied with some glue.

While I would recommend the tool, I think the Home Depot alternative 
mentioned earlier is probably the way to go.  While Griot's catalog looks 
like it has some fine tools in it, the prices are unrealistic, and there's 
so much badge engineering going on now I wouldn't be surprised if the HD one 
was the same thing.

By the way, I bought Griot's soft jaw channel pliers and cannot recommend 
them.  While beautiful to behold, the curve of the jaws and the wide closed 
gap to severely limit the tool's use.  Also, the polyurethane (?) jaws are 
too slippery for most purposes.  The one really great tool they sell is the 
ratcheting box spanner - ideal for fiddling with belt tension on my 928 
('belt' as in alternator, smog pump, etc, not as in cam!).  Try that why 
lying on your back with an open end wrench....

------------------------------

Date: 02 Jun 1995 16:30:31 -0400
From: william.anders@smc.com
Subject: torque wrenches

  "Before I go down to Sears or OSH, does anyone have any
  opinions or advice to offer on what a good quality manual
  (as opposed to compressed air powered) torque wrench should
  cost?  Any testimonials or caveats?"

  Imparts offers 2 different sizes of torque wrenches, a 1/2" & 3/8" drive.
  I have both & they have given me good service for a very reasonable
  price.  I use the 3/8 drive for installing spark plugs & the 1/2 drive
  for lug nuts, CV joint bolts, front strut upper mounting bolts, etc.
  These may not be durable enough for every day use in a shop, but for the
  weekend racer they work.

  Otto

Date: Fri, 2 Jun 95 13:46:30 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Torque Wrench


Paul-
For the kind of home wrenching you're talking about, buy
the Sears wrench.  I'd even recommend the torsion bar type.
They're cheaper, they don't go out of calibration, and they
don't break.  In a shop where a tool ius used every day, and
time is money, this might not be the best solution.  But for
those of us who use it a few times a year, so what if it takes
two minutes longer, or if it's handle isn't silky smooth.

I think they cost around $20.  Thing of what you can get with
the $280 you saved!

 -Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu

Date: Fri, 2 Jun 1995 20:58:03 +0000 (GMT)
From: wayne@aprf.arl.mil
Subject: Re: 542 again

Hello all,
A bit of background as I know it on the 542, maybe those more knowledgable
in Porsche history could correct me.

Probably because some Studebaker family members with lots of
relatives in Germany still sat on the board
of the Studebaker Corp, and because  the Marshall Plan to help out Germany was
underway, the Studebaker Corp became involved with the German auto 
industry after WWII.  Volkswagon of Canada and Mercedes of North America were
started as divisions of the Studebaker Corp.  For the '53 model year Studebaker
wanted a 'continental' look.  Design contracts went out, one being to
Porsche for the design of a sedan (saloon).   A prototype was built called
something like the 630 or 633.  From this first design a production
design evolved called the 542.  Now I had thought this was maybe just a 
prototype.

A fellow I met here, now deceased, worked at South Bend at that time 
and knew about the Porsche project, he said he worked in 'experimental' as
a toolman.
He said there was a small production run in '52 for testing.  He didn't
recall which parts were made in South Bend or Germany, but
the assembly was done in South Bend.  He thought the cars went to the
factory engineers for testing.  He did not know whatever happened to them
as the project was discarded when the Loewy design for '53 was adopted.

Anyway, I thought it might be fun to have one of the 'US-built Porsches'.
Also curious he said, 'Yep, they were gonna make them there Mercedes too,
in Plant ....' apparently some WWII truck plant.  Possible, since they
owned the sales rights.

Oh, I asked him if any photos were ever taken, since I had never seen a 
picture of one, and he said the photo guys were there all the time.   So
any Pfilers ever seen one of these..........is there a photo in the
'Excellence' book?  Is there one extant?
- -- 
Wayne Flowers                 Voice:  505-678-8303
Senior Scientist              Fax:    505-678-6049
Science & Technology Corp.    E-mail: wayne@aprf.arl.mil
White Sands, New Mexico       URL:    http://aprf.arl.mil/

Date: Fri, 2 Jun 1995 15:02:17 -0700
From: peterg@airdata.com (Peter Gregory)
Subject: my blown 912 motor

Folks,

A mechanic of good repute in Seattle wants to sell me a '64 'B' motor that
I'd put in my '69 912 - just long enough to sell the car in running order.

I figure my car, before the engine went, was worth maybe $6000.  tired paint,
but no rust, and LOTS of new parts (generator, shocks, clutch, etc.).  He
wants $1700 for his '64 'B' motor.

I looked at the motor the other day.  He pulled it out of a rust bucket,
and the motor looks like hell (corrosion on the valve covers, dirty grease
everywhere), but the sheet metal is all there.

Will this motor *really* bolt into my car?  For how many mechanic-billable
hours?  How long to switch Zeniths for Solexes (manifolds need swapping, too)?

On the positive side, at least the car would be running and, hence, far
easier to sell.  On the negative side, I could spend this money and come out
a little more behind $$$-wise than I would if I could sell as is.

Thanks,

Pete

through the Auto Trader for $2200, which is what I asked.  It's a long 
story, but the car was nicer when I bought it for $2500, before I put a 
penny into it.  Live and learn!

Date: Fri, 2 Jun 1995 21:05:56 -0500 (CDT)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 2 Jun 1995 21:20:39 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Need help on lousy 911S Cams

Dear Mike,

I have had good luck with hardsurface overlay regrinds from Web Cam.

It has been quite a bit of time since I spoke to them last.  I ordered 
them through a friends machine shop and we got a pretty good discount.

The rule of thumb has been that you could go up one level of grind 
without an overlay being applied to the cam.  In your description you 
could probably regrind the cam to the original profile and repair just 
the damaged lobe (maybe lobes?), with this overlay method.  Be sure and 
refurbish the rocker arms.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 2 Jun 1995 21:23:32 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Need help on lousy 911S Cams

> Be sure and 
> refurbish the rocker arms.

Heed this!!!!

When you put too agressive a regrind on a cam core, the geometry gets 
all hosed up. The rockers no longer track at the right angle, they
push not *DOWN* on the valve stem but sort of down and *OUT* on the
valve stem, causing premature guide wear, and possible stem failure.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 02 Jun 1995 22:43:07 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Need help on lousy 911S Cams

>My 2.4S cams are worn and pitted, looks like the shiny finish 
>on the lobes is worn off in spots. Maybe they were reground poorly?
>
>Anyway, I would like to repair or replace these cams to get some
>performance back (I need it to keep up with 993s!)
>
>Does anyone have a GOOD set of MFI S cams for sale?
>
>Anyone know a reputable shop that can get these cams back up to
>factory S specs in a short time?

Mike,

We use WebCam and Elgin.  They use different processes, and I cannot
swear to you that one is better than the other.  In any case, positive
experience with both places.  They will work with you, and they will
tell you their turn-around.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 02 Jun 95 22:24:38 +0700
From: dnimtz@mill2.millcomm.com
Subject: Re: 944S2 or Turbo (S)

I've owned a 944 Turbo, and presently a 89 944S2. I much prefer the S2. It seems MUCH more
responsive, quicker, and faster. In terms of repairs, the turbo needed more, but I think
that was because both were used cars, and the S2 was better maintained.

//-----------------------------------//
//   Dan Nimtz                       //
//      dnimtz@mill2.millcomm.com    //

the stupid part) can't get them apart. The wonderful people at Hanes say to
simply rotate the release bearing 90 degrees and this somehow will allow the
fork to slip off the bearing and then I can remove the tranny. Well I can
rotate the release bearing all I want in either direction but nothing seems
to loosen. So what is the simple solution I'm staring at but cannot see? Are
all Hanes manuals really for someone elses car?

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 3 Jun 1995 01:07:51 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: early vs. late 911s

> I drove a '82 911 this week and, compared to my '69 912 and the '73 911s I've
> driven, the '82 felt awfully heavy, more like a Corvette or a 3000GT.

Yup. It's significantly heavier than the early 911s. Gives up a whole lot
in power to weight to the '73 S (or E for that matter)...

> I've always had small, light sports cars (Triumph GT6, MGB, 912), so I'm
> wondering if I'd be happy with a 911SC...

Hard to say. I personally was very very happy with my Euro SC. On the
other hand, it made a lot (a whole lot) more power than a US spec car,
so I had a lot of that "punch" back. On the whole, as 911s progress up 
the timeline, they get more "refined". On the whole, that's good. For
Jim Bob General-Public, it's *REAL* good -- any gooberhead can drive a 993
pretty close to the limit, whereas that limit slips up on you pretty damn
fast in say a '67 S. However, if you're looking for that "sports car feel",
it's hard to get in any 911 -- they're just too heavy.

I made this discovery when I started driving my 356SC more. The more I drove
it, the more I wanted to drive it. Eventually, when something had to go
to cover the five-figure vet bills last year, it was the 911 *NOT* the 356
that made the exit trip.

Then again, while just about everyone I know instantaneously goes "wow!
cool car -- and you drive it all the time??" after the 2nd or 3rd trip
with the highly primitive no-support-at-all seats, early aircraft style
seat belts, no radio, no 12 volt "amenities" and no A/C, that changes 
rapidly into "why the bloody hell don't you get a REAL car and keep this 
in a garage somewhere???" On the other hand, that settles the "who drives 
to lunch" question really quickly... 8{)

Like I said, tough call. My next 911 will either be a '72-73 E or S in
bone stock condition, a project 930 that gets that tired old KKK swapped
for a Paxton blower, or a 993 if this new venture turns out well. 

At the risk of starting something I don't want to see started again, they're
like women -- they're all wonderful, they're all special, there's something
that draws you to each, there's something that drives you crazy about each,
and as much as you'd like to have a dozen of them, you're best settling for
one at a time...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 2 Jun 1995 07:56:09 -0400 (EDT)
From: Grayson Walker <gwalker@rtfm.mlb.fl.us>
Subject: Coolant Discussion -- continued

To underscore the previous posting. The use of a sacrificial anode in
your liquid cooling system should be considered a must. Lots of parts
stores have them -- as does J. C. Whitney -- less than $10.00. Don't
start the car without it!

FORZA!                  Smith, Walker And Associates, Melbourne, Florida
GWALKER@RTFM.MLB.FL.US      "Big brown river. . ." Tuli Kupferberg, 1963

Date: Sat, 3 Jun 1995 01:01:08 -0700 (PDT)
From: James Wood <jamesw@PEAK.ORG>
Subject: Hotrod parts for 944?


Hello all - I'm new to the list, and to Porsches.  It's good to be here.

I've recently picked up a 1988 944.  It has 36K miles, and runs great!  
Too bad it's not an "S" or "Turbo" model, however.  Luckily, a 5-speed.

I really want to throw on some hotrod parts; I've never been under the 
hood of a Porsche but I've built VW and V-8 engines before.

I'm totally unfamiliar with what hotrod parts exist for the "plain" 944 
and I request some input from other 944 enthusiasts, please.  Here's what 
I envision:

1) Header/non-catalyst pipe for off-road use.   I've been told that as late
   as 1988 (they quit 944s in '89, right?) the 944 was "tweaked" by Porsche
   such that a header won't really flow much and isn't worth the expense on
   this car.  Any second opinions?

   Toward this end, I've been told that a "test pipe" to replace the 
   catalytic converter (no tree-hugging speeches, please) and a cat-back
   (or test-pipe-back) system and muffler would work as well.  Can someone
   recommend or suggest a course of action and source/brandname for such
   equipment?

2) Computer chip - The only experience I have with playing with PROM chips
   in a car was on an '86 Corvette, and the difference could be felt -
   I didn't fully realize it until I swapped back in the stock part prior
   to selling the car, and it felt slower by the "seat of the pants."  I 
   am curious if the $300 cost will garner a significant gain on "such a 
   small" engine as the 2.5L in the 944.

3) Fuel pressure adjuster - this was a highly-touted Corvette item.  Is
   such also the case with the 944?

4) Camshaft - Although I know little of the 944 engine, I am intrigued with
   the OHC cam and the apparant ease of change due to the overhead location.
   I'm sure it will be more difficult to change than I anticipate, but at
   least it's not in the block!  What is the lift and duration of the stock
   part, and what is a popular recommended "high performance" replacement?
   As I have never changed camshafts on a computer-controlled engine, how
   will the F.I. and computer controls respond to a camshaft change?  How
   expensive are 944 cams?  While I wish I did not even have to go into 
   changing internals of the engine (such as cam), I am afraid that this
   may be necessary since how else am I going to eeek out some more
   grunt from a tiny SOHC engine?


Does anybody know what the rater HP was for the 1988 Porsche 944?  I 
looked up a Chilton's guide and it said that the 1986-1987 model (non-S, 
non-Turbo) was rated at 147HP.  Indeed, the car is no slug considering 
some of the wimpier "performance" cars to come out of Detroit during the 
'80s, but with Japanese 4-bangers abounding with multiple cams and 
variable valve timing, I feel that the stock performance of my 944 is in 
need of a little helping hand.  Anybody know what the 0-60 and 1/4 mi. 
times were for this car?  Anybody with an equivalent 944 that has bested 
those times with or without hotrod parts?

Thanks *VERY* much for any suggestions you may have!!  I assure you 
they'll be put to good use!


James Wood

>
>Hello all - I'm new to the list, and to Porsches.  It's good to be here.
>
>I've recently picked up a 1988 944.  It has 36K miles, and runs great!  
>Too bad it's not an "S" or "Turbo" model, however.  Luckily, a 5-speed.
>
>I really want to throw on some hotrod parts; I've never been under the 
>hood of a Porsche but I've built VW and V-8 engines before.
>
>I'm totally unfamiliar with what hotrod parts exist for the "plain" 944 
>and I request some input from other 944 enthusiasts, please.  Here's what 
>I envision:
>
>1) Header/non-catalyst pipe for off-road use.  

Worth about 5 bhp at most... Not worth the money

>2) Computer chip - The only experience I have with playing with PROM chips

Worth about 5 bhp at most... Not worth the money

>3) Fuel pressure adjuster - this was a highly-touted Corvette item.  Is
>   such also the case with the 944?

Let's just say that Porsche probably did a better job setting up the fuel 
pressure on your car than you can do by the seat of your pants.

>
>4) Camshaft - Although I know little of the 944 engine, I am intrigued with

Here's where you might find some value, but consider that you might have
to raise compression ratio, use larger valves, etc. to get the most out of
the cam.
 
>Does anybody know what the rater HP was for the 1988 Porsche 944?  I 

Yes, 158 bhp. It is higher than the early cars due to higher compression 
ratio.

Don't waste your money on trying to make this car faster. Spend the money on 
your PCA membership and take advantage of their track programs, then your 
car will be faster because of you, not because you have made undriveable on the 
street...
Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology

Date: Sat, 3 Jun 1995 11:06:20 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Gerald G. MacDonald - Thomas Cooley Law School" <macdonag@mlc.lib.mi.us>
Subject: Rear Lid strut question



Well, I finally got around to putting in the new strut.  Actually 
amazingly easy (1/2 hour max just to be sure you don't drop anything).  
Here's my question:  I got the strut from Tweeks.  When I took off the 
old strut, I noticed the end which connects in the back of the engine 
compartment was significantly wider than the same end on the Tweeks 
part.  The connectors on both ends of the Tweeks part were the same 
narrow width.  On the end connected to the lid, I noticed the original 
part had an identically narrow connector but had a bushing to take up the 
spare space.  Does anyone know if Tweeks will send the busshing to fill 
the space on the front?  Is is a problem to run the car without the 
bushing (other than the obvious potential rattle?  Anyone else have this 
problem with a replacement lid strut from Tweeks and if so how did they 
handle it?  I was told to call their customer service department on Monday.

Thanks for any info!  BTW, just got the car back from her 60k mile 
service.  My wallet will be hurting for quite some time from that one.

Date: 03 Jun 95 14:22:30 EDT
From: Dennis Winter <71334.2372@compuserve.com>
Subject: 911 A/C and rotary compressors

Neil,

What I can tell you is I had to replace the compressor in my 83SC, and took the
car to CT Engineering (formerly Carrera Tech) in Campbell. They replaced it with
a rotary (japanese) that works just fine. I dont remember exactly what they
charged me, I have the receipt somewhere, but it was a lot less than $1000. This
included the compressor, labor, and the recharge of the system.

	D.	03-Jun-95 at 10:19:32 PT

this weekend cuz it won't go into reverse gear!   this has
never happened before & the previous owner assured me the
same thing but added that it might only need to have a set
screw adjusted.

resolve this problem.   is there any chance the garage
might have screwed it up while they inspected it?   if
so, how could i prove it & what could i do about it?

the good news is that the car is noticeably smoother &
much quieter after they did the injectors/gaskets!

Date: Sat, 03 Jun 95 16:01:00 PDT
From: "Pickell, Kevin" <KPickell@ea.com>
Subject: Ouch


     Hello pfiles,

          I've been off the list for the last couple of weeks as I
     was in a bit of an accident on May 17th, and couldn't get near
     my computer until now. On my way to work I had a car decide to
     turn left in front of me (he was coming towards me) and I hit him
     head on. Unfortunately for me I was driving my Yamaha FJ100
     and proceeded to do a very good superman impersonation. I landed
     on my back with my lower half on the sidewalk and my upper half on
     the road. I suffered a broken back and fibula. My right knee has some
     torn ligaments and you should see the huge dent in my gas tank that
     was put there by my pelvis/ naughty bits *ouch*. The doctors say that
     my back is very stable so I'm currently hobbling around on crutches.
     When I was in the hospital getting my X-rays done I noticed a can of
     WD40 sitting on one of the X-ray machines, *as used in hospitals*,
     reminds me of the Monty Python sketch about string. My knee surgery
     is scheduled for July 5.

     Now for some Porsche content. Last month I decided to purchase a
     1989 911 Cabriolet, but figured that I would have to travel to get one
     as there aren't that many for sale locally (Vancouver, B.C.).
     The week after the accident I noticed (well my wife noticed it)
     an add in the local paper for the car that I have decided to purchase.
     An 1989 Carrera Cabriolet, in the color that I want, blue, and with low
     mileage that I want 47000 kms (about 30k miles?). After getting it
     checked out by the local experts I bought it. I still haven't driven it
     yet. My wife has been doing all of the driving, although she was scared
     to drive it initially as she was worried that I'd be pissed if she had 
an
     accident in it. She thinks that the location of the key to the left of 
the
     steering wheel is a little weird, and she also thinks that the pedals
     feel weird as they pivot at the bottom instead of the top. Other than
     those two weird things, and the stiff clutch  she doesn't mind driving 
it.
     If I wasn't injured she probably would never have driven it.

      I can't wait to get better so I can drive it as I have never driven a
     911, only my 914.

     Kevin Pickell
     kpickell@ea.com

Date: Sat, 3 Jun 1995 22:39:39 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: strange 356 phenomenon

> The oil filter cartridge in my 356 is bulged at the top as though it had
> become pressurized. Do you know why?

Ummm. Are you talking about the actual element, or the canister itself??
I've seen canisters bulge  a bit from either having the tops overzealously
tightened or from having a plugged up exit hose. I've never seen a
"bulging" element, though...

from behind (the engine, I think).

Date: Sat, 3 Jun 1995 22:02:37 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: My new 914

Hi Adam! A Porsche (por-sha) at 16 - congrats!

The shift pattern is:

R  2  4
|  |  |
+--*--+
|  |  |
1  3  5

There's a strong spring detent which forces the shifter away from 1st and
reverse.

Fuchs is pronounced Foochs, where the "ch" part is like the ch in
"Achtung!" if you've ever heard it pronounced properly -- Sorry, but it's
not a dipthong that occurs in English, French or Spanish (but does in
Russian, Yiddish and German). Say "Fooks" and you'll be pretty close.

I suggest you get a manual -- it will prove invaluable. Haynes and Lash
Int'l are under $20 ea.



 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  |

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 01:46:03 -0400
From: HHeath3@aol.com
Subject: Possible car worth a look

I was out on errands today, and ran across a car that might interest someone.
 It is on the used car lot of Larry H. Miller Lexus, Salt Lake City, UT
(801-264-3600.

1989 944T medium metallic blue
Lt grey leather seats, lt grey carpets
ca. 52,000 mi on odo

I inspected and drove the car, and thought it was pretty solid.  I saw no
signs it had been hit, all paint/upholstery looked original.  The salesman
(Rex Pearson) said it was a local tradein on a new Lexus.

Problem and good areas noted by visual inspection etc.:
  Paint good but needs a good treatment; looks as if it would be
    gorgeous when cleaned up
  Leather in good shape, minor cracking driver's seat only
  I saw no signs of being hit, no repaints, no waves, not even the
     usual door dings
  Hood shocks weak
  Hatch motor and sunroof both work normally
  Carpet under driver's feet is a bit nasty but looks as if it would detail
     out okay
  Clear light RF has cracked lens and must be replaced
  The plastic/rubber trim pieces at the very bottom of the front
     fenders just behind front wheels are slightly bowed downward
     at front but look repairable
  Tires Goodyear Z45 (?), in very good condition
  Wheels need detailing but didn't look bent
  A/C worked
  Car felt tight and together on brief test drive

The really good news: the price on windshield is something like $15,500, but
he offered it to me for 13,995.  By my NADA book (now out of date, 12/94
ed.), this is way below lowest retail.  The car looked as if it had sat on
the lot for a while (I do not believe the market for 944s is very strong
here) so maybe they need to move it.

I have no connection to LHM Lexus, just passing along what I saw.  Hope it
interests someone; looked like a good deal to me.  They were happy to sign it
out for independent inspection.

Ciao,

Hunter Heath

You can find out what "break away" torque is.

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 03:41:11 -0400
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: #1(2) Porschephiles #1450...

Dear Peter:
     With regard to that '64 "B" (sic) engine that supposedly will "bolt
into" a 912- it WON'T!!! (Well, actually  it WILL "bolt into" it just won't
work!) 
      First of all, there aren't any '64 356B's. It's either a  '63 356B or a
'64 356C. Tell me what the Engine Number is and I'll tell you what the Engine
really is.
    356B/C's have a completely different clutch, than a 912, and (more
importantly) 912's  are 12 Volt while 356's  are 6 volt. You must change the
flywheel and clutch. Also- the sheet metal is different- you must use the
912's Side Horizontal Tin, and Front & rear Plate. Also, the 356 6 volt
generator, coil, oil temperature gauge should be changed. 
    But more importantly- the 912 has a Rear Engine Mount that bolts onto the
Third Piece of the Case. 356's don't have any such thing! So, you gotta
change the Third Piece- putting the 912's Third Piece onto the 356. Oh, and
the 912 Third Piece requires FOUR long studs to mount the rear mount, the 356
only has ONE long stud there on the Third piece,  so you gotta change out
three of the short 356 studs for 3 of the long 912 studs.
      Oh, and don't forget  to check the size of #4 Main  Bearing on both the
912 AND the 356's crank ifin you're switching Third Pieces. 'Cause the Third
piece from the 912 may have a crank that's a different size on the Mains than
the 356. In which case, don't forget to change the #4 Main Bearing in the
Third Piece- using the old #4 main from the 356's Third Piece in the 912's
Third Piece you're putting on the 356. Is that clear?
    Oh, and the 912's  two lower engine mounting studs that mount the engine
 to  the trans  are jusssst a itty bit longer, long  enough  that the 356
lower studs won't fit through the 912's trans case. So you gotta swap the
lower studs from the 912 to the 356.
   Yes, you CAN put a 356B or C into a 912, it'll bolt  right up.
Unfortunately, it WON'T WORK unless you make the above changes/mods.

   If you'd like additional details, give me a call at (408) 727-1864. And:
KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!
The  Maestro

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 10:02:11 -0400 (EDT)
From: Scot Alan Douglas <scootman@engin.umich.edu>
Subject: 914 F.I./Carb Questions

I have a few questions that maybe someone can answer.

1.  I have a '74 914 with the L-Jetronic system.  Over the years the F.I. 
has been butchered and jury-rigged together, but it seems to run okay.  
The biggest problem is, the car only gets about 25 MPG.  Is this normal 
for 2000 lb., 76 HP car?  I haven't checked the color of the spark plugs, 
but it doesn't smell or look like its running rich.  As far as I know, 
all of the components are there, just the vaccuum hoses are awry.  Does 
this poor mileage have a solution?

2.  I really want to go to carburetors, but I don't know what would be 
the best selection.  I want Dellortos but would take Webbers just as 
fast.  Question is, what size would be best for a stock 1.8L?

3.  Does anyone have some used carburetors for sale?

Thanks alot!

Scot Douglas
Advanced Vehicle Technologies
Ford Motor Company
'74 914 1.8



------------------------------

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 09:38:30 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 F.I./Carb Questions

> 1.  I have a '74 914 with the L-Jetronic system.  Over the years the F.I. 
> has been butchered and jury-rigged together, but it seems to run okay.  
> The biggest problem is, the car only gets about 25 MPG.  Is this normal 
> for 2000 lb., 76 HP car?  I haven't checked the color of the spark plugs, 
> but it doesn't smell or look like its running rich.  As far as I know, 
> all of the components are there, just the vaccuum hoses are awry.  Does 
> this poor mileage have a solution?

Sure, trade for a Civic CRX HF.... No really, that's about right. You may
be able to get all the way up to 30, but there's really not that much room
for improvement. And if you drive it hard, there's *NO* room for improvement.

> 2.  I really want to go to carburetors, but I don't know what would be 
> the best selection.  I want Dellortos but would take Webbers just as 
> fast.  Question is, what size would be best for a stock 1.8L?

OK, you asked for it.... The *BEST* size is **NONE**. You'll get worse milage,
worse performance (unless you increase compression and change cams), and
worse streetability with carbs. The *ONLY* advantage that carbs have is
that they're "easier to understand". And if you're bright enough to be
working for that piece of Ford, have and be able to use Internet access,
and find this list, figuring out the EFI should be *NO* big trick, you just
need to spend the time on it.

If you persist with this lunacy, Webers are a *slightly* better choice than
Dellortos for one (and only one) reason: you can get Weber jets *anywhere*
because it's the default carb of the SCCA. And you'll need them, because I
can gurantee that you'll have to change all of them, as the unit will NOT
be jetted correctly for your application.

Near as I can tell, CB Performance in SoCal is the only real source of
parts for Dellortos. I have *NO* idea why the VW world decided that they
were a better choice than Webers, but as I say all the time, just because
you see it in a magazine doesn't mean jack shit about how well it really
works.

> 3.  Does anyone have some used carburetors for sale?

Sure. Lots of people in CA, NJ, NY, and parts of TX where they're making you
go back to the original EFI to pass the emissions inspection. You *DO* want
to be able to drive the car in a couple of years, right? Then save that 
old nasty EFI you take off -- you'll eventually need it again.

Stan

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 11:20:11 -0400
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: '81 911SC Won't Start

Steve,

I seriously doubt you have burned any gizmos, (or razanfrats or flavens
either).

When the key is in the "run" position you are supplying 12 volts to the
heating elements in both the auxiliary air regulator and the control pressure
regulator taking them from "start engine mode" to "normal operation" mode.
 The lower control pressure provided in "start engine mode" provides a
slightly richer mixture in the FI which is needed to start a cold engine even
on a relatively warm day.

Letting the car sit for a while (with the key off) should solve the problem
by returning the heating elements to ambiant air temperature.  Then you can
start over.

You might also try slight "priming"  of the engine.  This is accomplished by
removing the air filter housing, turning the key to the "run" position, then
lifting the sensor plate arm (seen in the back of the right side of the
airbox slightly hanging down from the top) until you hear a screeching sound.
 This sound is the injectors opening and will provide a little extra fuel for
the cold start.  If the arm offers no resistance to up-pushing and you don't
hear the injectors opening, you may have a fuel pump relay or fuel pump
sensor plate contact problem.

My guess would be that after sitting for an appropriate length of time, your
car will start fine.

Regards

Pat Moyle (pm9146@aol.com)

Dear Scot:
I had a 74 2.0 that I converted to dual Webbers, with the following 
results:

1) Better acceleration.
2) Much more noice from the engine compartment.
3) Worse gas mileage.
4) Harder starting.
5) Dirtier engine compartment.

So I went back to FI.

Mitch Feig 
1976 911S

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 13:48:48 -0500
From: Mark A Skala <skala@ecn.purdue.edu>

>From: ktl103@psu.edu (Adam Newlin)
>
>Hi Porschephiles,
>
>I just acquired what I hope to be the first in a long line of Porsches....
>a '72 914/4 which had alterations made to make it look like a 916.
>
>I really like it except for the fact that as I took it out for a drive
>after work I noticed the following problems.....
>
>1. The front left driving light(the orange light mounted on fender) doesn't
>light I'm not sure if the bulb is out or not.
>
>2. The previous intermediary owner said I should get more/stronger bolts
>for the passengers seat what size is supposed to be used?

This doesn't make sense, the bolts are 10mm and they can only go in the
2 hinges behind the seat on the floor.

>3. When I turn the key the first notch a red light to the left on the
>farthest left gauge turns on and the car makes a clicking noise which comes
>from behind (the engine, I think).

The light is the generator light which is normal when the engine is
not turning, hence there is no charging.  The fuel pump which would be
behind you on a '72, goes on for a few seconds when you turn the key,
however you say later that this is a carb conversion, so this should not
apply.

>4. The rear window rattles
>
>5. The front window is just epoxyed in it looks like. I think there is
>supposed to be weatherstripping, but there isn't. Is it supposed to be like
>this because I think it would be a perfect spot for the formation of RUST!.

The windshield should have a black butyl seal going all the way around, and
aluminum trim pieces.

>6. The flashers and turn signals don't work( no clicking to or anything).
>The horn doesn't work.

Check fuses first.  You may have either 1 or two horns in the front
bumper, and they do go bad, so check them.

>7. It stalls unless you are actively accellerating.

I don't know about this if it is carb'ed.

>8. I can't figure out gearing (No label showing 1,2,3,reverse. When I first
>started it I almost backed over my friend.)

R 2 4

1 3 5     is the pattern.

>9. One fuse is missing, so I'm interested in what fuse sockets affect what
>and what color and amp the fuses are supposed to be.

Don't know amps offhand, but the fuses are:
1-high beam, left
2-high beam, right
3-low beam, left
4-low beam, right
5-parking light, left
6-parking light, right
7-license plate light
8-fresh air fan, horn, wipers, cigarette lighter
9-brake lights, turn signals, reverse lights
10-fog lights
11-interior light, seatbelt light and buzzer
12-headlight motors

>10. The seats both have rips in the seams.

Get new or used ones from swap meet.  Join porsche club to know when and
where swap meets are and for companies selling new and used parts.

>Thanks, 
>Adam [a 16yr old who is now hooken on Porsches(With only a few ?'s)
>
>'72 914
>'73 VW Thing

Mark Skala          '73 914
mvmas@mvujc.att.com '88 924S

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 15:38:20 -0400
From: NEIL13@aol.com
Subject: 993 Questions

Fellow P-philes,

Not the best weather this weekend here in Florida fo cruising (<----
Hurricane Allison), and I thought I pick the collective brain of our group.

I recently replaced the rear tires on my 993(I got almost 11K out of them).
 The Dunlop SP-8000 are super tires; I especially appreciate their
performance in the wet.  Unfortunately, the Porsche-spec version of this tire
is in very short supply (the 255/40ZR-17 size) and my set took several months
to get here from Germany.  Dunlop customer service was very helpful, however:
ask for "Jim" at 1800.847.3382. Since I got the tires I sense a little more
vibration at "high speeds" (we're talking significantly more than 65MPH).
 Obviously the tires were balanced after being mounted, but how critical is
balancing in here?  Will just a small amount of imbalance lead to significant
vibration? Any thoughts?

Next topic: the 993 headlights are the BEST OEM lights I've ever used.
 They're nice and bright with an excellent "Z-beam" like pattern (the new 911
Turbo's lights are supposed to be even better, utilizing new "ion discharge"
technology!).  My owner's manual gives clear instructions on replacing the
individual elements in the headlight but doesn't identify the specific bulb.
Are these run of the mill bulbs? 9004-9006, and if they are, could they be
upgraded to the higher wattage bulbs now on the market (for "off road usage"
only, of course)?

Thanks in advance for your help

Neil Halvey

1995 993 white coupe

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 12:57:28 -0700 (PDT)
From: JAH@SLC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject: Re: My New 914

>Hi Porschephiles,
>
>I just acquired what I hope to be the first in a long line of Porsches....
>a '72 914/4 which had alterations made to make it look like a 916.

Congradulations! The 914 is an fun car, that just gets more enjoyable the
longer you drive it! :)  Before you try and tackle anything dificult, get a
repair manual. Haynes makes a book for the 914 that get you through almost
anything you're likely to encounter.

>I really like it except for the fact that as I took it out for a drive
>after work I noticed the following problems.....
>
>1. The front left driving light(the orange light mounted on fender)
>doesn't light I'm not sure if the bulb is out or not.

Probably a bulb, the're cheap enough to replace.

>2. The previous intermediary owner said I should get more/stronger bolts
>for the passengers seat what size is supposed to be used?

Did they say why? This sounds kinda fishy to me. Pull up the carpets and
look for rust. Either that, or it really is missing a bolt or two.

>3. When I turn the key the first notch a red light to the left on the
>farthest left gauge turns on and the car makes a clicking noise which comes
>from behind (the engine, I think).

The red light is the generator light which is telling you that the Key is "
on" but there's no voltage coming from the generator. This is bad if the
engine is running, but normal if it isn't. If the engine were running, it
would most likely mean that the belt broke. The "clicking noise" is
probably your fuel pump. It's loud and makes a whiring sound when you first
turn the key to the "on" possition.

>4. The rear window rattles

It's loose, mine rattles to. I'm going to try and fix it sometime in the
future, but not right now.

>5. The front window is just epoxyed in it looks like. I think there is
>supposed to be weatherstripping, but there isn't. Is it supposed to be like
>this because I think it would be a perfect spot for the formation of RUST!.

Hmm, I can't say more without a better description. Is this aparent from
the inside or outside?

>6. The flashers and turn signals don't work( no clicking to or anything).
>The horn doesn't work.

Check your fuses. One may be missing or burnt out.

>7. It stalls unless you are actively accellerating.

I can't help you much with a carb'ed engine, but I'd say you're probably
running lean. The stock 914 FI is really simple and quite effective, it's a
shame when people carb the engine in the belief that they can get more
power. Maybe at the top end a little, but not without loosing drivablity. 

>8. I can't figure out gearing (No label showing 1,2,3,reverse. When I first
>started it I almost backed over my friend.)

	R 2 4
	|_|_|
	| | |
	1 3 5   

>9. One fuse is missing, so I'm interested in what fuse sockets affect what
>and what color and amp the fuses are supposed to be.

Could be your horn/flasher fuse. There -should- be a plastic cover over the
fuses that say which is which, but the owners manual should also have it.

>10. The seats both have rips in the seams.

Those seats are over 23 years old. You should be happy that they han't
collapsed. There are some things that just come with the package when you
get an old sports car. But there are probably some good upholstory shops
near you that can do a good job. Personally, I'd just get some seat covers
and put the money into tires or maintenance.

>P.P.S What is the proper way to say Porsche? I say Por-sha but my friends
>say Porsh.

You've got it! Two sylables.


 -Josh

Joshua Hadler				'74 914 2.0L CSP

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 17:16:09 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : why want 71-73.5 911's

Charlo Barbosa asked :

>Can someone tell me why people want these older Porsches
> so badly these days? 

some reasons :

1) Light weight : my '72 S weighs 2330 pounds. It has 190
horsepower. Any questions?
When I carry 4 spare tires/rims, tools, jack, etc, it still
weighs less than an SC, but feels sluggish, and brakes
very weak (no power brakes!).

2) Simple to repair : My '72S has no power anything. It will
drive fine with no batteries except for the ignition.

3) easy to upgrade to later model stuff without destroying
the good points (although this hurts the value of an S, E,
or clean T).

4) rare - most have rusted away, and only a few thousand
of each year and model were made anyway.

5) performance in autocross and track : go to one
and find out. Though not faster on a high speed track,
they are more fun to drive than the later models.
A 2.4 (especially S or E) should be able to beat an SC
and most 3.2 Carreras in an autocross.

> What does CIS and MFI mean?  

CIS was introduced on the 73.5 911T as a cheaper alternative
to the MFI, as carbs would not meet pollution specs and MFI
was too expensive. CIS is a constant (non timed) injection
system which is also used on VWs, Audis, MB, and other
cars. It was used on all USA 911's from '74 to '83.
It is considered somewhat mechanical, as there are
no electronic injection pulses. CIS needs mild cams for air flow
monitoring. But it was good enough to use on the 930
turbos (and even the 934?).

MFI is a purely mechanical injection 
with a cam-belt driven pump with pistions forcing fuel at VERY HIGH
pressures to the injectors at exactly the right time. MFI can be
found on all 911E and S from '69 to '73 and the '72 - 73.5 911T.
It was also used on many early 911 engined race cars, and 
up to at least some 935 turbos (although the race version 
was often simpler without warm-up or cold start stuff).

Regards, Mike Piera '72S and '73E (not sold) MFI Targas, '73 914/2.0

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 17:42:21 -0400 (EDT)
From: Tomkow <tomkow@nando.net>
Subject: Alternator Problems (AGAIN!)


Hi All,

In Feb of 94, about three weeks after I brought my 84 911 Carrera home, 
the alternator died.  Put off by the local dealer's price I bought a 
reman unit from an outfit in Miami that advertises in Excellence.  Car 
ran great, until last week.

After a two and a half hour drive in the dark hours of the morning, the 
alternator again gave up the ghost.  Same symptoms: no battery light with 
the engine off and the key in the on position.  A burnt diode I'm told.

I did not have time for any problems on that day.  So my twisted little 
mind worked out a plan to get me through it.  I called my wife to bring 
out my truck.  Yes, she drove the same 2.5 hours as I did and took the 
day off to help me as well!  What we did was swap the batteries every 
hour and she accompanied me to every stop that day.  We drove about 400 
miles doing this and by the time we reached home again that evening the 
correct battery was in each vehicle.  The day was saved.

The next AM I wanted to check a few things regarding this problem, turned 
the key to the on position, and the damn light was back on!  I have never 
heard of a self-repairing alternator so I was reluctant to believe that I 
was out of the woods.  I have since driven the car for a week with no 
other problems.  I'm stumped.

Could there have been a loose wire or corrosion that I may temporarily 
have remedied while swapping the batteries multiple times?  Could high 
temps in the engine compartment have caused an intermittent problem with 
the alternator?  In my experience, diodes are like light bulbs, when they 
blow, they're gone. (Obviously not a burnt diode; at least the first time, 
last week.)

And worst of all, did I possibly spend money on an alternator that I didn't 
need last year?!  All suggestions/replies appreciated.  BTW, the priest 
won't consider exorcism until I rule out all of the normal possibilities.

Thanks in advance for the help!

   -Bill Tomko
    1984 911 Carrera

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 18:51:03 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: 66 912 fume problem solved!!!!

>I now have to figure out where I should put the crankcase breather hose.  I
>assume it use to go into the right carb air cleaner - but my K&N aircleaners
>won't allow that (I wouldn't want to do that anyway).

Scott, just cut a circle from a couple of layers of cotton cloth and cover
the end of the hose (a rubber band works fine to hold it in place).  This
will filter any oil from the crankcase fumes.  Change it as it gets dirty.
 Not an elegant solution, but it works fine on a daily driver.

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 16:35:09 -0700 (PDT)
From: James Wood <jamesw@PEAK.ORG>
Subject: Re: 944 performance: thanks



Thanks to all who replied in regards to my quest for improved 944 
performance.  Also, thanks to those who suggested the FAQ.  I was hoping 
that the FAQ would deal more with some of the cat-back exhaust systems, 
and perhaps camshaft selection - although I fear cam swaps/lifters are 
prohibitively expensive.

It is somewhat disappointing to learn that the standard 944 performance 
is all that can be expected from the car.  I've never owned a Porsche 
before this, and the only reason I ended up with this car is I was 
fortunate to find a low-mileage car at an ABSOLUTE STEAL.

Some of the suggestions I've received range from "enjoy the car the way 
it is" to "unbolt the steering wheel, enter a 944 Turbo, bolt the 
steering wheel back on the new car."  Heh heh heh.   In actuality, it 
would seem that those are the only options  if I am to drive a Porsche.

I will say that I am very surprised with the performance dilemma 
surrounding the Porsche 944.  As I knew almost NOTHING about Porsche 
prior to purchasing this car (and I still know almost nothing), I just 
knew that Porsche has had a reputation for wringing out enormous 
quantities of horsepower from comparatively small cubic centimeters.  I 
drove the 944 and found it to be a fairly spirited little car, but no 
drag race contender by any stretch of the imagination.  I bought the car 
because it was dirt cheap, and because I figured that with the Porsche 
stigma for high performance, I could tweak a few more horses out of the 
car without too much effort.  How wrong I was in the latter assumption, eh?

I cannot stress how surprising it is to me that hot-rod parts and 
practice are so rare.  The last "high performance" car I had was an '86 
Corvette (another good deal) that I was able to tweak into a formidable 
tread-burner with reasonably few dollars.  I figured that in regards to 
automobiles, the Germans usually do things better than the Yankees.
Do they really?

The Corvette, as much fun as I had with the car, was certainly NOT
an automotive paragon in terms of quality (IMO) - at least not the
1986 model I had.  Some parts weren't necessaryily cheap, either, but I was
able to do everything (inc. engine replacement) myself, and the Chev. 350 
parts were DIRT CHEAP.  I had LOTS of little things going wrong with that
car, which irritated the hell out of me and drove me to clean it up and 
sell it.  As I understand it, the newer ones (I hope) are better; the 
80's SUCKED in terms of quality coming from Detroit and I'll never own 
80's Detroit iron again.

What about my 944's quality?

According to the FAQ, the list price of the windshield is $2000!!!  What???

The timing belt potential for problems is not good news.

The motor mount problems are a problem I DO HAVE.  Good news to hear it's 
just a motor mount causing the vibrations I was having.  Lame that it 
will cost $110 each and I don't know how many I will need.

I haven't had any water pump problems yet, but what?  How many years have 
cars had water pumps, and there are still problems?   If I interpret the 
FAQ, the thermostat is a difficult item to change?  What???

The oil cooler seal (allowing antifreeze/oil mix) sounds like a real 
headache.  I haven't noticed anything wrong, but I guess I have no way of 
knowing if my seal has been replaced.

Ball joints not removable from suspension arms.   WHAT???  WHY!!!!


Good lord!  This makes my 944 sound as bad as something slapped together 
by a drunk UAW team on a Friday.  I suppose my expectations were that 
Porsche reputation for quality was up there with other fine German auto 
makers like BMW and Mercedes-Benz.  I find it difficult to believe after 
all the problems with the 944.

Nevertheless, I do like the car, although not as much as the 911 series.  
There is no doubt in my mind that a fine late-model 911 is waaaaay 
outside my budget.  However, a 944 Turbo may not be too far away - but I 
have never seen one for sale and don't know what I can get for my 39K 
mile '88 944.  Any suggestions?

A friend of mine picked up a used low-mile '93 Camaro (275HP/325 lb-ft) 
for a mere $13K, and put a Paxton supercharger kit ($3500) and some 
aftermarket headers.  Hell, the thing probably outhandles my 944, and 
with roughly 400HP/400 lb-ft on tap, offers performance probably close to 
a new 911 Turbo. (WHICH IS MY DREAM CAR, INCIDENTALLY).

Of course, I don't expect a 4-banger to run like that, but I suppose I'm 
surprised that if a "cheapie" American car like that can receive such a 
boost from bolt-ons, why can't a "fine quality" German car like my 944 
receive similar treatment?  Sure, I can bolt my steering wheel on a 944 
Turbo, and the Camaro owner could have bolted his steering wheel on a 
Corvette ZR-1, but he didn't have to - for a mere $3500+, he can make 
mince meat out of a Corvette ZR-1.

Here's to hoping that Paxton makes a 944 kit!  Heh heh heh.

James Wood
1988 944

Porschephiles #1453                         Mon Jun 5 02:00:11 CDT 1995

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 19:08:52 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Weber vs Solex Carbs in 912's

> I've got a pair each of Weber and Solex Carbs for my 912.  The webers are
> currently installed, but I'd like to hear about the pros and cons of each
> carb type. Both sets of carbs are in good shape.  What can I expect in terms
> of performance diff., mpg, idle drivability, etc...(I've repeated this mail
> because I don't think I got on the list before!)  

I've got to just write this up and leave it laying around somewhere so I
can just forward it to the list every time this comes up...

Solexs have *SIGNFICANTLY* larger main venturis than Weber 40, so they make
a lot more top end power. Weber 40s have higher air velocity at the intake valve
due to the smaller venturis so produce more power in the lower R's, but that
falls off rapidly over 4000 RPM. Weber 44s don't have the right metering
circuits for giving reasonable performance at lower R's (read: can't use on
the street), but work as well as Solexs in the high R's.

Solexes can be "worn out" -- the main bore is not round and the butterfly
doesn't fit, the throttle shafts "wobble" in their holes, etc. This is due
to old age (many are more than 30 years old), and can be fixed *TRIVIALLY*
by places like Eurometrix, NLA, Stoddard, etc for under $200 a carb.

Webers are most likely to be newer and for a variety of reasons, like they
have ball bearings on the shafts instead of bushings, don't wear out as
much. Webers are highly configurable and it is a very exacting art  to get
a pair of Webers set up just right for your engine, mean air density, and
operating characteristics. Can't be done without a dyno, can't be done without
a whole shitpile of spare parts. There is no "tuning guide" for the Webers
for your car, but you can assemble your own from other people's anecdotal
evidence and one of the several pretty good books on Webers. 

The Solexs on the other hand were *MADE* for this car, and the tuning
guide in the factory service manual is both exact and accurate. Even with
sophisticated tuning equipment, Peter Albrecht didn't find much room
for improvement in some testing he did this winter.

I have  Webers on my 356 right now, but that's because I needed something
"right then" when I was done with the engine and I had all this Weber
crap laying around from the various E Production engines so it was easy
to do. I have lived with the backfiring, the weak acceleration, the mis-jetting,
and all that for the last 18 months but haven't liked it. The Solexes that 
are supposed to be on the car are in the process of being rebuilt, and as 
soon as they come in, I'll change. I should have done so earlier, but had
other priorities like suspension parts gone bad, brake parts gone missing,
and the ever present electrical gremlins... Just got around to addressing
the carbs late last month, in fact. 

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 19:17:13 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 911T - Zenith vs. Weber Carbs

> Plus they are 
> becoming rarer than hen's teeth, and I should at least grab a 
> set and leave them on the shelf until I can either afford to 
> rebuild them or the Zeniths give their last puff.

Someone has either been smoking something, or is trying really, really
hard to sell you what they have in their garage...

> 1. How much HP are the Webers likely to add?

Zero. Well, not really, but damn near. If I recall correctly, the venturis
are slightly larger, so there will be additional airflow at high RPM, but
you gotta wind it on up there to "find" that power... Around town, you
won't notice the difference.

> 2. Are they really becoming so rare?

Weber is discontinuing production of NEW carbs. PMO is gearing up to produce
Weber knock-offs, at close to the original prices. There are still a few
thousand sets of 40 IDAs out there, though. So "rare" is *NOT* an appropriate
adjective. Finding a set for sale may be problematic, but as increasingly
larger numbers of states adopt CA emissions standards, people that have put
them on cars with CIS will have to re-fit CIS, so there should be a steady
supply...

> 3. How much should I be prepared to spend on them?

A set of new 40 IDAs from PMO under their Zenith Conversion option is
what? Just under a grand?? It's in that neighborhood, anyway. And that's
new carbs.

> 4. How much for a rebuild and where? (I understand this is a 
> specialized art)

A "casual" rebuild can be done by any competent shop, figure on a few
hundred per carb. A "complete" rebuild will be someone like Eurometrix
and I have *NO* idea how much they're likely to charge.

> 5. And finally, is there a market for my functioning Zeniths? 

Yeah, to people who wish they hadn't bought Webers.... This is one of those
deals where it's a tough call -- it's not like replacing the Zeniths
will hurt the value of the car that much, but I'd certainly keep them 
intact and with the car just in case it becomes important to someone 
at some time down the road. Originality is starting to become important
for these older cars, so screwing it up is not a good idea unless it's
reversible...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 19:25:09 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: The 911SC

> My search is still continuing.  I am hoping that someone can set me 
> straight about the various differences between the different years.  I 
> was orignally told, all things being pretty much equal, buy the latest 
> one you can afford i.e. a 1983 would be better than a 1978.  However, 
> over the weekend I was test driving a 1981 (not in that great of 
> shape,BTW), when the owner, who seemed to be fairly knowledgable about 
> Porsches, said that the 1978 and 1979 were supposedly better.  Can anyone 
> set me straight???

Porsches are great -- "Better" is completely in the eye of the beholder.
Or sometimes the seller, as it were.

The '78 and '79 models had larger intake valves and air pipes and plenums,
so they would flow more air. The later models had smaller valves and pipes
for the simple reason that at the lower operating speeds in the US, the
performance is *MUCH* better with the smaller valves as it increases
mean air velocity across the valve, pushing up power. Of course, there
is *SOME* restriction that shows up at higher RPM, but I have not been
able to find it with "street engines" using CIS at speeds up to 7000 RPM.
I will grant that with modified cams and valve timing, and programmable EFI 
instead of CIS, that the bigger valves are better for racing applications 
where you spend a lot of time north of 6000 RPM.

Me? I'd go for a later engine. In fact, I'd consider *SERIOUSLY* a '84-86 
Carrera instead. It makes more power, it already had the tensioner update,
and most importantly, it's not CIS. Don't get me wrong, CIS is *GREAT* when
it works right, but all this stuff is getting to be 15-20 years old and
hasn't always been taken good care of. You can spend a ton of money replacing
the fuel distributor, the control pressure regulator and the injectors
before you get the car running right. The DME systems in the Carreras are
a lot more "binary" -- they either work right, or thye don't work. And
when they don't work, it's a lot easier and cheaper to fix. 

Stan

------------------------------

Date: 04 Jun 95 20:37:20 EDT

Date: 04 Jun 95 20:54:13 EDT
From: "Eric S. Shea" <73633.1772@compuserve.com>
Subject: Porsche Rubbers

Hi Gang:

I thought that'd get your attention...

I need to find a complete rubber weather stripping kit for my 71T.  It's
currently being repainted  and I would like to re-due all of the major rubber
and molding.

rubber and weather stripping.  I had to buy twice to get the real thing.  Can
you help me avoid this problem again?  I'm looking for a quality supplier for
weather stripping and rubber.

Also... I would like to get a lens kit (front and rear) who's got the best

Thanks for your help.

Eric Shea

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 22:33:43 -0400
From: "Paul F. Lyman" <lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov>
Subject: Subject: Hot rod 944


Jim,

  I enjoyed your honest musings upon becoming an "accidental" 
Porsche owner.  I hope you come to enjoy it as much as me and 
some of my colleagues here like ours.  If not, you could probably
sell it to one of us for a modest return, if you really got
a deal!

   I'll leave most of the "defense" of 944's to others with 
more 944 experience, but I have to comment on two things.  
Why do you believe that the ability to improve the output 
of an engine by simple "tweaking" is a characteristic of 
a well-engineered car?  Would good engineering not already 
make use of more of the potential of an engine configuration?
Note, however, that the charms of a big, torquey, easy-to-
maintain 'Murrikan V8 are not lost on me!  I simply prefer
light slot-cars.

   As to the specific output, your "bottom of the line" 944 
has what, 158 hp/2.5l = 63.2 hp/l?  Your buddy's Camaro has 
(normally aspirated) 275 hp/5.7 l, or 48.2 hp/l, and even blown 
has only ~70 hp/l.  Hell, a 944S makes 75.2 hp/l!  So, yes, I 
think that your perception that the Schwabians are able to
wring more hps/cc than most folk is correct.  And there is no
way (IMHO) that the Camaro will "outhandle" your 944. 

Paul Lyman     lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov
'82 911SC Targa       (US spec: 60 hp/l)

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 23:39:54 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Lawrence D. Bershtein" <lbershte@nova.umuc.edu>
Subject: non-standard Motronic box

911.618.111.20 = standard US spec box for '87 - '89 Carrera. Some used 4K 
PROM (24 pins) some 8K (28 pins)

911.618.111.16 = don't remember this number exactly, but is sounds like a 
4K Euro box, probably '86 or '87.

Easiest way I can think of to check out whether or not you have a stock 
chip, whether US or Euro, is to see where the rev limiter kicks in. 
Should be about 6200 to 6300 for a standard chip (Euro or US) 6800 for 
factory sport chip and 7K or over for most aftermarket chips.

Also, there was really no great advantage to the Euro chip in these cars 
anyway. Fuel was similar and timing was same or sometimes less due to 
higher compression ratio of the Euro engines.

Larry Bershtein

 I have worked on cars since I was 12 years old, (25 years) and until I
bought a 1970 911T three years ago, I thought I was pretty good at working on
cars (I've even rebuilt an engine in a 1960 Renault Caravelle -- and y'all
are probably the only people online car-obsessed enough to even know what
that is) but my Porsche has me completely depressed and defeated. Every time
I try to do something on it, it turns out badly and I wind up having to have
it towed to a mechanic...my most recent nightmare happened when I thought I
would install new points, plugs, rotor and cap: I got it all in
and......Nothing! The car just won't start. I have had other misadventures,
as well (including destroying the pressure plate trying to get the $%^&*
engine separated from the &%^$&@#* transmission). 
So...the question becomes, can an experienced amateur ever hope to work on
these cars, or am I only fit to be a detail dweeb, endlessly scrubbing my
Fuchs with a little toothbrush and fretting about my rocker panel trim (and
signing over every other paycheck for the priviledge of taking abuse from
some guy who used to be Rommel's tank mechanic?)
Any help you might offer, I'd be very grateful. Or should I just sell the
*^&$# thing (First $6,000 takes it once I get it running again. No rust, 140K
miles, totally rebuilt at 80K  after chain tensioner failure.)

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 22:55:36 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 911SC

> how hard is it to work on CIS. I live in San
> Francisco and there are no shortage of good mechanics to be found and the
> price difference between a 78-83 and 84-up is pretty dramatic. Ideas????

Don't get me wrong -- it's not that hard (well, it obviously is for some
shops, but that's another story) but it can be *EXPENSIVE*. If you need to
change all the parts until it starts working right, that can be another
$2k. *PLAN* on changing the injectors as no one has likely done that until
now, and you *MAY* need to change the fuel distributor. At some point, you
will need to change the control pressure regulator, and if you do that
you may be *FORCED* to change the fuel distributor to remain compatible with
all the supercession parts in the series... So you're "cheaper" SC might
not be such a bargain in the long run. 

This is just something that I've started seeing in the last two years as
this stuff starts to age. I personally like CIS injection a lot, and
spent a fair amount of time learning how to make it jump through hoops
and let you pump up the power on a CIS engine. But you gotta be prepared
to spend the bucks if you want to keep it. DME on the other hand seems not
to have electronics failures for the most part, just injector and sensor
failures (which also show up in CIS) making it significantly cheaper to
maintain.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 00:25:24 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 headlight adjusting specs

>The headlights on my '89 951 are not shining at the same level.  Does anyone

>have a procedure for properly adjusting them to the correct levels?  Haynes 
>refers to using an optical alignment tool that I obviously dont have (except
for 
>garage wall).

You can spend big bucks for the "optical alignment tool", Tracey, or you can
take the car out on a straight, dark street and adjust the headlights by eye
(cover one while you do the other).  The latter will give you fool-proof
results if you do it carefully.

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 00:25:27 -0400

>A friend of mine picked up a used low-mile '93 Camaro (275HP/325 lb-ft) 
>for a mere $13K, and put a Paxton supercharger kit ($3500) and some 
>aftermarket headers.  Hell, the thing probably outhandles my 944, and 
>with roughly 400HP/400 lb-ft on tap, offers performance probably close to 
>a new 911 Turbo. (WHICH IS MY DREAM CAR, INCIDENTALLY).

James, your statement about the Camaro outhandling your 944 brings to mind
scenes of IMSA Camaros chasing 935s (admittedly not 944s) up the hill in Turn
1 at Road Atlanta, skittering wildly in the drifts as those solid rear ends
tried to match the firmly-planted independent rear suspensions of the
Porsches.  Bill Elliott, a NASCAR and Ford pilot of some renound, was
overheard saying, after a few laps in the Porsche, "Now THESE things HANDLE!"
 And THAT about a Porsche that's not noted for its forgiving demeanor.  Such
refinement is what you'll find in your 944.

Welcome to the fold.  Join the PCA and stay awhile.

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 4 Jun 1995 23:52:39 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Valvoline's new blended oil

> Has anyone tried (or researched..) Valvoline's new half-petroleum,
> half-synthetic blended oil????

Nope, not being a half-measures kind of guy... However in the two-wheel
world, there's this product called "Golden Spectro" that's a hybrid blend
that's supposed to be just the thing. Partly due to the problems that those
wet clutches have with having synthgoo sloshing around them, I think.

Since my ride is a Beemer, and I don't have the wet clutch problem, I went
straight to the real synthetics a long time ago.

I'm also using the Valvoline synthetic in my 356, so far to good effect.
It did exacerbate a problem I had with accuracy on my oil temp guage which
was finally fixed by some re-wiring, and it does seem to slip past the rear
main seal a bit, but it's fine otherwise. Change it every 2k miles, just
like clockwork....

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 01:45:03 -0400
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: POC Tribute to LeMans - Report

Just returned from beautiful Willow Springs, where I had the good fortune
meet, not one, but 2 Pfilers, in person! It's great to be able to put a face
with the messages posted by Wade Guthrie and Thomas Kuby!

Unofficially, Saturday nights's 3 hour, Tribute to LeMans, enduro, was won by
Mark Mehalic. I worked as a member of a pit crew for a 944 that finished 16th
overall/2nd in class (starting field was about 40) cars. 

It's an impressive sight, and sound, when 40 Porsches get the green flag and
head off into the night on a extremely fast track like Willow Springs.

After 3 hours, 3 cars were on the lead lap (R. Raimist's 3.8L RSR leading,
Mark Mehalic's 911 2nd, and B. Auberlein's pole sitting 911 3rd), with the
1st/2nd place cars only seconds apart. Raimist's RSR slowed, running out of
fuel less than 1/2 lap from the finish, allowing Mehalic to win! Raimist's
car coasted across the finish line in 2nd place (we later learned that the
driver for this leg of the race was unaware of the RESERVE switch!).

23 cars finished the race, with the leaders completing 108 laps.

I you have a chance to enter or attend this event in the future, I highly
recommend it.  We'll have a more complete run down on the event in PML this
month.

Phil Van Buskirk,  PMLetter@aol.com

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 00:37:35 -0700
From: Harry Pellow <maestro@well.com>
Subject: Webers or  Solexes for a 912?

to: CKRAUSE13@aol.com
from: maestro@well.com
Subject: Webers or Solexes on 912's?

Ah, yes, which carbs to use? Solexes or Webers? Yes, it's True-
the Maestro admits it! He likes Weber Carburetors. He ALSO likes good 
Solex and Zenith Carburetors!
    (Note that the operative word in the above sentence is "good".)
When Solexes and Zeniths are Good, they're great. And when Solexes and
Zeniths aren't good, they can be Very, Very Bad! 
But Solexes and Zeniths are Original! So, ifin you REALLY want to
Win the Concours, it helps to be Original. 
(Fortunately, the Maestro has a Solution for bad Zeniths or Solexes-
a MaestroMaster Carburetor Rebuild! Which magically makes good-running 
Solexes and Zeniths out of what had been Very, Very bad running Solexes 
and Zeniths.)
    However, ifin you're NOT climbing the concours ladder and just want to 
DRIVE the car. And say, you're living in an Area of the Country
"blessed" with oxygenated gasoline that comes and goes with the seasons,
you'll
find that changing the Main Jets or the Air Correction Jets makes your
356 run better.
 And ifin you've ever changed a Main Jet in a Solex or a
Zenith, you'll note that the entire contents of the Float Bowl gushes
out like a Mississippi flood- all over what used to be your Concours
Sheet Metal and onto your Spark Plug Wires, on its way to your hot
exhaust pipe.
 Nowadays with the Tertiary Butyl Ether oxygenated gasolines have,
a float bowl full of today's gas might put you to sleep before the 
fire starts. 
However, ifin you happen to have a set of Weber Carburetors, you 
can change the Main Jet (and air correction and Emulsion Tube) in less 
that 30 seconds per hole! With a dime. Or a screwdriver ifin you're 
broke and out of dimes. And NO gas leaks anywhere!
Try THAT on your Zenith or Solex! In less than 10 fun-filled,
gasoline-drenched minutes per carburetor.
Webers are meant to be adjusted, played with, raced with, have fun with,
so the adjustments are made with some forethought. 
Buy, hey, IT'S YOUR MONEY! Ifin you want a Concours set of
Solexes or Zeniths, no Problem. Or ifin you want Weber Carbs- 
either the 40 or 44IDF's, again, it's your money. 
     Anyhow, like everything else, Webers have gone through several 
evolutionary versions- mostly with the intent of improving the breed. 
Years ago Webers had a lousy 2-position accelerator pump (the fulcrum pin
for the accelerator pump lever had two positions- giving you a choice of
too much or WAY too much gas, or Too much and Not Enough.)
All Zeniths and Solexes had infinitely adjustable
accelerator pumps- so one could screw them up in infinite number of ways.
Weber soon saw the advantage of this and some 10 years ago
added infinitely adjustable accelerator pumps, as the current model
Webers currently have. (Check your Webers to see which you have.)
About 5 years ago, the Weber Jet Stacks sprouted a 1"
extension so they stood above the top of the carb. This made removal
of the jet stack a lot easier than when they were flush with the carb top. 
(Year ago, with flush-mounted brass jet carriers, unscrewing them was a
cinch, but getting the bastards out of the hole was a real pain. And no,
a magnet won't work-'cause the jets and carrier are brass!)
They fixed that with the 1" extension. Now, the only thing the Maestro
doesn't like about Webers today is that the importer INSISTS on supplying 
Linkage Arms that wedge at half to 2/3 throttle. After telling the importer
repeatedly about the wedging linkage arms and being told repeatedly by the
Importer that "Nobody else ever had this problem before",
the Maestro gave up and made up linkage arms that Go All The Way
Down! Giving you Full Throttle, 'cause you deserve it.
 Now, if you want a mild to warm street engine,
the 40IDF Webers are best for a mild engine, the 44's for a
"Hot" street engine. The 40IDF Webers should be used with Solex
Intake Manifolds and the 44's should be used with the "Weber"
intake Manifold and the necessary surgery performed on the
Side Vertical Sheet Metal. (The Weber Manifold sits lower than
the Solex Manifold, and the inside of the Weber 44IDF will hit
two of the three bolts that hold the Spring Plate for the Top 
Linkage Cross Bar. You must remove the washers from under those
two bolts and/or grind the bolt heads down a bit.)
Currently, there are several Weber
kits of varying degrees of quality. Or lack thereof. There's
a 20+ page section in "Murphy is my Copilot" describing the
detail difference and difficulty (or ease) of installation.
Since I install many Weber kits a year, I like the kits I use
to be as trouble free as possible. This was learned The Hard
Way by installing most every kit available!) 
 The current batch of 40/44IDF Weber kits, are the
Latest Model Weber having the Infinitely Adjustable
Accelerator pump and the 1" extension on the jet stack that
make jet changing a joy, the Large K&N Air Filters, linkage
that WORKS and the Weber manifold. Check your set to see what you have.
Any questions? Give me a call at (408) 727-1864. And:
KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!!!
The Maestro

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 13:30:06 +0200
From: Hans-Petter Lien <lien@hoggar.ethz.ch>

Subject: 944 DME and strange noises 

Hi there -
- ----------
As the proud newPorschephiles #1454                         Mon Jun 5 10:28:05 CDT 1995
 owner of a clean '87 944 S, I've of course got a few 
questions for the knowledgeable fellows I know are out there - my apologies 
if they've been covered after january '95! In that case, I'll find them in 
the files some day.... I bought the car with 67578 km, which is exactly 
42 k miles (and had both belts changed immediately thanks to this very list). 

1) On lesser cars, you can often just release the clutch without any extra 
throttle for initial acceleration. This works on my 944 S _when the engine 
is cold_, but any later starts without extra throttle, such as at traffic 
lights etc., mostly kill the engine. Seems that the engine requires some
1100 rpm before releasing the clutch to avoid trouble when hot. Has this 
anything to do with the idle regulator? Have already fixed the too low 
contact resistance due to an oil film or similar - as I learned from previous 
postings. That cured the slightly high idle, for some time at least. Now, the 
slightly high idle seems to have returned, _except when cold_. Think I've 
read somewhere that the L-Jetronic has a coolant temperature sensor - could 
a defective device cause an additional 200 rpm at idle?? Anyway, applying 
throttle before/when releasing the clutch only when the engine is hot seems 
weird to a newcomer like me. (Yes, this is my 1st car!) 

2) DME functions: Previous postings, for instance Stan's in july 94, indicate 
that the DME is adaptive. Exactly what is being adapted, and on what kind 
of information/sensors is this adaptiveness based? How long does adapting 
take, and to what extent is this of significance to the not-so-fast driver? 
Does the CPU (1802?) know the thermodynamics of fuel combustion etc.
Seems to me that I can depress the throttle fully when in 5th after some 
time at a constant 120 km/h - and nothing much happens the first few
seconds. Is this really 'a feature'? (120 happens to be the Autobahn speed 
limit around here <g>) Enlightning as to the secrets of the DME would be much 
appreciated! Maybe someone would care to elaborate. 

3) The steering wheel or its bushings sometimes emit 'rubbing' noises. 
I believe the noises are produced somewhere inside the coupe, along the
steering wheel shaft (not in the foot well), - and they are possibly 
temperature dependent. Is there a horn contact to be lubed or something? 
Sounds as if something plastic is touching something else. 

4) There's also a most peculiar noise coming from the leftmost air inlet,
or possibly from behind the instruments, again at certain times. Sounds very 
much like a frozen pea being gently shaken in a plastic cup, if you know what 
I mean... Seems to be correlated with acceleration, at 20 km/h in 2nd as well 
as at 80 km/h in the 4th. Pulsing the throttle reliably generates the
sound, if it's there at all that day. Is this car about to self destruct??

5) The lefthand windshield wiper emits rubbing noises even when the
windshield appears to be sufficiently wet. Very annoying to have to switch to
'intermittent' at every traffic light.. Can the wiper pressure be
adjusted?

6) Rainwater gathers at the bottom of the luggage compartments, although
all visible hoses seem to be intact. ASD Porsche, Zuerich, told me that
'this is normal, just dont't place anything in the compartments'. Should
I ever let them touch my car again? Can't really imagine this to be so 
'normal'. The car was beautifully repainted some years ago, so I guess the 
rear light seals were temporarily taken off. But would this really allow 
water into the luggage compartments?? I remember something about brake lights
turning into aquariums from the archives... The little 'platform' behind
the lights just below the carpeting is the most moist area, and the
drivers' side is most affected. 

7) All my new tires, Bridgestone RE71, lost 0.1 bar during the 1st 2 weeks,
with just 110km of non-heavy driving. The old ones kept their pressure for 
much longer. Is this ok? (another 1st-car-in-my-life q., I must admit!)

8) Had the front weels aligned some time before I got new tires, the old 
ones were badly worn on one side. Should I realign again (+1500 km)?

9) Someone said in the archives: 'If the cassette compartment hinge is ok, 
then buy the car'. Well, I did, and the hinge did of course break from
old age or whatever the 3rd time I carefully opened it. Someone
mentioned metal hinges a while ago - where can I get one (in Europe..),
and what should I expect to pay??

10) Compulsory newbie options sticker question: This has been covered several 
times, but apart from side mouldings #418, speakers/antenna amp. #441, the 
sunroof #650, electrical windows #651 and the power steering #657 , I've found 
nothing to decipher C10 and CL7. Seems to have sport seats etc. as well, but 
these don't appear on the sticker... The car is a ROW. Also, the sticker says 
the car is a 944 type 042. What's 042?? If anyone happens to know what these 
numbers mean, I would very much like to know! 

This got slightly long, but I'm of course a bit concerned about this my
1st car (nice choice, I think!). As I'm on a strong diet concerning e-mail, 
I would appreciate any answers to these questions directly to me as 
'lien@hoggar.ethz.ch' as well as to the list. 
Thanks in advance for any competent answers!

Sincerely,
Hans-Petter Lien
'87 944 S wine red  [bordeaux :-)]

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 08:56:56 -0400
From: PerryS7342@aol.com
Subject: Re: Valvoline's New Blended Oil

Lee:

I tried a oil change with Valvoline's Durablend on my Ford Explorer (with 30K
plus miles on regular Valvoline) and experienced seepage from the valve
covers and rear main.  Ford nor Valvoline tech reps (by phone) had any
"reported"  experience with leakage problems using Durablend.  Since it costs
twice as much and I change oil at half the recommended frequency anyway, I
went back to regular Valvoline.

Perry

alignment.

shoulder (good) or back up toward the crown (bad).

and they have a hard time explaining it.
