Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 10:21:46 -0400
From: jfoster@omni.voicenet.com (Jim Foster)
Subject: 944S2 down on power

I ran into a problem with my 944S2 (1991, 15K miles) at Watkins Glen this
weekend.  The car ran great for a day and a half but then several laps
into a mid-day run session I started to lose power at high RPMs.  I was
getting concerned that I wouldn't even be able to make it back into the
pits.  The car wasn't missing, but wouldn't pull high RPMs.  It seemed 
like it just wasn't getting enough fuel so we decided to replace the fuel 
filter.

The other symptom is that at low RPMs it's "bucking" as if I'm jabbing
at the throttle or not releasing the clutch smoothly.  You can even feel
this at 2,500 RPM in 5th gear.  It smooths out at higher RPM (so we just
drove faster on the way home... :-))

Replacing the filter made the car run _much_ better, but it was still very
slow to rev.  For example, I usually pull about 6K in 4th gear at the 
top of the esses.  Yesterday I was lucky to be hitting 5,800 RPM by the
_end_ of the back straight.  I guess I'm down about 20MPH in top speed.
I _could_ hit the rev limiter in 3rd gear, but it took much longer to 
get there.  All four spark plugs look okay.  Disconnecting the O2 sensor 
didn't help either.  The fuel pressure regulator has vacuum at idle, as 
does the other regulator at the front of the rail.    All the ignition 
connections are clean and tight.

Any ideas?  Could I have bought bad gas the night before?  We bought
gas about an hour after a very bad thunderstorm.  The car did run great
for two run groups the following morning though.  
- --
Jim Foster - jfoster@omni.voicenet.com                       (610) 825-4440
"Being on a Beemer and not having a wave returned by a                944S2
Sportster is like having a clipper ship's hailing not               DoD 142
returned by an orphaned New Jersay solid waster barge." -OTL  '91 K100RS16V

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 09:26:28 +0600
From: rondl@uscbu.ih.att.com (Ronald Jay De Lange)
Subject: My First Time!

Greetings!

If you can remember the anticipation, nervousness, worrying about
everything you took apart or rebuilt, and hearing your *first* porsche
turning over and *starting* - then you know how I felt this weekend!!

Finally, after *three long years* of restoring a rust-bucket '66 912,
it finally came to life this weekend!  It actually started rather
easily - I guess marking down all the carb settings during the rebuilds
payed off.  Then, smoke filled my garage!  Uh oh - but, after looking
towards the fire extinguisher, I realized that the smoking was coming
from the paint burning off the new Bursch muffler pipes near the
cylinders - phew!

After running it a while (stored for 3 years, a short idle then, and
before that 12+ years of storage) I noticed the driver's side carb
was backfiring a little bit.  Slight timing adjustments and adjusting
the valves took care of that.  Float bowl adjustments were easy, but,
messy.  Carb sync was close and we couldnt figure out how
to "twist the throttle shaft" as the factory manual suggests.  So, we
left that for another day. 

The valve covers leaked, even with new seals, so we still need to
figure that out - maybe some gasket sealer is in order?  The cork
doesnt want to form to the cover.

Well, it was time to back her out of the garage and try out the
transmission.  I had vowed to 'drive no Porsche before my own' so
the desire was high - even if it was a 50' driveway!  Reverse, no
problem, 1st okay, 2nd okay, 3rd yup, 4th nope, 5th nope!  What
the H*LL!?  I just knew that I should have left that leaking
transmission shift-fork seal alone!  Murphy had finally visited
me in a painful way.....

I decided to not let the transmission "rain on my Porsche parade"
and it could wait until Sunday night for closer inspection.  I'll be
damned if I can figure out why the stupid shift fork thingy isnt
engaging the 4-5th "floating gears"; guess I need a second pair
of eyes to see what I'm missing.

Although the transmission stuff is a bummer, it couldnt come close
to overshadowing the sweet sound of *my* Porsche idling smoothly in
the garage/driveway.  All my neighbors came over during the day to
hear it run and congratulate me (after privately wondering if it
would *ever* leave my garage!).

So, life is good!  Those long three years all of a sudden dont
seem so bad afterall!  I kinda like it that you could point to
anything on the car and I would have some kind of story to tell you.
Where the part came from, what it took to rebuild/restore, 
what it does, or who helped me.

Well, I hope this e-mail reminds those of you who like to do stuff
yourself and learn in the process of "your first time."

Ron   rondl@uscbu.att.com
'66 912 IT RUNS!
'95 Toyota Forerunner
'95 Dweezil the Cat



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 95 9:28:45 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; which torque-wrench to buy


>  "Before I go down to Sears or OSH, does anyone have any
>  opinions or advice to offer on what a good quality manual
>  (as opposed to compressed air powered) torque wrench should
>  cost?  Any testimonials or caveats?"

      If you mean a Torque wrench, I was finally satisfied (after
  having 3 or 4 just go bad....) with going to a Pawn shop and
  buying a Snap-On for $80. Nice stuff. Don't get a cheap torque
  wrench unless you are only fixing lawnmowers.

      If you mean an Impact wrench (I don't think there is an air-powered
  torque wrench, at least for automotive) you can probably get by with
  a cheap one from Home Depot or Harbor freight or..... Handy things to have
  around. Electric ones are even handier but don't make the kind of torque
  that Pneumatic ones make. 
      
           -Lee A.

last two weeks.  The car (having been driven relatively hard for about three

the battery is fine, powers the guages, etc., but the starter won't turn.  No

instantly and runs fine.  I am suspecting the starter solenoid, but it will
start all the rest of the time just fine. And, YES there are hills in texas,
I was at canyon lake, not in Houston all three times. <g>

Anyone ever have this kind of behavior before?  I'm puzzled.

side in the windshield.  Damn muddy pickup trucks throwing s*#& everywhere on

these "repair your windshield" things?

thanks for your time,

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 09:45:23 -0500
From: smaardyk@rs6000.SUGAR-LAND.WIRELINE.SLB.COM
Subject: Re: 944 headlight adjusting specs

Tracy,

Another simple method for adjusting headlights is the 'garage door method.'
Drive the car up close to a garage door or suitable vertical surface with
the lights on.  Mark the center of each beam spot.  Back the car up about
15-20 feet and see where the beam spots fall relative to the original marks
and adjust accordingly.  Final test is on a dark road at night.

Regards,
John

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 11:18:24 -0400
From: Barry Chapin (chapin@draper.com) <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: 911 Brakes are binding slightly.


Hi,

After fixing all my problems from last week...
My disc brakes on my 1981 911SC are not releasing completely after
stepping on them SOMETIMES.  I am not sure which wheel(s) are binding
on me, or if its front and/or back.  I happens maybe 3 or 4 times out of
15 or so stops.  

The brakes pads seem to stay pressed against the disc, but not so
bad as that I can't pull away from a stop.  Just a slight bind.  And
if I get them to bind then coast to a stop, it slows the car, and 
then stops it as if I had been pressing the brakes lightly.  After
they bind, the brake pedal is then hard to press right from the start 
of depression.  If I tap it a bunch of times, usually the binding 
releases, sometimes it takes a while.  I guess it must be the pistons 
in the calipers???

I store the car winters.  Do the walls of the cylinders in the brake
calipers get corroded after time?  How can I diagnose this problem
to figure which wheels are binding?  Is there a simple fix, or big $$$?
The rotors are smooth with no pits or scratches.  How hard is it to
remove the calipers and then the pistons, and smooth the walls, or
replace worn parts like the pistons?  Is this only a job for pro mechanics?
Lastly, how much would rebuilt calipers run me?  Thanks.

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 11:27:00 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : Am I just not cut out for this?

Food (Foodeditor@aol.com) wrote :

> I have worked on cars since I was 12 years old, (25 years) and until I
> bought a 1970 911T three years ago ... my Porsche has me completely 
> depressed and defeated. Every time I try to do something on it, 
> it turns out badly ... I thought I would install new points, plugs, rotor 
> and cap: I got it all in and......Nothing! The car just won't start. 
> So...the question becomes, can an experienced amateur ever hope to work ?

I think you have just had some bad luck, it's not hard to work on these.
Even the Haynes manual is enough to do most things. But I think you may
not be preparing correctly for you repairs. When you do points, plugs, 
rotor, and cap, you should replace one at a time and make sure the car is
running OK after each step. Then you know which one is bad if there's a
problem. I have had several NEW Bosch and other parts that were NFG.
I have found it is easier to change the points by removing the distributor.
Then you can clean it, set the gap, and grease the cam a bit. Also
a drop of oil down the shaft will make it happy.

The Bosch points are made very poorly - they don't line up parallel and
will often only touch at one side. Before installing them, hold them up
to the light and view between the points contact area. You will probably
see light coming through one side. Bend the solidly-mounted point
with pliers to make them meet parallel. Now you have blueprinted points
that will run longer before going out of spec.

Don't sell your car,  just get in the right frame of mind and you should
be able to do any necessary repair work.

Regards, Mike Piera '72S and '73E Targas, '73 914/2.0
(I have never taken a Porsche to a shop for mechanical work, and I'm
a true "shade tree mechanic" without much patience)

Date: Mon, 05 Jun 1995 08:21 -0800 (PST)
From: Robert_Yasek@NOTES.YMP.GOV
Subject: Re: 911SC versus '72 - '73 S;E;T's


  Hey Trond,

  I have a '73 T that I put an '83 SC engine into. I wrestled with the
  decision for a couple of years, then went ahead and did it when the old
  2.4 (MFI) was having difficulties with emissions. IMO, it is a good blend
  of old and new ( or perhaps more appropriately now, old and older) which
  make the car very enjoyable to drive daily. It is reasonable to maintain,
  and there is enough documentation and help (this list included) that I
  can work on it and learn more about it.

  As for creature comforts, it's pretty spartan, but is
  comfortable/convenient enough for my tastes.

   I suppose it is not a good choice for club racing or
  originality/investment, but I don't plan on racing it soon and if I
  worried about the car's value, I wouldn't drive it, in which case its
  value to me would go down.

  If you want to know anything more specific, e-mail me directly and I'll
  answer any questions you have about it.

  Regards,

  Rob Yasek
  '73 911T
  '91 Bixby Noodlehead

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 00:37:35 -0700
From: Harry Pellow <maestro@well.com>
Subject: Webers or  Solexes for a 912?

to: CKRAUSE13@aol.com
from: maestro@well.com
Subject: Webers or Solexes on 912's?

Ah, yes, which carbs to use? Solexes or Webers? Yes, it's True-
the Maestro admits it! He likes Weber Carburetors. He ALSO likes good 
Solex and Zenith Carburetors!
    (Note that the operative word in the above sentence is "good".)
When Solexes and Zeniths are Good, they're great. And when Solexes and
Zeniths aren't good, they can be Very, Very Bad! 
But Solexes and Zeniths are Original! So, ifin you REALLY want to
Win the Concours, it helps to be Original. 
(Fortunately, the Maestro has a Solution for bad Zeniths or Solexes-
a MaestroMaster Carburetor Rebuild! Which magically makes good-running 
Solexes and Zeniths out of what had been Very, Very bad running Solexes 
and Zeniths.)
    However, ifin you're NOT climbing the concours ladder and just want to 
DRIVE the car. And say, you're living in an Area of the Country
"blessed" with oxygenated gasoline that comes and goes with the seasons,
you'll
find that changing the Main Jets or the Air Correction Jets makes your
356 run better.
 And ifin you've ever changed a Main Jet in a Solex or a
Zenith, you'll note that the entire contents of the Float Bowl gushes
out like a Mississippi flood- all over what used to be your Concours
Sheet Metal and onto your Spark Plug Wires, on its way to your hot
exhaust pipe.
 Nowadays with the Tertiary Butyl Ether oxygenated gasolines have,
a float bowl full of today's gas might put you to sleep before the 
fire starts. 
However, ifin you happen to have a set of Weber Carburetors, you 
can change the Main Jet (and air correction and Emulsion Tube) in less 
that 30 seconds per hole! With a dime. Or a screwdriver ifin you're 
broke and out of dimes. And NO gas leaks anywhere!
Try THAT on your Zenith or Solex! In less than 10 fun-filled,
gasoline-drenched minutes per carburetor.
Webers are meant to be adjusted, played with, raced with, have fun with,
so the adjustments are made with some forethought. 
Buy, hey, IT'S YOUR MONEY! Ifin you want a Concours set of
Solexes or Zeniths, no Problem. Or ifin you want Weber Carbs- 
either the 40 or 44IDF's, again, it's your money. 
     Anyhow, like everything else, Webers have gone through several 
evolutionary versions- mostly with the intent of improving the breed. 
Years ago Webers had a lousy 2-position accelerator pump (the fulcrum pin
for the accelerator pump lever had two positions- giving you a choice of
too much or WAY too much gas, or Too much and Not Enough.)
All Zeniths and Solexes had infinitely adjustable
accelerator pumps- so one could screw them up in infinite number of ways.
Weber soon saw the advantage of this and some 10 years ago
added infinitely adjustable accelerator pumps, as the current model
Webers currently have. (Check your Webers to see which you have.)
About 5 years ago, the Weber Jet Stacks sprouted a 1"
extension so they stood above the top of the carb. This made removal
of the jet stack a lot easier than when they were flush with the carb top. 
(Year ago, with flush-mounted brass jet carriers, unscrewing them was a
cinch, but getting the bastards out of the hole was a real pain. And no,
a magnet won't work-'cause the jets and carrier are brass!)
They fixed that with the 1" extension. Now, the only thing the Maestro
doesn't like about Webers today is that the importer INSISTS on supplying 
Linkage Arms that wedge at half to 2/3 throttle. After telling the importer
repeatedly about the wedging linkage arms and being told repeatedly by the
Importer that "Nobody else ever had this problem before",
the Maestro gave up and made up linkage arms that Go All The Way
Down! Giving you Full Throttle, 'cause you deserve it.
 Now, if you want a mild to warm street engine,
the 40IDF Webers are best for a mild engine, the 44's for a
"Hot" street engine. The 40IDF Webers should be used with Solex
Intake Manifolds and the 44's should be used with the "Weber"
intake Manifold and the necessary surgery performed on the
Side Vertical Sheet Metal. (The Weber Manifold sits lower than
the Solex Manifold, and the inside of the Weber 44IDF will hit
two of the three bolts that hold the Spring Plate for the Top 
Linkage Cross Bar. You must remove the washers from under those
two bolts and/or grind the bolt heads down a bit.)
Currently, there are several Weber
kits of varying degrees of quality. Or lack thereof. There's
a 20+ page section in "Murphy is my Copilot" describing the
detail difference and difficulty (or ease) of installation.
Since I install many Weber kits a year, I like the kits I use
to be as trouble free as possible. This was learned The Hard
Way by installing most every kit available!) 
 The current batch of 40/44IDF Weber kits, are the
Latest Model Weber having the Infinitely Adjustable
Accelerator pump and the 1" extension on the jet stack that
make jet changing a joy, the Large K&N Air Filters, linkage
that WORKS and the Weber manifold. Check your set to see what you have.
Any questions? Give me a call at (408) 727-1864. And:
KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!!!
The Maestro

put the '72-'73 models *far* ahead the SC's (triple Nomex ON). This is up to

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 13:30:06 +0200
From: Hans-Petter Lien <lien@hoggar.ethz.ch>

Subject: 944 DME and strange noises 

Hi there -
- ----------
As the proud new owner of a clean '87 944 S, I've of course got a few 
questions for the knowledgeable fellows I know are out there - my apologies 
if they've been covered after january '95! In that case, I'll find them in 
the files some day.... I bought the car with 67578 km, which is exactly 
42 k miles (and had both belts changed immediately thanks to this very list). 

1) On lesser cars, you can often just release the clutch without any extra 
throttle for initial acceleration. This works on my 944 S _when the engine 
is cold_, but any later starts without extra throttle, such as at traffic 
lights etc., mostly kill the engine. Seems that the engine requires some
1100 rpm before releasing the clutch to avoid trouble when hot. Has this 
anything to do with the idle regulator? Have already fixed the too low 
contact resistance due to an oil film or similar - as I learned from previous 
postings. That cured the slightly high idle, for some time at least. Now, the 
slightly high idle seems to have returned, _except when cold_. Think I've 
read somewhere that the L-Jetronic has a coolant temperature sensor - could 
a defective device cause an additional 200 rpm at idle?? Anyway, applying 
throttle before/when releasing the clutch only when the engine is hot seems 
weird to a newcomer like me. (Yes, this is my 1st car!) 

2) DME functions: Previous postings, for instance Stan's in july 94, indicate 
that the DME is adaptive. Exactly what is being adapted, and on what kind 
of information/sensors is this adaptiveness based? How long does adapting 
take, and to what extent is this of significance to the not-so-fast driver? 
Does the CPU (1802?) know the thermodynamics of fuel combustion etc.
Seems to me that I can depress the throttle fully when in 5th after some 
time at a constant 120 km/h - and nothing much happens the first few
seconds. Is this really 'a feature'? (120 happens to be the Autobahn speed 
limit around here <g>) Enlightning as to the secrets of the DME would be much 
appreciated! Maybe someone would care to elaborate. 

3) The steering wheel or its bushings sometimes emit 'rubbing' noises. 
I believe the noises are produced somewhere inside the coupe, along the
steering wheel shaft (not in the foot well), - and they are possibly 
temperature dependent. Is there a horn contact to be lubed or something? 
Sounds as if something plastic is touching something else. 

4) There's also a most peculiar noise coming from the leftmost air inlet,
or possibly from behind the instruments, again at certain times. Sounds very 
much like a frozen pea being gently shaken in a plastic cup, if you know what 
I mean... Seems to be correlated with acceleration, at 20 km/h in 2nd as well 
as at 80 km/h in the 4th. Pulsing the throttle reliably generates the
sound, if it's there at all that day. Is this car about to self destruct??

5) The lefthand windshield wiper emits rubbing noises even when the
windshield appears to be sufficiently wet. Very annoying to have to switch to
'intermittent' at every traffic light.. Can the wiper pressure be
adjusted?

6) Rainwater gathers at the bottom of the luggage compartments, although
all visible hoses seem to be intact. ASD Porsche, Zuerich, told me that
'this is normal, just dont't place anything in the compartments'. Should
I ever let them touch my car again? Can't really imagine this to be so 
'normal'. The car was beautifully repainted some years ago, so I guess the 
rear light seals were temporarily taken off. But would this really allow 
water into the luggage compartments?? I remember something about brake lights
turning into aquariums from the archives... The little 'platform' behind
the lights just below the carpeting is the most moist area, and the
drivers' side is most affected. 

7) All my new tires, Bridgestone RE71, lost 0.1 bar during the 1st 2 weeks,
with just 110km of non-heavy driving. The old ones kept their pressure for 
much longer. Is this ok? (another 1st-car-in-my-life q., I must admit!)

8) Had the front weels aligned some time before I got new tires, the old 
ones were badly worn on one side. Should I realign again (+1500 km)?

9) Someone said in the archives: 'If the cassette compartment hinge is ok, 
then buy the car'. Well, I did, and the hinge did of course break from
old age or whatever the 3rd time I carefully opened it. Someone
mentioned metal hinges a while ago - where can I get one (in Europe..),
and what should I expect to pay??

10) Compulsory newbie options sticker question: This has been covered several 
times, but apart from side mouldings #418, speakers/antenna amp. #441, the 
sunroof #650, electrical windows #651 and the power steering #657 , I've found 
nothing to decipher C10 and CL7. Seems to have sport seats etc. as well, but 
these don't appear on the sticker... The car is a ROW. Also, the sticker says 
the car is a 944 type 042. What's 042?? If anyone happens to know what these 
numbers mean, I would very much like to know! 

This got slightly long, but I'm of course a bit concerned about this my
1st car (nice choice, I think!). As I'm on a strong diet concerning e-mail, 
I would appreciate any answers to these questions directly to me as 
'lien@hoggar.ethz.ch' as well as to the list. 
Thanks in advance for any competent answers!

Sincerely,
Hans-Petter Lien
'87 944 S wine red  [bordeaux :-)]



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 08:56:56 -0400
From: PerryS7342@aol.com
Subject: Re: Valvoline's New Blended Oil

Lee:

I tried a oil change with Valvoline's Durablend on my Ford Explorer (with 30K
plus miles on regular Valvoline) and experienced seepage from the valve
covers and rear main.  Ford nor Valvoline tech reps (by phone) had any
"reported"  experience with leakage problems using Durablend.  Since it costs
twice as much and I change oil at half the recommended frequency anyway, I
went back to regular Valvoline.

Perry

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 95 09:16:37 EDT
From: cohen@ATB.Teradyne.COM (steve cohen)
Subject: How do you test schock absorbers??

Hi All,

My '82 911 SC has some wiggles in the steering wheel at about 60 - 70
mph.  My guess is that the schocks are gone or the car is out of
alignment.

The alignment 'seems' ok.  I check it by moving to the right side of
the crown of the road and seeing if the car crawls down toward the
shoulder (good) or back up toward the crown (bad).

Anyone have an idea how I can test the front schocks?? I've seen folks bounce
the car and say yea or ney, but I dont know what they are looking at
and they have a hard time explaining it.

Any help would be greatly appreciated.

 -Steve

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 10:21:46 -0400
From: jfoster@omni.voicenet.com (Jim Foster)
Subject: 944S2 down on power

I ran into a problem with my 944S2 (1991, 15K miles) at Watkins Glen this
weekend.  The car ran great for a day and a half but then several laps
into a mid-day run session I started to lose power at high RPMs.  I was
getting concerned that I wouldn't even be able to make it back into the
pits.  The car wasn't missing, but wouldn't pull high RPMs.  It seemed 
like it just wasn't getting enough fuel so we decided to replace the fuel 
filter.

The other symptom is that at low RPMs it's "bucking" as if I'm jabbing
at the throttle or not releasing the clutch smoothly.  You can even feel
this at 2,500 RPM in 5th gear.  It smooths out at higher RPM (so we just
drove faster on the way home... :-))

Replacing the filter made the car run _much_ better, but it was still very
slow to rev.  For example, I usually pull about 6K in 4th gear at the 
top of the esses.  Yesterday I was lucky to be hitting 5,800 RPM by the
_end_ of the back straight.  I guess I'm down about 20MPH in top speed.
I _could_ hit the rev limiter in 3rd gear, but it took much longer to 
get there.  All four spark plugs look okay.  Disconnecting the O2 sensor 
didn't help either.  The fuel pressure regulator has vacuum at idle, as 
does the other regulator at the front of the rail.    All the ignition 
connections are clean and tight.

Any ideas?  Could I have bought bad gas the night before?  We bought
gas about an hour after a very bad thunderstorm.  The car did run great
for two run groups the following morning though.  
- --
Jim Foster - jfoster@omni.voicenet.com                       (610) 825-4440
"Being on a Beemer and not having a wave returned by a                944S2
Sportster is like having a clipper ship's hailing not               DoD 142
returned by an orphaned New Jersay solid waster barge." -OTL  '91 K100RS16V


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 09:26:28 +0600
From: rondl@uscbu.ih.att.com (Ronald Jay De Lange)
Subject: My First Time!

Greetings!

If you can remember the anticipation, nervousness, worrying about
everything you took apart or rebuilt, and hearing your *first* porsche
turning over and *starting* - then you know how I felt this weekend!!

Finally, after *three long years* of restoring a rust-bucket '66 912,
it finally came to life this weekend!  It actually started rather
easily - I guess marking down all the carb settings during the rebuilds
payed off.  Then, smoke filled my garage!  Uh oh - but, after looking
towards the fire extinguisher, I realized that the smoking was coming
from the paint burning off the new Bursch muffler pipes near the
cylinders - phew!

After running it a while (stored for 3 years, a short idle then, and
before that 12+ years of storage) I noticed the driver's side carb
was backfiring a little bit.  Slight timing adjustments and adjusting
the valves took care of that.  Float bowl adjustments were easy, but,
messy.  Carb sync was close and we couldnt figure out how
to "twist the throttle shaft" as the factory manual suggests.  So, we
left that for another day. 

The valve covers leaked, even with new seals, so we still need to
figure that out - maybe some gasket sealer is in order?  The cork
doesnt want to form to the cover.

Well, it was time to back her out of the garage and try out the
transmission.  I had vowed to 'drive no Porsche before my own' so
the desire was high - even if it was a 50' driveway!  Reverse, no
problem, 1st okay, 2nd okay, 3rd yup, 4th nope, 5th nope!  What
the H*LL!?  I just knew that I should have left that leaking
transmission shift-fork seal alone!  Murphy had finally visited
me in a painful way.....

I decided to not let the transmission "rain on my Porsche parade"
and it could wait until Sunday night for closer inspection.  I'll be
damned if I can figure out why the stupid shift fork thingy isnt
engaging the 4-5th "floating gears"; guess I need a second pair
of eyes to see what I'm missing.

Although the transmission stuff is a bummer, it couldnt come close
to overshadowing the sweet sound of *my* Porsche idling smoothly in
the garage/driveway.  All my neighbors came over during the day to
hear it run and congratulate me (after privately wondering if it
would *ever* leave my garage!).

So, life is good!  Those long three years all of a sudden dont
seem so bad afterall!  I kinda like it that you could point to
anything on the car and I would have some kind of story to tell you.
Where the part came from, what it took to rebuild/restore, 
what it does, or who helped me.

Well, I hope this e-mail reminds those of you who like to do stuff
yourself and learn in the process of "your first time."

Ron   rondl@uscbu.att.com
'66 912 IT RUNS!
'95 Toyota Forerunner
'95 Dweezil the Cat



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 95 9:28:45 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; which torque-wrench to buy


>  "Before I go down to Sears or OSH, does anyone have any
>  opinions or advice to offer on what a good quality manual
>  (as opposed to compressed air powered) torque wrench should
>  cost?  Any testimonials or caveats?"

      If you mean a Torque wrench, I was finally satisfied (after
  having 3 or 4 just go bad....) with going to a Pawn shop and
  buying a Snap-On for $80. Nice stuff. Don't get a cheap torque
  wrench unless you are only fixing lawnmowers.

      If you mean an Impact wrench (I don't think there is an air-powered
  torque wrench, at least for automotive) you can probably get by with
  a cheap one from Home Depot or Harbor freight or..... Handy things to have
  around. Electric ones are even handier but don't make the kind of torque
  that Pneumatic ones make. 
      
           -Lee A.


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 09:36:51 -0500 (CDT)
From: Chuck Campbell <campbell@Starbase.NeoSoft.COM>
Subject: mirror, starter, glass 911 questions

Well,
an interesting weekend all the way around.  Most of the bad stuff had nothing
to do with Porsches, so I'll limit myself to the three small things which now
need attention on the car...

Passenger side mirror is nearly dangling by the wires.  It appears that the 
small threaded, brassy colored "pipe" has come unscrewed from the mmirror,
and is sitting in the base.

Do I use an allen wrench to remove the base from the door, and will this all 
be painfully obvious as to how I can re-thread this into the mirror?  I'm 
hoping it is really that simple.  If not, please tell me where to look to get
started.  I can't believe how much I depend on that mirror.

Secondly, and even more strangely, I have had a problem three times in the 
last two weeks.  The car (having been driven relatively hard for about three
hours at highway speeds) doesn't start.  Now this is curious for two reasons,
the battery is fine, powers the guages, etc., but the starter won't turn.  No
clicking, no attempt to make noise, nothing.  All three times, a short roll
down a hill, pop the clutch (with the key on of course) and the car starts
instantly and runs fine.  I am suspecting the starter solenoid, but it will
start all the rest of the time just fine. And, YES there are hills in texas,
I was at canyon lake, not in Houston all three times. <g>

Anyone ever have this kind of behavior before?  I'm puzzled.

Lastly, I picked up a rock chip and 12 inch crack right in front of the drivers
side in the windshield.  Damn muddy pickup trucks throwing s*#& everywhere on
the road.  Do you recommend Porsche glass, or has anyone any experience with
these "repair your windshield" things?

thanks for your time,
 -chuck

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 09:45:23 -0500
From: smaardyk@rs6000.SUGAR-LAND.WIRELINE.SLB.COM
Subject: Re: 944 headlight adjusting specs

Tracy,

Another simple method for adjusting headlights is the 'garage door method.'
Drive the car up close to a garage door or suitable vertical surface with
the lights on.  Mark the center of each beam spot.  Back the car up about
15-20 feet and see where the beam spots fall relative to the original marks
and adjust accordingly.  Final test is on a dark road at night.

Regards,
John

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 08:07:33 -0700
From: rsaldana@qualcomm.com (Rolando Saldana)
Subject: Re: POC Tribute to LeMans - Report


The POC Tribute to Le Mans was quite an experience for a novice Porsche
owner such as myself. It is  unforgettable to watch, listen to the sweet
sound and smell the exhaust fumes of 40 awesome Porsches taking to the
track, at night! I knew that owning a Porsche would be a ton of fun. I just
did not know I would be allowed to have this much fun.

Having the opportunity to be  a member of Rick Raimist's RSR pit crew made
this weekend an even more exciting experience. Raimist's Team, A Racing
Enterprise (ARE), managed to place second with the RSR and fourth with 911
#41, quite an accomplishment for which we were all very excited.
Congratulations to all the ARE team members!

Kudos to the POC and its members for making such an event possible.

See you all at the next one!

if I get them to bind then coast to a stop, it slows the car, and 
then stops it as if I had been pressing the brakes lightly.  After
they bind, the brake pedal is then hard to press right from the start 
of depression.  If I tap it a bunch of times, usually the binding 
releases, sometimes it takes a while.  I guess it must be the pistons 
in the calipers???

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 11:27:00 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : Am I just not cut out for this?

Food (Foodeditor@aol.com) wrote :

> I have worked on cars since I was 12 years old, (25 years) and until I
> bought a 1970 911T three years ago ... my Porsche has me completely 
> depressed and defeated. Every time I try to do something on it, 
> it turns out badly ... I thought I would install new points, plugs, rotor 
> and cap: I got it all in and......Nothing! The car just won't start. 
> So...the question becomes, can an experienced amateur ever hope to work ?

I think you have just had some bad luck, it's not hard to work on these.
Even the Haynes manual is enough to do most things. But I think you may
not be preparing correctly for you repairs. When you do points, plugs, 
rotor, and cap, you should replace one at a time and make sure the car is
running OK after each step. Then you know which one is bad if there's a
problem. I have had several NEW Bosch and other parts that were NFG.
I have found it is easier to change the points by removing the distributor.
Then you can clean it, set the gap, and grease the cam a bit. Also
a drop of oil down the shaft will make it happy.

The Bosch points are made very poorly - they don't line up parallel and
will often only touch at one side. Before installing them, hold them up
to the light and view between the points contact area. You will probably
see light coming through one side. Bend the solidly-mounted point
with pliers to make them meet parallel. Now you have blueprinted points
that will run longer before going out of spec.

Don't sell your car,  just get in the right frame of mind and you should
be able to do any necessary repair work.

Regards, Mike Piera '72S and '73E Targas, '73 914/2.0
(I have never taken a Porsche to a shop for mechanical work, and I'm
a true "shade tree mechanic" without much patience)

Date: Mon, 05 Jun 1995 08:21 -0800 (PST)
From: Robert_Yasek@NOTES.YMP.GOV
Subject: Re: 911SC versus '72 - '73 S;E;T's


  Hey Trond,

  I have a '73 T that I put an '83 SC engine into. I wrestled with the
  decision for a couple of years, then went ahead and did it when the old
  2.4 (MFI) was having difficulties with emissions. IMO, it is a good blend
  of old and new ( or perhaps more appropriately now, old and older) which
  make the car very enjoyable to drive daily. It is reasonable to maintain,
  and there is enough documentation and help (this list included) that I
  can work on it and learn more about it.

  As for creature comforts, it's pretty spartan, but is
  comfortable/convenient enough for my tastes.

   I suppose it is not a good choice for club racing or
  originality/investment, but I don't plan on racing it soon and if I
  worried about the car's value, I wouldn't drive it, in which case its
  value to me would go down.

  If you want to know anything more specific, e-mail me directly and I'll
  answer any questions you have about it.

  Regards,

  Rob Yasek
  '73 911T
  '91 Bixby Noodlehead

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 08:54:33 -0700 (PDT)
From: banders@netcom.com (Brad Anders)
Subject: RE: 914 books

> In assembling my 914 library I was wondering what the list thought of the 
> following ( for overhall and restoration).
> 	Bosch Fuel Injection and Engine Management
> 	Porsche 914 Handbook
> 	914 Restoration Guide
> I already have the Idiot book and the Haynes manuel. Do I need the rest? 
> What do you think? I am pretty sold on the FI handbook, but the resto 
> guide and the handbook may cover the same material.

I had a chance the other day at Automotion to look through all of these
books. The Bosch book is a great book for learning about FI, but if your
car has D-Jetronic, the information is pretty limited. I was hoping to 
find a technical guide to D-Jetronic that had great detail on all of the 
components (i.e. complete info on each system component, electronic and
mechanical specs, etc.). L- and LH-Jetronic and K- based systems are covered
in great detail, along with Motronic. 

The restoration guide is excellent, filled with many pictures and details
about the cars. The "914 Handbook" is a manual similar to the Haynes guide
that is published under a new cover (I've goe one of the old ones at home). 
It's a very good complement to the Haynes guide. 

WRT this subject of FI: Has anyone on porschephiles ever made up a 914 
D-Jetronic and K-Jetronic tuning guide? I'm talking about a procedural 
guide for taking a car and putting into a base state of tune, with 914-
specific tips and specifications? Something like:

1.	Adjust valves (list of valve clearance specs for different 
	engines and proceedure or reference to proceedure goes here...)
2.	Set timing...

and so on. When getting my '73 2.0L engine into a state of decent tune,
I had a whole list of problems I presented my mechanic with (I went to 
a mechanic after years of screwing around with the thing with no luck).
He listened patiently, then told me that he would check on these items
after he went through his procedure of putting the car into a base state
of tune. Needless to say, many of the "problems" I had weren't around after
he was finished. He did a number of things I wouldn't have done, such as
check all the plug wires resistance (found a bad one) and a number of other
small items that added up to poor tune. An eye-opening experience for your
typical untrained home mechanic. 

One more thing: I'm getting ready to do my pedal bushings with the 
Automotion kit. Any tips?
 



- -- 
*******************************
* Brad Anders / Sunnyvale, CA *
*     banders@netcom.com      *
*******************************

>

> But for some reason the darn thing won't start today. The engine
> cranks quite well but won't start up.  The only thing I did different  
> today was leave the key in the ignition for a few minutes to the far 
> right position without the car actually running.  Did this somehow 
> burn out some ignition gizmo?    
> 

Hi Steve,

I had the same problem with my '88 911 a few months ago.

I was adjusting the windshield washer nozzles and had to leave the ignition
on for approx. 10 min while adjusting the spray pattern. When I finished I tried
starting the car but it wouldn't start; it would crank well but it won't start.
It finally started about 20 mins later. This starting problem would manifest
intermittently after that incident. 

I was told that a bad DME relay was the cause of the problem, I replaced the
relay about a month ago, and the intermittent starting problem still exists!

I suspected a ground problem, and checked/cleaned all ground points, relay contacts,
checked/replaced fuses and the problem still exists.

In my particular case, when the starting problem happens, the engine cranks ok
but it appears like there was no spark. When it finally starts, the engine runs
perfectly.

Now, I also think that somehow something happened to the ignition system. I hope
the problem is not the control unit.

Any ideas, please help us,

Javier - '88 911
javier@ascc01.ascc.att.com

Folks,

First, many thanks to those who reponded to my "Queer Ride Height" post.  
After careful inspection, the rear springs look like hell and will be replaced
with the 195lb progressive springs Stan mentioned.  Additionally, the 
passenger side torsion bar adjustment was "all the way in" while the drivers
side adjustment was "all the way out".  

I had some trouble trying the get the adjustment bolt to move on the drivers
side, but I will continue trying to adjust it as a short-term solution 
pending replacement of the torsion bars.

Now to the problem at hand.  I've tried three times to get the headlight
motor assembly properly aligned with marginal success.  After reassembly with
the covers, with the headlights in the closed position, they still are not
flush with the hood as they stick up just short of an inch.  

Since the drive bar is a solid, fixed-length piece, I can't see how the 
adjustment could be made there(I have tried).  Is is proper to make the
adjustment via the mounting plate for the light-mount itself? (The one with
three allen screws in trunk and two in the wheel well)

Any advice would be appreciated.  Thanks in advance.

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 12:14:56 -0400 (EDT)
From: Doug Donsbach <dld@Symtec.com>
Subject: Re: 944 performance: thanks

>A friend of mine picked up a used low-mile '93 Camaro (275HP/325 lb-ft) 
>for a mere $13K, and put a Paxton supercharger kit ($3500) and some 
>aftermarket headers.  Hell, the thing probably outhandles my 944, and 
>with roughly 400HP/400 lb-ft on tap, offers performance probably close to 
>a new 911 Turbo. (WHICH IS MY DREAM CAR, INCIDENTALLY).
>
The Camaro will *not* outhandle the 944. Improved as it is over the
previous generation of Camaro's, it still has a solid rear axle and
the cowl still shakes on rough roads. The 944 is as stiff and tight
as anything I've driven. And when the Camaro is as old as your 944
it'll be up on blocks, half primer / half rust and a salvage yard
would have to be paid to come pick the thing up.

Your original post also mentioned quality. If my car is any indication
the cars were built with quality. That means that when they came off the
line they were assembled to the specifications produced by engineering.
I also think the car was engineered with quality. When I work on my 951
I see lots of clever engineering and most of it looks like it was derived
from race experience. A response to your post pointed out the specific
power of the 944 engine. A similar situation exists in the chassis and
suspension. There are a lot of high-performance parts in a very stiff
and fairly light package.

Enjoy the 944. Maybe you should drive a 951 and see how that feels. Good
luck with your car.

Doug Donsbach - dld@symtec.com - Knoxville, TN
'88 951 - '88 735i

  of an inch, the noise seems to go away. Any ideas?

  15k miles in it. From what I've heard about changing/tensioning

Date: Mon, 05 Jun 95 09:14:46 PST
From: "RADSICKT" <radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil>
Subject: Removing 914 Head Studs: Help wanted

 Greetings to all,
 
 Yes, the 914 engine saga continues -- I need to remove the head studs before I 
 bring the engine to FAT to get machined.  So far I have removed all eight from 
 one side of the case, but on the other side, they seem to be quite confortable 
 in their current location.  I have only been able to remove two of them.  I 
 have been using the "double nut" technique and am wondering if I should bop on 
 down to Sears and buy one of those stud pullers (device that fits to a ratchet 
 set and uses an eccentrically mounted cam-like thing to clamp the stud.)  My 
 worry is that when using a stud puller, I will end up leaving some sharp little 
 tooth marks where it clamps.  This makes me worry about causing stress 
 concentrations in the stud at those discontinuities.  Most likely this won't 
 cause problems, but the solution seems less than elegant (perhaps I should 
 polish the head studs to a mirror like finish, thus impressing all admirers who 
  crawl underneath the car and look at the shiny studs... "And the winner for 
 the People's Choice Award in the Air-cooled Division is... Tim Radsick, and his 
 Blue 914, license plate "crom stud""... sorry, too much Diet Coke....)
 
 Also, methods to loosen up the studs would be appreciated (already squirted on 
 Liquid Wrench -- no dice....)
 
 Thanks Ahead of Time,
 Tim

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 12:26:19 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 books

> I was hoping to 
> find a technical guide to D-Jetronic that had great detail on all of the 
> components (i.e. complete info on each system component, electronic and
> mechanical specs, etc

You can find most of what you're looking for in the factory service manuals
and updates. Honest. The Haynes book does a respectible job of helping
with some of the measurements, but the factory book has it all. As one might
expect, if one thought about it.

> WRT this subject of FI: Has anyone on porschephiles ever made up a 914 
> D-Jetronic and K-Jetronic tuning guide? 

Again, see the factory service manuals.

The proceedure is really simple. You can't do *ANYTHING* until the valves
are adjusted correctly. Then comes static ignition timing, then fuel pressure.
As you progress from there, what you do next depends on the car model.

> One more thing: I'm getting ready to do my pedal bushings with the 
> Automotion kit. Any tips?

Patience. If the bushings have never been done, you may have ah, an
"entertaining" time taking the pedal assembly apart.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 95 10:35:21 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: (Un)stuck gearshift


Can anyone shed some light on the following? 

This weekend I opened the transmission on the  $1250 '72 911T that I 
lucked into a few months ago, and am now rebuilding.  You might 
remember it was stuck in one gear, either first or second, and couldn't 
be shifted.

The problem was that the ball end of the little arm on the shift 
selector rod, the arm that's accessed through the small cover plate,  
had somehow come out of the 1st/2nd -- 3rd/4th selector fork rods.  
Everything else looked fine, clean and in the right place.  I put the 
arm back in place, and can now shift through all gears (on the bench).  

My question is how did it come out?  The only thing I can think of is 
that someone really applied a lot of force, enough to pop the ball end 
out of the notches in the selector rods.

Has anyone seen this happen?  Should I do something more before 
putting it back in the car?

Thanks!

Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu
'72 911E  targa
'72 911T  coupe (in pieces)

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 95 10:40:01 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re: 914 F.I./Carb Questions

>> > 1.  I have a '74 914 with the L-Jetronic system.  Over the years the F.I. 
>> > has been butchered and jury-rigged together, but it seems to run okay.  
>> > The biggest problem is, the car only gets about 25 MPG.  Is this normal 
>> > for 2000 lb., 76 HP car?  I haven't checked the color of the spark plugs, 
>> > but it doesn't smell or look like its running rich.  As far as I know, 
>> > all of the components are there, just the vaccuum hoses are awry.  Does 
>> > this poor mileage have a solution?

>> be able to get all the way up to 30, but there's really not that much room
>> for improvement. And if you drive it hard, there's *NO* room for improvement.

Actually, I've seen 35mpg on a tank full, preceded by a 33mpg tank and
a 34mpg tank.  This was in full track trim (other than tires) and
fully loaded for camping.  It was pretty long stretches across Nevada,
Utah and Colorado after the '90 Parade in Monterey.  Nothing fancy,
and I'm still running the same setup (except for maintance) for
autocross and time trials.  However, 25mpg is pretty good on a general
note.

Pat Norris

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 10:59:43 -0700
From: "William Dunham" <dunham@bonehead.esd.sgi.com>
Subject: correct way to adjust valves?

This weekend I had some extra time on my hands (SO was out of town) and
I figured what better way to spend the day than in the garage banging up
my knuckles.  Anyway, since the valves hadn't been adjusted in a while and
I was noticing a few more backfires than normal I figured that would be
a good project for the day.  I was a little nervous having never done this
before and having seen those nasty pictures of what happens when the
valves are too loose or too tight.  I removed the exhaust valve cover,
set the crankshaft for TDC for the first cylinder, got on my back and went
to work.  The first problem I had was getting the feeler guage between the
valve and the rocker arm.  I spent WAY too much time fiddling with it.
When I did finally get the feeler in there, there was enough oil all over
the place that I had a hard time telling when I had the correct amount of
pressure on the guage.

My questions are:
1. what is the proper procedure for getting the feeler in
correctly, should I loosen the set screw way up and go from there (what if
I just wanted to check the clearence and not necessarily set it).  I'm using
one of the blade type feelers, should I be using the "wire" types?

2. How much pressure on the feeler is enough, and should that be without
engine oil all over the place?

3. How paranoind should I be about doing this myself?  Is .005 or .003
going to cause major problems?

TIA for any help

Bill
'72 911T (sitting in the garage waiting to be put back together)


- -- 
William J. Dunham
Silicon Graphics
dunham@esd.sgi.com
(415)390-2129

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 11:23:42 -0700 (MST)
From: Tim Jones <timjones@indirect.com>
Subject: Re: headlight alignment (et al)

Jerry,

> I had some trouble trying the get the adjustment bolt to move on the drivers
> side, but I will continue trying to adjust it as a short-term solution 
> pending replacement of the torsion bars.

I've found the best way to get those pesky bolts to move is to lift the 
front end off the ground to relieve the tension on the bars.  This makes 
the bolts much easier to turn.

> Now to the problem at hand.  I've tried three times to get the headlight
> motor assembly properly aligned with marginal success.  After reassembly with
> the covers, with the headlights in the closed position, they still are not
> flush with the hood as they stick up just short of an inch.  

Make sure that the cover is not hitting on the headlight blind (the little
trumpet shaped piece in the front of the assembly).  My driver's light
does this sometimes on my '74 because of rust where the two rubber points
position. 

> Since the drive bar is a solid, fixed-length piece, I can't see how the 
> adjustment could be made there(I have tried).  Is is proper to make the
> adjustment via the mounting plate for the light-mount itself? (The one with
> three allen screws in trunk and two in the wheel well)

If you are not hitting the blind, one method would be to remove power to
the assembly, disengage the motor, set the proper height of the assembly
and then reinsert the motor. 

Tim Jones
timjones@indirect.com
'74 914 1.8
'75 914 2.0
Keeper of the 914 Fan web page	http://www.indirect.com/www/timjones/porsche/

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 15:13:39 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Got the Porsche!!!!!

> I think that's IT. Half this stuff was pointed out to me by the
> mechanics at Rennwerke in Elmsford NY. That's who did the pre-purchase
> check out for me. 

Cool. I wasn't aware that Elmsford was big enough to have a Porsche
shop... Guess I could have gone to work for ANS after all... 8{)

> The only thing the car needs is some new rear tires. I believe it
> takes 245/55ZR16's. Can anyone recommend some tires and a process to
> get them put on. Should I just go to a tire shop, or a porsche shop
> or should I order the tires mail order and have a porsche or tire
> shop put them on? Thanks in advance.

The normal drill is this:

1) figure out what kind of tire you want. This is a religious issue in the
   main. I, and many others, worship at the Temple of Yokohama. There
   are competing schools of thought promoted by infidels, best not discussed
   in polite company 8{)

2) call Tire Rack and get current pricing, *INCLUDING SHIPPING*.

3) call your local Large Tire Vendor that also sells your Brand of Choice
   and say "I can get these tires from Tire Rack for $x each, delieverd,
   what's YOUR best price". 

4) if they're within say 10%, not counting mounting and balancing, drive on
   over and do it; otherwise, call Tire Rack back and order your tires. If
   you order them, take them to the Large Tire Vendor or other shop for
   mounting and balancing.

Hint: find out who supports the local PCA region and do a lot of business
with them if possible. In Houston, and for that matter most places that
have one, Discount Tire is very agressive. They not only try to match Tire Rack
or Dicount Direct mail order prices on a tire, but they throw in mounting
and balancing for free to PCA members.

Caution: don't put on rear tires that are less sticky that front tires. It's
also best not to mix brands and models within brands lest your car do odd
things when pushed to the limit. If that means you need to swap all four
tires to get where you want to be, then by all means do so.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 15:22:25 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: 914 books (fwd)

In response to text from Brad Anders:

I had a chance the other day at Automotion to look through all of these
books. The Bosch book is a great book for learning about FI, but if your
car has D-Jetronic, the information is pretty limited. I was hoping to 
find a technical guide to D-Jetronic that had great detail on all of the 
components (i.e. complete info on each system component, electronic and
mechanical specs, etc.). L- and LH-Jetronic and K- based systems are covered
in great detail, along with Motronic. 

There are only a few differences between the L-Jetronic and the D-Jetronic
systems.  Therefore, the author makes note of the differences and states
that the L-Jet information applies to the D-Jet as well. 

The major difference is the method of measuring the air mass at the intake
manifold.  Although both systems use air temperature senders as a compensator,
the D-Jetronic uses a manifold pressure sensor and the L-Jet a vane-type
air flow sensor.

Another difference is in the fuel pressure regulator.  I believe the D-Jet
fuel pressure regulator is exposed to exterior air pressure and thus is
automatically compenesates for changes in air pressure(due to altitude, etc.)

The book does cover the manifold pressure sensor and fuel pressure regulator
in detail for the D-Jetronic system.  If memory serves, none of the details
of the control units are discussed in the book in great detail.

I've found the book to be indespensible, especially since it applies to 
almost any Porsche you'll ever own(except for the ol' 911s with MFI/carbs).

WRT this subject of FI: Has anyone on porschephiles ever made up a 914 
D-Jetronic and K-Jetronic tuning guide? I'm talking about a procedural 
guide for taking a car and putting into a base state of tune, with 914-
specific tips and specifications? Something like:

This is a good idea.  Since I will be installing my engine soon and it is
a complete rebuild, I'll be double-checking *EVERYTHING* twice from the 
ground on up.  If I take the extra time to make good notes, I could come
up with the framework for such a guide.  We could sent it around for
editing and then install it with the FAQs...

Date: Mon, 05 Jun 95 16:22:59 EST
From: "Thwen Chaloemtiarana" <chaloemt@vrinet.com>
Subject: Re: early vs. late 911s (Non-Tech opinion)

Peter,

I don't have the pedigree born of years and years of sweat and toil like some 
of the folks here, but. . .

My Dad's somewhere close to the pedigree I mentioned, and, somewhere along the 
way post-puberty (mine, that is), he decided I was trustworthy enough to drive 
his cars.  So I was fortunate enough to drive a whole series of sports(?) cars 
as he's traded and doubled up over the years (MGB, 300ZX, 944, 924, 911SC, 914, 
930--all before I was 25!).

For my money, the SC was the best overall.  Some comforts of modernity, to be 
sure, but not all stable and civilized like the 44, nor underpowered like the 
14.  The 930 is a BEAST, and is more of a super car than a sports car, 
especially if we're talking about MGB-type stripped down, no power anything, 
feel every bump and heave driving.  944 was nimble at speed (50/50 front to 
back was ultra stable), but a little ponderous in town; had all the creature 
comforts--A/C, stereo, power everything, serious soundproofing.  SC had the 
best mix of exciting am I gonna fly off the road and o.k., the windshield is 
fogging up so I should turn on the defroster since IT WORKS.  Of course, 
sitting in city traffic during the summer in the SC, you're gonna wonder, "What 
the hell am I driving this and not a 944 for?"  Not having driven a 912, I 
can't tell you how much heavier the SC would "feel".

I love the fact that _my_ 914 is a totally bare bones driving environment and 
sports car.  No frills, no stereo, even.  SC seems to keep in touch with that 
sensibility, IMH(and young)O.

Thwen.

Date: 5 Jun 1995 14:03:35 -0700

P-filers:
Greetings from the Mojave Desert!
Here's a new thread I hope!  After reading some assorted articles recently on
the Beck Spyders (those well done copies of 550 spyders-for the uninitiated
among us) I began thinking: what has become of the original James Dean Spyder?
This isn't such an innocuous question: 
About two years ago, at a memorabilia swap in Los Angeles (I collect die-cast
Porsches, as well as fart around with the real thing) I had tried to buy a
nice model of an early America Roadster from this particular guy.  We got to
talking about Spyders and early Porsches in general, and he proceeded to tell
me that a certain, west coast Porsche/Ferrari dealer, was responsible for the
disappearance of the wreckage of Dean's car.  
I do remember reading elsewhere that the "'lil Bastard"'s carcass had
disappeared from whereever it had been in storage (in a rather professional
manner at that...)  I also remember reading from yet another source that James
Dean had never finished paying for the Spyder, having only traded in the
speedster that he had at the time.  this "source" went on to say that "this
dealer" had the Spyder extensively/completely restored and is in hiding
somewhere, presumably to surface when"the dealer" himself passes on.(I'm
assuming he's still with us...)  
Obviously, for everyone's protection, I ain't using any names other than
Dean's and my own.  I can't decide if this is all b******t, or if there is any
truth to this theory...does any one have any ideas?
Thom Kuby

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 14:36:32 -0700 (PDT)
From: KN@sundog.caltech.edu
Subject: 914 FI Article

To all 914 D-Jetronic owners,
     Since there has been a rash of questions of late, I have been writing
an article for use in Tims 914 Fan Page. The tentative title is "D-Jetronic
Fuel Injection for the Porsche 914 (Care and Feeding for the Owner-Mechanic)".
It will cover theory of operation, common problem, a recommended proceedure
for renewing and testing the system as a whole, adjusting mixture and
modifications (for a 1.9L rebuild for example). I am about 80% finished
and hope to have it out to the list by the end of this week.

Keep the Air-cooled Faith,   Kjell    kn@sundog.caltech.edu

"Porsche, no substitute for cubic dollars!"

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 17:59:06 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Hot rod 944 parts

>I cannot stress how surprising it is to me that hot-rod parts and 
>practice are so rare.  The last "high performance" car I had was an '86 
>Corvette (another good deal) that I was able to tweak into a formidable 
>tread-burner with reasonably few dollars.  I figured that in regards to 
>automobiles, the Germans usually do things better than the Yankees.
>Do they really?

If you were looking to buy a car that you could transform into a 
tread burner, you made a bad decision.  Porsche, unlike GM, cheated
us Porsche owners out of cheapie upgrades to significantly boost
performance - they included all of that stuff from the factory.

Reading the rest of your post, I get the impression that you would
be alot happier with a Camaro, Mustang, etc.  In the interests of
mass production/low costs, GM and Ford left ALOT of room for
improvement in their cars.

If you would really like to develop an appreciation for the 944, take
it to a PCA driver's ed event.  Not only will its performance surprise
you, but you will be investing in the best upgrade of all - the driver.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 19:41:53 -0400 (EDT)
From: Michell Feig <mitchsf@shadow.net>
Subject: Re: Re[2]: 914 F.I./Carb Questions



On Mon, 5 Jun 1995, Thwen Chaloemtiarana wrote:

> Mitch,
> Any recollection as to what the re-conversion problems/costs were?  I've a 1.7 
> rebuilt by PO with 1.8 heads and single barrel carb.  Deciding between waiting 
> for a 2.0 with FI stock to come into my life (and car) or going with converting 
> the 1.7 back.
> 
> Thwen.
> _______________________________________________________________________________
> <Slice and dice>
> 
> So I went back to FI.
> 
> Mitch Feig 
> 1976 911S
> 
Dear Thwen:
I kept the old fuel injection for the 914 (one of my better decisions in 
life), so it 
only cost a couple hundred dollars for labor from my former mechanic (now 
in jail) and new vacuum hoses to reinstall it.  This was about 5 years ago.  

I just purchased a complete fuel injection for my 1976 911S from 
Performance Wholesale for $450, and it's in very good shape.  It cost 
about $400 for the labor to reinstall it.  I also bought a new fuel pump 
because I didn't want to install one with unknown history, new hoses, and 
a fuel accumulator.  So I guess it's about $1200 to trash the carbs.  A 
914 should be somewhat cheaper, especially if you do the work yourself 
(or call my former mechanic in Rayford prison, somewhere in Northern 
Florida!).

I'd recommend calling all the used parts dealers in Panorama and 
Excellence.  I'm sure that you can come up with FI for a 914.

I only wish that the Porschephiles collective knowledge base was 
available years ago when I made that warped decision to install carbs.  
I would be about $1200 richer (parts and labor to install carbs - then 
reinstall FI), and spared untold aggrevation.

Mitch Feig
1976 911S

Date: Mon, 05 Jun 95 17:01:00 PDT
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: RE: Taking the plunge.


>So as not to embarrass myself (or GF), I'm painting my 73T targa before we
>drive up to Parade. Going back to the original Gemini Blue Metallic, in a
>Deltron base/clear. DP-40 primer, K-36 surfacer.  I'm lifting weights to 
get
>my arms ready for sanding :).

I painted my burgundy-orange-red-white-black-light grey
 -dark grey 914-6 last week....now it's mostly white.  I painted
it to provide some sort of rust protection, and to make it
one colour so it isn't too much of an eye-sore.  I won't be
doing the final bodywork until later this summer, or next year
so this is a temporary paint job.

This was my 1st time painting a car and I learned many things...

1)  Wear a baseball hat or *ANYTHING* to cover your head,
unless you like "interesting" hair.

2)  No matter how well you think you sealed off a partition in
the garage, cover everything else outside of your "plastic paint
booth" because the paint WILL find its way onto the car being
worked on in the other half of the garage.  In my case it took
about 3 hours of washing and waxing a black 911 targa since
it now looked "grey"!!!  Ooops....  :-)

3)  Mix the paint VERY well before proceeding....what you
see in the can is what you get.  A beige colour in a can of
gloss white paint will actually come out beige.

4)  Enamel paint may be cheap, but is a b*tch to spray,
especially if you've never done so before.

5)  Seal off the bottom of the car (ie engine area) unless
you like a painted engine.  It's amazing how much that
paint mist gets into everything.

6)  Painting a car in a cramped garage isn't the best idea.
You may discover you need to be in awkward positions to
paint, and this may result in runs, and having a greasy
air hose fall against your wet fender (BT,DT).

7)  You need good lighting to see what you're doing.

8)  Flies like the smell of the paint.  If one lands on your
wet paint, picking it out will definitely show.  I picked
out the first fly, then realized my attempt to "fix" it
didn't work, so I then painted over the next few flies
that landed on my car.  Perhaps in a million years
some future scientist can extract the DNA of a fly
encased on my car and clone it.

My car is a mix of various shades of "white" and also
ranging from "gloss" to "flat", with a couple of good-sized
runs on it.  From a distance it looks great, get a little
closer and you'll see it for what it is - a temporary
paint job worth every penny I paid for it!  :-)

But it was fun.....I'd do it again, but with laquer paint
or some other type which has the sanding/polishing
features of the laquer.  I'd also rent a spray booth
and wear a baseball hat!!!   :-)

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>
'75 914-6  3.0 SC

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 17:03:37 -0700 (PDT)
From: James Wood <jamesw@PEAK.ORG>
Subject: Re: Hot rod 944 parts



On Mon, 5 Jun 1995 MLBDayton@aol.com wrote:

> If you were looking to buy a car that you could transform into a 
> tread burner, you made a bad decision.  Porsche, unlike GM, cheated
> us Porsche owners out of cheapie upgrades to significantly boost
> performance - they included all of that stuff from the factory.


Well, in all honesty - I don't think anyone can look at the upgrade 
potential of a vehicle as a disadvantage.   "Cheapie" or not, a Paxton 
garners REAL HP, no matter what brand of car it's on.  Someone else 
mentioned in this thread that there IS a Paxton kit for 944!   It seems 
to me that unless your Porsche is force-fed, then there's one thing 
missing from the factory.

> In the interests of
> mass production/low costs, GM and Ford left ALOT of room for
> improvement in their cars.

I am very fond of Porsches indeed, and I wouldn't for a second insist 
that the quality of a GM product comes close in terms of refinement, but 
I wouldn't say that the new Camaros "leave a lot of room for 
improvement."  After the past 20 years of Camaros, I can't say that I was 
very fond of Camaros, but the latest genre is an admirable performer (in 
most quantifiable regards) and inarguably one of the best values on the 
planet in terms of bang for the buck.  As a Porsche owner (now), I can't 
look at the industry from a one-sided perspective and totally condemn 
what the cheap Yankee rides achive.  However, I admit I'd take a 911 over 
one anyday - who wouldn't, save for some gear-head Chevy man who thinks 
Porsches are overpriced and too difficult/impossible to modify to run
low 12's.


> If you would really like to develop an appreciation for the 944, take
> it to a PCA driver's ed event.  Not only will its performance surprise
> you, but you will be investing in the best upgrade of all - the driver.


I really do appreciate the 944 already!  I was just poking into the 
never-ending quest for more HP.  However, even in its stock form, my 944 
is a quick car if you bang the gearshift at the right revs.  There's a 
lot of pretenders out there (even some of the more "wuss" V-8s) that 
can't accelerate as quickly as the little SOHC 2.5.  Most anything out of 
Detroit from late 70's to mid-80's is a joke and even a 944 can toast 'em!

> Reading the rest of your post, I get the impression that you would
> be alot happier with a Camaro, Mustang, etc.

I don't know.  I'm going to stick with the Porsche for a while; it's new 
and feels sort of "exotic" (to overuse a word) to me.

However - just because I like HP that sinks the eyeballs in the skull 
doesn't mean that I'm some Chevy man who can't appreciate the unique 
qualities of a Porsche.  My real surprise stems from my humble Volkswagen 
beginnings.  My first car was a VW Bug, and despite all the laughs and 
jokes from the Chevy guys, I cleaned a number of clocks and blew some big 
Detroit iron away with 2-liters of normally-aspirated VW air-cooled 
power.  I had dual Webers and dual valve springs (etc. etc.) and never 
even got into turbos.  Seeing that Porsche always seemed like a "big 
brother" to VW, my surprise was that my 2-liter Bug ran low 15's and my 
2.5 liter Porsche - well...I don't know what it runs, but even with a VW 
Bug - question is:  How fast do you want to go?  There was nothing like 
watching the laughs turn to frowns when their 289 cid V8 got walloped by 
a air-cooled 4-banger...heh heh heh.

James

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 17:07:07 -0700 (MST)
From: Tim Jones <timjones@indirect.com>
Subject: Re: 914 smoke problem

Tommy,

> My 914 2.0 is smoking out the valve cover vents and crank vent.
> Looks like gas or water vapor, (white) not black or blue like oil.
> 
> I'm running carbs and have checked everything out with them.
> (I think).  The car runs a little rough at idle, but fine under power.

My first suspicion would be that your are too rich on the mixture.  Try 
adjusting this and lean it up a bit (or lot, from the sound of it).

> I have changed the plugs and the oil, but it still smokes.  When
> I changed the plugs, one looked fouled.  Could I just have a lot of
> gas that got dumped in the motor, that's trying to burn off?  It
> started doing it all of the sudden and would not idle until after I
> changed the plugs.  

Replacing fouled plugs with good ones will help for a while, until the 
new ones foul!

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 17:24:03 -0700
From: sss@ole.cdac.com (Stephen Sugiyama)
Subject: Re: carerra questions

"Elliot Lee" <elliot_lee@qm.symantec.com> wrote:
>Hi, my name is Elliott Lee and I'm new to this list.  I have a 1988 Carerra
>Cabriolet and I have a few questions.  About 5+ months ago I had my clutch
>fixed -- I was having extreme difficulty putting it into gear.  Lately if I'm
>driving at low rpm's i can hear the rear of my car vibrating.  It sounds like
>the license plate vibrating against the bumper, but I can't tell because of
>course I'm driving.  It seems to happen say if I was shifting to 2nd at a low
>rpm and start accelerating.  It really sounds like something is loose.  I tried
>putting something between the license plate and the bumper, but it still made
>the noise.  Could this have anything to do with the clutch service?  I think I
>have to be moving in order for this to happen.

The '87 and later Carerras have the G-50 transmission.  I've been told that
all G-50s make a groaning vibration noise at low speed when under load.
Mine does.

Other than the noise, it's a strong transmission; it's also used on the 930
of the same period.  And the G-50 syncros seem hold up better than the
earlier 915.  But the clutch had some problems that were apparently fixed
in various updates over the years.  My clutch was replaced (by the previous
owner) at 45K miles.

Stephen Sugiyama
1988 Carerra Coupe
sss@cdac.com



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 17:28:11 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: 911 valve adjustment

Bill,

> 1. what is the proper procedure for getting the feeler in
> correctly, should I loosen the set screw way up and go from there (what if
> I just wanted to check the clearence and not necessarily set it).  I'm using
> one of the blade type feelers, should I be using the "wire" types?

You should have a special Porsche feeler gauge with a bent handle 
and replaceable blades (buy a half-dozen spare blades when you
get the gauge). Some guys grind the handles to provide 
additional clearance. Yes, you should loosen the adjusting screw
a lot so that you can easily get the feeler gauge in.

> 2. How much pressure on the feeler is enough, and should that be withoutB
> engine oil all over the place?

It should be snug, but not so tight that the blade chatters when
you push or pull. Oil doesn't matter.

Good luck. It helps ease the frustation if you think up creative
tortures for the engineer responsible for the maintenance-unfriendly
design. He's probably the same guy responsible for the allen-head 
screws on the cam housings - when he designed the castings he didn't 
leave enough room for regular bolt heads.

 -Mitch

my questions about getting my first 911, and thanks also to the water pumpers
who tried to talk me out of it, don't worry I'm not telling who you are! :-) I
don't want to see anybody who is sharing their honest feelings to get Flamed.

My S.O. and I have read all the responses to my post and Brian Yee's mini
FAQ's.  I was suprised at the difference in the response to Brian's post,
which seemed to run "Don't do it on your(Brian's) budget :-( VS. the response
to my post, for which the consensus was "GO FOR IT!"

After reading the responses to Brian's post my S.O. is really worried, but I
think I may have found a compromise to start with .... a '76 912E.  At least
it's a 911 body, and with the Type IV motor I think we can get it repaired
even out here!  And I can write a check for one! DLIsPF :-))  I seen several
posts for the '76 912, they seem to be running (asking) 6.6k(straight Driver)
to about 12K for "pristine".  What's this car really like?, what's a fair
price?, should I hold out for an SC?,  will a912E hold it's value?, i.e. can I
drive it for a couple of years and then trade up without losing a bunch of
$'s?  I like the fact that if I scatter the engine I can buy one complete for
less than the top end on a 3.2!  I'd like to hear the pro's,  con's and
history of this car.  And yes, if you know of a "good" one for sale, your
welcome to write as well.  

Still Looking!
