Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 19:43:41 -0500
From: Mark A Skala <skala@ecn.purdue.edu>
Subject: re: 914 gas mileage

I had to put in my 1/50th dollar on this one, since I just made a 1000+
mile trip in my 1.7L 914, and got 37mpg.  I will grant you, this is
all highway, and I never really drove hard, just 65-70mph.  This car
has the stock FI but has (I think) 135000 miles on it.  The key to getting
good mileage should be to keep the tuning good, adjust those valves,
make sure the fuel pressure is within range, and check that pressure
sensor (D-jet only) for leaks by blowing in it.  As I recall, my 2.0
from years back would only do about 30 under similar circumstances,
but I think it was more worn out, too.

Mark Skala          '73 914
mvmas@mvujc.att.com '88 924S

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 18:02:36 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: 911 vs. 912E for first P-ca

Dear Chris,

The 912E was made strictly for the US market as a stopgap between the
phaseout of the 914 and the introduction of the 924.  It seems to have
held its value very well, as the car sold for about $12-13K when new.
If you get a nice one and keep it that way it should not go down at
all; in fact, since there were relatively few of them, its value may
in fact go up.  It's already done better in that department than the
911.

The upside is the easy maintenance and economy of operation.  The
downside is performance:  the engine of a 914 in a heavier body.
That's why it would never do in Europe, where a Porsche would be
expected to perform nearer its limit on a daily basis.  If you're
talking performance, there's no comparison.  If you want a car with
the eyeball of a 911 and the economy of a VW, then the 912E might be
for you.  I don't know of any for sale, but look for a stock one with
no accidents, maybe even original paint.  Finding a nice example with
a motivated seller may not be easy.

Good luck.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

------------------------------

Date:          Mon, 5 Jun 1995 21:21:45 EST
From: "KEN STANTON" <KSTANTON@mail.fas.yorku.ca>
Subject:       Porsche Dealers From Hell


Hi folks. I sent this to Gary Cook earlier, when I was still even 
*more* wound up, and with his advice, I have edited it for general 
consumption. I hope I removed a sufficient number of expletives and 
I *still* might send it to the Globe and Mail, Canada's nearest 
substitute to the Wall Street Journal  ;- )

I have owned a 1981 924 Turbo since 1989 and with the help of Gary, 
Kelvin, Paul, a bunch more fellow $931-ers, and Pfiles, I have managed 
to keep my car running most of the time even though I haven't always 
tricked the Bank Balance Sensor, and even repaired most of the damage 
done in the past, by often highly recommended Porsche, specialists. I 
have like most well seasoned $931-ers, been sorely tempted to burn 
this sucker to the ground on more than one occasion but so far, that 
first on-ramp has been sufficient to stave off my wrath. Still, the 
car keeps it alias -WCFH, The White Car From Hell...

In my early experiences, I knew very little about where to get good 
service, or parts but I slowly caught on. I eventually became a 
Stoddard's Fan Club Member, even though I had to endure the 
ridiculous import duties, shipping charges, and lag time of having 
parts sent over the border to Canada. They are in my opinion great. 
Generally a lot cheaper than the Canadian dealers and always 
plaeasant to talk to whether I want to buy parts, or pick their 
service guys brains for guidance. My experiences with other American 
dealers has been quite similar. No complaints.

Well, I am a poor graduate student, trying to feed one of Porsche's 
more hungry models, and now that the exchange rate has become so 
dreadful, it has become more difficult to continue buying parts 
across the border. Now it is further complicated by the fact that I 
am commuting every week between Toronto and Kingston and I only have 
the weekends to repair whatever goes wrong on the week's 300 mile 
flog fest so I find it more difficult to wait a week or so for parts 
delivery. Therefore I have found myself at the mercy of a few Toronto 
dealerships to a much greater extent than I would ever have chosen. 
My first exposure to these guys was with a dealer called Pfaff, who 
not only wanted $40 (CDN) each for 4 parts that I obtained across the 
border for about $11 (CDN) each, but also insisted in an uncalled for 
surly manner that I first FAX my credit card information before 
he would bother himself to process my order. I didn't bother to call 
there since that first treatment.

I have had reasonable treatment from Downtown Fine Cars, but they no 
longer seem to stock *anything* but must order it which means a 
minimum 4 day wait. Yes I know it is an old car. But 4 days for a 
G.D. filter!!!  :-(
Here's my latest bitch. Can be accompanied to the Alice's Restaurant 
theme music...
it goes like this...
I'm just waitin' for the guitar music to come around...
here it comes..

>From: "KEN STANTON" <KSTANTON@mail.fas.yorku.ca>
Organization:  FAS, York University
To: Gary@porsche.mce.com
Date:          Mon, 5 Jun 1995 18:30:34 EST
Subject:       Pcar dealers from Hell.

Hi Gary. I am still steaming from my latest visit to the local 
Porsche dealer here in Toronto. *So* pissed off that I am going to 
write a letter to Volkswagen  Canada over this *&%$. I scoured 
all over trying to find that vacuum limiter thingy here in town. 
Stoddard's listed it at about $75. I Checked around locally to find a 
used one and quickly figured that the time I was spending was adding 
up to the dealer price pretty quickly, so I called two of the Toronto 
dealers, as well as some Bosch places. Both dealers had the same 
price tag. $134.xx (CDN). Both required 4 days to get it in stock. It 
was running so crappy that I figured it would *have* to be done over 
the weekend so I didn't want to wait 4 days unnecessarily. I called 
another dealer. Same price. BUT, he had it on the shelf. AND he was 
not far out of my way on the way home to Kingston! :^)
I drive up in front of his place and park among the 911's and 968's 
etc. There is a guy out front washing the glass front of the place 
so that I can't get to the front door. He ignores me. Just then I 
remember I have a fragment of what I believe is part of the innards 
of the vacuum limiter, in the car so I do an about face and retrieve 
the bit of rubber. This time he looks up long enough to growl that  
the service entrance is in the back. I go to the back and find the 
garage bays open and make my way through to the parts counter. The 
parts guy has his back to me and is talking on the phone. No 
acknowledgement yet. Finally the uhhh...extremely friendly guy from 
the front makes his way back through and sees that I am still 
standing there. Asks me if he can help me. I tell him that I suspect 
I need a vacuum limiter, and 
holding out the bit of rubber, I explain that I found it in the 
throat of the auxiliary air regulator and ask 
if he thinks my guess as to its source is reasonable. "NEVER SEEN 
ANYTHING LIKE IT BEFORE" , he snarls. "I've never had an auxiliary 
air regulator apart." I calmly explain  that it is definitely not 
part of the aux. air reg. (I didn't get smart and tell him that I 
was more curious than he, and I had in fact taken an auxiliary air 
regulator apart before) but I am reasonably confident that it is 
from the Vacuum limiter, and considering how far I am from home, 
and 
how expensive the part is, I would feel more comfortable if he or one 
of his mechanics were able to identify the piece. This is where his 
cork pops. "WeLL! I am LUDWIG HEIMRATH!! AND IF I HAVEN"T SEEN THAT 
BEFORE THEN THE MECHANICS HAVEN"T SEEN IT EITHER BECAUSE I AM THE 
HEAD MECHANIC AND I TAUGHT THEM *EVERYTHING* THEY KNOW!!!!!! SEE THIS 
GUY HERE AT THE PARTS COUNTER. He will sell you anything you want! If 
you think you can diagnose a turbocharged Porsche, then I wish you 
luck! These guys who work on them everyday find it is sometimes 
difficult! There! Let him fix you up! I can tell you that I have 
never had to replace one of those things on a car yet! "
Knowing that this total fucking asshole has the only in stock one of 
these damned things, I keep my cool. I don't tell him that I 
have 100,000 miles of personal experience with this piece of 
shit, nor do I tell him that I have the collective experience of 
all of the rest of the $931-ers on Pfiles and perhaps if he had 
an I.Q. even marginally above room temperature, he might learn 
things from the people who drive *and* fix these damned things. 
No. I keep quiet. After he nips around the corner, 
I ask the parts guy why his boss is so obnoxious? He informs 
me right away that Heimrath doesn't *have* to sell *anything* to 
anybody. Besides, they do all the diagnosis in the back. If they had 
to answer questions from owners all the time they would need two more 
full time people. I 
bite my tongue. I make no comment about getting a hell of a lot 
more help from Stoddard's and neither do I comment about the 
wonderful and enthusiastic assistance I have grown accustomed to 
from fellow Porsche enthusiasts. I shove my MasterCard across the 
counter to pay still not providing any indication as to just how 
steamed I really am. He sneers and tells me that "they don't accept 
MasterCard. Only Visa."  
"Where's the nearest cash machine?" I politely inquire. He directs me 
across the  street to a Royal Bank. I return with the bucket full of 
cash. While paying I *sweetly* inform The Twerp that I am on the 
network with a 
*lot* of other _Porsche enthusiasts_ and I have become accustomed to 
Porsche people being very helpful, and friendly and that's why I 
found it difficult to understand why _Heimrath_ was behaving like 
such a TFA. "But. THAT'S NOT A PORSCHE!!!!", The obnoxious 
bloody Twerp snarls. Miraculously, I don't wollop him over the head 
with the gold plated part, but bite down hard on my tongue, vowing to 
get even somehow.
Apparently everybody around here knows this guy is an asshole. The 
next closest dealer, Pfaff, is hardly superior. 
Heimrath used to race for Porsche back when there were no Canadian 
racers and he made a lot of money. Now they still think it is ok for 
him to treat customers like shit or do whatever the hell he pleases. 
Volkswagen Canada has the whole game up here. I was told by a VW 
dealer that they are in deep shit all across Canada because none of 
their cars are getting off the lots. This is the third Canadian 
dealer I have encountered up here and NONE of them have made it above 
a grade of shitty, where service is concerned. 
This is a new low though. I am still wound up just thinking about it! 
I definitely will write a bleeding letter to the idiots.
I always thought I'd like a 911, but maybe those BMW's, Nissan's and 
so on deserve a much more serious look when I finally have deeper 
pockets. I really think the days when luxury car dealers could 
get away with that nonsense are gone. At least I hope they are. >:=> 
Grrrrrr.... Latuh. Ken.


P.S. It _was_ a faulty vacuum limiter. The car runs better and I took 
the limiter apart to see what makes it tick. Of course if I was a 
perfect mechanic like Heimrath, or if I only was allowed to know what 
He taught me, I'd know that  the person who drives and fixes the car 
couldn't possibly know anything about this car and therefore 
the problems are just my imagination. Gary, it's like the Pcar guy 
you talked to in Reno... "Vee haf no problems vis hower kars!"  ;-)


Ken Stanton
Doctoral Program (Finance)
York University

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 21:51:15 -0400
From: L8Apexer@aol.com
Subject: 951 cold idle problem

I recently put in a new clutch and while at it a light flywheel by Bremtek in
89 951.  Car has Autothority stage 2 chips and has run fine for 4 years with
these.  Car has 34k miles about half are driver's ed events.  Car now idles
rough when cold but fine once warm.  It tends to hunt from 5-1400 rpm.  Every
obvious thing has been checked and now the mechanic thinks there's a glitch
in the Dme box.  He's put the box in the frig and this reproduces the idle
problem.  Then he'll let the box warm up and it idles fine.  I really don't
want to shell out $1700 for a new box!  Any input would be greatly
appreciated.
L8Apexer-John Lochner

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 00:42:41 -0400
From: "Daniel G. Pouzzner" <douzzer@prez.mit.edu>
Subject: Re: Questions

I get a similar sort of sound in my antique '79 928. Emissions are
clean as a white sheet, which makes me think it's not valve-related
(correct me if this conclusion is unwarranted). The "guy at the
Porsche place" thinks it's the airpump. It does not, in fact, seem to
be emanating from the block at all, but rather slightly in front of
it, and below the level of the valves. Pop the hood and see if you can
localize the sound. I ran into a guy today who's stripping an '84 928
for racing purposes, and he commented that the rocker arms in these
engines have a tendancy to stick. He also checked my oil level to make
sure I wasn't some sort of idiot :-).

98 RON =~ 94 US Octane (CLC). I would think it's quite OK to use 93
octane fuel as is. Go much above that and you're talking about
airplane fuel, which is 2+ bucks a gallon and 100 (RON, I guess?).

I have seen additives that turn unleaded into leaded (or
pseudo-leaded?) gas in the supermarket, but are there octane boosters?
It sure would be nice to pay $1.25/gallon for 92+ octane gas!

 -douzzer

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 5 Jun 1995 22:30:54 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Colin O'Keefe" <oreilly@crl.com>
Subject: 944 Brake Question

Hi everyone,
My '84 944's brakes just started acting strange last night, and I'm 
wondering if anyone can explain.  I drove the car about 100 miles, with 
some stop-and-go toward the end, with no problem.  At the end of the 
trip, it idled for about five minutes, then I moved it again to park it.  
At this point, I noticed that the brake pedal felt mushy and seemed to 
depress a couple inches farther down than usual.  It did not hit the 
floor, and I was able to park with no problem.
	Today I turned on the ignition (but not the engine) and pressed down 
on the brake pedal.  It felt the same as it always did before last 
night.  Then I went looking for any brake fluid leaks.  Pulled all four 
wheels, examined the reservoir, master cylinder, etc.  I couldn't find 
any, and the reservoir is as full as always-right between the min. and 
max. markers.  The only strange thing I found is that when I jiggle the 
plastic brake fluid reservoir from side to side, I can see a little fluid 
squishing in the seam where the plastic meets the top of the master 
cylinder.  It doesn't drip, but fluid is visible.  Is this supposed to be 
tightly sealed?  The dealer who 
checked the car when I bought it 6 months ago did not mention anything.  
	Is it possible that air is somehow entering the system?  How can 
I test this?  I obviously don't want to drive it until I find out what 
happened....
	Just remembered this-may not be relevent-I parked last night with 
the nose of the p-car facing up about a 15% grade.  Today when I tested 
the brakes it was on a flat surface. ??

Thanks in advance for any help!
Colin O'Keefe

'844 944

>maintenance to replace items that wear out.

Don't get me wrong, I don't look at investment potential when I decide upon 
wheels. But if the car has *everything* else *and* investment potential, it 
should be irresistible!
Heck, doesn't have to be on the top 10 list, if it copes with the Bank 
interest rates around 5% it sure beats a red/green/blue little book with 
figures in it!!

cherio,

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 09:07:13 -0400
From: Barry Chapin (chapin@draper.com) <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: Re: 911 - Cooling Fan/Alternator Noise


Hi,

About your cooling fan/alternator...

For the rattle, check to make sure the fan belt pulley which is
bolted to the fan and alternator shaft is not loose.  I just installed
a new alternator in my 1981 911SC last week, and I forgot to completely
tighten down that shaft bolt.  When the engine was running, it made
a rattling noise.  This bolt should be snug.  It may be hard to tell if
its tight.  Try this - with the engine at idle, open the rear engine
trunk lid and listen for rattle.  If nothing, remove the oil cap from
the oil fill spout.  This will decrease the RPM's of the car and slow
the engine, due to the drop in oil pressure in the oil tank.  
With this decrease or change in RPM's you may hear the rattle.  You
can put the oil cap on then off then on then off, etc and isolate the
rattle.  My rattle from this loose fan/pulley nut would only appear
under changing RPM's, and this slight change allows you to detect it.

Also, check to make sure the fan itself is not rubbing on the fan housing.
This may be from something that hit the housing hard and deformed or dented
it.

Next, get a socket that fits the nut on the alternator shaft, loosen it,
to release the pulley and belt.  Be careful, there are some thin washers
on BOTH sides of that pulley.  Keep track of how many washers are on each
side of this pulley - this determines belt tension by allowing the pulley
to increase or decrease the distance that the belt must ride up or down
inside of its track between the pulley and the fan.  With the nut loose
and the belt off, the fan, and alternator shaft should spin freely and
swiftly by hand - without the feel of any resistance except its initial
weight inertia.  Try wiggling the shaft to see if the alternotr bearings
are shot.  If so, you probably need to replace the alternator, or if you
are a master mechanic and electrician, it is possible to rebuild the
alternator with just the needed parts.

Changing the alternator in a 911 is a job most people can do and it will
save them prpobably $200-300 in labor.  I can send you info (or the list) on
how easy it is to do if you would like.  Another list member helped me
out (H. Wilson Busby - thanks!) with detailed instructions he posted
about 2 weeks ago.  I bought a new alternator from Europroducts for $235.
You can get rebuilt ones for about $150.  Your is a 1971 911 so it may
be less - these even may be VW alternators???  The ONLY tools I needed
were a flat head scrwedriver, the rachet and socket for the fan pulley
nut, a 10 mm wrench, a 13 mm wrench, and an 8 mm wrench.  Also, an alan
wrech that fit the hex nut which held the fan housing clamp in place -
but your car will have 2 bolts instead of this hex nut I think.  I had
to remove and re-wire the alternator 3 times last week, and I got it
down to under 15 minutes to remove it on my third try.  Works fine now,
my windows (passenger side too) go up real fast!!

 -Barry Chapin

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 08:13:09 -0500

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 14:23:26 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Early 944 Seat Removal

On Thu, 1 Jun 1995, George Beuselinck wrote:

> 
> George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology
> Suppliers of Used 944 Parts to Her Majesty
> Orders: 800-all-p944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
> 172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
> 83 944, 97 944S, 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 80 GMC Pickup
> 

Dear Mr Beuselinck

Her majesty ha asked me to write to you on her behalf.

Mam is rather tissed auf with you claiming to supply her with recycled 
944 parts.

Mam wishes it to be known that whilst she has been known to wear wellies 
to feed the corgis, she has never-ever attempted to service german 
machinery, in fact he is greek. The stories about the german seem to stem 
from a misunderstanding, the german machinery was only being used for 
evaluation and was rejected when it was realised that metric screws did 
not have the reliability and longevity of the imperial hardened steel stud.

To quote her highness, "not much sense in putting in one of those 5mm 
jobs where an alf inch whitworth has already been".

Her highness suggests that in future, you modify your patronage claim, 
she is sure that you may claim to have supplied her daughters in law. 
They are both quite happy to experiment with used parts and their wide 
and varied vast experience in this area has often been used to foster 
improved anglo-german relations. 

+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 08:21:02 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 911 vs. 912E for first P-ca

> The upside is the easy maintenance and economy of operation.  The
> downside is performance:  

There's another downside: maintenence. It's a one-year only car, there
were not very many made, it was never popular so no one stockpiled parts
and guess what? Many of the SPECIAL one-year only parts that adapt the
914 2.0 engine to the 911 body are truely no longer available.

Don't get me wrong, I really like the cars (even contemplated racing
one when they became legal for SCCA E Prod) but you gotta know that sort
of thing going in.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 06 Jun 95 08:28:00 PDT
From: "Dayton, Mike" <DAYTONM@hvsmtp1.mdc.com>
Subject: 911 Heel and toeing


Hey,

While "fondling" my 911 this weekend (as my wife likes to call it),
I decided to try to adjust the relative position of my brake pedal
to allow me to heel and toe.  The problem I had (and from what
I can tell, it is a common 911 problem) is that even under hard
braking, my brake pedal was too far above the accelerator to
allow me to heel and toe.  Well, I seem to have fixed the problem.
I adjusted the brake pedal "down" a bit and was even able to
bring the accelerator closer to me by adjusting the threaded rod
that connects the pedal to the linkage just above the pedal assy.

It didn't take much adjustment at all.  Now I can easily blip the
throttle while braking.  This is an *easy* thing to do if anyone else
has this same problem.  I heard all kinds of fixes from screwing
blocks to the gas pedal to attaching another pedal on top of the old
one.  This works fine as long as you don't need alot of adjustment
(I moved each pedal about 3mm).

FWIW, YMMV, et al...

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 09:45:15 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : How to test and R & R 911 shocks?

Steve Cohen asked :

>My '82 911 SC ... guess is that the schocks are gone...
>Anyone have an idea how I can test the front schocks?? 
> I've seen folks bounce the car and say yea or ney, but I dont 
> know what they are looking at and they have a hard time explaining it.

It's hard to test a 911 by bouncing it because they are quite stiff
and the bushings and sway bars tend to bind it up.

I checked mine last week with the following method. It takes more
work, but it's the only way to really check them.

Jack up one side, remove the wheel, and disconnect the sway bar
(another reason people like the older 911s better -sway bar design
is better and easier to work on). You may not need to disconnect
the sway bar, but it lets you lower the suspension arm more.

Now open the hood and remove the big nut on the top of the shock rod.
You may first have to flatten the lock washer. Be careful that the suspension
does not fall down hard when you remove the nut!

Now from below, pull down on the top of the shock to compress it and
pull it out of the top mount. If it's a Bilstein (high pressure) you really
have to pull hard.

Now you can feel the shock through it's full range of travel. There should be
no weak points or sounds. The shock should be very firm. If not, you are
halfway done with it's removal!

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S

Date: Tue, 06 Jun 1995 09:45:56 -0500 (EST)

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 10:10:58 -0400
From: Barry Chapin (chapin@draper.com) <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: Re: '81 911SC Won't Start


Hi Steve,

> This is a weird one.  For years my 911SC has started flawlessly.
> But for some reason the darn thing won't start today. The engine
> cranks quite well but won't start up.  The only thing I did different  
> today was leave the key in the ignition for a few minutes to the far 
> right position without the car actually running.  Did this somehow 
> burn out some ignition gizmo?   

This happened to me a few years ago on my 1981 911SC.  It turned out
to be the fuel pump check valve.  Was the car warm when you shut it off
and then did you wait a while (say 15-20 minutes) and then it would not
start?  If so, let it crank for about 10-15 seconds, and the fuel will
finally reach the fuel injectors and fire up.  If the check valve is bad,
your may need to replace the fuel pump.  If it did not start first thing
in the morning, it may be the cold start valve.

 -Barry Chapin
1981 Euro-911SC Targa
Northeast (Boston) PCA member.

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 16:23:36 +0100
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Taking the Piss


I was pulled up in my 911 on the A23 fifteen or so miles
outside of Brighton by a large marked Police Jag several days ago. 
The offence was "Taking the Piss", "Taking the Piss in a Red 
Porsche 911" to be precise!

What happened was that I was in a hell of a hurry to get
down to the south coast for my flying lesson, cruised past
the Jag until he was half a mile back and round some bends, 
figured that he was not interested in me, and nailed the throttle 
through my favourite set of sweepers that go up through the South Downs.
El Big Mistake!

Three or four miles further on I saw a tiny white spec in 
my mirror, Oops, I lifted off and slowed down as the tiny 
white dot started to become rather larger very fast indeed. 
Too late, much, much too late. Various scenarios sped through
my mind "Yes, you got me bang to rights Guv, I was the one
wot done it, you got me red handed", or perhaps "you'll Never
take me alive copper, on top of the world Ma!, hahahahaha" or
perhaps "let him have it, Derick" all of which seem to
have been employed in the past. I considered all options, and 
there was no doubt that this was a sticky wicket.

The officer explained to me that I had averaged 89 MPH over 
the distance that he had pursued me, and that since I had 
passed him at 79 MPH and had been pulled up at 70 MPH I must 
have been going indecently fast in order to average 89 MPH.

He also explained to me that he regarded this as "Taking 
the Piss", an offence that I had not heard of before, but 
which sounded sufficiently naughty for me to decide that 
perhaps I should not explain that I was actually holding the 
afformentioned Red 911 back at the time, and that
really it was at it's best at 120 or 130 through the sweepers.

The Officer was suprised that I had Taken the Piss to such an 
extent, and I mentioned to him that I too was suprised at the 
extent and henious nature of of my crime, and I mentioned that 
I had no real explanation for Flouting The Law in such a grave 
and dastardly fashion except for oversight and the human condition. 

I discussed with him the remarkable nature of the oversight, 
considering that they were driving such a large and obvious 
Police Motor Car in the legitimate pursuit of collecting taxes, 
it really was inexplicable and remarkably clear that I had Made A 
Big Mistake.

The Officer asked for documents, all I had was my Class 3 CAA 
Medical Cert. I handed it to the officer, who inquired as to my 
destination, which I indicated as Shoreham Airport. The officer 
then wanted to know what kind of flying machine I was receiveing 
instruction in?, "Fixed wing or rotary?" were his very words. 

Well let me tell you, "Fixed wing or rotary?" is not something the 
non-airhead Police Officer will say to a citizen who has admitted 
Taking the Piss in a public place, and who is all ready to be taxed. 

No indeedie, "fixed-wing or rotary?" is airhead talk! Sensing that 
Perhaps There Is a God After All I mentioned that I was a fixed wing 
student pilot, and he inquired as to perhaps whether I was late for 
my lesson. "Why yes I am" I replied, to which he responded that 
perhaps I had better be Getting On My Way, because It Really Would 
Not Do to be late for one's flying lesson.

Yep, no ticket, no license points, no extra tax to pay, just the 
stern admonishment not to be late. The offence of Taking the Piss 
seemed to have evaporated like AVGAS in the breeze, and I jumped 
in the Red 911 and made excellent time. Yes, perhaps there is a 
God after all. 

################################################################
# Ben Evans, <Ben.Evans@london.sbi.com>                        #
# Salomon Brothers International                               #
# Victoria Plaza, 111 Buckingham Palace Road, London, England. #
################################################################

Date: Tue, 06 Jun 95 11:59:43 EST
From: "Thwen Chaloemtiarana" <chaloemt@vrinet.com>
Subject: Re[2]: Taking the plunge.

Couple things that might help; info comes out of professional house/interior 
painting, though, not _Pcar_ painting, so don't take my word for it.

Thwen.
_______________________________________________________________________________

>3)  Mix the paint VERY well before proceeding....what you
>see in the can is what you get.  A beige colour in a can of
>gloss white paint will actually come out beige.

If you have multiple cans of paint, don't take the chance that they don't 
match.  Box them.  That is, mix a whole can with half a can, then keep adding
to the mixture before it runs out.  Ideally, you'd have a 5 gallon bucket and 
mix a couple gallons at a time.

>4)  Enamel paint may be cheap, but is a b*tch to spray,
>especially if you've never done so before.

You should probably use a paint strainer, too.  Helps keep the spray gun from 
clogging, cause when it does the paint still comes out, just not in a mist and 
you get big, uneven, drops.

Date: 6 Jun 95 12:39:00 EST
From: "LOGISX::GIBBS" <GIBBS%LOGISX.decnet@vaxa.acdnj.itt.com>
Subject: RE: 951 cold idle problem

John- 

Although I have never worked on a Porsche DME box, I have fixed plenty of
other temperature-related electronics problems.  Success rate is generally
about 60-70% if you are patient and careful.

Most temperature-related problems in electronic equipment are due to simple
thermal expansion and contraction.  Something in there has developed a crack,
come loose, or otherwise developed excessive tolerance between parts that are
supposed to be in electrical contact.  At cold temperatures, the parts contract
and the electrical contact is broken or increases in resistance.

Some things to check are - 

Contacts - check the pins on the main connector for wear, spreading, or other damage.
If these are ok, remove the box from the car place it on a grounded worksurface.  
Ground yourself with an ESD wriststrap (available at Radio Shack for a couple dollars), 
and carefully open the box.  Check internal connections first.  If there are any socketed
chips, carefully press them down into their sockets.

Solder Joints - Remove the board from the case if possible and check all solder 
connections, including the ones where components are soldered to the board.  
They should be bright and shiny, with good mechanical contact between the solder 
and the component leads.  Look for dull, corroded connections, or for tiny, hairline 
cracks between component leads and the solder.  If you find a bad or suspect connection, 
you could have a pro resolder it, but it is not that hard to it yourself.  Use a fine tip,
 low wattage iron (25 watts or so), NOT a soldering gun!  Use an iron with a "grounded 
tip" to avoid stray voltages which can damage components.  Heat the component lead (not 
the solder) until the solder flows freely around the lead (a tiny drop of solder between 
the iron and the lead will speed heat transfer and make it much easier).  If possible, 
use a heat sink between the iron and the actual component (hemostats or self closing 
tweezers work well).  When you are done, the solder joint must be clean, shiny, and well 
adhered to all parts.  If not, clean it up as best you can and repeat the process.

Components - If the above do not find the problem, it is most likely a mechanical
defect within a component.  Chips have tiny wires inside them which connect the 
external leads to the IC die itself, and these sometimes become partially detached.  
You cannot repair a chip, but you can replace one if you can determine which chip 
is causing the problem.  Or, a resistor or other component may have developed a 
temperature-related problem.  Reinstall the box with the cover off and start the car.  
Now use a freezing spray (available at any electronics shop) to chill each component 
in the box, one by one.  If you find the one that is causing the problem, start by 
inspecting it extra closely for any external mechanical problem.  If none is obvious, 
it is most likely internal, and you will need to get a replacement.  The box will likely 
contain a mix of standard, off-the-shelf parts and Bosch proprietary parts.  If you
are lucky, the problem will be caused by a readily available part.  Look for part
numbers that start with an SN or an LS (i.e. SN7400, LS7400, etc.) - these indicate 
standard, readily available chips.  Or bring the box to your local electronics store,
point out the bad part, and ask the counterman if it is available.  If you are not 
an experienced solderer, it probably would pay to have a pro install it.  If the part
is Bosch proprietary, you may still be able to get it from a junked DME box (it doesn't
necessarily have to be from a Porsche box, as long as it is the exact same part).  Try 
your local junkyards, or ask here on Porschephiles, giving as much info about the part 
as you can (part number, size, number of leads, etc.).  Some Bosch proprietary parts may
have been used in many years and models, and so will be readily available, others 
may be tougher to find.

Good luck, hope you find it.

Ed Gibbs
gibbs@avionics.itt.com
'84 944, Guards Red, All Mine!

>Scenario:
>
>1986 944 Turbo drives to track running fine.  
>Porsche runs fine at track for two days.
>Porsche drives home from track running fine.
>(Car had been idleing (sp?) at high rpm, 1500-2000rpm, when driven hard at
>track and autocrosses)
>
>Problem:
>
>Porsche now stalls immediately when started.  Porsche will continue to stall
>unless I step on the accelerator and maintain 1500rpm.
>Porsche will not stall after 10 minutes of driving, but will idle very
>roughly.
>When underway, Porsche drives fine. (power seems normal)
>

Hi, Charlie,

Look for a vacuum leak... I know that's a lot to ask for on a 951, but the 
likely culprit.

Make sure that the clamps on the hoses leading to the intercooler are tight, 
and that no 
hoses have loosened...

Good Luck!

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 12:32:30 -0500 (CDT)
From: Chuck Campbell <campbell@Starbase.NeoSoft.COM>
Subject: tensioners - 83 911

I've rolled past 95000 miles quite happily with my nearly stock 1983 911 SC
Cabriolet.  I'm going in for major service thursday.  I hae a couple of 
questions:

The place I'm taking it is trying to talk me into an $1100 tensioner update
and chain replacement (he says it is needed at 100,000 miles).

There has been a lot of talk about these lately, EXACTLY what is the best
thing to do here (part numbers if possible).  I've seen stuff about
spacers, arms of different thickness, etc and it has just confused me, so
what is the best update to make?

I never had an owner's manual, so what needs doing at this mileage?  I am 
assuming the following:

last major work done at 78000 included:
  front brake pads
  pack all 4 cv joints
  new clutch cable
  set suspension all around
  new tires
  new rear torsion bars (broke one!)
  fluids, etc


This time around I'm doing the following:
  Rear brake pads (fronts are new at last service)
  brake fluid flush and change
  Oil & filter
  trans oil change
  clutch adjust (although it was done at last service too)
  valve adjust
  starter replace (intermittent failure due to probably worn bushings)

  do you recommend re torqueing the cyl/head studs?
  anything else I should have done while they are in there, epsecially going
  after the starter?

thanks,
 -chuck

1983 911 Cabriolet (Guards Red)
- --

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 95 10:42:18 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: James Dean 550 Spyder


To Thom Kuby and othe curious folk,

The Dean 550 Spyder was stripped of it's drivetrain and then exhibited 
at various car shows despite the protests of the Dean family. The car 
(remains) disappeared in transit sometime in 1958. I suspect that Porsche
and the Dean family had had enough.

The drivetrain is still accounted for and the pieces exist, the engine 
was in Los Angeles in another 550A Spyder asnd the transaxle in a car in 
the San Francisco area. There was an article in the Panorama about one
fan's research and finding these components.

Due to the impending 40th anniversery of James Dean's death, the press 
will no doubt publish more. 

It is true that Dean had not finished payment on the car. The estate sold
the car to settle his affairs, thus it fell into hands that tried 
to capitialize on the tragic event.

Jim Pasha  

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 10:41:22 -0700
From: dem@best.com (DEM)
Subject: re: refinishing wheels - phone dials

Mine are getting done today, so here's some info:

Professionally, they clean 'em up, paint them a "matching" grey/silver color 
and then clearcoat them.

Robert Wood wanted $125/wheel including center caps.  For $10/more a rim,
they would polish them instead of paint.  For $25/more a rim, they would
chrome them.

I personally don't like the look of polished rims, plus when the clearcoat
fails (it will, eventually) they will look very bad very quickly.

The whole idea of chroming aluminum seems silly and bad chemistry to me.

So I decided to stick with the stock look.

Wheel Techniques (San Jose) wants $60/wheel, plus $15 mounting/removal,
plus $40 for mixing up the paint for the whole job.  If you want the
center caps detailed (black paint inlay) they send them out to a specialty
guy.  Wheel Techniques wants $35 to do this part.  That comes out to
$120/rim.  They have a 10% PCA discount.  So that's $432 for all four
rims.  They use Sikkens paint, if that matters.

The moral of the story:  wipe your brakedust off every day, wax your
rims every time you wash your car, don't use *anything* to clean them
besides car wash soap and water.  Never, ever, ever take your car through 
an automatic car wash (the tire cleaner spray is extremely nasty here).

Hope this helps!

Dennis Mitsch (dem@best.com)
88 944S
74 914 2.0 Special Edition

Date: Tue, 06 Jun 95 10:54:00 PDT
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: RE: Taking the plunge.


Hi Allan,

This isn't my first complete repaint, fortunately.  I did a BMW 5-series in 
the fall, also in Delton.

I have the luxury of using a 'booth' that's an extension that I helped add 
on to my friend's garage.  LOTS of room, lighting top and sides, and best of 
all, a real Binks exhaust fan with filter system.  I also will use a fresh 
air respirator system, THIS time.
I get to use his LPHV (or is it HVLP?) guns too (Sata).  It's amazing how 
much less paint you use.  At $100/gallon, the guns pay for themselves pretty 
quick.

I usually put a balaclava on my head; covers what little hair I have left 
and my beard.  One of those disposable paint suits, too.

Think about using something other than laquer when you squirt your -6.  PPG 
and Glasurit make some pretty cool paints, and they aren't hard to work 
with.  It's nice having something you can spill brake fluid on and not have 
to worry about  it, at least for a short while.

Thanks for the comments.

Bob
>
>>So as not to embarrass myself (or GF), I'm painting my 73T targa before we
>>drive up to Parade. Going back to the original Gemini Blue Metallic, in a
>>Deltron base/clear. DP-40 primer, K-36 surfacer.  I'm lifting weights to
>get
>>my arms ready for sanding :).
>
>I painted my burgundy-orange-red-white-black-light grey
> -dark grey 914-6 last week....now it's mostly white.  I painted
>it to provide some sort of rust protection, and to make it
>one colour so it isn't too much of an eye-sore.  I won't be
>doing the final bodywork until later this summer, or next year
>so this is a temporary paint job.
>
>This was my 1st time painting a car and I learned many things...
>
>1)  Wear a baseball hat or *ANYTHING* to cover your head,
>unless you like "interesting" hair.
>
>2)  No matter how well you think you sealed off a partition in
>the garage, cover everything else outside of your "plastic paint
>booth" because the paint WILL find its way onto the car being
>worked on in the other half of the garage.  In my case it took
>about 3 hours of washing and waxing a black 911 targa since
>it now looked "grey"!!!  Ooops....  :-)
>
>3)  Mix the paint VERY well before proceeding....what you
>see in the can is what you get.  A beige colour in a can of
>gloss white paint will actually come out beige.
>
>4)  Enamel paint may be cheap, but is a b*tch to spray,
>especially if you've never done so before.
>
>5)  Seal off the bottom of the car (ie engine area) unless
>you like a painted engine.  It's amazing how much that
>paint mist gets into everything.
>
>6)  Painting a car in a cramped garage isn't the best idea.
>You may discover you need to be in awkward positions to
>paint, and this may result in runs, and having a greasy
>air hose fall against your wet fender (BT,DT).
>
>7)  You need good lighting to see what you're doing.
>
>8)  Flies like the smell of the paint.  If one lands on your
>wet paint, picking it out will definitely show.  I picked
>out the first fly, then realized my attempt to "fix" it
>didn't work, so I then painted over the next few flies
>that landed on my car.  Perhaps in a million years
>some future scientist can extract the DNA of a fly
>encased on my car and clone it.
>
>My car is a mix of various shades of "white" and also
>ranging from "gloss" to "flat", with a couple of good-sized
>runs on it.  From a distance it looks great, get a little
>closer and you'll see it for what it is - a temporary
>paint job worth every penny I paid for it!  :-)
>
>But it was fun.....I'd do it again, but with laquer paint
>or some other type which has the sanding/polishing
>features of the laquer.  I'd also rent a spray booth
>and wear a baseball hat!!!   :-)
>
>Allan
><ajohanson@ea.com>
>'75 914-6  3.0 SC
>

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 10:54:31 -0700
From: pjb@cco.caltech.edu (Paul J. Brewer)
Subject: Low Gas Mileage in 924S


Last year, at 20000 miles I got 20mpg when I bought it.
Now at 37000 m,iles I get 16mpg.

Its never been "tuned" vbut it has had quite a bit of work.

Done Recently:

Ran through some techron and checked the tire pressures.

Done this year:

Water Pump. 
VALVES (mechanic screwed up -- yes it was a Porsche person )
(Only the intake valves were replaced, indicidentally. )
FUEL TANK LEAK.  Supposedly all the rubber hose up above the tranny
was replaced, too. 

Driving habits...Well I drove it pretty hard when I first got it. Yet 
I got 20 mpg. Most of the time it was driven 40-50 freeway mi per day.

Now it sees 24 freeway mi per day (12 mi each way).  

Also, it was a california car., It had a lot of trouble in the winter here
in Atlanta, where it does fereze.

Paul Brewer
pjb@cco.caltech.edu
'87 924S

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 13:58:39 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Porsche Autocross information - part5

Hi,

I have been asked to submit my columns on autocrossing Porsches
to the archives. Here is the fifth of nine(?) columns. Please let
me know if there are any mistakes or omissions, or other questions
that I should answer. I am editing and submitting them one at a time,
and will upload the whole thing after final editing.

There have been several requests for permission to use this material
in PCA newsletters, etc. Please ask before using it, but basically
any PCA use will be granted if the author is noted. If not too
difficult, I would like a copy of the publication with my material.

	Three-Wheeling by Mike Piera	Part 5

	Setting up a Porsche for stock class autocrossing

	"Every Porsche ever built is a race car."

	"You can't make a race car out of a pig, 
	 but you can make a very fast pig!"

So we must maximize our Porsche's autocross abilities so we will 
not be beaten by any "pigs".

Starting with the basic car condition : everything should work
properly before getting involved in the details. You should
check the engine condition with a leakdown tester, which is
much better than a simple compression guage. By forcing compressed
air into each cylinder and reading the leakage, the valves, pistons,
rings, and seals can be checked. If there is much leakage, it is
easy to determine the culprit by listening for the hissing sound
in various places. If your engine proves to be worn-out, you will
need a rebuild. Excellent luck, as you can easily balance and
bluprint the engine while it is apart! Most rules do not allow much
blueprinting, all that is needed is weight and volume matching of
components (pistons, rods, cylinder heads, etc) so that your engine
runs smoothly and evenly. Some rules allow a slight overbore with
bigger pistons, which I recommend if possible (water-cooled engines).
Note that SCCA stock rules no longer allow this type of blueprinting
other than by matching unmodified factory parts. This makes it more 
expensive to balance an engine, but it can still be done.

	Ignition components (plugs, points, wires, cap, etc) should
be in perfect condition or replace them with genuine Porsche parts.
Don't try to save a buck at K-Mart! Ignition timing should be set
as advanced as the factory spec allows. A new air cleaner should be
used, or a cleanable K & N type (be careful on the 944 series, as the
K & N has been known to leak!). On cars with catalytic converters,
much power can be lost by a clogged-up cat. If your engine runs out
of breath at high RPMs, have the exhaust back-pressure checked,
try a "power tube" cat bypass, or just crack-open the exhaust pipe
before the cat to see if it improves. New cats are very expensive
but worth the performance and economy. Valves should be adjusted
and cam timing set correctly. The fuel mixture on older cars should
be not be adjusted too rich, you want good throttle response rather
than ultimate top-end horsepower. 

	Brakes are the next important item to check. Make sure
your pads are in good condition. Factory pads are OK for autocross,
but "soft" pads like Repco and some of the new carbon pads are better.
Stay away from hard road-racing pads like Ferodo DS-11 because they
have poor performance when cold. Rubber brake lines on older cars
should be replaced with new factory rubber lines. Many aftermarket
"high performance" steel braided lines are of poor quality and even the
good ones are not much better than stock. Steel braided lines must be 
replaced often, as they seem to fail regularly. Bleed your brakes 
carefully, purging all air and old brake fluid from the system. 
A pressure bleeder such as the easy-bleed seems to be the best
choice, as the vaccuum type tends to suck. Check the balance of your
brakes by locking up the tires at 25 MPH or so with an observer.
The fronts should lock up first, but you should be able to lock up
the rears with a little more pedal effort. Check that one side is not
locking up well before the other side. Don't go overboard and flat
spot your tires!

	Suspension bushings are the next "wear" item to check. Replace
any rubber sway-bar bushings which are cracked or distorted in shape
with new factory bushings. Aftermarket plastic or nylon type bushings
will not improve handling much over new stock bushings, but will make
the suspension harsher and noisier on the street. And only stock bushings
are allowed on the rear sway bar or any suspension points in SCCA classes.
Suspension bushings on older Porsches are not easy to replace.
911 front A-arm bushings are not normally removeable and new
A-arms must be purcha$ed to replace worn out rubber bushings. The old
rubber bushings can be cut off and replaced by aftermarket hard plastic
bushings, but these are not legal in SCCA stock classes and make a car
harsh when driven on the street. 911 rear spring plate bushings 
are very important. The spring plate must be replaced to install
new factory bushings. This is expensive in both parts and labor.
"Sway-Away" adjustable rear spring plates are legal in PCA, and
make adjustments much easier. Contrary to popular belief and
advertisements, the adjustment screw does not have enough range
to change the ride height much, it is useful for corner balancing.
But the advantage to these spring plates is that only a small 
part of the spring plate needs to be removed to re-index the 
torsion bar. This can be done without disturbing the camber
and toe-in adjustments. All of these bushings mentioned can be 
replaced by the hard plastic type legally in the Porsche club PCRs.
	
	Shock absorbers are extremely important in stock class cars,
as they are one of the only improvements that are legal. A Porsche
with perfectly functioning factory sport shocks (Koni, Bilstein, etc)
can probably use the original shocks, but all others should
be replaced. Koni makes an excellent low-pressure adjustable gas shock
which comes in a "Sport" model that is stiffer than the
normal model. This shock is good for Porsches without adjustable
ride height (914 rear, 924 front, etc) because the low pressure
will not raise the car as much as the high-pressure Bilstein shocks.
The Bilstein sport shocks work well in a 911. They seem to last
longer than Konis, ride better on the road, and keep the tires
on the ground better. The lack of adjustment is not such a big
drawback, as the adjustable shocks just give you one more thing to
worry about adjusting at the autocross (although many others like
this adjustability). Definately get a good pair of sport shocks on the
rear, which is much more important than the front on a 911/914.

	Alignment is one of the other ways that your car can be
made faster than stock legally. First set the ride height to the
lowest useable setting, with the front slightly lower than the rear.
On a 911, this will be when the front and rear wheel arches are at
about the same height. The suspension should not bottom-out on its 
bump stops on a normal autocross course, or it is too low.

	NOTE : in '94, SCCA rules stated that cars in stock classes
	must compete at the stock ride height! This made even sagging stock
	springs illegal. But now any factory adjustable suspension may
	be lowered again.

	On 914s, the front can easily be lowered to give
about 1 degree of slope front to rear (the rear is probably lower
than the front due to sagging of the rear coil springs). On 911s the
front can be lowered just as easily, but the rear is a pain in the
neck (as is the rear on the 924/944). The "Up-Fixin" books from the
PCA have many articles dealing with these procedures and most others
that I mention here. Some 924s/944/928 and Carrera 2/4s with sport
suspension options have adjustable threaded spring perches which allow 
slight lowering very easily. I believe the 993 has these on the front
only. Go as low as you can on most of these cars with coil springs.

	Next, the camber, caster, and toe should be set. For best
handling, negative camber is needed. About 1.5 degrees is a good
starting point, with a little less in front. Much more may hurt
braking performance. More can be used on the rear if the car tends to
oversteer. Caster should be equal on both sides, and I like to have
more than stock (try for the maximum equal caster). The front wheels 
can be toed-out slightly (1/8") for quick steering response on initial
turn-in. The rear should be toed-in slightly (1/16") for stability, 
especially on the 911/914. These settings should be OK for limited 
street use, but be careful on the track at high speeds with toe-out.

	Now the car must be balanced. On most cars without chassis
problems or bent sway bars, there is a simple method of getting the 
car set to baseline levelness. Simply disconnect one end (or the 2
center mounts if easier) of the sway bars and place something in
the driver's seat to approximate the driver's weight. Then try to
re-attach the sway bars and you will see if one side is higher
than the other because the mounts will not line up. Adjust the
sides until the bars line up and you have a basically level car
with no swaybar pre-load. But it is possible to have more weight
on two opposite corners of the car with this method. Try jacking up
one end of the car at the center-line and see if the car comes up
straight and both wheels leave the ground at the same time. If so, you
are probably OK. If not, or if you are a serious competitor, you
should corner-balance the car. The purpose is not to get the left and
right weights equal, but the proportions equal. The left side of
the car almost always weighs more than the right. Fred Puhn's book
"how to make your car handle" has a good explanation of this
procedure, or take your car to a good shop that understands the
concept. For example, if your right side weighs 1200 and the left 
1300, with a 40/60 weight distribution front to rear (mid '70s 911)
then the right-front should weigh .40 x 1200 (480) and the left
front .4 x 1300 (520).

	Now your car should handle better than when it left Germany,
without really modifying it. Next we will look at some more
improvements to make a stock class killer car. In addition to the
PCA autocrosses, you should try to attend some other autocross events.
The PCA is now pushing autocross over track competition in Porsche
Parades, Zone events, etc. because of safety and cost. Attending
other clubs' events will give you an advantage over other PCA drivers.

P.S. the "pig" at the beginning of this article referred to the 935!

More to come!

Mike Piera, Danbury, CT  AnalogMike@aol.com
'72S and '73E Targas, '73 914/2.0

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 95 13:08:15 CDT

> 8)  Flies like the smell of the paint.  If one lands on your 
> wet paint, picking it out will definitely show.  I picked
> out the first fly, then realized my attempt to "fix" it 
> didn't work, so I then painted over the next few flies 
> that landed on my car.  Perhaps in a million years

  One of the biggest tricks of home painting--never paint at night. Every bug
 is attracted to the lights. One morning after I finished a car (the first
 time I'd used Glasurit) I found where a bug had fallen a foot onto the hood,
 and re-enacted the trail of tears before finally falling off a fender. Roach
 prints everywhere. I told my wife that if she saw a roach limping around 
 with blue feet, to please step on it....

  Good thing cats don't like the smell of lacquer thinner !

      - Lee A,     felines Blue, Slimmer, and Thumper (with pink feet...)
                   '70 Mustang convertible w/2 embedded gnats

    Replacing the filter made the car run _much_ better, but it was still very
    slow to rev.  For example, I usually pull about 6K in 4th gear at the 
    top of the esses.  Yesterday I was lucky to be hitting 5,800 RPM by the
    _end_ of the back straight.  I guess I'm down about 20MPH in top speed.

Don't forget, the 944 has *two* fuel filters -- there's one in the tank, too.
If you got some dirty gas, you'll probably want to replace 'em both.

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 12:20:38 -0700 (MST)
From: Tim Jones <timjones@indirect.com>
Subject: 914 Engine Removal and Restore

Okay folks,
 
I've lived with the Florida-itas of my '74 914 for long enough!  So, as of
last evening, I've begun the task of removing the engine and tranny and
performing the major rust restoration that is required (inner rocker,
outer rocker, battery shelf, inner fender well - all passenger side). 
Therefore, I'm documenting the whole process from the perspective of a
novice to the world of vehicle reconstruction and restoration.  Step one
is the actual removal of the plant.  Drained the oil and removed the
various cable bits.  Photos all along the way.  As I progress, I'll be
putting together the evidence of my neophyte status on the 914 Fan web
page. 

I 'may' document the engine rebuild, but I've done that before, so I may 
not be as thorough with the step by step.

Tim Jones
timjones@indirect.com
'74 914 1.8 (getting ready to rebuild!)
'75 914 2.0 (just for the fun of it!)

Hello Phello Porschephiliacs,
	Just got back from my 11:00 court date, took 2 HOURS just to get
to my case!  It was interesting to hear the other cases, though.  The 
judge let a 78 year old man off for running a stop sign at night (just 
couldn't see it officer :^)  then gives full sentence (20 miles over the
limit) to a young man in a BMW who was, according to the officer, "showing
off".  When my case came up the officer described the situation then I 
showed him pictures of my 914 on my uncles trailer beside the "Welcome to
Tennessee" sign on I-40.  This convinced the judge that my car would no
longer be a nuisance in Charlotte, so he let me off.
	So now The Bastard sits next to my brother's '76 914 2.0 in my
uncles barn in TN, warm and dry.  My uncle also stores in his barn a '61
MGA 1600 and a rare early '74 MGB which has chrome bumpers with rubber
pads, rather than the ugly full rubber bumpers.  My sister's '85 VW GTI
also sits there up on stands, victim of a timing belt failure (never 
replaced with 132K miles on it!  I told her to change it but sisters 
never listen :^)  It also has knocking rods, maybe because it only had
two quarts of oil in it when I checked!  ARRGH!  So now she drives the
Toy 'rolla (332K) under explicit instructions to check the oil EVERY 
WEEK while I find a replacement engine for the GTI.  
	So I guess I'll have to do without The Bastard during the week
and commute in the Green Machine (924).  I get up to Chattanooga every
other weekend or so and can run her then.  My brother and I like to go
road carving in the TN back country, each in his 914.  I love TN laws,
it's as close to anarchy in the US as you can get!  Here's to Porsche's
and lonely TN roads...
			Jay Karolyi

'80 Toy 'rolla -hope it survives!

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 13:00:31 -0800 (PDT)
From: sham@acsc.com (Carlos Sham)
Subject: 928 Clutch Master Cylinder Replacement


While my clutch can still wait for another couple thousands miles
before the very end of its life, I discovered that my clutch master
is seeping fluid out when I depress it. It is just seeping at this
time, but I got the parts already to put on it.

I looked through the micro-fiche workshop manual, but it has no
coverage on this procedure. I guess this may be too trivial.
Anyway, here is what I plan on doing. Correct me if I'm wrong.

Description
	The clutch master is hiding below the brake booster. There
	are just two screw to hold it in place, which can be un-screwed
	from the cabinent. There are just two hydraulic connections to
	the master cylinder: One to the brake fluid reservoir, another
	is the line towards the clutch slave. 

Removal
1.	Use a clip to hold the fluid from the reservoir to the
	cylinder. 
2.	Disconnect the tube from reservoir to the master
3.	Unscrew the line that goes to the slave  from the master. Plug it
	with something.
4.	Unbolt the master and take it out.
5. 	Empty the brake fluid reservoir. Later replaced by new brake fluid.

Q. However, the space is kind of cramping. Any technique in reaching the
   master cylinder at ease? Do I really have to take out the brake master,
   brake reservoir, or even the booster to reach the clutch master?

Installing
1.	Connect the line from slave
2.	Connect the line from reservoir
3.	Bolt the clutch master
4. 	Fill reservoir and bleed the clutch system

Q. Is there anything I have to do with the new master before connecting?
Q. Am I over-simplifing the procedure here?

TIA,
Carlos

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 16:04:42 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : How to test and R & R 911 shocks?

Chris Bennet asked me :

> I'm replacing my front shock/strut inserts any day now. Any tricks to
> unscrewing the insert and putting the new one in ?  I'm taking out
> Boges in putting in Bilstein Gas in an '86 Carrera.  

This is the rest of my post about 911 shocks :

Removal can be accomplished without removing the whole strut if
you are careful. Remove the brake line attachment on the inner 
fender to give more room to tilt the strut out. Remove the cap 
on the top of the shock body holding it into the strut. This is 
usually easier with the shock attached to the top strut mount. 
You may also have to remove the dust cover first.
A large monkey wrench can work, and soaking in penetrating oil
will help too. The Bilstein has a special tool for this which is
supplied with the shocks.

When loose, compress the shock and pry down on the suspension
arm (you need the sway bar disconnected for this operation).
Tilt the top of the strut CAREFULLY out of the fender opening, making
sure not to scratch the paint on the fender lip (put some tape on the
lip for extra protection). Also don't pull on the brake line too much!

Now the insert can be removed and the new
one installed. Put some oil in the strut to come close to the top
when the new insert is installed. Put the top of the shock rod 
back into the mount. Now you can tighten the insert collar with
a monkey wrench or special  tool. Then lower the shock again
to put the dust cover back on. Finally re-mount the top of
the shock and replace the washers and nut. Torque to
spec (~60 ft/lbs). Then re-bend the lock washer.

Good luck!

Regards, Mike Piera '72S and '73E targas, '73 914/2.0

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 16:42:30 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : tensioners - 83 911

Chuck Campbell <campbell@Starbase.NeoSoft.COM> asked :

> I've rolled past 95000 miles quite happily with my nearly stock 1983 911 SC
> Cabriolet.  The place I'm taking it is trying to talk me into an $1100
tensioner update
> and chain replacement (he says it is needed at 100,000 miles).

> There has been a lot of talk about these lately, EXACTLY what is the best
> thing to do here (part numbers if possible).  I've seen stuff about
> spacers, arms of different thickness, etc and it has just confused me, so
> what is the best update to make?

The '83 SC has the good late style tension arms, which don't need 
spacers or anything to use the pressure fed tensioners. They also 
work the best with the normal 930.105.053.00 type factory tensioner, 
due to improved geometry with less binding. So you don't need 
spacers either way.

The BEST update would be the carrera pressure-fed tensioners, but
as you said they are not cheap (but the price quoted seems high).
The next best is to simply replace the stock tensioners with new ones,
with the safety clamps. 

As far as a new chain, I'm not sure if it's needed. But if you use a new
chain,
you don't want to use the safety clamps until the chain has a chance to
stretch.

If you don't change the chain, you should get new chain ramps.
They are cheap and not diffucult to install.

Regards, Mike Piera '72S and '73E Targas, too many posts lately...

Subject: 914 "Summer" tech tip

For the summer where heat is a problem and especailly for track, autox 
it is time to remove the engine lid drip tray and store it in the 
garage.

Your engine will appreaciate it.

You asked, "How hard is it to rebuild the calipers
myself with the rebuild kits you can buy? "

What's hard to one person may be a snap to another,
but in this case - rebuilding calipers - the procedure
is pretty simple and straightforward.  I wouldn't
hestitate to try it if I were you, especially since 
there are probably three dozen folks on p-philes
who have done it many times and can guide you along
if you need help.

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 16:34:54 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 "summer" tip

        Removing the rain tray may not be such a great idea in
places where it *does* rain in the summer--unlike California...
Water can cause interesting behavior in electrical systems that
are less than perfect.
        If you do take out your tray, make sure to at least put
a cover over your battery.  There's no need to add extra battery
acid to one of the most rust-prone spots on these cars.

- --DD  (Getting a batt. cover this week)

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 14:56:11 -0700 (MST)
From: Tim Jones <timjones@indirect.com>
Subject: Re: 914 "Summer" tech tip

Concerning the drip tray removal tip -

I tried that one here last Summer in the Arizona heat.  Doesn't do much for 
circulation around the engine, but did help clean the compartment of 
dust.  Unfortunately, it lets MUCH more of the desert dust INTO the 
compartment to be blown back out.  I put it back in place as the dust 
protection was worth more to me than the 5-7 degrees it dropped the 
engine temp.

Tim Jones
timjones@indirect.com
'74 914 1.8 (getting the rust beat out of it)
'75 914 2.0 (driving for the fun of it!)
Keeper of the 914 Fan web page	http://www.indirect.com/www/timjones/porsche/

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 95 15:11:25 PDT
From: bezzant@corp.cirrus.com (Dan Bezzant)
Subject: re: refinishing wheels -- center caps

>If you want the
>center caps detailed (black paint inlay) they send them out to a specialty
>guy.

I did my own detailing of the black paint inlay -- it was really quite easy.
Just brush the black paint into the groove area and wipe off whatever smeared
over onto the cap surface with a rag.  It took maybe 5 minutes per cap.  Don't
laugh but I did this with one of those little bottles of black model airplane
paint and it is holding up great after 4 years.

Dan B.
'68 912

In response to text from Thwen Chaloemtiarana:

If you have multiple cans of paint, don't take the chance that they don't 
match.  Box them.  That is, mix a whole can with half a can, then keep adding
to the mixture before it runs out.  Ideally, you'd have a 5 gallon bucket and 
mix a couple gallons at a time.

5 gallons!?!?  I primered my entire chassis with 1 quart. ;)  

Step 1) Fill your inground pool with 10,000 gallons of your favorite color.
Step 2) Drive car into pool
Step 3) Drive car out of pool and let dry.
Step 4) Paint over any flies that landed on car while paint was drying...

Date: Tue, 06 Jun 95 15:48:00 PDT
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: RE: re; taking the plunge


>  One of the biggest tricks of home painting--never paint at night. Every 
bug
> is attracted to the lights.

Yup...I painted at night - finished up at 1:30am.  Lots of bugs!!!

To answer Doug's question about the fly on my car, it turned
into a little blob.  The air pressure and sticky paint was too
much for the little guy and he just collapsed into a blob.

Thanks for all of the supportive e-mails about this...as I
mentioned, this is a temporary paint job.  The rear fenders
are still held on by sheet metal screws and the front
fenders haven't been "smoothed" into the rest of the car
yet.  More epoxy, bondo and sanding is required.

I'll do this later this year or next year...and I'll bring along
a hard copy of all of the great advice posted here for the
"real" paint job.

Thanks,

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 20:51:33 -0400
From: jfoster@omni.voicenet.com (Jim Foster)
Subject: Re: 944S2 down on power

At 03:18 PM 6/6/95 EDT, Tracy M Nelson wrote:
>jfoster@omni.voicenet.com (Jim Foster) writes:
>
>[ Jim tells of the car's sloth reaching high RPMs and "bucking" at low revs ]
>
>    Replacing the filter made the car run _much_ better, but it was still very
>    slow to rev.  For example, I usually pull about 6K in 4th gear at the 
>    top of the esses.  Yesterday I was lucky to be hitting 5,800 RPM by the
>    _end_ of the back straight.  I guess I'm down about 20MPH in top speed.
>
>Don't forget, the 944 has *two* fuel filters -- there's one in the tank, too.
>If you got some dirty gas, you'll probably want to replace 'em both.
>
Can anyone confirm this?  I know it's true on the older 944s, but I was told
that the S2 has a single filter.

The current theory is that we got bad gas.  The knock sensor is very quick to
retard the timing but very slow to restore normal performance when the gas
improves.  That's probably why I thought things were getting better.  
Disconnecting the O2 sensor sent me back to the beginning as the computer
assumes the worst in that case.

Thanks to everyone who offered advice!
- --
Jim Foster - jfoster@omni.voicenet.com                       (610) 825-4440

Sportster is like having a clipper ship's hailing not               DoD 142
returned by an orphaned New Jersay solid waster barge." -OTL  '91 K100RS16V

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 22:51:06 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : How to R & R 911 shocks

Chris & all,

> Thank you for the shock R&R instructions.  Forgive my 
> ignorance but I don't understand the "Put some oil in 
> the strut" part:

>>  "Now the insert can be removed and the new one installed. 
>>   Put some oil in the strut to come close to the top when the 
>>   new insert is installed. "

> Tomorrow night (Wednesday) is the night !

Sorry I did not make this clear. The insert is not a completely
tight fit in the strut. So pour a few ounces of engine oil in the
empty strut tube before inserting the insert. Then slowly
lower in the insert. You can add some oil if it does not seem to
come up towards the top. 

If you are replacing the original shock, it is probably full 
of oil when you remove the "guts". Then you have to remove 
lots of oil or it will pour out when you lower in the insert.
(The original shock is not a sealed insert, but a valved thing
that uses the strut as part of the shock).

This bit of oil oil helps in heat transfer, and to keep the
insert in place.

Regards, Mike Piera '72S and '73E 911 Targas, '73 914/2.0

Subject: 914 1.8L mileage / 911 wheels, rotors, brakes

 Greetings,
 
 L-Jet mileage:
 --------------
 My '74 1.8L with L-Jet (that's a bit redundant, huh) drove me to Colorado a few 
 years back.  Loaded with luggage for a 6-week trip, about four different Air 
 Force uniform combinations, with a mountain bike strapped to the back decklid 
 and blazing through CA, AZ, NM and CO at around 75-85 MPH where possible, it 
 averaged...
 
 33 MPG.  Oh, and the windows were open!
 
 I don't think I ever got 25 MPH, 'cept perhaps when I first got it and 
 introduced myself to world-class handling and trabant-class acceleration (sort 
 of requires having one foot on the floor at all times: either on the right 
 pedal (thinking that pushing really hard might give some sort of Flintstone 
 acceleration boost) or on the middle one (wishing you could augment with a 
 Flintstone braking system).)
 
 
 911 wheels, brakes and rotors on 914:
 ------------------------------------
 One of the junker 914's I bought has, besides the chrome bumpers and fog lights 
 I got it for, a set of oxidized Fuchs 5-spokes and what I can assume to be 911 
 rotors (radial venting and cross drilling).  I might want to swap this over the 
 the (soon to be) running car.  Is there a correct way to convert?  I don't want 
 to slap this stuff on if the PO used all the half-assed parts, etc.  Particular 
 questions: Are the rear wheel bearings the same? Are caliper spacers OK?  Will 
 offset remain similar?  Perhaps dumb questions, but if someone out there has 
 gone through the process I would appreciate any assistance (I would go look at 
 the car, but it is stored a ways away from me....)
 
 
 Random 914 stuff: 
 ----------------
 -I scraped off about two coke cans full of oil and dirt from the engine case 
 yesterday.  I guess a steady oil leak, a dusty, desert climate and a PO who is 
 too cheap to replace seals is not a good combination
 
 -I checked the Wilson book.  Indeed, book says to install engine first, then 
 transaxle.  I think most here would disagree.... 
 
 -According to responses: I will use the Viton pushrod tube seals, wet with 
 motor oil (of course the way the engine rebuild is going, that will be a ways 
 away.... :-(
 
 Thanks,

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 23:58:17 -0400
From: PIAUDIO@aol.com
Subject: 924 Questions

Shrikumar -
You can buy a 924 relatively cheap, but proper maintenance and repairs aren't
significantly cheaper than a 944. Best buy on a muffler is from PAR Porsche
in NY, about $150. Check the ads in Panorama or Excellence.

IMHO - Take the extra $1500-$2000 you'll spend to make the 924 right and buy
an 86 944 - you'll like the extra HP, 4 wheel disc brakes, etc.

Paul Ingebrigtsen
'79 924

Date: Wed, 07 Jun 1995 00:27:10 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Distilled or Non-Distille...


>I run distilled water with Red Line "Water Wetter" which improves heat
>conductivity and also (recently added) has corrosion inhibiters in it. A
>little anti freeze is also useful as it will raise the boiling point as well
>as lower the freezing point of the mixture.
>
>If you plan to run on the track, you will be loved by all if you eliminate
>anti-freeze from your system and replalce it with distilled water only. Anti
>freeze is worse than oil on the track surface and can cause long delays for
>mop up in the event of a spillage.

Make sure that you include a water pump lubricant in whatever mix you
run.  Antifreeze has it, as does one of the Redline Water Wetter products
(the powder vs. the liquid form, I think).

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 07 Jun 1995 00:47:52 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 

Hi Hans-Petter,

Let me answer what I can of your questions.

2. DME adaptation.  I have never seen an official statement of what the
ML.3 DME adapts.  But I have been told that there are two basic kinds
of learning it does:

  1. It will retard the spark timing of individual cylinders to eliminate
     knock.

  2. It will ignore sensors whose signal values are obviously out of
     range (eg, a resistive sensor which is zero or infinite impedence).

6. Rainwater at the bottom of the luggage compartments.  This will happen
if you are missing the rubber one-way valves which insert into the drain
holes.  They do tend to fall out.  The part number for the left and right
"cubby" valves is 111.801.177.  That for the spare wheel well is 111.701.309.

You can also get rainwater in the cubbies if the sunroof drain hoses are
not right.  In particular, there is a T-fitting hidden under the right-side
carpeting.  Make sure it's hooked up.

It is very common for the rear lenses to take in rainwater if not resealed
properly after removal and replacement.  There is a seal kit for them,
from VW is fact, but I do not have the part number handy.  I can dig it
out if you need it.  Typically, the lenses will fill with water, more so
than letting water into the cubbies.

It is *not* normal for water to enter the car.  I drive mine twelve months
a year, and it is perfectly dry on the inside at all times.

9. Someone else posted the part number...

10. In the US, the '87 944S was designated with "model order code"
944 342.  It has no meaning other than something for the salesman to 
write on the order form.  I do not know what the other option codes
mean in your list.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 6 Jun 1995 22:10:16 -0700 (PDT)
From: James Wood <jamesw@PEAK.ORG>
Subject: Continuing 944 thread



Thanx again to all who have contributed to this thread.  One can learn an 
enormous amount of information about Porsches in a comparatively short 
time via this list!

And now to quit pissing about 944 hotrod prospects....  Despite my 
inquiries about more HP, I can't say that the car is unpleasant to drive, 
nor can I say that its performance is bad.

There are a lot of neat things about the car.  It's difficult to put into 
words some of the things that I like about it - the styling?   Compared 
to other kinds of cars, there's some really cool styling in there, but 
there are NO gimmicks.  What's a gimmick?  I bunch of wild decals, gaudy 
tape-stripes, wild paint jobs, and tacked-on spoilers to give an ordinary 
car an illusion of being a performer.  There is a spoiler on the back of 
my 944 (all 944's?), but it fits in nicely with the lines of the car.

Subtlety?  Perhaps that's what I can describe it by.  When I get in the 
car and look at the dashboard, it seems so "German" and the gauges are 
the coolest assortment of any car I've owned - no gimmicks (like the LCD 
dash of my former Corvette - a $1000 maintenance nightmare if anything 
goes out) - no sharp angles in an attempt to "be cool" - just subtle 
signs of quality.  [note: I looked in an older 944 and I didn't like it 
as much as the newer ones - no offense].

Interesting is the reactions that even my "low end" 944 receives from 
observers.  [It's mint condition, black, all polished&waxed]  It gets 
more recognition than my big loud punch-packing Corvette did.  My mom is 
a good example.  She isn't really concerned with cars at all and doesn't 
pay much attention.  She could hardly tell my Corvette from a Camaro I 
used to have.  However, upon seeing my 944, she asked me "Where did you get 
that fancy car?"  She knew it was a Porsche immediately!  My boss's young 
son was absolutley MAD about the car, and I had to let him drive.  After 
we went for a short trip (he didn't even make the tach swing very far), 
it was obviously an important experience for him...heh heh heh.  The 
verdict: PEOPLE GO MAD OVER PORSCHES!!!....even my meager 944!!

I can see why Porsche drivers are some of the most "loyal to their brand" 
of any make.  Before I got this Porsche, I never seemed to pay much 
attention to Porsches - I did notice/lust for ones that were right under 
my nose, but now I find myself looking for Porsches (even unconsciously) 
when I'm on the road.  Even when I'm not looking, my subconscious picks 
them out.  Now I'm at the point where I wish I could guess what year car 
I'm looking at - but have insufficient information.  I can't even tell 
what year another 944 is!

I'm also interested in the history of Porsches - all of them.  How did 
the 944 come to me?  What is the relation between the 944 and the 924?  I 
am nuts about both the 928 and the 911.  From my casual observations, the 
911 becomes better-looking and faster with each year.  The 928?  There's 
a very interesting car - I love the back end - first saw one in the movie 
"Risky Business (Tom Cruise) years ago.  Am I correct in my assumption 
that every 928 hauls ass?  Don't they all have V-8s?  When did this car 
debut?  I'll bet it was waaaaaay ahead of its time when it did.

Rambling mode off....I did get the FAQ but want more information.   Is 
there any book that charts the changes and gives history of the Porsche cars?

James
88 944
