Porschephiles #1461                         Wed Jun 7 02:00:09 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 06 Jun 95 22:23:24 PST
From: "Don Schmidek" <dis@metricom.com>
Subject: Re: 912E as a first time

     Well here is my experience with a 912E -- it was an  association that 
     lasted 16 yrs!!!  I purchased the vehicle in 1979, it had:  A/C, SR, 
     El. windows, leatherette interior, 15" rims/tires, thermos removed, 
     etc.
     
     I had to have the engine redone twice in 60K miles -- first time 
     because a gallery plug between the two engine halves fall out -- 
     caught in time, but engine had to come out and be fully dismantled.  
     So -  we did it right, and did a full re-build - pistons, jugs, 
     camshaft, clutch,  etc..
     
     Three or four years later, the crankshaft end-seal (?) blew, and oil 
     spilled all over -- again caught in time (just as I pulling into a 
     gas station) but again total take apart.  This time crankshaft 
     regrind,  again new jugs and pistons, bearings, etc.
     
     I appears that most of the problem was due to the HEAT from the A/C 
     heat exchanger -- mounted in the engine air intake, which just 
     preheats the air, and overheats the oil, etc.  On hot days with A/C 
     on the temp gauge would get close to red!
     
     Installed an oil cooler with electric fan in rear fender.  
     Temperatures OK from then on.  I also installed full 911 gauges, 
     Cruise control, Sanyo AC compressor, etc.  Car was "pristine". Note I 
     did all this by myself, thus costs were nominal. I did a number of 
     valve adjustments -- it appears that every 3-5K miles they have to be 
     adjusted - the good about this is that I could do in 1 ~ hour.
     
     Just sold the car -- I paid $10K when I purchased it, and sold it for 
     $12K - not bad as to price, but not good given 2 rebuilds.
     
     I had fun with the car -- but now I have a 91 C-2 -  wow!!! what a 
     difference.  
     
     If I had known then what I know now, I would have never purchased 
     the 912E!!!
     
     So, if you like driving, handling and sophistication, buy a 911.
     
     If you want to be able to maintain the car yourself, save on 
     insurance, oil costs, low yearly license fees, buy the 912E!
     
     It is a good compromise, but it is a compromise -- you have one life 
     to live -- enjoy it!
     
     911 C-2
     633 Csi
     300 MBZ (6TD)

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 08:04:56 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: 993 ABD & ABS Problem

John in a fit of pique writes:
>pedal became very mushy and decided to bleed brakes.  I obtained a huge
amount of air >out of the rear calipers and the bleed nuts were still sealed
with paint.  That tells me that >they were never bled right at the factory if
at all.  Needless to say I'm p*ssed.  Porsche >has some explaining to do 

Before you blame the factory for not bleeding your brakes, which I doubt,
remember that air can get into a closed system by other means.
Perhaps the fluid has been contaminated with moisture, giving it a lower
boiling point. In that case spirited driving could cause boiling of the fluid
in the caliper and the resultant air and soft pedal. 
Have you done any AutoX or track events? If you did you easily could have
boiled the fluid even if it was fresh. Repeated high speed stops would do the
trick.
Replace your fluid and bleed the system carefully. ABS presents no problem
when bleeding. If your problem persists then get worried.
Good Luck
 

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
7:55 am

Date: Wed, 07 Jun 95 15:12:44 +0200
From: Chris Berry <chris@vbo.dec.com>
Subject: 83 944  DME box failure 


The recent mention of an intermittant failure mode on a 951 DME
unit comes at an interesting time.

Some pphiles may remember the intermittant '944 dies' problem 
that I have been having , on and off, for nearly a year now.

Every time I tried to trace the problem, the car would spring back to
life.

I systematicaly went through the entire engine management system, checking
components, cleaning up relays and contacts, checking the wiring, and so on
without a great deal of success.

What I ended up doing was repositioning the DME control box so that easy
access could be gained to the back of the wiring connecter. I then measured
all the voltages under various 'normal' conditions. ie cold engine/ hot engine,
ignition on but engine not running, idle, etc. etc. , then I just waited
for the little darling to go wrong again. And waited, and waited ..

Last weekend it eventualy failed, and I was able to detect the following.

Pin 13 (engine temp sensor) normaly reads 5.00 volts with sensor disconnected.
It reads 0.99 - 1.2 volts with sensor connected and engine warm.

When the car died, it read 0.01 volts . All other readings were OK., and
pin 13 - ground was correct at 260 Ohms.

Conclusion ? The DME box is busted .

Does anyone have, or know where to obtain , circuit diagrams for this little
beast .  Unfortunately I can't even trace this line on the PCB , as it's 
hidden by the part of the casing that acts as the heat sink. To remove the
board completely I need to unsolder the power trannies, and the multi-pin
connector. I am reluctant to do this .
What I would like to do is be able to trace back through the circuit to find 
(I think) a pcb crack, or dry solder joint.

Failing that, what is the general concensus on trying to pick up a used DME
box ?? Availability ?? How often do they go wrong ?? 

All help/advice welcomed.

Chris.

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 9:25:11 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: 944 Bithin' and moanin'

>As most of you know, I've posted numerous question about my 87 944.  And 
>thankfully most of you have responded quite well.  Yesterday, I passed a 
>major cornerstone of my car by reaching 130,000 miles!  But today, I got 
>the estimate for the service required to stop that damn whistling.  It 
>turns out that the timing belt, some unknown set of bearings, and the 
>sparkplugs need to be replaced!  For a grand total of $1000!!!  Yikes!  
>Well, happy mileage to my car and thanks for lending an ear.

FYI, I had all the belts on my car replaced a year ago at the 
local dealership for $300.  The plugs take me ~15 minutes to do
myself and cost less than $10.  Btw, the plug wires cost close
to $200 from a dealer, but you can pick them up for under $100
from a couple of the aftermarket places.  Are you sure they weren't
planning on replacing these too?

Hope this gives you some useful info for pricing.  What bearings are
they replacing?

Ross Stites
'87 951

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 10:30:21 -0400
From: HSpiva@aol.com
Subject: Allstate 911 flood payoff

Thank you all for your good wishes re: the recent loss of my 1986 Carrera in
"the flood" of New Orleans. As so many of you were interested in how much
they were going to give me for the car, I am writing with good news.

After taking receipts for renovations, rebuilds and accessories and a recent
3rd place in a Concours into consideration, they came very close to "high
blue book". I lost some for the 120K on the odometer, but received credit for
the Fuchs, spoilers, sunroof, leather, and the aforementioned work and award.
Basically I got in excess of $25K less $500 deductible {and the banks
portion].

I did inquire re: salvage, but this would greatly delay payment due to
cumbersome payment, transport and storage fees. That, combined with
sentimental reasons, eliminated this option for me.

For those interested, the car is now the property of Allstate and at the
Greater New Orleans Auto Auction in Slidell, LA. It has a blue interior for
those wishing to restore theirs. Most of the vinyl made it thru OK. For
information on bidding for the car, call the auction at 800-783-2062.

I am waiting to purchase another 911 until I am established in California. I
will be moving out there within the next 12-18 months. If anyone knows of
open positions in the preventative health and/or computer sector, please
e-mail me. CA is my home, and I will accept any decent offer in order to get
there.

Hasta Carrera,
Harlan

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 09:37:41 +0600
From: rondl@uscbu.ih.att.com (Ronald Jay De Lange)
Subject: Early 911/912 Transmission Questions


Greetings P-philers,

Well, you may remember my last email about starting my 912 for
the first time, and that 4th-5th gears were not working.  We
got underneath the car last night and tried shifting/moving
the shift linkage through the shift fork opening.  

We can sucessfully move the trans into r,1,2,3, and into 5 but
it pops out when we rotate the tire.  4 is impossible, the
linkage inside the transmission will not move past nuetral.

What could be blocking the 4-5 gear set from completely engaging
5th gear and totally not moving towards the 4th gear?  Visual inpsection
shows no wear on the gears and synchros look fine - given the limited
view.  BTW, we did get the shift fork/linkages correct when we
had everything installed.

Also, is there any reason to believe that pulling the car off the
jack stands and starting/driving it would produce different results?
Is there something that rotates/moves differently when being spun
by the engine that we cant reproduce on jackstands and rotating
the tire by hand?  Synchros?

We've decided that its *not* the shifter (or its rear tunnel linkage
connection) since we cant shift the 4-5 gears from underneath the
car with the shift fork out (using a screwdriver carefully).
And, we can shift all the other gears sucessfully from underneath.

Any help would be appreciated, or its rebuild the trans time....

Thanks (and very bummed out),

Ron D.

rondl@uscbu.att.com

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 16:41:18 +0200

Subject: Conclusions from shipping Transatlantic.

Hiall,

Yesterday it happened, my newly aquired '65 911 showed up at the first
stop on it's way 'home' to Europe. It will leave next Monday, and I
will have it in time for my Holiday.

The car will taste our splendid mountain roads this summer.....

I got some requests from people about which company to use for
shipping, and in my case it turned out that DEAN worldwide, through
CROWN Pacific is a very good choice.

Shipping from CA to Gothenburg, Sweden sums up to $900-1050 depending
on how lucky you get (e.g. last car in a 40 footer?).

I expect to pay $300 for hauling etc in Gothenburg, and all in all
$1200 plus insurance must be considered to be a good price.

cheers,
Trond V.

Subject: unknown bearing (?) in a belt change

When I had the belts done on my 86, they recommended changing the idler
pulley, which contains a sealed bearing. given the labor costs, and the
cost of even a "small" belt failure, I changed it. Added it to my
collection of desktop memorabillia: a valve, two pistons, and now this
pulley.

Date: Wed,  7 Jun 95 07:58:27 PDT
From: Scott=D=Berry%MfgEng%GPID@banyan.BV.TEK.COM
Subject: 022 Distrib. rebuild - HELP!

I am rebuilding an 022 distributor using the Shim kit, new springs, Insulator 
kit and new teflon piece from Stoddard.  I pressed the pin that holds the drive 
gear out successfully and now have a couple of questions.

1)  The springs attach to this plate that is slotted and is held down by two 
screws.  The two screws are only accessible if I remove the drive gear and pull 
out the shaft.  These slots allow you to change the position so that the weights 
can move without actually hitting the springs and also exert more or less 
tension on the weights.  My distributor had the plate tightened down so that the 
screws were at the extreme end of the slots and the spring tension was at it's 
greatest.  How do I determine what position to tighten this plate down?   If 
this effects the advance (which I think it must), is the only way to check it   
to attach the drive gear, press in the pin and install it in my 912?  If it is 
wrong then do I have to press out the pin again and start all over?

2)  Does the Stoddard shim kit designed to fit several distributors?  I have one 
shim size in my kit that doesn't fit anywhere in my 022.  I also have 2 
different types of retaining clips that don't don't fit my 022.

3)  How much movement should the drive shaft be allowed to have at room 
temperature?  When I say movement I mean if you pull back and forth on the  
drive shaft, the shaft will go up and down.  I can easily put enough shims in to 
allow no movement at all, but I would imagine some room is needed for thermal 
expansion.  How much?

Thanx in advance!

Scott

66 912  

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 11:50:59 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: 16 V Heads for 951 and Radar Detector Use

In Ontario, I've seen the OPP follow a car, and blast it with radar. If the
brake lights come on, the car is pulled over. Beware.

The consensus on 16 valve heads is: stay away. The 1979 Lemans 924 turbo
had 16 valve heads, but the 968 RS turbo has a two valve head. Of course
Andial claims to have two customer cars with 2.8 l 4-valvers running, so
you might try them.

doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat



------------------------------

Date:          Wed, 7 Jun 1995 10:01:30 +700
From: JBUTLER@park.admin.utah.edu
Subject:       Re: 022 Distrib. rebuild - HELP!

>1)  The springs attach to this plate that is slotted and is held down by two 
screws.  The two screws are only accessible if I remove the drive gear and pull 
out the shaft.  These slots allow you to change the position so that the weights 
can move without actually hitting the springs and also exert more or less 
tension on the weights.  My distributor had the plate tightened down so that the 
screws were at the extreme end of the slots and the spring tension was at it's 
greatest.  How do I determine what position to tighten this plate down?   If 
this effects the advance (which I think it must), is the only way to check it   
to attach the drive gear, press in the pin and install it in my 912?  If it is 
wrong then do I have to press out the pin again and start all over?

I set mine at the extreme position and the result was 33 degrees of 
total advance. That's in the middle of the factory tolerance range.

>2)  Does the Stoddard shim kit designed to fit several distributors?  I have one 
shim size in my kit that doesn't fit anywhere in my 022.  I also have 2 
different types of retaining clips that don't don't fit my 022.

I had lots of stuff left over.

>3)  How much movement should the drive shaft be allowed to have at room 
temperature?  When I say movement I mean if you pull back and forth on the  
drive shaft, the shaft will go up and down.  I can easily put enough shims in to 
allow no movement at all, but I would imagine some room is needed for thermal 
expansion.  How much?

If you get an answer for this that doesn't come thru "porschephiles", 
could you pass it on? I just set mine so the bottom of the 
distributor would take any  load as oppsed to letting the bottom of 
the contact plate take it.

John, U of Utah
jbutler@park.admin.utah.edu
*Fahren in seiner schoensten form*

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 12:07:54 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: WWW Page recommendations...

I will make these into an HTML that I will post and make available soonly 
(new and useful word).
You do not have to have, but it is highly recommended that for the 
coolest viewing, you use:
* A color computer, preferrably with at least 256 colors.
* Netscape 1.1 or higher (available from http://home.netscape.com)
* A fast connection (at least 28.8 SLIP is recommended, although you can 
of course, slug along at 14.4)

The reasons for these recommendations are that Netscape 1.1 in color 
shows backgrounds, the little colorful rainbow balls, and the font 
changes. It is also form compliant, allowing you to post forms in the 
request area (soon to include CRAP registration). The speed is for 
obvious reasons, the faster your connection, the faster you get to see 
things.

BTW, regardless of using Mosaic, Netscape, or Lynx, the page is fully 
standard, and the same information will be conveyed no matter how you're 
looking at it.
 -Derek Cahill


------------------------------

Date:         Wed, 07 Jun 95 10:58:56 CDT
From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
Subject:      Re: 944 Bitchin' and moanin'

On Tue, 6 Jun 1995 15:48:42 -0700 (PDT) you said:
>As most of you know, I've posted numerous question about my 87 944.  And
>thankfully most of you have responded quite well.  Yesterday, I passed a
>major cornerstone of my car by reaching 130,000 miles!  But today, I got
>the estimate for the service required to stop that damn whistling.  It
>turns out that the timing belt, some unknown set of bearings, and the
>sparkplugs need to be replaced!  For a grand total of $1000!!!  Yikes!
>Well, happy mileage to my car and thanks for lending an ear.
>
>Danny.
>87 944 white.
>
>

Is it a whistle or a whining?

When I first got my 87 944S, it had a rattling sound when the engine
was cold.  Turned out to be the balance belt was so loose, it was
rubbing against the belt housing.  So I tightened it a little to
stop it from flopping.  From that point on, I had this irritating
whine (worse when car is cold). A few weeks later I replaced the
timing and balance belts and all the rollers. Even had the balance
belt tensioned properly with the tension gauge. Still had the whine.
I've heard this is normal with some 944s.  So I hope you arent going
to spend $1000 on a whine that you may not be able to get rid of.
By the way, my timing/balance belt and rollers I got from Zims for
$200 and the mechanic charged $25 for balance belt tensioning.
I'd get a second opinion on those prices.

Oh, I have 131K on my car.

Darren Evans-Young
'87 944S Indischrot
darren@ua1vm.ua.edu

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 09:32:03 -0700 (PDT)
From: "'Beans' D. Tong" <bbaxter@u.washington.edu>
Subject: Re: 944 Bitchin' and moanin'

Actually it did start with a really bad whistling.  At first I thought it 
was cute, for the first minute because it sounded like a remote control 
car.   But I had it looked at and it turned out to be that the timing 
belt was on the verge of falling off within the next hundred mile and 
that the rollers weren't doing their job.  In fact, one wouldn't even 
turn!  So all that needed to be replaced and so did the fuel filter since 
it was still the original!  Obviously the previous owner didn't care to 
maintain such a nice care as this.  The total service maintainance costed 
almost $1000 and I still have to replace the engine mounts since the 
right side is blown to high hell which causes the care to vibrate quite 
violently when I accelerate and sit at idle.

Danny Tong

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 11:42:58 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 1.8L mileage / 911 wheels, rotors, brakes

> 911 wheels, brakes and rotors on 914:
> ------------------------------------
> ... a set of oxidized Fuchs 5-spokes and what I can assume to be 911
> rotors (radial venting and cross drilling).

        The /6 front rotors were also vented.  Beware of the cross-drilled
stuff, though.  Unless it was cast that way (i.e., not really "drilled"),
the holes make for really dandy stress risers which can lead to cracking.
Which is not a good thing.  If you put these on as is, be sure to check
them very frequently.  I don't know if once a week is too much or too lit-
tle, but we're talking about a possible catastrophic failure of your brakes.
*Possible*.

> -I scraped off about two coke cans full of oil and dirt from the engine case
> yesterday.  I guess a steady oil leak, a dusty, desert climate and a PO
>who is
> too cheap to replace seals is not a good combination

        I feel for ya.  I got about 1.5 times that much off of mine.  This was
before I discovered the rebuild was necessary...

> -I checked the Wilson book.  Indeed, book says to install engine first, then
> transaxle.  I think most here would disagree....

        I would.  If you can buy/borrow/fake up the special VW support tool,
put 'em together first and then stuff the whole assembly in.  You'd have to
support the rear end of the engine anyway while you were putting the tranny
in...

        Good luck!

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"



------------------------------

Date: 7 Jun 1995 09:45:20 U
From: "Clark Wallace" <Clark_Wallace@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: VANERRA - Porsche Minivan

Yep, it's a reality (at least conceptually)...

What's up you say?  Well, after missing that last opportunity to get a
glimpse of the Boxster when I let hesitation stand in the way of
unbridled spontaneity, I didn't let a nanosecond pass before saying "yes!"
when a local marketing research firm called asking whether or not an hour
of my time was worth $100 and did I in fact own a Porsche.

The whole interview was was rather fast and furious with computer screens,
spec sheets, photos, and conceptual drawings coming at me at a mile a
minute. The basic minivan looked like a Camry Station wagon/Taurus wagon 
hybrid.  The platform appeared to be closer to the Camry in size, with the 
roofline raised to accommodate six bucket seats (2x2x2).  There was a 
Taurus wagon-like integral roof rack also.  I was presented with 3 front 
cowl, side, and rear configurations all of which were none too spectacular, 
and without the Porsche badge on the hood and C2 turbo wheels I would have 
never quessed the vehicle had originated from the Porsche concept shop.

The specs I saw were as follows.  V6, biturbo, 2.9 liter, 248hp.  All 
wheel drive, 17 inch wheels, "Porsche braking system", 5 speed manual or
4 speed triptronic. Engine was obviously upfront, but none of the
concept drawings showed what was under the hood.  Cost was $53,960 US.

I was also shown some interior concepts representing sport, family, and
business options.  Some of the acoutrements looked rather Jetsonque.
Options included integral FAX/PC/phone hook-ups, onboard refrigerator,
digital stereo, video screens, refrigerated glovebox (The 928 lives on!),
a trash can ($20 <g>), heated seats, traction control, side impact
air bags, equipment racks, super-duper sun roof, and on and on.  A
pseudo ad for the business package I was shown stated the vehicle was 
"The Lear Jet of minivans!".

And I'm not kidding about the name - Vanerra.  Alternatives included
the Maxster, the Magster, and the Verrara.  Hey, take your pick, vote
now.

A  portion of the interview was dedicated to comparing the Porsche
concept to a Chrysler Town and Country and the Volkswagen Sharan and
Sharan RS.  From a cost and performance standpoint they were 
obviously in different leagues, but I'm sure they had their reasons.

Just to reiterate, everything I saw on the Porsche minivan were
drawings, nothing in metal, clay, or plastic. So, I don't think
this baby will be rolling stock for quite a while, if in fact
Porsche chooses to pursue it any further.

Later, Clark  - '89 944s2  (keepin the 944 faith)

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 13:13:35 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: 944 History, very long (maybe boring)

Hi James,

In a message dated 95-06-07 01:21:28 EDT, you write:

>I'm also interested in the history of Porsches - all of them.  How
>did the 944 come to me?  What is the relation between the 944 
>and the 924?  I am nuts about both the 928 and the 911.  From 
>my casual observations,...

Here is a brief history of the 944:

The 944 was first sold in 1983. Actually, the Porsche factory raced a car
called the 924 GTS Carerra (or something like that) in the 1981 or 1982
LeMans race my books are at home). This was a 924 Turbo, with special body
work, that looked VERY similar to what became the 944  In 1983, Porsche
discontinued the 924, and started selling the 944. 

The 944, although based on the 924, was a much better car. It has a real
Porsche engine, with 143 HP (as oppossed to the Audi 924 engine), 4 wheel
disc brakes, and a Porsche suspension. It was an immediate sales success.

Midway through the 1985 year, the car was extensively changed. The dashboard
was redesigned, the steering wheel was raised for more leg clearance, and the
suspension was improved. The car would basically stay the same until the 968
replaced it in 1992. 

In 1986 Porsche introduced the 944 Turbo. The design goals were a 50%
increase in HP and Torque, and no decrease in MPG. The HP went from 147 to
217, and fuel economy dropped by 1 mpg. The suspension and brakes were
upgraded to handle the addition power. I believe that 1986 was the best sales
year for the 944 line. Here are the sales figures: 944 10,901, Turbo 7,513

In 1987 two new Porsches appeared. For increased performance without a
turbocharger, there was the 944S, which went from an 8 valve to a 16 valve
head. For a less expensive car, Porsche reintroduced the 924S, which used the
older 924 body and suspension, with the 944 powertrain. The 944S has 188 HP.
The 924S was actually faster than the 944, because it was lighter, and more
aerodynamic. In 1987, ABS brakes and airbags were available.  

1988 was the banner year for the 944. There was a 924S (924 body, 944
powertrain), regular 944 (8v engine, 158HP), 944S (16v, 188HP), 944 Turbo
(8v, 217HP), 944 Turbo S (8v, 250HP). The 944 Turbo S was the fifth faster
production car in the world, behind 2 Ferrari's, 1 Lamborghini, and the
928S4. It has a top track speed of 162! It also was the best handline Porsche
in 1988, being quicker in slamons and on the track than the 911 Club Sport.
Even though there were all these 944 models, sales continued to drop. This
was probably due to the continuing price increases. The 944 Turbo S model
cost more than $50,000!

In 1989 the model line was changed again. There were now three models. The
regular 944, which tried to improve performance by increasing the engine
displacement  from 2.5l to 2.7l. HP went from something like 158 to 165. The
944 S was changed into the 944 S2 by increasing the engine size from 2.5 to
3.0l, HP went to 208HP, and 944 Turbo (same as 88 Turbo S, 250HP). 

In 1990 and 91 the only 944 sold in the US was the S2, which was produced in
coupe and cabriolet version. 

1992 saw the 968 being sold. The was bascially the same as the 944, with the
front body work being different. The headlights retract like a 928.. The
engine is the same 3.0l as the 944 S2, with the addition of variable valve
timing. This increased HP from 208 to 236. It looks like 1995 is going to be
the last year for the 968, as the 986 or Boxter is due to appear.

Some other interesting notes:

Porsche created a special suspension package for club racing called the M030
option. This included stiffer sway bars, stiffer springs, adjustable shocks,
and a Limited Slip Transaxle. This was standard on the 1988 Turbo S and the
89 Turbo. 

The ultimate 944 performance cars are the 88 TurboS (400 -1000 sold in US)
and the 89 Turbo (700 -1000 sold in US). These cars are really set up for the
race track. They have adjustable shock absorbers, special brake ducts to cool
the brakes, oversized brakes from the 928S4, transaxle coolers, etc. These
cars are
selling for $15 - 20 K depending on condition.

The real bargain car is the 85.5 944. Most people think they are 85's, but
they really are 86's, with all of the benefits. You can find these cars in
good condition for around $7000.

The first Porsche with available ABS brakes and airbags was the 944. This
happened in 87, a few years before they were available in the 911. If you did
order the airbags, you had to order them for both the driver and the
passenger..  

If you have any more questions on 944's, just ask.

Barry Lenoble
Blenoble@aol.com
89 944 Turbo, Alpine White



------------------------------


Porschephiles #1463                         Wed Jun 7 16:27:37 CDT 1995
Date: 07 Jun 95 13:19:17 EDT
From: "Jay S. Karolyi" <102062.710@compuserve.com>
Subject: Shrikumar and his 924 vs.944

Hello Shrikumar and Phello Porschephiliacs,
	Regarding Shrikumar's prospective '82 924 and Paul's suggestion 
that his money would be better spent on an '86 944 I have a few opinions.
For one, I've never seen an '86 944 for $2-3,000 more than Shrikumar's
924, whose owner is asking in the 2K range.  Even '85.5-'87 944s I've
driven in the $7-9000 range are trashed and in need of AT LEAST as many 
repairs as Shrikumar's '82 924.  Also, parts for the 924 ARE significantly
less expensive than 944s.  Where can you find a 944 muffler for $150?  A
friend of mine on p-philes has compiled a list of 924 parts that are
interchangeable with variable VW's and Audis.  These parts can be found at
NAPA whereas the almost all-Porsche 944 parts must come from one of the
communist Porsche part suppliers.  
	I have freinds with 944's that report up to TWICE the yearly
repair bills of my 924, which last year only needed $228 in repairs.  My
average yearly repair bill for the past five years is $296.53, though I
do small repairs myself (a must with any Porsche).
	Paul does suggest a great place to buy specialized parts such as
the $150 muffler.  PAR in Yonkers NY can be reached at (914) 476-6700, 
but have no 800 number that I know of.  The only thing that bothers me
about his particular 924 is the broken odometer, which can be repaired
(about $100) but never made "correct".  Shrickumar, the best way to make
a deal on a car that needs a few repairs is to find out how much the 
repairs are going to cost, show them to the owner, and ask that this 
amount be taken off the price.  I still think that around $2000 is a 
good deal on an '82 924, which is a fairly rare car.  Write back and tell
me (or us :^)  about the condition of the car and what other repairs it
needs.  Hope this helps!
				Jay Karolyi
'75 Corvair/914 "The Bastard"
'77 924 "The Green Machine"

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 95 11:14:12 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Broken 944 three-spoke steering wheels


Chester,

This is more common than you think. I have broken two three-spoke 
steering wheels (two different cars) while autocrossing. The welds 
actually fail. This is due to the high level of effort required to 
turn sticky tires with no power assist.

When you replace the wheel, I will highly recommend the 4-spoke sport
steering wheel. It is slightly smaller in diameter and a little easier 
to grip. Perhaps George Bueselinck can help you georgeb@mhv.net. 

You will need a 24mm socket to remove the remains of your wheel. A
15/16" inch socket is close in a pinch. Set the wheels straight prior 
removing the steering wheel. Make sure your new wheel has all of the 
pads, springs and horn contact with it. I paid around $150 for a good 
4-spoke steering wheel.

Jim Pasha

Date: Wed, 07 Jun 95 10:39:10 PST

Dave,

>        The /6 front rotors were also vented.  Beware of the cross-drilled
>stuff, though.  Unless it was cast that way (i.e., not really "drilled"),
>the holes make for really dandy stress risers which can lead to cracking.
>Which is not a good thing.  If you put these on as is, be sure to check
>them very frequently.  I don't know if once a week is too much or too lit-
>tle, but we're talking about a possible catastrophic failure of your brakes.
>*Possible*.

I realized when I wrote my initial note that I was being misleadind.  Ooops.  
The rotors in question have axial venting that I believe is cast in (nice little
chamfers at the edge, stuff like that.)  They look just like the came that way 
from the factory.  Can anyone tell me which year/model 911s had radial and axial
venting cast in from the factory? (if any?)


>> -I checked the Wilson book.  Indeed, book says to install engine first, then
>> transaxle.  I think most here would disagree....

>        I would.  If you can buy/borrow/fake up the special VW support tool,
>put 'em together first and then stuff the whole assembly in.  You'd have to
>support the rear end of the engine anyway while you were putting the tranny
>in...

 
Yeah -- I am a fan of the single unit install (tranny and engine) although I 
must say that the third "single unit" I removed came out MUCH easier when I 
removed the injectors and rails.  Those things always seem to catch on the body 
where the outboard ends of the engine-mount bar bolts up.  I don't know if I 
will install sans fuel injectors though -- I seem to remember having a hard time
connecting those 2" pieces of fuel hose from the rail to the injectors.

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 95 11:27:44 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Distributor adjustment


Scott-


>My distributor had the plate tightened down so that the 
>screws were at the extreme end of the slots and the spring tension 
>was at it's greatest.  How do I determine what position to tighten 
>this plate down?   

I faced the same question with my '72 911 distributor, and I adjusted 
it so that at rest, i.e., with the weights snugged in, the springs were 
neither loose nor under tension, but just ready to stretch as centriptal 
force cause the weights to swing outwards.  Works fine.

>check it   to attach the drive gear, press in the pin and install it in my 
>912?  If it is wrong then do I have to press out the pin again and 
>start all over?

There are special tools, like a Sun analyzer, that allow you to check 
advance curves with the distributor out of the engine.  You can take it 
to a shop that has one.  You can also put it in the engine and try it.  


>How much movement should the drive shaft be allowed to have at 
>room temperature?  

Had the same question, but in the end I figured it wasn't a real 
important issue.  There really isn't any load to speak of on the 
distributor drive gear.  It sort of just rests lightly on the intermediate 
shaft gear.  I just shimmed it so there was some play, but not much.  
Maybe .003" or .004"

 -Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu
'72 911E
'72 911T

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 95 10:57:01 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re: 914 1.8L mileage / 911 wheels, rotors, brakes

>>> -I checked the Wilson book.  Indeed, book says to install engine first, then
>>> transaxle.  I think most here would disagree....
>> 
>>         I would.  If you can buy/borrow/fake up the special VW support tool,
>> put 'em together first and then stuff the whole assembly in.  You'd have to
>> support the rear end of the engine anyway while you were putting the tranny
>> in...


Actually, there is an easier way.  If you use two floor jacks.  
Put one in from the side of the car and the other from the tail.
Roll the engine/trany on one of those moving dollies (these are
great and reasonably priced.  Or, just put casters on a square board).
Reach under the engine cross bar in the front with the jack moved in
from the side, and under the tail of the tranny with the jack moved in
from the tail of the car.  Now, either with a helper slowly jack up
the drive train and align it (be careful of FI and electricals on the
way up!)  Or, jack a few inches on one, then move to the next and
repeat until you've got the assembly up all the way.  Very doable.
I've done the job both ways.

Pat Norris
pat@ixi.saic.com
'72 914

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 15:39:52 -0500 (EDT)
From: randy@sensor.com (Randy Kirby)
Subject: Re: car cover ?s

> 	well summer is definitely here in northern california and as i 
> park my car outside all day long (gasp) i am looking at purchasing a car 
> cover for protection.  My main concern iis protection from the sun and 
> heat but I would like some level of moisture protection.  I've heard the 
> kimberly-clark evloution series fabrics are pretty hard to beat.  any 
> opinions on what kind I should get and a good place to buy from?  also is 
> there a benefit to getting the custom fitted ones vs the stock covers 
> (are the custom fitted ones really custom fitted??)  are the porsche 
> factory covers a good choice?  thanks for any info.
> 
> mujahid mahmood   mmmahmood@ucdavis.edu
> 

I recently bought a factory cover for my C2 and after using it 2 times
returned it. It seemed a bit cheap to me, a lightweight, thin material,
that was kinda rough to the touch with a silver, spaceman coating that
looked like it would eventually flake off. I then did a little research and
found that the Evolution 3/4 fabrics, although good at repelling the sun
and water, are quite bulky. One would probably fill the entire trunk of my
911. And the Evolution fabric is only moderatly durable. THere's a new
fabric called Tyvek that is kinda like paper surgical booties and hats. No
thanks. Finally, there's Ultralon, a mid to lightweight fabric with a 
slight stretchy quality, provides excellent sun protection and water
repellancy and is quite durable. This is what I decided upon and so far I'm
well pleased. Can't attest to the water repellancy yet, but I like the
weight and the sun protection (South Florida sun is brutal).

I also recommend buying from AutoXtra in Santa Monica. Their prices
were the best (~$130) I found and they are very helpful.  They also have great
prices on Lloyds floormats (got a set from them a few weeks ago $99)
1-800-221-9872


Randy Kirby
'90 911 C2 Cab

> mujahid mahmood   mmmahmood@ucdavis.edu

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 13:17:59 -0700 (PDT)
From: James Wood <jamesw@PEAK.ORG>
Subject: My 1st 914 experience



All of this rambling, and the mentioning of "snobbery" against a 914 
being a "real" Porsche leads me to ramble about the 1st and only race I'd 
had against a 914.

This was during my high-school days, in 1986.  I was in a then-new '86 
Camaro with a 5-liter and 5-speed. (pathetic carbureted pile)  In my 
youthful ignorance, I thought I was driving a fast car.  One day while 
crusing up and down "the strip" in Anchorage (AK), I encountered a couple 
of hippies (no offense, anyone) in a bananna yellow 914.  The car was 
very ordinary, and it looked like it had VW Beetle wheels on it.  I'd 
been into VW Bugs back then - didn't know anything about Type 4s, but I 
didn't figure 914s were much of a car.

These dudes were certifiably, undeniably inebriated.  The passenger 
nonchalantly toked on a pot pipe, while in between swigs of his 
40-ouncer, the driver challenged me to a race, in slurred speech.  I 
thought he was joking and I laughed.  It took some serious facial 
expressions on his part to convince me that he was indeed serious.

We faced off at a stoplight (popular spot) where a city road becomes 
freeway - that way you get to drag and go for top speed in a single 
race.  I revved that sluggish 305 until the pushrods would have liked to 
bent and slipped the clutch a little off the line to avoid wheelspin 
(what little that wheezy powerplant could muster) and we were off!  We 
were only even to the top of 1st gear - when I hit second, I knew I'd 
lost.  Everytime he let off to shift, his 914 would backfire and spit 
flame - which only dramatized his victory.

However, prior to the race, I made sure and told him that this was a 
top-end race too, and we'd race to the next town if we had to.  I figured 
there might be a possibility he has a light car with a modified engine 
and 4.56's in the transaxle.  Well, when I hit 120MPH (which took time), 
his taillights were only getting smaller.  I don't think they Chev had 
much more in her.  I maintained speed for another little while, thinking 
how fun it would be to catch up - but I never did.  I let off and took an 
exit, fearful of speedtraps.  I took a parting glance down the highway 
and those little 914 taillights looked awfully small....I never saw them 
again - they probably hit a moose!

The verdict:  I think a 914 qualifies as a Porsche.

James


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 13:24:11 -0700 (PDT)
From: James Wood <jamesw@PEAK.ORG>
Subject: Re: car covers


I may not be the most informed person about car covers and where the 
technology has taken them in recent years, but I've seen car covers do 
more damage than good - on a couple occasions.

A friend had a cherried-out '56 Chevy all car-covered, but left it 
covered for about 2 years (through snow, etc) without checking it.  The 
chrome on the car started to rust under the cover.  Perhaps a pinhole 
developed or water/moisture just blew in - but however the moisture got 
there, the cover kept it from evaporating.

Another instance was where the wind chaffed the paint of the car with the 
cover.  THis wasn't a "rough" feeling fabric, either.  I suppose it's 
just like you can theoretically rub through your paint with the finest 
Carnuba wax - if you rub it long enough and as constantly as every breeze 
blows your car cover.

Technology may have improved - just my $.02.

James

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 16:47:00 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : Brake Bleeding

Barry Chapin (chapin@draper.com) asked :

> I am the guy having the brake sticking problem.  
> I bleeded my brakes last night and noticed that when the bleed
> valve on a caliper was open, and I pumped the brake pedal down to 
> eject fluid from the valve into a one-man-bleeder tube that
> I bought, the pedal did NOT spring back up.  It wold stay
> depressed at the floor.  Note that this was with the bleeder
> valve open.  Is this normal?  Could my spring be bad on the 
> pedal (as someone suggested).

It's probably time for a pedal assembly rebuild. The bushings are 
probably binding due to swelled bushings. I have this problem
on my 2 project cars (73 911E and 914/2.0).

Use new factory-style nylon bushings. It is not a difficult job but
a press is useful.

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S etc

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 13:52:45 -0700
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Mike Willis)
Subject: Re: car cover ?s

For car covers I use only the ones from beverly Hills motoring.
In fact I use the blue guard I think they call it. Have used one on our
bonneville since 1987 and it is still going strong.

Do not use any cover in the rain. There is nothing worse in trying to fold
up and put away a wet cover. Let alone getting it dry.

Covers work great for sun and also as a theft deterint as most folks will
not go after a car with a cover as they don't know what awaits them under
the cover.

mike
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 95 14:01:03 PDT
From: hbrandt@InterServ.Com
Subject: HRE Wheels - Bad experience

I recently had a disasterous mail-order experience with HRE Performance Wheels 
of Vista California.  I liked the look of their wheels from an ad in 
Excellence and ordered a set at over $3000.  That's where the nightmare 
begins:

(1)  I was initially promised delivery within three weeks.  I didn't receive 
the wheels for over 2 months.  They were then sent to my home, instead of to 
the address of my mechanic, where I asked that they be sent.

(2)  The wheels were sent with the wrong center caps (chrome instead of GPX 
white), and the center caps protruded from the wheel as opposed to the way 
they appeared in pictures they sent me in which they were machined flush with 
the wheel.  When I discussed this with HRE, they told me that "different 
center caps have a different fit" and that if I wanted them to look like they 
did in the picture, I would have to send the 4 wheels back to California for 
lathe machining.

(3)  After a couple of months on my car, the valve stems in 2 of the 4 wheels 
began to leak leading to flat tires, and requiring that I send the wheels back 
to HRE.

(4)  Since I had to send the wheels back to HRE for the valve stem repair, I 
asked that they fix the faulty center caps so they would appear as they did in 
the literature they had sent me. They told me I would have to pay for this.  
They didn't even offer to pay the shipping to get the valve stems repaired 
even though the wheels were still under warranty and less than 3 months old.

(5)  I didn't get the wheels back for 2 months.  Then they sent back the 
wheels, but didn't send back the tires.  Several calls and 3 weeks later, I 
finally received my tires.

(6)  The people at HRE have been rude, discourteous and obnoxious.  I had to 
threaten to reverse credit card charges to get any service at all.

In summary,  this has been the worst mail order experience of my life.  I've 
ordered Porsche parts and equipment from numerous companies and have never had 
problems.  If I could turn back the clock.......needless to say.....I'd order 
from elsewhere!!!!!!!!!!!

Harry Brandt
'89 911 Carrera 4 sss

Date: Wed, 07 Jun 1995 17:30:01 -0500 (EST)
From: NFENNESS@PEARL.TUFTS.EDU
Subject: Brake Calipers

Barry Chapin
   You asked about rebuilt calipers.  Foreign Autoparts on Massachusetts 
Ave. in Arlington farms out caliper rebuilds to someone located somewhere in 
lovely Everett by-the-Sea).  They've done them for me a $80.00 per 
caliper and I've had no problems. (porsche and mercedes).  
   With regard to your pedals sticking, I'd say it's high time to pull 
the pedals out and install a bronze bushing set.  Well worth it.

	- Neil
	'67 912 (awake at last for the 1995 driving season!)

Date: Wed, 07 Jun 1995 17:37:22 -0600
From: Bdale Garbee <bdale@gag.com>
Subject: 944 squealing/whistling repairs


Ross Stites (STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com) wrote:

: Hope this gives you some useful info for pricing.  What bearings are
: they replacing?

The belts are fairly cheap, as you stated.  The rollers and sprockets that 
the belts ride against aren't real cheap, and are important to replace if they
aren't in good shape.  

I just finished chasing a similar squealing/whistling noise problem, and
ended up having the belts, and all the rollers and sprockets they ride on
replaced.  Mine is an 87 944S with about 76k miles that I've owned for about
three months, and I'm just too busy to have undertaken this myself right now,
even if I had known going in what to look for.  I spent just under $950 for
parts and labor, and am pleased with the results so far (160 miles or so
post-repair).

The rollers clearly had no grease left in the bearings and were starting to
"wobble" a bit.  One of the sprockets appeared to have a bearing that was 
coming apart, it sort of "clunked" around instead of turning smoothly, and 
was very noisy even when turned by hand.  Further, there was a chunk missing
from the external, multi-ribbed belt that drives the alternator, et al.  And 
we went ahead and put a new v-belt on the power steering pump for good 
measure since it's cheap and was off anyway.

There was also a weird noise around the end of the driven can, which turned
out to be some trash on the hall-effect sensor that feeds cam position info
to the DME, I guess?  The labor to pull the cover and find that, then clean
out the sensor and put things back together, probably added to the "normal"
bill for belts and rollers, if there is such a thing.

The balance shaft belt was *really* worn from running back and forth across
the rollers and sprockets due to the wobbling roller, and the squealing noise
was *very* un-Porsche-like...  I'm much happier now!

Bdale
'87 944S


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 17:01:17 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: car cover ?s

mujahid:

Call A.P.A. Industries at 818-361-9719.  They carry Evolution IV Technalon
(the Kimberly-Clark stuff) covers, custom fitted, for $95-$105 depending on
the vehicle.  I've bought six or seven such covers from them over the years
(they last about 2 years in the SF Bay Area, and one was stolen on
Halloween :(  ), and have been very happy with them and the product they
sell. All their covers (that IO have) fit like a glove.

Evolution IV is pretty cool stuff - it can rain for days and the car will,
at worst, have a faint "wet" smell underneath the cover -- the underside of
the cover will still be dry, though.  They certainly reduce the harmful
effects of the sun. These Evo IV covers fold up pretty bag -- don't even
think about putiing them in a trunk sack, day after day.

 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  | 
|___________________________________________|

|   itself but a means to the end of a free |

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 17:01:22 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Pressure Washers

Hi Bob! Re pressure washers:

I have a 150-atmospheres (2000+ psi) and I find myself using it "full on"
all the time, so I don't see how a 1000-1200 unit would do the job.

It is very powerful, and will tear skin right off your fingers.  However,
it's not a cure-all -- some stubborn gunk still requires some manual
intervention to get it off.  By and large, I think it was a worthwhile
investment.  It removes all but the most caked-on stuff. I wish I had a
hot-water hookup, though.

Date: Wed, 07 Jun 1995 20:33:47
From: DENNIS DEEDS <5010.4218@trader.com>
Subject: 914 Books

In response to a recent question about what books a 914 owner should add 
to the book shelf, the 914 Owners Association suggests and frequently 
refers to the following:
Factory shop manual set
Factory spare parts catalogue
Haynes 914 manual
Clymer 914 manual
Porsche 914 Caught By Camera
Das Grosse VW-Porsche Buch
Brooklands 914 Collection
914 Guide to Authenticity
Classic Porsche
Great Marques Porsche
Porsche A Tradition of Greatness
Porsche The Fine Art of the Sports Car
Porsche The Enduring Legend
Porsche Museum
Porsche Road Car Race Car
Porsche Catalogs
Illustrated Porsche Buyers Guide
Road & Tracks Used Car Classics
Porsche Excellence Was Expected
The first 4 will help with maintenance and the rest will show colors, 
options, and varieties of 914s.  Some of the *picture* books are a wealth 
of misinformation - but the pictures are nice if you disregard the text.   
                                                                           
Dennis Deeds        5010.4218@trader.com                                   
914 Owners Association & 914-6 Club USA

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 21:09:43 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: New Old 911 questions

>        The engine is a 74 2.7 T.
>        I plan on changing the oil and filter this weekend.  Any good oils
>or filters to use or bad ones to avoid?

        Synthetic if you think you can justify the $$$$.  If not, then get
a good dino juice like Kendall.  Go to the dealer, or call Imparts or GPR
for the oil filter.  Sometimes there just ain't no substitute for the Real
Thing.

with only Porsche factory Carrera RS/Carrera Cup parts.  White with black
interior.  Street legal in all 50 states or makes an outstanding track/club
race car.  275 h.p., 2660 lbs./ 1210 kgs. (dry).  Aluminum hood, complete
Euro suspension, brakes and gearing.  Lightweight flywheel and sport clutch.
 Recaro SP-G's, 6 Pt. Sabelts, Matter rollbar etc. etc.  No sunroof, A.C, or
radio-just limited slip.  Reinforced chassis same as used on European RS,
complete with rolled fender lips and reinforcement welds.  Includes two sets
of factory Cup wheels, 1 set of B.F. Goodrich R-1's, 1 set of Bridgestone
Expedias.  Full factory sponsor decals and number plates.  Complete
documentation including list of all parts used, factory manuals and parts
list.  Absolutely no detail overlooked.  Concours condition, 7,500
miles--$72,500.00---Call for complete list of equipment and photos. John
Ruther--Office-312-424-4813-Home-708-639-1094.

Date: Wed, 7 Jun 95 20:30:15 -0700
From: donr@tdnet.com (Don Rutherford)
Subject: Pressure Washers

<I'm sure a pressure washer will do it, but am unsure as to how 
much pressure one needs to do make it worth while.  Are the 
the smaller 1200psi units that sell for $200 - $300 adequate?
Thanks!

 -Bob Spindel>

I've been using one which puts out 1500 psi. Does everything I've needed, 
and a neighbor borrowed it to clean the mess out of an MGB when the engine & 
trans were out. Did a spectacular job!

The smaller units would probably do a reasonably good job. Their main 
limitation is in the area of volume of output rather than psi. OK for small 
parts/jobs, but when you begin to find out all the things a pressure washer 
can do it may become a limitation.

FWIW mine is a 5 HP and puts out almost 3 gpm @ 1500 psi. Cost between $400 
and $500 and I wouldn't want much less.

Cleans cars, drives, tools, parts, litter boxes, eaves troughs, any number 
of dirty containers, trucks belonging to mud-whumping offspring/neighbors, 
preps for painting, lawn furniture (including umbrellas), garage floors, 
wasp's nests, airplanes, cat-piss from Fuchs....

More info if you want.

Don
1994 5 hp Briggs & Stratton pressure washer
some cars
more animals
a spouse who likes all of the above.......

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 1995 02:25:26 -0400
From: "Daniel G. Pouzzner" <douzzer@prez.mit.edu>
Subject: faster!

This is a cloud-9 fantasy by someone who thinks his 928 isn't fast
enough. If you don't like this sort of thing, skip to the next
message... If you've actually _done_ this sort of thing, tell me how!

I am very happy with my car as-is. However, I have concluded that the
car of my dreams is a 928 with 500HP, limited-slip differential AWD,
and a six speed gearbox. I think this would necessarily also involve a
different clutch, perhaps crankshaft work?, I've never done anything
like this so I just don't know.
I want to keep the suspension as-is; perhaps slightly harder
springs. I want to keep the chassis, cockpit, and shell as-is also.

What does one have to do to a 1979 928 engine to get that sort of
horsepower? Is it possible? If so, how do the two turbochargers and
intercooler(s) fit into the already-crowded engine bay? What sorts of
modifications to timing/injection/camshaft/cylinder/piston/crankshaft
are standard fare for this sort of thing? Also, is the cooling
infrastructure going to lose its marbles? Instinct says yes, so how do
I fix?

I would like to have cockpit-controllable boost levels, from zero to
40PSI (*very very* high, race car territory (actually, those pressure
levels are against regulations in most if not all events now I
believe)). Are there turbos that can achieve this sort of pressure,
with <.5s turbo lag to full boost? I believe the way to achieve the
pressure modulation ability is to have some sort of valve system that
routes the exhaust into the turbo and exhaust pipe in varying
ratios. A similar configuration on the intake side would work, with
the necessary addition of a one-way valve (a simple slap-shut job
would work I think) to allow the turbo to do its thing when it is
generating pressure. This would allow the engine to operate with
entirely conventional aspiration, entirely turbocharged, or anywhere
inbetween, at will. I believe a new injector computer would have to be
integrated with the turbo system for this to work as advertised. A new
fuel pump is probably also needed, to achieve that dreamt-of 5MPG (heh
heh).

Because I plan to replace the entire post-engine powertrain, I think
concerns about the increased torque are taken care of. So, when one
buys a gearbox, can one choose the ratios, and will it fit where the
old one was? Will the higher-capacity clutch fit where the old one
was?

I would like to add another brake caliper to each of the wheels. Does
this necessitate a reworking of the entire brake system, starting with
a new master cylinder?

How can I fit three limited-slip differentials under the car, and
modify the front wheel mechanics to allow power transfer there? I
think this might be one of the harder things to do (most of the things
I want to do seem fraught with gotchas, come to think of it..).

A final addition is some modest aerodynamic enhancements: an airdam
and a modest, understated, but unique "signature" spoiler.

How much would all this cost in parts and hours? I am guessing 30
grand in parts and over 1000 hours by a genuine expert.

With the modifications, the car will weigh at least 3700 pounds
(an increase of 350 pounds). With that weight and limited-slip AWD,
will a 500HP engine be able to spin all four tires in a clutch-drop
launch, or will it just bog down? I would like the engine to be
powerful and tractable enough to spin the tires (in a straight line!)
at up to 30MPH. With this sort of weight, what sort of power curve
does the car need to achieve this? Target numbers are <=3.5s 0-60, <12s
through 1320 feet, <=100 feet 60MPH to 0MPH braking, top speed >=210MPH.

If I can build this monster, and the final product has real
refinement, is there a market for this sort of thing? Are there dozens
of people out there who would shell out 200 grand for a 928 that can
leave diablos and (1996) 911 turbos in the dust? Starting with a new
GTS engine (360HP), I would aim for over 600HP, creating a real
rocket, with real-world ergonomics (drive to work in it! you don't
look silly in one, more than can be said of a diablo or testarossa).

Maybe all I'm doing is reinventing the 959, sans four wheel steering,
with more power.

 -douzzer

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 1995 00:31:00 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: 914/914-6 Owners/Experts -- I need your help

I'm preparing a Tech Tip for Porschephiles on upgrading the front calipers
of the 914-4.  It's pretty in-depth (3000 words and counting), and covers a
whole lot of 914 brake and brake upgrade issues. 

I'd like to get my facts straight on the 914-6 (don't own one, :( ), so I'd
like to ask a few questions and would appreciate responses, with specs if
possible.  I've scoured my various manuals and catalogs, but many points
are still unclear. Here they are (there's a little overlap, but please bear
with me):


1) Are late (73-76) 914-4 front pads thicker than the early ones, and if so
by how much?

2) How do the early (70-72) and late (73-76) 914-4 front brake rotors
differ? See 8)

3) Does the 914-6 use the same proportioning valve as the 914-4? Does it
use one at all?

4) Does the 914-6 use the same pads front and rear? Do the 914-4 and the
914-6 share the same front pad, or does the thickness vary over the years?

5) What's the difference between the 914-4 (914.352.423/4.00) and 914-6
(914.352.901/2.00) rear calipers? Just the ability to accomodate a bigger
pad and thicker rear rotor on the 914-6?

6) What's the difference between the 914-4 rear axle flange and that of the
914-6?  Did the early 914-4 units have reinforcements to permit 5-stud
mountings?

7) Am I correct in saying that the 914-6 uses _exactly_ the same front
struts, brakes and rotors as the same vintage 911 with vented front rotors?
If close but no cigar, what's the difference?

8) When did the switch to hubcentric front rotors occur on the 914-4? In
73? Is that the only difference between 411.407.075 and .075B? See 2)

Thanks,

Date: Thu, 08 Jun 95 11:22:00 PDT
From: "Thiger Jonas, Netsupport" <jonas.thiger@netsupport.telia.se>
Subject: Re: 944 History, also long

Additions to Barry Lenoble's (nice) 944 history:

>The 944 was first sold in 1983. Actually, the Porsche factory raced a car
>called the 924 GTS Carerra (or something like that) in the 1981 or 1982
>LeMans race my books are at home). This was a 924 Turbo, with special body
>work, that looked VERY similar to what became the 944  In 1983, Porsche
>discontinued the 924, and started selling the 944. 

The 944 production actually started in 1981 (pre-production and demo cars), 
with the first cars sold 1982, in Germany only I believe.
The 924 was discontinued in 1985, and the 924S came in 1986 as a 
successor (they might have overlapped for some time?).

>In 1989 the model line was changed again. There were now three models. The
>regular 944, which tried to improve performance by increasing the engine
>displacement  from 2.5l to 2.7l. HP went from something like 158 to 165.

Reason to this was to give catalythic equipped cars same performance as 
they used to have with the non-cat 163 hp engine. This was the general 
Porsche philosophy at the time, that cars should not suffer from tougher 
emission laws (in Europe...).

>In 1990 and 91 the only 944 sold in the US was the S2, which was produced in
>coupe and cabriolet version.

Also the 944 Turbo was being produced until 1991, sold mainly in Germany.

In addition, Porsche also produced the 944 Turbo Cup, for a special racing 
series in Europe. This car was available in 1987-89. Production figures I 
don't know, and for tech details I have to dive into the bookshelf, will take 
some time... Maybe someone else can fill in?
What I remember is: top speed in 1987 about 170 mph, suspension upgrade 
included coil-overs in the rear, bigger brakes (same as 944 Turbo S?) and a
roll cage. If you U.S. guys want one, please don't buy Swedish because I
want to get one myself and there aren't to many of them here (two 89's) ;-)

I mentioned the 968 Turbo S (ADAC-GT racing series homologation car) a 
few weeks ago, and most areas has been covered, but here's some more: 
I've seen some ads claiming 20 produced. Also, price in 1993 was 175.000 DEM. 
Hockenheim short circuit in 1 min 18 sec, same as a 1995 Honda NSX-R (GT 
series homologation car). The german magazine "sport auto" had a very nice 
feature on it in 1993 (March, April or May, can't quite remember).

Long live the waterpumpers!

Rumours tells me that the 996 will get a new air-cooled boxer. Anyone to 
confirm?

Jonas Thiger
jonas.thiger@netsupport.telia.se
87 944, Limone gelb (anyone seen this color, seems to be only one in Sweden?)
Lulea, Sweden

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 08 Jun 95 12:47:00 PDT
From: "Thiger Jonas, Netsupport" <jonas.thiger@netsupport.telia.se>
Subject: Re: 944 History (long)

Addition to Barry Lenoble's (nice) 944 history:

>The 944 was first sold in 1983. Actually, the Porsche factory raced a car
>called the 924 GTS Carerra (or something like that) in the 1981 or 1982
>LeMans race my books are at home). This was a 924 Turbo, with special body
>work, that looked VERY similar to what became the 944  In 1983, Porsche
>discontinued the 924, and started selling the 944. 

The 944 production actually started in 1981 (pre-production and demo cars), 
with the first cars sold as 1982 model, in Germany only I believe.
The 924 was discontinued in 1985, and the 924S came in as a successor (they 
might have overlapped for some time?).

>In 1989 the model line was changed again. There were now three models. The
>regular 944, which tried to improve performance by increasing the engine
>displacement  from 2.5l to 2.7l. HP went from something like 158 to 165.

Reason to this was to give catalythic equipped cars same performance as 
they used to have with the non-cat 163 hp engine. This was the general 
Porsche philosophy at the time, that cars should not suffer from tougher 
emission laws (in Europe...).

>In 1990 and 91 the only 944 sold in the US was the S2, which was produced in
>coupe and cabriolet version.

Also the 944 Turbo was being produced until 1991, sold mainly in Germany.

In addition, Porsche also produced the 944 Turbo Cup, for a special racing 
series in Europe. This car was available in 1987-89. Production figures I 
don't know, and for tech details I have to dive into the bookshelf, will take 
some time... Maybe someone else can fill in?
What I remember is: top speed in 1987 about 270 km/h, suspension upgrade 
included coil-overs in the rear, bigger brakes (same as 944 Turbo S?) and a
roll cage. If you U.S. guys want one, please don't buy Swedish because I
want to get one myself and there aren't to many of them here (two 89's) ;-)

The 968 Turbo S (ADAC-GT racing series homologation car) was mentioned a 
few weeks ago, and most areas has been covered, but here's some more: 
I've seen some ads claiming 20 produced. Price in 1993 was 175.000 DEM.
0-100 km/h in 5,5 sec, top speed 280 km/h, Hockenheim short circuit in 1 min 
18 sec, same as a 1995 Honda (Acura) NSX-R (GT series homologation car).
The german magazine "sport auto" had a very nice feature on it in 1993 
(March, April or May, can't quite remember).

Long live the waterpumpers!

Jonas Thiger
jonas.thiger@netsupport.telia.se

Lulea, 
Sweden

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 95 22:56:11 +1000
From: MURRAY WILKES <mdwaust@ozemail.com.au>
Subject: Re: Broken 944 three-spoke steering wheels

Broken 3 spoke steering wheels are easily fixed.

1. Undo the stitching on the leather cover.
2. Slit the rubber padding.
3. Neatly MIG weld the joint.
4. Glue rubber back.
5. Re-stitch the leather.

This takes an hour or two but saves $$$ and works well.


Murray Wilkes (Australia)
1977 911S
1978 911SC
1979 911SC

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 1995 10:21:49 -0400
From: TommyWmson@aol.com
Subject: 914 smokin 

Hello all,

I am still having problems with my 914 blowing smoke out the
valve cover vents and the crank vents. Appears to be a light misty
smoke, maybe gas? No smoke coming out the tail pipe.

here is the situation:
914 2.0 motor with 40 IDF carbs.
Pertronix Ignitor and Bosch blue coil.
Motor rebuilt top to bottom 4 years ago,  approx 40,000 miles.
Running carbs for 6 years.

I have checked or replaced the following:
Oil and filter replaced
Spark plugs replaced
spark plug wires replaced
removed top of carbs and checked float level
cleaned jets and float bowl on carbs (looked OK)
swapped coil 
checked timing
checked air flow on all 4 venturies

After running for a while, rechecked the new plugs. #1 seems a 
little too clean, like it's not firing much on the idle circuit. Unplugged
#1 plug wire, not much change, just a little rough at high idle 
3000 rpm.  Plugged #1 back in, unplugged #2....engine dies.

I have been running the same carb setup for several years now, so
it is jetted and set up more or less correctly. 

I had noticed some smoke occasionally for the past couple of
months. Two weeks ago I left the car at the tire store for alignment.
When I picked it up it was running rough on idle but OK once under
power. After driving the 15 miles home on the highway, it was 
smoking heavily from the vents and would hardly idle.  My first thought was
that they may have turned the ignition key to unlock the 
steering wheel for the alignment, which also turns on the fuel
pump. If left on for a while I figured it could have dumped some gas
into the motor. So I changed the oil....but its still smoking. I haven't
driven it more than a few miles so the oil temp has not gotten over 
180 for any extended period.

Questions:
could I still have some gas in the new oil?
could the carbs need new needle valves? 
could this be worn valve guides, rings, burned piston??

This ones got me stumped.

Tommy - TommyWmson@aol.com
73 914 
88 Honda Accord
93 Honda Harmony
94 Acura Legend

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 1995 09:19:36 -0700 (MST)
From: Tim Jones <timjones@indirect.com>
Subject: Re: 914 smokin

Tommy,  You've uncovered the problem right there -

> After running for a while, rechecked the new plugs. #1 seems a 
> little too clean, like it's not firing much on the idle circuit. Unplugged
> #1 plug wire, not much change, just a little rough at high idle 
> 3000 rpm.  Plugged #1 back in, unplugged #2....engine dies.

Since removing #1 causes very little change in the idle - you either have 
a bad spark plug wire, fouled contact point for #1 in the disti-cap or 
another bad spark plug.  The oredr of presentation here is the most 
likely order to solve the problem.  What you are seeing is the unburned 
gas from #1 being thrown out of the exhaust and, possibly, back through 
the recirc from the blow-by.

Tim Jones
timjones@indirect.com
'74 914 1.8 (getting the rust beat out of it)
'75 914 2.0 (just for the fun of it)
'86 Jetta GLI (Hey, its got air and I live in the desert!)
Keeper of the 914 Fan web page	http://www.indirect.com/www/timjones/porsche/

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 1995 13:16:45 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Distilled vs. Tap H20, chemical explanation.


>From my brother the Chemist:


>I decided to do a little experiment. I polished a small sheet of 
>aluminum, washed it with a solvent, and cut off 4 strips. I placed
>each strip in identical jars which had been cleaned in a laboratory. 
>I filled each jar as follows:
>
>1. 100% distilled water
>2. 100% tap water
>3. 100% Prestone
>4. 50% Prestone, 50% distilled water 
>
>That was May 19th. Today, here are the results so far:
>
>1. White precipitate (flakes) coating the top surface of the
>aluminum.   (looks almost like 1 mm specs of dandruff) There are 
>also flakes settled  at the bottom of the jar.
> 
>2. About 1/4 the precipitate of jar 1. The flakes are much smaller,
>almost  making the water look cloudy rather looking like they are in
>suspension.
>   Also visible are small gray specs of corrosion on the aluminum
>(not  visible in jar 1 perhaps due to the thick coating of flakes).
> 
>3 & 4. No discernable precipitate or cloudiness. Aluminum surface
>still as satiny as when first polished.
>
>So jars 3 & 4 proves what we all know already, that antifreeze
>prevents corrosion. Only time will tell whether my use of an 
>antifreeze which probably has phosphates will make any difference. 
>Unfortunately, I don't have phosphate-free antifreeze to use for a 5th jar.
>
>However, jars 1 and 2 behave the opposite as I would have expected.
>Any chemists out there to explain why using distilled water produced more
>precipitate than tap water?
> 
>Joe '86 944
>


This is actually an interesting question from a chemistry
          point of view. Being an analytical chemist and not a
          inorganic chemist this is not my direct forte. I will give
          my attempt at an explanation.

          Here goes; First we need to think about what corrosion is to
          understand the chemistry involved. Corrosion, as used in
          this E-Mail, would be the oxidation of metals to form metal
          salts and  precipitates. Different metals will oxidize to
          form different metal salts. Rust is the classic oxidation
          product of Iron.

          For those who forgot their general chemistry oxidation is
          the loss of electrons. This is promoted by what is called a
          oxidizing agent. An oxidizing agent is something that wants
          an electron or is electron deficient. Chlorine (Cl) is one
          of the best oxidizing agents there is. Cl is one electron
          short of a full electron state.  So it will take an electron
          from anywhere it can.

          Next we must look at what metals come in contact with the
          coolant to figure out what things may be corroded. In most
          cars that would be Iron (Fe), Aluminum (Al), and steel
          (which is a blend of Fe, Carbon, and other metals, like
          Nickel (Ni) and Chromium (Cr). Any of these can be oxidized.

          Al is easily oxidized, more so then Fe or steel. The reason
          that Al looks dull is the surface is oxidized and this
          prevents further oxidation. If you polish Al it will oxidize
          immediately and if you continue to polish it will continue
          to oxidize.

          Now to the heart of the matter. Why did they Al in distilled
          water oxidize more then in tap? The answer is that distilled
          water is more reactive then tap water. This is because in
          distilled water you need to think of the water as a lose
          association of H+ and 2O- ions. These ions can react or
          oxidize metals. Tap water has other ions like (Fe3+, Mg3+,
          Fe2+, Ca2+, Cl-, F-).  These ions will form lose
          associations with the H+ and the O- and make the water less
          reactive.

          The bottom line is that you should use antifreeze and tap
          water as your coolant. Antifreeze is designed to help
          prevent corrosion. At some other time I can talk about what
          is in antifreeze and how it works.

          Send your next chem question at Rod.Lenoble@Hauser.com

Barry Lenoble
Blenoble@aol.com
89 944 Turbo, Alpine White


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 95 10:23:56 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Re: Broken 944 three-spoke steering wheels


As Murray Wilkes points out, the three spoke steering wheel can be 
repaired. It will also break again if you are autocrossing or on the 
track. This is why I am recommending the four spoke steering wheel as a 
replacement.

If your wheel breaks on an 85 or earlier 944, you can use a 924 two spoke
steering wheel in a pinch.

Any 924 owner can upgrade to a three or four spoke steering wheel from 
the early 944. 

Or you can use a VW chain steering wheel if you desire. (VBGrin)

Jim Pasha 

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 1995 10:26:46 -0700 (MST)
From: Tim Jones <timjones@indirect.com>
Subject: Re: Advice on busted 914 torsion bar replacement?

> side).  Car's sitting on its wheel, and the adjuster for the ride 
> height/torsion bar moves in my hand (but is rusted solid so I don't think it's 
> stripped splines).

BTDT - It happened to me just prior to my drive across from Florida to 
Phoenix.  Just on the passenger's side.

> So, I'm trying to figure out if it's worth taking it in to someone (2 hours per 
> side, $55/hr, plus they order parts from AutoMotion!  Something like $500+ _if_ 
> the bars/bolts aren't rusted in there solid).  Any advice on doing it myself?  
> (probably end up replacing the bushings while I'm in there, especially if I 
> have to take the whole A-arm off the car.)  Are used bars a bad idea?  Or 
> replacing just the one?

It's always best to replace these as a matched pair.  You can replace 
just the one, but I would suspect that if ONE was weak enough to snap, 
then just how long can you trust the other?

You can replace these with little grief.  Here's what I did:

Lift the entire front at least 20" and make sure that the jackstands are 
NOT directly behind the rear of the torsion bar tube.

(of course, the wheels are off)

Remove the front valance

Remove the protective cup (uses a hex wrench) - two bolts each side.

    On three cars that I've worked on, there's been small holes in the front 
    cap of the torsion bar tube.  On one, it was solid.  Since the 
    three were stock, I suspect that either the holes are factory, or
    someone was looking out for me.

Loosen/remove the adjusting bolt and then remove the rear section of the 
bar in the adjuster.

Using the hole I mentioned above (or a close facsimile) spray a volume 
of Liquid Wrench or WD-40 into the tube.

Using a small metal rod, tap the remainder of the rod out of the rear of the
tube. 

Spray the splines on both ends of the new torsioin bars with a light oil or 
WD-40

Insert the new bars.

Place the adjuster onto the rear splines.

Insert the adjustment bolt and set to the middle of the travel.

Put the wheels bacl on

Lower the car and examine the set of the tires.  I actually had my 
neighbor sit in the car before I looked.

raise the frontend enough to relieve the pressure on the bars and adjust 
based on your inspections.

Drive around the block and then reexamine the set.  Repeat this until 
satisfied with the results.

I'm not claiming that this is 100% factory, but then again, it beats 
$55/hr times two sides!

Tim Jones
timjones@indirect.com
'74 914 1.8 (getting the rust beat out of it)
'75 914 2.0 (just for the fun of it)
'86 Jetta GLI (Hey, it's got air and I live in the desert)
Keeper of the 914 Fan web page	http://www.indidrect.com/www/timjones/porsche/

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 1995 14:02:09 -0400
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 engine problem

Dear John:
Two things immediately came to mind:
1. The head temperature sensor is failing. This can be checked by
substituting a grounded wire for the sensor. If the problem disappears
replace the sensor. It is located at the right rear of the engine and its
lead exists through the cylinder cover.

2. The fuel pump circuit is momentarily failing. Either the fuse or relay is
temporarily losing connection and the pressure is dropping. Hot wire the fuel
pump and install a high pressure fuel guage between the two drivers side
injectors to monitor pressure.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 1995 13:12:15 -0800 (PDT)
From: bvs@photon.com (Bruce Shetler)
Subject: Re: car cover ?s

Randy Kirby writes...
> 
> I recently bought a factory cover for my C2 and after using it 2 times
> returned it. It seemed a bit cheap to me, a lightweight, thin material,
> that was kinda rough to the touch with a silver, spaceman coating that
> looked like it would eventually flake off. I then did a little research and
> found that the Evolution 3/4 fabrics, although good at repelling the sun
> and water, are quite bulky. One would probably fill the entire trunk of my
> 911. And the Evolution fabric is only moderatly durable. THere's a new
> fabric called Tyvek that is kinda like paper surgical booties and hats. No
> thanks. Finally, there's Ultralon, a mid to lightweight fabric with a 
> slight stretchy quality, provides excellent sun protection and water
> repellancy and is quite durable. This is what I decided upon and so far I'm
> well pleased. Can't attest to the water repellancy yet, but I like the
> weight and the sun protection (South Florida sun is brutal).
> 
> I also recommend buying from AutoXtra in Santa Monica. Their prices
> were the best (~$130) I found and they are very helpful.  They also have great
> prices on Lloyds floormats (got a set from them a few weeks ago $99)
> 1-800-221-9872
> 
> 
> Randy Kirby
> '90 911 C2 Cab
> 
> 
> 


I'd like to offer a counter to the above.  I bought a factory cover last
year and it's unquestionably the best car cover I've ever had (and I've
had alot).  It is light and easy to use while providing great sun and 
water repellency with good breathability.  I unfortunatly have to leave
my car outside all the time (no garage right now) and I pay alot of 
attention to my cover performance.  I'm not all that cost conscious, but
this was also quite a good deal.  I haven't tried Ultralon, but I'd 
recommend against Evolution.  Aside from being bulky, it degrades into
some kind of funny state wherein it always leaves a nasty film all over
the windows and paint, in addition to "Ultralon particles".  Kind of like
ArmorAll outgassing does to the inside of a car (although no one who is 
reading this would use ArmorAll I know).

I'd give the factory cover a try, the shiny coating keeps the interior
temp down and I've got about a year of constant use on mine and it just
looks a little dirty, no other signs of deterioration.

Besides it says Porsche on it and its not overpriced, how often to I
get to buy a "part" like that?

Bruce
