Date: Thu, 08 Jun 1995 16:26:33 -0400
From: sjagernauth@attmail.com (Stephen I Jagernauth)
Subject: 951 and zero oil pressure

I got a good scare yesterday on the way home from work.  I was doing a max 
boost run down this twisty road going thru the gears shifting at 5500k.  When 
I hit 3rd gear somewhere around 4000-5000 rpm, the engine lost power suddenly 
and the oil pressure dropped to **ZERO** bar and the red light came on.  The 
engine still ran and would rev freely in neutral but there was no response to 
throttle input.   I couldn't pull over right away due to the traffic in the 
right lane and coasted to a stop with the engine still running about 500 yards
away.  I killed the engine immediately to prevent further damage.  I thought I
had blown my engine but when I checked under the hood, the large (2.5" diam) 
metal hose to the intercooler had popped out from the rubber hose (going to 
the turbo?) right above the airbox.  I got out the tool-kit (Thank you, 
Porsche, for being so thoughtful), and had the hose back together in 5 minutes
and the engine started right up with regular oil pressure.  

Now, I think I left the hose too loose the last time I worked on the car and 
it worked itself loose under the max boost conditions, but why would the oil 
pressure drop to zero????  What is the likelihood of any engine damage under 
the above scenario?  What is the correct action to take if you lose oil 
pressure suddenly?? I didn't want to switch off the ignition and lose steering
control as I maneuvered between traffic.  

P.S. 1/2 hour later, I had to rescue my wife because the clutch went on her 
car.  When it rains...

____________________________________________________________________________ 
Steve Jagernauth	               	'87 951 Pearl Black 
AT&T BCS			  	'87 Audi 5K CST 
Bridgewater, NJ 
sjagernauth@attmail.com

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 1995 16:38:15 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Re: Advice on busted 914 torsion bar replacement?

Tim Jones <timjones@indirect.com> replied :

> Spray the splines on both ends of the new torsioin 
> bars with a light oil or WD-40.  Insert the new bars.

You should coat the entire new bar with grease before
inserting it, especially the splined ends. 

You may want to use 911 19mm torsion bars instead
of the stock 914 ones, as they are readily available and will
match many of the stiffer rear coil springs available.
This will make the car handle better (unless you have 
the soft stock rear springs) but ride slightly stiffer.

Regards, Mike Piera '73 914/2.0 '72S and '73E 911 targas

Date:         Thu, 08 Jun 95 15:52:18 CDT
From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
Subject:      Re: How does 944 cooling sys. work?

On Thu, 8 Jun 1995 16:11:32 -0400 (EDT) you said:
>
>Occasionally, however, temp gauge stays steady close to the
>lower middle mark (no recycling) even in heavy city hot day
>driving. What worries me is the loud whining sound coming from
>the engine. This whining does not change with rpm.
>Is it oil cooler or what? I have noticed that it usually happens
>when I use the A/C. But even after turning off the A/C, I does
>not stop.
>
>Can somebody please explain me what is going on together with
>how the system works ?
>
>Thanks a lot in advance.
>
>Armagan.
>85.5 whining 944.

My guess is the hi-speed fan that comes on when you turn on the A/C.
My electic fans switch to high speed (depending on engine temp) when
the A/C is turned on and when the A/C is switched off, it takes a few
seconds before the fans return to normal speed.

Camaro?  Say, aren't you on the wrong list?  My advice is to sell your
low-mileage 944 to someone who'll appreciate it and move on to some Detroit
heavy metal that moves you.  Good luck.

Hunter

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 1995 16:25:20 -0500 (CDT)
From: robert merithew <merithew@uxa.cso.uiuc.edu>
Subject: 914 starter advice needed


I'm in the middle of a cross-country trip in my 914 and am having
trouble with the starter.

Power gets to the solenoid when I turn the ignition to 'start', and
power gets to the big terminal on the starter (the one straight from the
battery).  The solenoid clicks feebly and the alternator and oil light
dim when I try to start it.

After a day of driving without shutting the engine off (from Salt Lake
City to San Francisco) I was all ready to replace the starter & solenoid
but today the car starts fine.

So what's the diagnosis?  Do solenoids typically fail intermittently?

I seem to remember reading about a 914 modification wherein a relay is
added somewhere in the starting circuit - does this sound familiar to
anyone?

I hope to at least understand the problem (if not rememdy it) before I
start the return trip to Illinois in about a week...

At least a 914 is easy to push-start.  They should put more gas stations
at the tops of hills.

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 1995 16:39:07 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 starter advice needed

>I seem to remember reading about a 914 modification wherein a relay is
>added somewhere in the starting circuit - does this sound familiar to
>anyone?

        Auto Atlanta and AutoMashin' both sell "fixes" of this type.
Something else to check is the ground strap between the tranny and the
chassis.  That's the major ground path for the starter.  I seem to re-
member that there was a heat-induced problem where that ground wasn't
working so the current found another ground through something else... ?
(Anyone?)
        Battery is OK, etc?

- --DD

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 95 14:51:55 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Batteries


I just measured a bunch at the local parts
store and bought one that would fit.  There was
only one, size 26 I think.  I can check if you
want, but you're better off making your own
measurements.

It goes in the driver's side battery box.  Sidewise.
You'll have to fashion a hold down strap.  It's
pretty straightforward.

Don't forget tio disconnect or cover the other
terminal.

 -Bob Spindel

Date: Thu,  8 Jun 95 18:05:08 PDT
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: distilled or tap?

>          The bottom line is that you should use antifreeze and tap
>          water as your coolant. Antifreeze is designed to help
>          prevent corrosion. At some other time I can talk about what
>          is in antifreeze and how it works.


Barry,  your point about distilled water being a loose association
of 2H+ and O- ions is understandable, I've long forgotton my chem
courses but doesn't this imply that the attraction of the H+ and O-
ions is weaker than the O- and Al+?  Ifso, I guess it makes sense..

I always thought it better to use distilled because I was concerned
that any dissolved minerals in tap water would precipitate and leave
deposits and scaling when the water temperature is raised, then 
lowered. (like in a water heater)

my $.02...

Matt Carpenter
E-mail: mwc@lubrizol.com

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 1995 20:23:55 -0400
From: rgrayson@atlanta.com (Richard Grayson)
Subject: Re: Pressure Washers

Bob Spindel wrote: 

>Has anyone had any experience with pressure washers?  After 
>having spent who knows how much time, using who knows 
>how many cans of Gunk, on too many projects, cleaning off 
>grease and road debris, I'm ready to find a better way.
>
>I'm sure a pressure washer will do it, but am unsure as to how 
>much pressure one needs to do make it worth while.  Are the 
>the smaller 1200psi units that sell for $200 - $300 adequate?
>

I just rented a Honda 5hp / 2000 psi unit last weekend to clean the deck,
patio, and my grungy project car - a '73 Datsun 240Z. (Yeah I know, not a
pcar. But dirt is dirt.)
It did a decent but not great job on the car. It cleaned up areas like
wheelwells and suspension components ok. But baked on oil/grease under the
engine or even on the differential was really slow going. I think a 1200 psi
unit would test my patience. You'll probably still want to spray on some
sort of degreaser anyway to loosen up the crud.

Hope this helps.

Richard Grayson 
rgrayson@atlanta.com

1985 Porsche 911 (daily driver)
1973 Datsun 240z (IZCC #309)

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 1995 21:40:11 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Trunk cover.

>Does anyone know how to repair the retractable trunk cover attached to 
>the rear seat?  Someone told me that I should have it done 
>professionaly.  Yea, right.  Any tips?
>
>

Well, I guess that it depends on what you mean by "repair"...

If your end caps are broken, and that is keeping the "roller shade" from 
returning, then you need to buy new end caps (available from the dealer for 
about $22 each) and pop-rivet them in place, with the proper amount of 
tension on the spring...

Simple, yet effective.

Or, you could buy a used one from me...   :-)  After all, "Her Majesty" is 
serviced by me....

Good Luck!

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 1995 19:59:30 -0600
From: tgilton@micron.net (Terry Gilton)
Subject: Re: 73 911 batteries

>I'm converting from the stock dual batteries to a single battery
>so does aney one know what single battery to use.
>
>Tom Marcotte
>      73 911 targa

'69-'73 had twin 36 amp-hour batteries. '74 on uses one 66 amp-hour. Both
the '73 and '74 used the 770 W alternator, so you should be able to just
pop
the new battery in.

Terry Gilton
'74 911

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 1995 21:43:48 -0700 (PDT)
From: James Wood <jamesw@PEAK.ORG>
Subject: Re: Ziebart Removal.



On Thu, 8 Jun 1995, Jerry Brady wrote:

> BTW, does anyone have a tried and true method of getting the engine bad
> adhesive off of the firewall without damaging the paint?


I don't know what endgine bad adhesive is., but:  I once took a pinstripe 
off a car, and it left some residual glue.  Many times Coleman fuel (or 
other petroleum solvent will work - but it didn't.  I tried lacquer 
thinner (harsh, but I was careful) and I was afraid to continue or damage 
the paint.  I went to the automotive paint store and got a bottle of "3M 
adhesive remover" and it worked like a champ!  Don't ask me why it would 
remove stuff that even lacquer thinner wouldn't - and it didn't hurt the 
paint.

James

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 1995 22:09:53 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Adhesive removal

The safest product for adhesive removal is trichloroethane, which is
harder to get than it used to be.  Glass shops use a spray version
called "Quick Release Agent."  It is pretty benign as far as paint is
concerned, and softens rubber-based cements.

I haven't used 3-M Adhesive Remover, which may be the same substance.
BUT I'd be careful with other brands.  There's a Jasco Adhesive
Remover which is basically a paint remover.  Check the chemical
composition:  1-1-1 trichloroethane is what you want; methylene
chloride is *not*--unless you want to have your paint emulsify into a
washable goo!

Mineral spirits ("paint thinner") is cheap and readily available.
It'll do the job...eventually.

Steve Gilbert

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 01:03:48 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Porsche Factory LSD versus Quaife

> Can someone who really understands how these things work please explain the 
> difference and what the pro's and con's of each may be.  I'm particularly 
> interested in the characteristics of the factory limited slip that was 
> available for the 911SC (1982) as compared with a Quaife.  Other questions I 
> have include:

911 factory LSD, much like all of the Porsche LSDs since the '50s, is a multi
disk clutch affair. Slippage of a wheel causes power transfer via a collection
of friction and pressure disks, etc. Lockup is pre-set at some point to
facilitate maximal power transfer without really eating up the clutches.
Needless to say, the clutch disks are a wear item, have to be rebuilt with
some frequency. In the 356 world, rule of thumb is an LSD is good for about
10k street miles or a nearly infinite number of track miles. The 911 LSDs
are a lot better, but should still be considered a routine service item
at about 50k intervals.

The Quaiffe is a licensed version of the Gleason-Torsen torque sensing
differential. It uses a complex interwoven planetary gear setup to send
power to the wheel best able to use that power. It does not have a lockup
mode. The Gleason-Torsen is *WIDELY* used in high-power four-wheel drive
applications, as it is nearly indestructable, can transmit tons of power,
and is *NOT* a maintenence item.

I've compared (via seat of pants and stopwatch testing) the Quaffe, the
factory LSD, and a welded locker diff on the 914 and late 911s (915 gears).
For a full-race car that has enough power, and a driver that knows how
to drive such a thing, the locker is faster on high-speed courses. For
"Joe Average" (and maybe even "Joe A Little Above Average"), or for
low speed courses, and all autox applications, the Quaiffe is clearly the
best setup. The LSD is best reserved for those situations where sanctioning
body (like the Sports Car Communist Assholes) rules stipulate use of
the factory parts to remain in a "stock" class.

> a. Were there further developments on the 915 LS differential after 1982?  If 
> yes, what were they.

No. 

> b. Will a LSD from a G50 work in a 915?

No.

> c. Was there ever a variable lockup LSD available from Porsche which works in a 
> 915?

Define "variable". You can set the factory LSD lock-up when you're 
installing or rebuilding it. But not once it's in without taking it out.

> d. Were there different fixed lockup ratio's available from Porsche?

See above.

> e. Were there any LSD options available in Europe (actually ROW) which were not 
> available in the US?

Not that I'm aware of.

Stan

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1467                         Fri Jun 9 02:00:11 CDT 1995
Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 01:16:41 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: New Old 911 questions

> 	The engine is a 74 2.7 T.   What octane gas is best to use?

I run super unleaded -- at least -- in all my air-cooled engines. Have
a preference for Chevron, but that's arguably a personal preference.

> 	I plan on changing the oil and filter this weekend.  Any good oils
> or filters to use or bad ones to avoid?

As noted, I use Valvoline even though I no longer have a sponsorship deal
with them. Good stuff. On filters, *ONLY* use the factory OE filters. 
Fram and the American Purolator filters tend to explode due to overpressure
in certain failure modes. Usually you get the best prices from Zim's
in case quantities, $6 or so each.

> 	Just to be safe - any companies that make a cover to protect the 
> targa top from potential leaks??   

Certainteed makes a nice line of fiberglass and asphalt composite 
shingles... 8{)

> ANy good places that redo the vinyl(?) covering on the
> targa top - it couls use a little work.

I used Hinkle Auto Glass and Upholstery in Houston TX (713) 694-8194. They
do like-new work using OEM materials. I've had one-afternoon turnaround on
an unscheduled drive-in (after my top let loose in a major rain storm one
afternoon about 2:00 PM) for only about $325. They'll do "mail order" 
service, too, but I don't know on what pricing basis. Excellent work. They've
been doing concours-grade interior work on most German cars for about 30
years, plus "taxicab grade" interiors on 'merikun cars if that's what you
really want. It's an odd mix of true craftsmanship mortgaged to the
necessities of keeping the bills paid...

Stan

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 11:04:43 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Adhesive removal

On Thu, 8 Jun 1995, Steven Gilbert wrote:

> Subject: Adhesive removal
> 
> The safest product for adhesive removal is trichloroethane, which is

to the best of my ken, trike has long been banned from use in cleaning, 
as it is a cancer forming agent

we long ago (1975 ) stopped using it and used IPA ( iso propyl alcohol ) 
which is pretty useless at getting off Ziebart.

I once had a ziebart treated motor ( my trusted TR6 ) it used to p*ss me 
off because every time you wanted to change a plug, or do any thing, you 
ended covered in the stuff. I found that Jizer disolved it just fine, so 
every time I cleaned the engine bay I was left with a pool of oozing 
molten cak on the garage floor.

After that, I went and bought one of those big plactic trays that brickies 
use for knocking up mortar, it is ideal for catching engine leaks etc, 
and you can run over it without it breaking or even tipping up.

Pete
+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 07:58:29 -0400

Disclaimer:  I'm not a lawyer, nor do I play on on TV....

It seems to me that if you got a bill of sale from the dealer, then you've
got a sales contract for that amount stated on the bill of sale.  I'd 
contact a lawyer and have him send a nasty note to the dealer.  You seem
to be on pretty firm ground here.   Further evidence of sale is that the
dealer accepted the bank wire as payment for the car and let you have
possesion.

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 95 08:15:25 EDT
From: cohen@ATB.Teradyne.COM (steve cohen)
Subject: Re: distilled or tap?

Just to throw in my $0.02, the use of distilled water in batteries makes a lot of sense.  Batteries seem to be a machine that works by moving ions around.  If you use tap water some of those ions are already bound to minerals.

Does this make sense to anyone??

 -Steve

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 13:44:24 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: distilled or tap?

On Fri, 9 Jun 1995, steve cohen wrote:

> Subject: Re: distilled or tap?
> 

The trouble with tap water is that it is an unknown quanity

in some areas it it full of lime, and thus tends to cause little damage 
in other areas it can be slightly acidic - for example water running off 
off peat bogs (scotland etc) 

the acid areas pose the big problem, because you have a nice little 
battery cooking away, copper rad, aluminium head, and sundry iron 
components all washed in weak acid. I once took to bits a 2 year old 
central heating system that had been run with acidic tap water. the 
pressed steel rads were full of FeO not rust but black iron oxide, there 
were numerous pin holes in the rads.

I guess that the manufacturers say distilled water, so they can be fairly 
certain of what they are mixing with the anti-freeze

Pete

+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 09:17:25 -0400
From: JUtter914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 starter advice needed

I had the same problem a couple of years ago -- intermittent non-starts when
hot, no problem when cold.  Had a starter relay put in and no problem since.
 Just checked Perf. Prod. and they sell a starter relay for $20.95 complete
with instructions.  Claims 10-minute screwdriver and plier installation.

John Utter
'76 914

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 95 06:23:03 PDT
From: thatguy@uplex.net (Tim P. Heikell)
Subject: 73 911 batteries

>Return-Path: <porschephiles-request@tta.com>
>From: Marcott911@aol.com
>Date: Wed, 7 Jun 1995 23:44:37 -0400
>To: porschephiles@tta.com
>Subject: 73 911 batteries
>
>I'm converting from the stock dual batteries to a single battery
>so does aney one know what single battery to use.
>
>Tom Marcotte 
>      73 911 targa
>
>

In my opinion the only battery to use is the Optima 8000 dry cell battery so 
you no longer have to worry about corrosion problems due to the battery. 
I've been told it has more cranking power than the two original batteries. 
The only catch is you have to mount it on it's side but it's really no 
problem since these batteries do not have to be mounted upright.

Tim

Date: Fri,  9 Jun 95 12:00:45 PDT
From: Robert M Zampardi <us000812@interramp.com>
Subject: 77s -> 87 turbo, The Story, long

Since so many have asked about 77s-87turbo here goes:

The story goes like this:

Boy has 77s drives it around, thought it was pathetic, (tired suspension, 
sticky pedals,a/c that didnt, IMHO weak motor for the weight of the car) 
sells motor to Joe Povi aka man with dp 935, looks around and finds an 87 
turbo drivetrain and suspension for sale.
Buys it.
During the 6 month project many people saw it in the shop and made comments, 
some
were sorry to see a 77s cut up to be a turbo, others thought it was a neat 
idea; pretty
obvious what I thought.  Just for kicks I drove it by the original owner that 
I bought it
from, he couldnt believe it was the same car,  (He is a realtor and opened an 
office 1mile from the shop)  He asked for a ride; I said no just to be a 
a-hole.

Motor had 29k miles on it, with one of those big ss exhaust systems on it.
Front suspension went in easy, just a few bolts had to be ordered for the 
thicker mounts.
Rear suspension was another story, it turns out that 87 rear susp arms are 
SHORTER
then 77s.  So new brackets had to fabed and installed, easier done then said.

Then we went to bolt the motor in, but the tranny mount wants to push the 
motor
back 1.5 inches, so a new crossmember had to be fabd, and some room made for
the turbo.

Electric, hole had to be drilled to run wires to mount computer under driver 
seat, no big deal, a little bit of harness work was done to wire in the dual 
fuel pumps and different CD box, no big deal.

I fitted 8x15 in the front and 10x15 fuchs in the rear, glass front fenders, 
steel turbo
rear quarters, glass IROC turbo tail. (big)

People break their necks trying to look at it, right now its in yellow primer 
getting ready
for MR2 yellow paint. This color is a little more green then the turbo 
yellow.
I like it, we painted the tail that color to test it, looks great.

The whole project took about 6mos to complete, and a lot of money.
Worth it, yes and no.
No in that It took so long and I will probably have to sell it, tho I dont 
want too.
Yes in that it is lighter then an 87 turbo and has the same 
brakes/suspension...

Oh if any one is interested in it, the price is 22k firm.

Other mods: turbo pedal assembly, turbo oil cooler in rt front fender, new 
radio,
new windshield with antenna in glass.

If there is enough interest i will post a picture.


RZ
- -------------------------------------
Name: Robert M Zampardi, MADMAX, see below
E-mail: us000812@pop3.interramp.com (Robert M Zampardi)

THE PORSCHE FLEET, etc

73 Race 914 custom cage, cell, no seat/motor,
73 914, Rust Free Project, (like I need another)  4 Sale

76 Street 914, Lagoon Blue, with Saratoga Top     4 Sale

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 95 11:39:29 EDT

Sure fire: point out to him that if he fails to deliver the appropriately
endorsed title within 5 business days, at no additional charge, you
will pursue a fraud charge against him. Have a lawyer write him a letter
to that effect. Then, if you haven't received the title within five days,
file a criminal complaint against him. This will work, unless you have
not actually told the whole story there...

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 09:50:24 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re: Early 911/912 interior question

I have my rear seats out (1975 99S), the tail is about 23 cm (or 9 inches to 
imperialists), but one thing I noticed is there is a piece of fibreboard (you 
know hte german stuff that is the result of mating wood with cardboard) 
attached to the backside of the tail. This is about 7 cm wide and appears to 
have no other use than to make sure the thing lays flat and doesn't rumple as 
you suggested yours did. Question would be whether this is a later update or 
whether someone else has removed yours from your car or what....

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 16:45:37 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Porsche 944 Engine Durability / 911 Costs


Hi Naresh

I am a high mileage 944 driver, my current stead now has 127k miles.

My engine appears to have plenty of life left in it, however there are 
lots of other things that tend to wear out.

as you have been round the list for a while, you will know about engine 
mounts, brake rotors, cam belts.

I would also add interior trim, if the trim is tatty, expect to spend 
$1000 to buy replacement seats lockerbox etc. I also have a shot radiator 
$200.

window lifters may be worn, the list is endless

Right now to get my machine back to a lets say "good condition" would 
cost me around $2000.

If the engine was seized solid, a replacement engine from george b would 
cost say $1500, so seen in that light you can see that you need to 
consider carefully the whole condition of the car. If you can find an 
early car with say 60k miles for another 2k or so then I think I would 
try to find the extra cash ( yeh I know about student funds ) anyway go 
look at it, make a comprehensive list of things you want to check, then 
be carefull it's easy to get seduced once the engine goes rrrm.

Oh by the may, if the owner turns the hi-fi on before he starts the 
engine, you can guarantee he is trying to hide some unpleasant noise.

Have fun

Pete

Date: 9 Jun 95 08:54:00 -0700
From: MIFSUD_BRIAN@Tandem.COM
Subject: 914 to 911 Wheel/Tire/Brake Conversion

Hi All,
  Am laying groundwork for switching over to 5-lug 16"x6" 911 wheels/brakes on
my '76 2.0 914.  I'm interested in a long lasting (big commute miles) compound
for the 16" tires.  I realize that this wheel format is intended for high
performance and thus (usually) soft "grippy" compounds.  Who makes a 16" (50ser
es) tire that leans toward the hard compound/high mileage side?  My definition
of "high mileage" is a tire that is good for about 40K miles. What is price
range for these tires.  ( I would expect around $ 150/ea)
  Also, anyone have any 914-6 rear hubs they want to unload?
   Now the Politics:  Regarding the "Camaro-Admirer or XXXXXX-Brand Bashing", I
                     feel that comparisons or even COMPLIMENTS toward other
                     brands and models is ENTIRELY appropriate in this forum. I
                     use this People-Base as a resource to LEARN as much as I
                     can about PORSCHES.  Since I have the HUMILITY to ADMIT
                     that I HAVEN'T owned or driven or got to know intimately
                     every aspect of every PORSCHE, I leap at the OPPORTUNITY
                     for comparisons to be made to cars I am familiar with.
                     The use of ANALOGY is a very POWERFUL learning tool.
    Camaros do some things very well where Porsches are quite pathetic, and
    VICE VERSA. There is nothing wrong with pursuing the DREAM car, which
  MIGHT include incredible handling, incredible acceleration, and incredible
  reliability.  I admire well engineered machinery, no matter what the NATION
 of ORIGIN, or INTENT or DESIGNER.  Remember, ALL these cars are for FUN
(including neck-straining BIG BLOCK, HARD AXLE, 2x4 suspended gas-hogs)

freeway - that way you get to drag and go for top speed in a single

bent and slipped the clutch a little off the line to avoid wheelspin 
(what little that wheezy powerplant could muster) and we were off!  We 
were only even to the top of 1st gear - when I hit second, I knew I'd 
lost.  Everytime he let off to shift, his 914 would backfire and spit 
flame - which only dramatized his victory.

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 95 09:13:20 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 951 Oil Pressure Indication


Steve Jagernauth reported that the oil pressure dropped and the oil light
came on when the intake tube worked loose on his 951.

This is probably normal for the Motronic system when this occurs. The 
system is all elctric, the idiot light comes on when there is ignition
on but no fire on the engine. The event reset the ignition to the "on"
but engine not running point. The loss of indicated oil pressure is 
because the engine ignition and the DME box were off, electrically 
speaking. 

This can happen to all CIS and DME equipped Porsches when the intake
tract develops a sudden, massive air leak between the throttle plate 
and the airflow sensor. 924 owners have had one of the rubber tubes pop
off the intermediate tube with the same results Steve had. 

If this occurs, do as Steve did, reconnect the loose pieces and the car 
will start. If something occured that was expensive, you will hear it or 
see no or low oil pressure.

I have seen very few 924/944/928s with any sort of massive oil pump/
system failures outside of the oil cooler on the 944. Failures seen on
track vehicles were concentrated at #2 main and rod bearings for other 
reasons. If you have a bad 944 motor mount, it can break the oil pickup
tube in the sump. I have two from club members that managed to catch the 
problem before it ruined the bearings.

If you have any reason to suspect oil pressure, substitute a mechanical
gauge at the point the stock gauge takes pressure and compare. I have 
had a few bad VDO senders and gauges in my cars. One did go to zero and
gave me a real start. I tapped it and it worked again for 15 minutes.

Jim Pasha

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 11:06:08 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Big Brakes for a Modified '75 911S

	I am in the process of rebuilding a 1975 911S, upgrades are numerous 
but include a Kremer built 3.2, with K-jetronic and SSI's, based on an SC 
case, Carrera flares and attendant tire size increases to 17 inch (255/40 rear 
and 205/50 front).

Question is whether anyone out there has had any experience with adding the 
power brake booster to a non-power brake equipped car, and secondly, has 
anyone out there have any experience with any of the numerous big brake 
upgrades. My bias is towards using the C2 Turbo "red" calipers, but I am not 
sure how the other options would work and how reliable and well engineered are 
the adapters which mount them. I currently have the type M calipers all 
around, and expect to have to use bolt on adapter pieces.

Other question is what to do about rotors and the mounting of them. Any 
experiences which perhaps I can learn from? It makes sense to me to move to 
the cross drilled rotors which would match the C2 calipers, but have looked 
with lust at the aluminum composite rotors in Panorama...

Car will be a street driver, odd bit of track time (for the fun of it), but 
since I may be transferrred back to Europe for a while I want to be able to 
bahnstorm with the best of them!!

Dennis Kalma

REGARDING                911 search 

Hi Gang,

O.K., so the 912E wasn't such'a hot idea.  Thanks for all the info, even the
loving owners of 912E's alluded to the fact that it's a bit under powered(a
dog!), thermal units...overheating, a/c brackets that are prone to breakage,
parts that are no longer available.....the general consensus seemed to be
"hold out for the 911, if you can't afford that, get a 914!"

So the S.O., after a quick drool on the nice neighbor's beautiful Petrol
Blue'79 SC, has given in.  The "search" is now back to the 911.

More questions:
Spoilers-Were the "Factory Spoilers" a dealer installed option or did the cars
come from the factory with them.  How could you tell (and would you care?) if
the spoilers were install after purchase?  Are any of the after market
spoilers "better" than the factory?  I understand that the factory spoilers
have a second a/c condenser in them, would this be a way to discover a
nonoriginal installation? Were they a common option?  If I find "THE CAR" and
it doesn't have the spoiler kit, how big of a deal is it to add($$?) and how
does it affect the cars value(+-).

86 A/C vents- I've been told that the '86 P-car has better A/C vents, a big
deal here in the desert! Are the Fresh air/heater and A/C vents different duct
systems? Is there a really noticeable improvement?  I rather not rule out
pre'86 cars, but if the A/C was marginal before, it's a big factor. Forty five
consecutive days over110F last summer!!!

87 G-50(?) transmission- same questions as the A/C, is this a big deal or just
an incremental improvement?

"Buy the latest Porsche you can afford" >>>>>> I'm going to have this tattooed
on my ..........

Again, thanks to everyone, YEA STAN! :-)) this is a great list!

Subject: Re:Porsche 944 Engine Durability / 911 Costs


<---- Begin Included Message ---->
Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 10:50:41 -0400 (EDT)
>From: "Naresh H. Singh" <nhs1681@is2.NYU.EDU>
Subject: Porsche 944 Engine Durability / 911 Costs
To: Porschephiles <porschephiles@tta.com>


Hi Porschephiles,

By the end of summer I hope to be a Porsche owner. I'm not a "newbie" per se,
I've been on the list for the past six months and have read the FAQ's so I
know the standard stuff (timing belts, water pumps, maintenance records, etc)
I have come across a couple good prospects in the past and the list has been
most helpful in offering advise. Thanks!

My new question is: How many miles can you get from a 944 engine without 
doing a rebuild ? (Assume average maintenance, I know YMMV :) 

I ask this because there is a '87 944 advertised w/ 130k miles for asking 
price 
$5,000. Sounds to good to be true! (Haven't seen it yet, it probably is :)


Also, I've gotten 944 average yearly maintenance costs estimates from list 
members in the $1,000 to $2,000 range. What would maintenance costs on a 
74-77 911S run me ? (I know about the 2.7 durability issue :)


As always thanks for any and all advise!


Naresh H. Singh

2 pieces of Detroit Metal (soon to be one)
'92 German Shepherd "Bandit" (hey, at least he is German!) 


<---- End Included Message ---->
Naresh, I have an 84 944 with 79,000 miles on it. I purchased it in 1989 with 
32,000 miles and have spent the following on maintenance and repairs. All 
costs are in Canadian dollars.

front brake pads - $27
slave cylinder kit - $8
timing belt,pulley & labor - $200
cap & rotor - $100
tires - $400
tune up - $60
spark plugs - $10
alternator rebuild - $65
regular oil changes - $20
fan temp switch - $17

I do all my own work with the exception of tensioning the timing and balance 
shaft belts.
I also drive it in the winter (I know, I know) but the car always starts, has 
a great heater and shows no affects of road salt (I try to keep it clean). For 
my money I'ld be hard pressed to find a Japanese car that 
has been as trouble free as my 944. I understand in talking to Bruce Anderson, 
the technical editor of Excellence magazine, that a well maintained 944 engine 
should be good for up to 200,000 miles.

John Lowe (Calgary, Alberta)
84 944
92 SHO 
looking for a 1989 944 Turbo

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 13:08:03 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: My 1st 914 experience

>        That's strange, I thought the decel. valve was supposed to shut off
>fuel on overrun....

        There's something that shuts off the fuel on overrun on the earliest
cars (like yours), but the "decel valve" on later cars (at least 73+) was
for the exact opposite purpose.  It lets air bypass the closed throttle on
overrun.  It was discovered that shutting off the fuel on overrun actually
created *more* emissions instead of less!  Supposedly due to the air-cooled
nature of the beast.
        The 2.0 decel valves are adjustable--you get to pick how quickly
you want your engine to drop back to idle.  Not sure if the 1.7's are or
not, and I can't find anything on my 1.8's valve to adjust...

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"

Date: Fri, 09 Jun 1995 12:56:51 -0500
From: stamper@interaccess.com (scott sanda)
Subject: Re: Porsche Factory LSD versus Quaife


Nice artical, with good explainations, but as both an SCCA and PCA racer, I
have to take exception to your feelings on SCCA rules. I don't know of any
current class that requires a factory limited slip in SCCA, The various
GCR's and such all seem to indicate that any limited slip is ok. (with the
possible exception of showroom stock... actually by definition, showroom
stock must have factory items).

It is PCA (racing) that has a silly rule about limited slip diffs, saying a
factory diff is ok, but a non factory diff moves you up one class.

Now if you want to help me complain over a beer about the shamefull lack of
classes for Porsche in SCCA, I'll buy!


Scott Sanda
86 944 race car (SCCA ITS)

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 15:08:25 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Wheel polishing

This is a matter of taste. 89 944 turbo wheels were anodized and once damaged
they are a bear to fix. You can have them re anodized to close to the
original, polished and clear coated to your taste, or polished and them
chromed, again to your taste. 
IMHO just polishing is a short term deal. They will look good for awhile but
soon go tatty on you.
Any method requires the removal of the original anodizing and this is not a
small job.
Regards,
Jerry

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 15:05:04 -0500 (CDT)
From: Chuck Campbell <campbell@Starbase.NeoSoft.COM>
Subject: Re: Distilled vs. Tap H20, chemical explanation.

> 
> While I certainly won't try to argue chemistry with Barry, the 
> owners and shop manual for my car say specifically to use distilled
> water.  Could it be that the antifreeze helps to neutralize the 
> corrosive affects of the water?
> 
> Ross Stites
> '87 951

While I don't claim to be a chemist either, your owner's and shop manuals
make the most sense to me.  Sure distilled water is corrosive due to it's
lack of metal ions, but tap water has many things in it which are not really
harmful to your cooling system directly, they can (and often are) deposited
in the system.  

Think of boiling a pan of tap water dry, you get all the salts (metals)
deposited on the inside of the pan, and it requires a corrosive acid to
remove them (ie. vinegar).

Theoretically, deionized or distilled water will not contain these things to
be deposited, and instead, being corrosive, it should help pick up those same
salts (metals) from your cooling system.  This is why we flush and change
coolant periodically.

Antifreeze may (I don't know) have a specific chemistry to control this 
corrosive nature of distilled water (I strongly suspect this is the case).
Using distilled water with antifreeze prevents you from introducing anything
else which may be much more corrosive, and which the antifreeze is not designed
to control.

 -chuck


1983 911 Cabriolet (Guards Red)
- -- 

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 95 15:23 EST
From: Peter Rhim <0006877381@mcimail.com>
Subject: 88 & 89 951 Question

I was looking through the FAQ on 944s & Barry's recent post on 944s and was
trying to figure out which year 951 to target for purchase...

First, what, if anything, is the difference between the 88 Turbo S and the 89
Turbo (besides the year and the S after Turbo ;-)?  From what I have read, they
both have the same 250hp engine.  What else (suspension, brakes, special
packages, etc) is different from 88 to 89?  Which year should I buy if given a
choice (all else being the same: mileage, maintenance, condition, etc.)?

Second, given the *small* number of these cars sold in the US, do I have a
chance in hell of finding one these two beauties?  What would be an appropriate
price range for a well maintained 88 Turbo S or 89 Turbo?

Barry or George: care to share any more of your knowledge on 944s?

TIA,
Peter
6877381@mcimail.com
No Porsches *yet*

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 17:27:09 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Re: 88 & 89 951 Question


Hi Peter,

In a message dated 95-06-09 16:33:36 EDT, you write:

>First, what, if anything, is the difference between the 88 Turbo S and
>the 89 Turbo (besides the year and the S after Turbo ;-)?  From what 
>I have read, they both have the same 250hp engine.  What else 
>(suspension, brakes, special packages, etc) is different from 88 to 89?  
>Which year should I buy if given a choice (all else being the same: 
>mileage, maintenance, condition, etc.)?

There is really NO difference between an 88 Turbo S and an 89 Turbo. I quote
the Porsche brochure for the 89 944 Turbo

  "However impressive such a level of performance may be [talking about
original 944 turbo], last year [88] Porsche introduced an even higher
performance version of the 944 Turbo. Produced in a limited series of a 1000,
this automobile was derived directly from a racing version that competed in
the Porsche Turbo Cup series waged throughout Western Europe. For 1989 the
new 944 Turbo includes all performance chacteristics of the 944 Turbo S. It
features 30 BHP more power, significantly higher torque and improved
suspension, brakes wheels and tires..."

So all 89 944 Turbos are really Turbo S models. I would look for either one.
Buy the car that is in better condition, regardless of year.

>
>Second, given the *small* number of these cars sold in the US, do I
>have a chance in hell of finding one these two beauties?  What would 
>be an appropriate price range for a well maintained 88 Turbo S or 89 Turbo?
>

One thing that surprised me when I was looking for my car was that I was able
to find plenty of cars for sale. Of course they were scattered around the US.
I actually found three of them withing an hours drive of my house, but the
owners all wanted about $3000 more than I was willing to pay. I eventually
found a suitable car in Florida (I live in NY), had it checked by a mechanic
(oddly enough, my local shop recommended a mechanic in the south), flew to
Atlanta, bought the car, and drove it back to NY). 

Of course when I took it to my shop for a PCA tech inspection, my mechanic
insisted that I replace the water pump and all belts before he would let me
drive it on the track, (about $1000) but that's another story...

If you look in Panorama, Excellence, Autoweek and Hemmings, you can find
plenty of the cars. Current prices range in the $17 -$22K range, depending on
condition. I also found a few at Porsche dealers. Any car bought from a
dealer (year 87+) includes a 1 year UNLIMITED mileage warranty. This might
make it worthwhile to buy a car from a dealer. I thought I save a LOT of
money buying from a private person.

Good luck in your search. These cars are fantastic, and are about the fastest
best handling cars you'll ever see. 

Let me know if you need more info.

Barry Lenoble
BLenoble@aol.com
89 944 Turbo, Alpine White


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 17:29:02 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 88 & 89 951 Question

At 03:23 PM 6/9/95 EST, Peter Rhim wrote:
>First, what, if anything, is the difference between the 88 Turbo S and the 89
>Turbo (besides the year and the S after Turbo ;-)?  From what I have read, they
>both have the same 250hp engine.  What else (suspension, brakes, special
>packages, etc) is different from 88 to 89?  Which year should I buy if given a
>choice (all else being the same: mileage, maintenance, condition, etc.)?
>
>Second, given the *small* number of these cars sold in the US, do I have a
>chance in hell of finding one these two beauties?  What would be an appropriate
>price range for a well maintained 88 Turbo S or 89 Turbo?

The definitive answer can be found in the MY89 944 Turbo Technical Info
book from PCNA.  I have a copy but do not have it or its p/n handy.  The
differences were small.  At some point, they changed the brake calliper
piston sizes.  They also dropped the rear anti-sway from 16 to 14 mm.;
forget exactly when.

There are lots of both the MY88 and MY89 cars around, and lots for sale.
At the time, PCNA had overproduced them for the US market, and a large
number of them went for well below list price.

I would not worry about 88 vs 89 differences.  Find a nice clean one of
either year, and think about fine-tuning the package later if it becomes
terribly important to you.

Kevin Gross

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 95 17:51 EDT
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: 88 & 89 951 Question

BLenoble@aol.com writes:
    If you look in Panorama, Excellence, Autoweek and Hemmings, you can find
    plenty of the cars. Current prices range in the $17 -$22K range, depending on
    condition. I also found a few at Porsche dealers. Any car bought from a
    dealer (year 87+) includes a 1 year UNLIMITED mileage warranty. This might
    make it worthwhile to buy a car from a dealer. I thought I save a LOT of
    money buying from a private person.

Just so people don't get the wrong idea, if you buy an '87+ Porsche from an
authorized dealer, a 1-year warranty is AVAILABLE, at extra cost.  They aren't
included with the price of the car.

At least, mine wasn't, and I know of one other person who paid for theirs --
has anyone gotten one gratis?

Cheers!  Have a good weekend!
- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 17:02:04 -0500

>
>	I'm having trouble with my rear calipers and wanted some info on the
>rebuild kit.  Brad said they are not doing Porsche 914 rear caliper rebuilds
>because the kit that does the job best (Porsche's, of course) is not
>available right now.                    ^^^^^^^^^


The brakes on my 914 were ATE's. I have the empty box from my rebuild. Here'
s the ATE # on them 13.0441-3303.2 (repair kit 1ea). I had no problems with 
them.

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 15:31:24 -0700
From: "William Dunham" <dunham@bonehead.esd.sgi.com>

I saw an add this morning in the local paper (San Jose Mercury), all it
said was '72 911S good condition, no price or other description. It turned
out that it was a real S, needed some body work (dents and dings mostly) but
otherwise orignal and in running order. It had been sitting for three years.

It sold today for $6,500, the guy got his first call at 7:30AM.  Does this
sound like someone got a deal?  Of course, it depends on the specifics
of the condition, but it seems cheap for a complete, runing 911S if fair
mechanical shape.  I've seen pretty run down 72 and 73 T's sell for more.
Today was the first day the listing showed up in the paper.

Bill

Subject: 944: paint & owner's manual



My '88 944 isn't quite mint:  There's a little spot on the front fascia
(down low) where somebody must have bumped a snowbank and the plastic 
flexed and a very small triangle of paint popped off.

The car is all original paint.  I feel reluctant to paint any panels and 
just try and touch this up.  With other brands of cars, I've been able to 
find a decent match (eventually) at automotive paint stores, but the only 
Porsche literature I have says that the paint is "special" and has a 
certain fade characteristic/etc. that has to be matched.  Is this special 
paint?  Will those characteristics be matched with brands like PPG or 
DuPont, or must I find a can of paint from across the Atlantic?


Also:  There was no owner's manual.  Kudos to the FAQ and its 
contributors; I had uncuccessfully tried everything short of a crowbar 
(jesting) to get that sunroof off and for many days I hung my head in 
shame - bested by its complexity!

I don't even have an address or phone of wherever I might get the manual 
from.  Any suggestions where I might get one?  Shoud I just go to the dealer
or is there and easier/cheaper way to get one?  Junkyard?  It's an '88 944.

Thanks.

James

I found DAP Weldwood Cleaner & Thinner at Home Depot today.  It's
1-1-1 trichlorethane, probably same as 3M Adhesive Remover, easier to
get, and cheaper.  It's in the paint/solvent section, green and white
can.

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 22:09:34 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Re: Porsche Factory LSD vs Quaif

stamper@interaccess.com (scott sanda) wrote :

> as both an SCCA and PCA racer, I have to take exception to your 
> feelings on SCCA rules. I don't know of any current class that requires 
> a factory limited slip in SCCA, The various GCR's and such all seem 
> to indicate that any limited slip is ok. (with the possible exception of 
> showroom stock... 
> It is PCA (racing) that has a silly rule about limited slip diffs, saying a
> factory diff is ok, but a non factory diff moves you up one class.

Here's an autocrossers view of the silliness of the PCA rules.
In SCCA Solo-II Stock class, you can use ONLY the factory LSD with
no penalty, but ONLY if it came stock in your year and model.

In PCA's stock (production) class PCRs, you get penalty points even 
if it was stock. An aftermarket LSD (quaife) seems to be legal
with the same penalty points, but I'm not sure.
In SCCA street prepared, you can use any type of LSD
(except for the grateful dead type).

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S with no LSD (just a few hallucinations)

Date: Fri, 9 Jun 95 21:34:04 -0500
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William Marten)
Subject: 914 Ground straps/rear caliper kits

Dave Darling mentioned spontaneous re-routing of the ground in the 
914 a couple of digests ago.  When this happened to me, it was the 
accelerator cable that was forced into service.  Not a good 
arrangement.  The cable is rather small (relatively), heated up and 
melted the casing causing the accelerator to sieze (fortunately, 
throttle *closed*).  If you find you have to push increasingly hard 
on your accelerator, check the ground strap. 
 
Someone else mentioned sub-standard rear caliper rebuild kits.  The 
story I heard several years ago was rebuild kits were not made 
available by the factory initially (as in "when the car was new") and 
so a 'substitute' was found in an effort to avoid buying new calipers 
every time one started to leak.  The 'substitute' was a VW kit.  The 
seals didn't fit well, but it was better than $400 per for some 
people.  The story has persisted, however, and some parts vendors 
maintain that 'appropriate' kits are unavailable. 
 
I have rebuilt a whole 4 (oooo, ahhhh) rear calipers using the kits 
from Automobile Atlanta and have never had a problem.  YMMV. 
 
Bill
wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu
Madison, WI, USA


------------------------------

Actually ('scuse the lesson) we have 6 states and 2 territorys (no provinces
here :^). WA(Perth); SA(Adelaide); Queensland(Brisbane); NSW(Sydney);
Victoria(Melbourne); Tasmania(Hobart) and the Northern Territory(Darwin)
Oh...and the Australian Capital territory(Our Capital, Canberra) (end lesson)

Someone else has asked me the same question regarding LHD P-Cars in Oz ... 
we have an excellent selection of RHD's here, so ..unfortunately
there's not much point bringing them in (unless you intend to convert them)
There is one chap I know of in South Australia who is however importing 911's
from the US for that VERY reason. P-Cars have an extrodinarily high resale 
value here (a bit of a shame..but it keeps the RIFF RAFF out of 'em hee hee)

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 10 Jun 1995 08:10:21 -0400
From: BUBBAUSA@aol.com
Subject: Re: Beware 914 Caliper Rebuild Kits

The kits sold now are ATE and a mixed bag of other vendors-but they actually
for a SAAB...NOT a 914.  The guys at UGI are extremely careful to handle only
the CORRECT part. The SAAB kit works ok but the seals are different in the
thousandths of mm in measurement and thus not an EXACT fit. Until recently
the Porsche/ATE kits were available, but for some reason the are NLA
temporarily. Most vendors latched on to the closest thing...a sale is a sale
and parts is parts....right? I  can not say authoritatively if the SAAB kit
will work in the long haul...after many heat cycles, etc etc....but I think
searching for the correct part is a worthwhile thing especially if its brake
related.      IMHO :-)

Date: Sat, 10 Jun 95 16:44:00 PDT
From: "Thiger Jonas, Netsupport" <jonas.thiger@netsupport.telia.se>
Subject: 944 Turbo Cup

May be taking up unnecessary bandwith with uninteresting stuff, but as a 
supplement to what I mentioned earlier on the Turbo Cup cars, here are 
the differencies compared to standard Turbos:

944 Turbo Cup '86, around 45 produced.
Oil Pan and Air inlet pipe in magnesium.
Driver's Race seat and 6-point harness.
Roll cage
No PS, AC, PW, sound insulation, etc. 55 kg lighter than regular Turbo.
Adjustable spring+shocks front & rear (coil-overs).
Stiffer bushings.
Larger brakes, Fuchs wheels.
220 hk, 270 km/h, 0-100 in 5,9 sec. (Beats me why the Cup car is faster than 
the regular. 55 kg isn't that much...)

944 Turbo Cup '87-88, less than 50 produced '87, no info '88.
Same as '86 plus:
ABS
Larger brakes (same as 944 Turbo S)
Front Brake cooling kit
Stiffer suspension & bushings
New seat and roll cage.
New wheels 8/9 inch, magnesium (Phone dial most common).
Fibreglass hood.
Larger Turbo, boost 0,8 bar, 250 hk (Turbo S)
1165 kg, 290 km/h

'89 no info.

With reservations, Source magazines might be full of errors!

Jonas Thiger
Lulea, Sweden
'87 944 Limone gelb

Date: 7 Jun 1995 13:50:05 -0400
From: "Nathan Ulrich" <nu@barrett.com>
Subject: 944/968 control arm replace

                      944/968 control arm replacements
I'm glad to see the PMNA acknowledges the problem with stock 944 control arms,
although their proposed part is expensive and not really a major improvement.
The following is an explanation of the 944 control arm failure problem based on
the information we've been able to gather. I prepared this to provide
information to 944/968 owners who have asked for a relatively concise
explanation of the problem, and who are concerned that they are in danger of
experiencing a failure.  Please feel free to distribute this to anyone who is interested.

The Sports Imports Racing replacement control arm prototypes have now been track
tested on two different cars, and destructive strength testing of one of the
prototype arms (in comparison to stock aluminum arms) will begin shortly. 
Volume production has begun and we expect arms to be available for both pre-87
and 87-on cars to be available from stock in approximately four weeks.  The arm
is fabricated from chrome-moly steel, is heat-treated, and has replaceable ball
joint bearings and studs, as well as spherical front pivot bearings and
adjustable rod-end swaybar mounts (with adapters available for both stock and
popular aftermarket swaybars).  The price is $650/arm.

Please contact Scott at 508 563-3848 to order, or myself (Nathan Ulrich) at 508
564-4995 for technical questions.

<< Begin enclosure >>


944 Front Control Arm Failure

Nathan Ulrich
Technical Director, Sports Imports Racing


A number of individuals have reported problems with failure of 944 front control
arms in track use. Since a control arm failure can have dramatic consequences in
high-speed driving, this problem has received a great deal of attention recently.
This explanation is the result of anecdotal evidence from individuals who have
experienced failures as well as technical analysis of the stock cast aluminum
control arm and two acceptable replacements, the Fabcar arm and the Sports
Imports Racing product.

The stock cast aluminum control arms exhibit two failures in track use:  first,
the arm fractures at the anti-roll bar mounting point; second, the ball joint
loosens in its mounting bore and/or fractures at the base of the stud.  Although
it is difficult to determine this conclusively, the parts in question seem to
fail primarily because of material fatigue rather than overload.

Both types of failure are much more likely on cars with stiff anti-roll bars and
stock or near-stock spring rates.  In this situation, nearly all of the roll
resistance is caused by the anti-roll bars, which puts very high loads on both
the mounting point and the ball joint stud.

The first type of failure occurs because the stock Porsche casting is marginal
in strength for cars with stiff anti-roll bars and stock springs. Voids or inclusions
in the casting, repeated high shock loading (such as hitting curbs or off-course
excursions), or simply many miles of service can eventually lead to failure.
Simply because of the geometry of the forces, the danger is exacerbated by
anti-roll bars which mount above the A-arm (for example, the ubiquitous Weltmeister
bars). The suggested Porsche Motorsport alloy control arm is not significantly
better than the stock arm in this failure mode.

The second type of failure, fracture of the ball joint stud, is not as easily
explained. Unlike some information has suggested, there is no evidence that wear
in the joint or cracking of the epoxy potting at the bottom of the ball joint is
necessarily a contributing factor to the failure, but rather is a further symptom
of control arms that have been highly stressed. There have been reports of
brand-new control arms exhibiting cracking of the epoxy. Again, very stiff
anti-roll bars with stock springs cause high forces at the ball joint studs,
which eventually can lead to failure. The little anecdotal evidence available
suggests it is a tension failure rather than a shear failure. Cars that have
been lowered can exhibit a geometry in hard cornering that maximizes tensile
stress on the inside ball joint, causing failure.

Because there is so much variation between the various 944 models, as well as
between each car which has aftermarket suspension parts, it is difficult to
accurately predict which cars are at the highest risk.  However, it is clear
that cars with stiffer aftermarket anti-roll bars are more likely to experience
control arm failure.  In addition, lowering these cars can significantly lower
the roll center, which increases the roll moment and can dramatically increase
the stress on the control arm and ball joint.  This is why IMSA has required
replacement of the stock control arms for the Firehawk (now Street Stock)
series, where cars are lowered, endurance raced on sticky tires, and driven aggressively.

Replacement of the stock control arms is recommended for cars that are modified
and are driven aggressively on the race track. There are currently four options
available. Some firms are adding reinforcement to the early (Rabbit-style) arms
and suggesting these as a replacement. These arms, in their original form, are
dangerously overstressed even in street use, but will usually bend rather than
break.  Adding sufficient reinforcment to make them safe for track use would be
very difficult, especially since they are formed of mild steel and cannot be
heat-treated.  In some cases, welding reinforcement to these arms may add stress
raisers or brittle weld areas, resulting in a control arm more dangerous than
the original part.

Dave Klym of Fabcar has been supplying replacement control arms for some time.
The Fabcar arms are simply a copy of the stock design in sheet steel. They are
approximately 50% stronger than the stock control arms, and, although there were
early problems with the design, seem to have worked well in Firehawk use.

Porsche Motorsport North America is offering a factory motorsport version of the
aluminum control arms which has an improved ball joint fixing.  Although this
should minimize the chances of a ball joint loosening and/or failing, it is only
a marginal improvement.  These arms are not significantly more resistant to
breakage at the anti-roll bar mounting point.

The Sports Imports Racing control arms are a proper engineering redesign, and
have been developed to handle the extreme loads experienced in professional
racing use. They are fabricated from tubular alloy steel, with plate
reinforcement and gusseting, are heat-treated and are approximately three times as
strong as the stock arms. Although originally designed only for racing use on
the SIR Porsche 944 Turbo race car, there has been sufficient interest from PCA
members that a small production run has been started and the control arms are
available for sale.


Sports Imports Racing was formed in 1993 as the racing division of Sports
Imports of Cape Cod, based in North Falmouth, Massachusetts. SIR has prepared
and raced 944s and 944 Turbos successfully in a variety of SCCA amateur and
professional racing series, winning two championships and setting two lap
records in the process. They currently campaign a car in IMSA's Exxon Supreme GT
series. Dr. Ulrich, SIR technical director, has been developing suspension and
chassis components for 944 series race cars since 1992.  In addition, he has
extensive experience in the field of mechanical design on projects ranging from
NASA space robots to consumer electronic imaging products.




------------------------------

Date: Thu, 08 Jun 1995 17:10:42 -0500
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@medtronic.com>
Subject:  914 starter advice needed -Reply

robert merithew <merithew@uxa.cso.uiuc.edu> writes:
>I'm in the middle of a cross-country trip in my 914 and am
>having trouble with the starter.
>
>Power gets to the solenoid when I turn the ignition to 'start',
>and power gets to the big terminal on the starter (the one
>straight from the battery).  The solenoid clicks feebly and
>the alternator and oil light dim when I try to start it.

Heh, heh, heh...  mine did the exact same thing on a trip from
Kaliforn-i-a to Wisconsin.  After a goodly amount of driving,
the starter would soak up heat from the engine and quit working.
After things cooled down, the starter would work fine.  The
relay kit is supposed to fix this.  In my case, I had a worn terminal
in the "start" position of the ignition switch and the wire from the
ignition to the starter solenoid was partially broken.

When this happens, a way to get going again in an emergency
is to set the parking brake, make *SURE* the transmission is in
neutral, turn the ignition switch to run, reach under the back end
with a screwdriver, and short the big terminal on the solenoid
(straight from the battery) to the solenoid terminal from the ignition
(the one on the right, I think).  This energizes the starter solenoid
directly from the battery.  Be very careful if you do this as you will
have your head and body under/behind the car when the engine
starts.

The best thing is to fix the problem so you don't have to do this, but
this trick has saved me a couple of times on long trips.

Pete Klager
'75 914  1.8L

Date: Sat, 10 Jun 1995 12:54:41 -0400
From: RedNineCo@aol.com
Subject: want my title/bright idea

So i purchase a 1993 C-2 from an insurance company in florida,but through a
nearby VT dealer,that has an inside connection to purchase directly.I agree
to the terms and wire the requested amount and a week later I  take delivery
of the C-2.So far so good right ? WRONG !I never get a title.Dealer says it's
lost,I call the insurance company to confirm this and yes it is .So i figure
shit happens it all  will be taken care of.WRONG! I call florida RMV and they
state problem all solved ,title was sent to the dealer,get this one month
ago.I then tell the dealer send me the title already!!!
he says I need $1500 more for the car because I feel the car is worth more
than  I said from the beginning and is holding the title hostage for more
money. So I get an attorney and the chase is on .A few more months have past
since all of this.Even after pressure from the  RMV,Sec.of state,AG, he
refuses to give in to any authority.
So every day I walk past my C-2 and just shake my head.What I realy need is a
way around this mess,loophole,create a lein,court order,something .The bad
part is most of the solutions require filing paperwork with the slimebag
dealer's cooperation.WRONG!!
Need a bright idea
Thank you

Date: Sat, 10 Jun 1995 12:02:54 -0700 (MST)
From: Tim Jones <timjones@indirect.com>
Subject: 914 D-Jetronic Tutorial Online!

Hi Folks,

If you have need of information on Bosch's D-Jetronic fuel injection 
system, then you need to surf on over to the 914 Fan Web Page at

    http://www.indirect.com/www/timjones/porsche/

Kjell Nelin has produced a wonderful tutorial on the D-Jet system based 
on real-world experience.  This tutorial can take you from completely 
stripping down your system to completely replacing every hose and 
connection and then help you make sure that the gas is flowing where and 
when it should.

As always, the 914 Fan web page is dedicated to providing 914-centric 
information and technical articles to 914 owners and fans.  If you've got 
a great series of tips, please drop me a note and we'll get them online 
for others to share.  A hearty thanks to Dave Darling and Kjell Nelin for 
their help in providing great information.

- ---
Tim Jones						timjones@indirect.com
'74 914 1.8 (getting the rust beat out it)
'75 914 2.0 (just for the fun of it)
'86 Jetta GLI (Hey, it's got air and I live in the desert)
Keeper of the 914 Fan web page  http://www.indirect.com/www/timjones/porsche/

Date: Sat, 10 Jun 95 17:28 EDT
From: mikecool@wsp1.wspice.com (Mike Cooley)
Subject: I am told it is totaled.

Help is needed to instruct my directions in an accident. I just bought a
1974 914 2.0 less than 30 days ago. It had been reconstructed from an
accident over 3 years ago and looked super else I would have not bought it.
The only thing I could see wrong with it was the battery tray was partially
missing. In other words, it was almost a perfect rust free 1974 2.0 with
Fuel Injection still intact except for the battery tray. No corrosion below
anywhere. All I did was replace the muffler. Beautiful Niverna Green without
a blemish. Original.
Now to my problem. I was driving to work. A huge truck with about a 40 foot
trailer jacknifed across the center line and hit me all along the drivers
side of the 914 with the major damage concentrated behind my seat and the
built in roll bar. The door was also heavily damaged. The firewall is broken
loose 3/4 ways across the width of the car with the engine lid standing at
about 30 degrees high on the drivers side. Windshield and back window
shattered.Oh yeah, the dash is buckled out to the left of the steering
wheel. Dash was perfect, but now split in straight lines in 2 places and
mirrors went south at crash time. The hood and truck are rolled just at
their  drivers side edge about 1 inch.
The driver admitted fault and I had him write on his business card to that
effect, sign and date it. I received no ticket. I was hurt in the lower
right side of my back, left shoulder and right leg. No injuries are visible.
Back is the only pain I am feeling now, 16 days later. No broken bones but
the damn pain is sure real. The Insurance Co. for the truck driver is
claiming that the 914 was totaled when the previous owner had it, but in
fact, it was reconstructed. I was titled and insured at the time of
accident. My quest for help is: Since it is again called a total loss, do I
have to accept what they offer? Can I demand that they replace it with 914
of similiar value? Can I demand it be reconstructed at their cost to its
condition prior to the accident? Anyone have any idea of the cost? (I am in
Memphis. Tn.) Do lawyers only do the injury claims and what about my 914?
What will you sell your 1974 914 2.0 with fuel injection for? Answers from
Stan Hanks or Dr. 914 appreciated although I did not want to bother anyone
who may not have the time to ponder on this.
Thanks in advance for all interested. You never know when it could happen to
you.
A 914 is not a car, it's a way of life. I have owned 14 since 1970.
Financial problems is the only reason I don't still have them all!

variety of parts.  Here's what I got for $60.00:

Date: Sat, 10 Jun 1995 22:33:56 -0400
From: "H.Shrikumar" <shri@eternity.cs.umass.edu>
Subject: I got my 924.


Hi everybody,

I can now claim the rightful place on the list ... I went and bought
the 924 yesterday !

This is a crimson '82 924, with the obligatory cracked dash, obligatory
drivers seat cushion split :-) one obligatory minor dent when someone
backed into it years ago, and not much else amiss. The speedo was
broken, so I checked compression on the engine - all cylinders checked
about 150psi, which I gather from the archives on this list is pretty
good for 80K miles (estimated).

Not bad .. Esp. since this is my very first car ever, I am excited.
(have I said that enough times already :-)

My sincere thanx to Paul, Jay and Lee for their encouragement and
positive discussions related to my query.  Hey, I owe you guys a beer!
Also thanx to people responded with equal gusto to a thread some
year(s) ago - I recall it was "Sreelal's 924 .. which he thought was a
928" - thanx to the P-file list and archives I knew more about the car
than the guy I bought it from !

And now I continue my quest for that slightly elusive 924/VW/Audi
compatible parts list ... I have to prove myself one again that there
is indeed a P-car that is possible to maintain for $200-300 a year :-)
Oh, and to start saving for my upgrade to a 944 :-)

- -- Shrikumar

'82 924

Date: Sat, 10 Jun 1995 23:25:43 -0400 (EDT)
From: Mark Krieger <msk@unipress.com>
Subject: 914 transmission

Here's what happened to the Mark & Fred 914 last week and a few 
questions-- this is kinda long:

Fred was coming into the straight at Lime Rock, tried to shift gears, and 
found within a few minutes that he had only 3rd gear to choose from. He 
drove home -- 100+ miles -- in 3rd.

It was either (a) the transmission or (b) the linkage. 

We found out this morning that it was the linkage -- we're both very
happy: The car is running, and the real problem was a lot cheaper than a
new transmission. ($5 worth of nuts and bolts, *not* a new trans.) What
was the 'real' problem? The motor mounts, of course. 

When we started to jack the car up we both simultaneously noticed that
there was this loose crossbar attached to nothing. It was the motor
mounting bracket, with no bolt. (the other side was barely holding, I mean
barely.)Thanks to Keith for telling us what size nut and bolt to use, and
to Stan, Mark S. and Doug for advice. Yes we did bolt it back in
place...and when we tightened the other side that bolt (22 yrs old) broke
in half. We have two new nuts and bolts now, one on each side. With lock
washers too. The shifter bar sure works better without the motor mount
bracket sitting on it! And we drove the car, it works now... 

What's the moral of this story? Check *everything*. I thought we did, but 
we almost screwed up bigtime. If the other bolt falls out at 95 mph, what 
a mess.

And I have a few questions:

1. We have checked lot's of stuff out in this car, like the braking 
system, etc. We obviously missed the motor mounts. What else isn't 
obvious but should be checked. Our car has very very little rust and 
seems very sound, but what can anyone suggest. I drive the car every day 
and Fred tracks it, so we can usually notice when something is wrong, but 
what might we miss?

2. The rubber boot where the shifter bar attaches to the trannie had a 1/2
cup of trannie oil in it. This might be a 9 month buildup or be recent,
due to the shifter bar pulling so hard on the trannie where it is attached
and letting oil past the oil seal. Can this oil seal be renewed without
taking out the transmission? (We are changing the trannie oil on Monday)

3. The speedometer cable broke -- not in the cable itself -- but where it 
attaches to the trans. It looks like this attaches to the rear of the 
trans. and that the speedometer unit can be replaced by bolting a new 
unit into the transmission and into the cable on the other side. Is this 
correct? If so, what should this part cost? Does anyone have one of these 
they'd like to part with? (We own the porsche shop books for the 914, but 
I just cannot find the speedo unit in any of the books)

Thanks.

Mark -- Blue 914 2.0 1973 ---running again,yeah!
_______________________________________
Mark Krieger          
UniPress Software     http://www.unipress.com 
msk@unipress.com      (908)287-2100 x937

Date: Sun, 11 Jun 1995 00:50:52 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: Any of you guys know Panteras?

Robert Duckworth (gp310ad@prism.gatech.edu) wrote:

>I know it's not Porsche related beyond rear engine RWD but
>I'm looking at a '71 Pantera.
>Any of you guys owned one or know where to go for
>info on what to look for when buying?

Bob:

I know enough to be aware that Panteras are MID-engine, not rear...

Seriously, though, there are a LOT of things to watch out for.  Buying 
performance cars (especially old, multiple-owner performance cars) is 
sorta risky, since most have been thrashed by their owners.  DEFINITELY 
join your local Pantera Club and learn all about the cars before you go 
out and spend... what are they going for now?  $20-25K or so?... on 
one.

My wife (yes, the same one who now owns that Toyota MR2 Turbo that 
caused such a furor here) briefly owned an early-70's Pantera... If you 
have any specific questions, I guess I could ask her.  All I know about 
them is that they MUST have the "cooling updates"; early Panteras 
apparently overheat pretty badly.  The "Hall mods", whatever they are, 
are also allegedly desirable.

 -Andy

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 11 Jun 1995 01:40:00 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: Cut-off switch help

Jim Mali (jim@vlibs.com) wrote:

>I have a question for the racers...
>I just bought the Merit cut-off switch with altenator protection, but 
>the thing did not come with a schematic! And the shop that I bought
>it from doesn't have a clue. ( great) So if anyone knows or has 
>a schematic for the altenator hook-up, I would greatly appreicate it. 

Jim:

Disconnect your battery.

Find the wire from the ignition key that controls power to the CD or 
coil.  It's likely to be red, and it goes through the fuse box on its 
way to the CD/coil.

Remove it from the fuse block and connect it to one of the "z" 
terminals on the underside of the kill switch.  Add a wire from the 
other "z" terminal back to the fuse block.  You should now have the 
kill switch between the key and the fuse block, with the wire from the 
fuse block to the CD/coil undisturbed.

Find the cable that's between the positive terminal of your battery and 
the starter.  Remove it from the battery.  The kill switch has two 
large threaded terminals.  Connect the cable from the starter to the 
one on the same side as the wire that's going to the fuse block.  
Connect another wire from that terminal to the "w" terminal under the 
switch.

Buy a battery cable and connect it between the other threaded terminal 
on the kill switch and the positive terminal of the battery.

Finally, add a wire between the remaining "w" terminal and the 3-Ohm 
resistor that should have been included with your switch.  Connect the 
other end of the resistor to a good ground.

At this point, you should have:

    On one side:
    a wire from the key to the "z" terminal.
    A wire from the starter to the lareg threaded terminal.
    A wire from the large threaded terminal to the "w" terminal.

    On the other side:
    A wire from the CD/coil fuse to the "z" terminal.
    A wire from the positive terminal to the large threaded terminal.
    A wire from the "w" terminal, through the 3-Ohm resistor, to
    ground.

Voila.

 -Andy

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 11 Jun 1995 01:55:12 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: I am told it is totaled.

Mike Cooley (mikecool@wsp1.wspice.com) wrote:

>it was almost a perfect rust free 1974 2.0
> ....
>Since it is again called a total loss, do I have to accept what they 
>offer?

    No.

>Can I demand that they replace it with 914 of similiar value?

    No.

>Can I demand it be reconstructed at their cost to its condition prior 
>to the accident?

    No.

>Do lawyers only do the injury claims?

    No.  Your message was a little vague on the "insurance company
    claims the car was totalled last time" point... If they're claiming
    that your car was worth nothing at the time of YOUR accident
    because it was once totalled and later salvaged and repaired, you
    may have a case.  If, on the other hand, they're offering something
    close to what a 21-year-old 914's usually worth (I'd guess around
    $1.-2K), there's not a lot you can do.

    It's probably not worthwhile to repair the car, but if the cost
    estimates you get from your favorite body shop are less than about
    150% of what the insurance company's offering, you may be able to
    get a reputable Porsche expert (maybe even the body-shop guy) to
    convince the insurance company that yours was a
    particularly-valuable 914, and so is worth more than the cost of
    repair.  This has worked for me in the past; I've been hit a couple
    of times, and my body shop has always managed to convince the
    at-fault drivers' insurance companies that $5K-or-so repairs on my
    914 were justifiable.

    On the other hand, my car's visibly different from most
    run-of-the-mill 914s.  It sounds as though yours is basically
    stock, which is going to make the task difficult.

    Good luck...

    -Andy

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

This James Wood vs. "The Heath" question brings up something 
that put me off buying a Porsche for years. I love the track, 
and for that Porsche is the only vehicle to have. And no other 
car garners the reaction a Porsche does. Which can be negative. 
(Remember the joke about the difference between a porcupine and 
a Porsche.) I didn't buy out of arrogance or the need to 
impress. It's refreshing to find  Porsche has recognized their 
roots and dropped snobbery from the tone of their advertising 
and gotten back to the sheer joy of driving and hey, with a 
smile instead of smugness. And it's  great porschephiles has 
the sense of fraternity which makes the car even more special. 

So with this backdrop, back to this James Wood vs "The Heath" 
thing. I found James' questions (while causing me to wince at 
times) made out of a sincere desire to understand. Should "the 
Heath" apologize. Yes, if he's a gentleman, No if he's a 
porcupine needle. 

Sorry for going public and over one word.Thanks for the 
venting...


Doug Poad

Date: Sun, 11 Jun 1995 10:13:55 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Alabama Driver's Ed

Guten tag,

Saturday June 10th, the Alabama Region PCA held a 
driver's ed event at Talledega Gran Prix Raceway
(near *the* Talledega).  Several pfiles were in attendance
despite the brutal heat/humidity.  I think this event
was run in conjunction with Weight Watchers - that's
how hot it was.

Darren Evans-Young continued his streak of bad luck (his
thermostat stuck closed at the last school-dang) when he was
suddenly unable to find *any* gear in his 944S.  He was
able to get thing working after sitting out a while and
bravely headed right back out onto the track.  The only
thing more brutal than the heat yesterday was Jon and
Nancy Lowe's 944 Turbo.  Ludicrously fast car.  Bryson
Beaulieu (sp? - sorry) was there in his white 928 (that
serves double duty as a support truck - he can really pack
alot of stuff in the back of that thing)!  Keith Roberts
made the trek from Atlanta in his beautiful 930.  Pfiles
Jim McCullers and Jack Criswell were also there, but sans
cars.  I wouldn't have been able to stand watching everyone
else.

I sacrificed all-out speed yesterday to work on my heel/toe
downshifting (yeah, that's my story and I'm sticking to it)
and treated everyone to a nice spin right in front of the pits
as a result.  I wasn't very pleased with my driving.  Sadly enough,
the most encouraging thing for me yesterday is that my 2.7
liter engine (with the 5-bladed fan, no less!!) never got over
230F in the heat of battle.  

Too much fun!!

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911
