Date: 11 Jun 95 10:59:31 EDT
From: Rich Burns <71511.1672@compuserve.com>
Subject: 924S Incontinence

My '87 924S has been dribbling oil (Swepco 201) from the transaxle since I
bought it last November.  The transaxle was rebuilt (bearings and synchros)
early either late in '93 or early in '94.  I'm pretty sure less than 5000 miles
have been put on the rebuilt tranny.

Not wanting the car  to be piddling $50/gal Swepco on my floor, I had my P-mech
(who did the rebuild) take a look.  Input shaft seal was leaking.

Seal has been replaced, and after about 100 miles is again leaving spots on the
garage floor <grr>.  P-mech and I immediately hit on a possibility...  shaft
bent?  This is scary.

Even scarier...  could the main shaft of the transaxle be out of alignment
slightly?  Bearing problem??  Mechanic wouldn't be happy if I impugned his
rebuild as the cause of the leak...  am I off base here (I hope)?

Being a long-time lover of the marque, but a neophyte in ownership, is this a
common high mileage problem (114k... mostly hard miles, by my guess)?  What
would cause a bent driveshaft?

Could the Swepco be slippery enough to get out of the shaft seal?  I like it,
but would be glad to switch to conventional oil if the fix is that simple...

Any other ideas?

Rich Burns
71511.1672@compuserve.com
87 924S, 89 H-D Sportster (guess which one has the oil puddle under it :-})

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 11 Jun 1995 09:12:56 -0700 (PDT)
From: James Wood <jamesw@PEAK.ORG>
Subject: high-performance hype



I've finally finished finals week (yeah!) and I'm heading home shortly, 
so I have some time to post about an aspect of "hot-rodding" that 
irritates me:  the hype in advertising!!!!!!  Specifically, here are some 
of the worst offenders:

#1!!!  K&N Air filters.  They call their air filter element a 
"filtercharger."  According to K&N, the specially-designed element 
actually "straightens" (whatever that means) the air going into your 
intake, reducing intake turbulance to such an extent that it warrants the 
name "filtercharger."  Is there anyone with a semblance of a brain who 
believes that Madison Ave. hogwash???  I clearly understand that it may 
be a "low restriction" air filter, or at least "lower restriction" than a 
stock paper filter, but a "charging" effect and "straightening" of the 
intake air?  If that was true, I'd order a truckload of K&Ns and fasten 
them to the front of my 944 and be able to go 200 MPH due to the 
"charging" effect of the filter....hah hah hah!  How does the FTC let 
them get away with that claim?  What jury-rigged "test" have they based 
that claim on?  The only K&N I ever used was on a late-model Corvette - a 
flat-panel type element.  It was very thin and when I held it to the sun, 
I could see lots of little holes letting the sun shine through.  I would 
be concerned about its effectiveness if I lived in a dusty area.

#2!! "High performance" spark plug wires.  If your factory wires are in 
good condition and the motor is running great, how are larger diameter 
(or pretty colored) wires going to get you a lower 0-60 time as some 
vendors advertise?  If there's enough juice for you to pull to redline 
smoothly, what difference does it make?

#3!!  Split-fire plugs.  I've seen claims of "easiest 5HP gain there 
is."  I've had salesman try to vigorously push these on me (at some 
ridiculous price I can't remember) when I try to buy exhaust or intake 
parts that actually contribute to making HP.  I base my skepticism on the 
same reasoning that I question new plug wires.

I'm certainly no expert, but I still remember from "How to Hotrod VW 
Engines" (my 1st hot-rodding exp. and subsequent rebuilds) that 3 ways to 
increase HP are (1) getting more air/fuel mixture into engine, (2) 
getting the most out of what gets in (such as increased compression), and 
(3) reducing friction and pumping losses.

Obviously, most mods that produce significantly increased HP fit in the "#1" 
rule."  Plugs and wires would have to fit in the "#2 rule."  I don't know 
much about electricity or spark plugs, but my suspicions are that if 
getting proper voltage and spark was a problem, then ignition coils would 
still be as big-a-round as a coffee can - rather than the tiny things 
that sit inside the distributor cap on some models.  I just can't see the 
inadequacy to the stock parts or how the highly-touted replacements will gain a 
stock motor 5HP when I've run the piss out of all sorts of modified (and 
stock) cars all with stock ignition components and no problems.  Am I off 
base here?  Since I've never tried "split fire" plugs, I can not 
definitively say they are worthless, but I'd like to hear from someone 
who put them in and noticed increased performance.

James "skeptical" Wood


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 11 Jun 1995 09:22:54 -0700 (PDT)
From: James Wood <jamesw@PEAK.ORG>
Subject: 944 mtr mts and timing belt



I haven't had the time to crawl under my 944 since I've suspected the 
motor mounts were bad.  One of my curiosities when I first got the car 
was that the engine wasn't as smooth as I had anticipated for a Porsche.  
I was further surprised when I saw that the 944 has balance shafts, and 
it was still so rough!!!  Then I read the FAQ and now I am almost sure of 
what I need.  There was a place mentioned selling the mounts for $110 
each.  As mentioned, I haven't looked (yet) to how many there are, how to 
tell if they are all bad, etc.  How many are there?  How can I tell if 
they are bad?  I'm assuming that it is possible for the fluid to leak out 
and my untrained eye won't be able to tell.

I'm also paranoid about the timing/balance shaft belts.  I won't trust 
the car (and I won't even rev it high) until I get these replaced.  
However, I haven't been able to completely comprehend the procedure.  I 
bought a Haynes book on the 944, and it seems like they don't even want 
to get into it and recommend a dealer, then there's an engine rebuild 
section that (obviously) has to deal with it.  Seems contradictory.  
Somewhere I read that tension is a delicately-performed procedure, 
requiring special tools and expertise.  I believe it stated that if you 
"guess" at the tension then take it (slowly) to a dealer immediately, 
they can set the tension on a belt that you install.

Then I read somewhere else that the 1988 model (that's what I have) has 
an "automatic" tensioner??  Does this mean I can slap it on myself and 
not worry?  This car has about 38K miles on it now - I assume the belts 
have never been changed.  If these belts are good (typically) for 60K 
miles, then should I even worry about it now?  Any advice in this regard 
will be greatly appreciated.

James "overwhelmed" Wood

Date: Sun, 11 Jun 1995 13:15:39 -0400

2 - 26%

6 - 95%

cylinders are in pretty rough shape.

At any rate, while he's doing all the valve magic, he's going to check the
tolerances of each piston and cylinder.  When everything is being put back
together, he'll install new Dilivar studs.  My question concerns Raceware
fasteners.  Has anyone had any experience with these and, if so, has it been
a pleasurable experience?  I do find their ads tempting.

Date: Sun, 11 Jun 1995 12:13:01 -0700

"Internet Guy".  Cost Plus 20% or so.  I just bought a 911 Targa roll bar
seal List at $360 + tax. Got it for a little less than $300.  $60.00 is
$60.00...I thought this was OK, as my local dealer wanted full list.  .

She's at 415.856.0611.  She is very helpful and a real delightful & funny
lady.  She may even be on the net by now as they were installing a "system"
of some sort last week.

There are other sources like Tweeks, etc.  See the last June 1 FAQ update
for a list.  Good luck.

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 11 Jun 1995 14:16:07 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Improving power on 3.2 liter Carrera engine

> I have a 3.2 liter Carrera that I plan to put into my 914.  This is a 
> stock US market 3.2 liter engine that has been converted to a carburetor 
> version.  
> I would really appreciate it if anyone know of a relatively inexpensive 
> way to improve the output of this engine.  Budget $3000.00.  Thanks  

Well, this is another one of those "it depends" cases...

If you're doing this in any state with CA style emissions laws, you're
already hosed -- you won't be able to register it as-is because you need
to comply with emission regs for the NEWER of the engine or the body year 
of manufacture, which means you'd need the DME back, *AND* a catalytic 
converter.

Let's assume that for the sake of argument that this is NOT the case, or
that you're building this as a not for street vehicle. In that case,
the single biggest improvement you can make is in the exhaust system.

There are several really good header systems for 914-6 conversions. 
You need to avoid the temptation to get really big diameter pipes,
though -- smaller pipes == higher velocity == better scavenge effect
in the header. And trust me, you're not going to be doing *ANYTHING* 
that can challenge the throughput of the smaller pipes. Big problem with
most of these is that they're designed as straight-pipe systems. You
can fit SuperTrapps to them, but again, remember to think small -- each
"half" of the engine is only a 1.6 liter, so you should use the smaller
SuperTrapp setup (one per side). The previous owner of my 914 racer made
that mistake, and as a result I had a very very hard time getting the 
car to run right -- I had an exhaust basicly designed for a 4.0 engine...

Other than that, there's *NOTHING* cheap that you can do. The next
stop is probably a programmable crankfire ignition system, like the
Electromotive. That adds some flexibility but not much power. For more
power, you'd into opening then engine up which you can't do on your
budget.

Good luck.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 11 Jun 1995 13:28:59 -0600 (MDT)
From: mark r gillis <mgillis@unm.edu>
Subject: mikecool's crash

Sorry to hear about your crash. I had a VW bus that saved my life last 
summer when a pickup and large trailer went into the back of it. The 
insurance company was very willing to give me the current market value of 
the bus. State Farm was very good. If your insurance starts messing with 
you get a lawyer. A good one doesn't necessarly advertise but will be 
well known.
Now about your back. If it is hurting- get off it and lay down. See a doc 
now. Please do not settle with the insurance company till you have 
established how disabling your back is going to be. The insurance 
companies are very good at pressuring you to settle early. Wait at least 
one year. You have a long road ahead of you if the pain persists, so try 
to do as much healing on you own early on.
Good Luck!
M Gillis, Albuq.

Big *THANK YOU* to Mr. Woods for pointing out some of the hype out there.
There is a *LOT* of bad stuff out there. "There are no silver bullets; 
there is no magic dust."

I'm constantly amazed at how many people think that they can just walk
into the store and *BUY* better performance, like somehow the factory
is holding out on them. Car people must even be stupider than golfers
at this. I can't think of any other group that the marketing types must
think are so gullible -- just spend this $15 and get an extra 43 MPG!
Buy this glove, correct 20 years of bad swing habits! Sheesh. Makes
be almost ashamed to be a member of both groups...

Stan

Date: Sun, 11 Jun 1995 17:25:46 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: 914 master cylinder

> 
> In the process of making one good 1970 914 out of two, I
> relocated the master cylinder and a couple of brake lines
> from one car to the other. After installing the cylinder, I 
> filled the reservoir with new fluid. However, after pumping 
> the brake pedal many times, fluid flows out the overflow
> tube and not into the system. I can't understand what the
> problem would be other than blockage somewhere. Any advice
> would be greatly appreciated.
> 
> Wayne
> 

It's *real* easy to get the lines into the master cylinder wrong.

You probably knocked one of the little washers into the wrong spot
while trying to wedge the almost-impossible-to-cram-back-in rubber
fittings.

Gary

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 11 Jun 1995 17:38:33 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: I am told it is totaled.

There is an alert due here.  AAA has been known to call people
that are advertising Porsches for sale, (without saying who
they are) and arm-twist them into a low-ball price.

They then tell the insured that they found the same car for
whatever low-ball price they squeezed out of you, and that
is all the money there are going to give for the car.

When I was selling my '74-914-2.0, about half the calls I got
were from insurance companies around the state.

Gary.
PS.  If you think you have a *special* car, GET IT APPRAISED!


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 11 Jun 1995 20:39:34 -0400
From: "Daniel G. Pouzzner" <douzzer@prez.mit.edu>
Subject: Re: Help! my doors won't lock! (or UNlock!)

It sounds like what happened to my car a couple years ago is happening
to yours. Apparently, the lock/key system is sufficiently worn by
actuation over the years that they eventually don't work right
together. If the key will not physically turn in some or all of the
cylinders then I would guess this is what has happened. You will
probably need to have the car rekeyed if this is the case, but see if
you can find a really honest locksmith to have a look at it.

 -douzzer

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 11 Jun 1995 22:19:51 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: high-performance hype

On Sun, 11 Jun 1995, James Wood wrote:

> I've finally finished finals week (yeah!) and I'm heading home shortly, 
> so I have some time to post about an aspect of "hot-rodding" that 
> irritates me:  the hype in advertising!!!!!!  Specifically, here are some 
> of the worst offenders:
Well, this is a capitalist country... so it is to be expect that someone 
unloading their goods onto you will try to make it sound as good as 
possible, after all, you wouldn't buy an air filter that claimed to 
actually generate turbulence, thereby restricting air-flow et al, would 
you?

> #2!! "High performance" spark plug wires.  If your factory wires are in 
> good condition and the motor is running great, how are larger diameter 
> (or pretty colored) wires going to get you a lower 0-60 time as some 
> vendors advertise?  If there's enough juice for you to pull to redline 
> smoothly, what difference does it make?
Okay, this I believe is part real, part crap. Part real: the lower the 
resistance, the better, the bettwer the RF shielding, the better... the 
pretty colors are for show engines. Part crap: even zero resistance 
wouldn't give you more power than a gnat slamming into your rear, why? 
Because in order to really get more juice through, you have to put it 
through... ie. better coil or HEI.

> #3!!  Split-fire plugs.  I've seen claims of "easiest 5HP gain there 
> is."  I've had salesman try to vigorously push these on me (at some 
> ridiculous price I can't remember) when I try to buy exhaust or intake 
> parts that actually contribute to making HP.  I base my skepticism on the 
> same reasoning that I question new plug wires.
I just put these in an '85 Buick today... They were.. expensive, yes. BUT 
they did make the car run smoother, and they did remove that nasty top 
speed of 55 MPH (for how I shall never know)... I think that they are 
mostly hype, and considering that not all engines are the same, how can 
everyone get 5 more HP? (not EXACTLY what the box reads, but for the 
flaming purposes, it'll work) They are basically spark plugs with a 
little more spark... The spark isn't any hotter, So I'm not sure what the 
real advantage is, other than they are new...
(oh, BTW, the engine did run smoother and have a faster 0-60 time from 
what I could tell, but then, I don't have the time, equipment, or desire 
to test this car)
The thing about Split Fires is that just having them will make the 
average uninformed person go "ooh!"
 -Derek

Hi,

>From porschephiles-request@tta.com Sat Jun 10 16:53:05 1995
>From: <katz_p_m@bt-web.bt.co.uk> katz_p_m 
>Subject: Anyone going to LE MANS this year?
>Date: Fri, 9 Jun 1995 11:07:43 +0100

>	Apologies if this has already been discussed, but I no longer subscribe 
>to Porschephiles after a complaint from a senior manager about the quantity of 
>mail! Boy do I miss it :-( and I hope to rejoin in the not too distant future.

And also to the other person who was worrying about overloading his
secy with eMail from the list . ...

You can request that your subscription to P-files be set up as a digest
 - so you get *one* mail a day with all that transpired that day. That
way your mailbox does not beep you 50 times a day, and yet you remain
in the loop without needing to unsubscribe.

YMMV FWIW .. just in case you overlooked. (This may or may not solve
Philip Katz's problem if bytes volume is the issue.)

Date: Sun, 11 Jun 1995 22:55:10 EDT
From: GBYU00A@prodigy.com (MR PAUL W MURPHY)
Subject: hvr/pca driver's ed

i just want to share my experiences in my first foray into
high-speed motor events. the hudson valley region sponsored 
a driver's education event on june 5th at lime rock race
track in ct. i'll admit, i had some apprehension; driving at 
such a distinguished site, in the midst of proficient
drivers with faster cars-i drove an '87 944. i humbly
proceeded onto the track, feeling like a baseball fan might 
feel stepping onto the diamond at Yankee stadium. like the
other novices, i had an instructor in my passenger seat
guiding me. having an expert driver giving me constant
coaching was invaluable to me. fortunately, he wasn't afraid 
to let fly an almost constant blitz of admonitions and
comments. he managed to get through my "wall of adrenalin"
and my helmet. the primary goal, he urged, was to follow the 
correct "line" around the course. this enabled me to drive
through the turns at a maximum pace and use the whole track. 
gradually, by following his advice, my laps became smoother 
and faster. i knew i was doing something right as my
passenger became uncharacteristically quiet. there are fews 
delights greater than passing a car with 60% more hp than
you have. though i often pushed it to the redline, my
worries about pushing my "daily transportation" too far
 subsided, as my respect for porsches grew. afterwards, i
thought about all those people who own these great cars but 
don't come close to realizing their performance abilities; i 
can only pity them. to those of you who haven't tried a
track event-go for it! i'd like to thank my instuctor, Fred 
Pack, and those who organized; great job!

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 00:58:13 -0400
From: "Daniel G. Pouzzner" <douzzer@prez.mit.edu>
Subject: Re: high-performance hype / golf

Having been an enthusiast in a really wide variety of scenes, I would
definitely vote for "high end" audio being the most goofball hairbrain
industry anywhere. They are sillier than those guys who went from town
to town in the old west with their magic potions.

Meantime, those splitfire things make some sense. They spark along two
simultaneous paths, which should theoretically result in more complete
ignition unless the car was already igniting completely (due to proper
injector adjustment and in-cylinder vapor tumble/spin). It is unlikely
any of us have near-perfect fluid dynamics in our cylinders, so we can
probably all benefit, a _little_, from these things.

 -douzzer

Date: Sun, 11 Jun 1995 22:19:17 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Timothy A. Budd" <budd@rohan.sdsu.edu>
Subject: Noisy Air Conditioning in 911SC

My buddy has a 1980 911SC.  He has been complaining about a noisy air 
conditioning fan.  I thought he was being a bit too sensitive until I 
heard it this weekend.  The noise sounds a lot like a saxaphone being 
blown off key.  To get rid of it he either waits or turns the fan off, 
then turns it on a little while later.  It became pretty anoying.  His 
mechanic said that many Porsches do this and to get at the problem it 
would take about 3 or 4 hours labor i.e. not worth it.  He said, "Thats 
whey they invented radios"  Does this sound right??  Are there any quick 
fixes?

We also experienced another problem this weekend. After a weekend up in 
the mountains, we headed down to the valley, we were crusing on a wide 
open, straight freeway at about 90.  At one point, a 5.0 mustang wanted 
to play a bit, my friend took it up to 110, but then stoped playing.  A 
short time later, the engine died at 85mphs.  My friend popped the clutch 
and got it started again.  We then cruised home between 75-80 MPH.  A 
friend said that we may have experienced vapor lock?  ANy ideas?  It was 
a hot day, the temp gague was still in the white and there was plenty of 
oil.  

Thanks,

Tim

James here again....neverending 944 questions.

Of course, I didn't get an owner's manual for the car and since
I'm traveling away for the summer leaving any day now, I'll have to
order one at my destination, so I'm without.

What the hell is that extra keyhole in the left rear fender of the car?
I strongly suspect it's an alarm, but I didn't see any results when playing
with it - which I am afraid to do intensively for fear of setting off a 
possible alarm.

On the subject of alarms:  I'd like to put one on this car.  Anybody else 
have an alarm on their 944?  It seems kind of cheesy to put on another 
alarm (over the factory) and end up with a bunch of redundant components, 
but many factory anti-theft measures are woefully inadequate.  I remember 
when the 1986 Corvette came out with "pass-key" antitheft measures, the 
theif would just bring along the "black box" computer from a 1985 
Corvette - break in and plug it into the wiring harness under the dash - 
and drive away in the car....ha ha ha!!!!

As always - your contributions to this 944 thread will grant you eternal 
salvation (or at least contribute thereof)!

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 00:36:30 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: high-performance hype / golf

> Having been an enthusiast in a really wide variety of scenes, I would
> definitely vote for "high end" audio being the most goofball hairbrain
> industry anywhere. They are sillier than those guys who went from town
> to town in the old west with their magic potions.

Oh yeah -- I'd completely forgotten about that particular brand of crazy.
Shit like "oxygen free copper wiring" to prevent "audio distortion due
to pathyway impurities"... I used to be a closet audiophile until my
officemate in grad school (who had about a $20k stereo) decided to get
a CD player. I had a First Generation unit from Phillips, where the whole
transport slid out of the unit for changing the CD, and had just
replaced it with a newer Phillips, their first with just the sliding
CD tray, dual DACs, and 4x oversampling (this was like in '84 or so).
He wanted to buy this super-high end product that started life as my
Phillips unit but had all of the power supply, analog, and connector parts
replaced by "high end" "pure" components to the tune of about $1500.
So naturally, we had to arrange a blind A-B testing... *EVERYONE* in the
store picked mine as the high-end unit and on asking where I got it, rushed
right down to the discount shop where I'd paid $269 and cleaned them out.
Dave stubbornly insisted that the $1800 unit *HAD* to be better even if
he'd picked mine 4 out of 5 times. I sort of swore off the whole thing
after I saw him write that check...

> Meantime, those splitfire things make some sense. They spark along two
> simultaneous paths, which should theoretically result in more complete
> ignition unless the car was already igniting completely (due to proper
> injector adjustment and in-cylinder vapor tumble/spin). It is unlikely
> any of us have near-perfect fluid dynamics in our cylinders, so we can
> probably all benefit, a _little_, from these things.

Wrong. You get *ONE* spark path. At best, you get two chances for the
spark to form in case there's anything keeping the "primary" path
from forming. All of the tests I've seen indicate that there's not a
net difference that couldn't be matched by just replacing the plugs
with *NEW* conventional plugs of the correct heat range.

The SplitFire isn't even as good as the Bosch W225T7 plugs from the Dark 
Ages -- they at least had multiple different electrodes rather than this 
forked tounge thing... (Hmmmm.  Interesting to note how good a metaphor
that made...)

Not to mention real problems had by people I know that thought it might
at least be worth trying. Everything from "car ran like shit" to "blew
plug out of head, major damage".

Snake oil. More friggin snake oil...

Stan

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 95 10:16:00 PDT
From: "Thiger Jonas, Netsupport" <jonas.thiger@netsupport.telia.se>
Subject: High-performance hype

According to what I learned in school (some 10 years ago, excuse me for bad 
memory), when the voltage is high enough on one electrode to overcome the 
resistance (i.e. number of electrons gets high enough) they'll take the 
shortest way over to the opposite end (the one with least resistance), until 
both ends are counterbalanced. Conclusion:

The spark will _not_ be split between the two ends of the electrode, but 
use only one of them. Exeption is if both ways are equal in resistance 
which would be virtually impossible.  So, where am I getting it all wrong, or 
does this prove they're bulls** t?
As I see it, best would be to have the thinnest electrodes possible, but 
still be able to pump up the voltage high before releasing a spark. 

More spark plugs:
I used to have really expensive Bosch WR7DS (silver) in my 944, but switched 
to regular NGK BPR6ES (copper). Result: performance exactly the 
same... Made lots of acc. tests before and after, no difference.

Jonas Thiger
Lulea, Sweden
87'944

------------------------------

Date:          Mon, 12 Jun 1995 10:37:10 +0000
From: "Peter Remeijer" <peter@qv3pluto.LeidenUniv.nl>
Subject:       Re: Storing 944 Detachable Sunroof

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 05:22:31 -0400
From: "H.Shrikumar" <shri@eternity.cs.umass.edu>
Subject: Diddling Lambda on the CIS (924)


Hi,

>From the Owner's Manual of my '82 924, I learnt about the O2 sensor
wire, and that got my attention up. To an avid electroniker, this spelt
opportunity of combining an old hobby with a new preoccupation.

Found a thread on fuel injections in the P-file archive -
>From stan Mon Jun 22 08:12:40 1992 >Subject: EFI follow-up

One thought, instead of just putting a resistor in the signal wire of
the O2 sensor (which I can understand wont work too well), I am
thinking I can insert a variable transconductance op-amp, (whose gain
is close to 1, but is adjusted by something.)

What I am thinking of doing is to sense a COMBINATION of low gear (esp
gear #2) AND high accelaration, (typically the face-off scenario) - and
under that situation alone diddle the lambda to run a richer 1:12.4
gas/air ratio than the usual lambda = 1.0 (1:14.5).

My knowledge of automobile fuel injection is just 2 days old, so I may
be a bit naive, but the above seems reasonable to me. Should give just
a bit more oomph on the 0-60, without hurting emissions.

BTW, what lambda is 1:12.4 ? (got to get me the Bosch book).

Of course, the next step is to couple a GPS reciever to a uP diddling
the CIS - switch modes from city-mode to highway-mode to face-off-mode,
depending on lat/longitude and tacho/speedo :-) :-)

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 05:38:56 -0400 (EDT)
From: Scot Alan Douglas <scootman@engin.umich.edu>
Subject: Re: high-performance hype

James,
I can only try to answer one of your questions;  the K&N filter.
K&N claims that their filters straighten the air-now if this is true, 
there should be an increase in intake air flow.  Most intake systems 
aren't the optimum shape a create turbulence at the inlet that the air 
has to fight to get into the engine.  K&N filters don't charge, just aid 
flow.  And if you'll remember from fluid mechanics, a bell shaped inlet 
is the choice for optimum flow i.e. velocity stacks on Webber carbs.  
This all goes back to your explanation of more intake flow/fuel=more 
horsepower.  As for me, I don't know if they work but they sure have 
built themselves quite a reputation (good).
Scot

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 06:10:42 -0500
From: Mark A Skala <skala@ecn.purdue.edu>
Subject: re: Splitfires

douzzer has said:
>From porschephiles-request@tta.com Mon Jun 12 00:02:10 1995

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 00:58:13 -0400
>From: "Daniel G. Pouzzner" <douzzer@prez.mit.edu>
Message-Id: <199506120458.AAA23449@prez.mit.edu>

Subject: Re: high-performance hype / golf
Status: R

Having been an enthusiast in a really wide variety of scenes, I would
definitely vote for "high end" audio being the most goofball hairbrain
industry anywhere. They are sillier than those guys who went from town
to town in the old west with their magic potions.

Meantime, those splitfire things make some sense. They spark along two
simultaneous paths, which should theoretically result in more complete
ignition unless the car was already igniting completely (due to proper
injector adjustment and in-cylinder vapor tumble/spin). It is unlikely
any of us have near-perfect fluid dynamics in our cylinders, so we can
probably all benefit, a _little_, from these things.

 -douzzer

end included message **

We've been through this before, there is no way you will actually
get 2 sparks from this or any plug.  Otherwise why don't you
just build a plug with 47 leads coming off it and ignite the leanest
mixture you can think of?  A spark is current getting through the
air between 2 points with a high voltage difference.  The spark will
occur betwween the 2 points with have the lowest resistance at the
instant of time when it occurs.  The spark ionizes the air in its
path, which reduces that air's resistance, so that the whole spark
will choose that same path.  So you only have ONE spark.  And the
strength is not any different for a normal plug or tor the splitfire plug.
What it could do, having a probably larger area for the electrode,
is that when an area becomes fouled, spark will happen from another
area, thus having a longer life (if all other thiings are equal,
which may or may not be).

Mark Skala            '73 914
mvmas@mvujc.att.com   '88 924S

------------------------------

Date: 12 Jun 95 07:54:00 EST
From: "LOGISX::GIBBS" <GIBBS%LOGISX.decnet@vaxa.acdnj.itt.com>
Subject: RE:  How does my 944 cooling system work?

Armagn-

You do not have a problem  - the cooling system is working as designed.

Under normal driving conditions, the coolant temperature will rise until
the fan switch activates, which turns on the electric cooling fan.  This
cools the radiator, and thereby the coolant, until the fan switch opens
(at a considerably lower temperature) and shuts off the fan.  Then the 
temperature will begin to climb again.  In traffic on a warm day, it is
perfectly normal for the system to cycle between two temperatures as the
fan comes on and goes off - this means everything is working right.

When you turn on the AC, a second, high speed cooling fan comes on.  This
fan is somewhat overpowered, and will have no problem keeping the engine 
temperature at the low side of the gauge, even in traffic.  It also runs
for a short while after the AC is turned off.  So with the AC on, you will
not see the cycling that you do without it, unless it is an extremely
hot day.

Ed Gibbs
gibbs@avionics.itt.com
'84 944, Guards Red, All Mine!

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 09:23:13 -0400
From: JWilli911@aol.com
Subject: Re: Help! my doors won't lock! (or UNlock!)

Jim Bauman wrote:

>Quite suddenly the air-actuated door locks on
my '86 Carrera won't work. I can't lock or
>unlock the door with the key. The red button
on the console lights but that's it.

Jim,

Your problems with the central door locking feature will be extremely hard to
troubleshoot without an electrical schematic diagram. In addition to the
control switch (with the button on the console), there is a logic module
which resides under the cowling, accessible from the front trunk, an
electrical switch in each door, and an electrical solenoid in each door which
does the locking.   The logic module contains bunch of diodes and other
electronic components, as well as a a couple of relays which control the door
solenoids.

In lieu of having the factory manual wiring diagram, there is a publication
by Mitchell which you may be able to find at some larger libraries which has
Porsche wiring diagrams that include those for the door locks.

Hope this helps.

Jim Williams (JWilli 911@aol.com)


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 09:27:53 -0400
From: JWilli911@aol.com
Subject: Re: Head Studs

Tim wrote:
>At any rate, while he's doing all the valve magic, he's going to check the
>tolerances of each piston and cylinder.  When everything is being put back
>together, he'll install new Dilivar studs.  My question concerns Raceware
>fasteners.  Has anyone had any experience with these and, if so, has it been
>a pleasurable experience?  I do find their ads tempting.

Tim,

I don't have direct experience with the Raceware stuff, but from their ads,
know they have both rod bolts and head studs available for the 911 engine.
 If I'm not mistaken, Bruce Anderson has had some experience with them and
rather than tell you what he said to me about them which I interpreted as
positive, perhaps you should email him if he hasn't already responded to your
question.

I know that the fasteners are quite expensive, but then, so will your
rebuild, and if they are as bullet proof as the ads indicate, might be good
insurance.  The main problem with the dilavar studs is long term
susceptibility to corrosion-related stress cracks, which is probably the root
of your leakdown figures.  The latest dilavar studs were epoxy coated to help
mitigate the corrosion problems.  I don't know how the Raceware fasteners
will fare in this area.

JWilli 911@aol.com (Jim Williams)

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 09:35:15 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: 944 mtr mts and timing belt

I had a motor mount go on my '83 944, and it was so rough it stalled! This
was before they started using a heat shield on the exhaust side. I swear
that until recently it seems like there was no one at Porsche that thought
about heat flow. You can verify the mount failure by measuring the location
of the engine in the car. As the mount dies, it allows the engine to
settle.

No advice for the belts. I figured paying the dealer was cheap insurance.
the penalty for a small "mistake" is a trashed engine. Your mileage may
vary.


doug dykaar

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 09:51:35 -0500
From: Eric Yuzon <YUZONE@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>
Subject:  Re: high-performance hype / golf -Reply

Nothing about Porsches, but I had to put my 2 cents about the CD
players.

The reason that the older Magnavox CD players sounds so good is that
the chip sets in them are the classic SAA7220 Digital Filter and the
TDA1541Dual 16 bit DAC from Phillips which are considered as one of
the best of the multi-bit chips.  It was even used in other players such as
the older Rotel 855.

Eric Yuzon

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 09:50:56 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: high-performance hype / golf / audio: Spit Happens

>Having been an enthusiast in a really wide variety of scenes, I would
>definitely vote for "high end" audio being the most goofball hairbrain
>industry anywhere. They are sillier than those guys who went from town
>to town in the old west with their magic potions.
>
>Meantime, those splitfire things make some sense. They spark along two
>simultaneous paths, which should theoretically result in more complete
>ignition unless the car was already igniting completely (due to proper
>injector adjustment and in-cylinder vapor tumble/spin). It is unlikely
>any of us have near-perfect fluid dynamics in our cylinders, so we can
>probably all benefit, a _little_, from these things.
>
>-douzzer


WRONG!

 The spark will not work any harder than it has to. That means that as the
voltage across the electrodes increases, it will arc as soon as it can,
across the lowest resistance path. In a car ignition then starts
immediately. in a TV commercial, the ionized air will present a lower
resistance path, but as the ionized air moves around and is heated, the
path will distort and "dance" resulting in many paths becoming the lowest
energy path over extended periods of time. The flame front in a car spreads
away from the electrode at the speed of sound in the air/fuel mixture, and
will be long gone before the second electrode gets around to doing anything
useful. The likelyhood of both electrodes arcing simultaneously would
require truly identical conditions, including gap, electrode surface
condition, and path resistance. How likely is that?

Ever see a jacobsen's ladder? Thats the old frankenstein movie special
effect where two wires are arranged vertically and have a larger separation
at the top than at the bottom. As the voltage is cranked up, an arc starts
at the bottom, and runs up the "ladder". Have we learned why?

Flame off.

doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

I have to apply this comment to the world of Porsche audio.  While Bart
has a good point in the fact of "drive for the sake of driving," I still
like my tunes (ala "Iron Eagles" movie).  I've gone through all of that
promotional crap and even had a competition system installed in an older
Jetta.  Phooey - once you're rolling at '70 with the revs hitting 5K in
third, all that performance audio sounds like so much static.  The judges
should be forced to check the sound under REAL conditions. 

I've since smartened up.  Both of my 914's have $98 pull out Craig units 
(built in 25 wats RMS per side) and a pair of Radio Shack Minimus 7's 
behind the seats.  Total package deal: $210 per car and I can hear it 
fine even with the top off at the posted speed limit of 55mph (yea, 
right).

When a crook looks in a spots a Craig in the dash, I'm surprised that they 
don't leave me a sympathy note (or someone else's Alpine!).

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 10:44:17 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: How does 944 cooling sys. work? 

Hi Armagan,

My experience with the later model cars is that, all things being OK,
the coolant temp will pretty much stay put on the lower white gauge mark.
It may come off a little bit if you are running the AC or stuck in
city traffic on a hot day.

Porsche updated the radiator fan switch, to memory, in Feb '88.  That
would make the fans come on at a slightly lower temp.  It will not
change behaviour in highway driving, though.

The later cars have a three-contact fan switch, controlling the two
fans.  If you run the AC, the high-speed fan is also automatically
switched on (I believe).

Most common problem with cars that won't stay cool in the coolant is
insufficient bleeding of air from the coolant.  Particularly with the
sixteen-valve heads, it sometimes take a little driving to move air
through the head to the point to which it can be bled.

Kevin Gross

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 10:56:05 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 944 mtr mts and timing belt

Hi James,

The only way to really check the motor mount is with a C-shaped gauge,
which you can make from stiff wire or flat stock.  Porsche described
this "locally made" tool in a tech bulletin some years ago, and I would
be happy to send you instructions.

You cannot accurately eyeball it, and because of the part's location
and surroundings, you cannot hold a ruler up to the mount.

Regarding the belt tension, the MY87 and forward cars have an automatic
tensioner on the cam belt.  However, a couple of caveats.  First is that
the tensioner can go soft or otherwise fail.  Second is that despite the
tensioner, Porsche had belt slap problems with the 944S2 and recommended
use nonetheless of the gauge.  Third, you still need to measure the
balance shaft belt tension.  (They also call out gauge values for the
PS and alternator belts).  Finally, if you are reinstalling an old cam 
belt, say because you just did the water pump, you need to use the
gauge to "index" the tensioner so to get the lower belt tension (2.7?)
called out for broken-in belts.

And, for all of you 911 owners chuckling at this 944 foible, get this:
Last December Porsche issued a tech bulletin prescribing the need to
measure the 911's fan belt tension with a new tool!

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 95 10:58 EDT
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: 944 Rear view mirror fell off.

>From: Ujjal Bansel <ujj@server.chem.ufl.edu>
    Help, my mirror fell off!!! It looks like the adhesive (or something) is 
    on the window... How can I fix this? What's the best way to remove the 
    adhesive and reattach my mirror? 

When this happened to my 944, I just got one of those Locktite rear-view mirror
adhesive kits.  First, take a marker or grease pencil and, on the outside of
the windshield, mark where the adhesive is.  This is so you'll know where the
mirror should be attached.  Then, take a razor blade and scrape the old adhesive
away.  Then, remove the little metal insert from the rear-view mirror.  Scrape
all the old adhesive off of that, too.  Then just follow the directions given
in the kit.  I think I just glued the metal insert to the windshield, waited
twenty minutes, then reattached my mirror.  I did this about three months ago,
and haven't had any problems.

Good luck!
- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)

>#1 - 901:

Original designation for the 911. Had to be changed from 901 to 911
because Peugot had trademarks in France on all three didgit numbers
with a zero in the middle.

>#2 - 907:

A purpose built race car. Used primarily in European hillclimb events.

>#3 - 916:

A special version of the 914-6. The car went to production for 15 or
so copies. It had unique bodywork but was built on top of the standard
914 chassis.

>#4 - 930:

The 911 Turbo....

>#5 - 934:

The racing version of the 911 Turbo

>#6 - 936:

Another purpose built racer that won Le Mans and the Sports Car World
Championship.

#7 - 956:

Predecessor to the 962. Very fast and successfull.

>#8 - 961:

Race version of the 959. Only one was made and that one burned to the
ground after a crash (Hockenheim??).

>#9 - 964:

1989 (C4 only) to 1994 911.


Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 14:05:34 +0500
From: pbf@tdc.com (Paul Foster)
Subject: Re: What's that for

Doug writes: "...funny oil drain plug..."

It's a magnet. It's for grabbing hold of ferrous miscellania that would
otherwise want to circulate throughout your engine along with the oil.
:-)

Paul Foster
'84 944
pbf@tdc.com

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 12:45:24 +0600
From: rondl@uscbu.ih.att.com (Ronald Jay De Lange)
Subject: 901 Trans and Stoddard

Hi All,

Thanks to those of you who responded to my 901 xmission questions.
I found a 901 tranny at the Stoddard swapmeet for $100 which I 
could shift into all gears by hand.  I'll use this as a temporary
trans and rebuild my original this winter.  I hope $100 isnt too
bad a price, it seemed fair at the time....

Got lots of goodies this year, weather played a important factor for me!

1.  Got 3 boxes full of "stuff" from a '67 912 for $5
2.  Jack for $5
3.  Really "cool" fat/bullet like mirrors which I think are
	hard to find.  $25/pair, and they are perfect!
4.  901 5speed Tranny $100
5.  5spd shift knob (new in Stoddard's parts tables) $5
6.  Early tail light rear lenses pair for $20 and they are in great shape!
7.  After it started raining, people put cardboard boxes in front of
	their table and yelled "free box!" and the chucked "stuff"
	into the box.  Got a whole bunch of stuff, dont even know
	what it all is, but, a lot of it is 356 stuff.

My buddy got a pair of nearly new Recarro seats so he can autox for $500,
he was excited that it was a fair price.  Another person had a 911 wood
steering wheel for $1000, boy am I glad I got mine last year
for $50 and I just have to refinish it! Lots of wheels, but,
outrageous prices - many were just plain junk.  I saw one wheel
with 6oz of lead on it and he wanted $150 for it!

All in all, not bad!  Weather cut our time short, but, a good shopping
spree just the same.  The Toyota 4Runner was packed!

See ya at Tweeks (7/16) in Indianapolis!

Ron D.

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 12:59:59 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: high-performance hype / golf / audio: Spit Happens

On Mon, 12 Jun 1995, doug dykaar wrote:

> >Meantime, those splitfire things make some sense. They spark along two
> >simultaneous paths, which should theoretically result in more complete
> >ignition unless the car was already igniting completely (due to proper
> >injector adjustment and in-cylinder vapor tumble/spin). It is unlikely
> >any of us have near-perfect fluid dynamics in our cylinders, so we can
> >probably all benefit, a _little_, from these things.

> WRONG!
Just for a note, according to the EPA, the average car has an 
inefficiency (that's what this all is about, getting the most out of 
everything) in the area of unburnt gas of .003%, so out of every l litre 
of gas, you burning all but less than one drop.

> useful. The likelyhood of both electrodes arcing simultaneously would
> require truly identical conditions, including gap, electrode surface
> condition, and path resistance. How likely is that?
Or two separate positive and negative surfaces...

 -Derek

Last week Ashley Dunn wrote to tell me that his experience was that
having the front camber set wrong caused his car to wiggle.  I checked
mine and, sure enough, the front camber seems to be about 1.7 degrees
(top of wheel toward center of car).  The manual says 0 degrees.  I
will have that fixed before I change the schocks.

Thanks Ashley!

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 95 12:14:00 PDT
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: RE: Carerra 3.2 engine and 915 gearbox in a 914 - Help


>I have a 1975 914 and I plan to put in a Carerra 3.2 engine with a 915
>gearbox.  As the gearbox would be in a different location a cable linkage
>system would be needed.  Has anyone heard of Patrick's Motorsport out of
>Arizona that offers such a cable system.  Is it good.

I've installed a 3.0 SC engine and 915 tranny in my 914.  I'm using the
Patrick Motorsports cable shifter too.  I don't know if I can recommend
it or not....shifting my car is difficult right now compared to the 914
tranny I had in it last time the car ran.  It could be due to a few things:

 - Cable shifter design (not likely...those are HUGE cables!)
 - Fresh tranny rebuild (definite possibility - should get better)
 - Pennzoil gear lube - not Swepco (will change this ASAP)
 - Short shift lever and throw (3.5"!) - not enough leverage (definitely)
 - I'm not used to the new shifter and new tranny (definitely)

My main complaint is I have to "muscle" the shifts....it takes a
lot of force to move the lever in and out of gears.  Not good for
autox where quick shifting is necessary.

Another problem with this setup is the cables are a little too long.
Finding a good cable routing is hard.

I believe the Renegade Hybrid guys have their own cable shifter - you
may want to talk to them for more info about their setup.....or you
could go the Vellios side-shift conversion route...more money, but
more "factory".

As I weed out the issues listed above, I can give a more accurate
recommendation.

>Given the weight of the 914, I hope that this engine combination would
>give it a good power to weight ratio and make it a quick 914.

It will.....I know 2 local guys who have the 3.2/915 combo in their cars.
One guy is running GT2 track events, and the other is the current
DM autox champ in our area.  Both of these guys have Vellios
side-shift conversion kits - 1 guy likes it, the other has had a
few problems.

>I also plan to upgrade the brakes to the 911 brakes.

Good.

>I would really appreciate  it if anyone can offer me technical tips or
>suggestion for such a conversion. Any idea on how fast would this car be.

I've got a bunch of info I'm compiling into a 914-6 conversion FAQ
that (hopefully) will be done soon.  There are a LOT of things you've
got to figure out.

>I plan to take this car on the track and would also be grateful for
>any suggestions on setting up this car.  Thanks.

What % of use is it going to see (and how important is each area
to be "correct"):

Street_______%
Autox________%
Track________%

This is VERY important if you'd like a good recommendation from
the very experienced P-philes on this list.

Considering your other message about a $3000 cap on modifying
the engine, I have to ask if you've thought of all the things you'll
need in order to get this project going.  It WILL be expensive.
Here are the areas I've modified from the stock 914-4 in order
to get my 3.0/915 combo installed:

911 struts/brakes/master cylinder
rear stub axles/CV's
stiffer rear shocks/springs
wheels/tires/flares
motor mount
tranny mount
muffler mount
914-6 engine sheet metal
shifting mechanism
oil tank and lines
interior gauges (oil pressure/temp, tach,speedo)
throttle linkage
clutch linkage
modify 915 tranny for mid-engined use (includes speedo pickup
    for street use)
headers/muffler(s) (cable shifting needs dual mufflers - this area
    is critical for good performance - I'm still gathering info)
wiring harness changes

Each area listed above has its own headaches and problems
you've got to decide how to solve.  A lot of it depends on what
you're using in another area.  For example, don't go out and buy
a motor mount from company "A" and a tranny mount from
company "B"....they may not line up.  There are also ground
clearance issues with a "Quick-6" motor mount....some
companies make short ones, and others make tall ones.
Of course, ground clearance problems really become
apparent with low profile 15" tires.....which is what I have.
3" of ground clearance underneath my motor mount isn't
what I'd call a "good" thing - especially when a speed
bump is in front of you and a growing lineup of cars
behind you.  :-)

Your carbed 3.2L has its own issues too....smog check,
throttle response, recurving the distributor....

I'll try and get my FAQ done ASAP.

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>
'75 914-6  3.0 SC

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 10:59:40 -0400

Tim,

The experiences I've heard/had with the Raceware parts have been very
positive.  However, in your application I do not think that there is
a problem requiring them as a solution.

There is a small list of common problems with the early SC's that you
probably want to address during rebuild.  I think that Bruce Anderson's
book lists the improvements made in the first couple of years.

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 15:09:07 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: "Big Brake" question


Hello Brake Experts:

What is the benefit of having very big brakes on a car? My car is an 89 944
Turbo. In 89, Porsche made three different 944 models, all with ABS. Each car
had different brakes. The standard 944 had single piston brakes, the S2 and
Turbo had 4 piston, with the Turbo brakes being larger, from the 928 S4.

Since the regular 944 brakes were powerful enough to lock the font wheels,
what is the benefit of having the larger rotors / calipers? Is it to
dissipate heat better, so that the brakes continue to work under extreme
(track) conditions? If so, would the addition of a cool brake duct kit make
the regular 944 brakes as good as the Turbo?

TIA
Barry Lenoble
BLenoble@aol.com
89 944 Turbo, Alpine White

Date:         Mon, 12 Jun 95 14:01:28 CDT
From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
Subject:      944 Clutch


Had some problems with my 944S this weekend at drivers ed.
Perhaps someone can shed some light on what's wrong.

While going around the track, it would not go into gear.
I pulled into the pits and the car would not go into any
gear.  It would go into gear with the engine off. I started
the car in 1st with clutch pushed in. It bucked a bit against
the parking brake, then quit bucking. From that point on, it
went into any gear easily.  I did my track time and everything
was fine. However:

1) when I let the clutch out in neutral, it makes
   a loud clack noise that it never made before.

2) I get engine vibrations at certain RPMs, (1400, 2800)
   The steering wheel does not vibrate at all. Just the
   engine (visibly) and the shifter. Dont think it's MM.

3) When driving and I let off the gas, there is a clunk feeling.
   And again when you hit the gas. It used to be a smooth transition
   from acceleration to coast and vice versa. The car goes into
   gear just fine. It just feels like there is some play somewhere
   there shouldn't be.

I suspect a clutch problem, but I'm not sure. One theory is the
slave cylinder. It has never been bled before (since I've had the
car for 1 year).  As for the engine vibrations, I checked the balance
belt and shafts. They are in time, belt is ok.

Any ideas would be greatly appreciated.

Darren Evans-Young
'87 944S Indischrot
darren@ua1vm.ua.edu

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 8 Jun 95 05:56:45 PDT
From: bezzant@corp.cirrus.com (Dan Bezzant)
Subject: re: Pressure Washers -- tearing your skin off

I remember my dad telling me a story about a guy at work who
was using a pressure washer to clean out a bucket he had been
using for a painting project.

Seems the stream from the pressure washer hit the bottom of the
bucket where there was still a little paint hanging around,
and a jet of water/paint reflected back up off the bottom of
the bucket and drilled a nice little tunnel of paint and water
right into his index finger.

The guy didn't think much of it 'til he went to the doctor
because it hurt a little.  The doctor *immediately* operated
to get the paint out, and then had the guy keep the finger
elevated for weeks, with the threat of losing his finger
if he didn't.

Moral of the story: BE CAREFUL with a pressure washer.
Wear all the protective stuff they tell you to.

Dan B.
'68 912

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 19:43:45 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Clutch

I would guess that your rubber center of your clutch disk has let go.

That would explain the clunking (metal stops hitting) and the vibration 
(chunks of 
rubber have been torn out of an otherwise balanced assembly) and the "would 
not go into any gear (chunks of rubber jammed into the works, preventing 
normal clutch release)        

Probably not the slave cylinder (it does not explain the vibration or the 
clunking).

Good luck,


>
>Had some problems with my 944S this weekend at drivers ed.
>Perhaps someone can shed some light on what's wrong.

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 95 13:52:38 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re: Targa Top Repair

>jus awunderin' whur in tarnation youns can git a new
>top for $80

Any number of places that advertise in Pano or Excellence
sell the Targa top for around that price.  It's a bit more
for German vinyl.  $100 or $120, if I recall.

The costs associated with rebuilding or recovering the
Targa top are almost entirely in the labor, not the 
material.

Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa

bhogan@newbridge.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 95 09:51:05 PDT
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert H. Albrecht)

Just a clarification on the below opinion of Gleason differentials
_____________________________________________________________________________

The Quaiffe is a licensed version of the Gleason-Torsen torque sensing
differential. It uses a complex interwoven planetary gear setup to send
power to the wheel best able to use that power. It does not have a lockup
mode. The Gleason-Torsen is *WIDELY* used in high-power four-wheel drive
applications, as it is nearly indestructable, can transmit tons of power,
and is *NOT* a maintenence item.

____________________________________________________________________________

        I installed a Gleason in my Jeep (AMC20 rear diff.) a few years
back.  The unit worked very well in that it transferred torque much better a
Spicer Positraction (disk type), and was less harsh than a Detroit Locker.
However, the Gleason only lasted about a year!  I'll admit to abusing it in
two ways.  First, in "Jeepin" we do some pretty tortuous things at very slow
speed.  Climbing over boulders with two alternate wheels in the air, where
you simply would go *NO WHERE* without "lockers".  Second, the Gleason unit
specified a maximum tire diameter of about 28" for my application.  I used
33" tires, so was applying more torque than specified.  Anyway, the "barber
pole" hears in my Gleason galled, turning the gear lube into something
approximating metallic metal-flake paint.  It started acting funny one day.
I returned home immediatly and pulled the Gleason out shortly before
catastrophic failure (saving the R&P, etc.)

        The Gleason works fine in a high speed/low torque (relative to
boulder crawling) applications.  However, due to numerous failures in the
application I described, Gleason stopped making units for aftermarket
off-road applications.  I was unable to obtain rebuild parts for my unit,
which could be very nice in a less extreme application.

Bob

Bob Albrecht, San Diego Region
'83 SC Targa, Platinum
'65 SC, Battleship (Dolphin) Grey
Cat named "Mouse"

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 14:46:37 -0700
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Mike Willis)
Subject: Re: 911SC wiggles, was 911 schocks

I don't think that the camber will cause the car to wiggle what the negative
camber will do is make the car handle better. When you turn the tire will
roll under the car with more negative camber the tire will still roll but
the roll will cause the tire to place a bigger contact patch on the pavement.

Toe in or tow it out of adj with cause wiggle. The major cause of wiggle is
out of round tires, out of balance tires, and lose wheel bearigs.

mike


>Last week Ashley Dunn wrote to tell me that his experience was that
>having the front camber set wrong caused his car to wiggle.  I checked
>mine and, sure enough, the front camber seems to be about 1.7 degrees
>(top of wheel toward center of car).  The manual says 0 degrees.  I
>will have that fixed before I change the schocks.

>Thanks Ashley!

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 13:48:27 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: camber, was 911SC wiggles, was 911 shocks

I don't think it's a matter of zero camber versus -1.5.  Zero camber
may be the official factory street setting, but many of us are driving
with negative camber without any wiggles.  It sounds more like unequal
toe-in.  

Dwight Mitchell, for example, has a competition alignment that calls
for aggressive camber, but no toe-in in front. 

An improperly lowered car will bump-steer; that may be the problem
here as well.  From what I've known and experienced, I'm pretty sure
your situation is not a result of negative camber alone.

Negative camber is the norm in competition settings because,
presumably, the car will lean in cornering and a negatively cambered
wheel will have more tire surface on the ground in those conditions.
Conversely, a zero camber will have you more on the edges.

FWIW, IMHO, and all that.  Hope this helps.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

Subject: MFI Pump


When I opened (for inspection and cleaning) the MFI
pump of the '72 911 I'm rebuilding, I noticed that
the four bolts surrounding the idle adjustment screw
were not screwed down tightly.  If you've been inside
one of these things, you'll know why I say it is not
obvious that they should be screwed tight.  They are
odd shaped bolts that sort of 'hang onto' cylindrical
pieces that press against a series of springs.  Can't
make it any clearer than that.  This is a case where
one picture is worth...

Is there someone out there who knows whether they should
be snugged up?  I did it, so it's too late to go back
to where they were, so please tell me I did the right thing.

BTW, this is the second one of these 23 year old pumps
I've been into, and except for warranting a good cleanup
with solvent to remove old oil residue, there have been
no visible signs of wear.

Thanks!

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 11:10:13 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: high-performance hype

At 05:38 AM 6/12/95 -0400, Scot Alan Douglas wrote:
>  Most intake systems 
>aren't the optimum shape a create turbulence at the inlet that the air 
>has to fight to get into the engine.  K&N filters don't charge, just aid 
>flow.  And if you'll remember from fluid mechanics, a bell shaped inlet 
>is the choice for optimum flow i.e. velocity stacks on Webber carbs.  

Hi Scot,

This is inaccurate.  In fact, you want laminar flow up until the charge
enters the cylinder head, or close to it.  It's the most efficient way
to move air.

You do want turbulence past a certain point because it does a better job
of mixing the air and fuel.  Hence "swirl" designs in ports, for example.
There are also considerations given to controlling flame front propagation
within the combustion chamber: with an off-centre spark plug, you want
to use assymetric air flow quality to control flame front propagation in
the chamber and so even it out.

A good source of info on this sort of thing is David Vizzard's book,
titled something like "Theory and Practice of Cylinder Head Modification."

Kevin Gross

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 95 13:23:21 TZ
From: Eric Brown (NetNT) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Improving power on 3.2 liter Carrera engine

} From: Melissa  <hongth@singnet.com.sg>
} To:  <porschephiles@tta.com>
} Subject: Improving power on 3.2 liter Carrera engine
} Date: Sunday, June 11, 1995 7:09PM
}
} I have a 3.2 liter Carrera that I plan to put into my 914.  This is a
} stock US market 3.2 liter engine that has been converted to a carburetor
} version.
} I would really appreciate it if anyone know of a relatively inexpensive
} way to improve the output of this engine.  Budget $3000.00.  Thanks

Before you beef up an engine that already will just about triple the
HP over a stock 914, what about the rest of the car?
Have you already modified the chassis and suspension to take the
200+ HP of the new engine? If not, you will have an ill-handling, even
dangerous car. The normal 914-6 mods include chassis stiffening with
weld in brackets (a full suspension-console mounted roll cage would
be even better), 911 front suspension/brakes, 911 (or if you can find
them, 914-6) rear brakes, and heavier springs, torsion bars, and
sway bars.

I haven't done this yet, but I am seriously considering a 914-6
conversion as my next project.

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 11:13:15 -0400
From: jccw@ilab.mitre.org
Subject: Re:  Hirschman automatik antennae

I took mine apart a couple of years ago - if I saved any information,
it's at home, and I'm at work now. So I don't remember the colors
of the leads. But it's pretty simple inside. There should be ground
on one lead, +12 all the time on another. The third lead switches
between +12 (radio on) and either ground or open (radio off). The
third lead controls a relay, which reverses the polarity of the dc
to the drive motor, and also determines which of two limit switch
positions (fully up or fully down) the voltage to the drive motor
goes through. The limit switch is kind of cute - takes about five
turns to go from one stop to the other. In my case, the relay was
hanging up - a bit of filing and a drop of oil fixed it. It still
doesn't always retract 100% unless I keep the mast lubricated a bit.

It appears to me that you can't do any harm by briefly applying +12
to two of the three leads and ground to the other. The worst that
could happen is that you would have the wrong match between drive
direction and limit switch - obviously a bad long-term match, but
not harmful for a few seconds. Or you could just go ahead and take
it apart; it's an imperfectly sealed unit in a very wet location
and could probably use some cleaning up anyway.

 -John White-
'84 928S

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 95 13:37:41 TZ
From: Eric Brown (NetNT) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 924S Incontinence

} From: Rich Burns  <71511.1672@compuserve.com>
}
} My '87 924S has been dribbling oil (Swepco 201) from the transaxle since I
} bought it last November.  The transaxle was rebuilt (bearings and synchros)
} early either late in '93 or early in '94.  I'm pretty sure less than 
5000 miles
} have been put on the rebuilt tranny.
}
} Not wanting the car  to be piddling $50/gal Swepco on my floor, I had 
my P-mech
} (who did the rebuild) take a look.  Input shaft seal was leaking.
}
} Seal has been replaced, and after about 100 miles is again leaving 
spots on the
} garage floor <grr>.  P-mech and I immediately hit on a possibility...  shaft
} bent?  This is scary.
}
} Even scarier...  could the main shaft of the transaxle be out of alignment
} slightly?  Bearing problem??  Mechanic wouldn't be happy if I impugned his
} rebuild as the cause of the leak...  am I off base here (I hope)?

I have Swepco 201 in my 944 transaxle and it doesn't leak a bit. This is a
transaxle with 130K original miles on it.

If the mechanic missed the fact that the input shaft was bent when he did
the rebuild, then he ought to admit the oversight and volunteer to fix it.
If there is any question _at_all_ about the skill and honesty of your mechanic,
then get a second opinion from another reputable mechanic. Don't tell them
too much other than "it was rebuilt not too long ago."

Good luck!

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red



------------------------------

Date: 12 Jun 95 12:16:00 EST
From: "LOGISX::GIBBS" <GIBBS%LOGISX.decnet@vaxa.acdnj.itt.com>
Subject: RE:  944 rear view mirror fell off.


>Hello,

>Help, my mirror fell off!!! It looks like the adhesive (or something) is 
>on the window... How can I fix this? What's the best way to remove the 
>adhesive and reattach my mirror? 

>Thank you in advance.
>Ujjal Bansel

>'85 944 (165k mi with two overused side mirrors)

Ujjal-

Before you do anything, get a crayon, and mark the perimeter of the adhesive
footprint on the windshield on the OUTSIDE of the glass (so that after you
clean off the inside, you will be able to put the mirror back in the right
spot).

No get a "Mirror Remount Kit" from your friendly auto parts store.  This 
kit has two vials of chemicals, and should cost around $3.

Clean the inside of the glass by using a razor blade to scrape off the 
remaining glue, then use pure alcohol to remove any oil or residue on 
the inside of the window.  

Examine your mirror, and carefully remove the mounting button from the
mirror arm.  Now follow the directions on the remount kit to glue the
button back to the window.  After it is set, remount the mirror on the 
button.

Don't worry if you don't get it exactly right, because you will be doing
it again in 6-12 months.  So far I've done mine 5 or 6 times, and it always
comes off again.  I suspect that UV light degrades the cement that they
use.

I have heard that there is a double sided tape that can be used on the 
85 1/2 and up models, but don't know anything more about it.  If anyone
has a better or more permanent method I'd love to hear about it.

Ed Gibbs
gibbs@avionics.itt.com
'84 944, Guards Red, All Mine

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 11:12:54 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Gerald G. MacDonald - Thomas Cooley Law School" <macdonag@mlc.lib.mi.us>
Subject: Re: 944 Rear view mirror fell off.


Ujjal,
I am a recent mirror replacement survivor, so let me give you my 
experience.  There's rear mirror adhesive made by Loc-tite which includes 
a solvent and the adhesive.  There are good directions on the back of the 
package.  One thing I learned though (after the mirror fell off the first 
time I used this stuff):  Do NOT be conservative on the application of 
the adhesive to the back of the mounting plate.  I did the "one drop" in 
the center and when the mirror later fell off I dicovered the "one drop" 
had only sread out to about half the full diameter of the mounting 
plate.  Lesson:  Make that "one drop" of adhesive a BIG one (yes, there 
may be a little mess around the base of the mirror, but at least the 
mirror stays stuck!)  To get the old adhesive off the windshield AND the 
back of the mounting plate (don't forget this!) just use a razor blade.

Good luck!

Jerry Mac
84 911 Targa
Motor-stadt Region PCA

Prof. Gerald G. MacDonald
Thomas M. Cooley Law School
217 S. Capitol Ave
Lansing, MI 48901
(517)371-5140 x563
(517)334-5748 FAX
macdonag@mlc.lib.mi.us

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 20:03:02 -0400
From: Drive951@aol.com
Subject: Porsche limited used car warranty

For what it's worth:

I bought my 1986 944 Turbo two years ago and received the factory warranty.
 (Incidentally the warrenty is for all cars from model year 1986 on)

The program had been in affect all of one month.  The warranty was included
in the price of the car at apparently(!) no cost to me.  It came in handy
because I had the air conditioner compressor (a cozy $1000 part) replaced for
free.

I have heard from other fanatics who have since purchased their cars at this
dealer that a) they did not receive a warranty and/or b)  it was offered at
an additional cost.

Perhaps the dealer wisened up after a couple months under the new warranty
and was trying to take advantage of un-knowing customers?  

It helped me out at any rate.  I wonder how it is "really" supposed to work
and would be curious to hear from others who received/did not receive the
warranty.

Thanks,
Charlie Boyer
Drive951@aol.com

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 1995 16:48:20 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: "Big Brake" question

>Hello Brake Experts:
>
>What is the benefit of having very big brakes on a car? My car is an 89 944
>Turbo. In 89, Porsche made three different 944 models, all with ABS. Each car
>had different brakes. The standard 944 had single piston brakes, the S2 and
>Turbo had 4 piston, with the Turbo brakes being larger, from the 928 S4.
>
>Since the regular 944 brakes were powerful enough to lock the font wheels,
>what is the benefit of having the larger rotors / calipers? Is it to
>dissipate heat better, so that the brakes continue to work under extreme
>(track) conditions? If so, would the addition of a cool brake duct kit make
>the regular 944 brakes as good as the Turbo?
>
>TIA
>Barry Lenoble
>BLenoble@aol.com
>89 944 Turbo, Alpine White

YES! If you actually use those brakes they eventually "go away". The fluid
boils, or the rotors warp, etc. If you are going to start up the
modification spiral, the cool ducts are a good investment, as they can be
used with virtually any brake set up. In general the brakes were upgraded
by the factory as the cars got heavier. The factory pads also reflect a
different design philosophy: the factory would prefer you warp the rotors,
BEFORE boiling the fluid, so the pads are more thermally insulating than
some of the available track versions.

The 86 951 was an exception. It was WAY underdesigned from the beginning.
If you're worried about cooking the brakes on the track, you can attach a
thermocouple gauge to the brake pad and monitor the temperature while
driving.

have fun,

doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
(Red Calipers, 255/40, and 275/40-17s, turbo-cup suspension, soon)
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
Groucho the cat



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 95 14:31:50 CDT
From: wpcostel@porsche.aud.alcatel.com (William Costello)
Subject: In Defense of Porsche Dealer Service

I would like to give the Porschephiles members hope for Porsche dealers. I
was sent a postcard inviting me to bring my 86 911 Carrera in to Town North
Porsche and Mazda in Richardson TX (Dallas) for a free Porsche Service Clinic
(the postcard came from PCNA in Reno).

I took my car in last Saturday afternoon expecting that I would
be getting an estimate for $$$$ money. The head Porsche mechanic test drove
the car and than put it up on a rack to check it over. He than brought me
into the garage to go over what he found. To my supprise, the work he
recommended was the following:

  1. Repack and adjust the front wheel bearings.
  2. Repack the CV joints on the half-shafts.
  3. Weld new rear sway bar mounts on.

I have been needing to get item #3 done for a long while, but have not
taken the time since I had removed the sway bar after I found one mount
broken. Items #1 and #2 were expected with the age of the car.

I made a comment about how small the estimate was and he said he wish he could
find more things to fix, but that was all it needed. The mechanic also told me
that my car was one of the best he had seen in a long time. He said that people
had brought some cars in that had been so abused, that they were unsafe to
drive. He also looked up my options using the sticker under the front hood
and told me that the car came loaded, except for limited slip. He also gave
me a coupon for a discount on all parts and labor good until the fall.

Even though I do my own maintainance, I feel much better about this shop and
will use them for anything that is beyound my know how. I hope this gives
others hope that good Porsche dealer service is available.

W.P. Costello

------------------------------

Date: 12 Jun 1995 12:46:26 U
From: Steve Poole <stevep@wrq.com>
Subject: PNW PCA tour report

On Saturday I took part in my first PCA event: a 300 mile tour of the Olympic
peninsula in western Washington. We met at 9:00 just south of Seattle, went
south to Tacoma, west to Gig Harbor, and then took a beautiful winding route,
with a couple of stops for coffee and B.S., north to Port Townsend, where we
arrived at about 2:30.

We had about 18 cars -- mostly 911s, ranging from '74 to '89, plus three 944s
and an extremely menacing-looking black '89 928. Our route included travel on
I-5, where our caravan was quite the gawk target, and highway 101, the lovely
and curvaceous coast-hugging path along the Pacific, where we had to deal
with the occasional Winnebago. Despite these slight inconveniences we made
good time and I had occasion to discover that my magnetic-mount CB antenna
does stay firmly affixed at 100 mph, despite the manufacturer's only
assurance being that it would stick "at legal highway speeds."

The scenery was gorgeous, even in the cloudy weather, and it was an
incredible high to be screaming around the curves in the middle of a pack of
beautiful, roaring Porsches. We made a stop at Dosewallips national park,
where our arrival and departure drew scores of onlookers out of their damp
tents.

On the return trip I cut out early and took the Kingston ferry to Edmonds,
then drove home to Seattle. While waiting for the ferry to arrive, two people
stopped by the car to ask if I'd been with the pack and ask what it was all
about. I gleefully took the opportunity to proseletyze for Porsche and PCA!

As was suggested by other list members, I purchased a CB radio before the
trip and found that it greatly enhanced the experience. If you've never done
a tour like this with your local PCA club, I highly recommend catching the
next one -- you'll have an absolute blast.

I'm sporting MAJOR wood in anticipation of the next tour! Wahoo!

Steve Poole
stevep@wrq.com
1979 911SC

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 95 14:16:28 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Splitfires and Hirschmann Antennas



Hi all,

Splitfire spark plugs, as a few people have already posted, are basically
snake oil. The only advantage, as a few posters noted is the additional
area exposed to the center electrode under very high load conditions, 
noteably midrange acceleration. Other spark plug types offer similar 
characteristics from the use of noble metals, which take longer to break 
down in these conditions.

All spark plugs should be indexed to expose the open area of the electrode
to the top of the piston, assuring a minimally shrouded spark and ignited 
mixture to expand and propagate correctly. The angled spark plug holes in
914 2.0 heads allow a better mixture burn than the stock 1.7/1.8 straight 
plug heads because the angle and indexing will provide better combustion 
and scavenging as the exhaust valve opens. 

The new Splitfires yield a little more torque and a few HP in the midrange 
area. But so do the Bosch Silver plugs. 


Hirschmann electric antennas.
The wiring is thus: Black is ground, Red is + battery 
power, on at all times, white is actuation voltage (+) from the radio. To
test, connect the power leads to a 12V power source, observing polarity. 
Touch the white lead to the power and the relay should trip and the antenna 
extend. Remove power, the antenna should retract. Occasionally the relay 
opens, it is on a printed circuit board and can be replaced with a Radio 
Shack replacement unit. 

If the internal mechanisim corrodes, toss the unit. You can't get parts unless 
you have a few laying around.  There are replacements that work exactly the 
same and will fit in the original location for less than $70. There is nothing
magic about a Hirschmann except the price. I addapted the mechanisim of a 
replacement to fit a Hirschmann case for a concours car. 

If the antenna mast is sticking as it extends or retracts, a little WD-40 to 
free the mast segments can be sprayed at the junctures. If the mast is broken, 
replacements are available from car radio shops that sell Hirschmanns.

Do not loose any of the fender mounting hardware for your 924/944 as the 
angle pieces are special. If you buy a used unit, make sure it works before 
you pay for it. Most shops do not allow returns on electrical components.

Jim Pasha

Subject: Karcher Global Endurance GT Series

Just a brief report about the Karcher Global Endurance GT Series that
has grown very popular here in Europe.

I just got a glimpse of the results last night from the last race
and noticed that there where Porsche's (GT2's) on 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 
5th and 6th positions. This in competition with McLarens (that usually
wins), Jaguars, Venturis, Ferraris etc. The Porsches have much less
horsepower than the McLarens so its quite interesting to see these
results. I unfortunately missed the race so I don't know what happened
to all the McLarens. 

Many of these cars will be at LeMans but the next race in the series
is at Anderstorp, Sweden, 2nd of July.

Magnus Ottenstrom
