Porschephiles #1477                         Tue Jun 13 12:43:59 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 09:08:26 +0100
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: 911 Test drive fatalities


Three people were killed during a 911 test drive in
the UK. A potential customer and a salesman were
on a test drive in a 911 Tiptronic when it collided
head on with a Renault 5.

The Porsche driver and passenger and the driver of the Renault 
all died as a result of injuries sustained in the crash or the 
ensuing fire.

Police were unable to say who had been driving the
Porsche because the nature of the accident means that dental
records need to be traced to identify the casualties.

Police said speed may have played a factor in the accident.
Porsche UK said that it checked that customers were experienced
drivers for test drives, and that it was their policy for
the customer and salesman to adhere strictly to speed limits during 
demos.

This is the second fatality during a sports car demo in 
recent months. A Ferrari test drive in April concluded when
the customer crashed and burned after loosing control
of the vehicle.

The article in "The Independent" of  13th June 1995 from which I draw 
these facts was commendably neutral. rather than a "BAN these
Killer Kars NOW!" headline, with a picture of a 935 on a racetrack
cartwheeling into the barriers or similar, the article was restricted
to the facts. It included quotes from The MD of Porsche GB who
stated that the 911 was a very safe car, particularly in terms of
the handling and braking performance, as well as a quote from the 
spokesman for the British Safety Council who called for a code of 
practice to provide guidelines for promotional driving of
high performance motor cars. 

I am not sure what the guidelines would contain except for
the fairly intuitive direction that driving outside of
your performance envelope in an unfamiliar motor car might
result in crashing and burning. Having said that, there does seem
be a problem with customers who screw up big time on a test drive.
I wonder how many people are killed in test drive situations in 
motor cars other than Porsche or Ferrari, and simply don't get 
reported in the newspapers because it does not make a good
splash in the headlines?

Cheers

Ben

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 08:31:16 -0500
From: Eric Yuzon <YUZONE@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>
Subject:  New MOMO Steering Wheel -Reply



>>> Steve Elkins <spelk@bert.arc.nasa.gov> 06/12/95 05:56pm >>>

Howdy,

I just installed a new MOMO steering wheel in my
'87 944S.  It works/feels great, but has a slight  problem.  Every once in a
while the horn honks for no reason.  I have looked at the horn button and
wire from the hub adapter and every thing looks
OK.  What could be causing this?  Could I have a bad hub adapter or
horn button?  It seems to happen about once a day.

Steve '87 944S
*****************************************************************************
Steve Elkins
Sterling Software
NASA Ames Research Center spelk@bert.arc.nasa.gov
*****************************************************************************

Check the return spring and make sure there is enough clearance on the
switch before it actuates.  If the clearance is too small or the spring is
too short or weak, any good bump will set it off.


eric
86 GTi 
80 911sc (awesome bug killer)

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 95 08:38:50 EST
From: cornelius-halvey@smh-mail.smh.com
Subject: sparkplugs

Regarding this spitfire thread:  I had an RX-7 for years. Why did it's 
plug have FOUR electrodes? Doesn't this support the Spitfire claim?

Neil Halvey

1995 993 white coupe


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 08:58:50 -0500
From: Eric Yuzon <YUZONE@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>
Subject:  sparkplugs -Reply



>>> <cornelius-halvey@smh-mail.smh.com> 06/13/95 08:38am >>>
Regarding this spitfire thread:  I had an RX-7 for years. Why did it's  plug
have FOUR electrodes? Doesn't this support the Spitfire claim?

Neil Halvey

1995 993 white coupe

That was probably for an early RX-7.  The later RX-7s had the ground
electrode as a ring around the positive tip.   This I believe increased the
size or area of the spark to increase the probability of ignition.  Some
Nippondenso have a "U" shaped groove to manipulate the shape of the
spark as well.  The Split Fires is just another chapter of the same story. 
They just market it like crazy.  People who do not understand the basics
of the IC engine are the must susceptible.   They would probably buy the
gasoline pill, too.  The people at Mazda used knowledge from their racing
program.  So the answer is YES.  Its just that there are other spark plugs
that will do the same.  The differences will be the shape or area of the
spark and the material of the electrodes (this contributes to life
expectancy; ie the Platinum Bosches)


Eric Yuzon
EE at TRW
86 GTi
80 911sc



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 09:01:03 -0500 (EST)
From: ANDRUC00@SNYBUFAA.CS.SNYBUF.EDU
Subject: Re: 924 CIS mods

    Speaking of modifications... I have a '79 924 with the older CIS (no 
lambda (o2) sensor). But being willing to screw with anything and everything
(The best way to learn is to screw with it). I came up with a simple way to
convert over to a lambda based system with very little cash...  In a nutshell
(to conserve bandwith) It needs basically an Oxygen sensor, an OP-AMP (Operat-
ional Amp) for non elctrojunkies... and a hobbyist servo and a few screws,
bolts and wire. Plus it could also be manually tuned by the driver on the fly.
All that is actually modified on the fuelk system is a clever modification
to the warm up regulator. (The thing that controls fuel pressure, and thus
the Mixture on CIS...)   Anyone interested email me direct for faster response
I seem to be getting missing and or duplicate list mail, so you may need to 
em,ail me twice....

Dave A.
Andruc00@snybufaa.cs.snybuf.edu


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 09:09:52 -0500 (EST)
From: ANDRUC00@SNYBUFAA.CS.SNYBUF.EDU
Subject: Re: Splitfires. Its not the SPARK!!!!


    I've seen the splitfire thread for a while and nowe i want to put in my
$.02.   Whoever said that the spark goes along two paths is wrong, but
thats not the purpose of the plug. The split in the electrode is for the
FLAME FRONT (no pun intended) When the mix ignites it fires through the split 
going straight down to the piston the outward. (more effective combustion) 
Where as a conventional plug has a flame front that comes out sideways
and hits the walls first creating a less fierce and lower power "bang"
As for all the claims on power. I never really noticed a difference. But what
did change was idle. The splits' ran with a smoother idle and seemed to last
a hell of a lot longer in my nissan which had tended to run rich. I haven't 
been able to try them in my 924 though.  But if you're interested in the 924 
bit. Excellence wrote an article on spilts in a 924. And i believe that they
came up with a zero difference in accelleration and in mileage.

Well thats my 2 bits....
Dave  A.
Andruc00@snybufaa.cs.snybuf.edu
As for the flame front stuff. I read about it in the Splitfire brochure....

94 850 turbo wagon
Groucho the cat



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 09:31:39 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: sparkplugs -Reply

> > Regarding this spitfire thread:  I had an RX-7 for years. Why did it's  plug
> > have FOUR electrodes? Doesn't this support the Spitfire claim?

> The people at Mazda used knowledge from their racing
> program.  

Actually, they stole this one from a Bosch plug last made in about '62,
the W225T7.

Again, nothing new here: more electrodes means more chances that the
plug won't foul. But note that the ShitFire has *ONE* electrode, with
a forked tongue. Must be from marketing...

BTW, you can get the same "ring electrode" plug mentioned from Bosch as
well as NGK. The Bosch unit was apparently developed for NASCAR, according
to Bruce A.....

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 12 Jun 95 11:46 EDT
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: What's that for?

>From: dougc@mails.imed.com
  Instead of taking my 928 to have the oil
  changed, I decided to do it myself. After removing
  the drain plug, which I expected to be a plain old
  bolt like most cars, I was supprised to find something
  that looked like it came out of an aircraft. 
  In particular, I noticed a center insert that
  protrudes maybe 1/8" beyond the threads into 
  the oil pan. What's that for?

On my 944 (and, I imagine, on the 928) that is a magnetic pickup.  It'll grab
and hold any small pieces of (ferrous) metal that might find their way into the
oil pan.  You should check and clean it every time you change the oil.  On my
motorcycle(s), I would occasionally find small bits on it, but never had any
problems.  I've never seen any on my Porsche, so I don't know if finding any
counts as significant.

Cheers!
- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 95 10:58:30 EDT
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Advice needed -Reply

> >>> Timothy A. Budd <budd@rohan.sdsu.edu> 06/12/95 11:26am >>>
> Well this isn't exactly porsche related, but it is because of a Porsche  that
> I am in this dilema.  I have been looking for a 911SC for the past  couple
> of months.  Unfortunately my toyota celica blew up (oil and  collant
> mixing...ouch!).  So I need a new ride.  I don't want to rush  into a
> purchase of the next Porsche I see, so I have two possibilites, on  which
> I have placed a $1000 ceiling.
> - early BMW 320i (borderline)

Hi Timothy,

   I have done both of the suggested courses of action, with mixed results.
I put a used engine into an '80 Datsun 210 for a total outlay of $140.
The result of that was that I had a rustbucket that ran great. It still
does, you can have it for $700 if you want, and I have since fixed most
of the rust. Compression is 184-186psi on all cylinders, power is good and
the rest of the drivetrain is fine. Good brakes too. Also I bought an '80
BMW 320i for $1000 last year. I have put about $200 in parts (waterpump,
rear shoes, front pads & rotors) onto it, and will proceed with rust chasing
this summer. No, it's not for sale. My general feelings about the two
alternatives is that they are quite evenly matched, but there would be no
comparison if I had paid someone else to do the work instead of doing it
myself. The Bimmer would win hands down in that case - the Datsun would have
been a write-off. Moral: never pay someone to work on a beater, particularly
one that is easy to work on yourself. The other moral: don't waste your money,
sweat, and knuckle skin on a car you don't have a strong emotional attachement
to. I'd rather walk than work on a Renault, for instance. And I'd rather
work on a Porsche than eat or sleep. But sometimes I eat and sleep anyway...


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

What a beautibul Mornin!
I walked out this morn, the air was clean, crisp, and there was a fresh smell 
in the air.  Decided right away to pull the sunroof out of my 924 for the 
mornin commute.  Cranked up the engine - love that sound!- and started my 40+ 
mile commute into Ann Arbor over some of the best country roads Michigan has to 
offer a porsche.  (they made em that way just for me)

Once up to the main ave. I spied a white Mustang 5.0 tooling along at above the 
posted - so since my ride is white, and for NO other reason - I proceeded to 
catch up. Having my speedo buried in no time, (damn 924's only say 85) we had a 
wonderful time makin it to the next town - best time i've done in a while.

Keepin a sharp eye in the rearview just in case. All that I saw was a new kelly 
green dodge ram tryin to keep up - doin a damn good job, if I must say so too!

When I finally got to my fav coffee hole, the dodge pulled in behind me, as I 
proceeded to exit my ride for that cup-o-joe I noticed the gentleman in the 
dodge ram and said "HI! nice mornin, Nice truck!".  He said good morning also 
and. . .  "Nice car!" with a big grin.

I held open the door for him, and as I proceeded to get my coffee, he hit the 
doughnut counter.

Just a lovely mornin I thought as the man in the uniform, a deep blue uniform -
with a badge and all the fancy riggin on - left the store -

"Youall have a great drive home now - yahere"

Gary Bowden
Still only 8 points - and countin???
White 1982 924

owners.  I consider myself fortunate to count a few 914/944 owners as friends,

in the area -Ann Arbor - want to carry on some dialog?

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 13:17:53 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Porsche Autocross information - Part 6 : TIRES!

Hi,

I have been asked to submit my columns on autocrossing Porsches
to the archives. Here is the sixth of nine(?) columns. Please let
me know if there are any mistakes or omissions, or other questions
that I should answer. I am editing and submitting them one at a time,
and will upload the whole thing after final editing.

There have been several requests for permission to use this material
in PCA newsletters, etc. Please ask before using it, but basically
any PCA use will be granted if the author is noted. If not too
difficult, I would like a copy of the publication with my material.



	Three-Wheeling by Mike Piera Part 6 of ?

	Setting up a Porsche for stock class autocrossing

	Of all the modifications that can be made to make a killer
stock class autocrosser, tires give the greatest improvement over
factory equipment. Street tires are designed with tread life
as one of the top priorities, whereas autocross tires are
designed strictly for performance. There are only a few special
purpose street-legal autocross tires on the market : BFG Comp TA R-1,
Yokohama A008 RS-II, and Hoosier Autocrosser. Nearly all serious
autocrossers use one of these tires. There are a few newcomers who
make very soft performance tires such as Toyo which may be 
competitive. Goodyear and Bridgestone make good tires for road
racing, but they do not currently have autocross-specific tires. 

	In '94 the BFG tire was available in two versions, 
Competition (230) and autocrossing (226) but the 226 was discontinued
in '95 as the 230 seemed fast enough. The 230 was designed mostly for
road racing, but is also good for autocrossing, especially long 
courses or pro-solos where your tires get warm. The Yokohama is also
available in a road racing version (RS) and autocross (RS-II). Even
the Hoosier has a road-racing version, called the Street TD. The
difference between the two versions of these three brands is
basically the tread compound. The autocross version is generally
softer and designed to work best at lower temperatures (there is no
warm-up lap in autocrossing). The tradeoff of the autocross tires'
great performance is that they wear out much faster. For occasional
autocrossers, or those who also want to use their competition tires
on the track, the road racing compound can be used for autocrossing. 
These include the Goodyear, Bridgestone, Toyo, and Hoosier street TD.
The road racing tire will be slightly slower on most autocross courses.
In 1995, the BFG 230 "competition" tire is still winning most classes
in the big events, so may be the best compromize.

	The Hoosier is in a class by itself because it is a bias-ply
tire, not a radial. The handling characteristics are quite different,
and the Hoosier was not legal in SCCA stock classes even though it
was "street-legal", until 1995. In general terms, the Hoosier is not
as quick to respond to driver input, but will not lose traction as 
quickly as the radials. The bias ply tires work with a greater slip
angle than the radials. This means you must drive with more effort,
and allow the car to slide more than on radials. You can drive as
much with your feet as with your hands. This suits some driving styles
better than others. Tire pressures are lower and tire roll-over is
greater than radials. Hoosiers are generally better suited to cars 
with a higher level of modification than a stock class car. These
tires can be faster than radials, but they are an aquired taste. If
you are serious, try a set and see for yourself. Hoosier is also
making a radial street-legal autocross tire, but it probably will
not be legal until 1996. This tire has a super-aggressive tread
pattern, almost a slick! There are only one or two grooves.

	The BFG R1 has a very stiff inner sidewall and a tread 
pattern similar in concept to the Yokohama, with an outer tread
area which will become a slick after use or shaving. The outside edge
is very square, but does not roll over even at very low pressures.
These tires work well at lower pressures than previous autocross
tires. Try pressures in the low 30's or lower. Pressures are a
personal choice depending on your car setup and driving style, there	
is really no "ideal" pressure. A higher pressure will give quicker
response, but a lower pressure may give more cornering speed
in a constant corner. For the truly serious competitor who
needs immediate performance, tires should be shaved on a tire
truing machine. New full-tread autocross tires handle poorly until
they are worn in. The Hoosiers are an exception and work well
after a few "scrub-in" runs. The BFG may actually last longer if
shaved due to less "scalloping" of the outer area, and less uneven
wear to the middle block, which causes the tread groove to wear to
the cord while the rest of the tire is still fine. The 230 is
better than the 226 in this respect (maybe why the 226 was dropped).

	After selecting a tire, the size must be chosen. Basically you
want the lowest profile tire in the widest size that will fit on your
rim properly. Also consider the rules, as PCA parade rules have silly
minimum circumference rules. I was able to get around the PCA rules
and still run a 50 series tire by squeezing a 225/50/15 on my 6"
rims in '91 (not recommended, but it worked!). For '94 I got a set
of 7" rims for the 225/50/15. This was legal, while my normal
205/50/15 on 6" rims were not. A standard 911/944 7" rim will fit on 
the front of most 911's, but a pre-78 911 may need the 911R offset to 
fit 7" rims on the rear. Revolution makes a wheel for this application. 

	Before spending lots of money on new tires, make sure you
have the widest rim that is legal for the class you are running. 
Also a smaller diameter rim is better because it will effectively
change your final drive ratio and lower the car if a smaller diameter
tire can be used. For example, several Porsche models such as the 911 SC,
Carrera, and 944 can choose between 15" and 16" rims. The 15" rim with 
50 series tires would be the best choice unless the width is less. A 
911 Carrera with 7" and 8" wide 15" wheels with 50 series tires will be
faster than 16" tires of the same width in an autocross.

	Here are some common Porsche rim sizes and tires. For the 914,
the 5 1/2" x 15" forged Fuchs alloy is best, with 195 or 205/50/15
tires. The 195 will really help acceleration and lower the car,
although the 205 has been more popular. Even with my heavier and
much more powerful 911S on 6" wide rims, I had one of my best events
ever on 195/50/15 Yokohamas, giving Roger Johnson's Corvette one of
his few losses at a Pro-Solo. For the early 911 or other Porsches
with 6" x 15" rims, the 205/50/15 is probably best. This tire will
also work very well on a 7" wide rim if a 225/50/15 tire will not
fit under the car's fenders (an early 911 with 7" wide rear rims).
The 225/50 fits well on 7" and 8" rims. But on a powerful 911, 
245/50/15 tires will work great on the 8" rears. These recommendations
generally apply to 16" rims also, but 45 series tires are available 
which are even better. In 17 inch rims, the new BFG 235/40/17 is
great for the narrow 7" fronts on late model 911s. The tire 
companies have "recommended rim widths" for their tires which will 
also help, and they can tell you what sizes successful 
autocrossers are currently using. The BFG tires seem to work OK
on narrower rims than you would think, so if you are stuck with 
narrow rims they may help.
	
	The Yokohama tires can be ordered from most tire dealers. Call
Kevin Rogers at Yokohama in California at (800) 423-4544 X-3862 for
technical questions. BFG tires are ordered direct from Team T/A,
although there are a few "team T/A" dealers who can get them for you.
Call (800) RACE BFG to join team TA. You will get their informative
newsletter and can find out how to order tires.



More to come!

P.S. I'll be away for a week, so won't be able to reply for a while,
and won't be getting the Porschephiles list.

Mike Piera AnalogMike@aol.com
'72S and '73E Targas, '73 914/2.0 (last two project cars for sale?)


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 11:23:34 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 911 Flywheel

At 09:58 PM 6/12/95 EDT, MR MICHAEL R GRIFFITHS wrote:
>I just took my clutch off the flywheel and the clutch disc
>is worn down to the rivets.  How do you tell if the pressure 
>plate is worn out, as well as the throw out bearing?  Also
>how do I tell if the flywheel needs to be machined? How
>signifigant is a lighter flywheel(8 lbs. vs. 12)?  Is four
>pounds a big difference at the flywheel?
>
>             Thanks in advance
>
>                             Mike Griffiths
>80 sc turbo lk  on jack stands 

Pressure plate and t/o bearing: you don't, you replace them as a matter
of practice.  The belleville washer-style spring fingers on the PP
get tired.

On the flywheel, look for signs of gouging.  Absent them, it is probably
fine.  If you want to be very careful and correct, have the surface
milled flat and have it balanced.  There is probably a run-out spec
but I don't have it handy.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 11:04:27 -0400
From: PerryS7342@aol.com
Subject: RE:Want my Title...

Please understand that I am not trying to defend the actions of the dealer in
withholding your title, but from your description "something smells fishy".
 Until you identify the chain of ownership and custody of the vehicle in your
possession you won't find out the real problem in withholding title and
precluding registration.

You indicate the car was in possession of an insurance company.  Did the car
have a salvage title at that time?  Was there a lienholder on the original
title (DMV should be able to tell you)?  Was an additional lien recorded (or
a mechanics lien established) as a result of repair or other event that put
the car in possession of the insurance company?  Did the dealer assert at the
time of your purchase and payment that they were the legal owner or were they
merely acting on your behalf as a agent in negotiations with the insurance
company?  Does the bill of sale you received (or a conditional sales
contract) indicated the form was approved by the Department of Motor Vehicles
in the State of Purchase?  Does the document indicate liability or exclusion
from liability on any liens, documented on title or otherwise?  You really
need to find these things out (I would presume the lawyer you have would
already have done that).

The bottom line (in my view) is that if the dealer clearly asserted ownership
at the time of your agreement and payment to them, they committed fraud by
offering a vehicle for sale for which they did not have clear title.  Your
state's attorney should be able to initate fraud action against them (include
a copy to your state's dealer association).  If one the other hand the dealer
merely acted as a purchasing agent on your behalf with the insurance company,
you may have a problem.  You mentioned repossession.  If the dealer incurred
additional costs (towing, storage, etc) associated with repossession, then
they could in turn expect to pass these costs on to you as the ultimate buyer
if they were acting only as your agent.  The clue here is that the DMV
apparently recognized the dealer as the legitimate owner by issuing the title
to them somewhere in the process.  You or your attorney need to find out why.
  

Perry

Date: 13 Jun 1995 08:28:32 -0700
From: "Thom Kuby-CTA" <thom_kuby-cta@cl_c21smtp_gw.chinalake.navy.mil>
Subject: 84-85 carrerra questions

                      Subject:                              Time:  6:58 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         84-85 carrerra questions              Date:  6/13/95

To the p-filers
I am looking for some technical input, and I'll need it real soon.  
I have a friend with an 84-85 (don't know which) carrera targa that he bought
new.  the car has slightly more than 100k showing on the odo.  He came to me
the other day complaining about the "assist spring" going away...
Before we get to the actual problem; Let me give you guys a little
background...Since we live out in the middle of nowhere, I have taken it upon
myself to help the other Porsche owners in this immediate area however I can,
before any real shops get called in.   Trying to get a p-car fixed locally is
a huge pain in the ass and general waste of time/money.
Going to any good, Porsche-oriented shop from here is at least a four hour
road trip-needless to say, it's a good idea to have a firm grip on whatever
the problem is beforehand.  So, I try to help...Besides the necessity
factor-this is actually a lot of fun for me.   
Now, having said that, let me point out that I'm not exactly a pro mechanic,
far from it-I learn as I go along.  But I am comfortable with the basics (I
have a fairly well-equipped garage...) and I think I can generally save the
other local p-car owners time, money and grief by simply being a nice guy and
helping out...
Now-"the problem"
The driver has said that his spring assist (for the clutch) has gone away. As
I write this-I have not actually looked the car over yet (hence your
suggestions and advise are solicited beforehand)  
My immediate thought was the pedal cluster-is this valid? 
do the pedal clusters on these later cars have a similar spring layout like on
the early 911/912s and 914s?
Is there another spring layout that I can get to on these later transaxles?  
Is this serviceable without splitting engine and transaxle?  
Would it be worth it to take the engine out? (if so, might as well change the
whole clutch while we in there right?)
could this problem stem from any other linkage areas? (Like the transaxle
coupling?)
Whatever input, advise, comments, suggestions any of you may have is highly
welcome. 
Thanks in advance!
Thom Kuby 
PORSCHE "res ipsa loquitor..."

thomkuby@owens.ridgecrest.ca.us

'68 912 coupe (daily driver-resto project)

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 15:07:11 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Re(2): What's that for

>>It's a magnet. It's for grabbing hold of ferrous miscellania that would
>>otherwise want to circulate throughout your engine along with the oil.
>
>Speaking of this advanced magnet technology, does anyone have an opinion on
>those magnetic bands that one can strap around the oil filter to provide the
>same service? Is it redundant? Doesn't seem like it could hurt.
>
>Steve Poole
>stevep@wrq.com
>1979 911SC

A magnetic field gets weaker as you move away from the source. maybe if you
wrap it around your head.
It would stick to the plate in my head, or I'd have one on right now.

In general, if you find yourself saying " Doesn't seem like it could hurt,
" It means "snake oil".

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 95 11:15:53 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: $200 Pressure Washers


I bit the bullet and this weekend bought one of
those electric, $200 pressure washers to help 
clean and degrease my current project.  It really
was a big help, and I'm sorry I didn't do this 
years ago.  What used to take a half dozen applications
of Gunk and vigorous hosing--sometimes more--took only
one or two.

As others advised, it's not the kind of tool you'd use
to clean a large concrete driveway, for example, because
the size of the spray pattern isn't that large, whereas
the more expensive units offer the needed wider spray.  But
for engines, transmissions and an annual deck washing,
it seems just fine.

Thanks again to all those who offered advice.

 -Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu
'72 911E Targa
'72 911T Coupe (pretty much degreased!)

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 14:26:07 -0500
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Re: 911 Flywheel

(warning non-tech answer follows)
>I just took my clutch off the flywheel and the clutch disc
>is worn down to the rivets.  How do you tell if the pressure 
>plate is worn out, as well as the throw out bearing?

I look at the mating surface where the throw out bearing meets the
pressure plate. Then I weigh the cost of replacing the entire
assembly, with the value of my time (in my "given" profession), then I 
replace the whole assembly! Pressure plate, throw out bearing, piolet
bearing.

(the following questions are left for someone who "realy" knows)

  Also
>how do I tell if the flywheel needs to be machined? How
>signifigant is a lighter flywheel(8 lbs. vs. 12)?  Is four
>pounds a big difference at the flywheel?
Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1966 911 cpe

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 95 17:25:10 EDT
From: "Bill Kan" <bkan@banmail.ml.com>
Subject: 951 Control Arms -- Failures without lowering susp

Hi all,

Are control arm failures on 951s common even if the car has not been lowered?  
A local dealer, who decided to give me a free check up while the car was in 
the shop,  informed me that my 1988 951 has a loose control arm on the driver 
side.  A second opinion from a reputable independent shop (where my car is 
usually serviced) confirmed the diagnosis.  Both tell me that it is time for a 
replacement.  

What troubles me is that the car has only 35,000 miles and has been tracked 
only once.  Also, the control arm is loose only on the driver side.  The 
passenger side control arm is fine.  My regular mechanic also noted that 
*recently* he has had to replace  the *driver side * control arms of several 
other 951s, all of which were not lowered!!  He hasn't seen much on the 
passenger side control arm.  So much for all the attention that have been 
devoted to 944/951 track cars that have been lowered.

Have any of you experienced similar failures (defects?)?  I certainly didn't 
believe it when I first heard it from the dealer.  Given the confirmation and 
the other incidents, I would suggest that folks check their control arms even 
if the car has not been lowered.

Hopefully, this is not widespread so there's is no cause for alarm.  

I will be communicating with PCNA to explore this issue.


Cheers,

Bill Kan
1988 951
internet:  bkan@banmail.ml.com

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 17:26:57 -0400
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: Potomac Region Club Race 

Sean,

The Potomac Region Club Race will use the standard Club Race format which is
2 open practice sessions for each run group (there will be 4 run groups of
approximately 25 cars each) followed by a third session Friday afternoon
consisting of practice starts and fun races for each group.  Saturdays
itinerary will be one warm-up session, one qualifying session and one feature
race for each group.
There is a cookout at the track Friday night, but I don't know details such
as cost or how to get tickets.  I would assume you could get tickets for the
dinner at the track Friday by seeing someone in registration.
There is a rumor floating around that there is going to be a "bragging
rights" showdown between Nick Ventura and Martin Snow at this event.  The
Chief Steward for this event (moi) finds this interesting and will paying
extra attention to the conduct of both drivers.
Cars will be going out on track at 9:30 Friday and 9:00 Saturday.
If you want to be even more involved, check with registration when you arrive
and I'm sure they could even find a worker spot for you.  It's a lot more fun
when you are directly involved in the event and Potomac Region is putting
this event on with an all volunteer crew.
If you come, look me up and say hello.  I will be in the tower while cars are
on the track but will be out and about at other times during the weekend.

Regards,

Pat Moyle (Chief Steward, Summit Point PCA Club Race)
(pm9146@aol.com)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 95 10:14:17 PDT
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert H. Albrecht)
Subject: T Top noises

In response to the following message.  After 5 relatively silent years, my
Targa top started making noise (a low frequency squeek).  I tried lubing the
indexing pins with silicone spray.  The noise became worse, TERRIBLE!  I
wouldn't consider driving with the top on, it was so bad.  Next I tried
cleaning the pins.  I used the same SEM vinyl cleaner I had bought to prep a
headliner re-paint.  Be careful with this stuff, as it is supposed to soften
the vinyl a bit.  Anyway, I just used on the plastic pin covers, and in the
pin sockets.  Instant silence!  :)  FWIW

I had recently treated the vinyl on the top.  Possibly some of the vinyl
dressing found it's way to the indexing pins and caused the squeek.
Cleaning them well certainly solved the problem.

Bob

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 19:10:42 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: 951 Control Arms -- Failures without lowering susp ension

Bill,

You said:
>Are control arm failures on 951s common even if the car has not been
lowered?  
>A local dealer, who decided to give me a free check up while the car was in 
>the shop,  informed me that my 1988 951 has a loose control arm on the
driver 
>side.  A second opinion from a reputable independent shop (where my car is 
>usually serviced) confirmed the diagnosis.  Both tell me that it is time
>for a replacement.  

The problem with lowered, track driven, 951's has been the ball joint stud
breaking in half catastrophically, and the suspension collapsing as a result,
usually at a bad place on a racetrack.  Ball joints can still wear out and
get loose.  Two ENTIRELY separate issues.  I've had a ball joint wear out on
our 951.  Got a rebuilt one from an advertiser in Panorama.  Some ball joints
just wear out early.  Happens on American cars, and happens on Porsches.

Jon Lowe
944T Escort Series car


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 95 16:30:10 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Bargain 911 Update


For those who are interested, here's where I'm at with the $1250 
(I still can't believe it!) '72 911T Coupe that I bought a few 
months ago for restoration/rebuilding.

The engine's out, apart and cleaned up.  Found only two 
problems, both minor.  One rod bearing had spun, but the 
crank journal looks fine and measurements show it is right on 
spec.  I will polish the crank and resize the guilty rod.  I've been 
told that once a bearing has spun, even if the rod big end looks 
and measures fine, and mine does, one should still refinish the 
rod to provide a good grip on the new bearing.  The second 
problem is that the top piston ring groove is worn and is now 
out of spec by a few thousandths, i.e., the side clearance exceeds 
the 0.004" spec.  On the previous 911 I did, where the top 
groove had worn to a few thousandths wider than spec, I 
simply used US standard 1/16" rings instead of 1.5 mm Porsche 
rings.  They are 0.0035" thicker, and accommodate that much 
wear.  In the present case the wear is greater and 1/16" isn't 
thick enough.  I also think the ring groove is so worn it should 
be squared up, so I'm having it grooved for a standard 5/64" 
ring which is 0.078" thick.  I don't have the bill yet, but a new 
piston/cylinder set is about $1500, and I think this will wind up 
costing less than $100.  Anyone ever followed this route instead 
of getting a whole new p/c set?

Heads are at German Precision getting a valve job.  

Transmission is cleaned up, and as far as I can tell is fine.  When 
I bought the car it was stuck in one gear, 1st or 2nd.  It looks to 
me like the previous owner must have forced the stick so hard 
that he managed to pop the shift selector lever out of it's proper 
position.  Now back in place it shifts through all gears just 
perfectly.  It's still possible that one of the selector rod detents is 
out of place.  I still have to check that.

I discovered that the car is equipped with alloy 'S' calipers in 
front, as well as Koni adjustables that seem OK.  Nice surprise.

Stay tuned.

 -Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa
'72 911T Coupe

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 17:06:50 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)

>Yesterday while pulling out of the parking lot, I heard a popping noise

>has dropped down almost to the ground, and the right rear has dropped a

>collapsed while I am doing a high speed corner !

Michael,

Don't take this the wrong way, but the only time I have heard of Porsche
suspensions doing something like this is when the owner either abused the
suspension or did not properly maintain the suspension. This would include
regular inspections just to verify everything is as it should be.

I know I would not take any car around a high speed corner unless I knew
the suspension was in proper condition.

Let us know what broke when you find out....

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 95 10:56:21 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re: 912 engine woes/question


Michael-

>Could this be the result of its dormancy (i.e., rusty rings...

Sure could.  Depends on how it was preparted for storage and where
it was stored.

But I wonder.  Did you first warm the car to operating temperature before
checking the compression?  Or did you check a cold engine?

There can be a **huge** difference between warm and cold
tests.  The one that's meaningful is the one that's done
on a warm engine.  I hope you checked yours cold.  It still
might be OK!

 -Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 11:53:27 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 944 Clutch

Darren,

Your rubber centre has gone to its great reward.  The difficulty in gear 
selection is because bits of it have lodged in places which inhibit
the normal motion of the clutch bits.

The clunking you feel is because of mechanical stops in the friction
disk centre.  They are sort of like big, loose splines which back up
the rubber centre.  The nice thing about them is that if the rubber
centre goes, you still have a car which can be driven -- gently --
home or to the shop. ( However, I've seen an example where someone
drove the car for an extended period on the stops, they failed, and
s/he was stranded.)

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 14:27:34 -0500
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Re: 911 Flywheel

(warning non-tech answer follows)
>I just took my clutch off the flywheel and the clutch disc
>is worn down to the rivets.  How do you tell if the pressure 
>plate is worn out, as well as the throw out bearing?

I look at the mating surface where the throw out bearing meets the
pressure plate. Then I weigh the cost of replacing the entire
assembly, with the value of my time (in my "given" profession), then I 
replace the whole assembly! Pressure plate, throw out bearing, piolet
bearing.

(the following questions are left for someone who "realy" knows)

  Also
>how do I tell if the flywheel needs to be machined? How
>signifigant is a lighter flywheel(8 lbs. vs. 12)?  Is four
>pounds a big difference at the flywheel?
Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1966 911 cpe

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 14:28:49 -0500
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Re: 914 suspension question

>Oat 
>Performance, but to replace the shocks (Koni's) would put this over 
>$1000, which is far more than I can spend.  Should I just replace the 
>springs and go from ther or get a better deal elsewhere on decent shocks, 
>I'd like to try my hand at autocrossing soon!  THanks in advance!  Rick

1st of all you should do some shopping. I use RD Enterprises (no affiliation)
for shocks and springs. 2nd of all at the very least while you have the rear
assembly apart put in shocks with those new springs. If the OEM springs are
on the car now, you need a spring compreser to do the job. It's NO FUN and 
dangerous. The replacements I have seen (since I was told OEM is NLA) need 
no compressing to install. Be carefull with the old springs, spring jobs 
give me nightmares. Have fun!

Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1966 911 cpe

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 08:13:18 -0700
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Mike Willis)
Subject: Re: 911 Flywheel

The standard practice is replace the clutch as a set, disk pressure plate.
Always replace the throw out bear any time you have taken the clutch off.
Just cheap insurance. What does it cost to R&R an eng,trans now. $500 +++.

For a street car I don't recomend any flywhell lightening. It makes that car
harder to drive in traffic. Will have more tnedancy to stall as you take off. 

I don't even have a light. fly. in my autox car. just didn't want it as the
car is also used on the street.

mike

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 12:42:47 -0800 (PDT)
From: John Wright <jpw@reebok.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Targa Bar removal

>Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 13:37:21 +1000
>From: dhamilto@ozemail.com.au (David Hamilton-Matthews)
>Subject: Targa Chrome Trim

>In preperation for paint I would like to remove the Stainless Steel 
>Trim/Capping that extends over the outside of the Targa Bar and bears the 
>"Targa" script. I have removed the 6 billion or so self tapping screws 
>from under the interior lining and the black strip of trim that covers 
>the Trim/Capping along the rear windshield. 

>From my reading it looks like you've removed the self tapping screws from the
leading edge.

You're almost there.

There are two 10MM nuts under each quarter panel that you'll need to
remove.

Then the targa bar covering can be lifted up off the car.

On the 72 the oil tank must be removed/dropped down to get to the right 
side nuts.  

The tank is clamped on with one metal strap.

BTW, when it is time to re-install it, get some help to guide
the covering into position. 

This will lower your risk of chipping your new paint.

John Wright   jpw@sr.hp.com

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 09:40:38 -0700

Subject: DME chip?


Automotion/Weltmeister is looking for a car like mine (88 944S, Manual) to
finish up their power chip program.

Normally I would avoid the whole DME chip concept on general principal, being
of the opinion that there is too much mechanical variation among different
cars for them to be of much use.

However, the concept of using my actual car to base the DME profile on is
intriguing.

I've already spoken to them and they say they need the car for 2-3 days.
They use Dynan Engineering (a BMW shop, I believe?) to do their chips.
They stick on their own wheels/tires so mine won't get torn up on the dyno.

So, unless someone out there can talk me out of this I'm going to do it.

Besides, it will be cool to have a full 500 rpm increment torque/HP
graph before and after the chip (which they said I will get).

Any reason I'm going to regret letting them torture my car?  Since the 944S
has knock sensors I don't think they can actually damage the engine by
advancing the timing too much?

Thanks much.

Dennis Mitsch (dem@best.com)

74 914 2.0 Special Edition


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 95 11:04:20 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re: 911 Flywheel


Mike-

Check both the flywheel and pressure plates for signs
of small cracks on the face.  Replacement/machiningh is
in order if there are any.  Also, check the flywheel to
see how much of it is worn away by the clutch disc.  If
you can see/feel a ridge on the flywheel you ought to
have it resurface to better accomodate the new disc.
Machining a flywheel is inexpensive, especially
compared to the high price of Sachs pressure plates and
discs.

If the throw out bearing turns smoothly with no grinding
or rough sounds, it's OK.  A lot of people routinely replace a
throw out bearing when the clutch is done, just to be on
the safe side.  For lots of cars a TO bearing is $15, in
which case it makes sense.  For a 911 it's $100 which to
my way of thinking warrants rethinking popular wisdom.

If your disc is down to the rivets, I'd bet your pressure
plate is worn and that your flywheel needs resurfacing.
In fact, if any rivets became exposed, they would have scored
the flywheel/pressure plat and that would definitely mean
machining and replacing.

 -Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu

have only replaced my passenger side one, though.

To make 'em last longer, avoid those potholes and other annoyances.  Not
much else you can do.

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 10:15:52 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re: "Big Brake" question

	My understanding, being the one who asked about big brake upgrades for 
a 911S, is that the major benefits are twofold:

	1. Increase in braking power, which is only of value if you are short 
on the ability to apply friction, your point on being able to lock the wheels. 

	2. Increased heat sink capacity and heat radiation capacity. The 
larger calipers and rotors can absorb more heat without doing nasty stuff like 
boiling fluid and vaporizing pads and thus retain their capability for 
stopping. Porsche did a test between a C2 and an Acura NSX a couple of years 
ago. Both cars are very similar in horsepower and weight. teat was to 
accellerate to high speed (220 kmh or so) and then decelerate at maximum rate. 
By the 8th iteration, the Acura's brakes pads were burning, and it went past 
the stopped C2 at 80 kmh as its brakes were essentially completely faded. 
Brake pedal effort increase for the C2 was minimal while the NSX's pedal 
effort was very high with little effect as the brakes were not functioning at 
all. Porsche attributed this to heat sink and the open bridge caliper design, 
vented and cross drilled rotors all contributing to radiating the heat far 
faster than the NSX could.

My logic for upgrading is 50% to gain the benefits of 1 and 2, especially if I 
go back to Germany where you definitely eat brakes, the other 50% is pure 
vanity as I love the lookd of those shoebox sized calipers peaking out of my 
17 inch rims!! The power brake upgrade is only to make the larger calipers 
work as the manual master cylinder can't move enough fluid to fill all those 
pots....

Sorry for the longish note... I tend to wax lyrical from time to time


Dennis Kalma

'75 911S with Kremer 3.2 and deep considerations for bigger brakes

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 14:07:21 -0400
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: 84-85 Carerra questions

Thom,

There are two spring assists on the 84-85 Carerras.  The first is a large
coil spring on the clutch pedal itself which was first used in 1974.  The PN
is ( I think) 911.423.305.06.  It is a pain in the keister to replace, but
can be done in the car.  Save up an adequate cache of 4 (or more) letter
words and go for it.
The second is referred to as the "over-center" or "horseshoe" spring and is
located on the bottom of the gearbox above the clutch arm.  The PN is
930.116.064.06 and is not that difficult to replace.  Once you are under the
car and see it, it is very straight forward.  There is also a third spring
going from the clutch arm to the side of the gearbox, but it has little
effect on clutch feel.  It is a small coil spring and it's job is to hold the
short clutch arm away from the long clutch arm's adjusting bolt, allowing you
to see and feel the freeplay between the two arms.  (Should be 1-2mm) PN is
915.116.614.02.
If you disassemble any of the rear clutch linkage, you will need to readjust
everything.  first, connect the cable to the long arm and adjust it with the
nuts on the bowden tube so there is no slop in the cable.  Tighten it so the
cable just starts to pull the arm off the stop, then back it off until the
arm just touches.  Then adjust the freeplay with the adjusting bolt so there
is 1-2mm between the end of the adjusting bolt and the short arm.  This makes
a big difference in the clutch pedal feel.
Also while you have the floorboard out to check the spring on the pedal
assembly, check the clevis pin bushing on the end of the clutch crosshaft,
where the cable connects to it.  If it is gone, the clevis pin has probably
started to wear the hole oblong and you will need a new crosshaft, bushing,
and clevis pin.  To do this you must remove the pedal assembly.

Hope this helps.

Pat Moyle
(pm9146@aol.com)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 13:08:38 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: Splitfires. Its not the SPARK!!!!

illd/mail/postponed-mail/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

On Tue, 13 Jun 1995 ANDRUC00@SNYBUFAA.CS.SNYBUF.EDU wrote:

> did change was idle. The splits' ran with a smoother idle and seemed to last
> a hell of a lot longer in my nissan which had tended to run rich. I haven't 
> came up with a zero difference in accelleration and in mileage.

The following is a report on Day 3 of my use of SplitFires... the engine 
runs an incredible amount smoother compared to before, although, it has 
this tendency to go boomp-boomp when you back off the gas on an 
upgrade... This was there before, it isn't like a major thing, as it 
happens only 1 out of every 20 times, but it is more noticeable now. The 
beast appears to have slightly better midrange acceleration (30-50 mph), 
although, as I said, I have no numbers, so this is not a Slick 50 
'independent' study or anything... I haven't a clue about the time they 
last, as this is only day 3, although they do come with a 2 year (I 
believe, I'll get the warranty out tonight) warranty...

Obviously, I don't TRULY believe they'll have any major impact for 
changing such a piddly piece of engine can't have that type of effect... 
There are no good bolt on, or pour-in hot rodding tricks (well... octane 
booster seems to make a tank of gas last a little bit longer, but the car 
doesn't go any faster)... I do believe that the split fires will probably 
last longer, and due to the fact that this is an early GM inverse layout, 
changing spark plugs can take a great deal of time and effort (in the 
back 3)...

Either way, the car that these are being used on has had two major 
frontal collisions, runs relatively well for a 10 year old car, etc... 
and so is a good guinea pig for all sorts of things before they make 
their way to better cars... Luckily, I must say, that nothing has ever 
made the car any worse... but nothing has made this car a performer either...

In conclusion: Split Fire's (or as Stan prefers: ShitFire) not worth the 
money... They are nice to have, for there is more electrode area, but 
they don't gain anything... After all, you're not really changing the 
system, you're just modifying a little component of it...
 -Derek


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 22:47:57 -0400
From: SLR944@aol.com
Subject: re;detachable roof bag

Most 944's came with a vinyl bag to store the sunroof in, but sometime in the
late 80's they stopped supplying them, my 90 S2 does not have one, yet my '84
did.  Best bet is to contact George and see what he has in stock, Porsche
prices are absurd over $100 for a vinyl bag!!!!!!!

                         Steve '90 944S2

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 22:36:07 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: "Big Brake" question

Hi Barry,

As your speed increases, it becomes harder to lock the brakes.  You have
to overcome the energy of the rotating wheel, which goes up as the square
of the speed (I think!).  So despite being able to lock 'em up at 50 MPH,
it's a different story when going 150 MPH at the end of your favourite
track's long straight.

The bigger rotors have the advantage of greater heat sink mass.  That
means lower temperature rise for a given amount of sunk energy, and so
lessened problems with overheating of the pads, rotors, and fluid.

Larger pad area means larger pad volume and similar heat-sink grooviness.
It also means more pad area to do work.

A Cool Brake is pretty much essential, IMHO, for any 944 whose driver is
starting to learn go fast.  (Except George B.)  It will not, however, make
your 944/S brake like a 951/944S2.  I wrestled for years with keeping the
brakes of my 944S happy, and with marginal success: Cool Brake, high temp
fluid, Cool Carbon pads, rebuild/rebuild/rebuild, feh.  Even when they
didn't overheat, they simply would not slow the car enough.  At
Bridgehampton, that ended up meaning I had to coast a bit between Turn
7 and Turn 8, 'cause there just wasn't room to straighten out and slow
down enough (twice...)  Temperature paint showed pad edge temps above
1100 F, rotors above 1000 F.

The larger pad area and fixed-calliper design of the 951/944S2 brakes is
a night-and-day difference from the floating-calliper, single-piston 944
(928) brakes.  I upgraded to them, and now brake much later and have zero
fade.  Phenomenal.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 13:08:38 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: Splitfires. Its not the SPARK!!!!

There are no good bolt on, or pour-in hot rodding tricks (well... octane 
booster seems to make a tank of gas last a little bit longer, but the car 
doesn't go any faster)... I do believe that the split fires will probably 
last longer, and due to the fact that this is an early GM inverse layout, 
changing spark plugs can take a great deal of time and effort (in the 
back 3)...

Either way, the car that these are being used on has had two major 
frontal collisions, runs relatively well for a 10 year old car, etc... 
and so is a good guinea pig for all sorts of things before they make 
their way to better cars... Luckily, I must say, that nothing has ever 
made the car any worse... but nothing has made this car a performer either...

In conclusion: Split Fire's (or as Stan prefers: ShitFire) not worth the 
money... They are nice to have, for there is more electrode area, but 
they don't gain anything... After all, you're not really changing the 
system, you're just modifying a little component of it...
 -Derek

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 21:58:45 -0600
From: tgilton@micron.net (Terry Gilton)
Subject: Excellence - 911S article


I quote from the 6/95 _Excellence_ article, "Faster Than Schnell" by David
Colman: "But the euphoric good times came to an end in 1974. That was the
year all 911's (911, 911S and 911 Carrera), regardless of model
designation, served up exactly the same amount of horsepower. ... How dare
the company build a 2.7 liter, so-called S, that put out exactly the same
horsepower as the garden variety 911?"

Okay, am I missing something here? I have one of these '74 models, and the
spec book and Bruce Anderson's book point out that the "garden variety" '74
911 had engine type # 911/92 and was good for 150 DIN HP with 175 lb-ft of
torque, whilst the 911S and Carrera had type # 911/93 with 175 and 187.
While I know engineers that would claim 175 was "exactly" the same as 150
(what's 20% or so among friends?), I certainly would not. Too, while the
2.4 liter is a great engine (and the 2.7 has more than its share of
problems), the stock 2.7 (even "garden variety") has more low end torque
than the 2.4 S engine. And, sure, the change to the CIS and the milder cam
dropped the HP (190 to 175), the bigger bore brought the torque up (158 to
187). AND you don't have to wait 'til 6500 revs to get at the HP peak on
the 74 engine either (it comes at something like 5800). Of course, the red
line on the 2.4 S was quite a bit higher than the 2.7.

I am not saying the 2.4S was bad (it most certainly was GOOD), I am just
trying to salvage some measure of dignity for those of us unfortunate
enough to have a '74 model. Though the author rags on the rubber bellows
crash bumpers, I actually like my '74...


******************************************************************************
* Terry L. Gilton
* Boise, Idaho
* tgilton@micron.net
******************************************************************************

hydralics in to make it a hydralic  1.8. ( I know Stan, you don't like 
the idea, but I am making this a later model engine )  I will get a 
hydralic cam, lifters too.  My final question is compression- The 1.8 was 
really low (7 something) what would be best way to increase compression?  
I am also going to hemi-cut the heads, to make the unleaded gasoline a 
bit more digestable.
Thanks for all your help! 
Mark Gillis, Albuq.

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 00:36:21 -0600
From: qmoolla@gpu3.srv.ualberta.ca (Qassim Moolla)
Subject: Hirschmann power antennas

Paul,
The little ring with the two slots is the piece you need to unscrew.  It's 
called an "escutcheon" and you will need something like a set of snap ring 
pliers to undo it. Directly below it, is a spacer and below that, is a 
rubber gasket.  Once you undo the escutcheon, the antenna can be removed 
from the bottom of the fenderwell. Make sure you dont just drop it.  You can 
prevent this by holding the antenna mast.  I am assuming that you know how 
to undo the unit by removing the screw that secures the "L" shaped bracket 
inside the fenderwell.  I also found that the leads going into the unit are 
very short and had to unscrew the plastic grommet and rubber seal first, 
then removed  the plate cover off the unit to release the wires from within 
the unit before the unit can come off the car. (the antenna wire also needs 
to be unscrewed)  BTW if you are only replacing the mast you do not have to 
take the unit off the car.  All you do is to unscrew the escutcheon, have 
someone turn on the radio and while the mast is extending pull it out of the 
unit.  To reinstall, you thread the plastic mast lead back into the unit as 
far as it will go and then have someone turn off the radio,      thereby 
retracting the mast back into the unit. 
Voila! you are done.
  
Ike Moolla
1984 944
1987 944S
qmoolla@pop.srv.ualberta.ca


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 00:53:49 -0600
From: qmoolla@gpu3.srv.ualberta.ca (Qassim Moolla)
Subject: 944 Wet Distributor

The little hole is indeed an inspection port to view the TDC marks on the 
camshaft sprocket and should be closed off with a 75cent rubber grommet. I 
however don't think that your moisture problem is due to this hole being 
open.  IMHO I think you should check the distributor cap for hairline cracks 
and also the condition of the gasket between the cap and the camshaft cover.
Ike Moolla
1984 944
1987 944S
qmoolla@pop.srv.ualberta.ca

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 12:58:08 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 944 Wet Distributor

The most likely cause is a water pump leak

what is happening is you are dribbling a small quantity of water on to 
the cam belt, this is being spun off when you try to start the engine.
Try tasting the water - if you have any anti-freeze, the water tastes 
revoltingly sweet.

There should be a plastic disk behind the rotor arm to stop muck getting 
into the dist cap, if this is missing then the water gets into the cap.

The plastic disk get left off, because often the rotor arm cannot be 
removed from the cam shaft, so you cannot remove the cam belt. Crook 
mechanics break the disk, remove the belt ...

I am surprised that the small amount of water that you get in the dist 
cap is sufficient to stop the car firing. This sounds like the last 
straw, ie your motor has so many minor problems that the bit of moisture 
is just too much.

When were the plugs, air filter etc last changed, are you burning oil?
is the ignition timing correct?

Hope you find your problem

Pete
+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
|          3rd Floor            |
|          Lion House           |
|          23 - 31 St Mathew St |
|          Ipswich              |
|          IP1 3EL              |

| Phone  : 01473 293715         |

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 08:21:50 -0500
From: ricp@ids.net (james stephenson)
Subject: Carrera Engine Failure?

A friend of mine has an 1986 Carrera engine with a custom chip and a 915
transmission. At a track event, he overaccelerated going into corner, the
rev limiter came on at 7,300 revs to cut the engine off, and then a few
seconds later after getting back on straight, he stepped on gas but engine
was low on power. It turned out, valve was bent and valve guide was in pieces.
How can that happen? Valves should not get bent from the gas pedel when the
rev limiter is working  - valves should only be bent by misshifting into too
low a gear ( ie 5th to 2nd) and where it causes engine revs to go above
8,000 rpm. Anybody got an idea? Could custom chip cause this problem ( even
though the rev limiter did come on) ? Could valve be weak from past and then
later bend from acceleration?
James Stephenson
Rhode Island Capital Partners
115 Brisas, East Greenwich, RI 02818
Phone 401-885-4357 Fax 401-884-2255
E-Mail address: ricp@ids.net

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 95 8:43:44 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; Panteras

> I know its not Porsche related beyond rear engine RWD but
>I'm looking at a '71 Pantera.
>Any of you guys owned one or know where to go for
>info on what to look for when buying?

> -bob

    Unmodified Panteras are hard to find. Most owners are heavy on making them
 look like a Countach (complete with flares and wing) but a stock Pantera is
 a beautiful car (tip your hat to Tom Tjarda).
    Call Hall Pantera in Bellflower, CA for tips and a catalog.  Most prices
 for Pantera parts from Hall are actually very fair, and a huge amount of
 aftermarket product exists to spend on the car.
    Panteras are famous for rust (the kind that goes to the core) and
 overheating. There are a couple dozen "solutions" for the overheating
 problem...its just a matter of money. I nearly bought a '74 L, but at the  
 time was driving a 928; if you've driven either, you'd have to agree the  
 Pantera is  a world behind as a driver, and (despite the domestic V8) not a
 dime cheaper to really drive than a Ferrari (a 308 will cost you just a bit
 more anyways).  The Cleveland motor is famous for making power, but is groggy
 at lower throttle and is NOT famous for its reliability (poor crank oiling).

    As with any car this old, maintenance and care means everything. Avoid an
 abused car.

       Lee A  Pantera-motored '70 Mustanng :)
              '70 Detomaso Mangusta (brothers car)
              sn 15346 (79 308 gt4) on jackstands...

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 9:20:39 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: 951 Control Arms -- Failures without lowering susp

Ball joints fail eventually on all cars and have to be replaced.
This isn't a big deal on most cars, but because you have to replace
the whole control arm on late model 944s it is a very expensive fix.
35k miles seems a bit low - you may be able to get PCNA to replace
the arm at their expense.  If not, there is a place in Texas that 
sales rebuilt control arms (ie new ball joints).  I got one earlier
this spring for $225 + shipping.  This is a relatively simple part
to replace if you feel like doing the work yourself.

Btw, my passenger side failed.  I looked around for a used one for
a bit and could find no passenger side arms, only drivers side:)

Ross Stites
'87 951

release.  I have had an assistant try to push/pull on the lid while I
engaged the solenoid, but to no avail.

the trunk to diagnose the problem and can't do it because of the
problem!  The only way in I can think of is from underneath(the 
circular access cover).

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 11:13:31 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: Ground (earth) Strap. 

On Tue, 13 Jun 1995 ECJACK@aol.com wrote:

> I have looked in and under engine compartment and haven't had any luck
> locating it.  Could the car function without one?  Any other suggestions re:
Well, there are three... One for the transmission... One for the engine 
and its various attachments... And one for the battery (or batteries as 
some cases may be) The one for the battery is in the front, attached to 
the battery and this is the one that generally creates the problems, for 
due to battery acid and other things, it usually unattaches itself and 
corrodes first... The other two are a little less convenient, so check 
the battery one first...
 -Derek


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 11:17:29 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: Slick 50

On Tue, 13 Jun 1995, Terry Gilton wrote:

> Is this Slick 50 stuff good for anything? Are their claims true?
Be forewarned, you have just sentenced yourself to a hell and misery like 
no other...
This discussion is currently going on on the VintagVW list as well... and 
the general consensus is that because DuPont (the originators of Teflon) 
have said that only a complex process will bond Teflon, it can't happen 
by using Slick 50... I say, even if you did go to the trouble, it would 
at best only stay on for 2.5 minutes
 -Derek

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 10:05:26 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: RE: Big Brakes


 exceeded.  Message probably in a routing loop.

- ---- message ----
Content-Type: Message/rfc822
Content-Description: RFC822

 My understanding, being the one who asked about big brake upgrades for 
a 911S, is that the major benefits are twofold:

 1. Increase in braking power, which is only of value if you are short 
on the ability to apply friction, your point on being able to lock the wheels. 

 2. Increased heat sink capacity and heat radiation capacity. The 
larger calipers and rotors can absorb more heat without doing nasty stuff like 
boiling fluid and vaporizing pads and thus retain their capability for 
stopping. Porsche did a test between a C2 and an Acura NSX a couple of years 
ago. Both cars are very similar in horsepower and weight. teat was to 
accellerate to high speed (220 kmh or so) and then decelerate at maximum rate. 
By the 8th iteration, the Acura's brakes pads were burning, and it went past 
the stopped C2 at 80 kmh as its brakes were essentially completely faded. 
Brake pedal effort increase for the C2 was minimal while the NSX's pedal 
effort was very high with little effect as the brakes were not functioning at 
all. Porsche attributed this to heat sink and the open bridge caliper design, 
vented and cross drilled rotors all contributing to radiating the heat far 
faster than the NSX could.

My logic for upgrading is 50% to gain the benefits of 1 and 2, especially if I 
go back to Germany where you definitely eat brakes, the other 50% is pure 
vanity as I love the lookd of those shoebox sized calipers peaking out of my 
17 inch rims!! The power brake upgrade is only to make the larger calipers 
work as the manual master cylinder can't move enough fluid to fill all those 
pots....

Sorry for the longish note... I tend to wax lyrical from time to time


Dennis Kalma

'75 911S with Kremer 3.2 and deep considerations for bigger brakes

- ---- message ------



<---- End Included Message ---->

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 11:12:16 -0500 (CDT)
From: THOXNER@ualr.edu
Subject: Trying to Sell a 356B

I have looked at a 914-6 and would really like to buy it. Unfortunately, I have
too many cars at the present time. I would like to sell my 1961 356B Karmann
Hardtop. Karmann hardtops are rare but not valuable. This car is in good shape
(certainly not concours). It is yellow with black interior. The interior and
paint were redone about 7 years ago. The engine was rebuilt at that time (it
is a Super) with NPR big bore barrels. The engine is stock otherwise. The 
transmission was rebuilt at that time (with new synchros and bearings). The
car looks good, but it has a lot of bondo in it. It has been converted to a 12
volt system and has the 5 1/2 inch brazilian chrome wheels. It has been driven
about 10,000 miles since it was redone ( I have 4 other cars, so it doesn't get
driven much). I am asking $8,000. The car is located in Arkansas (as I am).
I am off Porschephiles right now, so if you are interested, please e-mail me
at "THOXNER@UALR.EDU". I hope to be back on Porschphiles soon. Thanks.
Tom Oxner          THOXNER@UALR.EDU"

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 11:08:52 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: MagneticTrack Numbers

>FWIW, I've never seen magnetic numbers (or advertising logos) come
>off.

        I have!  We had to keep picking up a Yokohama logo up at
Hamilton.  Every run, at the end of the straight (a long one for
an autocross!) the magnetic logo would come flying off...  I've
also seen several go flying up at Redwood, where speeds are gen-
erally much lower.
        Most people put some tape on the leading and trailing
edges of the numbers and logos.  This seems to keep them from
lifting off.

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 10:12:07 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re: CV Joint Question

I think that you are ok as long as you are referring to the sheet metal flange 
which slips over the actual joint. Mine were bent as well, from what I can 
tell the bending in my case was caused by some overzealous mechanic pulling on 
the shaft after it was disconnected from the transmission and the shaft itself 
pulled the sheet metal out of round. While it didn't seem to be an issue, I 
ended up replacing mine just because the old ones were a bit rusty and I am 
overly fussy.....

Dennis Kalma

'75 911S with Kremer 3.2

Date:          Wed, 14 Jun 1995 09:37:52 +0000
From: "Dirk Bergstrom" <krid@unix.sri.com>
Subject:       Lightened Flywheel

To All and Sundry:

Mike Willis' comment on lightened flywheels rang a bell with me.  My 
'75 911S tends to bog when I let out the clutch at a light, even if I 
have the revs up.  Once it gets moving things are fine, but the first 
ten feet are usually kinda slow.  Now I'm wondering if perhaps my 
car has a lightened flywheel.

You see, the P.O. lost the documentation on the engine rebuild, and 
he couldn't remember all the details.  I've been trying to piece 
together what all was done, but I fear I'll never know.

So, can anyone tell me what the advantages, disadvantages, and 
symptoms of a lightened flywheel are?  Whether or not I actually have 
one, I'm curious as to what they are good for (I can guess, but I'd 
rather ask).

Thanks for your (collective) wisdom,

Dirk Bergstrom
'75 911S, Brick Shithouse Red, strong 2.7 w/mystery componentry...
S.F. Bay Area

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 95 12:56:39 EST
From: mark_salvetti@ABBSMTP.abb.com (mark salvetti)
Subject: Re: 911 Head Studs

          In the past year, I remember reading a Bruce Anderson
          comment (probably in Excellence) that compared Dilivars to
          Raceware studs.

          He said that he is aware of more and more situations where
          real Dilivars were actually breaking when being torqued
          during reassembly, apparently by competent mechanics.  I'm
          pretty sure he went on to recommend the Raceware studs
          instead of Dilivars.

          Mark_Salvetti@abbsmtp.abb.com
          1979 911SC Targa

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 95 09:52:00 PDT
From: "Coshow, Jim  (N-ACCT/PDX)" <jim.coshow@mccaw.com>
Subject: Excellence - 911S article


""I am not saying the 2.4S was bad (it most certainly was GOOD), I am just
trying to salvage some measure of dignity for those of us unfortunate
enough to have a '74 model. Though the author rags on the rubber bellows
crash bumpers, I actually like my '74...""


It's wonderful to hear someone talk up a '74 with the often harangued  2.7. 
I have humbly driven a '74 911 for 6 years. I love it. If there is such a 
thing as an understated Porsche, this is it. To take it a step further, it's 
brown!

I bought this car with 125k miles and a fresh, properly rebuilt and updated 
engine in 1989. Since then it has been a daily driver everywhere I have 
lived, Portland, OR to Toronto, ONT. to Vancouver B.C. back to Portland OR. 
Only in Toronto, in the winter (heavy salt), did I resort to a beater to 
commute. It now has 185k and is running very strong. It has been from 
Northern Maine to the Florida Keys; from San Diego to the northern tip of 
Vancouver Island. It the last two summers alone I have logged 6,000 miles in 
road trips with many hours of triple digit speeds.

On top of all this commuting and road trip use, it is a notorious track car! 
I have driven it numerous times at Mosport and Shannonville Ontario, Watkins 
Glen NY, and probably 50+ times at Portland International Raceway. There is 
nothing more gratifying on a track then driving my light weight homely 
little 911 right past 944's, 911 SC's and even the occasional Carrera.  Now 
it is evolving into a PCA Club Racer and it's first event will be the 
Portland race August 13.

These cars are amazing, I doubt that I could ever be content driving 
anything less and I seldom see anything comparable.

Jim Coshow
'74 911 and pleased as could be.

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 95 09:31:59 PST
From: "RADSICKT" <radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil>
Subject: high-performance hype solution

 The more I hear about all these "performance parts/fluids/etc" the more it 
 seems that their performance claims can be verified by using one of three 
 techniques:
 
 (1) Gee Wiz Method
 ------------------
 
 Manufacturer makes some nifty claim and demonstrates it in an ad.  Everyone 
 goes "gee wiz"!  But their experiment has NO CONTROL GROUP to show what would 
 happen if their product was NOT used.
 
 -Engines running without oil because of an additive:  Hmmmm, do engines run 
 without oil even no additive was present?  They do.  Just as well as the ones 
 WITH the additive
 
 -Magic Spark plugs are inserted into an engine and instant horsepower gains are 
 measured.  Hmmm, what if a clean set of STANDARD plugs was installed?  For the 
 most part if the previous plugs were crummy, instant horsepower gains will 
 result.  (In my best David Spade imitation) It's called a TUNE-UP! Get one!
 
 (2) Gedankin (sp) Experiment
 ---------------------------
 
 Ahhhh, the things I learned in my Physics days.  Make a little mental 
 experiment by looking at the extremes.  If you are interested in the effects of 
 coolant flow (a discussion on the Brit Car list where it was asserted that 
 slower flowing coolant will stay in the radiator longer and thus cool the car 
 more) look at the extremes.  Coolant flows infinitesimally slow: cyl head heats 
 and boils, coolant in radiator cools off to ambient and just sits there.  Bad!  
 Coolant flows infinitely fast: water in rad and head are same temp. Good!
 
 -Filtercharging:  Hmmm, if I reduce the flow restriction, I get a bit more 
 horse power.  What if I totally eliminate the restriction?  Even MORE flow! 
 What if I totally block off the air?  No contaminates enter the engine.  AH!!! 
 I see!  There is a trade off between filtration and flow rate!
 
 (3) Why isn't the car Made that way! (thanks to STAN)
 ------------------------------------
 
 Self explanatory.  If car get 10 more HP and 15% better mileage with the 
 addition of a $10 part, why doesn't the car manufacturer use it?  Is it because 
 the "hype-rformance" part manufacturer is making so much money on the 
 aftermarket that he would rather not seel to a big company?  Uh... if you 
 believe that, look at corporate earnings or perhaps see if Slock-50 or 
 ShitFires stock is calculated into the Dow Jones average.
 
 Well, that's it for now. Caveat Emptor!
 
 (Porsche content:  914 heads to Bieker today! Finally!  Still can't get the 
 dang case apart though)
 
 -Tim
 radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 95 10:12:00 PDT
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: RE: MagneticTrack Numbers


Barry,

I've not had any personal experience with the magnetic numbers but have 
heard they hold on over 100mph.

Since I'm basically cheap, I printed my numbers out on a laser printer in 
the size and font I wanted, and used those as templates for white shelving 
paper (you know, inside your kitchen cabinets) that's semi-sticky.  As long 
as you wax your paint, these work great and don't cost much.  I have my kids 
help me cut them out :)

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu
73 911T Targa, almost naked in prep for new Gemini Blue Metallic

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 95 10:13:18 PDT
From: thatguy@uplex.net (Tim P. Heikell)
Subject: Re: MagneticTrack Numbers

>Hi All,
>
>I'm getting tired of using shoe polish.What is the general consensous on
>magnetic numbers for track use? I have a catalog from Solotime, and they have
>good price / selection on numbers. Will the numbers stay on the car at track
>speeds (over 100mph)? If not, what is better for a street car that needs to
>be driven to the track, have numbers applied, driven on the track (and have
>the numbers stay on), have the numbers removed, and then driven home?
>
>Thanks,
>Barry Lenoble
>BLenoble@aol.com
>89 944 Turbo, Alpine White (and shoe polish numbers)
>
>
>

Magnetic numbers are very sensitive to the thickness of the paint (and 
bondo) thickness. If the car has never been repainted magnetics are fine, if 
not you might want to look into static cling numbers on the inside of the 
rear window if your club doesn't have a size restriction that prohibits 
this. Up here in the Northwest a lot of people use static cling.

Tim

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 10:47:30 -0700 (PDT)
From: banders@netcom.com (Brad Anders)
Subject: Re: Lightened Flywheel

More on lightened flywheels. I've had no end of idle problems with my
914 which has a 2.0L and a "severely" lightened flywheel. I'm convinced
that when I go back to a stock flywheel my problems may be fixed. BTW,
I've had the FI and ignition worked on to no end to fix these problems,
but they still persist. And I too, have the transitional bog others have
noted. It does spin up nicely, though.
- --

* Brad Anders / Sunnyvale, CA *
*     banders@netcom.com      *

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 95 10:53:26 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  magnetic #'s

>> I'm going to need a set of numbers for a track car. Does anyone know of 
>> sources for the magnetic one and the sorta stick on plastic ones that adhere 
>> with some kind of surface tension?  Thanks, Ted


For this, another solution would be to mount the normal vinyl numbers
and letters (for classes) on a background.  Pegasus has white circles
for mounting numbers on in either magnetic, static cling or adhesive
application.  

I've been quite happy with the contact/shelf paper solution.  Remember
to wax the paint first, and then if you use a water bottle and spray a
fine mist over the area before applying the number, you can work the
air bubbles out and get the possitioning with a lot less work.

Pat
pat@ixi.saic.com

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 15:03:59 -0400
From: Fred Pack <fhp@unipress.com>
Subject: Numbers for Track

I go to the local cycle shop a few days before the event
and buy the numbers I need. They come in a plastic bag;
3 per bag for about $3.

These numbers are adhesive backed -- you apply them at the track and 
remove them when you leave. They look good, and are cheap.
