Date: Wed, 14 Jun 95 12:54:25 PDT
From: John Wright <jpw@hpsadlb.sr.hp.com>
Subject: RE: Chrome strips under Targa rear window

>Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 14:21:22 -0600
>From: mhatch@alphabusiness.com (Mark Hatch)
>Subject: Chrome strips under Targa rear window...
>
>When I took my Targa rear window out (73.5 T), the rear window was enclosed
>in that expensive piece of rubber weatherstripping. The rear window and
>aforemention rubber sat on a couple chrome strips. Under these chrome
>strips were thin pieces of rubber that provided sometype of weatherstriping
>between the chrome strips and the actual body.

>Is this the way things are suppose to be?

Yes.

There is a thin piece of rubber under the chrome strips.

I replaced my rear Targa window after a repaint, so I got some personal
experience.

The 72/73 parts book, which I have at home, has the part number.

It is a dealer only item.

>I just bought a full set of weatherstripping from International Merchantile
>(good company by the way, competitive prices and according to others on
>this list, provide high quality weatherstripping) and they don't carry or
>know anything about that weatherstripping below the chrome strip. They said
>that their catalogs don't show this piece (althought they have had calls
>before on this part before). I was told that the chrome strips are enclosed
>by the rear window weatherstripping that I was sold.

>What's the facts here?

>Do I need the chrome strips at all? (Mine have seen better days and I was
>going to buy some new ones).

I re-installed mine.

When it comes to manufactured items, I assume if the profit oriented company 
tooled up for a non-cosmetic part, produced it and installed it, then the 
part has a good functional reason for existing.

But I can't say for sure the chrome strips are needed.  

Possibly the rear window gasket shifts during driving and can wear
away the paint if the chrome strip isn't there.

You might consider re-chroming the strips, or getting better ones
from a salvage yard.


John Wright   jpw@sr.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 16:10:36 -0400
From: hultgren@neca.com (Lon or Debra Hultgren)
Subject: 944S Chipping experiment

Dennis --
Please post the results of your experiment, if you decide to go through with
it.  I installed the Autothority chip in my '87 944S after first checking
acceleration times in several gears.  The result was that my car was
actually slower in all gears at most revs except for the very, very bottom
of the revs.  Needless to say, I uninstalled the chip and sent it back to them.
Lon H.

Uhm, I don't mean to be rude, but this mailing list has the highest "signal
to noise" ratio of any mailing list or newsgroup I've ever seen. What do
expect this list to be anyway. An official "help-line"? This an open forum
for people to talk about the cars we love and technical issues that concern
them. We are -NOT- a corporate help-line or a proffesional on line
technical assistance program. We are 1200+ porsche owners who have a fairly
broad base of experience and would like to share that experience. Yes,
there are proffesionals on this list, but I don't expect them to respond to
each and every question as soon as it's posed. And secondly, I wouldn't
call it "worthless jabber". Just because the topic of someones mail doesn't
pertain to what you're interested in doesn't mean it's worthless. I play
with 914s, but I don't consider all of the 911 and water-pumper posts to be
worthless. There's still quite a lot of usefull info out there. 

Yes, there is a very large volume of mail that goes through this list, 1200
+ porsche folks with internet access tend to create a high volume of text
spewing accross the lines. But if you're not interested in it, don't read
it.

Ok, I've spewed enough for now, unka bart? some more green ones please...

P.S. I would like to say that I am always pleased to see profesional porsche
people on this list, but don't expect this to be entirely dry and technical
. It wouldn't be as much fun to read if it was. 

 -Josh

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 15:58:57 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: 951 Control Arms -- Failures without lowering susp

Kevin,

>How does this work?  The "cup" of the control arm ball joint is the
>control arm casting itself.  Does this place sleeve it in some way,
>or is the assumption that the cup is OK and all you need is to replace
>the rest of the bits?

I'm not 100% certain on this.  It appeared that they had cut the
seem of the weld, inserted the new ball joint, and rewelded the
control arm cup.  I hope that makes sense.  The name of the company
is European Dynamic Something-or-other (Engineering maybe?).  They
advertise in Pano and/or Excellence.  You might give them a call.

So far, I've put almost 10k miles on the new joint with no problems.
For a daily driver that sees an occasional auto-x I think it's a 
good solution.  For a car that sees a lot of track time I'd invest
in the FABCAR control arms or the control arms that Nathan Ulrich 
advertised a few days ago.

I'll be under the car sometime before the end of this weekend.  I'll
take a closer look at them then.  

Ross Stites
'87 951

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 14:33:10 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: Bra for 911

Dear Darryl,

This is the sort of thing that belongs in a FAQ--not an answer,
necessarily, but a summary of the debate.  The bra is an American
invention, and the factory types from Germany still don't see what we
see in them.  Some people still don't like them.  "I'd rather repaint
my hood every once in a while," I've been told.  Well, I wouldn't.

To make a long story short, a bra will help protect your painted front
end.  It's not perfect.  Especially on lowered cars, pieces of road
junk will collect between the bra and the front valence.  The question
is, whether the junk will do more harm if it is stationary or if it is
moving toward your hood and windshield.  I think the former. 

The caveats are, therefore:  take it off and clean the backing after a
trip.  Don't leave it on in the rain, especially if the car is
standing still.  Don't put it on paint that isn't fully cured.  And
(this will only apply if your car has been repainted with lacquer)
don't let bare vinyl rest on lacquer paint.  That's why the back is
flocked.  I once had a horror story with a vinyl piano cover on a
black lacquer Steinway--the exposed vinyl along the seams etched into
the lacquer and made funny scratch and hatch marks.  It took a while
before I realized what that was--thought it was my cat's doing.

Steve Gilbert

Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu
'75 911S, original paint

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 95 15:02:45 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 951 Control  Arms


Well,

The only explanation I can offer on only the left side being bad is thus,
consider which direction you turn on most freeway exits. It is to the right
in many cases. The cornering loads go to the outside of the car, the left 
front wheel in this case.  Some RX-7s have the rear floorpan 
sheetmetal get very distorted over time.

If the rear of your 924/944/968 is set to ride high for the bumper/crash
test requirements, you will throw even more force against the control arm.

Set the car to level height, get a good alignment. Put some (1/2 to 3/4
degree negative) camber in the front. you will have much better stick in 
the front with somewhat lower forces.

And above all, avoid roads that have bad pot holes. That does a lot more 
damage than you think to ALL cars. Some RX-7s have the rear floorpan 
sheetmetal get very distorted over time after being continually driven over
pot holed roads.

As Kevin Gross and others have pointed out, these are ball joints working 
loose rather than catstrophically.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 95 14:36:00 PDT
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: Gas pedal warning to 911 and 914 owners


Hello 'philes,

A while back I was driving a '76 911S with a 3.2L euro-spec
engine (231 HP).  Fast, fun car....about as fast as my 914....
and even more scary when the gas pedal jammed against
the tunnel as I was approaching a corner!!!

The stamped metal "pivot" piece of the pedal assembly
suffered from a broken factory weld and moved sideways
to jam itself against the tunnel - holding the throttle wide
open.

I've heard of this happening on another local 911.

During the replacement of my throttle cable on my 914,
my mechanic discovered a similar broken weld between
the stamped metal "pivot" piece and the metal pin.  I fixed
this last Saturday by removing the part and re-welding it.

Next time you have a chance, check out your gas pedal
and associated lever assembly for side-to-side movement.
You shouldn't find much play....if you do, it could be a
weak gas pedal itself, similar broken weld problem as I
had, or worn bushings.  Whatever it is, have it properly
fixed ASAP.....I was very lucky I didn't go flying into
something!!!

Take care,

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>
'75 914-6  3.0 SC

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 09:09:11 -0500
From: Eric Yuzon <YUZONE@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>
Subject:  what to buy? -Reply

A 911 is very different from a 944.  

911: An early 911will be expensive if it is in good shape or even if it is in
restorable shape.  (71 - 73) 911s 's  are very fast and very desirable. 
Save more money if you want this one.

944:  These are more in the price range of $6 - 8K and I see more
becoming available as sellers start to move into newer 944s.  944s are
also easier to drive and the office is more driver oriented (read race
oriented).  This would be my pick especially if you can get an S (16
valves).


Eric
86 GTi
80 911sc


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 15:50:47 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: bras and third brake lights

My post about bras had a mistake--for "the former," read "the latter."
IOW, I'd take trapped junk over flying junk.

The third brake light, I know, can be disconnected and removed.  Hank
Watts has a cabriolet with the E.T.-style light removed.  As for the
window-mounted light, it's a rubber-based adhesive that can be removed
without damaging the rear window defroster.  If I recall, the lines of
the heating element don't interfere.  Since the third brake light is a
U.S. atrocity, I don't think the lines were curved in the way American
cars are--that is, I don't think Porsche made a specific rear window
for the U.S. market.

Conversely, my Porsche mechanic mounted one in his '85 Mercedes to
create an '86 factory look.

At one time, _Motor Trend_ ran a piece on ten things to watch out for:
drivers with hats, drivers whose heads do not project above the seat
back--in short, drivers who are likely to be inattentive and
notoriously conservative.  I would add people with big old cars with
aftermarket third brake lights!

Steve Gilbert
steveng@csufresno.edu

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 15:56:02 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: what to buy? -Reply

>A 911 is very different from a 944.
>
>911: An early 911 will be expensive if it is in good shape or even if it
>is in restorable shape.  (71 - 73) 911s 's  are very fast and very desirable.
>Save more money if you want this one.
>
>944:  These are more in the price range of $6 - 8K and I see more
>becoming available as sellers start to move into newer 944s.  944s are
>also easier to drive and the office is more driver oriented (read race
>oriented).  This would be my pick especially if you can get an S (16
>valves).

Actually, the '72 911S and '73 911S are the real desirable and expensive
early 911's. The 911E's from '72 and '73 are actually a little better for
daily driving due to the street oriented power curve. There is nothing to
special about the '71 911's.

944's are easier to drive at the limit sure. But they are not any faster
and, based on what I can see, may be a tad slower when the 911 (when the
power to weight ratio is similar) is in competent hands. Anyone that wants
to race a 911 is going to take a little more time getting up to speed, but
watch out when they figure it all out.

What, pray tell, "is more driver oriented" about the 944 cockpit when
compared to a 911 cockpit? The cockpits are different for sure, but I
cannot see how the 944 would be any better. Especially the early 944
cockpit.

Both the 944 (later models) and 911 are very nice cars. I would pick
the one that turns you on the most. Why drive a 911 when you really
want a 944?? Why drive a 944 when you really want a 911???

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 18:57:10 EDT
From: MDJS51A@prodigy.com ( KARL E HAUG)
Subject: Carrera Engine Failure

Valves don't bend from "acceleration".  They bend when the valve spring
can't close them fast enough to get them out of the way of a piston.  The
stock Carrera rev limiter comes in at 6500 RPM.  Get the picture?

 -Karl, '88 Carrera Coupe


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 18:03:40 -0500 (CDT)
From: Chuck Campbell <campbell@Starbase.NeoSoft.COM>
Subject: Re: 86 Carrera collapsed rear suspension

Well,
my car (three years older than yours) did something similar recently, it turned
out to be a torsion bar failure.  This is apparently NOT very common.

I looked at the failed part and it looked like a flaw in the forge/cast (I
don't know which it is) process.  It also appeared to be factory original.
I agree I was upset at the prospect of this happening at speed or in a turn
(neither was the case for me, just when I was in stop and go traffic).

I must say, it took 80000 plus miles and 11 years before the flaw became 
critical though.  That is realistic in my opinion.  We drive old (relatively)
cars, we must expect things to break from time to time.

BTW, I believe it is accepted practise to replace both rear torsion bars at
once, and not just one side (if this is what really failed).

> 
> Yesterday while pulling out of the parking lot, I heard a popping noise from the
> rear of my 86 Carrera.  I went out and found that the left rear has dropped down
> almost to the ground, and the right rear has dropped a few inches as well.
> Seems
> like something in the rear suspension broke.  
> 
> Anyone has any idea of what may have happened ?  Any estimates of what it is
> going
> to cost ?  I am disappointed with Porsche, what if the suspension collapsed
> while
> I am doing a high speed corner !
> 
> Michael Lo

Porschephiles #1482                         Thu Jun 15 02:00:08 CDT 1995
Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 20:26:00 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: MagneticTrack Numbers/cheap way

Hi Barry,
Magnetic numbers are OK but tend to scratch the paint and blow off. Not to
mention expensive. A little racers tape on the leading edges will usually
keep them on.
I used to make my numbers out of a stencil kit that is available at any art
supply or office supply store and white vinyl shelf paper. Just trace the
numbers desired onto the paper and cut them out with sharp scissors. They are
low tack and come off easily when you want them to come off. There is no risk
to the paint.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
8:06 pm

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 20:29:08 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: 951 Control Arms -- Failures without lowering susp

Kevin,
How The heck are you?
FYI- The ball joint assembly including the cup of the ball joint are epoxied
into the arm. The group in Houston, European Dynamics, heats the arms until
the epoxy is soft and yanks out the old ball joint. They then replace the
ball joint with a, claimed, heavier duty item and re epoxy that assembly back
into the arm.
I've used them and am impressed with the quality of their work and the turn
around time. You also get and arm back that looks factory new. All cleaned up
and shiny.
BTW sorry to take up bandwith with worthless jabber. I beg everyone's
forgiveness.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
8:23 pm

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 23:00:11 -0400
From: Mrbill456@aol.com
Subject: CDs/911 Tunes

When I bought my car the PO would NOT stop talking about the $1400 stereo he
had installed (in a 1971 911E!?!). I told him I could care less and in fact
it was a negative as I would have to remove it, locate and install
replacement door pannels and locate and install a period 911 radio.

It turned out the engine exhaust valve guides had about 5mm of play, the MFI
pump had been jury rigged to avoid a rebuild and the transmission was
defective. Also the car had tires from 1986 which were hard as rocks.  It
would have been nice if he spent the $1400 on some of this.

Of course this does not mean everyone with nice stereos in early 911s ignore
the mechanical integrity of their cars. But I must say that (for early 911s
driven for recreational pleasure) an expensive stereo does not add vale and
could be a warning signal. 

I only listen to the thing when I clean or work on the car. When I'm driving
the engine noises provide more than enough enjoyment. It's still in the car
because I spent my budget on the mechanicals first.  Someday it will come out
(at least I have the recipts so I should be able to sell it).

Bill Hutton
1971 911E coupe #0038 

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 23:03:41 -0400

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 23:03:31 -0400
From: Mrbill456@aol.com
Subject: Re: Bargain 911 Update

Bob writes:

"The second 
problem is that the top piston ring groove is worn and is now 
out of spec by a few thousandths, i.e., the side clearance exceeds 
the 0.004" spec.  On the previous 911 I did, where the top 
groove had worn to a few thousandths wider than spec, I 
simply used US standard 1/16" rings instead of 1.5 mm Porsche 
rings.  They are 0.0035" thicker, and accommodate that much 
wear.  In the present case the wear is greater and 1/16" isn't 
thick enough.  I also think the ring groove is so worn it should 
be squared up, so I'm having it grooved for a standard 5/64" 
ring which is 0.078" thick.  I don't have the bill yet, but a new 
piston/cylinder set is about $1500, and I think this will wind up 
costing less than $100.  Anyone ever followed this route instead 
of getting a whole new p/c set?"

My 71 911E had the same problem on all pistons, i.e. the top piston ring
groove was rounded and the machining required to re-square the groove made
the groove too wide for a single ring. Since I did not plan to race the car
or drive it at high rpm for extended periods of time, the head mechanic
sugested to use TWO rings per groove. He installed a new Porsche ring of
standard width with another, thin US ring. The combination would give the
right gap.  I wish I could remember why a single wide ring is undesireable,
but I did not include this in my notes. I think the rings seated quite
slowly. The idle smoking (see below) decreased steadily throughout  the first
2K miles but it never went completely away. 

I have about 4K miles on the engine and it works well (so far!).  The oil
consumption is well below specification. I have noticed the generic "cloud of
blue smoke"  during some - but not all - cold starts. Occasionally (oil T
showing 180 or greater) at idle there will be more blue smoke than I would
prefer and I can not correlate this with anything driving hard, loafing
along, etc. I have never noticed smoke upon hard acceleration or extended
engine braking (deacceleration).

If your pistons are otherwise in good shape (mine looked perfect when cleaned
up and all other measurements were in spec) and the cylinder walls also check
out, you might want to try this fix.

Best wishes,

Bill Hutton
1971 911E Coupe

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 21:36:52 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re: 86 Carrera collapsed rear suspension

I suspect as others do the torsion bar broke, perhaps the inner support which 
holds the inside of the spline went poof as well or as a cause. 

As to why, my understanding is that these bars are taking some pretty severe 
stresses as a result of all the suspension movement over time. If a crack 
begins to develop, maybe at a rust pit or perhaps a flaw (what!! would Porsche 
actually have a flaw in a part??) the stresses will over a relatively short 
period of time cause the steel to fracture. 

Carroll Smith has a nice article in his book Engineer to Win which talks in 
layman's terms about stress and fatique....may not fix your problem but will 
at least give you an insight as to what happened.

Please let me (us??) know what the real cause was, the second breakage is the 
one which interests me if in fact it did go within seconds of the first...

Dennis Kalma

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 95 03:15:00 UTC
From: w.oconnell4@genie.geis.com
Subject: MagneticTrack Numbers

For normal track events, good mag numbers will work just fine - assuming you
don't have a door full of Bondo.  If the numbers do not lay flat due to
improper storage or whatever, you can put a small piece of tape on the
leading edge to keep air from getting under the number and lifting it.
another thing to be careful of is the grit than can get under it.  A good
coat of wax on both the door and the bottom of the number will help there.
Many moons ago I bought a roll of the heavy duty stuff from a company in
Ohio and used templets to cut out the various numbers.  Found that the door
on the spare fridge in the basement was a wonderful place to store them to
keep them flat.
 Current hot setup seems to be the static cling numbers but I have found that
they don't like a nice wax job and can come free at speed.
 
Bill O'Connell - Riesentoter Region, PCA
 81 SC Pacific Blue - Der Luft-Klub fur Manner
 94 Pontiac Dustbuster
 95 Saab 900SE
 88 Hobbes - aka Retardo Montakitty, with fine Corithian fur

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 95 0:04:23 EDT
From: BlaineDeLancey <Blaine.Delancey@lambada.oit.unc.edu>
Subject: Re: AC Fan

> 
> Anyway, my friends AC in his 1980 911SC makes a very obnoxious loud sound 
> that can be best described as a off-tune saxaphone.  We both think that 
> it is the fan.  To get the noise to stop, he has to turn down the AC, 
> wait...then turn it back on.  Usually the noise stops, for a little bit.  

My 1980 SC does the same thing.  It's done it for the entire 4.5 years
I've owned it.  When really bad, at low speed, it will stop blowing.  I
think it's a bearing in the fan unit in the little 'secret compartment'
that used to hold gas heaters in older cars up in the front trunk.  It
gets better as the summer wears on, so I suspect it's partially a
lubrication problem.  You'll find that thunking the unit (while the car is
stationary, preferably) will often stop the squeal for a bit as well.  As
the units cost several hundred dollars, I've been waiting for the final
squeak, but it ain't come yet...

Blaine
The Carolinas PCA Web page is currently dormant until I get full access
back after my recent move.  Don't worry, (hah, like anybody was) it's just
a matter of Real Soon Now.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 00:04:09 -0400
From: Jolcycle@aol.com
Subject: Re: RUF Wheels

>Has anyone had experience with the 17", 5 spoke RUF wheels?

I have the 17" X 8" & 9" RUF (original style) on my 911, and have mixed
feelings about them.

They look fully boss, and have a maximum of pose quality, and the workmanship
is excellent. 
The downside is that they are really heavy, which supposedly "stabilizes" the
car on the old autobahn, but makes them a decidedly lousy choice for autoX or
track.
Another down is that the flange tipe rim is easily scraped on curbs and such,
although several tire companies have started to mold a protective lip on the
lower profile tires. (Yoko AVS for example). 
All in all its hard to beat the factory alloys, that's what I use on the
track. Maybe the OZ wheels are lighter?

Hope this helps

Facta Non Verba
Jolcycle


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 14 Jun 1995 23:02:17 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 2.8 engine

> If you look further back in the issues, there is an article on bumping 
> displacemant up to 3.1 litres.  (summer of '90, I think).
> 
> > Ck out the article in the 7-95 issue of Hot VW's. Fat perforance has built a
> > 2.8 type IV engine.
> > 
> > Stan you should like this one

Stan has built big displacement Type IV engines using 4" TRW pistons
and some high-custom cranks (Type IV mains, Chevy rods, LONG stroke)
with Carrillos and custom cam grinds and way-serious head work. Just
like the 1.8 EP engines, they don't last too damn long. The EP engines
are good for about 10 race hours, these suckers are good for about 
80 street hours if you drive them hard. Difference is, I can *freshen*
a race motor and have it back in the harness that day, but these big
bore hummers, when they go, you usually get to start over again with all 
new parts. Well, I take that back -- at least new *CASE* and often cam
and crank. Carrillos are roughy indestructible and the pistons and cylinders
usually aren't a problem...

I keep being asked if there's maybe not a way to "mate" all the things I
know about high-performance engines and high-reliability engines to build
a large displacement street engine that gets 100k miles. It's not likely --
just the increased heat alone will mean you need a rebuild significantly
sooner, and the added torque from banging that larger piston down a longer
hole means the mains had *BETTER* be checked very frequently....

No free lunch, guys.

Stan
Stan

Houston Rocket Boyz whup up on thoz city slikers frum Florida.  It wuz 
bout as much fun asa watchin' my mister cookin' them thar porsha heads in 
my oven, then areachin' in to git em out an forgittin to put on hiz 
little azbestes mit, I axed him whut he wuza doin' an he tried to say he 
wuz jus alookin at them thar heads.  So I axed him ifn he burnt his han, 
an he sed, "no, it jus dudn't take me long to look at a P-car head."  I 
tol him I aint never herd of anywun acookin a car, he lookt at me like I 
wuz pert neer stupit or sumpin and sez ," woman, I aint acookin' these 
heads, Ise jus relaxin em afore I duz them guides."  I aint too shur I 
like him adoin' guides, but I rekin itz better than fightin' with them 
thar revanewers over hiz damd ole still

nite frum this lonly ole widder woman here in porsha holler.

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 04:23:49 -0400 (EDT)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: What color to paint?  Your .02 wanted!

Always repaint a car the original color.  When rock chips occur,
and they always do, the old color will show back through.  It is
very difficult to do a color change without disassembling the car.
My 66 912 came from the factory paint code 6609 (black).  It had
been repainted to BRG.  Whoever performed this abortion did a
very complete job.  It took me a couple of hours to find any black
when I inspected it before purchase.  When I repainted, I repainted
it green again.  The prospect of disassembling all those parts and
shooting the jambs correctly just turned me off.  Bottom line, if you
want a red, (or black or (for godsakes) yellow) car, buy that color car.

I wish mine was still black.


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 02:15:13 -0700 (PDT)

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 07:33:57 -0400
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: Subject: Re: 914 suspension ques

>Performance, but to replace the shocks (Koni's) would put this over 
>$1000, which is far more than I can spend.  Should I just replace the 
>springs and go from ther or get a better deal elsewhere on decent shocks, 
>I'd like to try my hand at autocrossing soon!  THanks in advance!  Rick

Rick:   take your pick on springs, depending on your requirements.  However,
bear this in mind when pricing Koni's - $1000 is too much - you shouldn't
have to pay more than ~$500 for the shocks, and anyone can replae the front
ones( rears take b*lls!).  But, remember this little known fact - if you
change to Boge's, you'll need different lower spring supports for the rear.
 Unless you can find used (not likely), the current PCNA price is $95
each!!!!  Hard to believe, but true - stay with Koni's - mt set lastest 22
years!

Just a note that under the newly passed senate ammendment to the 
telecommunications bill (the Exxon ammendment) the use of "indecent"
language on a computer network accessible to those under 18 is 
a crime punishable by 2 years in prison and $100,000 in fines.  

Indecent communications (as opposed to obscene or pornographic) 
include the use of cuss words, such as s**t.  Basically, anything
you couldn't say on TV during the kiddie hours will be illegal.

my 944, resulting in close to $500 damage, I'll f***ing kill him!

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 09:05:45 -0500
From: Eric Yuzon <YUZONE@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>
Subject:  Re: what to buy? -Reply -Reply



Well, I've always liked the 911.  That's why I bought one.  I still prefer the
944s cockpit, though.  In particular,  the shifter is shorter and positioned
high.  The orientation of the pedals are better suited to driving
techniques, like heel and toeing and double clutching.  On my 911sc,  I
tie-strapped a block of wood to the accelerator pedal to bring it closer
and adjusted the brake pedal forward to match the acc. pedal.   Now,
they are closer together when I brake hard.   The clutch, though, still has
a longer travel than I am used to.  These little things add up.   Look in a
cockpit of a 962.    Everything is positioned better for the driver.  You
don't see a long shifter.   Anyway, the newer 911s (C2 and C4)  shifter
has improved dramatically.  I guess, we could go on and on, on this one. 
But anything that improves the driver-to-car interface will improve that
persons driving at the limit, whether its a smaller steering wheel, better
grip with gloves and shoes, more supportive seat, 5 point harness, etc.
You might step into one car, adjust everything, and say "this car fits like
a glove"  and step into another and say "this is going to take awhile".

Anyway, thats what I meant!!

Eric Yuzon
86 GTi
80 911sc



------------------------------

Date: 14 Jun 95 22:57:24 EDT
From: "Eric S. Shea" <73633.1772@compuserve.com>
Subject: Re: Radar Detectors/Jammers

Hi Gang:

Mike Selfridge wrote:

<<Could anyone recommend or comment on specific brands and models of radar/laser
detectors and jammers?>>

>From what I've heard and experienced, passive jammers DO NOT WORK.  Smoke and
mirrors... spend the extra cash on a REAL radar detector.

My friend owns an alarm/stereo shop and he sells BEL and the K40? devices.  I
had resigned to purchasing an "intermediate" detector because I thought "what's
a few extra feet of protection for $200?".  Wrong.  My friend wouldn't even sell
me the 735i.  His words:

"Buy the Valentine.  You won't be satisfied with anything else."

Seeing as how I was prepared to spend $299 for the BEL, an extra $100 bucks got
me the Valentine.  IT'S FABULOUS!  This thing is like the "early" passport
stuff.  It's so well engineered you've just gotta grin when you take it out of
the box.  Tips:  Plan ahead, if you have more than 1 ride you'll want to use it
in get the extra suction cup mount and an extra straight cable and the permanent
wiring kit.

You'll never regret spending the extra $$$ and getting the best detector out
there.

Good Luck!

Eric Shea
71 Neunelf T



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 09:35:12 -0400
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bartonc@annap.infi.net>
Subject: Chagrin d'amor endure la vie...

Please forgive the non-automotive bandwidth, but you are my friends, and
once *again,* I seek the catharsis of unburdening my self to my friends.

Those of you on this list for a year may remember the painful passage of
my old buddy Spike last August.  Tuesday, I had the anguish of giving the
last loving gift, that of surcease from the pain of living, to my Sweet
Little Precious varmint, Felix.  At the moment, my heart is filled with
grief; my attachment to Felix is making a mockery of my alleged ability
to deal with life's viscisitudes ...

He hadn't eaten anything for the last 8 to 10 days, and only a few
nibbles in the week preceding that.  His liver had failed him, and that
was exacerbated by his failing thryoid.  He wanted food, but the smell of
it nauseated him and he could not eat.

Monday night, he came, as he always did, one last time to lay inside the
crook of my arm as soon as I got in bed.  He always woke me if I had gone
to sleep before he came to join me, and waited until I rolled onto my
left side so that he could lay against my left arm with his head under my
palm. If I would fall asleep too soon, he'd butt hy hand, telling me he
still wanted "head scritchin'".  After about 15 minutes of this cuddling,
he got up and went down to my feet to sleep, as always.

I stayed with Felix all day.  In the morning, he seemed so relaxed and
happy as he glued himself to my lap and stretched out fully, that I was
racked with doubt that I had made the right decision.  After noon,
however, his increasing discomfort became obvious.  He wouldn't
(couldn't) stay in my lap because he couldn't stretch out.

About 2:00 PM, I accompanied him down into the forest for a last trip.
When he tired, he asked me to pick him up and take him back up to the
deck, where he retreated into his house (a small fiber-glass airline
animal carrier with a cushioned floor and no door, that stays just
outside the kitchen door).

I made him a fresh catnip sock (from a stock we keep in the freezer) and
offered him a crushed leaf that I picked from *his* catnip clump in the
garden, both of which he refused.  These were his *favorite* treats,
showing how *badly* he felt.  He spend more and more time in the pain
posture, his back increasingly humped, showing his increasing discomfort.
I sat down beside him and waited with him until the vet arrived.

He died in my hands in his beloved home, from a lethal injection at about
5:35 PM. The things that make this bearable are knowing that he had as
rich and happy a life as was possible, there was no option, and it was
not a moment too soon.

Well, *thanks* for being there to hear this!  I had to share this load of
grief, and writing about it has helped.

Rest in Peace, Felix, my little love.  And to the group, Thank you for
your indulgence.

Cheers

Bart

Frau Dora, 
(big empty place in my heart, currently full of pain)
'86 Indischrot Carrera Cabriolet, 
'87 Alpenweis Syncro.
Custodian, Porschephiles Phund


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 95 8:51:58 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; DME chip and knock sensors

Subject: Re: DME chip?

>>Any reason I'm going to regret letting them torture my car?  Since the 944S
>>has knock sensors I don't think they can actually damage the engine by
>>advancing the timing too much?

>Dennis,

>The knock sensors are no guarantee that they won't ruin your engine.  Make
>sure you trust these guys to know what they are doing.

>Kevin Gross

  Dennis, my understanding is that knock sensors are ineffective over
 5krpm (of course, where you were interested in making power...!) so the
 knock sensors are basically ignored anyways over that limit and could never
 really prevent you from overadvancing your engine. I expect that some DSP wiz
 will do it eventually, but for now keep your ear tuned and think about
 whether this is something you -have- to have done....

           Lee A.


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 10:08:31 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Re: Bargain 911 Update

Excerpts from mail: 14-Jun-95 Re: Bargain 911 Update by Mrbill456@aol.com 
> My 71 911E had the same problem on all pistons, i.e. the top piston ring
> groove was rounded and the machining required to re-square the groove made
> the groove too wide for a single ring. Since I did not plan to race the car
> or drive it at high rpm for extended periods of time, the head mechanic
> sugested to use TWO rings per groove. He installed a new Porsche ring of
> standard width with another, thin US ring. The combination would give the
> right gap.  I wish I could remember why a single wide ring is undesireable,
> but I did not include this in my notes. I think the rings seated quite
> slowly. The idle smoking (see below) decreased steadily throughout  the first
> 2K miles but it never went completely away. 

    I would think that two rings would give you positive sealing, a la
total seal rings for 'murrican hot-rods.... just align the gaps 180
degrees apart and you have almost no blowby/leak-down.  The extra area
of ring would probably explain slow seating.  Sounds like a pretty good
setup, to me.
    You probably lost a little power due to the increased friction... 
but did you really notice it?  (Total seal rings aren't any thicker,
they just have funny machined ends where the ends of the rings are each
half as thick as the whole ring and overlap each other.)  I've never
used either setup (if my 914 needed pistons, they're cheap, and total
seal rings are a bit beyond my hot rod budget) so I can't speak from
experience....


later,

Nate

'71 914/4
'49 Chevy Fleetline coupe (still for sale...)

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 10:33:30 -0400
From: BTARGONSKY@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Trunk

Here try this, 
 ( I can't take credit for this, it is on page 89 of the Automotion catalog )

    "When your 914 trunk lid refuses to open, you can still get in the trunk.
 Open the engine lid.  Locate and remove the forward bolts holding the trunk
lid to the hinges.  The lid will then move enough so you can remove the rear
bolts and lift off the rear lid.  When replacing the lid, align it on the old
paint marks and tighten the bolts."

     If this works, tell the world (if they ask).  If it doesn't, tell
Automotion (800)777-8881.

I guess it doesn't matter where the answer comes from as long as you get it.

Drive it untill the wheels fall off, put them back on, repeat.

Brian E. Targonsky
'80 924 49k and rising

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 07:55:45 -0700
From: peterg@airdata.com (Peter Gregory)
Subject: '73.5 911T leakdown results

Folks,

First of all, I appreciate the help that many of you have offered me in the
past several days regarding my considering the purchase of a '73.5 911T.

I had a nice one checked out by my mechanic yesterday.  Everything is in
good shape: no rust, good engine/tranny, etc.

The leakdown test results puzzle me, however, and I don't know how to
interpret them.

They came out between 6% and 10% (median 8%).  My mechanic said, however,
that they first were 20-25%, but after turning the crankshaft a TEENY bit,
the leakdowns went down to the 6-10% range.  He explained that he was moving
the pistons juuuust enough to seat the rings, and that the valve trains
did not move.  His explanation is that the ring lands are wearing out, and
that moving the piston just a squeak is enough for the rings to grab in the
cylinders and seal better, thereby improving the leakdown.

I've never heard of this before.  Are the *proper* leakdown values in the
20's or between 6-10% ???

The engine has 125k miles on it, 30k since a valve job.  Original pistons
and jugs, no leaks, runs even and strong.

I thank you for your help!

 -Pete

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 08:40:02 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: Subject: Re: 914 suspension question

> 
> Rick:   take your pick on springs, depending on your requirements.  However,
> bear this in mind when pricing Koni's - $1000 is too much - you shouldn't
> have to pay more than ~$500 for the shocks, and anyone can replae the front
> ones( rears take b*lls!).  But, remember this little known fact - if you
> change to Boge's, you'll need different lower spring supports for the rear.
>  Unless you can find used (not likely), the current PCNA price is $95
> each!!!!  Hard to believe, but true - stay with Koni's - mt set lastest 22
> years!
> 

I'm confused....   When I replaced the REAR shocks on my 914, all
I had to do was unbolt them top and bottom, move the springs over,
and bolt the new ones in.

When I did the FRONTS, I had to pull the struts away from the body,
mess with the ball joints, screw in a very large nut with a 
special wrench, and watch out that I didn't mess up the alignment
in the process.
 
Gary.


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 08:59:27 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: Radar Detectors/Jammers

> 
> I'm ready to buy a radar/laser detector and jammer, now.
> 
> Any advice would be very much appreciated.  Thanks.
> 

Laser detectors don't work.  The tiny spot that flashes onto
your car is so small that unless you covered the entire car
with detectors, it wouldn't be "seen".  Users are trained
to spot it at the headlight, so you would have to cover those.

A radar jammer would involve putting a fairly large UHF transmitter
in your car.  People that operate these on a regular basis have
probles with various body parts wilting and falling off.  (Seriously!
It's a major cause of work-related injury with traffic officers.)
Are you sure you want to do this?

But.  Someone out there is making a 'stealth bra'.  Covered with
the same stuff they put on the skins of the Stealth Fighter.  Makes
the car harder to "see" with radar and laser.  Worth looking into.

$0.02,
Gary.

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 12:03:10 -0400
From: "H.Shrikumar" <shri@era.cs.umass.edu>
Subject:  Re: 924 CIS mods


Hi Dave,

>Date: Tue, 13 Jun 1995 09:01:03 -0500 (EST)
>From: ANDRUC00@SNYBUFAA.CS.SNYBUF.EDU
>Subject: Re: 924 CIS mods

>    Speaking of modifications... I have a '79 924 with the older CIS (no 
[..]
>convert over to a lambda based system with very little cash...  In a nutshell
>(to conserve bandwith) It needs basically an Oxygen sensor, an OP-AMP (Operat-
>ional Amp) for non elctrojunkies... and a hobbyist servo and a few screws,
>bolts and wire. Plus it could also be manually tuned by the driver on the fly.

I have a '82 924 that comes with the lambda sensor, but being an avid
electroniker, I could not resist the  temptation of (planning on)
adding a variable transconductance op-amp in the line from the O2
sensor, so that I can lower the lambda, during initial accelaration
phase, to make it run richer and a little more oomph on the 0-60. I
probably wont get around to actually doing it till fall, but would love
to chat with you, compare notes  and share designs with you.

I was thinking either just a manual switch, or a 555 triggered by the
driver just before hitting the throttle to lower lambda for 15 secs, Or
a couple of logic gates to trigger the 555 automatically from 'starting
from rest' condition detected somehow.

I would need to next find out the lambda-voltage curve from the O2
sensor. Hope the Bosch book would have it.

- -- Shrikumar

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 09:00:55 -0701
From: dem@best.com (DEM)
Subject: an amusing car tale


Well, not Porsche specific.  But a friend of mine told me this last night,
and I was amused.

Apparently this couple my friend knows decided to purchase a brand spanking
new top of the line Volvo - the one with all the super duper hyper attenuated
safety airbags, etc.

A week later, his wife accidentally drives up on a curb at low speed.

*All* the airbags explode.  Taking the dash, and most of the windows with
it (no fooling!).

Obviously, replacing all the airbags, dashboard, and windows was expensive.
Insurance covered it.

But, Volvo won't guarantee the warranty unless the car is sent back to
Volvo for a check up.

The cost of all this together was within a thousand or so of the value
of the car.  If volvo finds anything wrong with the car, the insurance
company would write it up as a total.

Next time I ride in a Volvo, I shall feel very safe knowing that if
any curbs suddenly jump in front of the car, I'll be saved.

Dennis Mitsch
no volvos, two porsches, one with airbags

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 12:24:08 -0400
From: "H.Shrikumar" <shri@era.cs.umass.edu>
Subject: Fun with my new toy ...'82 924.


Hi,

Love this .. having much fun with my new toy, (and a new hobby)
my '82 924.

Can someone decode the options list for me please :
C51 423 425 461 477 650

TIA 

I have told you how it sounded like harley davidson :-) when I
test drove it. So I said "bad muffler" and went ahead to make a
deal, using the muffler to negotiate the price by $500, and buy
it.

The day I bought it, drove it to the mechanic for a compression
test. In the first 15 mins of the drive (first drive for the car
that day), I heard a phenominal backfire. I apply my newly
being-acquired car-debugging skills on its first ever real case
(other than religiously listening to car-talk on NPR :) and
figured :- air-leak between muffler and engine, lets out sound.
Just needs some tightening of screws.

Also first 5 mins of drive, muffler is cold, condenses unburnt
gas, next 5 mins of drive, muffler gets hot - gas explodes with
air from leak (backfire), thereafter muffler is too hot for any
condensation.  If the theory is right, just need to tighten
muffler - so I save myself some bucks, pat on the back, I got a
good deal.

Mechanic takes a look next day - news is bitter sweet. The
engineer in me is thrilled - since my first ever car-diagnosis
is right. The grad student in me is worried - apparently the
exhaust manifold has a unweldable crack :-( He says $400, 3
weeks special order !!

Luckily located a Bofal (sp?) after-market exhaust pipe, Imparts
had it ex-stock, for $198.  Thanx to the P-files list, I knew
where to look. Pat on the back, its still a good deal.

So my new toy should be on the street before next weekend.

- -- Shrikumar

'82 924 Crimson
hp100lx

shri@cs.umass.edu    ------+ Qua!-lx - cc:Mail<->Unix g/w for HP100lx/200lx

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 12:47:28 -0400
From: BTARGONSKY@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Trunk

Here try this, 
 ( I can't take credit for this, it is on page 89 of the Automotion catalog )

    "When your 914 trunk lid refuses to open, you can still get in the trunk.
 Open the engine lid.  Locate and remove the forward bolts holding the trunk
lid to the hinges.  The lid will then move enough so you can remove the rear
bolts and lift off the rear lid.  When replacing the lid, align it on the old
paint marks and tighten the bolts."

     If this works, tell the world (if they ask).  If it doesn't, tell
Automotion (800)777-8881.

I guess it doesn't matter where the answer comes from as long as you get it.

Drive it untill the wheels fall off, put them back on, repeat.

Brian E. Targonsky
'80 924 49k and rising
'79 924 rolling parts bin



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 12:03:14 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: Electrical Adventures


The electricals on my 914 are sorted out :). Turned about to be a bad
ground(what else?) and a bum relay.  Lights work, fan works, wipers work, 
signals, radio, et. al.  Many thanks to those of you who helped me out.

a) Headlamp wiring is:  (looking at rear of lamp) 
- ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
figured out by trial and error:

			 yellow
			 ----- 
                 white |       | brown
		       |       |


b) Wiring 914 foglights for independent operation(thanks George and Dave):
- ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    Two wires need to be switched and the they are as follows:
     	1. The white with blue striped wire exiting the 85 terminal on the
    foglight relay has to be connected to a hot source. (The wire goes to the
    high low beam relay on 70/71 and to low beam on the fuseblock (fuse No.1)
    on the '72 and later vehicles).
     	2. The black with blue wire on the driving light switch terminal 15
    needs to be connected to a hot source. Originally connected to terminal
    58b on the early 70/71 914s or terminal 56 on the 72 and up 914s on the
    headlight switch.

c) Getting into solenoid activated trunk when solenoid fails:
- ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
   (good advice from many here)

   1. get trunk open(remove targa top cups and manually activate latch)
   2. fix solonoid
   3. (best advice:) make a secondary cable release by running a cable
      to the engine compartment should the solenoid fail again.

  The problem was caused(I believe) by the fact that one of the torsion
  bars for the rear deck lid wasnt cocked under the driver's side door
  hinge(the plastic roller-type piece was missing and hence the torsion
  bar flipped over against the chassis).  This caused the deck lid to
  want to fall closed rather than spring open.  Shouldn't be hard to fix.

  I just dread having to remove those torsion bars.  The last time I did
  that with a 914 I didn't get my hand out of the way quickly enough and
  one caught me right on the end of my thumb!  I was cursing six different
  ways to Sunday on that one.

d) What mail from me would be complete without a question?
- ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
  I haven't installed the fuel tank yet(waiting on new hoses/filter up
  front) and was wondering about the pump.  Should I hear it run when 
  the key is in the on position?  Is it ok to run it dry?  It seems like
  either a) it won't operate without fuel and b) it *needs* the fuel
  for lubrication and cooling.  Please advise.

Regards,
- -- 
- ----------------------------------------------------------
 - Jerry R. Brady               internet: jrb@one.com     -
 - Open Networks Engineering              abaris@msen.com -
 - '76 914 1.9                                            -
- ----------------------------------------------------------

work. 

Do you think I need a qualified psychiatrist? Once I started washing it, I
had to Amourall the tires (only for the tires), and then use "Black Again" on
the rear spoiler and rubber bumper pieces. And then I took the sunroof out
because it was a nice day, so I had to "Black Again" the wind deflector, and
clean the area where the sunroof sits. Luckily, I had cleaned the interior
the previous weekend, so that was ok.

Am I sick, or what?

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 12:08:36 -0500
From: jeffk914@groucho.roc.servtech.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Original color vs different color

>Always repaint a car the original color.  When rock chips occur,
>and they always do, the old color will show back through.  It is
>very difficult to do a color change without disassembling the car.

I think it'd be better to say, never do a paint job without disassembling
the car. If you're not going to take the time to do it right, why bother?
The paint'll never look right, and you'll still have all the rust, waves,
dents, dings, etc, of the original paint.

The ONLY way to do a good paint job is to strip it down to nothing -
everything that can come off, should. Doors, trunk lid, hood, and, of
course, engine, tranny, etc. Any rust or questionable areas should be
completely sandblasted, everything should be fixed RIGHT (no Bondo or 'glas,
if there's filling, use All-Metal), then primed, wait as long as possible,
and paint (obviously, there's tons of stuff I'm leaving out - prepping,
sanding, etc). And wait as long as possible before re-assembling, so the
paint can dry as much as possible. Then re-assemble with all new seals,
gaskets, re-install the glass, put the doors back together and on... And
voila, a car better than the factory did, and it will last longer than it
did before. If you're really slick, paint all black underbody areas with
POR-15, and it'll REALLY last.

It's impossible to do a real high-quality paint-job cheaply, unfortunately...

| Jeff Kyle		 Visit my new web page!  |
| jeffk914@groucho.roc.servtech.com   car pics & |
| "Katarina" 1975 Porsche 914         more soon! |
| http://www.servtech.com/public/jeffk914/	 |

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 12:54:01 -0500 (CDT)
From: reco@wwa.com (Armand R. Duco)
Subject: Re: Re(2): Radar Detectors/Jammers

> 
> Along similar lines, I've seen a product advertised that covers the license
> plate with some kind of laser-diffusing plastic. Not a clue if it works, but
> the concept seems sound if the plate is, in fact, the common target.

FWIW:

   I did read an article about laser detectors and radar jammers in C & D 
about a year ago.  They basicly said the same thing that all the jammers 
were worthless, some even were had only a couple of LED's and not much 
more inside.  Anyway, their reccomendation against laser was the plastic 
license plate cover you mentioned.  They suggested it was well worth the 
$25-50 they went for.  On a side issue, I've been told (by IL state 
troopers and others) that the reason many cops are actively ticketing 
people without front plates is because they are slowy switching to 
laser & photo (which uses laser) and these typicaly use the front plate 
to bounce the beam back.....

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 95 13:08:27 cst
From: "emontgo" <emontgo@cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Oil lights 

     
     
     I'm really puzzled with this one. I have a '86 944 and after it has 
     been running for a while (after engine gets to full temp), the oil 
     pressure at idle drops to just a hair below 1. This of course causes 
     all of the red lights to light up. The engine runs exactly the same. 
     No missing or changes like that. With the slightest bit of pressure on 
     the gas the lights go off and the pressure goes up as normal.
     
     I had a bad oil pressure sending unit that was replaced about two 
     weeks ago and I didn't notice this for a week or so because I drive 
     short distances normally and the temp doesn't get that hot. 
     
     Could it be a sending unit that the calibration is just a hair off or 
     possibly (as on person commented) the oil that I am using has a low 
     viscosity and I should change to something like 20-50 weight.
     I could also very easily idle up from 800 to 900 rpm and eliminate 
     this problem but I don't want to take this to lightly if it could be 
     something else.
     
     Any suggestions would be appreciated.
     
     TIA
     Ed Montgomery

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 12:00:13 -700 (MDT)
From: Jim Conforti <jec@us.dynix.com>
Subject: Laser/Radar Jammers


I'm gonna call this the "Internet Ebola Topic" since there seems to be
a continual reccurrance of outbreaks :)

Ways to "defeat" radar:

1) Passive ... by design (shape) or material ... there are Bra's made
   that *supposedly* reduce the range, but I wouldn't bet my license
   on them ;)

2) Active ... any active jammer is illegal ... some work .. Stealth
   Technologies makes the VRCD which DOES work, is FEDERALLY legal,
   and has been tested by C/D and the BMW CCA Roundel staff ...

   All the others are JUNK!

   You can also build a hi-power jammer which is FEDERALLY (read FCC)
   illegal, they work .. but ....

   (The reason all jammers are illegal are that every state I know of has
    laws against "obstruction of justice"!)


Now onto laser ...

1) Passive ... Remove the front plate ... Cover it with something non-transp
   arent at 904nm IR light ... get a paint color that's LOW in IR reflectance
   at said wavelength ... 

2) Active ... Get some Hi-Watt driving lights covered by IR filters ..
   this was tested by C/D and works ... build a jammer with some 904nm laser
   diodes (expensive as heck!, but *should* work)

All of the other stuff out there is ONLY good at separating you from your
hard earned money ...

Buy a good detector .. a VALENTINE or a Bel ... learn how to use it ...

Jim Conforti
<jec@us.dynix.com>

650 - sunroof

the general consensus was "snake oil."  (I've learned well Stan :)

to that... (Don't speed in your home state :)

	On a more serious note, I doubt that they discard "out of state" 
plates because an out of state plate draws more attention to the car in 
the first place. Ever try driving down to Florida with New York plates...


My <0.02 on the topic,

Date: 15 Jun 1995 12:04:08 U
From: "John Tucker" <John_Tucker@engr.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: 911: '71 Smog Help?(long)

                                                                    10:19 AM
  OFFICE MEMO                                                 Time:
                      Subject:
                      911: '71 Smog Help?(long)#000#                    06-15-95
                                                              Date:

I have a '71 911 T that needs to pass california smog.  It has original zenith
carbs that have been professionally tuned.  I have changed the oil, put a
bottle of swepco 503 down the carb venturis, checked the timing, dwell, and
carb syncronism (all checked out ok).  Spark plugs are new, but as you might
guess sooty black.  I was told to shoot some some water into the carbs and
clean them off (anyone else try this?). I had it tested and it failed.  The CO
was 6.6 and HC was about 1500 at a higher rpm than idle (rpm unknown). I took
it to the mechanic that tuned my carbs and he said that he's had about 4 70's
vintage 911's that he has worked on and none of them have passed.  One in his
shop now has failed four times!  He thinks the new gas may have something to 
do with it.  He's going to try different idle jets. 

He says the idle circuit works up to 4000 rpm, is this true?  

I did notice that a vacuum line that goes between the two carburetors was
unconnected.  What does this do and could it be the cause of my high emissions?
 I replaced the vacuum hoses with new hoses and you can still see the exhaust. 
Going to retest. 

In California you must now spend $450 and fail twice to get a one time waiver.
Does anyone have any advice on how to get my car to pass?  Re-adjust or replace
valves?  Rebuild engine?    

Should I spend $1400 on Weber carbs?  What model of Weber's? 

Any help or other stories about CA smog hassles invited.  How did you get yours
to pass?
Thanks, John.#000#

Hartford, Conn., was taken hiking on the Dipsea Trail over
 Mt. Tam on Monday by her Berkeley friends, Lee Tiedemann 
and Marya Frech. Ms. Tiedemann parked in Mill Valley, 
figuring they'd take the bus back from Stinson, but what-ho, 
no bus on Mondays. So Lee started hitch-hiking and was 
presently picked up by a stark naked guy in a Porsche who 
nodded ``Yeah, I'm heading for Mill Valley'' and explained, ``
Just finished my weekly Ultimate Frisbee game at the nude beach.''
 The ride was otherwise unremarkable, says Ms. Tiedemann. 
Good Luck!

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 15:30:59 -0600 (CST)
From: "thak chaloemtiarana" <tc17@cornell.edu>
Subject: 911 rubber bumper guards

Just an update on the bumper guard question I posted some months ago.  I
finally took off the torn one on my 87 930 and replaced it with one from a
78 911SC.  The parts number on the bumper guard itself were the same.
Therefore it is still a puzzle to me why there are two numbers listed for
the early SC's and later Carreras and Turbos.  The latter cost more.  The
people at Tweeks did not know.  The person I spoke with at Stoddard did not
know but went to the warehouse and pulled the two and compared them for me.
He said that the inside mouldings are different.  Go figure.

Is this typical of Porsche to make slight variations and charge more?
Thak Chaloemtiarana                              EMail:TC17@cornell.edu

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 15:38:27 -0400
From: "Frank Sanford" <fsanford@pamd.cig.mot.com>
Subject: 914 plastic fuel lines

	This weekend I'm planning on swapping the plastic fuel lines
that run through the center tunnel with metal replacements. The way I
see it, I have 3 commonly available choices to do this with.
	1. Use steel the tubing with flared ends and fittings (like
large I.D. solid brake line type) and barbed fittings to attatch the
hose.
	2. Use copper tubing with compression fittings and barbed
fittings to attatch the hose.(I vaguely remember hearing somewhere
that compression fittings aren't good to use with fuel lines - if
anyone can confirm or deny...)
	3. Use copper tubing with as close to 7mm O.D. as possible
(1/4" ?) and simply slide the hose over and clamp it like the factory
did with the plastic lines.
	I'd appreciate hearing from anyone else who has done this as
to their experience, methods, materials, etc. or anyone else with
 experience in this "plumbing" work.

PS if anyone wants my old lines, their yours for shipping costs. I
have all 4(2 long, 2 short). there isn't anything wrong with them
besides being 20 some odd years old.

- -- 
Frank Sanford				Email: fsanford@pamd.cig.mot.com
Motorola 				Phone: (404) 333-2121 (w/ voice mail)
Cellular Infrastructure Group   	Fax:   (404) 333-2142
Suite 550			
2839 Paces Ferry Road
Atlanta, GA 30339

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 95 15:45:32 EDT
From: AALEXAND@CMSA.gmr.com
Subject: HIRSCHMANN OF AMERICA (Power Antennae)

>From:    Alexandridis, Alexander A.
         Vehicle Systems
         986-1547

Subject: HIRSCHMANN OF AMERICA (Power Antennae)

___________FOR GENERAL INFORMATION_____________


In order to repair my automatic power antenna of my 1984 911, I went directly
to the source, Richard Hirschmann of America, Inc.  for parts.

This is what I know:

Address: R. Hirscmann of America, Inc.
          P.O.Box 229
          Riverdale, NJ 07457
          Attn. Customer Service
          1-800-225-0524

They do have replacement masts (telescopes) for the older units (mine is a
6000 U ). No other parts are available for those older units.  They will ship
to individuals with Certified check or Money Order (No Cards or COD).  For
reference, my mast costs $35.55 for chrome tip or $36.10 for black tip.  The
mast is available only in chrome.  They were able to identify the replacement
part Number from the model type of the unit.  The Hirschmann Part number for
my mast is 825.948.105.

Imparts told me the mast that fits the 6000 U is Imparts #477.035.513 for
($32.79).  Is it the same item??  Would be nice to find out somehow.

Hope this helps.

Alex Alexandridis
1984 Carrera
1992 BMW K75S
1978 BMW R80/7
etc.

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 95 15:56:11 EST
From: "Thwen Chaloemtiarana" <chaloemt@vrinet.com>
Subject: Re: Do I need Help / Am I ill?

Put it this way:

I am the classic case of a car abuser.  Used to try to light 'em up on every 
car I had every time the light turned green.  Didn't know to check the oil 
until I ran a Ram 50 dry once.  Wash the car?  For what?  Vacuum?  Why?  What's 
that noise?  Oh, it went away so it must have "fixed itself."  Ad infinitum.

So now I find myself with a little rust bucket 14 I bought for $700.  With a 
backyard paint job.  Dent in pass front fender.  Not much left behind the 
firewall on the passenger side.

What do I do every morning before the 15 min. ride to work?  Wash it by hand in 
my suit, of course.  Vacuum it 3 times a week.  What do I do when I get home?  
Work on it then wash it again.  Even though I have to park outside under the 
sap and crap from black walnut trees and willows (that will require washing in 
the a.m.).  Car cover and therapy soon, at this rate!  My SO wants to know who 
I am and what I did with her husband.

Thwen.

I have an '89 944 in which I run 5w-30. At idle with a warm car oil pressure 
is about half way down
the scale. At anything above idle, pressure needle is pegged.

Had the same problem with mine about two years ago.  Turned out to be the 
gauge itself.

>From: porschephiles-request
To: porschephiles
Subject: Oil lights
Date: Thursday, June 15, 1995 1:08PM



     I'm really puzzled with this one. I have a '86 944 and after it has
     been running for a while (after engine gets to full temp), the oil
     pressure at idle drops to just a hair below 1. This of course causes
     all of the red lights to light up. The engine runs exactly the same.
     No missing or changes like that. With the slightest bit of pressure on
     the gas the lights go off and the pressure goes up as normal.

     I had a bad oil pressure sending unit that was replaced about two
     weeks ago and I didn't notice this for a week or so because I drive
     short distances normally and the temp doesn't get that hot.

     Could it be a sending unit that the calibration is just a hair off or
     possibly (as on person commented) the oil that I am using has a low
     viscosity and I should change to something like 20-50 weight.
     I could also very easily idle up from 800 to 900 rpm and eliminate
     this problem but I don't want to take this to lightly if it could be
     something else.

     Any suggestions would be appreciated.

     TIA
     Ed Montgomery

Subject: '66 912 (3 instrument) production totals

hi friends ! 
i recently EEEAASED over the line from 356 land w/ an
original owner '66 912. the car only has 3 instruments
in the dash. i never gave it a thought until i heard
somebody say that this is 'incredibly' rare and that 
maybe only 150 or so were built in this configuration
until the factory split the gas/oil temp guage & added
the clock. does anybody know (or have any better guess)
at what this number may actually be? 
 i know this is jabber. hopefully it isn't worthless :)

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 14:15:26 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: 914 CV joint problem - Advice sought

Hi Everyone.

I just was under my '74 914-4 2.0, bleeding the proportioning valve.  In
the process I noticed that the gasket-material-like "seals" (Haynes, p. 96,
Fig. 6.11, #4) that go between each inner CV joint and the tranny's output
drive flanges are "coming out".  This despite a careful installation and
correct torquing.  

I presume I'll slowly lose CV joint grease if this isn't fixed.  How does
one properly install and maintain these seals?

 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  |

Subject: Re: 914 outside mirror

*Was* there ever a factory 914 RH outside mirror?  My impression is
that the RH mirrors I occasionally saw on cars were flipped over and
added by owners.  That was before the days of remote mirrors on
Porsches, and before remote mirrors the RH mirror was something of a
rarity.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 17:09:20 -0500
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Re: Subject: Re: 914 suspension question

..   When I replaced the REAR shocks on my 914, all
>I had to do was unbolt them top and bottom, move the springs over,
>and bolt the new ones in.

Yea.... Beware of instructions that start with "all ya have to do" ;-)
The problem with switching the springs over is that if they are OEM
factory springs, you must compress them 1st. And you must compress them
if you are going to reinstall them. The compressers are of interesting
design. If you don't get them straight, they tend to be a problem. Personaly,
I have nightmares of the gaurage springs that shot thru our roof when I was 
a kid! As I stated earlier, I beleive that OEM springs are no longer 
available and, if you reinstall the replacements (at least the 100lb 
springs) they require no compression. They just "drop" right in. 

Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1966 911 cpe

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 20:16:40 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Dash Cracks!   Help!

>Hi all
>   I Noticed some small cracks in my dash at the base of the windshield 
>spreading out of the defroster vents, they are about an inch long and 
>not noticeable. Question: is there any way to stop it? what can I do to 
>save my dash? My interior is/was perfect!
>

Not much you can do to stop it once it starts.  Try using a dash cover (I 
prefer the fabric kind - handy place to leave the radar detector under) to 
prevent the sun from beating on it...

Mostly, the new style 944 dashes that I have seen are in pretty good shape, 
without cracks in them... Needless to say, I have a couple of good ones that 
may suit your needs... (Insert mindless jabber here 8-)  )

Good Luck!

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 17:46:39 -0600
From: gwilensky@gryphonsw.com (Gabriel Wilensky)
Subject: 911S Ergonomics

Hi everyone! I recently bought a 1977 911S in very good shape as my first
Porsche. I'm absolutely thrilled with the car. I use it as my daily driver,
and in never fails to provide me with an adrenaline rush! Two things about
the ergonomics of the car puzzle me, though, specially for a sports car:

1. The car has the stock seats, which are very high. These seats put my
shoulders way above the steering wheel, and my forehead almost at the top
of the windshield. My legs are very close to the bottom of the steering
wheel, and when turning I touch my legs when my hand gets to the six
o'clock position, especially if I need to press any of the pedals at that
time. So the question is: how is it possible that this car doesn't have a
*much* lower seat? Is there anything that can be done to lower it? In case
there isn't, is there any relatively inexpensive seat replacement?

2. I have no idea what the designers of this car were thinking of when they
designed the pedal assembly. There's no way you can heel-and-toe on those
pedals! Can they be adjusted? Is there any other solution?

On to a different topic: has anybody installed a subwoofer in a 911? Is
anybody familiar with the one Pioneer manufactures that goes on top of the
spare wheel (!?), or another they make that looks like a small rectangular
box that could conceivably be installed under or behind the seats, or what
about a non-amplified Bazooka (or any other suggestions)?

My last question is about Driver's Education in southern California. Does
anybody know if there is such a thing, where, when, how much, who to
contact, etc?


Thanks very much in advance. I'm looking forward to exchanging some info
with you guys!


Gabriel Wilensky

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 17:47:35 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: 911 Flywheel & clutch

Michael, you wrote:

> Also how do I tell if the flywheel needs to be machined?

It should be be very smooth and flat.
For flywheels (and brake rotors), I check for ridges by scratching
along a radial line with my fingernail. If there are any grooves
or ridges, you should definitely have it resurfaced. (With brake
rotors you need to be on the lookout for warpage as well).
I agree with the other posters that you should avoid a light
flywheel for street use.

The clutch, pressure plate, and TO bearing in my 911 have only
about one year's use in them but the PO managed to nearly
wear out the disk in this amount of time (I know why, I have
witnessed the guy's driving style: rev up to about 4000 rpm
at a stop, grrrrradually let out the clutch over about a 5 sec period...
argghhh!).  Since I had no problems with slippage, I'm replacing only 
the TO bearing and disk.

 -Mitch


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 21:25:11 -0400 (EDT)
From: takaharu@sas.upenn.edu (Takaharu Mizutani)
Subject: Where Do I Buy a Valentine Detector? (fwd)


Mike Selfridge wrote:
> Okay, the votes have been counted.  It seems that the highest
> recommendations are for Valentine radar detectors.  Thank you
> all for your help and advice.
> 
> Mostly negative opinions were given for jammers.
> 
> The next question is:  What model should I get (I need radar
> and laser), and where can I buy one at a good price?

Valentines are only sold directly by the manufacturer. I don't have the 
number handy, but you can easily find the ad in almost any car magazine 
in the USA. Pricewise, I think the radar-only model is something like 
$329, and the laser model is around $400.

I heard on this list that Valentine also has a limited quantity of 
reconditioned detectors at a discounted price. Anyone who knows about 
this, please re-post this info on the list. I might get one.

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 12:52:20 -0700
From: jcjensen@raychem.com
Subject: Re[2]: 911 Head Studs

     
     In researching this recently, Bruce Anderson stated that the 
     Raceware studs were not the right choice for the early magnesium 
     (like my 2.7) cases.
     
     For magnesium cases, Bruce suggested staying with dilavar.

broken and jam  the clutch and pressure plate.  We spent a lot of time trying
to convince  ourselves it was something else but its the clutch.  Sorry for

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 19:21:03 -0700
From: peterg@airdata.com (Peter Gregory)
Subject: For Sale: '69 912, good project car

For Sale
- --------

1969 Porsche 912, polo red/black, coupe, ~130k miles.

5 speed, 5-gauge

Body straight, never crashed, 100% structural rust-free (small amounts of
   rust only in lower edge of driver's door, nowhere else).  Complete service 
   records going back many years.  Driver's log going back seven years.

Blown Motor (suspected broken crank right behind rear main bearing, specific
   cause unknown).  Tranny is okay, clutch seems okay.  10k on new
   generator; 50 mi. on tuned ignition, fuel system.  Engine sheet metal
   good.  Brakes, steering, suspension in excellent shape.

5-1/2 x 15 Fuchs clone alloy rims in excellent shape, good Yokohama A378 tires.

3k on four new Boges, 5k on new clutch, 15k on refurbished fuel tank.

Interior excellent (forward map pockets missing - I never had 'em; driver's
   map pocket in good condition but not in car; carpets 50% worn; nice-fitting
   dash-cover in place [been there since I've owned the car], interior
   otherwise clean).

Absolutely everything on the car works except the rear defogger window (and
the engine of course).

Exterior paint is tired but otherwise all there.  No bare metal showing.

In a nutshell, this car is all original, well-maintained, but unrestored.

VIN 129021117; have pedigree from PCNA, original owner's manual, several
   fix-it books (Haynes, etc.).

- --

This is an excellent 912 project car for someone who wants to get into a 
Porsche for not a lot of money up front.  IMHO it's too good to part out.
Literally, this car would be an excellent daily-driver with only a working
motor put in it.

Why don't I fix it??  I don't have *time* for a project car.

$3000 or make offer.  Located in Seattle, Washington, USA.

Peter Gregory
20026 NE 190th Ct.
Woodinville, WA  98072
206-788-8833
pete@morhila.wa.com (h)
peter.gregory@asix.com (w)
peter.gregory@airdata.com (w)

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 22:29:51 -0500 (CDT)

Subject: Re: 911S Ergonomics

> 1. The car has the stock seats, which are very high. These seats put my
> shoulders way above the steering wheel, and my forehead almost at the top
> of the windshield. My legs are very close to the bottom of the steering
> wheel, and when turning I touch my legs when my hand gets to the six
> o'clock position, especially if I need to press any of the pedals at that
> time. So the question is: how is it possible that this car doesn't have a
> *much* lower seat? Is there anything that can be done to lower it? In case
> there isn't, is there any relatively inexpensive seat replacement?

How tall are you? I'm 6'3", and most of it is from the hips up. My big
problem is that I can wear a helmet in a sunroof coupe. Otherwise, no
problem. The wheel *DOES* drag on my thighs.

There are a couple of fixes, ranging from Recaro's to surgery on the seat 
mounts. I've done both in two different cars, and finally decided to just
live with it in my last 911.

> 2. I have no idea what the designers of this car were thinking of when they
> designed the pedal assembly. There's no way you can heel-and-toe on those
> pedals! Can they be adjusted? Is there any other solution?

Beg to differ. 30 years of the most successful competition record of *ANY*
car ever devised might be used as a counterpoint. You do have to adopt a 
slightly different style, but it is *FAR* from impossible.

> On to a different topic: has anybody installed a subwoofer in a 911? 

Ah! A *stereo* guy, not a *car* guy, that explains it... 8{)

Stan

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 00:36:37 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 plastic fuel lines

> 	This weekend I'm planning on swapping the plastic fuel lines
> that run through the center tunnel with metal replacements. The way I
> see it, I have 3 commonly available choices to do this with.

I chose Option 4: run Aeroquip steel braided hoses across the floor to
bulkhead fittings on either firewall where I mate up with the rest of the
plumbing in a clean manner. It's a race car, you can do things like
that...

My personal preference would be the steel lines, but be aware that 
you will need a fuel filter at each end of the car -- the steel
lines *DO* eventually rust out, and you don't want that rust in the
pump or the injectors...

> PS if anyone wants my old lines, their yours for shipping costs. I
> have all 4(2 long, 2 short). there isn't anything wrong with them
> besides being 20 some odd years old.

As I'm fond of saying "Thanks, I already have some 20 year old lines"...

Stan

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 15:52:42 -0700
From: "Wayne Michelsen" <wayne@darien.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Re: 911 shocks/etc. & Bike Rack

Elliot,

Not much to say about the shocks, but about the bike rack...

I have an '87 Targa w/Carrera Tail.  I bought a Rhode Gear Ultra Shuttle 3 and
made some modifications.  I shortened the vertical u-tube so the pivot point is
closer to the tail lip, and I made a new horizontal u-tube to reach out to the
base of the rear window (3/4" elec. conduit was the perfect size).  I am quite
happy with the results.

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 23:03:00 -0700
From: paulm@kestrel.engr.sgi.com (Paul Mielke)
Subject: Re:  Radar Detectors/Jammers

| Date: Thu, 15 Jun 1995 14:30:03 -0400 (EDT)
| From: "Naresh H. Singh" <nhs1681@is2.NYU.EDU>
| Subject: Re: Re(2): Radar Detectors/Jammers
| 
...
| 
|         I remember someone saying that troopers always aim for the 
| headlights because the radar/laser is attracted to the heat and it gives 
| back a good reflection. Don't know how true it is.
| 

The part about radar/laser being attracted to the heat is completely
nonsensical.  A radar or laser gun is simply radiating a beam in the
direction it's pointed.  I make no claims as an expert in radar
gun technology, but I did take a couple of years of undergraduate
physics (longer ago than I care to admit).

The reason that the headlight would make a good target for a laser is
that it is a nice smoothly curved surface that is facing forward.
It is likely that there will be at least one point on the surface that
has a tangent plane perpendicular to the incoming laser beam,
which will thus reflect the beam right back at the gun.  Which is the
whole point:  the gun has to receive a reflection from the target in
order to detect anything.

It is because curved surfaces make good reflectors that the
stealth fighter looks so bizarre.  Somebody used one large boatload of
computer time (that was a *metric* boatload <g>) to compute the exact
angles at which to position all those flat surfaces to minimize the chance
that an incoming beam of anything will hit a surface perpendicularly and 
reflect back to the point of origin of the beam.


Paul Mielke (paulm@sgi.com)
Silicon Graphics, Inc.
