Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 02:01:03 -0400
From: OWENSTEIN@aol.com
Subject: Re: Race team names

Hi all
     This a name you may get a kick out of. A friend of mine 
races off-road RC(radio-control) cars and the name of his one 
man team is "Half Fast" racing team. If it isn't funny say it 
again, you might have missed the pun. These little cars are 
pretty amazing actually, and fun to drive. The're wildly 
overpowered and have fully adjustable suspensions with oil shocks and
everything. Not as much fun as driving a real car on a track, but when the
big crash comes bodily injury is minimal!!!
                                                        Todd

Porschephiles #1486                         Fri Jun 16 11:22:01 CDT 1995
Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 04:05:42 -0400
From: OWENSTEIN@aol.com
Subject: another airbag story

I knew a gentleman who was driving his BMW 325ix(4WD) and hit a small deer.
 That doesn't do a car much good, but unless you either swerve into traffic
or off the road nothing much happens. In this instance the driver hit the
deer and was still in complete  control, However the deer was propelled
forward and hit the front a second time. This time the air bag went off
blocking his view and keeping his hands from the wheel. As he could not steer
he went into the ditch and ran over a rock. The rock ripped out the oil
pan(with integral differential and pass through sway bar) and broke the
bellhousing!!!!   The damage to the front was about $1800. The rock(ahem air
bag) damage exceded $12,000, to top it off while in the ditch his arm was
broken!!! 

           Air bags probably provide significant protection in a heavy
frontal impact, however there seems to be a few trade offs.
                                                     Todd

P.S. A man was killed in South America in an explosion at a Mercedes Benz air
bag factory in 94

Date: 16 Jun 95 07:46:00 EST
From: "LOGISX::GIBBS" <GIBBS%LOGISX.decnet@vaxa.acdnj.itt.com>
Subject: Re:  Oil Light

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 95 13:08:27 cst
>From: "emontgo" <emontgo@cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Oil lights 

     
     
>   I'm really puzzled with this one. I have a '86 944 and after it has 
>   been running for a while (after engine gets to full temp), the oil 
>   pressure at idle drops to just a hair below 1. This of course causes 
>   all of the red lights to light up. The engine runs exactly the same. 
>   No missing or changes like that. With the slightest bit of pressure on 
>   the gas the lights go off and the pressure goes up as normal.
     
>   had a bad oil pressure sending unit that was replaced about two 
>   weeks ago and I didn't notice this for a week or so because I drive 
>   short distances normally and the temp doesn't get that hot. 
     
Ed

Don't mess around with this!

Get a calibrated gauge and put it in place of the sending unit.  Check
the pressure at idle when warm.  Now you know.

By the way, my guess would be the sending unit - always suspect the last 
thing you changed.  But it could also be that the pressure has been low
all along, and the old sending unit was hiiding the problem.  Given the
potential negative effects of low oil pressure, this needs immediate 
attention.

Ed Gibbs
gibbs@avionics.itt.com
'84 944, Guards Red, All Mine

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 07:54:47 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 timing belt tension

>Hi,
>  I did that job several times on my 944.  It is easy and I did it w/o 
>the manual or special tools.  IMO  it is not that precise.  Just apply 
>about medium arm wrestling strenght to a standard sized socket wrench 
>and that is about right.  I guess your really need some experiance with 
>this but I do it all the time.  I do Ferraris by feel too.  Never had a 
>problem.  But I guess do at your own risk.  I think all the porsche 
>special tools are a lot of B.S..
>
>
Carlton,

The problem with the belt tension on the 944 is that the engine grows in 
dimension (length, width and height) by 9 mm from cold to hot.

I use the tension tool because I have to guarantee to my customers that it 
is going to work for them on the street and on the track.

I have never done a Ferrari belt, so have no opinion on their tools...
Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 08:06:16 -0500
From: Eric Yuzon <YUZONE@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>
Subject:  911S Ergonomics -Reply



>>> Gabriel Wilensky <gwilensky@gryphonsw.com> 06/15/95 06:46pm
>>>
Hi everyone! I recently bought a 1977 911S in very good shape as my
first
Porsche. I'm absolutely thrilled with the car. I use it as my daily driver,
and in never fails to provide me with an adrenaline rush! Two things
about the ergonomics of the car puzzle me, though, specially for a sports
car:

1. The car has the stock seats, which are very high. These seats put my
shoulders way above the steering wheel, and my forehead almost at the
top of the windshield. My legs are very close to the bottom of the
steering wheel, and when turning I touch my legs when my hand gets to
the six o'clock position, especially if I need to press any of the pedals at
that time. So the question is: how is it possible that this car doesn't have
a
*much* lower seat? Is there anything that can be done to lower it? In
case there isn't, is there any relatively inexpensive seat replacement?

2. I have no idea what the designers of this car were thinking of when
they designed the pedal assembly. There's no way you can heel-and-toe
on those pedals! Can they be adjusted? Is there any other solution?

On to a different topic: has anybody installed a subwoofer in a 911? Is
anybody familiar with the one Pioneer manufactures that goes on top of
the spare wheel (!?), or another they make that looks like a small
rectangular box that could conceivably be installed under or behind the
seats, or what about a non-amplified Bazooka (or any other
suggestions)?

My last question is about Driver's Education in southern California. Does
anybody know if there is such a thing, where, when, how much, who to
contact, etc?


Thanks very much in advance. I'm looking forward to exchanging some
info with you guys!


Gabriel Wilensky


- --------------------------------

First off, congratulations on the purchase!! I just bought my first 911sc,
too.  For the seats, you might try removing some of the padding on the
bottom.  You didn't mention if they were the sports seats or not.  Also,
think about getting a MOMO steering wheel (12.5").

About the pedal assembly, I had the same problem.  After some research
and discussion with the PCA members, here is my solution.  The
accelerator has only about a 1/2 of adjustment, so I just tie-strapped a
block of wood to it. Not elegant but it works.  I also glued a rubber pad to
it for some grip.  The clutch is not adjustable, but the brake pedal is. 
Remove the carpet and panel cover.  Both the brake and accelerator use
the same type of adjusting rod.  Its self explanatory once you see it.  By
the way, you should be able to move the brake pedal forward enough to
match the accelerator.  Remember to adjust them so that the brake is just
a little closer to you than the accelerator when braking hard.

Good luck.

Eric Yuzon
80 911sc (lt blue; great fun)
86 GTi (soon to be replaced by a 16 v for a daily driver)






------------------------------

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 08:18:22 -0500
From: Eric Yuzon <YUZONE@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>
Subject:  electrical instability -Reply



>>> Daniel G. Pouzzner <douzzer@prez.mit.edu> 06/16/95 06:27am >>>
both my portable CD and portable DAT can run off this radio shack
adaptor thingy i plug into the cigarette lighter. however, after about 30
minutes, they seem to just get fried. this typically happens when i
downshift. the portables aren't permanently damaged, just stressed to
the point that they turn themselves off.

so, what should i do about this? build a box with another voltage
regulator and a big filter capacitor?

 -douzzer
 ('79 928)


- ----------------------------------

I need more info to diagnose this one.  What do you mean by turn off?
Does the fuse in the RS adaptor get blown? Or the fuse in the car?
If the portables are getting turned off, they must not be getting enough
voltage.  I don't how that happens just because you downshift.  Also,
does the voltage of the adaptor match both portables?   Typically, the
cheaper adaptors (voltage regulators) have some small caps.  If you
want, just hang a big polarized cap off the adaptor wires.

Eric Yuzon
80 911sc
 <YUZONE@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 08:35:55 -0400 (EDT)
From: Michell Feig <mitchsf@shadow.net>
Subject: Re: Where Do I Buy a Valentine Detector?



On Thu, 15 Jun 1995, Mike Selfridge wrote:

> Date: Thu, 15 Jun 95 17:06:24 -0700
> From: Mike Selfridge <selfridg@encoreengineering.com>
> To: porschephiles@tta.com
> Subject: Where Do I Buy a Valentine Detector?
> 
> Okay, the votes have been counted.  It seems that the highest
> recommendations are for Valentine radar detectors.  Thank you
> all for your help and advice.
> 
> Mostly negative opinions were given for jammers.
> 
> The next question is:  What model should I get (I need radar
> and laser), and where can I buy one at a good price?
> 
Dear Mike:
You can only get the Valentine direct, although they do discount 
reconditioned units, slightly.  I have an Escort and a Valentine, and 
while I think the Valentine is fantastic, there are a few things about it 
that bother me to no end.  First, they use a RJ11 phone jack for power 
connection.  This is a standard telephone connector, not meant to be 
plugged and unplugged daily.  They last about 2 or three months, each.  
Second, the mounting bracket doesn't hold the unit securely, and the 
plastic cracks easily (although the last one I got at no charge, has 
lasted about 6 months).  Third, you must reset the mode every time you 
start the car.  This is OK if you want to use its most sensitive setting, 
but I need the full logic mode, and I have to reset every time I start the 
car.  Even the Escort keeps its settings.
Otherwise, I like it a lot, and wouldn't do without the feature that 
displays the direction the radar is coming from.

Mitch Feig
1976 911S

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 95 09:01:39 EST
From: Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov
Subject: 951 Maintenance info

Hello Fellow 'philes;

With all the recent traffic about maintenance costs and the value of the Porsche 
Used Car warranty, I thought I would pass along this food for thought.

I took my car into my trusty Posche dealer yesterday because the AC was not 
working, the right front ball joint was spitting out grease and the sunroof 
would not raise.  All this stuff was OK aboout 10 months ago when I bought the 
car and had a pre-purchase inspection done.  I got a call from the dealer about 
lunch time with the results of their investigation.  Not only was the right side 
ball joint bad, but the mechanic also found play in the left side as well.  The 
AC condenser had a leak and needed to be replaced.  The sunroof lift mechanism 
gears were stripped.  The dealer had to special order all the parts.

I went home and added up the damages: left and right control arms, AC condenser 
and sunroof gears.  Using the Euroselect catalog price listings the total came 
to about $2,500 in parts alone.  Since my car is an '89 Turbo I do not think I 
can use the Euroselect parts although they are the same in many cases.  I figure 
with labor at $62 an hour and a front end alignment I am looking at a bill of 
over $3,000 for a car that basically runs well.  This car is a daily driver with 
only 49K miles on it.  I have put on about 12K of those miles.

Now for the good news.  I received the Porsche Used Car warranty when I bought 
the car last August.  All of these items will be covered by the warranty.  The 
moral of the story: If you buy the car from a dealer, get the warranty.  It only 
costs about $500 and the dealer will usually throw it in to close the deal (mine 
did).  End of story.

Tracy Meyer


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 95 09:30:57 EST
From: mark_salvetti@ABBSMTP.abb.com (mark salvetti)
Subject: Re: 911 Head Studs

          Thanks to Bruce Anderson, I have the rest of the info from
          the article I recalled reading about Raceware vs Dilivar
          studs.

          Apparently, for the last couple of years, Bruce has been
          getting regular reports of Dilivar studs from reputable
          sources failing while being torqued.  Also, tuners going for
          high power outputs in 911 turbos have had problems with the
          Dilivars stretching, causing combustion leaks.

          The Raceware Fasteners have the proper thermal expansion
          properties, and are 24% stronger than the Dilivars.  Bruce
          goes on, "These studs achieve a higher initial clamp force
          without having excessive force when the engine has thermally
          expanded.  To achieve this result, the manufacturer has
          managed to alter the effective stress-strain curve of the
          stud.  They accomplished this by both mechanical and
          metallurgical processes.  These are a much stronger cylinder
          head stud without the brittleness of the Dilivar which leads
          to the broken head studs.

          The Racewares also have a special finish that prevents
          corrosion and galvanic action with the alloy 911 crankcases.
          Bruce continues: "I really think that these 911 head studs
          will be a good replacement for the Dilivar heads studs that
          we have seen breaking in the 911SC, 911 Carrera and 911
          Turbo engines as well."

          Since the above article appeared in a national publication
          (Excellence, I think), I have assumed that Bruce does not
          mind being quoted.  Thanks Bruce!

          Raceware advertises a set in the latest Excellence for $390.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 08:12:19 -0700 (PDT)
From: mse@msd.amd.com (Malcolm Early)
Subject: Price Quote For '83 911 SC

Gentelmen-

	I am requesting your assistance and expertise in generating a price
quote for a 1983 Porsche 911 SC.  Here are the details:

 - the car has been garaged all of it's life with only 6k miles and has been
	driven in upper Wisconsin, no rust can be seen.
 - for the last seven years, it hasn't moved...it has become a closet for 
	old clothes (I know...it's a terrible fate).
 - it is RED with black trim and interior....fully loaded with all the
	options.
 - the main crank _does_ turn over, but oil hasn't been changed in at least
	seven years.
 - the car has not been on jacks for the seven years.
 - unfortunately, there has been gas in the tank.

So, that is what I know...when I saw the car a couple of months ago, I
wasn't in the market.  But now I have the opportunity,  and garage, to take
on such a project as getting this car back into shape.  My goal would be to
restore it to it's orginal condition and then decide if I just want to use
it as a Sunday driver or turn it into an Auto-Cross car.  There is no
question it is a great looking car, but it needs a lot of work:

 - New tires, fuel lines, possibly new tank and injection system.
 - the engine could probably stand being rebuilt.
 - the shocks and other suspension parts need to be looked at to determine
	if any damage has been done to them just by sitting there so long.
 - and of course..there will be some electrical problems (Murphy's law).

I would appreciate any advice or tips, along with what price would you all
think is reasonably for this car.  Please send responses directly to:

				Malcolm Early
				mse@msd.amd.com


Thank you.

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 08:51:53 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: electrical instability

> 
> both my portable CD and portable DAT can run off this radio shack
> adaptor thingy i plug into the cigarette lighter.
> however, after about 30 minutes, they seem to just get fried. this
> typically happens when i downshift.
> the portables aren't permanently damaged, just stressed to the point
> that they turn themselves off.
> 
> so, what should i do about this? build a box with another voltage
> regulator and a big filter capacitor?
> 
> -douzzer
>  ('79 928)
> 

The cigarette lighter is a *terrible* way of getting at the battery.

Before I went to all the trouble to build an external regulator,
I would put a better connector in.  Even a 1/4" headphone jack
would be better than the lighter socket; I'm sure you can find
something even better.  What you're looking for is called a
"quick disconnect power connector".

Gary.

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 11:27:22 -0500
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Re: RE:Want my Title..answed


>mention.New research tells me that the title has come back as salvage for
>being a previous theft.this explains the insurance companies involvment.
>As to holding the title, it is clearly written on my bill of sale of
>recieving a clear and clean florida title upon payment in full .my only guess
>todate is that the ultimate dealer I bought the car from has gotten a salgave
>title, and is stalling to find a way to fix it :says the RMV.
>One way of stalling is to  tell me I owe him more money and provide a
>situation to get more money at the same time waste time in the hope of fixing
>this title discepency.Fact,he has the title.Fact refuses to release it unless
>more money is sent.Fact he is lieing out the yazoooo.

Fact..... A reconstructed title is worth SERIOUSLY less then a vehicle that
has a clean title. Fact... once that title is marked with an R it is the 
sellers responsability to represent that vehicle as being reconstructed.
Fact... Even if the dealer "cleans" your title, Carfax and a couple of other
title databases will record it as an R title.



H>I have set the state on him.They gave him an ultimatum A)turn over this title
>to the state of VT and if money is owed write it as being a lien holder for
>this amount he allegedly says I owe ,because holding this title is illegal,no
>excuses!! or B) all of his dealer wright will be revolked until this is done.
>
>He has chosen option B it makes no difference to him because he has other
>dealer licences available in other states to him and can continue business as
>usual only that they can not be on display for sale or be seen making
>transactions of sales in VT but still has the power to sign off paperwork and
>transferals of ownership because he is still a dealer even if he is'nt in
>that state.It can all go through one of his other dealer licenses.


 Or how about this. Option C. Dealer has made a material misrepresentaion
on the bill of sale (assuming that your buyers guide and bill of sale do not
mention the Reconstructed nature of you purchase). This is unexcusable 
business practice. Dealer owes you $$$$$. You realy should get proper 
representaion. Either that or tell dealer your plans in his misrepresentation
of you purchase. Beleive me that R on your title was very important to be 
mentioned to you before the sale.

Porschephiles #1487                         Fri Jun 16 19:33:57 CDT 1995
Date: Fri, 16 Jun 95 9:31:03 PDT
From: Mark Blaskovich <blaskovi@cisco.com>
Subject: Re: Price Quote For '83 911 SC

to all, can people PLEASE give an asking price for cars they'd
like us to comment on as a point of reference??!!  Either what
the owner is asking or what you're thinking of offering?

if the owner wants $5k for the car buy it, if he/she wants
$25K pass.  I doubt that the car will need all the work you
descibe (ie engine rebuild).  I'd spend some time changing
fluids and trying to determine the condition of the
mechanics if you have reason to believe they are in
need of rebuilds.  Even trailer the car to a shop to
have them check the car out.

I normally respond to people directly with my comments (something
maybe more of us should learn to do.....) but the issue of 
folks asking the value of a car based on a few lines of description
without giving any pricing info frsutrates me.  I believe that
the more info we have on these cars (like a price range) the
better advice we can give.

Mark

Date: Thu, 15 Jun 95 08:35:00 PST
From: "RADSICKT" <radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil>
Subject: Re: Re: high-performance hype solution

Stan,

>Can't get case apart == you missed at least one fastener. Not to worry,
>they're tricky little fuckers...
Having read my Wilson book (and having screwed up alot with Type I engines) I 
carefully layed out all afsteners on the table so I could count them up.  I 
promptly found that the Haynes manual and Wilson differ in how many fasters they
say to remove.  I originally came up with 19 and then spent 20 minutes scraping 
away gunk and looking for the last one.  Then I remembered that I had to remove 
one to take off some FI part.  Ah, they are all off!

Then I started searching for the dang metal tabs to smack.  Not as prominent as 
with the Type I.  I tapped with a rubber mallet, and used a brass drift with a 
metal hammer. Crack opened but case didn't separate.

Then I cut some "all thread" rod and two blocks of particle board and using two 
counter rotating nuts I made a little spreader tool to insert in the oil 
strainer, main seal and oil filler holes.  Viola (not the big violin, the other 
one) the case halves now have an open crack all the way around.  But when I try 
to open one area, the other area closes.  I gave up on getting it done by 
yesterday (the day I drove down to LA to do a funeral with the base honor guard 
(I am the commander-type guy) and scheduled a drop off of the heads with Bieker)
so I guess I am just going to make multiple spreader tools and bang on the case 
for a few days.  I suspect that a dowel pin is happy where it has been for 20 
years and doesn't appreciate the fact that I am going to remodel it's house 
before it moves back in.

>If I'd had any sleep in the last two 
>days, I'd attempt to help you guess which one. Odds are good it's at the
>flywheel end of the case, on the bottom, or the other end of the case
>near the crankshaft hole...
Almost missed those but thank God for them how-To books!

Regarding H.G. Bieker:  Neat place -- perfect little hole in the wall with junk 
everywhere.  Definitely not a storefront.  It reminds me of the mexican 
restaurant rule #1:  Best food comes from the place with the most bug lamps and 
the smallest Margarita glasses. I'll post more about my heads once I figure out 
what we're gonna do with them (Bieker and me....)

 -Tim
radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil

>while trying to pry into my car at work.  It's fixed, but now when I 
>get up, I check the weather report, and if it's a beautiful day, I sigh, 
>get depressed, and take the van anyway.  
>
>Even with a chain link, barbed wire topped fence and company guards 
>roaming the lots we can't keep these guys at bay.  So far this week 
>they've broken into three cars and stolen radios.  Alarms don't stop 
>'em either.  They have no fear, 'cause they know nothing will happen 
>to them if they get caught.  And we're in a "good" part of NJ!

>gibbs@avionics.itt.com
>'84 944, Guards Red, In the Garage at Home

I sympathize.  My uncle has the same problem with his 928.  The
difference is that he owns the company.  He has electonic security
and several hundred employees.  But, still his 928 gets vandalized
regularly.  Luckily, no major damage so far.  The vandals seem to
be ex-employees, who are trying to torment him by breaking into his
warehouses (whichever one he is parking his car in at the time),
and partially dismantling his car.  It has caused him to loose all
joy in driving that car, because every time he looks at it, he is
reminded of these incidents.

I am in the St. Louis area and am in need of either a complete 3.0 engine or
the bottom end for my 2.7. In May I had a problem best decribed as a spoon in
the blender sound and had the engine pulled out. upon removing the heads it
seemed that the valves were hitting the tops of 2 pistons, so we did a
complete valve job on it but to no avail and the sound is still there. It is
not a consistent sound but rather comes and goes, any idea's? Also if anyone
can tell me of a good mechanic in the St. Louis it would be much appreciated

Thanks
Scott

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 11:44:37 -0600 (MDT)
From: Wilson Luther <Luther.Wilson@Colorado.EDU>
Subject: Re: Radar Detectors/Jammers

Mike--
I posted almost the same query a few months back. The consensus:
Valentine 1 is the VERY best. Bel 645STI Plus was second choice. The 
consensus also was that if a jammer is legal, it won't work. To work it 
would have to return some sort of signal to the radar/laser source, and 
that is illegal.
I had a great experience with Bel. Tandy Corp. closed all its Video 
Source outlets, and sent a lot of merchandise to Denver for discount 
sale. My son and I bought three 635STIs for $135 each. Unfortunately, 
each proved defective in one way or another (mainly giving false alarms).
I called Bel Customer Service. They replaced all three with top of the 
line 645STI Plusses, no charge. There is now a new top of the line model, 
the 745STI which includes stealth (detector detector) technology, a good 
thing to have in areas where detectors are banned. The advantage of the 
Bels is that they combine radar and laser detection, whereas the 
Valentine is only a laser detector. It is also very pricey at $399, 
especially when you have to add another couple hundred for a radar 
detector. I have has the Bel 645STIs for a couple of months now, and have 
used them on a couple of long trips. They work as advertised. No tickets.
Luther

------------------------------

Date: 16 Jun 95 14:18:42 -0600
From: Craig_Zaplatynsky-CCZ001@email.mot.com
Subject: Type IV Lifters & Cams


The July issue of European Car published an answer in their Tech Letters feature 
regarding 914/4 engine rebuilds.  Excerpts of the question and answer are as 
follows:

 - Reader Writes, "#4. Are VW Type IV 2.0 hydraulic lifters compatible and 
encouraged for use with Porsche 2.0 cam, pushrods and heads? "

 - European Car Replies, "On question 4, the VW Type 2.0 hydraulic lifters are a 
drop in replacement for the 914 motors, but you'll want t get a complete kit, 
including the stiffer valve springs for hydraulic lifters.  Your stock push rods 
will work fine with this set up, but you'll need a new camshaft designed to work 
with the special characteristics of the hydraulic lifters.  The experts we talk 
to tell us that virtually every 914 needs a new cam at rebuild time anyway, so 
this won't add to the cost too much.  You may want to choose a mild performance 
cam, one compatible with the stock injection.  We understand that Automotion is 
going to offer both stock and performance versions of the Type IV hydraulic cam 
and kits for the 914.  Hydraulic lifters are a highly recommended swap because 
air-cooled motors depend on correct valve adjustment for best engine life, and 
hydraulics are always adjusted correctly.  We understand the motor is quieter 
and produces more power and less emissions as it's always adjusted correctly."

This seems like a good argument for hydraulics and I know that this has been 
discussed here before, but I'd like additional clarification from Stan and 
others who have knowledge/experience with lifters and cams.  Is this really a 
good idea for a 2.0 liter 914 ?

Craig Z.
'74 914 2.0L

------------------------------

Date: 16 Jun 95 14:17:01 -0600
From: Craig_Zaplatynsky-CCZ001@email.mot.com

I feel bad about not knowing the last 3 on the list, and had profesional help 
for the first 6.  

My brief descriptions as taken from the "Illustrated Porsche Buyers Guide" by 
Dean Batchelor.

#1 - 901:	1963 - Prototype 6 cyl sports car

#2 - 907:	1968 - sports racing coupe, short tail, right-hand drive

#3 - 916:	1967 - DOHC Racing engine version of 901
		        1968 - 5-speed transmission for 908/01, 908/02
		        1971 - Projected 2.4 liter version of 914/6

#4 - 930:	1974 - 911 based Turbo and Turbo Carrera

#5 - 934:	1975 - Group 4 racing 930 Turbo coupe

#6 - 936:	1976 - Group 6 turbocharged spyder

#7 - 956:	?

#8 - 961:	?

#9 - 964:	?


I tried,

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 95 16:00:34 EST
From: "Thwen Chaloemtiarana" <chaloemt@vrinet.com>
Subject: No more oil changes? Purifiner? No P-content.

P-folks,

Anyone heard of an outfit in Boynton Beach, FL that makes an oil filtration 
system called Purifiner?  I saw an article on Headline News a few weeks ago.  
Apparently, you buy the kit, hook it up, put oil in your car, then change the 
filter and send an oil sample to the company periodically.  But the oil stays 
in there for years!

According to H-news, it is in service on Jacque Cousteau's Calypso (that huge 
floating laboratory), and several trucking companies.

If cost is not prohibitive, would there be enough value-added in not having to 
recycle all that oil to warrant eventual switchover to this technology?  (Not 
that I want to, just wondering. . .Not as a cost- but rather environmental-
conscious issue)

TIA, Thwen.

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 95 16:47:48 EDT
From: cohen@ATB.Teradyne.COM (steve cohen)
Subject: Re: No more oil changes? Purifiner? No P-content.

One of the obstacles to overcome with this approach is that many of the additives that are put in oil are sacrificial.  It's likely that they will need to be replaced long before the oil "wears out"

 -Steve

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 13:56:22 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: No more oil changes? Purifiner? No P-content.

I saw the news story also.  It sounds like a sophisticated version of
the Frantz filter, which my cousin used in his fleet cars 25 years
ago.  The filter element was a roll of toilet paper--you just replaced
the toilet paper, never the oil.  Really.  And it apparently worked.

The downside was that the car manufacturers didn't approve of it, so
it voided any warranty.

I guess if it makes your day to use it in a diesel truck, that's one
thing.  But I wouldn't burden a sports car with more plumbing.

Putting oil in the ground, IMO, is recycling in its purest form.
That's where it came from in the first place :-).

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 15:41:45 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: Type IV Lifters & Cams

In response to text from Craig_Zaplatynsky-CCZ001@email.mot.com:

>- European Car Replies, "On question 4, the VW Type 2.0 hydraulic lifters 
>are a drop in replacement for the 914 motors, but you'll want t get a 
>complete kit, including the stiffer valve springs for hydraulic lifters.  
>Your stock push rods will work fine with this set up, but you'll need a 
>new camshaft designed to work with the special characteristics of the 
>hydraulic lifters.  The experts we talk to tell us that virtually every 
>914 needs a new cam at rebuild time anyway, so this won't add to the cost 
>too much.  You may want to choose a mild performance cam, one compatible 
>with the stock injection...

>Hydraulic lifters are a highly recommended swap because 
>air-cooled motors depend on correct valve adjustment for best engine life, and 
>hydraulics are always adjusted correctly.  We understand the motor is quieter 
>and produces more power and less emissions as it's always adjusted correctly."

>Is this really a good idea for a 2.0 liter 914 ?

I'll let everyone know how they work when I get my new engine fired up(soon).

During my rebuild, I chose a FAT Performace FI Type IV Cam and the 
corresponding lifters to match.  Should offer a *mild* performance increase
while still supporting the FI system.  I think I'll be happy with it.

Unfortuneately, I had already sent the heads to the shop for rebuilding when
I ordered the cam/lifters and therefore didn't get the stiffer springs. I 
plan on swapping the stock ones out when the time comes for the first 
top-end rebuild.

Could someone explain to the un-initiated why hydraulics ensure that the
valves hold their adjustment?

Regards,

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 95 17:29:57 EST
From: mark_salvetti@ABBSMTP.abb.com (mark salvetti)
Subject: Re: 911 Child Seats

          Well, I thought I would thank everyone who has posted
          suggestions and offered advice, and then provide a summary
          of what seems to be available.

          Generally, no one seems to have found a US-made seat that
          will fit in the rear of a 911.  Part of the problem is that
          the seatbelts are mounted too far forward, and part has to
          do with the shape of the seat bottom.

          I currently use the type of restraint that consists of a
          flat steel, plastic-coated backing plate that has padding
          and a 5-point harness attached to it.  To use it with the
          911 I have to stuff a pillow behind it to take up the space
          between the forward mounted belts and the seat back.  I
          think this is safe, but I would like something that works
          better.  This type of restraint is offered in the One Step
          Ahead catalog.

          The inflatable seat offered by Imparts looks interesting,
          but is only good up to 40 lbs.  My son is 30-35 lbs, and I
          know I'll still need some type of restraint once he's over
          40 lbs, so this one is out.

          Maria Duryee and Vol Spalding sent me the phone number for a
          dealer (AFN) in Chiswick, England.  AFN told me that they
          sell two seats made by Porsche that should fit my 1979
          (without a 3-point rear harness).  The cheapest is 175
          British pounds, exclusive of VAT.  They said they ship about
          one a month to the US.  It is designed to fit perfectly in
          the rear 911 seat.  It is the only seat available in the UK
          that will fit.  If you want a leather seat, they have
          another style for 350 pounds.  This seat will supposedly fit
          children up to 9 years old (as if a 9 year old would
          actually sit in a car seat). If anyone is interested, AFN's
          number is 011-44-1-81-742-7700.

          Before I spend $300 plus shipping on this seat, I will look
          around a bit more.  If I find a solution, I'll post it.

          Mark_Salvett@abbsmtp.abb.com
          1979 911SC Targa

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 14:24:57 -0700
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: Re: No more oil changes? Purifiner? No P-content.

     
     


______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________

Thwen said

>P-folks,
     
>Anyone heard of an outfit in Boynton Beach, FL that makes an oil filtration 
>system called Purifiner?  I saw an article on Headline News a few weeks ago.  
>Apparently, you buy the kit, hook it up, put oil in your car, then change the 
>filter and send an oil sample to the company periodically.  But the oil stays 
>in there for years!
     
>According to H-news, it is in service on Jacque Cousteau's Calypso (that huge 
>floating laboratory), and several trucking companies.
     
>If cost is not prohibitive, would there be enough value-added in not having to 
>recycle all that oil to warrant eventual switchover to this technology?  (Not 
>that I want to, just wondering. . .Not as a cost- but rather environmental- 
>conscious issue)
     
>TIA, Thwen.
     
     Oil becomes ineffective and not usable for more than the contaminates 
     suspended in it.  If I remember correctly, the thermal cycling 
     (especially in an air cooled motor!)and mechanical stress reduces the 
     lubrication properties of the oil.  
     
     In low stress applications,such as a low specific output, slow reving 
     motor on a boat, maybe this would make sense.  I doubt you could get 
     away with it on an automobile power plant.  
     
     It's a proven fact that proper maintenance, especially oil changes 
     improves the longevity of an engine.
     
     While it's nice to be environmentally correct, I think practical 
     solutions will more readily adopted.
     
     Dan

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 09:42:56 -0500
From: Eric Yuzon <YUZONE@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>
Subject:  Antenna problems

Hi Pdudes!!

I have a small annoying problem.  My 911sc came with a power antenna
and I do not particularly like the aesthetics of an antenna in the
passenger fender.  So, I just removed it and left the black collar and metal
tube in the fender.   Most of the newer 911s have a windshield antenna. 
Does anyone have the same problem? What did you do?

 I know that the VW Golfs that have the fender antenna have available to
them a plastic antenna plug if the owner wanted the roof antenna to get
the GTi look. The only Porsches that have the roof antennas are the 928.
Putting a roof antenna is out of the question.  (Drilliing = eeek; yuck)

My options are:
1.  Radio Shack windshield antenna (foil tape type)
2.  Cellular lookalike FM antenna (any sources?)
3.  Internal whip hidden in the cabin.

What can I do about resulting antenna hole?  Does anyone know of a
good way to cover it (antenna plug?) without resorting to body work?

Eric Yuzon
80 911sc.

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 95 16:18:07 PST
From: "jim cheung" <jim_cheung@smtp.retix.com>
Subject: Re: Antenna problems

     > My options are:
     > 1.  Radio Shack windshield antenna (foil tape type) 
     > 2.  Cellular lookalike FM antenna (any sources?)
     > 3.  Internal whip hidden in the cabin.
     
     It all depends on what's important to you.  I have a very nice stereo on my 
     1985 carrera that have the worst time with a windshield antenna.  It seems 
     that a windshield antenna is not what you want if good radio reception is a 
     priority.  The reception is especially susceptible to areas with tall 
     buildings or through mountain passes.  At first, I thought this was a 
     problem with my radio.  But even with a replacement with a top of the line 
     Pioneer Premiere system did not result in improving the situation.  My 
     stereo installer informed me that this problem can be easily fixed with a 
     external antenna.  He must be right.  Since I put the old stereo in to my 
     Toyota pickup.  It sounded great!
     
     Jim...
     '85 Carrera Coupe

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 19:31:29 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Type IV Lifters & Cams

> This seems like a good argument for hydraulics and I know that this has been 
> discussed here before, but I'd like additional clarification from Stan and 
> others who have knowledge/experience with lifters and cams.  Is this really a 
> good idea for a 2.0 liter 914 ?

Sigh... Here we go again....

*NO*. Absolutely, incontroverably *NO*. That is the word; there is no other.
**NO**

Reasons, in Four Sections:

Section I: Evil Between The Lines -- What's Wrong with Car Mags

1) reading car magazines where editorial policy is set by advertising sales
   considerations (like *ALL* of the for-profit mags) for any kind of technical
   detail and expecting it to be unbiased and correct is like asking 
   Dan Rather to read the evening news from the National Enquirer. Sure, 
   it's *INTERESTING* but it's not necessarily all right. Not necessarily
   all wrong either, but it's damn sure not all right. And guess what?
   Joe Average will never know the difference until it's too late.

2) these mags are writen by journalists who want to be car guys. Real car
   guys are too damn busy making cars work to write most of the time. There
   are exceptions, but they are *VERY* easy to spot: it's a tech tip
   column, the author is *CLEARLY* identified and has impeccaible credentials,
   and he has no financial benefit derived from any suggestion or promotion.
   In the Porsche world, mmmm, that's *EXACTLY* one. (side story: the former
   car editor for many, many years of a no longer existant major metro paper
   has been a personal friend of mine for a long time. If he was really
   lucky, he's be able to go down the feature list in the marketing crap
   and tell you why a given feature was supposed to be good. Inevitably, 
   he would fail to be able to identify *where* on the car it was... And
   lots of folks lived and died by his Wednesday car reviews...)

3) even if the article is written by someone of the highest caliber with the
   best possible intent (our own Jim  Pasha's work in Execellence comes to
   mind), it still has to make it past the editor. You may not realize it,
   but all articles are but to fit the space around the ads. Sometimes, the
   not-a-car-guy editor will rip out whole sections that have KEY information
   about the caveats associated with other sections, leaving you the reader
   to draw inappropriate conclusions based on what's left. 

Moral: don't trust the for-profit car mags. Enjoy the ads, enjoy the pictures,
even enjoy the articles. Just don't believe any of it.

Section II: I Just Want to PUMP... You Up: Hydrualic Lifters

The Type IV engine was designed to be flexible. It was *NOT* a Porsche 
design, and was really not even built to Porsche specs -- it just happened
to be on the shelf and handy when the original VW-Porsche handshake deal 
was done that created the 914. On the VW side of the house, the target was
to do a couple of things: increase the life of the core engine, deal with
SIGNIFICANTLY hotter running environment (the 411/412) than the Type I,
and provide the evolution for the next generation Type II engine. That's
why the case is thicker, made of aluminium instead of magnesium, has bigger
oil passages, etc. On the Porsche side, that turned to be an advantage 
as it let you put in more power.

The hydraulic setup was designed for the 412, where service was effectively
impossible. (Ever worked on one? I have. Girlfriend in high school had one.
Nice car, impossible to work on..) There was *SIGNIFICANT* motivation to
keep from having to adjust the valves. Shit, even I would lie about having
done so... Alas, the 412 died out, and as the engine went into the Type II,
the hydraulic cam was kept for the same reasons. Now, NOTE THIS: both of
these applications had several things in common: low engine speed, high
heat, VW owners where the motivation to follow the service manual seemed
inbred. We'll get back to that...

What you do when you put a hydraulic cam in a 914 is use something that
was *NEVER* engineered by the factory to do this job. And further, I can
just about certify that it was *NOT* engineered by anyone in the aftermarket.
They just said, roughly, "oh cool -- we can take this part from here, and
this part from there, and hey, it's a 914 hydraulic cam kit!"

So how do you make sure that the followers track the cam? Well, you design
them so that they just do. *OR* you put in *BIG* springs to make damn sure
that they do (which may wear the bottom surfaces off the followers or just
eat the surface of the lobes, which ever is softer). How do you keep the
lifters from either pumping up solid, or going soft (depending on the
design flaw you wish to exploit here)?? Well, if this is engineered for the
application, you know what sort of specific heat you have to face, the
oil recommended, the filtration used, etc and you cope with it. *OR*
you have a part that is for a different application and can't as a result
say for sure that won't happen.

This is not to say that all hydraulic lifters are evil -- if they're designed
in by the engine's designers, and you operate the engine within its service
envelope, they're GREAT. I've even built dragster engines with hydraulic
lifters...

But it very much *IS* to say that you gotta have the right stuff. In this
case, you want the right cam grind to start with, and the right valve timing.
Then you gotta have the right slope on the lobe, so that you don't dig in
too much and cause the internal bits of the lifter to drag on each other and
stick. Then you gotta make sure -- really sure -- that the oil is as thick
as it needs to be, and as clean as it needs to be so that it meters out of
the internal lifter valving just right. And then the pushrods have to be
right so that they aren't 100% stiff so as to somewhat cushion the load
but don't collapse from being overly flexible, and you gotta get the
valve springs right to make sure that the valve closes properly and the
follower tracks the lobe with the right pressure.

No one has ever convinced me that they had all this for the 914.

Now, if that's not enough, consider this: you have a car that is supposed
to have the valves adjusted with some frequency -- 3000 to 6000 miles or
so. So you put in the new hydraulic cam. You're happy -- that's your
last ever valve adjustment. Now lets say that for some reason -- you're
busy, you sell the car, your regular mechanic is out sick, whatever --
someone that does not know that this car has hydraulic lifters is the
next to adjust the valves. Ever look at the specs on how to adjust hydrualic
valves? They're *VERY* different than mechanical valves. And just looking from
the heads, you *CAN'T* *TELL* that it has a hydraulic cam. So it get's a
regular mechanical cam adjustment. If you're really lucky it makes enough
noise that you figure it out before you get to see the next valve adjustment
happen on an engine rebuild stand.

What is it that I keep seeing on someone's signature: "be very happy that
the previous owner took good care of your car". Yeah. That. It's missing
BIG TIME in this conversion.

Section III: True Confessions

Go back and grab the archives from '90, and you see that I come off big
time  in favor of using hydraulic cams in 914. Ease of maintenence. We've
had the pump up thing whipped for *YEARS* in the 'muriken V8 world. The
mags say it's just the thing. Etc.

Yup. I said it all. I meant it all. Then I got bit by it all. Started looking
into *WHY*. Did the engineering work that needed to be done to determine
what was wrong. Determined that I hadn't the time nor facilities to re-do
all the work that needed to be done to get it RIGHT. 

Concluded that hydraulic valves were *NOT* the right answer for 914s. Or,
if you will, that I had previously been wrong. So there.

Section IV: Finis

There is no reason to believe that with readily availble parts that can
be cobbled together that *ANYONE* in the biz will actually put the time
into re-engineering this stuff correctly. That's not to say that they 
might not SAY that they will, but the economics just don't work that
way. It's cheaper to say "so sue me" every so often over a $150 part 
than it is to do The Right Thing.

That however does not deminish the notion that a correctly done hydraulic
cam would not be thing of joy. It's just that about 10k miles in,
it's more like a thing of dog doo.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 18:49:29 -0700
From: cjk50g@ix.netcom.com (Christopher Woodward)
Subject: RE: 944 clutch

Darren,

I suppose many theories exist as to the demise of rubber centers.  It 
is a problem as, in my personal observations and experience with 
mechanics, 70-90% don't eventually wear out.  They break!

I don't think this is common with most cars, and this lends itself to 
how 944(S) should be cared for (as well as maybe some 911's).  The 
rubber wears out because in its life time it has seen all the twisting 
it can take.  This twisting comes from basicly two things: The natural 
acceleration/deceleration through the driveline and the 
engagement/disengagement of the clutch by the operator.  The former we 
can not (or will not) do much about, but we can always practice 
smoothing out the latter (I hope going through a clutch a year was an 
exageration on your part). 

When we learned how to drive, we were always taught to minimize clutch 
wear by minimizing slippage, or the time that we are on it.  In  the 
small amount of distance it takes the 944's (and most Euro cars) clutch 
to engage, this becomes pretty easy.  Problem is, we got too used to 
the accompanying forward/backward jerkyness that came from not mating 
the revs well.  This jerkyness really helps kill that rubber center.

So, now we have two evils to dance between.  Wearing it out by slipping 
too much, or breaking it by poor, less than seemless, engagement.  I've 
let the failure stats tell me the lesser evil:)

Chris
944S

------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 22:19:19 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: 911 2.7 Engine Questions

The warm up regulator on these cars seems to a constant source of 
problems. My '76 got progressively worse on temperature correction until 
I replaced it. Do you have your air pump working? Sometimes having a 
richer (unburned mixture) in the exhaust can cause backfiring, as can an 
overly rich mixture. The dipstick is inside the oil filler neck. Be sure 
not to add oil unless the level is low at idle and at full warmup 
temperature. Otherwise the dry sump system will appear to be low on oil 
when it's just attributable to the oil being to cool or the engine not 
being at idle.
Dave Christiano, Springfield, Missouri
1974 914/6 3.0 liter
1976 911S
1986 930

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 21:57:40 -0700 (PDT)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: UNGO ???

Craig -

You wrote:
> My 88 911 has a small red light labeled UNGO between the flasher and mirror heater buttons on the console, 
> does anyone know what this is?  I think it might be an alarm or disabler but don't know, the light has never 
> come on.  If anyone know what this is I would sure like to know how to activate/deactivate.  Where the 
> control box might be located and how to contact the manufactuer to get a manual!  

Yes, the red light is the indicator to tell you that the alarm is on or 
off. THe unit used to be made by Techne Electronics located in Palo Alto, 
California.  Techne was bought out by Clarion, Inc. about two months 
ago (the company only and the name Ungo, not the name Techne Electronics).  
The alarm is probably a remote activated unit which has been their 
common on/off activation for many years.  The "brain" as they call it is 
probably located under the dash or in the 911 more certainly located 
under the front trunk carpet near or around the fuse box area.  From what 
I understand, Techne is still warrantying their previous sales including 
fixing broken units, while Clarion (Ungo) is now manufacturing the new 
alarms and doing their own warranty on the equipment they produce.  
Previous manuals and parts are readily available from what I understand.

You can try and contact Joe at Techne.  You should be able to reach him at
415-856-8646.  

The reason I know so much is because I have two of their recent units
(1990 and 1993 models) and one of their older units (early 80's).  I also
take care of their heating and air conditioning equipment on their
buildings. 

I have had great success with their equipment including the optional 
garage door opener switch that is part of the remote unit that goes on
your key chain.

Good luck.

Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 16 Jun 1995 22:30:28 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Solution to Michell's Valentine Problems

Michell Feig (mitchsf@shadow.net) wrote:

>while I think the Valentine is fantastic, there are a few things about 
>it that bother me to no end.  First, they use a RJ11 phone jack for 
>power connection.  This is a standard telephone connector, not meant 
>to be plugged and unplugged daily.  They last about 2 or three months, 
>each.  
>Second, the mounting bracket doesn't hold the unit securely, and the 
>plastic cracks easily (although the last one I got at no charge, has 
>lasted about 6 months).  Third, you must reset the mode every time you 
>start the car.  This is OK if you want to use its most sensitive 
>setting, but I need the full logic mode, and I have to reset every 
>time I start the car.

Mitch:

I own two Valentines.  One's permanently mounted in an enclosure 
against the rear window of my 914, and the other is shared between two 
other vehicles.  I've had to solve all three of the problems you're 
having.

The first one's easy:  Cut the telephone cord and put more-suitable 
connectors on the cut ends; instead of plugging and unplugging the cord 
from the Valentine, you can simply plug/unplug the new connectors.

If you're not using the Remote Display Module, you only need two of the 
four conductors; a simple mini-plug/jack (like a headphone plug/jack) 
will work fine.  If, like me, you use the Remote Display, you'll need a 
slightly-more esoteric connector.  Actually, you could go the easy 
route and just buy a short telephone cord (like, for a wall-mount 
telephone -- about 8 inches long) and an inline telephone-cord coupler. 
Both are sold at Radio Shack.

The second problem was easy for me, too, but may not work for you and 
your car:  Throw away the mounting bracket, buy some Velcro, and put a 
strip or two on your dash with matching pieces on the Valentine.  Aside 
from anything else, this keeps the Valentine off your windshield, where 
it can be easily seen by any peace officer.  This is useful even if you 
don't live in an area where detectors are illegal, since there's no way 
you'll talk your way out of a ticket if the cop sees by your taste in 
automotive accessories that you're an obvious compulsive speeder.

Because the detector in my 914 is mounted in an enclosure against the 
rear window, the button became inaccessible.  This was a huge problem 
for me, since I also run the thing in "L" mode.  A note to Mike 
Valentine (delivered thru "Unka" Bart -- Thanks!) immediately got me a 
"remote button" wiring diagram.  The remote button just shorts one of 
the two data lines in the 4-conductor telephone cable to ground, so I 
built a simple microcontroller-based circuit, spliced into the 
telephone cord, that "presses" the button twice whenever the unit's 
powered up.  If you have no software experience, yuo could probably do 
the same thing with a 555/556 or two.  I also ran a couple wires out to 
a real button on the dash so I could mute the audio when I wanted to.

The Valentine setup in my 914 is ideal:

1.  The detector's mounted where it has an unobstructed view thru the
    front and rear windshields.

2.  It's fully enclosed (except for the front lens, which had to remain
    uncovered for the laser detector), so I don't have to worry about
    tempting would-be thieves and/or forgetting to pull it out of the
    glovebox and plug it in every time I get in the car.

3.  Since it's mounted right next to my right ear, I have no problems
    hearing the alarm.

4.  The Remote Display is mounted right in front of me, so cops behind
    my car don't see the detector light up like a Christmas tree when
    they switch on their radar.

Hope this helps...

 -Andy

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Sat, 17 Jun 1995 03:57:13 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Warmup regulator (was 911 2.7 questions)

A contributory factor to the warmup problem in '76 is that '76 was the
first year of the automatic warmup regulator in the 911.  The '75 was
basically the same car, but it still had the hand throttle (which I've
always been glad to have).  '76 was also the year of the disastrous
five-blade fan, but that's another matter and simple to change.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Sat, 17 Jun 1995 08:25:58 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911  2.7  Engine Questions

> 74  911  2.7  engine with the following quirks:

> 1) After warming up  to around 180 degrees (according to temp.
>gauge on instrument panel), engine has light backfires when going down
>hills with no throttle and in gear.  No problem at idle.  Same small
>backfires occur when giving gas while not in gear as engine revs back down
>to idle.  Any clues??

My 2.7 does the same thing.  It may be due to small air leaks in the 
exhaust allowing unburned fuel to ignite.  I've noticed that mine does
it when I have the mixture adjusted a bit on the rich side.  I wouldn't
worry a whole lot about it.  Maybe someone else can tell us if we
*should* worry about it.

> 2)Tough starting in morning - idle is up and down until engine gets
>warm (over 120 degrees).  My 914 has no trouble at all starting ( I realize
>I may be comparing apples and oranges here).

Sounds possibly like your warm-up regulator might be a little screwy.  I
would get a set of pressure gages and check your system and control
pressures during warm-up to see what is going on.  You may also want to
make sure your "auxiliary air device" is functioning correctly.  This thing
is supposed to stabilize the idle during warm-up, so it is suspect also.

> 3)  Finally - where the hell is the oil dip stick!!!!!!

If it is not in the tube where you add oil to the tank, then I'm stumped.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Sat, 17 Jun 1995 09:22:14 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 2.0 F/I 914 fuel system

> Reviewing the discussions on the clear plastic fuel hoses,  
> #1 are these a source of common failure?

Yes. They're ancient, made of plastic and have been under pressure for the
better part of 25 years. They're brittle and can go without warning.

> #2 are new ones available?

Not to the best of my knowledge. There are probably NOS parts around
somewhere, though. There always are if yoy have the bucks. Note however
that they *ALSO* are twenty years old....

> #3 why not use the black braded high psi hose thats use in the engine
> compartment instead of making up steel ones as discussed?

Safety. Common sense. You don't want to run gas through the passenger
compartment in a potentially porous material. Particularly if you ever
have a smoker ride with you. And, if you compete, *ALL* of the major 
sanctioning bodies say that any fuel or oil lines routed through the passenger
compartment must be of a solid metal or braided steel construction.
(BTW, we used to use 5/8" thinwall conduit for the racing 911s, and 1"
for the oil lines. *SHITLOADS* cheaper than AQP, just as effective)

> Also,  different diagrams and manuals show fuel filter ahead of fuel pump and
> some show filter after fuel pump.  Does it matter?

Depends. On the pre-75 914, the fuel filter is used as a diameter converter, 
taking 9mm hose coming from the tank down to the 7mm hose used for
distribution inside the engine compartment. Given that, you gotta do 
*SOMETHING* to make it work. But then, the fuel pump is in the rear
then too... For the racing 914s, I used a Fram HG41 filter between the
tank and the pump, then a "regular" filter at the back end of the car
before the fuel rail. And I get crap in both, even with all-new parts.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 17 Jun 1995 09:24:02 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Front Sway Bar Bushings

> My 95 968 was making a strange rubbing sound in the front end.  The problem
> turned out to be the a torn sway bar bushing.  Seems strange at less than
> 11,000 miles.  Does anyone know of after market bushings which will fit the
> front bar of an M030 equipped car (30mm)?

That *DOES* sound odd... Any marginally competent machinist can make
one from Delrin in about half an hour if you can provide a rubber one 
to go by and the relevant dimensions (or the car so he can take the
measurements).

Stan

Date: Sat, 17 Jun 1995 10:09:23 -0500 (CDT)

Subject: Re: 356 email or bulletin board

> Is there a 356 email subscription like porschephiles
> or a bulletin board for 356ers? If not,why not?

                 FIRST PUBLIC ANNOUNCEMENT

Coming this summer, there will be new model-specific subsets
of Porschephiles. This will feature sections for the 356 and 928.

Why do this, after years of saying NO? WHy *THESE* models?

1) there is very  very little bleed over from any of the 356 or 928 topics
   that apply to the other cars

2) it's an EXPERIMENT. Needed to be done, given (1) these were the
   logical cars to do it with

3) my filtering technology is a lot better than it used to be.

Here's how it will work: you sign up for either Porschephiles, in which
case you get *EVERYTHING* from all the groups, or just the 356 or 928
groups in which case you just get the material direct from those groups
*plus* anything relevant from the main Porschephiles group. Otherwise,
its' just like Porschephiles.

TARGET DELIVERY DATE IS 1 JULY 1995.

Don't be a dumbass and try to sign up before it's annouced. Sheesh.

Watch this space for further announcements.

Stan Hanks 
Porschephiles ListMeister

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 17 Jun 1995 11:35:29 -0400
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: 951S power loss-solution

You have the classic "what happened to the power" syndrone common to
specifically 89 turbos. The default boost for the car is 1.2 on the gauge. In
other words if any thing is wrong it won't go over 1.2. If everything is
right then it will go to slightly above 1.8.
Most often it is the throttle position switch which is located on the
throttle body. This is just forward of the intake manifold. On one side of
the throttle body is the cable the controls the throttle opening. On the
other side is a black plastic device that reads the position of the throttle.
This is usually the device that is at fault and I have found that most
usually it is the connection to that device that gets slightly corroded and
f**ks up the electrical system. Usually wiggling the connector does the trick
for a couple of months and then suddenly the problem reappears. The solution
is to take the connector of and use some dielectric grease on it.
Of course it could be something else but I have had this happen to my 89 and
I know of several others that had the same problem. All were solved by the
method I described.
If this works let me know. If it doesn't work let me know also. Send money if
it works!

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
11:30 am

Date: Sat, 17 Jun 1995 18:43:46 -0400
From: Red912@aol.com
Subject: Wow, that was close

I was driving to a PCA concours (as a spectator) today when suddenly my
engine started cutting out. I drove about 100 yards like this, then pulled
over to look into the engine compartment. What I saw was that the screw that
holds the coil in it's bracket had somehow loosened enough to let the coil
slide down almost out of the bracket. The (+) side of the coil was resting on
the fuel line, (that has an inline fuel filter connected with rubber hoses)
which put enough pressure on it to touch the side of the carb, where it was
arcing with a big spark. Good thing I wasn't stuck in traffic where I
couldn't pull over...jeez. If you have a 356 or a 912, you might want to make
sure this screw is tight.
Rich Lambert
unburned '68 912
'89 Carrera Targa


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 17 Jun 1995 20:47:44 -0400
From: BTARGONSKY@aol.com
Subject: 924 CIS MODS MISSING POINT!

     After seeing varying topics relating to this cross the bandwidth for
some time, I feel it necessary to respond.  Forgive me if this just sounds
like the demented ramblings of a madman.

     It has been my experience that to deliver "true" Porsche performance
form a 924 one must increase its ability to move air not fuel (necessarily)
and reduce reciprocating mass.  I have seen everything from people trying to
use their cold start valve for fuel enrichment to tweaking their oxygen
sensor via resistors, etc.  All of these methods seem to have produced no or
only marginally measurable performance gains.  Bosch and Porsche spent a
considerable amount of time and a large amount of money developing these
systems to perform correctly.  If there was a fix this easy THEY WOULD
ALREADY HAVE DONE IT!!.  There is no easy fix.  I've seen too many burned
valves and pistons, broken rods and wasted fuel to not say something.  I do
not want to see yet another 924 go to the dismantler due to lack of
information.
     In order to gain performance the two aforementioned issues must be
addressed.  Since obtaining lightweight internal engine components can be
prohibitively expensive, here are a few lesser steps you can take.  On my
cars, and the cars of my friends, these have worked.  Most, except for the
major (i.e. $$$) ones yielded very small performance gains.

- -- My exact setup is actually a lot more detailed than this and required
hundreds of hours of tuning and experimentation so don't take it verbatim;
however, for making my point it will suffice.
 
Use a K&N air filter.
Obtain and install the throttle body form a 924 turbo.
Use a mild after-market camshaft (if possible, avoid regrinds as the smaller
base circle causes severe ramp angles and possibly premature follower/lash
cap wear or even bent valves)
     Headers, a header, pardon me, are still a matter of contention.  Some
will tell you that they are definitely the way to go.  To me, headers crack,
rust out, their flanges warp, are noisy and most are of such a poor design as
to offer little or no performance gain for the tradeoffs.  Plus, if you live
in an exhaust nazi state, like Connecticut, California, Colorado etc. you
wont get away with it.  The local DMV barbarians can spot a header in an
instant, but to the other modifications they are totally oblivious, as long
as its tuned right.  I suppose you could have the exhaust manifold Extrude
Honed, I just left mine alone.

Now, if you still have any money left you could have the intake manifold
Extrude Honed and the head ported and larger valves installed.
- --BTW, Eurorace makes a big valve head which is much to the same effect as
the latter and seems to be an excellent choice if you prefer not to do the
work yourself.  I haven't seen an ad from them in a while but it was $1299.00
with your choice of cam, exchange.
     After having gone this route, it helps to use the turbo injectors and
their requisite insulators (yes, the insulators are different, even the
dealer did not believe me).

     THE POINT IS,  just what are you trying to prove.  Do you ask a 356 to
go 200 MPH?  Do you like to build engines and spend lots of money?  I suppose
if you spend extended periods of time at or over 95 MPH like me you may
really need this.  Even after all this I still have only 185 real horsepower
(runs at 11.6:1 A/F  to a perfect stoichiometric 14.7:1 with an otherwise
factory stock fuel injection) even with the lightened rods, albeit a 70 hp
gain, but at a large expense.  If you want to put effective money into your
924, put it in the suspension and tires.  Springs, larger anti-sway bars,
shocks, and plus 1,2,3 performance radials work wonders.  
     In any case which would you like to run out of first at speed, power or
handling?  With the former you don't win the race, loose that pesky state
trooper or dust that Camaro.  With the latter, you DIE!!  If you want all out
speed, start saving for your 993.

Feel free to pick my brain, a have a vast body of information.  Also, if you
know something TELL ME.  I am always learning and will never chastise someone
for telling me something I already know.

Ignore me at your own risk,

Brian E. Targosnky

Won't say what car exactly, now that the (freakin' expensive) cat is out of
the bag.

Date: Sun, 18 Jun 1995 05:16:57 +0000 (GMT)
From: wayne@aprf.arl.mil
Subject: Re: corroded exhaust stud

A solution to the problem of exhaust studs corroding and breaking that I have
used on other makes might also be applicable to Porsches - take an original to
a machine shop and have them make up a set out of A-286.  This is a 
high-tensile, aerospace grade stainless.  A-286 nuts are readily available in
US threads, not sure about metric threads, altho I would expect that Kaynor
makes those too.

Expect to supply the A-286, most toolrooms don't stock it unless they do a lot
of aerospace work (must admit even the machine shops here on the Missile Range
don't have it).  A-286 is pretty much just used for fasteners, so only a 
fastener producer or steel service center is likely to have it.  It is about
a Grade 8 in tensile, compared to the grade 4 for standard 18-8 stainless.

- -- 
Wayne Flowers                 Voice:  505-678-8303
Senior Scientist              Fax:    505-678-6049
Science & Technology Corp.    E-mail: wayne@aprf.arl.mil
White Sands, New Mexico       URL:    http://aprf.arl.mil/

Porschephiles #1490                         Mon Jun 19 02:00:09 CDT 1995
Date: Sun, 18 Jun 1995 02:15:21 -0500
From: Ezra Goldman <ez@chi.shl.com>
Subject: re: C4 brake startup delay


A while back someone asked about the time it takes for the brake
system warning lights to go out when starting up their C4.

On my C4 the light will stay on for about 15-30 seconds when I 
first start the car; longer if I haven't driven for a few days.

The hydraulic system on the C4 combines to serve the needs of the 
brake & clutch assist and the drive locks. A pressure accumulator
keeps pressure ready, and a pump fills the accumulator when pressure
drops. The delay on startup is the pump cycling to build pressure.
The pump will run any time it's needed; typically depressing the brakes
three to five times depletes enough pressure to cause it to run during
driving.

I was recently sensitized to the brake system on my C4 when I lost 
assist as I approached a red light. When I pressed delicately on the 
brake pedal (as we that are spoiled by power assist are wont to do)
it was like pressing on a rock. Surprise! I stomped more firmly and
discovered (re-discovered?) standard (i.e. non-power assisted) braking.
I stopped about 2 inches from the rear bumper of the guy ahead of me.

I drove the car over to the dealer where they determined that the ABS
control unit had failed and disabled the hydraulically assisted brake 
booster. Porsche, to their credit, fixed the problem, parts and labor
on my 4 year old, 20k mile, car. The new pump caused a hum when it ran
and a click if the radio was on when it stopped. Porsche suggested that
the dealer add an additional grounding wire and the hum is mostly gone.

Ez Goldman
ez@interdyn.com
'91 C4

Date: Sun, 18 Jun 1995 05:39:21 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: LeMans Update -

 Two McLarens were leading midway through a rain-soaked
 Le Mans 24 Hours race, where Mario
Andretti led his team back into contention after an early accident Saturday. 

An all-British team of Andy Wallace and the father-son 
combination of Derek and Justin Bell led with a McLaren BMW F1
GTR with 142 laps, or 1,931.2 kilometers (1,200 miles), on the 
13.6-kilometer (8.45-mile) circuit. 

Another McLaren with Yannick Dalmas of France, J.J. Lehto of 
Finland and Massanori Sekiya of Japan was less than a lap
behind. 

The Courage-Porsche C34 of Andretti and Frenchmen
 Bob Wollek and Eric Helary was in third after a long battle to come
back after dropping to 27th following an accident by Andretti after four hours. 

Rain began shortly after the start of the race and continued, causing a 
number of accidents. 

Just before dark, Andretti skidded while coming up behind a car, 
spun and hit a wall. He was second at the time, just more
than a minute off the lead. His car had damage on the right side and rear 
wheel and lost its rear wing. He was uninjured. 

Andretti said he hit mud that caused him to crash. ``You can't go on
the brakes on that stuff, it's so loose. I spun and hit the
wall,'' Andretti said. ```It was not that hard. We just kissed the wall just 
enough. It just was something we didn't need.`` 

He made it back to the pits, but the car needed nearly 30 minutes to get 
repaired before returning to the race more than six
laps behind. 

Once back on the track, the Courage car consistently ran laps a
few seconds faster than the McLarens in the rain and
overtook a number of cars. 

After restarting in 27th, the car moved back to eighth over the next
four hours. Then Andretti got into the car again just after
midnight and brought it into third, four laps behind, by the 12-hour mark. 

``I was in a groove,'' Andretti said. "I was in a groove all along except 
for that surprise early.'' 

He found the wet track was in worse condition in 
the early-morning hours. ``It was atrocious. It's like a slime, an oil mix
and mud,'' Andretti said. 

Johnny Nielsen of Denmark and Germans Thomas Bscher 
and Jochen Mass led for nearly 10 hours driving a McLaren
BMW F1 GTR and were in the top spot before dropping 
back just before the 12-hour mark with clutch problems.

engine and comes out pretty easily. You can unplug it first to see
if thats the problem.

Date: Sun, 18 Jun 1995 08:07:47 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: corroded exhaust stud

Morning Wayne,

One of the old time solutions that was used on 'merican iron was brass 
nuts on the exhaust manifold.  These held well.  If the stud corroded you 
still could get the nut off.  Need brass metric nuts?  Well for 13 mm I 
use 1/2" brass hex and tap them with a metric tap. You can purchase 1/2" 
brass hex in bulk length.  These could be made long enough for your use 
to cover the entire exposed threaded area of the stud.  

I also use Anti-seize compound on all of these studs.  This helps prevent 
corrosion and forms a sealent for the threads that are in contact with 
the nut.  It helps when you take them off.

BTW for those of you following this thread, 8 mm X 1.25 mm nuts that are 
normally found on P-Cars with 13 mm wrench flats can also be had with 
12mm wrench flats.  Check out the Nissan-Toyota type cars.  This extra mm 
of clearance is especially helpful in the exhaust area of early model 911 
turbos.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974

Date: Sun, 18 Jun 1995 13:49:57 -0500 (EST)
From: ANDRUC00@SNYBUFAA.CS.SNYBUF.EDU
Subject: Re: 924 CIS MODS MISSING POINT

    My whole point of creating my system, was not designed to produce more
power, but to increase gas milesage. Acording to the numerouse porsche books
that i own, the 944's with the computer controlled fuel had a much better
mileage rating that the old electromech, 924 CIS. My whole purpose, was to
develop an active, closed loop system to increase mileage, without detering
from performance... I also designed it to cope with a supercharger which
will increase air flow, thoughMy system will help keep the system in Check
and allow me to manually tune it i/e to the richer or leaner side, as i 
choose to fit the situation. That was my purpose, to improve mileage...

Dave...
Andruc00@snybufaa.cs.snybuf.edu
'79 924 in REstoration....

Date: Sun, 18 Jun 1995 13:17:03 -0500 (CDT)
From: Paul Christopher Schlesselman <pcs0001@jove.acs.unt.edu>
Subject: Re: 951S power loss - Part 2

On Sat, 17 Jun 1995, Scott Alexander wrote:

> Dear friends,
> 
> 	A couple of days ago I posted a message about the eratic turbo
> performance of my 89 951S. I took the car out on "the back roads" and did 
> some "research" into the problem. It appears that sometimes under hard 
> acceleration my boost gauge won't go over 1.2 bar. The next time I try, 
> it pushes up to at least 1.8 bar under the same conditions previously 
> (this is when I feel the "turbo rush" that we know and love). What's up? 
> Does anyone know what the maximum boost should be on a stock 951S? Is my 
> wastegate performing improperly?
> 
> 	In looking at the past service records I noticed the Turbo Timed 
> Valve had been replaced. What's that and could that be the cause of my 
> performance delima.

This valve might still be a problem.
that little valve baried under the intake manifold
is about 60mm diameter and has 3 vacuum houses going to it.
It controls the waste gate via DME signals.
It might be malfunctioning, but first I would
check hoses and connections for good flow and sealing.

(a hose broke of my T-valve, the result being the wastegate NEVER opened
resulting in overboost - DME shuts off fuel-injectors when that happens)
> 
(Call Paul in Denton at 817 660-0949 if you like)

> 	Any help would be greatly apprecieated. Have a nice day and happy 
>  Porsching.
> 
> Scott Alexander
> Dallas, TX
> 89 951S
>

Date: Sun, 18 Jun 1995 15:06:37 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Concealed Radar Detectors

>I hope that this question is relevant.  I am looking for a radar detector 
>that can completely be concealed.  Radar detectors are illegal where I 
>live and what I need is a radar detector that is totally concealed, with 
>a small switch to turn on the unit and perhaps a small led that will 
>flash when a radar is detected.  Usually the sound from the radar 
>detector is loud enough to be heard even if the unit is hidden in the dash.

Melissa,

I gather from your userid that you are posting from Singapore...

Given recent reports of punishment there, are you sure that you want to 
break the law?  It would not be nice to hear that a porschephile was flogged 
for using an illegal radar detector...

Given that radar detectors are illegal, keep in mind that there are several 
types of radar detector detectors (units that can determine the presence of 
a radar detector in a vehicle by detecting the heterodyning frequencies used 
within a radar detector...)

That having been said, there are several manufacturers of remote radar 
detectors and several detectors which can be easily modified to do what you 
want...
Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net

(although he races EP in the SCCA)  I have never heard of a problem like
this before and was wondering if anyone could shed some light on this, like,

come up with is oversized valve guides and this sounds like it could be a
real pain.  Anyone know maybe WHY this happened?  When we put the valve
guides in, we did the std. heat the head, chill the guides, and they still
had to be driven in with a drift.

Date: Sun, 18 Jun 1995 20:49:49 +0000 (GMT)
From: wayne@aprf.arl.mil
Subject: Re: corroded exhaust stud

Regret I cannot at all recommend brass for any auto application - the stuff
is simply too soft and weak - tensile is probably around a grade 2.  If you have an aversion to stainless and don't mind a weak tensile then I recommend 
monel fasteners - or titanium, both far superior to brass.

- --

Senior Scientist              Fax:    505-678-6049
