Date: Sun, 18 Jun 1995 15:54:43 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 Valve Guide Problem

> Anyway, I recently pulled off the heads to trace down an
> exhaust leak (long story :)) and noticed that the valve guides are
> loose...ie you can move them with your FINGER.  I was talking with a local
> 914 guru and found out that he just had the same problem with his 1.8
> (although he races EP in the SCCA)  I have never heard of a problem like
> this before and was wondering if anyone could shed some light on this, like,
> how in the hell I am supposed to fix this!?   

That's pretty odd. I'm used to seeing valve guides where the bore of the
guide is out of round, but not LOOSE in the head...

> The only thing that I can
> come up with is oversized valve guides and this sounds like it could be a
> real pain.  Anyone know maybe WHY this happened?  When we put the valve
> guides in, we did the std. heat the head, chill the guides, and they still
> had to be driven in with a drift.

Hmm. Sounds roughly correct. I usually press the guides in with an arbor
press and ream them to the correct size, per The Book. Never have any 
trouble with that.

I've got a couple of thoughts:

1) the guide holes are in fact oversized. There's some chance that this could
   happen, but it's not real likely. In fact, there's not even a spec in
   the spec book for checking that dimension. 

2) you had defective guides. That's real unlikely, as the wear would be
   along the guide path, NOT on the outside.

3) you have *WAY* screwed up valve train geometry. That's possible. If the
   valve stem is mainly being pushed side to side instead of straight up
   and down, then you *USUALLY* get oval shaped guide interiors and funny
   wear patterns on the valve stem.

4) your installation was flawed. This is most likely. You did't use the 
   right method. What else didn't you do? Did you check the resulting ID 
   of the guide? Did you check the OD of the valve stem? Did you check the 
   clearance between the valve stem and the guide? Did you check the
   "rock" (i.e. how much side-to-side end play you have)?? And, of course,
   it's entirely possible that you really didn't get the guide to go in
   all the way with the heat-and-beat technique you used. 

Suggestion: just on the off chance that something *IS* wrong with the heads,
send them off to one of the more competent places to have it all checked
out and made right. I tend to prefer H.G. Bieker for anything I don't
do myself. Super high grade service. You get a little attitude with that,
and there are cheaper people, but damn few better.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 18 Jun 1995 15:56:46 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Battery Drain

> I have '89-C4.  the battery completely drains after 5-6 days without use.
>  Why?  

There is something drawing current. It's not like the electrons just drain
off onto the floor...

> how do I correct this??

Have a competent shop that specializes in automotive electrical problems
check this out. Hint: it's likely to be some aftermarket doo-dad that was
added incorrectly. I had this problem in my 911SC, turned out to be a
power amp wired directly to the battery that did in fact *NOT* turn itself
off when the stereo head unit was down...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 1995 02:31:42 +0100 (METDST)
From: Morten Christian Holmgreen <joker@diku.dk>
Subject: Braking at track-events

Hi,

I have a couple of questions for you track-gurus and instructors, since
I've been told different things by different people (and read differently
in Vic Elfords book), and I'd like to know what's the best and why...:


(1) When for instance braking at the end of a long straight - why should
    you downshift through the gears (4-3-2)?

    Isn't it better to just (a) declutch (b) put gently it in second during 
    your brake (or whatever needed at the turn) (c) brake hard (d) heel-and-
    toe some revs to the engine and engage the clutch when you're about 
    finished braking.

    If (1) the brake balance is adjusted perfect such that the front locks
    just a fraction before the rear and (2) your brakes can handle the
    heat - wouldn't the downshifting through the gears (and engage the
    clutch) actually upset the balance in the car?

(2) When braking hard (again :-) ) - should you press down the brake-pedal
    40% first and then do for max preassure or should you just go for max
    pressure immediately and as fast as you can. (Vic Elford says do the 
    40% first to move weight to the front - and then go for max. preasure).


I'd like to know what's the best way of braking - especially after a long
brake. I'm having a tough time getting used to braking as late as I should
so I'd like to know the optimal way before experimenting with later braking.

Thanks,

Christian

Subject: Brakes From Hell

Ive posted this problem before with no response, but Im repeating it
again with the hope that I can get some ideas about the solution to a 
really serious brake problem Im having.

Ive got an 86.5 928S whose ABS brakes come on by themselves when Im
driving.  It can happen at any speed.  It starts with slight dragging
in the front and the brakes slowly begin to apply themselves.
Strangely enough, if I sense it happening, I can stop it by pulling
up on the brake pedal.  There seems to be nothing obviously wrong
with the braking system.  I put a second return spring on the pedal,
but it did not help.

944 turbos and 911 turbos, so maybe the data base will be big
enough that someone besides 928 owners will have had similar
experiences.

Any help would be greatly appreciated.  Thanks.

Date: Sun, 18 Jun 1995 19:26:10 -0700 (PDT)
From: scokelly@netcom.com (Scott Kelly)
Subject: Re: Battery Drain (89 911 C4)

Poorsh,

Like Stan says - it could be an aftermarket drain.  It could also be a 
drain caused by the sophisticated alarm found on C2s/C4s.  There was a 
write-up in Excellence (Aug 91 pg79) that discusses one owner's problems 
with resolving the drain.  Seems a wire from his newly installed radio 
head was shaved establishing a short.  This kept the alarm from arming 
itself properly and imposed a drain b/c all alarm "inputs" are on one 
circuit.  In '91 Porsche changed it so that all system inputs are on 
different circuits.

One other Porschphile (don't remember name) had similar problem.  Let's 
see .. article says that the background draw should never exceed 15 to 20 
milliamps.

The article also mentions that even though the alarm doesn't "arm" - the 
LEDs in the door buttons flash.

How can you test to see if alarm is armed?  Do what I commonly do by 
accident- turn off car; pull handle to open front bonnet; get out of car; 
shut-door; lock car; LEDs flash; go to front of car and raise bonnet to 
remove car cover,etc ; when bonnet is raised - alarm will go off.

Good luck,
Scott (scokelly@netcom.com)


Poorsh's original follows..
> 
> I have '89-C4.  the battery completely drains after 5-6 days without use.
>  Why?  how do I correct this??
>

Date: Sun, 18 Jun 1995 23:42:51 -0400
From: Turbocamel@aol.com
Subject: P club event in Taiwan

Greetings from Taiwan!

I am in Taiwan for about a week for business and had a chance to attend a
local track event that included a Porsche Club time trial/race today (as a
spectator). 

This is the only road course in Taiwan and boy, it is tight! Approx. 1.1
miles with TWENTY-TWO (yes, 22) turns. Imagine a wide autocross course with
FIA curbing and concrete walls and Armco!  The place used to be a tea
plantation, so the locals call a spin "picking tea leaves"

About 16 Porsches were on the track, including 993s (one of them just took
delivered yesterday!), a 3.6 turbo, a 968, a 928 and a lot of C2/4's. It's an
open passing time trial. They time you for continous 16 laps with all the
cars on track at the same time(i know, it's strange). Most of the cars were
bone-stock, and most drivers were rookies. It was certainly entertaining to
watch 3-4 cars dicing on those very tight turns. The fastest car was a 88 911
with a Ruf modified 3.4 (normally asperated). Surprisingly second place went
to a stock 928.

The support race was a FIA Gr. N cars under 1.4 liters. The cars were Citroen
AX's, Nissan March, Peugeot 105 and 205's, Opel Corsas and tiny Daihatsu's.
The winning Daihatsu on slicks turned a best lap of 1'22", the exact same
time as the Ruf. Fast little cars!

I just wish i had a ride... (sigh)


 -Royce
87 930 (on the other side of the Pacific)
currently car-less in Osaka.

Date: Sun, 18 Jun 1995 22:01:31 -0700 (PDT)

Subject: Re: corroded exhaust stud

> 
> Regret I cannot at all recommend brass for any auto application - the stuff
> is simply too soft and weak - tensile is probably around a grade 2.  If you have an aversion to stainless and don't mind a weak tensile then I recommend 
> monel fasteners - or titanium, both far superior to brass.

2 cents worth, and not a tad more:

What most people guess to be brass is actually bronze.  Quite a bit
stronger, similar corrosion properties.

Gary.

The new stuff was 'rubbery' :-)

Perhaps the heat and ozone over 5 or 10 years 
change the material enough for it to break.

Happens to the tires, hoses, seals, etc. why should
clutch doughnut be any different.

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 1995 09:23:42 -0400 (EDT)
From: gp310ad@prism.gatech.edu (ROBERT DUCKWORTH)
Subject: Dirty Solvent:  Where do I dispose of it? (fwd)

>  Quick question for those of you with a solvent tank,
>  
>  What do I do with the dirty solvent?
>  
>  -Tim
>  radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil
> 
I don't know what you use for solvent. Me it's kerosene.

I'm saving the old stuff for use in a back yard foundry.

So far I have firebricks, used oil furnace pump and igniter, blower,
and some pipe. Still need crucible, stack, rig for screen and
filter.

You could also use to fire kiln.
Old oil will burn pretty cleanly too.

Beer cans make pretty good stock for aluminum castings.

 -bob

comparative review of the 914, the Fiat x1/9, the Pantera and one other
car.  As I recall, the 914 won on all fronts except top end and 0-60, which 
the Pantera won hands down.

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 1995 15:12:48 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdbg.suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Le Mans - some comments

Mario/wollek in the Courage Porsche would have won, but for the mario
spin, the car ran faultlessly for the whole 24 hours (except for
mario/wall incident)
A
It looks like they could have still won if they had changed tires at 2.00pm. 
The last set of tires were on the car for around 3 hours.
just before mario handed to wollek at 2.30pm he had been closing on the 
lead car at 10 secs per lap. After the change, the porsche slowed 
gradually to around 4.10/lap, and the gap stablised at 3 mins.

It will be interesting to read the write up, could be the porsche was 
gradually dying.

It's a shame that the bell/wallace car stalled in the pit, and the 
porsche slowed, with 2 hours to go there were 3 cars all with a chance to 
win, and it even looked like there would be a close finish

Shame about the Calloway Porsche - how do you manage to be excluded for 
being 20Kg under weight - I should think someone got fired for that!!

The Maclaren cars had gobi desert spec wipers fitted, apparently 
one car had no wipers for the whole race - and they were still lapping at 
100MPH+

For me the highlight of the weekend was changing into dry clothes at 9.00 
pm, saturday 12.00 I changed into t-shirt & shorts, by 6pm, I was wearing 
2 jumpers, denim shirt, poser porsche jacket and water proofs ( and 
shorts ) we still got soaked.

At the race start, it was around 10 deg C, the Hawain Tropic girls were 
there, in swim suits - they must have been freezing.

The sight that got the biggest cheer throughout the race, was the Marcos 
 - don't know if any of you US folks have ever seen one, but they date 
back to GT40 days and still have the same bodey design, and 6.1 litre GM 
lumps.

As of last year, the french have made it an offense to "interfere with a 
sporting event" - you can get jail for running on to the track. So to 
further discourage enthusiastic fans, the marshalls have stopped waiving 
all the flags when the cars come round for the last time. The race ended 
very subdued, nothing like the jag wins of a few years back.

As a final summary, I would say that it was a good race, but it would 
have been far better with some real factory support, we really need 
porsche, jaguar, peugeot, mercedes to make it a great race.

Pete

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 95 11:13:17 EDT
From: lwalc@mcgraw-hill.com
Subject: Re: 993 tire wear

       I have a 993 with 4,000-mi. on the odo. I run A008Ps on the street 
     and BFG R1s on the track. I'm getting decent wear on the street tires, 
     though it's too early to make any final judgment. However, my first 
     set of R1s wore very rapidly on the rear. The wear was even across the 
     face of the tire, but the tread vanished after three track days. As a 
     result, I am having the car realigned to check the rear settings, and 
     maybe to dial in a little more negative camber all around. Conclusion: 
     The 993 is hard on rear tires, and the softer the compound, the more 
     wear you're going to get.
       Anecdotally, I have heard that some owners are getting about 
     5,000-mi. from a set of rear street tires, so I don't think the wear 
     you're experiencing is out of the ordinary for spirited driving. This 
     seems to be the price you pay for driving a truly great car (and the 
     price figures to go up once you put on those new-design Yokos or 
     Bridgestones at about $440 per rear tire).
        Lee Walczak / Wash., D.C.


______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: 993 tire wear
Author:  cowan%sccsi.com@interlock.mgh.com (Ken Rentiers) at ccnode
Date:    6/19/95 06:34 AM


        Any 993 owners out there want to comment on rear tire wear? There
is a report on CompuServe by an owner claiming 4700 miles max for the rears 
(OEM Contis). This sounds a bit radical to me.

local paper (or better yet...the PANO ads).  I highly recommend it.

advertise everywhere though.

avoid confusion-the 356 cover plate is still available and is a curvy shape,

very unobtainable)  this is an NLA part, so any leads are highly welcome.

answer is that I'm hard-enough of hearing where a radio in this type of car is
worthless.  Besides I believe this 912 was originally delivered to the first
customer sans radio.(subsequent PO put some cheep piece o'shit in it which I
immediately took out...)

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 1995 11:32:32 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: 911 exhaust studs & nuts

David, thanks for the info:
 
> One of the old time solutions that was used on 'merican iron was brass
> nuts on the exhaust manifold.  These held well.  If the stud corroded you
> still could get the nut off.
 
The only problem here is that the brass is so soft that the nuts tend to
get rounded off. They also seems to swell sometimes, making it difficult
to get your wrench on.
 
I guess this is still better than the alternative, i.e. having the 
nuts permanently bonded to the studs.
 
> BTW for those of you following this thread, 8 mm X 1.25 mm nuts that are
> normally found on P-Cars with 13 mm wrench flats can also be had with
> 12mm wrench flats.  Check out the Nissan-Toyota type cars.  This extra mm
> of clearance is especially helpful in the exhaust area of early model 911
> turbos.
 
One of the most difficult experiences I've had with my 911 so far was 
getting the exhaust off, even with the motor out of the car and upside-
down on the engine stand. I was using regular 6-pt sockets with a u-joint
attached. The only way I could get enough clearance was
with a 1/4" u-joint, which wasn't really strong enough for the
job (the first one broke halfway through the job).
 
For the 911 manifolds, I think that you really need a 3/8" short socket 
that has a built-in u-joint.
 
 -Mitch


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 95 14:40:58 EDT
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: RE: 911  2.7  Engine Questions

Assuming stock CIS induction on the engine, get a 3mm allen wrench and play
with your mixture a little; it sounds rich.  Write your changes down in a 
notebook ("1/4 turn clockwise, Tuesday 5pm") along with the resulting
behavior.  Small turns have big effects:  I think the screw takes a wear
pattern so that turning just a little from where it's been the last 15 years
will make an especially big change.
Good luck
B.

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 1995 12:44:11 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: 2.7 five-blade fan

Please forgive me for this group post--I mistakenly deleted the
message posted to me (was in the middle of a reply when my connection
froze).  Meanwhile, there may be others who have advice to offer,
since I haven't done this job myself.

To Ben (who just bought a '76 911 with a five-blade fan):

In '76 and '77 Porsche tried a fan with half the number of blades that
went twice as fast.  It didn't work as well--in fact, I knew someone
whose pulley came off and bunged up his decklid when the car was
fairly new.

You need to change the fan and pulley.  If you can get by without the
air pump (depending on where you live and whom you know), the
single-stage pulley looks neater and is cheaper to buy.  Most likely
you need to change the belt as well--wouldn't be a bad idea in any
event.

This is an easy job for a Porsche mechanic, though I've not done it
myself and no doubt someone seeing this has, and can take over where I
leave off.  For the correct parts at a fair price, without padded
so-called handling charges (they only charge actual shipping), I'd
call Stoddard (800-342-1414).  I'm not on their payroll, but you won't
go wrong with them.

A front oil cooler is highly desirable, especially with a/c.  I have a
cheapie one on my '75 (Rapid Cool), and it doesn't do all that much;
if I had it to do over again I'd get the best system I could.  The
Terbatrol kit advertised in PANORAMA promises to do the job, but I
haven't used it myself.  No doubt someone else can add to this info.

Steve Gilbert
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 95 15:05:59 -0500
From: Mike Selner <mike@is.com>
Subject: 944S Coolant Problem

Hello,

I'd like the list's wisdom on a problem with a friend's
'87 944S with 100K miles.

The car is getting coolant in the oil - the evidence is mainly
found on the underside of the oil filler cap as a white scum.  No
oil scum is found in the coolant filler tank.  This began last
year and the oil cooler was suspected.  The cooler seals were
replaced along with the rod bearings.  The car then sat most of
the winter till a track event this year.  The scum re-appeared
and so the head gasket was replaced.  Again the car basically
sat till the track event and the scum re-appeared.  Now the odor
of coolant is strong and after the car is shutdown hot you can
hear a hissing if you listen at the oil filler.  The mechanic who
did the work was present and now suspects the oil cooler again.
I generally trust the mechanic as he has a lot of experience
(including Porsche dealership experience) with these cars.
I'm not sure about this diagnosis though because I would expect
to see oil in the coolant as the oil pressure is higher than
that in the water jacket.  There is some white smoke in the
exhaust under accelleration.  I am suspecting a crack in the
head - I don't know if it has been checked.  There was a
valve job done with the head gasket so I assume it was checked.

Advice/Opinions appreciated.

Mike

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 95 14:26:48 PST
From: "jim cheung" <jim_cheung@smtp.retix.com>
Subject: Re: Porsche Audio

     I installed a Pioneer 6 disc changer in my '85 Carerra coupe myself 
     under the passenger seat.  The installation took about 3-4 hours for 
     this amateur audio installer.  This setup allows me to change disc 
     packs without going to the trunk.  I chose the Pioneer changer over a 
     Sony one due to its slim size.  I needed to position the opening to 
     the rear of the seat due to the amount of hardware near the front.  
     The changer works much better than my in-dash CD player with little or 
     no skips.  As you know, the suspension of the 911 isn't exactly a ride 
     in you granny's caddy.  I found the in-dash unit not suitable for city 
     street use due to this.  Cheers!
     
     
     Jim C.
     '85 Carerra Coupe

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 1995 16:37:14 -0500
From: jeffk914@groucho.roc.servtech.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: 914 stats

>Any one know what the stats were for say  the 1.8l 914's?
>I'm looking for figures such as 0-60 and 1/4 mile times that type of stuff.
>Were they reviewed in any of the car magazines? If so anyone have the dates?

I haven't been able to find any real full reviews of the 1.8l 914 in my
searching, but I DO have the factory stats... These are for a 1975 model,
from Porsche's '75 service and training update for the 914...
For the 1.8l (76 DIN hp, 72.5 SAE hp; 125 DIN torque, 121 SAE torque):
Max speed: 107.5 mph
0-100kph (62mph, if I recall correctly): 13.5 seconds
Kilometer - 35 seconds.

Just for the record, the 2.0l: (88 DIN hp, 84 SAE hp; 137 DIN torque, 132
SAE torque):
Max speed: 113 mph
0-100kph: 12.0
Kilometer: 33.5 seconds

I dunno, my '75 1.8l sure feels a lot faster than that. :)

(Amazing the data this thing gives. Even gradient capacity, etc...)

| Jeff Kyle		 Visit my new web page!  |
| jeffk914@groucho.roc.servtech.com   car pics & |
| "Katarina" 1975 Porsche 914         more soon! |
| http://www.servtech.com/public/jeffk914/	 |

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 1995 16:56:21 -0500
From: Brian Scudder <bscudder@spdmail.spd.dsccc.com>
Subject: Re: 944 CV Joints and Transaxle Oil

Darin asks about CV Joints:
>1) What is the best type of grease to use?

I'm currently doing this, I bought the Red Line CV-2 with Moly for about
$8 a tube. I haven't tried it yet, but the Red Line products are about
the best.

>2) Is there any tricks or things to watch out for?

This is a very messy job. The black Moly grease attacks me. All I need
to do is look at it and it ends up on my face, hands, clothes,
etc... :^(

>Also, What is the best transaxle oil to use (the car will see some
> track time)?
Again I'm going with Red Line, although many use SWEPCO 501.

Brian Scudder
'83 928S (transmission waiting for a part)
'93 Redi-the-Cat (caught a mockingbird and a blue jay this weekend!)

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 1995 20:54:08 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944S Coolant Problem

Sorry to be the bearer of bad news, but sounds like
the oil cooler seals are gone again...

You may have to check the rod bearings again...

>
>The car is getting coolant in the oil - the evidence is mainly
>found on the underside of the oil filler cap as a white scum.  No
>oil scum is found in the coolant filler tank.  This began last
>year and the oil cooler was suspected.  The cooler seals were
>replaced along with the rod bearings.  The car then sat most of
>the winter till a track event this year.  The scum re-appeared
>and so the head gasket was replaced.  Again the car basically
>sat till the track event and the scum re-appeared.  Now the odor
>of coolant is strong and after the car is shutdown hot you can
>hear a hissing if you listen at the oil filler. 
Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net

Porschephiles #1492                         Tue Jun 20 02:00:09 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 19 Jun 1995 18:12:12 -0700
From: mloomis@ccnet.com
Subject:  CIS &Alternator ??

I recently purchase a 73.5 911 T. I just had a major service on the car and
everything seemed fine except for the cold start. They richened the fuel
but they said that the car was still running a bit rough because the the
injector for the cold start was only getting 10.6 volts and it required 12
to operate. Another problem I described to them was after the car was
sitting a while it would be hard to start again. They diagnosed this as the
"hot" start which is really a valve on the fuel pump. It's duty is to keep
the system pressurized. Well today after work the car was REALLY hard to
start. After about 10 minutes of careful cranking I noticed the alternator
light was on....with the key in the off position! The car finally started
and the light went out with the motor running but comes back on when the
key is in the totally off position. The light stays on with the keys out
until I move the key to the second position (right before the starter
engages)...The car had a new alternator in March and runs perfect once
warm....any ideas...?
TIA~

Marc Loomis
73 T CIS

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 1995 18:34:34 -0700 (PDT)
From: Jacob Bayless <bayless@wco.com>
Subject: Virginia City Hillclimb?

Howdy p-philers, 
	I was just wondering if anyone was going to be attending the 
Virginia City Hillclimb in V.C., Nevada this upcoming weekend.  
	Anyone interested in attending to watch is welcome!  Just outside 
of Carson City, V.C. is an old mining town with some historic gambing to 
be had.  A wonderful place to escape the S.F. Bay area for the weekend!
	The hillclimb is put on by the Ferrari Owners Club, and welcomes 
all who are serious at hillclimb competition.  There is sure to be a show 
this year, from Ferrari F-40 to 993 Twin Turbos...  Years past have even 
seen a few stock racers from chevys, lolas, to daytonas.  It is a raging 
red race spectacle if there ever was one.  The course is accessable by 
short hikes from the main road, (the course is a retired main road) and 
has some 2000 vertical feet climbed in only 5 miles!!
	There is no admission fee, but be ready for excitement!

	Italy vs. Germany...   Years past have shown Germany victorious!  
Come see what happens this year!

					J.D. Bayless
					   mechanic - guards red 1969 912
							race ready, and 
						       Daytona eating!

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 95 14:11:36 EST
From: "paul foster" <paul_foster@imailhub.tdc.com>
Subject: g.Analyst Data Wanted

     I am looking for g.Analyst data from autocrossing and road racing that 
     has been downloaded to a PC or Mac. Any supplemental information you 
     have about the runs would be helpful: track conditions, driver, 
     experience level, vehicle make & model, class, date, type and 
     condition of tires, etc. If you had multiple drivers in the same car 
     on the same course, that would be great, or different vehicles on the 
     same course.
     
     The purpose of this data gathering is to develop analytical methods 
     and tools to evaluate the data. I have 4+ years of data from Stock 
     Class autocross cars in the San Francisco area and IT cars at Sears 
     Point and Laguna Seca. I have noticed that pulling Gs does not 
     necessarily equate to lower elapsed times, and driving styles vary 
     greatly between individuals while the elapsed time may not.
     
     If you provide the data, I will provide you with a summary of my 
     analysis along with Beta software for a Friction Circle Analysis 
     Program that I am developing for the PC (Win32 platforms).
     
     TIA,
     
     Paul Foster
     Track Data Corporation
     95 Rockwell Place
     Brooklyn, NY 11217
     718-522-7373
     
     pbf@tdc.com (We are having Internet firewall problems. If your 
     auto-reply does not make it through, try sending email directly to 
     this address.)
     
     P.S. Track Data Corporation makes trading systems for Wall Street. The 
     above activities are a personal project, and they are not endorsed in 
     any way by my employer (unless they decide to sponsor my bad habits!).

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 1995 19:10:41 -0700
From: hcrms@chevron.com (Mitchell Craig)
Subject: Solvent and oil disposal

Tim,

>  What do I do with the dirty solvent?
>  
>  The old methods that people I know used to use (let evaporate and throw 
>  remaining crud, mix with motor oil and pour in oil containers and then pretend  it is oil) won't work with current laws and with the 8 gallons volume of 
>  solvent in my tank.
> 

I would check with your county or state government, or the EPA.  
Another possibility is a regional water quality control district,
if it exists in your area. I believe that in California
sites who handle disposal of this type of stuff (e.g.  solvent, paint,
etc) fall under county jurisdiction.  In Dublin CA, in order to dispose
of solvent I have to make an appointment and drive
about 10 miles to meet someone who will accept it.  Before I got around
to making the appointment, the solvent had evaporated.  Fortunately, it
is easier to get rid of used oil. There is a Kragan Auto Parts that takes
it near where I live, no charge.

BTW, when recently examining a newer Porsche engine case (3.0 or 3.2), a
friend pointed out that they have replaced the old circular strainer
plate with a flange and plug oriented horizontally.  He said that for
domestic 911s, they don't even drill and tap for this plug, that in order to
change your oil you have to suck the old oil out through the dipstick
hole.  This apparently came about because of problems with people who
would drain their old oil by driving out into the woods, pulling the 
drain plug, and letting their old oil spill onto the forest floor.

 -Mitch

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 1995 19:49:15 -0700
From: dem@best.com (Dennis Mitsch)
Subject: 944 CV joints/What is a 951?


Both of these are FAQ.  If you have, or are planning to purchase a 4
cylinder water cooled porsche, you should check out the 924/944/968 FAQ.

The FAQ can be FTP'd from TTA.COM or accessed via the WWW page.  The
FTP directory & file is: /pub/porschephiles/FAQs/944.faq

>From the 944 FAQ:

>
>   5.3  What is a 951?  Is this some Porsche I haven't heard of before?
>
>        No, it's simply the factory designation for the 944 Turbo.
>
>

And on CV Joints:

>
>
>   10.3 I could use some information about CV joints (failure mode, replacing, 
>        etc.), is there a FAQ about them?
>        Ed Gibbs (gibbs@avionics.itt.com) has written a nice little FAQ on 
CV   
>        joints on 944's.  It can be found on the porschephiles FTP server at:
>        /pub/porschephiles/TechTips/944-cv-joints.txt
>
>

If you have suggestions or contributions for the 944 FAQ, please drop me
a note.

Dennis Mitsch (dem@best.com)
88 944S
74 914 2.0 Special Edition

Subject: Re: 951S power loss-solution


Thanks Jerry,


A friend of my and a fellow PCAer has a black 89 951 with a simular 
problem with his turbo. He claims that on real hot days he can drive
off and have no turbo boost available past 1bar, but he can shut the
car off while coasting and restart and the turbo works fine, 1.8bar.

shuts it down the computer resets it's bad readings. I try your 
suggestion.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 1995 23:08:36 -0400
From: Jrhetten@aol.com
Subject: Re: Battery Drain

 My '91 911 C2 does the same in cold weather.  The Hickory, NC Porsche
 Dealer installed a new battery after the initial purchase 2 years ago.  It
ran fine through the summer.  Then more problems last winter.  The Charlotte
Porsche dealer checked it out and found nothing during the last service.
  For Father's day I received a Porsche labled trickle charger that plugs
into the lighter.   List price is $91 (made in W Germany, not Taiwan).  With
a PCA discount of 15% the bite was bearable per my spouse. . .and we do not
need to jump start any more <hopefully>.  NOR endure the hassle of them
looking for a fault they have been unable to find.

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 00:24:52 -0400
From: JaimeB7810@aol.com
Subject: Re: #1(2) Porschephiles #1491 Mon Jun 19 19:51:55 CDT 1995

993 Tire Wear

My experience has been that  993's go through tires like crazy.  My car has
9500 miles on it and it is already on its third set of tires: Michelins
(oem), Pirelli PZeros and currently Yoko A008P's.  Admitedly, I run the car
on the track, but so did my old SC, and the tires lasted forever.  I want to
run R1's but I am afraid I will ruin them too quickly.

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 95 21:20:17 PST
From: "Don Schmidek" <dis@metricom.com>
Subject: Colgan bra -- '91 C-2

     I have just purchased a bra from Colgan -- it is a two piece, for my 
     1991 911 C-2.
     
     I am not pleased how they suggest the bra be attached inside the 
     fenders -- they require that the plastic fender liners be loosened, 
     and the tabs be inserted behind the liner.  After that the liner 
     screws are to be tightened.  This makes for a really messy removal and 
     re-installation process.
     
     Has anyone come up with a better way -- one which is faster to install 
     and remove - in case the bra gets wet, etc.
     
     I have a further question -- as I have used the bra yet -- does the 
     trunk lid section tuck under the bumper section, or over it -- in from 
     and on the sides.  This way dust and dirt will not get into the trunk, 
     but it may flutter.  I plan to test both ways, once I get it 
     installed.
     
     Any words of advice would be appreciated.  Is there a competitive bra 
     which works better -- since I have not used it yet, I can still return 
     it, I think!!!!
     
     Don

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 1995 23:04:29 -0700 (PDT)
From: tfab@netcom.com (thom fitzpatrick)
Subject: Re: 911 exhaust studs & nuts

Mitchell Craig coughed up:
> 
> One of the most difficult experiences I've had with my 911 so far was 
> getting the exhaust off, even with the motor out of the car and upside-
> down on the engine stand. I was using regular 6-pt sockets with a u-joint

I bought a cheapie 13mm combo wrench, heated it up and bent it to angle
under and the nut came off "like butter"  Oye!

Took a few minutes of experimentation with different amounts of angle,
but it was worth it.

Thom

Porschephiles #1493                         Tue Jun 20 15:44:22 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 02:25:16 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 356 Caliper Replacments

> It has come time to replace the front and possibly the rear calipers on my 
> 1964 sc coupe. Does anyone now of any alternatives to using N.O.S. or 
> rebuilt O.E.M versions 

Dragging your foot from the rusted-out bottom of the car?

Tossing an anchor overboard?

Driving into stationary objects when you need to stop???

Look, the car is over 30 years old. I know, I have one too. You just can't
dodge that bullet unless you can either rebuild the calipers yourself
or pay someone else do to it. That's *STILL* expensive if you value
your time and don't have the facilities. It's pretty bad if you *DO*
have the facities, come to think of it...

For those that care, the Dec '94 archives have my "Brake Job From Hell"
story on what happens when you actually try to *DO* that full brake
service on a 356SC that you've been meaing to get around to for oh,
the last 20 years or so...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 02:33:34 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: EZ Bleed vs Eezibleed

> Stan please help as I and a lot of other people out here are confused as to
> which brake bleeder you keep saying is good.  It seems half of the responses I
> received are talking about a device that takes pumping of the pedal to bleed
> and the other half are talking about a device which uses compressed air from a
> tire or compress.  Which is it?  

It's the gizmo that takes air under pressure from the spare tire (or
whatever) and uses it to pressurize the master cylinder from the top.
*GREAT* device, highly highly recommended. 

I *THINK* you can still reach them at "eezibleed@aol.com". Like I said,
it's a good thing to have. 

Usual disclaimers, no relation except satisfied customer, etc.

Stan

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 08:59:58 +0100
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: 993 tire wear


|     I have a 993 with 4,000-mi. on the odo. I run A008Ps on the street 
|   and BFG R1s on the track. I'm getting decent wear on the street tires, 
|   though it's too early to make any final judgment. However, my first 
|   set of R1s wore very rapidly on the rear. The wear was even across the 
|   face of the tire, but the tread vanished after three track days.

To be honest, I would say that three track days out of a set of
rears is pretty good going. I saw a Porsche "Test Engineer" (aka
sadistic 911 thrasher) destroy *two* complete sets of standard
street tires in about sixty laps of the Weissach (sp?) test track
in a 911 C2.

Regards

Ben


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 09:20:52 +0200
From: Christopher Hegarty <chh@esec.ch>
Subject: Re: 911 Test drive fatalities 


Interesting.  I was at Le Castellet this weekend for a Porsche
driver's education event.  I leapt at the chance to drive the new
turbo for a couple of laps.  A truly incredible car, I'm trying to
resist the temptation to buy one.  My C2 feels like a Trabant in
comparison.

One of the Porsche dealers was offering his customers test drives in
the new turbo on the street in the evening.  One of the customers
managed to spin the thing out at high speed.  I drove past the scene
the next morning and the tire marks clearly showed two complete
rotations, right across onto the other side of the street.  Nobody was
hurt, the car wasn't damaged.  Very lucky, it could easily have been
otherwise given the heavy traffic at the time.

Apparently AMAG (the Swiss Porsche distributor who organized the
event) are now planning to ban test drives on the road during driver's
ed events.

Chris

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 95 9:37:00 BST
From: stevec@cfc.co.uk
Subject: Re: 944S Coolant Problem

> The car is getting coolant in the oil - the evidence is mainly
> found on the underside of the oil filler cap as a white scum...

Even get this in my 911 when it is left for a long time in a fairly
damp climate (ie. England in the Summer). I guess condensation in the
oil galleries etc, ends up being emulsified when the car is run.

I've taken a two way approach of changing the oil when it happens, and
running the car to full opperating temperature now and again for
prevention.

Better solutions (apart from moving to the South of France) very
welcome.

Steve Chapman
911 Carrera 3 Sport 
9000 Saab Turbo

> 
>        Any 993 owners out there want to comment on rear tire wear? There
>is a report on CompuServe by an owner claiming 4700 miles max for the rears
>(OEM Contis). This sounds a bit radical to me.
>

I have Bridgestone Expedias: The rears seem to last about 8000 km of
street driving, the fronts at least twice as long.

Chris

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 07:55:09 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: socket for heat exchanger removal


>Mitchell Craig coughed up:
> 
>> One of the most difficult experiences I've had with my 911 so far was 
>> getting the exhaust off, even with the motor out of the car and upside-
>> down on the engine stand. I was using regular 6-pt sockets with a u-joint

There's a major difference between a regular socket on a universal and a
universal 13mm socket. The later is about half as tall and the socket 
portion is very short so you can get a better angle. Buy the best one you
can find so that the socket will hold it's position rather than flop around.
These really work great - just don't try to cheat and use a 1/2".

I also spray the bolt heads liberally with WD-40 or CRC penetrating oil
and go have a cup of coffee (or other attitude adjuster) for half an hour
before I start. When reassembling I *always* use NeverSeeze. I've had
studs come out before, but I've never broken one off.

Since I'm on the soap box - one more thing. I never reuse the head to 
manifold gaskets. IMHO, Leaks here are what cause most of the stud problems
by superheating the alloy around the base of the studs. No scientific
evidence, just opinion. The heat exchanger/muffler gaskets can be reused
if not deformed too badly.

Reid Zeigler
(reid_zeigler@merck.com)

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 08:30:31 -0400 (EDT)
From: Gary Cuozzo <cuozzo@pb.com>
Subject: Re: Porsche Audio

I have a 1980 911SC with an Alpine head unit and 6 disc changer.  I have 
the back seats folded down, and the changer is on the seat, but under the 
back.  You can't even tell it is there if you hide the wire properly.  
You can change CD magazines while driving very easily if you put the 
changer on the passenger side.

My head unit fits perfectly in the dash but cannot be pulled out without 
first removing the dash knobs (these simply unscrew).  This is not a 
problem since I rarely remove the radio anyway.

I prefer the disc changers to the in-dash players.  My changer skips only 
over VERY severe bumps.  The Alpine units also look great.  They match the 
styling of the dashboard well.

There is nothing special about installing a stereo in a p-car.  But, it 
is very time consuming to do a good job installing speakers and running 
wires.

Hope this helps a little.

Gary.
'80 911SC - Guards Red
'86 944   - Guards Red

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 08:41:34 -0500
From: Eric Yuzon <YUZONE@fhsmtp.fh.trw.com>
Subject:  Reply: 944 CV Joints and Transaxle Oil

Date: Mon, 19 Jun 1995 16:27:28 -0400
>From: User Dgarner <dgarner@grtk.com>
Subject: 944 CV Joints and Transaxle Oil

>>>>>
[I am planning to clean and repack my CV Joints on my 944 and have the
[following questions;

[1) What is the best type of grease to use?[
[2) Is there any tricks or things to watch out for?

[Also, What is the best transaxle oil to use (the car will see some track
[time)?


[Thanks in Advance,

[Darin
[1984 944

I have an '80 911sc with about 57k on the odo.  The transaxle oil was
due for a change and the shifting was getting a little notchy.  Some local
PCA members suggested using Mobil 1 synthetic gear oil.  So, I had it
done and after about a 100 miles, the shifting became a lot smoother!!  My
local mechanic also suggested using an additive for the factory installed
limited slip to reduce any clutch chatter around turns.  There are other
brands out there, though,  like Redline, so shop around.



Good Luck!!

Eric
80 911sc
86 GTi (looking for a replacement; ie 88 GTi 16 v)

be of interest.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 08:25:58 -0500
From: smaardyk@rs6000.SUGAR-LAND.WIRELINE.SLB.COM
Subject: Four Konis to go ...

I finally got around to installing the M474 suspension upgrade from
Kahler on my '89 944.  Special thanks to Jim Pasha for the news and 
advice concerning the upgrade.  The ride is somewhat "crisper" (to quote
Jim) and handling seems to be improved substantially.  I will try to
quantify that this Sunday at our Lone Star Region (PCA) autocross.

To answer a previous question - Kahler had their Eibach springs specially 
made to keep the ride height unchanged.  The 250# springs listed in
various catalogs generally lower the height by about an inch.

During the installation I discovered a couple of things that aren't 
covered in any of my manuals:

1.  The upper attach bolt on the rear shocks uses a lock nut.  And speaking
of lock nuts - every time I go to the local dealer for these items they
have to be ordered.  It makes me suspicious that the dealer's shop doesn't
replace them routinely as the factory recommends.

2.  There are some plastic pieces on the struts which have to be removed
and installed on the new struts.  One holds the connectors for the brake 
wear indicators and the other secures the wire for the ABS sensor.  These 
pieces are held on by fingers inserted through cutouts in a metal bracket 
on the strut.  A small plastic plug keeps the fingers spread.  Pulling the 
plug makes it easy to remove the part.  I didn't have a suitable tool which 
could push the plugs out from behind so I drilled a small hole (#48) in the
center of each plug and used my smallest bolt extractor (EZ out?).  

3.  When the strut is unbolted from the steering knuckle there is no support
for the knuckle except the ball joint.  It didn't seem like a good idea to
leave it hanging by the ball joint so I supported it with a soft web strap
running from one of the lug bolts, up over the fender and secured to a hard 
point in the engine compartment.

John Smaardyk, Fleet Maintenance Officer
	
The Fleet:	'87 Nissan 300ZX (son)
		'88 Acura Legend L (SO, family transport)
		'89 Honda Prelude 2.0Si (daughter)
		'89 Porsche 944, 2.7l, 8v (daily driver)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 95 09:43:01 -0400
From: "THOMAS R BRITTON" <britton@a1.esvax.umc.dupont.com>
Subject: Re: 951S power loss-solution


To David Watters:
Hi,

	Non "S" turbos for 1988 have turbo boost of 1.8bar 
(+/-10%) at 3000rpm but then drop off to 1.58bar there after.
The "S" cars have 1.8bar maintained up to 5800rpm. 

Quick check to see if you have a "S" car: on the exhaust side of the 
engine near the firewall on the engine block is the stamped engine 
code. If you have a non "S" car it will read M44/51, if your car is
an "S" car it will read M44/52. Good luck and happy hunting.


Tom Britton
88 951 S

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 10:21:11 -0400
From: RUBBERDOC@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911 exhaust studs

There is a socket extension available from Snap On 
called a "wobbly".  It allows the socket, for lack
 of a better term, to wobble,  It's great for getting into
 tight places where a the angle is slightly off. 
Tom

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 09:20:08 -0500
From: smaardyk@rs6000.SUGAR-LAND.WIRELINE.SLB.COM
Subject: Re: Re: Four Konis to go ...

Doug,

The Koni/spring combination I purchased from Kahler did NOT lower the car.
I was concerned about this and discussed it with Denny Kahler who said
they had the springs made up specially to match the stock ride height.
My before and after measurements on the car have confirmed this.

While on the subject of ride height I note that my spec book says the
rear height is measured from the center of the torsion bar to the
center of the axle (wheel).  The spec is 3.5+/-10 mm with the torsion
bar below the axle.  On my car this was 4.5 cm.  From the survey we all
did for George B. on ride height a few months ago I learned that my
car is near the upper end of ride height so I don't think my car has
been lowered.  Either I am making the measurement incorrectly or both
the spec book and shop manual are off by an order of magnitude.  If
anyone can enlighten my I would be grateful ...

Regards,
John Smaardyk, Fleet Maintenance Officer

My 74 914 2.0 seems to be geared to it's brickness, since it pulls to
redline in 5th (pretty regularly :) with little difficulty.  I believe
the speedo reads around 120 at that point.  Accounting for speedo error,
that should be right around 115 (this is the 150 mph speedo).

According to my owners manual (74):

1.8
HP: 73
Torque: 91 lb ft
Top Speed: 107.5
0-60: 13.2 (from accel curve)
1/4 mile: 19.5 seconds @ 72.5 mph (from accel curve)

2.0
HP: 91
Torque: 105 lb ft
Top Speed: 115
0-60: 10.5 (from accel curve)
1/4 mile: 18 seconds @ 80 mph (from accel curve)

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 08:13:59 -0700

On Jun 20,  9:46am, doug dykaar wrote:
> Subject: Re: Four Konis to go ...

>

> car, bilstein said it would.
> So far, the rear shock appears to be about an inch shorter than the length
> of the koni when it came out. Of course the Bilstein is a coil over, so
> there may be less settling. any body else done Bilsteins?>
>
>
> doug dykaar
>
>-- End of excerpt from doug dykaar

I just installed the Bilstein coil-overs in my 944turbo- (they go on the rear)
it lowered the car about 1.5 inches in the rear, also put new 250# springs in
the front- lowered the front by 1 inch. Still within the PCA club racing specs
for ride hide (stock classes). The shop who did the work has considerable
racing experience with this setup which is still considered to be mild and not
compromise the suspension geometry. FYI when you put the coilovers on the rear,
you should back off the pre-laod on the torsion bar, since the coilovers will
be working with the torsion bar.

And what a difference!

jim-

87 944turbo

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 95 9:37:00 BST
From: stevec@cfc.co.uk
Subject: Re: 944S Coolant Problem

> The car is getting coolant in the oil - the evidence is mainly
> found on the underside of the oil filler cap as a white scum...

Even get this in my 911 when it is left for a long time in a fairly
damp climate (ie. England in the Summer). I guess condensation in the
oil galleries etc, ends up being emulsified when the car is run.

I've taken a two way approach of changing the oil when it happens, and
running the car to full opperating temperature now and again for
prevention.

Better solutions (apart from moving to the South of France) very
welcome.

Steve Chapman
911 Carrera 3 Sport 
9000 Saab Turbo

Date:         Tue, 20 Jun 95 11:14:56 CDT
From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
Subject:      Re: EZ Bleed vs Eezibleed

On Tue, 20 Jun 1995 02:33:34 -0500 (CDT) Stan Hanks said:
>
>It's the gizmo that takes air under pressure from the spare tire (or
>whatever) and uses it to pressurize the master cylinder from the top.
>*GREAT* device, highly highly recommended.
>
>I *THINK* you can still reach them at "eezibleed@aol.com". Like I said,
>it's a good thing to have.
>
>Usual disclaimers, no relation except satisfied customer, etc.
>
>Stan

I second Stan's endorsement of the Eezibleed system.
Please read the instructions and do not exceed 20 psi!!!!
I bleed down the spare tire from my other car to 20 psi and
use it as my pressure source. Even then, I can see my brake
reservoir swell up. Works great though.

Darren Evans-Young
'87 944S Indischrot
darren@ua1vm.ua.edu

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 95 13:26:35 EDT
From: cohen@ATB.Teradyne.COM (steve cohen)
Subject: Re: EZ Bleed vs Eezibleed

I made one of these myself a long time ago and it has worked quite
well.  I did find one aspect of brake bleeding that is better done
using a spare human to pump the pedal.

At one point I found that the master cylinder began to stick a bit and
cause the brakes to drag.  A few pumps on the brake pedal from a good
friend cleared the problem.

 -STeve

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 95 10:00:00 PDT
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: Socket mod tip


Greetings,

All this talk of corroded fasteners reminded me of a great tip
I learned from my mechanic.  In those situations where a
fastener is heavily corroded and the base of it is partially
covered in corrosion (like a pedal assembly nut), take your
6-point socket to a grinder and remove the top millimeter
or two until that rounded off area (for easy placement on the
fastener) is removed.  Now the socket will "grab" the fastener
with its entire length.  This mod helps reduce the chance of
rounding off the nut in those cases where the socket can't
get down to the base of the fastener.

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>
'75 914-6  3.0 SC

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 13:35:23 -0400
From: RedNineCo@aol.com
Subject: Re: Help... Curled Dash

What's under the leather is just a regular vinyl dash that is in the rest of
cars that don't have leather.but in some cases the factory has leather
covered there second grade or not so good vinyl dashes with leather.This is a
way to make use of an otherwise discarded imperfect part.
I have tried vasoline to resretch the leather and had 50/50 success.but for
badly srunken leather it's new leather time.
if this is the case you may still need the vasoline.

RedNine Co.

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 14:56:45 -0700 (PDT)
From: maxw@falcon.cc.ukans.edu (Max Waddington)
Subject: steering wheel removal ?


I'm going to recover and re-align the steering wheel on my 928.  It has the factory 
three spoke steering wheel.  

To remove the steering wheel, do I simply have to pull off the horn pad and remove a 
nut......or will I need a special tool.

Thanks for any help,

Max

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 13:27:28 -0700
From: dem@best.com (DEM)
Subject: automotive painting ?'s


Hi, my name is Dennis and I'm dangerous when I paint things. :)

I had been procrastinating on finishing up painting the trunk of my
914, figuring "It's summer, I have plenty of time before it rains
again."  So much for that idea.  In any case, the recent rain storm
has given me incentive to finish it up.

What I've done so far:
cleaned surface with silicone/wax remover
wire wheeled all rusty bits down to bare metal
cleaned
sanded to even out edges and roughen up leftover glossy paint
cleaned
tack ragged
primed with a generic enamel white primer

Now, originally I had planned to follow up with some near-matching
enamel spray paint (ala rustoleum in a can) since this is, afterall,
just the floor of the trunk and maybe an inch of the trunk walls.

However, I recently stumbled upon an exact match laquer paint for
the color of my car (light ivory, I believe) in the form of aerosol
touch up paint for VW's.

So, I'm sitting with an enamel primer and I want to put a laquer top
coat on it.  I know that's wrong, but how wrong?  if it's really
really wrong, what do I do to make it right?


Thanks much.

Dennis Mitsch
88 944S (4-5 weeks before it goes on the dyno for the DME chip)
74 914 2.0 (4-5 weeks to have trunk painted and all it's parts put back on)



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 95 15:37:34 CDT
From: gwbird@prairienet.org (Garry W. Bird)
Subject: oil change



just purchased an '87 944s and decided to change oil and filter.
found that when you remove the filter, oils spills into the 
pan under the vehicle.  oil stayed there until i backed it out of
the garage. @#$% all, what a mess!  
helpful hint-using a punch or a drift,  knock a hole in the top
of the filter prior to draining the oil.  after the crankcase had
been drained, the oil in the filter has drained also.  removing
the filter doesn't make that mess then ;->
didn't see this in faq's, did everyone know but me?

- --
Garry W. Bird
Champaign-Urbana Public Health District
217.352.8486.146   fax217.352.0126

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 95 13:35:14 PDT
From: Jeff Munsey <jmunsey@hpcvicae.cv.hp.com>
Subject: Re: Type IV Lifters & Cams

On the subject of hydraulic lifters in a 914 (type IV), I'm having trouble
understanding how this would be different from that of the type IV
powered bus.  The factory did the whole package on the busses.  Did
they not do it correctly?  I don't know.  Wouldn't a factory hydraulic
cam and lifters just drop into place and live happily ever after?

I'm interested on this one because I'm tired of the joys of mechanical
valve adjustment on something that is a real pain to get at.

Jeff Munsey (jmunsey@cv.hp.com)
'74 914 1.8


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1494                         Wed Jun 21 02:00:09 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 16:51:54 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: oil change


>just purchased an '87 944s and decided to change oil and filter.
>found that when you remove the filter, oils spills into the 
>pan under the vehicle.  oil stayed there until i backed it out of
>the garage. @#$% all, what a mess!  
>helpful hint-using a punch or a drift,  knock a hole in the top
>of the filter prior to draining the oil.  after the crankcase had
>been drained, the oil in the filter has drained also.  removing
>the filter doesn't make that mess then ;->
>didn't see this in faq's, did everyone know but me?
>

Yeah, but before you punch that hole, better make sure that your filter
is not frozen to the flange... It makes it really tough to drive into town and
get the proper tool to remove it...

Even better tip is to remove the filter first, so that when you drop it down
to the drain pan, it doesn't splash dirty oil all over your clean garage floor.

Pilots say "Checklists are written in blood."  My Porsche checklists are 
written in oil splotches all around my garage...
Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net
Purveyors of Used 944 Parts and Services to "Her Majesty"
Orders: 800-all-p944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
83 944, 87 944S (for sale), 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 80 GMC Pickup

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 15:55:54 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Type IV Lifters & Cams

> On the subject of hydraulic lifters in a 914 (type IV), I'm having trouble
> understanding how this would be different from that of the type IV
> powered bus.  The factory did the whole package on the busses.  Did
> they not do it correctly?  I don't know.  Wouldn't a factory hydraulic
> cam and lifters just drop into place and live happily ever after?

Different factory.

Different performance objectives.

Different operating heat ranges.

Not The Same.

However, this is *EXACTLY* why I don't trust the aftermarket kits. Think
about it: there are say 120,000 914 made. Assume 90,000 still exist,
further that about 75,000 are still on the road. How many need engine
rebuilds a year? Let's say 15% -- call it a round 11,000. Of those,
how many are cheap and dirty, versus those who have some money to spend
on new upgrade parts. Let's be charitable and say 25% will spend the
money. That's say 2,600 (rounding again). Now let's say that I have *GREAT*
advertising and marketing, and capture 20% of that market -- I can
potentially sell (drum roll here ----) 520 hydraulic cam setups a year.
Hmmm. What does a cam cost? Shop cost is about $160. So that means I have
to cover my manufacturing, marketing, and R&D costs from a net of about
$83,000 a year. Am I going to spend R & D dollars on that?? NO WAY! I'll
just sell something I can buy off the shelf somewhere else.

FYI.

Stan

P.S. I've clearly been driving spreadsheets too much lately.....

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 18:01:33 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: 951 "cup" suspension

>Doug.
>Where did you get the coil over Bilsteins. I want to find a pair instead of
>replacing the torsion bars. Seems to me that those "helper" springs combined
>with my stock 89 26mm torsion bars should be just about right. Any comments?
>
>Regards,
>Jerry
>89 944turbo S black (track Car)
>89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
>Muffy & Portia,  the cats
>5:34 pm

I got them from VCI in Dover NJ. Same place I got the red caliper upgrade.
Its not on yet, so I can't say.   The bilsteins are a non adjustible
(shock) setup spec'd by porsche. I agree (obviously) that coil overs are
better, although I have wimpier torsen bars ('86) and may end up changing
them too.
There's apparently two kinds of bilsteins around, a road race (not
coilover) and "cup" suspension. The cup struts are NOT inserts and have a
40 mm diameter piston !! The shock appears to be shorter than the koni. I'm
hoping that this will solve the tire rubbing. Even if it doesn't change the
ride height, I may have to swap out the control arms. yuk! My wife is
beginng to think a mistress might be cheaper.

doug

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 95 15:57:39 MST
From: thenke@amex-trs.com
Subject: 944 info exchange

Hi all, I'm fairly new to p-cars, but got interested after driving
a friend's 928S.  Didn't take long until I had an '85.5 944 with
40K miles.  Next my wife just *had* to have one too, so we also
have an '87 944 in the garage now.  Fun cars.

Anyway, here's some info 944 owners might find useful sometime.
My 944 had the fuel gauge work correctly for about the first
minute or 2 the car was turned on, and then it would instantly
go to the empty mark.  The fix was not the fuel sensor unit (in 
the fuel tank) as I and my mechanic suspected.  The fix was the
fuel gauge itself in the dash.  The temp gauge is also part of
the fuel gauge unit, and that always worked fine.  Anyone need
a fuel sensor unit?

My current problem maybe someone has an answer for???  my AC toggles
the compressor on and off about every 8 or 10 seconds.  My p-mechanic
has emptied and properly recharged the AC system twice, checked the
high and low pressure switches, and replaced the temp sensor.  Still
the same problem.  AC runs cold and works, I just think that toggling
on and off so much can't be good for the compressor.  My wife's 944
does the same thing, just not quite as fast.  I live in the Phoenix
area where it gets a bit warm in the summer, but the same symtoms
occur in the winter.  Anybody have any possible solutions I should look
into?  Anyone consider this normal for '86/'87 era 944's?

Thanks,
Terry Henkels

    
The opinions expressed in this message are those of the author only,
and do not necessarily reflect the opinions of American Express.

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 20:41:50 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Yellow things (wires and dist. cap)

To finish off the engine compartment on the '73 T, I'm looking for two 
things. First, a yellow distributor cap/cover I've seen these for Bugs 
and such, but never in the 6 cylinder variety. Doesn't really matter if 
it is opaque or transparent. The other thing is sparkplug wires that are 
yellow with black ends, these being either 180 or 45 degree wires.
As soon as I can find free scanning from a reputable service or place of 
computing, I will scan in pictures of the engine compartment. I had the 
K&N waterproof covers painted yellow on top, black on bottom to 
match/accent the fiberglass? or whatever it is surrounding the engine. It 
looks nice... as an uninformed person pointed out, "that doesn't look 
stock now" and I conveniently replied, "neither are the filter covers, so 
what?" As the paint was beginning to chip and rust, it was time for new 
paint anyways, so we went with an idea from Excellence, and it turned out 
pretty nice, but now it is on to other little things.
Oh, not that this car is concours or anything, so lets not hear the 
'trick look' speech... (although, those towers of power are viewable from 
outside the decklid now... hehehe
 -Derek


------------------------------

Date: 15 Jun 95 17:15:17 EDT
From: Mark Forrester <Mark_Forrester.LOTUS@crd.lotus.com>
Subject: Re: Radar Detectors/Jammers

Gary,

My experience with the Valentine One with the laser detection feature has been 
different than what you describe.  Recently on highway 88 in upstate New York I 
was saved TWICE by a sufficiently early laser warning.  On the valentine one, 
the laser alert signal is unmistakable, it screams full volume and has a set of 
three horizontal bars which mean LASER detected.  Highway 88 has long and wide 
open stretches where you can see for miles all around.  In both cases the 
revenue collector was situated about a mile or so ahead and out of my sight.  
There was a car about a half mile ahead of me which I presume was the "target" 
of the laser when my detector started screaming.  In both instances I had 
plenty of time to slow to 55 and cruise right on by the RC without incident.  
Not sure exactly how wide the laser beam is at a particular distance or what 
it's effective range is, but there is no doubt that my detector detected laser 
and in sufficient time for me to do something about it.  Perhaps it picks up 
scatter from vehicles ahead (Mike??).  If I had not had laser and only had 
conventional protection I would have undoubtedly received one mother of a 
ticket.

Mark
mrf@lotus.com (maybe soon to be ibm.com)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 21:10:01 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 info exchange

>My current problem maybe someone has an answer for???  my AC toggles
>the compressor on and off about every 8 or 10 seconds.  My p-mechanic
>has emptied and properly recharged the AC system twice, checked the
>high and low pressure switches, and replaced the temp sensor.  Still
>the same problem.  AC runs cold and works, I just think that toggling
>on and off so much can't be good for the compressor.  My wife's 944
>does the same thing, just not quite as fast.  I live in the Phoenix
>area where it gets a bit warm in the summer, but the same symtoms
>occur in the winter.  Anybody have any possible solutions I should look
>into?  Anyone consider this normal for '86/'87 era 944's?
>

Definitely not normal... Are the AC relays working properly (note that there 
are two relays for the AC, one in the fuse block and one under the dash...)

Is your thermocouple to the ac control working properly?

After all, this is a Nippondenso AC unit, entirely...any honda shop should 
be able to figure this one out....
Good Luck!

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 20:09:39 -0700
From: inter-bw@violet.berkeley.edu (Pete)
Subject: 944 Longevity

P-philes:

Recently my mechanic, whom I generally have great respect for, quoted some
numbers for me which were hard to believe.  I asked how many miles I could
expect out of a well maintained early 944 engine before a valve job and
engine rebuild would be needed.  I drive over 20k a year, mostly freeway.
He responded that, barring random parts breakage, I could expect to do a
valve job at 250K and a rebuild at 500k. Though I believe my 944 should go
far, I find those numbers VERY optomistic!.  Any comments or insights would
be appreciated.

Pete

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 23:18:08 -0400
From: Mrbill456@aol.com
Subject: Re: Purchased '73-1/2 911T !!

Peter wrote:  

"This 911 I've purchased will be a daily driver, and I'll keep it at factory
spec (except for necessary updates like tensioners, etc.).

Can anyone recommend a book that might discuss "Now that you've purchased
your used Porsche, do this..." ??  I want to change fluids, etc.

I've got lots of little questions that are probably answered somewhere, like:
which brake fluid, tranny fluid, engine oil, etc., to use, as well as what
the proper operating parameters of the car are.  Can someone recommend a "How
to care for your porsche" book?"

Hi Peter,

 Congratulations on your new purchase. The 731/2 T is a very very nice 911.

Several mail order companies (Perf. Products 800 423 3173 and Stoddards 800
342 1414 just to name two of the more well known ones) sell original factory
owners operating/maintenance/technical manuals for your car. You should
certainly buy one of these (but they are expensive - welcome to Porsche
ownership!). For all I know your local Porsche dealer may sell them as well.
Speaking of Porsche dealers... a visit may very well put you on to the
Seattle Porsche Club of America chapter. You should join and get in touch
with other Seattle area 911 owners who own early 911s (in my opinion the
731/2 was the last early 911, but then what do I know). These fellow owners
will likely be happy to have a chance to talk about their 911 experiences. 

Seattle must have at least one auto repair shop that specializes in early
911s. If you  have your  fluids changed there they should be willing to
discuss why they use the what they use. If they don't seem to want to talk
about this type of stuff I'd look for another shop. Again the local PCA
membership may be of some guidance. 

Just about any large book store will have info about cosmetic care. There are
extensive discussions on this in the Porschefiles archives and this topic
never dies on the Usenet rec.autos.misc (or something like that) newsgroup

You mention your 911 will be a daily driver. I'd like to hear about your
experiences driving your car everyday. I hope your commute is long enough to
get the engine oil up to at least 180 deg F.

I apologize for being ignorant about Seattle but if they ever salt the roads
there (or where ever you take the car in the winter)  be very certain to
rinse, rinse, rinse that salt away. In general (apparently there are
exceptions) early 911s contain practically no galvinized metal which means
your greatest enemy is rust.

The only other advice I would give you would be to take the time and trouble
to be certain ALL the rubber gaskets on your trunk, fenders, doors and engine
compartment...everywhere are in excellent shape and make proper seals. I do
know it rains in Seattle and I would think rubber integrety would be key to
holding off corrosion.

Best wishes for many miles of enjoyable driving!

Bill Hutton

1971 911E coupe

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 00:20:52 EDT
From: AWJK94A@prodigy.com ( DREW SPENCER)
Subject: Re: Colgan bra -- '91 C-2


Hi Don,

I have a Colgan that I put on my RS America for track events and
general highway driving.  It is a pain in the butt to remove and
replace.  Mine had no cutout for the license plate (good ole Utah
license plate laws...) so I also have to unscrew the license plate
bracket from the front bumper.  I have a stubby Snap-on phillips
screwdriver that works quite for removing the three screws that
have to be removed in the wheel well.

As far as your question about whether the hood (trunk lid) goes
under or over the bumper section, I supposed you could do this,
but you would have to undo this to open the hood.

I've been relatively happy with mine (it saved my paint job when
a competitor at a track event pinched a corner and threw up
rocks in my face...).

Drew
Drew Spencer (aka awjk94a@prodigy.com)
'93 RS America
'82 911 SC ("Stiffy" the race car, currently locomotion impaired)

I have begun writing some CGI scripts (yes, I know the advantages of

now. I'd like to know if everyone finds that it works... the URL is:
http://tta.com/cgi-bin/whoswho
It is not designed for looks, much like the Boxster prototype, it works 
though, or so I belive. This is where I need the value of Porschephiles 
to test it out. Use the index, search for your name. If you can't find 
your name, doesn't this suggest that maybe you should get on that list? 
You can also search for members from your state! (with relative accuracy, 
for instance, searching for NJ will pull up all the members from NJ AND 
anyone with nj in any other part of that line, for instance, someone 
named Ranjii would also come up)
E-mail me if you find ANY problems!

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 01:39:54 -0400
From: HHeath3@aol.com
Subject: P'philes mini-convention

I had to be in Washington, DC last week for a conference, so made
arrangements to meet Ol' Unka Bart, who lives not too far off in Annapolis,
MD.  To my pleasure, 'philes Herb Myers of Phillie, and Asad Husain of Balt.
were also to be present.  So last Sat., an old friend drove me from the DC
convention center (witnessed a drug deal go down across the st. from my
hotel; what a city!) to Bart's house, a beautiful place set way back in the
woods.  Made me wonder where he hid the still.  There, I made a *stunning*
discovery.... despite Ol Bart's talk about Green Ones, Blue Ones, Yellow
Ones... what I saw was that he was actually consuming *brown* ones... bottles
of beer, that is!  After preliminaries, Bart, Dora, Asad and lovely wife
Amina, Herb, and my friend Dan and I piled into four cars (!), 3 of which
were P'cars, and drove a beautiful twisty route to a seafood restaurant on
the West River.  There, we enjoyed a great meal, terrific conversation, and a
relaxed time as if we had all been friends for years.  We parted with regret,
planning for another visit during one of my many trips back to DC area.

So, we had a mini Porschephiles convention, and enjoyed every minute of it.
 Ol' Unka Bart is one smooth dude, and lots of fun to be with.  Lady Dora is
elegant, patient, and tolerant of Car Guys' listing their most recent
tickets!  I encourage all 'philes to keep track of who's where and have these
mini-conventions!  It was a blast.

Bart, thanks for persisting in arranging our meeting-- see you this fall, I
hope.

Hunter Heath
1983 944 plat (dirty-- I gave up on compulsiveness when my job made it
impractical-- will take it up again in retirement!)

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 07:31:16 -0400 (EDT)
From: Gary Cuozzo <cuozzo@pb.com>
Subject: Re: oil change

I use a funnel with a long hose attached to it and put it under the 
filter before I unscrew it.  The oil from the filter goes right into the 
drain pan without spilling a drop.

Gary Cuozzo
1980 911SC
1986 944



On Tue, 20 Jun 1995, Garry W. Bird wrote:

> 
> 
> just purchased an '87 944s and decided to change oil and filter.
> found that when you remove the filter, oils spills into the 
> pan under the vehicle.  oil stayed there until i backed it out of
> the garage. @#$% all, what a mess!  
> helpful hint-using a punch or a drift,  knock a hole in the top
> of the filter prior to draining the oil.  after the crankcase had
> been drained, the oil in the filter has drained also.  removing
> the filter doesn't make that mess then ;->
> didn't see this in faq's, did everyone know but me?
> 
> --
> Garry W. Bird
> Champaign-Urbana Public Health District
> 217.352.8486.146   fax217.352.0126

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 07:25:57 -0500
From: "Martin C. Walker" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: Vargas Girls

Hank,

As one of my other hobbies I paint reproduction leather WWI bomber and
fighter jackets ($1,000 ea interested :->).  I have searched high and low
for various sources of Vargas Girls.  There are some books on old
pinups, many of Vargas Esquire girls are included.  The best source
I have found however, is a book entitled simply "Vargas".  This has
pretty much all the Esquire girls, plus others.  The book is 11"x14 or
close to it, most of the girls are on page, some of them two.  You may find
this book hard to purchase, I'm not sure if it's still in print.  Your local 
library
might have it, mine does.

As far as finding posters the only thing I can suggest it perhaps an
aviation museum poster of some bomber nose art.

My favorite if February, 1942 - she was "my first girl" on a 5th airforce 
P-38 lightning.  The jacket/plane was called "2 big and too heavy" (the
girl is rather well endowed:-)).
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Martin C. Walker                                         martinw@eapi.com
Project Lead                                           Voice (513) 629-2517
Eagle-Picher Industries                                     (513) 721-7010
580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                   Fax (513) 629-2449


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 08:16:42 -0500 (CDT)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: HELP-Timing Equipment


Good Morning Bruce,

In an earlier post concerning this, I wrote that our region needed timing 
equipment when we started.  We contacted Chrondek a maker of timing 
equipment for drag strips.  They supplied us with a low cost very 
reliable small setup.  We got a two light setup, start and finish.  We 
later put a switch in the finish circuit so we could easily run laps on 
some of our events.

By adding large tubes to the "eyes" and good driving lights as sources we 
negated the effects of sunny vs. cloudy vs overcast weather problems 
affecting our results.

The addition of a switch to your setup may add some welcome variations to 
your events.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 08:42:34 -0600 (CST)
From: HENSLEY@uwplatt.edu
Subject: Where is 'ROAD AMERICA'?

Hi All:
	I could not let this one to by.

	'ROAD AMERICA' is in Eastern Wisconsin, very close to Elkhart Lake.
It is about half way between Fond Du Lac and Sheboygan.  About 3 hours from
Chicago, about 5 hours from Minneapolis, About 2 hours from Madison, about
2.5 hours from Rockford, Il, and about 3 hours from Platteville, WI.
Platteville is in the south-west corner of Wisconsin.  We are know as the
summer home of the Chicago Bears.  

	'ROAD AMERICA' is a 14 turn, 4 mile road track with some nice
elevation changes.  It was a great place to watch the 962's race in the late
80's.  The SO and I go over about twice a year to watch the INDY CARS race and
the Chicago Historic Cars races.

Harvey Hensley
University of Wisconsin-Platteville
E-MAIL:	hensley@uwplatt.edu
PHONE:	608-342-1657
FAX:	608-342-1566
CAR: 	PORSCHE 964

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 08:59:47 +0600
From: rondl@uscbu.ih.att.com (Ronald Jay De Lange)
Subject: My Fault??

Greetings Philers:

WHile trying to figure out the demise of my 901 transmission in
my '66 912, I got a sick feeling:

When I jack up the car using my floor jack, I place the jack on
the center of the transmission mount.  This has worked nicely in
the past to bring the entire rear of the car up to get it on jack
stands, etc. while not being drivable.  When I jack the car up,
the trans moves up vertically quite a bit before actually lifting the
car up.

Could I have bent the shift rod that extends out of the transmission
through this technique?  It might be hitting the side wall
attached to the floor pan.  All of a sudden, it seems to me that
I may be the culprit to my current transmission woes.  Now, I dont
want to repeat that when I put the tranny back this weekend!

How does everyone else jack the entire rear of their 911/912 up when
it doesnt move??  Somebody tell me it wasnt me!.....

Thanks,

Ron D.

rondl@uscbu.att.com

  This reminds me of the time I test drove a 911 down at Big Red Imports in
  Norman, Oklahoma. The salesman didn't trust me to pilot the car without
  him, so he came along for the ride. Problem is, a friend of mine was
  coming along for the test drive and the salesman would not have been very
  gentlemanly to ask the lady to sit in the back seat of the coupe, even if
  she would have sat there or if I would have permitted such unchivalrous
  behavior. To make things even better, some of you might recognize that
  Norman, Oklahoma is home to the Sooners of football fame, college type.
  Well, this salesman probably got his job from some alumnus, as he was one
  of Barry Switzer's (yes, this was back when Oklahoma had a professional
  football team <bg>) finest farm-bred specimens. How he could get in the
  back seat, I'll never understand, kind of like Bart's proverbial 10
  pounds into a 5 pound sack, but it was one hell of a shoehorn.

  The test drive was a blast. Can you say "skidpad"? I knew you could....
