------------------------------

Date: 21 Jun 1995 08:18:04 -0700
From: "Thom Kuby-CTA" <thom_kuby-cta@cl_c21smtp_gw.chinalake.navy.mil>
Subject: Re- Road America "stupid" q

                      Subject:                              Time:  6:54 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         Re: Road America "stupid" question    Date:  6/21/95

on Wednseday (digest #1494)
Trevor Sadler wrote what he thought was a really STUPID question...
I disagree with that, as he was asking about one of my absolutely favorite
tracks of all time.
Road America is Elkhart Lake.  Elkhart Lake is in Wisconsin-a little bit
further north of Sheboygan, which in turn, is several hours north of Chicago.
The track itself is a beautiful four-mile course set in the equally
intoxicating Kettle Moraine countryside.

As a member of the Chicago Region SCCA, I was a timer/scorer there in the 70's
for the June Sprints, Trans-Ams and the "real"Can-Ams.  
Believe me, It was instant religion hearing 25+ Can-Am cars on the pace
lap-most of them Traco Chevy powered, with the first of the "917 class"
Porsches adding their demonic screech to the thunder.  A sound that will never
be repeated-even in vintage racing, simply because there were no holds barred
then...

I guess the best look you can get of the culture of Road America now is to get
to the June Sprints-which I guess is still a SCCA National event (it's been
many years-sorry, I live out in the Mojave desert now).  People have called
the sprints the "woodstock" of sports car racing.  this isn't far from the
truth-not far at all...
The Sprints is nothing but people, color, cars, lots of loud engines echoing
through the trees and more people.  the Sprints are a real tradition that any
sports car/racing fan really needs to experience at least once...I don't know
what other events are held there, besides the indy car circus stopping there. 
When Clift Tufte owned the place it was the same  three gigs each and every
summer: June Sprints, Trans-Am, Can-Am; next summer repeat, and so on...
Corn-on the-cob, cold beer, beer-soaked Bratwurst, midwestern summer nights,
more cold beer, meeting the girls...

And a whole lotta Porsches!  In fact I very clearly remember someone showing
up in the paddock with a 550A Spyder w/ Wisconsin street tags that said "D
550".  (or something to that effect-I have a very nice color photo of that
car, among others...)  Back then, the Porsche guys had a special parking area
called the "porsche paddock", far, far away from the corvette guys with their
"corvette corral"

Needless to say, it was all lotsa fun then...I'm sure it still is. 
(suggestion: call Road & Track's Peter Egan and ask about Elkhart, He'll wax
poetic for days!)
Go there. Do it...
Cheers
Thom Kuby 
PORSCHE "res ipsa loquitor..."

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 95 10:38:44 EST
From: Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov
Subject: '89 951 Brake System Questions

Hello All;

I have a question about the brake system on the '89 944 Turbo models.  Is there 
some kind of pressure reservior mechanism the keeps the brake pressure up for 
the power assist function?  If so, where is it located and how can it be 
inspected?

The reason I ask is that the brakes on my 951 feel like there is no power assist 
to them.  I have put in new pads (Metalmasters) and bled the system but I still 
do not have a real firm pedal.  There feels like a few inches of pedal travel 
before the car starts slowing down.  Any suggestions would be appreciated.

and Saturday.  I will be watching and working if needed, not competing.  TIA

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 95 11:30:31 EDT
From: "Jeffrey A. Shorey" <js@ee.duke.edu>
Subject: Re: corroded exhaust stud

Re: to Wayne Flowers' suggestion to have a new set made out of stainless -
according to Carroll's "Nuts, bolts, and fasteners" (I like Stan's alias,
"Screw to Win"), stainless has galling problems when used with aluminum.
Also, by having the threads cut into the stud instead of a factory "rolled"
thread, the fastener is made much weaker.

My solution: use the correct studs (most Porsche repair places should have
a good stock).  Use the correct nuts (I think they were all copper - don't
remember for sure).  Use anti-seize on the threads so you might actually get
the exchangers off a second time.  Torque them to spec.  Torque them again
with the exhaust hot.

When I put on SSI exchangers, fully half of the studs came out (most fused to
their nuts) - didn't break a one.  One of the studs had been replaced with
a bolt ;-) and there were at least two varieties of nuts.

 - Jeff Shorey  js@ee.duke.edu
  '73 911S Coupe
  '85 535i Coupe

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 12:14:23 -0500 (CDT)
From: Paul Christopher Schlesselman <pcs0001@jove.acs.unt.edu>
Subject: Re: '89 951 Brake System Questions


I would suggest carefully checking the vacuum supply to the 
brake booster servo, located between firewall and master cylinder.
it could be a pluged or broken line or a blockage in the 
booseters inlet or even outlet.
(boosters don't fail very often themselves)
It is possible that there is air in system or the master cylindar is
failing also.

> 
> I have a question about the brake system on the '89 944 Turbo models.  Is there 
> some kind of pressure reservior mechanism the keeps the brake pressure up for 
> 
> The reason I ask is that the brakes on my 951 feel like there is no power assist 
> to them.  I have put in new pads (Metalmasters) and bled the system but I still 
> do not have a real firm pedal.  There feels like a few inches of pedal travel 
> before the car starts slowing down.  Any suggestions would be appreciated.

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 13:31:54 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: '89 951 Brake System Questions

>Hello All;
>
>I have a question about the brake system on the '89 944 Turbo models.  Is 
there 
>some kind of pressure reservior mechanism the keeps the brake pressure up for 
>the power assist function?  If so, where is it located and how can it be 
>inspected?
>

The power assist for all 944 cars is the vacuum brake booster, which is 
located between the brake master cylinder and the firewall.  It is a large 
(12-14 inches in diameter) black thingy with a vacuum line attached to the 
passenger side front of the thingy (sorry to not be properly EEC and metric 
in my specifications...)

If you're not getting any brake assist, it could be that there is a vacuum 
leak between the intake manifold and the booster. Check it out...

>The reason I ask is that the brakes on my 951 feel like there is no power 
assist 
>to them.  I have put in new pads (Metalmasters) and bled the system but I 
still 
>do not have a real firm pedal.  There feels like a few inches of pedal travel 
>before the car starts slowing down.  Any suggestions would be appreciated.

You may have to re-bleed the brakes until your brakes start feeling better...

The brake booster tends to make the brake pedal feel softer, not firmer...
As far as that goes, I have not yet driven a 944 with the same hard pedal 
feel that I get out of a 911.  I chased mine for a couple of weeks (trying 
all of the various fixes) until I realized that the brakes were just fine 
and it was my head that was screwed up...

Try another 944 before you condemn the brakes on yours...

Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net
Purveyors of Used 944 Parts and Services to "Her Majesty"
Orders: 800-all-p944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
83 944, 87 944S (for sale), 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 80 GMC Pickup

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 95 11:01:29 -0700
From: selfridg@encoreengineering.com (Mike Selfridge)
Subject: Re: Radar Detectors/Jammers

Clipped from a message from Mark Forrester:
...
>Not sure exactly how wide the laser beam is at a particular distance or what 
>it's effective range is, but there is no doubt that my detector detected laser 
>and in sufficient time for me to do something about it.  Perhaps it picks up 
>scatter from vehicles ahead (Mike??).
...

That's great you got a warning so far in advance of the speed trap.
With all of the information I have gotten from Porschephiles, I decided
to go with the Valentine detector (with laser).  It sounds like the best
unit available.

As far as the width of the laser goes, I was told by my father that the
published specs on the lasers used by police list a beam divergence of
6 feet at 1000 feet distance.  With some trigonometry, that works out
to be .34 degrees of divergence.  So, at 1 mile, the area covered by
the laser would be 32 feet.  You may have picked up a direct signal at
one mile, but it would have been VERY weak.  If so, that's another good
testament for the Valentine.

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 95 16:19:24 -0500
From: Mike Selner <mike@is.com>
Subject: 944S Coolant Problem Followup

Earlier I posted Re 944S:

>  The car is getting coolant in the oil - the evidence is mainly
>  found on the underside of the oil filler cap as a white scum.  No
>  oil scum is found in the coolant filler tank.  The cooler seals
>  were replaced along with the rod bearings.  The scum re-appeared
>  and so the head gasket was replaced.  Now the odor of coolant is
>  strong and after the car is shutdown hot you can hear a hissing
>  if you listen at the oil filler.  There is white smoke in
>  the exhaust under acceleration.  I am suspecting a crack in the
>  head - I don't know if it has been checked.  There was a valve
>  job done with the head gasket so I assume it was checked.
>

The answers generally suspect the oil cooler seals.  I'm sure it
is getting hot enough to bake off any moisture in the oil - it is
a 2 hr drive to the track and a very hot weekend.  One person
mentioned an oil cooler housing modification.  Is this a well
known modification and what is it?

The car is using coolant at about 1 qt/150 miles.  There is also smoke in the  
exhaust.  It is strange, there must be coolant in the oil because the
breather has a lot of greenish white scum, but no coolant smell is
noticable on the dipstick.  I'd think oil would be in the coolant if the
oil cooler failed and I don't see/smell any.

Any further opinions/advice?

Thanks

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 23:02:30 +0000 (GMT)
From: wayne@aprf.arl.mil
Subject: Re: SS fasteners

Stainless only has a galling problem with aluminum in those cases where 
there is frequent assembly/disassembly without a thread lub.  In the case
of exhaust studs this is pretty much a one-off deal and I have never seen
a galling problem in this sort of application.  Use some Silver Goop
from the Swagelok Fitting suppliers (found in major cities) as a thread
lub between the studs and the block, and the nuts and the studs.  The
tensile difference between a cut and rolled thread is minuscule compared
to that between unrusted studs and those rusted halfway through.  The 
main problem with cut studs is that stress cracks are more likely - but
this is only a problem in high stress situations.  Holding headers on
is not a high-stress apllication, but for connecting rods, or attaching 
jet engines or rocket motors then one would specify rolled threads.

I have used stainless metric studs from Metric and Multistandard
Components Corp. in the past, and my reccollection is that they
were rolled thread.  They have both 304 and 316 alloys available,
not as good as A-286, but their prices are reasonable.

Some of the MS/NAS fasteners are pretty snazzy - rolled threads, head
undersurfaces ground and filletted, individual zyglo tested, 12pt
heads, A286 alloy.  And expensive, wow!  Big problem is  getting this
quality fastener in metric. 
- -- 
Wayne Flowers                 Voice:  505-678-8303
Senior Scientist              Fax:    505-678-6049
Science & Technology Corp.    E-mail: wayne@aprf.arl.mil
White Sands, New Mexico       URL:    http://aprf.arl.mil/


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 16:11:14 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: 911 - 914/6 Distributor ??

Hi Dan.

Re:
>     I have a 914/6 with a Bosch distributor.  The stock Bosch cap does not 
>     have any "key" to align with the distributor body.  The result is the 
>     cap is free to rotate as far as the retainer clips will allow.  What 
>     gives?  On my 4 cylinder stuff, the cap always had a key.  I thought
>     that the proper phasing of the cap to rotor over the operational range 
>     of advance was important.

I'm not up on this _particular_ distributor, but there are generally two
kinds of Bosch caps, those with the locating "key" and those without.  I've
seen both kinds, on both 4- and 6-cylinder Bosch distributors. Most of the
6-cylinder caps I've seen are as you describe (no key).

If you have a mismatch (as you do, where the cap is missing what you call
the "key") you can obtain or fabricate a Bosch distributor part which is
essentially a small, bent piece of thick sheet metal that attaches under
one of the distributor clip holder screws.  It's curved to fit the
distributor body, etc. This provides a metal "tang" that sticks up above
the surface of the distributor body and will locate the cap nicely. 

If the cap for your distributor has the same "base circle" size as that of,
say, the '74 914-4 2.0, you should be able to find 6-cyl caps in both
styles, both with and without the key -- I've certainly seen both. If it's
the bigger size cap, I don't know, but BMW has used both sizes and Mercedes
used the small size, so you might want to cross-check there.

I had such a distributor/cap mismatch, and a garage was able to provide me
with the little part (proper Bosch) I mentioned above.

 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  |
|        standard disclaimers apply         | 
|___________________________________________|         


------------------------------

Date: 21 Jun 1995 16:19:38 U
From: "Soren LaForce" <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re- corroded exhaust fastne

Jeff writes:



Snip

  Use anti-seize on the threads so you might actually get
the exchangers off a second time.  Torque them to spec.  Torque them again
with the exhaust hot.

When I put on SSI exchangers, fully half of the studs came out (most fused to
their nuts) - didn't break a one.  One of the studs had been replaced with
a bolt ;-) and there were at least two varieties of nuts.

*************************

The anti-seize a good idea.  However, there is a generic method
of removing exhaust fastners that I've never had fail.

Spray each fastner with liquid wrench *every day* for about 
*one week* before attempting removal.  Generally a day or two is 
enough time but 2 hours isn't.

Pound each nut a few times while you're in there.

With this treatment, stuff generally just comes off with no fuss.

Oh yeah, the bad part: don't drive the car during this time.


- --Soren
soren_laforce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov

Date: 21 Jun 1995 16:28:12 U
From: "Soren LaForce" <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re- airship p-content

Leonard writes:


   
     I read the following in the "soc.culture.new-zealand" newsgroup...

Swiftair Corporation today announced details of a special trans-global
flight to be made next month in the newly commissioned "Malatesta", a 
luxuriously appointed Zeppelin NT LZ-184.  Swiftair is the flag-carrier 
for the Sultanate of Okusi-Ambeno.

The airship "Malatesta" is built to carry 40 passengers and 12 crew in
sumptuous comfort.  The ship is powered by five Porsche IC engines which
give the ship it's top cruising speed of 125 knots, and a range of 9,493
kilometers.

**********************************

This is not the first airship to use porsche powerplants.

Westinghouse Airship Industries (WAI) builds an airship powered
by two 930 engines.

The "Fugi Blimp" is one of these.

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 20:16:40 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944S Coolant Problem Followup


>The car is using coolant at about 1 qt/150 miles.  There is also smoke in the  
>exhaust.  It is strange, there must be coolant in the oil because the
>breather has a lot of greenish white scum, but no coolant smell is
>noticable on the dipstick.  I'd think oil would be in the coolant if the
>oil cooler failed and I don't see/smell any.
>

Well, that little tidbit of additional information seems to indicate a bad 
head gasket or a cracked head or block... Try a leakdown test and see where 
you are leaking...

It still could be the oil cooler seals, but more likely in the head...

(The real question is...why didn't you tell us all of the symptoms before 
you asked us for our diagnosis???  Any more clues that we don't know about???)
Good Luck!

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 22:09:41 -0400
From: AutoBahn1@aol.com
Subject: Makes WD 40 Look Like Water.

Gutten Tag.
I keep seeing that there is a lot of problems with rusty heat exchanger nuts.
I had the same problems on some core 911 engines that I was taking breaking
down for parts. Anyway, I told a fellow P- car nut about me problems and he
gave me a small container of some penetrating oil. He told me that the stuff
 makes WD-40 look like water. His instructions were to aply a little to each
nut and let sit overnite and wait for the magic. Of course I looked at him
and said, yeah right. Well, I tried the stuff out, (smells awful),  I came
back in the morning and got to work and I could not believe it,
5 of the 12 nuts were hand loose. The stuff is simply amazing.  If any one is
interested I can see if I can lay my hands on the address of the company. 
Matt Safranski / AutoBahn1
AutoBahn Classics
65 911

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 21 Jun 1995 22:57:45 -0400
From: Star3335@aol.com
Subject: PCA Club Race in Brainerd

Brainerd is a wonderful tourist trap of a town in the north woods of
Minnesota.  Brainerd International Raceway (BRI) as the track is called, used
to be called Donnybrook Raceway until Paul Newman raced there and it changed
hands, and the whole naming thing got pretty lofty.  The track is about 5 or
miles north of town and is a fine place to run it out.  10 turns, 2 good
straightaways - one really long one into turn one, which is a big, swooping
banked thing that you'd have to be blind to miss.  Turn two is trickier, and
turn 3 is 120 degrees - the turn just keeps on comin'.  If you're going,
you'll have a great time.  I did.

Dan Starkey (Star3335@aol.com)
'80 911SC Targa
'86 RX7

Date: 21 Jun 95 16:50:00 +1700
From: MIFSUD_BRIAN@Tandem.COM
Subject: 914: Alternative Engine Swaps

Anybody out there own a diesel Vanogon? Is the rabbit-block oriented in a tran-
verse or longitudinal orientation? If transverse, is the transaxle similar or
same as rabbit? If longitudinal, is transaxle similar or same as Vanagon? Get
where I'm going with this?  If engine is longitudinal, the engine-transaxle
adapter would be highly useful in slipping a GTI engine into a 914 wouldn't it?

Second series of STUPID questions: When I was a teenager, I read all of my dad'
s old Popular Scienc/Mechanics collection (vintage to 1930's). In a '50's era
issue, I saw a short feature on a fellow who fabricated and sold a copper water
jacket intended to be installed on a Beetle for the purposes of liquid cooling.
Dad sold collection and I forget which issue it was in.  Anyone out there ever
hear of such a thing?  I'm a mechanical engineer who can't leave (semi-) well
enough alone and I want to f*rt around with the thermodynamics and flowdynamics
of my Type I and IV motors.  For all those out there who need to lead me back
to the straight and narrow, please don't stomp on my "what if's", it's the only
fun thing about engineering.  P.S. for Porsche relevancy, the race turbos had
liquid cooling in heads so even the factory "cheated".

thanks  brian    '76 2.0
                 '88 16' Bank Dory, (will trade + cash for VW Double Cab)

Porschephiles #1497                         Thu Jun 22 12:43:03 CDT 1995
Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 09:33:10 +0200
From: epkjna@kaepk4.ericsson.se (Johan Andersson)
Subject: Fitting of pre '74 exhaust


Hi all,
I'm backdating the exhaust on my '77 911 to the pre '74 exhaust.
In this way I will hopefully gain some HP's (Anybody knows how many?).

However I've been told that this should be an easy fix where the
main problem would be to remove the old rusty exhaust as discussed 
here recently.

But is there ever an easy fix???
                     ====

Yesterday as I had removed the old exhaust and was in order to mount the
older type of heat exchangers, I discovered a not foreseen problem!!!
The problem is that the older type of heat exchangers doesn't fit 
because an oil line is in the way!!!
The oil line is going from the left side of the engine towards
the rear and then round the rear of the car, through a
rubber hose on the right side of the car, and then into the oil cooler.

Does anybody know how this oil line was mounted on the pre '74 911's ?
Is there a factory replacement part or do I have to reconstruct
the oil line myself ?

Any help would be greatly appreciated!

- ------------------------------
Johan Andersson
epkjna@kaepk4.ericsson.se
- ------------------------------

# This list is operated *MANUALLY* -- all requests are handled by hand, by
# me; there is no "listserv" functionality. 
# 
# PLEASE do not burden the whole list with any of the above, and if you give 
# out info about the list, refer to the "-request" address ONLY.  Use the 
# "@tta.com" addresses listed above, instead of any other porschephiles
# addresses you might have heard about in the past. They are defunct.
# 
# Now the bad part: I run a couple of companies and a racing team. I don't
# have a lot of time  to spend on this -- it's not like I'm a grad student or
# "just a programmer" somewhere. I already *HAVE* a life...
# 
# So, what does this mean for you?
# 
# 1) adds, drops, and changes will take at least a one day turn-around.
#    No more than a three day turn around, but *AT LEAST* one day.
#    If you don't like the list or need to drop off of it, SENDING MORE
#    THAN ONE REQUEST ONLY PISSES ME OFF AND DOESN"T GET YOUR REQUEST
#    PROCESSED ANY FASTER.

I'm sorry that you feel like "it didn't work". The last time I did any
list maintenece was *exactly* three days ago, so I know you're under my
advertised turn time. Here I am getting to really read mail for the
first time in three days, and I get this. See Figure One.

OEM Continental rears are at 5,000 miles and already I am shopping for
new ones (of a different brand).  These are street tires with two
sort-of track days. I didn't run it hard either day - and it still beat
my '77 with 3.2 motor and 7 years of track development and some spirited
track driving.  The 993 beat it by a second and I was trying to make
sure the tires didn't squeal.  This result gives mixed emotions.  Am I
glad the 993 beat it so easily or just a little disappointed that all of
that effort and money in the '77 was trumped so easily?  Philosophy was
never a strong suit.  I have heard the Yokohama AVS are recommended for
the rear. They may not be better for the track but I understand they
last longer and I have to drive it everyday.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 20 Jun 1995 22:04:51 -0500 (CDT)
From: Paul Christopher Schlesselman <pcs0001@jove.acs.unt.edu>
Subject: Re: A/C on 944 info exchange



RE: a/c compressor cycle 'problem'

I believe that the a/c is supposed to cycle on and off.
The system on a great many other autos do it as well.
(my ac cycled when I lived in Phoenix and when i was in Alberta)

there is a resivoir that is filled (accumulator) with liquid
refrigerant (R-12) and the compressor turns off when it is 'full'.
and then comes on again when 'low'.  
also the system is designed to 
keep the evaporator (under dash) from droping below about 1c 34F so
ice doesn't form.

Hope that helps

- ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
schless@jove.acs.unt.edu **Perfection is Acceptable** schless@cyberspace.com
http://www.unt.edu/~schless *Porsche 951* http://www.cyberspace.com/~schless
- ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 95 08:30:31 EST
From: cornelius-halvey@smh-mail.smh.com
Subject: 993 Tire wear

          I've got 12K on my 993 now. When I changed the oil and 
          filter at 7300 miles ($240!!!!), the dealer recommended 
          replacing the rears (Dunlop SP-8000).  Unfortunately they 
          were on backorder and I didn't get them until I had 10,700 
          miles on the car ( and one flat later).
          
          This car is such a kick to drive, those rears have to take a 
          beating. Any guesses on rear tire life for the twin turbo? 
          It probably says in the owner's manual: "at each 
          fillup,check the oil level and rear tread for excessive 
          wear. Replace the rear tires if necessary."  ;-)
          
          Safe motoring P-filers...
          
          Neil Halvey

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 09:28:59 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: 1971 911T - Original Bumpers - To sell or no.

On Tue, 20 Jun 1995 dpoad@inforamp.net wrote:

> This is a tough decision. I recently put fabricated RS style 
> bumpers on my 911. It's been suggested to me to keep the 
> originals on the shelf for future resale. I'd like to comply, 
> but I believe it'll be a long while before a "T" is a 
> collectable;in the meantime cashing in on the bumpers is pretty 
> tempting. Am I being a heretic here? In the meantime, any 
> offers?  
Many people have said in magazines and such that the 'early' (up 'til '73 
when all the electronics came along, '73 incl, BTW) 911's will become 
collectable cars in the next 5 years as they all become 25 years old. The 
ones most worth keeping are good, mostly original, 911 T,E,S (the others 
already know they are something) I would keep the bumpers if I were you. 
On another note, some of the E and S 911's of that period had a tendency 
to self destruct their engines because of too high compression, leaving 
only T's behind... Keep in mind too, that T's are the lowest of the 
bunch, and therefore are the most affordable 911 a person can get (well, 
excluding Oklahoma Foreign's specials on rollovers and such)
 -Derek


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 07:15:05 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: 914 FI question

Hi Rick. Re:

>I have made all the tuning adjustments to the ignition system and fuel 
>system of my '72 914-4 and it runs beautifully with the exception that it 
>is running a bit rich.  I've heard I can adjust this by turning the screw 
>on the pressure sensor, but which way???  Clockwise or counterclockwise 
>to lean out my engine?  THanks in advance!   Rick

"Right (cw) for Richer, Left (ccw) for Leaner"

| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  |

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 07:45:45 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: Solution to Michell's Valentine Problems

You wrote: 

>my point is that for $400, we shouldn't have to put up with these 
>obvious flaws.

Mitch:

Yeah, I know the short life of an RJ-11 jack seems like an "obvious 
flaw", but there really isn't another solution that's any better for 
the average Valentine user.

The RJ-11 phone jack has two very large advantages:

    1.  It's the only 4-wire connector in real common use, so it's
        cheap.
    2.  When a user needs a custom-length power cord, he can get one at
        any hardware or electronics store.  This is much nicer than
        having to cut the old connectors off the power cord, buy wire,
        solder the new wire to the old connectors, etc.

I can't think of another 4-wire connector, as commonly-available as 
RJ-11,  that would be more reliable.  Do you have any ideas?
  
 -Andy

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 08:58:04 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re: Fitting of pre '74 exhaust

Just finished installing SSI (pre '74) exhaust on my 1975 911s. Yes you do need 
two new oil lines, one metal line which goes from the fitting on the drivers 
side of the engine around to near the oil cooler on the passenger side, and then 
a second line which mates up to the oil thermostat in the passenger rear fender 
well. 

Both of these are readily available, I am surprised that the seller of your 
exhaust didn't tell you that they were necessary. The cost (oem) is about $159 
in Excellence.

You also need to remove the air injection system and plug the rotten little 
holes in the head. The thread is M10 x 1mm which is hard to find. I took some 
bolts, cut the tips off into plugs and hacksawed as screwdriver slot into them, 
then loctited them into the holes. (PS to all...was this a nutty or unnecessary 
move??).

I didn't have any trouble removing the old ones as they were essentially new 
when I replaced my 2.7 with a Kremer built 3.2. Replacing the nuts is tough as 
you really need a wobble socket fitting as you need to torque them to about 17 
ft lbs, while placing them at an slight angle to get around the actual 
exchanger.

Oh yes, you probably need to buy some of the new type heater hoses to mate up to 
your existing system, I haven't go mine in yet as they seem too bloody long, but 
Tweeks swears they are the right ones. 

Give me a mail if I can fill in more war stories.....they are great once they 
are in!!

Dennis Kalma

PS anyone out there interested buying a complete air injection system including 
pump and manifold in excellent condition??

Also, I have the pre-muffler (replacement for a cat on a 911SC)  original 
Porsche part with 1300 km on it....anyone want to buy it??

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 11:25:40 -0500 (EDT)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: I Can't Drive 55


Check out the Nationwide Police Car Description Web server at:

	hhtp://eden.telalink.net/zommst/cocars/copcars.html

It is a database of highway patrol car descriptions for cities around
the United States, offering a detailed look at many of them.

It also gives helpful hints regarding the most common radar traps.

I haven't checked it out yet, but thought some of us might like to have
a look...

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 16:33:03 +0000
From: Gerald Haussler <ghaussle@ecs010.usps.gov>
Subject: dean pilgrimage

sorry folks...tried to reply to chris' post but mail was returned "unknown

- ----- Begin Included Message -----


chris !
re: dean pilgrimage
i was there in 85 (30 YEAR) as part of the 356 registry west coast holiday.
there may have been media etc. but i didn't see any, although i was only there
for a couple of hours. it seemed that most of the fan base is hot-rod oriented.
LOTS of chopped '49 mercs!! and i mean lots. i understand that they start out
at johnnie von neumanns' place, stop at a malt shop (!), and continue along the
same route that dean took that day making all of the stops along the way. i also
understand that there are more than a few clubs. some big others not. i was 
quite impressed. lots of greasy hair and bleached blondes. the post office was
there with one of their mobile offices, special cancellations, etc. the coolest
thing was a t-shirt with a haunting image of deans' eyes on the front designed
by the japanese (mega) fan that erected the monument a few miles up the road 
from the crash site. giant bronze plaques (like 4' x 6') have been added over 
the years. the 'road marker' you refer to is a stainless steel triangle that
surrounds a tree. the plaques are supported off the ground at the trees' base.
the actual crash site has been obscured by the fact that, due to road improve-
ments, the intersection of highways 41 & 46 now resides about 50 yards away.
anyway, good luck w/ your idea. who knows?
best 
jerry

p.s. just got done replacing (or is that ADDING??) the forward shift linkage
bushing in the 912, JESUS does this thing shift nice now! 'cuz you know me i
don't know nuthin' but "monkey motion".

'58 speedster (brigette)
'59 coupe (natacha)
'66 912 (2 blue)
'40 merc. (elizabeth louise)
turbo, carrera & sluggo the felines

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 12:30:38 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 Oil Press/Temp Guages

>1) Oil Pressure.  0-30 or 0-100 PSI (I'm assuming 0-30).

        The two ranges of gauges I was offered by GPR were 0-80 and
0-150.  0-30 is *definitely* too small.  I'm getting the gauge because
I want to keep mine under 60-70 PSI.  (Non-stock oil pressure control
spring.)

>2) Oil Temperature.  What should my 'normal' operating range be ?

        Get a gauge that will read up to 250 F or more.  Normal would
be just over 212 F--gotta get the water out of the oil!  240 is too damn
hot.

>4) Anyone know where I can get senders for these at reasonable $$ ?

        GPR is pretty good.

>5) Any tips on putting these in (73 2.0L w/carb, 72 car).

        Carbs?  Yech!  Oh, well.  To put the oil pressure sender on a
914, you need a new sender (duh).  One that is calibrated to work with
your new gauge.  Dual senders are not much more expensive than the
single ones, and it's still a Very Good Thing to have the idiot light
right in your field of view.  There's an "adaptor kit" which is essen-
tially a hose with fittings on either end.  You screw the hose into the
hole where the idiot light sender is now (up by the distributor) and
then screw the other end into the dual sender.  Then find somewhere to
mount the sender.  You'll need two wires going into the cockpit--the
old idiot light wire is good for one, try locating the defroster wire
for the other one.  Or some other unused (*really* unused!) wire.
        You can get the sender, adaptor, and gauge for about $70 total
from GPR.

        For the temperature sender, you'll need to replace a "sump cover"
on the bottom-left side of the engine.  Porsche made ones fitted for a
temp sender, and they are available aftermarket as well.  Check with GPR,
AutoMashin', and local wreckers.  AFAIK, put the sender in the new plate,
drain your oil, replace the plate, and find a wire to hook the sender to.
In the stock applications, it goes across the bottom of the engine, up
through the sheetmetal on the right-hand side, and connects with a wire
from the main harness.

        Putting the gauges in is your problem.  Several companies make
plates to hold them.  My new oil pressure gauge is going into the center
console, replacing that cheesy clock.

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"

Porschephiles #1498                         Thu Jun 22 22:37:35 CDT 1995
Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 12:51:36 -0500 (CDT)
From: Chuck Campbell <campbell@Starbase.NeoSoft.COM>
Subject: mail stoppage /was drop for vacation

Sorry to drop a non porsche related message, but this is probably of interest
to anyone on this and other mailing lists.

get procmail!

This is a public domain package that filters mail for you.  It can be installed
even if you use a dial up service for mail (usually).  This is what I've done
since my current provider does not have it installed for general use.

It will do a lot for you, but mostly...

you can send any/all mail to /dev/null while on vacation, not bother anyone
on the list with drop/add messages, not bother stan with drop/add messages
to the correct location, and you can turn it on and off as easily as renaming
or editting a file.  It will not use any disk space when messages are sent
to /dev/null.

It also makes a great sorter for breaking out anything (and I mean anything)
you wish to ignore, focus on, etc.

If you want help finding it or setting it up, email me and we'll get it 
working.  This should help stan's administration issues some.

 -chuck

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 95 10:52:00 PDT
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: RE: My dream come true


I have to offer up a little defense for our fellow porschephile,  here.  I 
agree that there is usually a good reason for low limits, 25, 35, but 45s 
are generally road defined.  I've never seen anything greater than 25 or 35 
 where there are children or residences.  In suburban areas, 45s here in the 
state of Northern California mean the traffic engineers (these are the 
engineering students who couldn't do anything else) thought that those 
curves might be too much to Grandma in her old buick.

I don't know anything about Hickory, but it may be quite desolate and rural, 
so the possibility exists that our friend was just enjoy his P-car for a 
day,  and not unnecessarily endangering anything more than rabbits or quail.

If it was near where my kids play, however, he should be emasculated.

Bob Brewer


>On Wed, 21 Jun 1995 sidak_ok@MIKE.LRC.EDU wrote:

>got
>> out of the car the cop drove up next to the 993 rolled down his window 
and
>said
>> "NEXT TIME SLOW THAT THING DOWN"
>>  There is a GOD.
>
>There is indeed a god - and he decreed that thou shalt not drive like an
>absolute prat in areas with low speed limits - the usual penalty is going
>to jail for killing someones child!!!
>
>If there is a 45 mph limit it is probably there for a good reason - why
>not stick to it and help keep the cops of the backs of the rest of us.
>
>we all enjoy getting the hammer down from time to time, but 45 limits
>isn't the right time.

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 11:33:06 -0700
From: thaas@ix.netcom.com (Tad Haas )
Subject: 914 Oil Temp Gauge - How much red?

Hopefully simple question:

On a 74 914 2.0L with center console oil temp gauge,  how far into the 
wide red zone is 'too far?'   

I just got this 2.0L this past weekend and the gauge is different than 
on the 1.8L (w/ctr console) that I have been driving and racing 
(autocross and time trials) for the past two years.  

On the 1.8L  there is just a little (less than 1/8 in) red zone all the 
way to the right.  It is real obvious when you get too hot.  Hasn't 
really happened much, unless on long hot summer day trips in TX sun or 
extended track periods at full blast.

The 2.0 has a red zone that starts about midway on dial.  This car 
reaches that red zone much faster.   Any comments???   Yes I know I 
probably want to put in an oil cooler,  I am planning too eventually.

Tad Haas
thaas@ix.netcom.com
74 1.8L 914 (Stan Hanks old car) Nicknamed "Rodney" cuz gets norespect!
74 2.0L 914 - New addition

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 14:40:19 -0500 (EST)
From: NFENNESS@PEARL.TUFTS.EDU
Subject: DOT5 and Brake Light Switch Death

Dear P-Philes
   Some time ago, we held a discussion regarding the pro/con of using DOT 
5 (silicon) brake fluid.  For the past 3 years, I have had to replace the 
brake light switch in Ol' Blue come spring wake-up inspection time.  The 
original switch lasted 8 years under silicone before "heading south".  
I've been using cheap $7 switches rather than the $22 switch in 
Automotion or Tweeks.  Has anyone else run into this problem?  

     - Neil
     '67 912

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 95 19:59:54 PDT
From: Roy Duckles <aa25@solo.pipex.co.za>
Subject: Re: 914 specs (British)

This is a message from Mark Honman

A bit late, but for curiosity's sake, figures from "The Autocar". The
914/S (1679cc) was tested some time before November 1970 (as far back 
as I can go): 102 mph, 0-60 14.8s, 25 mpg.

A test of the 914/6 (2.0) was published in the 7 January 1971 issue.
125 mph,    0-60 8.3s,    1/4 mile 16.2s 84 mph,    21.3 mpg. 
standing kilometre 30.0s 102 mph
110bhp(DIN), 131 lb.ft (DIN).

P.S. This issue has a cutaway drawing of the 914/S. They describe the
     914 aerodynamics as "exceptionally clean". 

Mark Honman

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 95 12:51:02 PDT
From: John Wright <jpw@hpsadlb.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Targa glass install

>Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 09:02:03 -0700 (PDT)
>From: tfab@netcom.com (thom fitzpatrick)
>
>One last thing:  I plan on painting my 911 later this year, maybe late summer.
>I want to remove the back windshield when I do.  The question is, how do
>you get that puppy back in?  I know how to do the front, but not the back,
>unless its exactly like the front, which it doesn't appear to be.  Remember, 
>it a targa!

I removed mine (72T) but had a local auto glass shop install it.

As I remember, it was about $80.00 to install on an "spare" time
basis.

It probably took a week for him to get around to it.

He asked that the glass/wiring harness/gasket/trim be delivered first
so he could set this up before the car arrived.

These parts are assembled and then the assembly is installed.

I had to install the Targa bar cover, interior paneling.

BTW, I had the rear glass film-tinted when it was off. 

This cost $150 at a shop in San Jose, CA. 

If you're planning on having it tinted, glass off the car is the only way to
do it.

John Wright   jpw@sr.hp.com

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 95 11:36:51 PST
From: "RADSICKT" <radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil>
Subject: H.G. Bieker and my 2.0 litre heads

 Stan,
 
 (next in my series of stupid questions)
 
 I called Bieker to ask for him to add a few things to my list of "things to do" 
 on the heads:
 
 First I asked if he was going to match the combustion chamber volumes and he 
 said that was a waste of time.  I guess that they are gonna be really close 
 when he is done so that there is no reason to do that?  (I asked that because 
 on my last set of VW heads, they did that but then again they reshaped the 
 chambers as well....)
 
 Then I was gonna see if he could install a set of stiffer springs, in 
 particular, the FAT performance set.  I told him I plan on using the FAT FC 
 HP440 fuel-Injection-friendly cam.  He said that he basically does two types of 
 914 engines... bone stock and race modified.  He warned me about using a 
 non-stock cam with FI and said that the springs would increase the wear on the 
 valves.  He said to check with my guru (that would be Mr. Hanks, formerly of 
 Ghost Racing) about if I wanted to get FAT to send out a set of springs.  He 
 seemed to like the stock ones....
 
 Questions for you (and the p-phile list):  I know that using stiffer springs 
 and the 440HP cam is a trade-off, but is it a good one?  How about using the 
 440HP with stock springs or sticking with all stock stuff?  Any idea as to what 
 sort of HP and performance gain that cam alone would provide on an 8.2-8.5 cr 
 2.0L d-jet engine when compared to stock cam on that same engine?  Am I gonna 
 have any driveability probs with the 440HP and d-jet?
 
 Oh, one more:  For a high-flow oil pump, what do I use? I heard that the 
 Melling pump is good -- I assume that people mean the Type I since I have seen 
 a Type IV.
 
 I realize that these questions were probably answered before, so I apologize.  
 On the other hand I really want to do this thing right!  Thank you again for 
 your time!
 
 -Tim
 radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 20:39:15 -0400
From: Jrhetten@aol.com
Subject: Re: Battery Drain

The  PCNA  part numbers for the 'battery maintainer" are 000 043 202 56,
01027-S0, 2086243, BA 16 B 2. 

The device looks like any other ac to dc transformer, plugs into a wall
socket and has about 30' of cord to reach the cigarette lighter.  List price
is about $90.

Jim Hettenhaus
911 C2 CAB

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 95 17:34:16 PDT
From: Scott=D=Berry%MfgEng%GPID@banyan2.BV.TEK.COM
Subject: re: "Need Honda for Daily Driver,"says wife. Need Assistance.


Buy a 1988 or newer Honda CRX (an Si if you want to spend the extra $).  My wife 
has one.  I bought it with 40K miles on it for $5000 and it now has 100k on it 
and feels as good as the day we got it.  In fact the only thing I have had to do 
to it is tune it up once, change the rear brakes and put in a new timming 
belt/water pump at 90k.  This little pocket rocket is hard to beat for the 
money.

Scott

66 912

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 21:00:13 -0400
From: ed@softarc.com (Edward Agabeg)
Subject: 944 A/C Info

Hello all,

Very quick question regarding A/C as Toronto just had a heat wave and I was
able to use it for three days straight.

How often should the A/C Relay  click on/off? In my '87 944 I hear this
relay (I assume it's a relay) click about every 30 seconds or so. I also
feel something that can be described as a "power drain" when the A/C kicks
in (click sounds) then Approx. 30 seconds later I feel some power returning
as the other click is heard. This continually cycles as the cabin fills
with nice cool air.

Question: Is this normal operation? It's the clicking that really bugs me I
guess.

Thanks,

Edward Agabeg
Upper Canada Region
ed@softarc.com
'87 944 (cool)

P.S. No the sunroofs not fixed yet and yes I'm calling the shop constantly
trying to book the car in. Anyone have a large polo mallet? :)



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 18:26:56 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: A few loose ends...

Hi Jerry. Re:

>P-volke:
>
>Mein erstes Porschefahrt ist garade dabei!

It's _die_ Fahrt, therefore "Meine erste Porschefahrt ..."

>My "to-do" list is shrinking fast before the powertrain goes in.  I have 
>run into a bit of a snag and since I don't want to lose a finger or hand
>I seek advise:
>
>One of the torsion bars for the rear deck lid(914) isn't seated under 
>the plastic wheel on the hinge(the other is fine).  Any words of wisdom
>as to how to re-seat the torsion bar so both hinges are properly loaded?

I have used a Hazet 10/11mm offset box-end wrench (the end is in-line with
the handle of the wrench, but about 1" lower) in a way that allows me to
lever against the end of the rod. Not the right tool for the job, but it
worked in a pinch ...


 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  |
|        standard disclaimers apply         | 
|___________________________________________|         


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 21:45:12 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 A/C Info

>
>How often should the A/C Relay  click on/off? In my '87 944 I hear this
>relay (I assume it's a relay) click about every 30 seconds or so. I also
>feel something that can be described as a "power drain" when the A/C kicks
>in (click sounds) then Approx. 30 seconds later I feel some power returning
>as the other click is heard. This continually cycles as the cabin fills
>with nice cool air.
>
>Question: Is this normal operation? It's the clicking that really bugs me I
>guess.

Yep, a cycling like that is about normal...

More likely than not, it will depend on the temperature setting that you 
have set the control to... The higher the setting, the less often will the 
AC clutch cycle...
Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net
Purveyors of Used 944 Parts and Services to "Her Majesty"
Orders: 800-all-p944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
83 944, 87 944S (SOLD!), 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 80 GMC Pickup


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 22:23:37 -0400 (EDT)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: re- corroded exhaust fastne

Soren

You forgot to mention one of my favorite techniques for removing
those stubborn fasteners.  Get out the old gas hatchet (acetylene
torch), heat to cherry red, douse with ice water.  Be careful what
you heat, use plenty of fireblanket, and don't forget the fire
extinguisher (don't ask me how I know this!).

This technique is not for the faint of heart and I *definitely*
recommend less aggressive procedures first.  I have had
excellent results with Kroil penetrating oil applied per your
recommendations.  (If you know you're going to do the 
maintneance, soak out *everything*, just in case.)


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 19:47:57 -0700
From: alexands@ix.netcom.com (Scott Alexander)

had red brake calipers, which I thought were pretty slick. I have these

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 23:12:40 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Battery Drain

At 04:23 PM 6/18/95 -0400, Poorsh@aol.com wrote:
>I have '89-C4.  the battery completely drains after 5-6 days without use.
> Why?  how do I correct this??

To memory, on the early C4's there was a problem with a wire on or
around the radio.  I think it was getting the insulation rubbed off, and
draining the battery.

There was a tech bulletin last year describing protocols for solving
drain problems on the 4 and 6 cylinder cars.  It included a change to the
wiring of the 911 clock to reduce drain.  Bulletin is book K, group 2,
number 9402, dated 29 Mar 94.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 23:14:39 -0400
From: ECJACK@aol.com
Subject: Vehicle Id Numbers

P-philers,
     I'm making great progress re-reassembling my '82 911SC Targa.
 (reassembled theft recovery).  I'm trying to reconstruct the history of the
car,  but all of the original VIN numbers (redundant?) are gone.
It has a reassigned six digit Kentucky number which obviously doesn't  tell
me much.  My Haynes manual mentions two places where the VIN will appear: 1)
on the "A" pillar adjacent to the winshield on the drivers side. 2) on the
trunk floor, forward and to the right of the gas tank.  I can see where the
numbers have been removed in both of these places.  My question is, does the
VIN appear anywhere else on the car?

                                                            Thanks,

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 23:43:15 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: '89 951 Brake System Questions

At 10:38 AM 6/21/95 EST, Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov wrote:

>I have a question about the brake system on the '89 944 Turbo models.  Is
there 
>some kind of pressure reservior mechanism the keeps the brake pressure up for 
>the power assist function?  If so, where is it located and how can it be 
>inspected?

Hi Tracy,

Your car uses a vacuum boost.  It's that black flying saucer behind the
brake master cylinder.  It's a simple yet clever device.  When you step
on the brakes, the linkage movement causes a valve from the intake manifold
to open, "bleeding" vacuum into the booster.  The booster contains basically
a large diaphragm connected to the brake linkage.  With vacuum on one side
and atmospheric pressure on the other, you get up to 14 PSI (times area)
extra boost to the linkage.

As others have suggested, check the vacuum line to the booster, esp. the
one-way valve.  Also check the booster for fluid leaking into it from the
MC.

Kevin Gross

Date: Thursday, 22 June 1995 10:58pm MT
From: MARTENS%STKWWHDQ@ccsvm.stortek.com
Subject: Guinness Book of records

Pfilers,
        Porsche has attained entry into Guinness Book of Records,
following a 100,000 kilometre endurance test of a production line
911 Carrera 4. The car piloted by Gerhard Plattner and P.Ag. board
member for development Horst Marchant demonstrated its superior
driving dynamics and remarkable traction on snow and ice, over
mountain passes and international race circuits.
The test consisted ofthe following separate elements:-

A 24 hour Artic test at minus 35 degrees Celcius on the frozen
Mackenzie River, north of the polar circle in Canada;

A 24 hour run on the water covered salt layer of the Bonneyville
Salt Lake in Utah, USA;

Driving over 24 Alpine passes in 24 hours;

2,000 kilometres at full speed on a race circuit in southern Italy,
reaching an average speed of 251.6 km/h including pit stops (this
is a world record for four wheel drive vehicles);

A 24 hour run on the Porsche test track at Weissach. One kilometre
of this course is pitted with holes dents and grooves (corresponding
to stresses normally incurred in 27 kilometres of ordinary traffic).

The 911 Carrera 4 comfortably completed and passed all test elements
of the "toughest 100,000 km test for a sports car".

>From PCA Porsche Cars Australia,
via Joe Martens.

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 00:07:26 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: H.G. Bieker and my 2.0 litre heads

>  First I asked if he was going to match the combustion chamber volumes and he 
>  said that was a waste of time.  

>  Then I was gonna see if he could install a set of stiffer springs, in 
>  particular, the FAT performance set.  I told him I plan on using the FAT FC 
>  HP440 fuel-Injection-friendly cam.  He said that he basically does two types of 
>  914 engines... bone stock and race modified.  He warned me about using a 
>  non-stock cam with FI and said that the springs would increase the wear on the 
>  valves.  He said to check with my guru (that would be Mr. Hanks, formerly of 
>  Ghost Racing) about if I wanted to get FAT to send out a set of springs.  He 
>  seemed to like the stock ones....

The HD springs are mainly useful if you plan on having a high-rev application.
That means that you do the *REST* of the stuff for making reliable high
revs, which I don't think you're doing. So stock springs are OK. The valve
wear issue has never come up on a racing engine, they get torn down frequently
enough that it's never not been caught in routine "clean up". 

BTW, "high rev" means planning on sustained operation over 6000 RPM. Bursts
into that area is OK.

>  Questions for you (and the p-phile list):  I know that using stiffer springs 
>  and the 440HP cam is a trade-off, but is it a good one?  How about using the 
>  440HP with stock springs or sticking with all stock stuff?  Any idea as to what 
>  sort of HP and performance gain that cam alone would provide on an 8.2-8.5 cr 
>  2.0L d-jet engine when compared to stock cam on that same engine?  Am I gonna 
>  have any driveability probs with the 440HP and d-jet?

You *WILL* have a noticeably different idle with the 440HP. You will. Period.
It's OK for a street car that doesn't have A/C. It's intractible if you have
and insist on using A/C. 

You will see almost no HP gain in a good stock rebuild with *slightly*
higher compression. Maybe half an HP or so. Really. If you go to the
"hotter" cam, and 9:1 or better compression (max is 9.5:1 for street gas,
with oil cooler) then you'll get a fairly significant increase, on the
order of 15%. The springs issue has to do with how high you run the
engine. If you stay under 6000 RPM, you're fine with NEW stock springs.
If you're shooting for the 8000 RPM limit that you *CAN* have on more or
less stock heads, well, you've got another 3 kilobucks of parts and
labor to go -- Carrillos, lightended wrist pins, etc etc etc. *THEN*
you *NEED* the stiffer springs.

>  Oh, one more:  For a high-flow oil pump, what do I use? I heard that the 
>  Melling pump is good -- I assume that people mean the Type I since I have seen 
>  a Type IV.

Yup. Whatever FAT is selling. It's at least a Melling design...

Stan

Scott:

I had the same thought, then realized that it'd take a pretty special 
paint to handle the heat without blistering.  This led me to the 
more-important reason to leave my calipers alone, which is that heat 
transfer out of the calipers to the air probably wouldn't be improved 
by painting the things.

Those red calipers DO look bitchin', though...

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 07:14:57 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re: New paint job; what do I need to know?

Getting a car painted is a real challenge, mainly as I have found in my area 
that there is little correlation between a firm's reputation and their actual 
work. I have done all my own paint work during the rebuilding of my 911 and I'd 
do the following.

1. Try and enlist the help of other Porsche owners, car buffs or other folk who 
may have knowlege of the paint shops in your area and see if they are aware of 
any shops which can do a good job. Obviously if they are willing to go with you 
to inspect/discuss then so much the better

2. Read up on paint technology and techniques so that you at least understand 
the lingo

3. Make up your mind on things like budget, how far you want them to go (ie 
strip it down to the metal versus just apply a top coat to the visible 
surfaces). This is quite important as you need to decide whether you want them 
to strip out the windows, trim, rubber etc or whether you want them just to mask 
around all that stuff. You also should decide if you want to do some of the 
work, for example are you willing and capable of stripping the trim off of the 
car, are you willing to start with the rough sanding or repairs etc.

4. Decide on colour, if it is a colour change, remember that they then need to 
paint door jambs and the like to match

5. Go visit some shops, insist on walking around the shop and inspect the work 
and paint areas. If it looks professiona, if it appears to be kept clean in the 
paint area and if it appears that they are not just slapping on coats of bondo 
and paint then at least you have a starter. Ask to meet some previous owners, 
preferably P cars or other classic/high end cars so that you can find out 
directly from a previous client how good the work is. Try and get one at least a 
year old, in case some adhesion or similar problem came up....many lousy paint 
jobs look good for the first 6 months.

6. Have a long chat on point 3 and 4, get a firm quote, ask about whether it is 
a fixed price and, when you have 2 or 3 such quotes.....decide and go.


I won't take up the bandwidth for what to do during the whole exercise, if you 
are interested we can continue off line....

Dennis Kalma

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 07:28:40 -0700
From: "jim gregory" <jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com>
Subject: Re: New paint job; what do I need to know?

SOme qualifying paint shop questions:

	1. References. Good painters are *DAMN PROUD* of thier work
	2. INspect the facilities. Quality paint shops will have some
	   *VERY* expensive equipment in their paint booths. Downdraft
	   exhasut system is a good sign. Look at the filters near the
	   air intake areas of the paint booth. Good shops change/clean
	   these VERY frequently. It will be obvious if they do this.

	3. Ask about materials. My experience is that the really good
	   Porsche/BMW/Mercedes shops use the same paint that the factory
	   sprays. It is *DIFFICULT* to work with (I know from personal
	   experience). Few paint shops do this. The difference: Exact
	   color match, comparable finish and durability to factory finish.
	   FYI, the facotry uses polyurethane enamel paint.

	4. How do they prepare the car (preparation is everything if a quality
	   finish is desired). Is the car disassembled (mirrors removed,
	   bumpers removed, all trim removed, glass removed, etc) or is
	   it "masked off" (bad sign). Look around at other cars in process.

	5. Do they strip the car first? (only really bad prior paint will
	   require this, your facotry finish has special protective primers
	   that cannot be duplicated- remember Porsche brochures showing
	   the cars being dipped in primer with electric charges applied
	   to create better bond?)

	6. Inspect finished cars under flourescent lighting. THis exposes
	   all the imperfections in paint. Pay attention to minute details
	   (orange peel, overspray, sand scratches, dirt in paint, runs,
	   uniform gloss, uniform distribution of metallic)

A quality paint job will not be cheap. It is worth paying a premium if you
really want it to look new and last many years. TAke your time selecting and
getting to know your potential paint shop.

Good luck

 -jim

87 944turbo
(put myself thru college in a paint shop, my Porsche made possible thru capital
gains realized on Corvette show car, painted myself 5 different shades of Candy
Apple red with 18 coats of clear, trophied every show)

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 10:40:39 -0500
From: mac3d@superlink.net (Ed Dougherty)
Subject: Re:speeding/there is a god

cornelius-halvey@smh-mail.smh.com wrote:
>Subject: Speeding
>
>     We all know speeding is to be avoided. It can be dangerous on
>     our public roads. People who speed tend to be addicted to it.I
>     don't think scolding them is going change their behavior.
>     P-philers moralizing about not doing it (nobody ever called me
>     a "pratt"!) are just wasting bandwidth.
>
>     Anyway, I'd like to know what people are really doing with
>     their P-cars. If we know we're going to undergo a major flame
>     job when we admit we did 78mph in a 65 zone, the copy on
>     Porschephiles is going to rather dry.

The "dream come true" post and replies prompted me to post a similar story.
Last summer I was driving from Princeton, NJ up to Macworld Expo in Boston.
On I-84 (87?) in Conn (flame retardant: it's a 4-lane, fairly low-traffic
interstate) I finally gave in to the temptation to see just what my 951
could do. Well, speed is thrilling, but if you want a *real* adrenaline
rush just try blowing past a state trooper at 145+ mph ;>).
My co-pilot suggested ducking into the next rest stop "in case he got on
the radio". We were sitting there drinking coffee when the trooper pulled
in right next to us. I was getting ready to kiss my license goodbye when he
said "Jesus Christ almighty that's a fast little car. I thought they just
looked good. Now that you've had your fun, lighten up. Have a safe trip."
BTW, the 300+ mile drive took 3 hours, including 1 rest stop. My co-pilot
is now trying to sell his Vette to buy a Porsche. Flame if it makes you
feel better, but I didn't buy a Porcshe just to impress the neighbors.
 -ed
87 951, Guards red
89 Doberman, Dobe red

the metal crunch cut clear through my heart.

She was driving a stock 4wd toyota pick-up truck with a cab/camper/cover? on
the back.  (You know the things that go on the back of the truck to effectively
make it a king size station wagon.)  So, in a way, I can't blame her too much.
 I'm sure she could not see me.  But of course, the only damage to her was some
red paint on her chrome bumper.  15 minutes with some paint remover, and she'll
be good as new.

On the other hand, I now have an otherwise perfect Targa with some serious
damage to the passenger door and right rear quarter panel.  So, HELP please.
 Does anyone know of a few absolute top notch body shops in the Mountain View,
Sunnyvale ... Bay Area of California?  I'll be getting insurance quotes next
week.  I want my baby repaired as soon as possible (without sacrificing any
quality).

Thanks lots.
Wayne

  Wayne Michelsen  |  wayne@darien.arc.nasa.gov
   '87 911 Targa   |  Michelsen@aol.com
  GuardsRed/Black  |  415-604-0402

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 08:29:08 -0700 (PDT)
From: Walter Stander <wstander@cts.com>

> >     Porschephiles is going to rather dry.
> 
> The "dream come true" post and replies prompted me to post a similar story.
> Last summer I was driving from Princeton, NJ up to Macworld Expo in Boston.
> On I-84 (87?) in Conn (flame retardant: it's a 4-lane, fairly low-traffic
> interstate) I finally gave in to the temptation to see just what my 951
> could do. Well, speed is thrilling, but if you want a *real* adrenaline
> rush just try blowing past a state trooper at 145+ mph ;>).
> My co-pilot suggested ducking into the next rest stop "in case he got on
> the radio". We were sitting there drinking coffee when the trooper pulled
> in right next to us. I was getting ready to kiss my license goodbye when he
> said "Jesus Christ almighty that's a fast little car. I thought they just
> looked good. Now that you've had your fun, lighten up. Have a safe trip."
> BTW, the 300+ mile drive took 3 hours, including 1 rest stop. My co-pilot
> is now trying to sell his Vette to buy a Porsche. Flame if it makes you
> feel better, but I didn't buy a Porcshe just to impress the neighbors.
> -ed
> 87 951, Guards red
> 89 Doberman, Dobe red
> 
> 
> 

Okay, so here is my skeleton on the subject:

At the time , I was active duty military and had a 1986 944. So, it is 
0300 on a 4-lane urban freeway, the moon is bright, the road clear, my 
halogens on burn-through, and I enter the I5 to I8 interchange at 5500 in 
4th, bend left into the perfectly banked, 3-lane, uphill curve, 
flattening out in 5th and continue hard onto the straight. I can see 
forever to the west..........

This road runs 3+ miles straight until it ends at a T controlled by a light.
About 1/2 mile into this run I detect a 'tailgater' on my butt. Large 
chills hit my spine as I realize that this car is so close to my rear 
that if I lifted (let alone braked), there would be a collision. Jinking 
left or right didn't shake him and by now I was down to less than 90mph; 
he was now so close I could not see his headlights! I also know that in 
less than 45 seconds, a decision point (the T intersection) would occur 
and all the PCA racing school lessons were instinctively coming to play.

One half-mile before the intersection, the lights on the police car came 
on and he backed off enough to let me hit the brakes and clear the left 
turn into the intersection. Very calmly he wrote me the ticket for 80+ in 
a 55 zone (his speedo was only certified up to 80). 

I never ran like that again. Two reasons (1) the police car that 
tailgated me could very well have been a drunk and  may have rammed me or 
forced me off the road (2) $273 fine plus $180 increase on my insurance.

(Next time: Walt tries to control a Geo Metro sideways on three wheels.)

wstander@cts.com
wstander@score.com
1987 944S (recently sold)
1994 Ford Aspire
1994 Itasca Passage
1984 Yorkshire Terrier (Pyper)
1986 Yorkshire Terrier (Cynnamon)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 11:44:16 -0400
From: bktech@ot.com
Subject: Re: 944S oil cooler problems

Mike,
	I have just gone through a similar experience with my 1987 944S.
we replaced the oil cooler seals twice with no success. After pressure testing 
the cooling system with the cam cover off it appeared that there was coolant
leaking from the upper front head stud. After removing the head, cleaning it, 
and preparing for new valve guides, we saw a crack in the head between the two 
front head bolt holes on the top of the head (cam side). I thought I had a 
rare 
problem, but maybe I didn't. I suspect you have a similar problem. My oil was
not milky so we did not replace the rod bearings ( no problems yet). We 
replaced
the head with a rebuilt one from Porsche (use the new part number with - CRX 
suffix). It came with new valves and springs and appeared to be as close to 
new as you could get. Good luck. - Bill Maroun (bktech@ot.com)

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 08:54:59 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: A few loose ends...

> 
> One of the torsion bars for the rear deck lid(914) isn't seated under 
> the plastic wheel on the hinge(the other is fine).  Any words of wisdom
> as to how to re-seat the torsion bar so both hinges are properly loaded?
> 

This is a common point for metal fatigue failure..  I wound up
replacing both of my engine lid pivot points.  Check carefully.

AEK's method of grabbing the bar with a box-end wrench works.
Watch your hands though; they cost a *lot* more than engine lids.
(limit two per customer.....)

Gary.

Oh please, Ralph Nader, calm down!  Like you wouldn't wind up a 993 if someone
gave it to you for the day!  In fact I was surprised that they only took it
to 100 MPH, I've had my 928 at 120 in a 45 just last weekend.  This was on a
road bordered  by trees and no houses.  Remember, these cars do have brakes
and when I'm driving this fast my senses are completely focused and ready to
react, whether it be a cop or rabbit.  Where would you suggest we drive 100?
The Beltway? I don't think so, not where the cops are ready, willing and able!


If there is a 45 mph limit it is probably there for a good reason
>>>

That is BULLSHIT!!@!  There was a great article in Car and Driver a while ago
about how the government decides on speed limits on certain roads.  They use
this absurd formula that takes every possible danger into account(like snow,
deer, school busses, etc.) and then subtract 10 miles per hour for good measure
!  So, a curve that is safe to take at 45 miles per hour is set at 20 mph
because someone might not have the common sense to slow down in the snow during
 deer season while school busses are dropping off kids from school!  My
favorite sign is on the way to Summit Point raceway where the speed limit is
30 MPH on most of the wonderful road that leads to the track.  On one of the
curves there is a sign that tells you that is is only safe to go around it at
35 MPH!  Go figure...


we all enjoy getting the hammer down from time to time, but 45 limits
isn't the right time.
>>>

As I said above, it depends where you are!  Don't generalize!

**Sorry, but I've sort of kept to mysef the whole time I've been on the list
(almost a year!) and this one really got to me...  I'm ready for the first
flaming of my Porschephiles career!  :)

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 12:11:51 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: p-philes James Dean pilgrimage

On Wed, 21 Jun 1995, Chris Robyn wrote:

> Okay, this may be morbid.  After all, he did die behind the wheel of a
> Porsche, but does anyone know if there might be any type of gathering,
> formal or informal on September 30, 1995...the 40th anniversary of "the
> crash?"
Well, being from Indiana and all, and having lived most of my years only 
a short drive away from his hometown, I know that there is a James Dean 
festival EVERY year at about that time. I'm not sure if it will be on the 
30th this year or not, but there have ALWAYS been a showing of nice 356 
and 550 (I believe there was one real other than James Dean's, and the 
rest replicars) along with some other 50's style cars...
Oh, and be clear that if you don't want to be in the parade, you're 
looking for PUBLIC PARKING. The first year we went in the '73T, 
unsuspecting that anyone would consider this to be a classic automobile, 
we just asked where we should go, we were pointed to a line, and in 4 
minutes, the procession started moving slowly but steadily... Soon, when 
we realized that all the people on the sidewalks were stopped and cars 
ahead and behind us were throwing candy... THEN we realized, "Oh shit, we 
got in the wrong line!" But hey, it was fun... just not enough to ever be 
in the parade again...
I will see if I can get the date and address and post it here.
 -Derek

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 16:35:45 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Craig B. Grivette" <sac62235@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: Dream?  Not mine.


Regarding comments made by the following subscribers:

> On Wed, 21 Jun 1995 sidak_ok@MIKE.LRC.EDU wrote:

Mr Pete Diffey already commented appropriately on the 100+ speeding in a 
45 mph zone, but I think it warrants additional treatment.

I'm not a prude, or else I wouldn't own a 944 Turbo (guard's red).  But, 
I also am confident in wha"t I have and don't feel the need to flaunt it.  
Driving 100+ in a residential or other 45 mph zone doesn't just "Smack of 
showoff", it reeks of immaturity and is exactly what can lead to giving 
us other drivers a "bad rep."  

Please, grow into your Porsche with style.  Showing off is only required 
if you have something to prove.  You have a Porsche;  thus, you needn't 
prove a thing.

Jackie Stewart once spoke more eloquently on this point than I could 
ever.  But, he made the distinction between driving on the track and 
driving where his or other's children might play.

I enjoy exhilerating driving just as we all do, and there is no better 
place than the track.  If you need a release, give a call to Skip Barber 
out at Sears Point.

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 95 09:35:00 PDT
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: RE: Brake fluid


Brake fluid, if kept sealed in the container, should last indefinately. 
 It's hydrophilic, however, so after the can is opened it absorbs moisture 
which is undesirable.

Bob
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 12:53:42 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 944S oil cooler problems

At 11:44 AM 6/23/95 -0400, bktech@ot.com wrote:
>Mike,
>	I have just gone through a similar experience with my 1987 944S.
>we replaced the oil cooler seals twice with no success. After pressure testing 
>the cooling system with the cam cover off it appeared that there was coolant
>leaking from the upper front head stud. After removing the head, cleaning it, 
>and preparing for new valve guides, we saw a crack in the head between the two 
>front head bolt holes on the top of the head (cam side).

Hi Bill,

Sorry this happened to you.  There was a tech bulletin describing this
problem with the 944S and 928S4 heads.  With the 944S, there was *no*
part number change on the new casting.  They bumped the part number for
the 928S4.  The "CRX" tag simply means that it's a Porsche reman'ed part,
no guarantees as to casting number.  I am not sure how one is supposed
to tell the new from old version -- perhaps the casting number is indeed
different.

There have been a bunch of repeat problems with oil/water heat exchanger
sealings, also for the sealings of the 944 Turbo's manifold (same location
as aspiro but no heat exchanger).  You have to measure and use the right
number of shims on the rear boss (or whatever it's called); covered in at
least one tech bulletin (qua PCNA nastygram to their dealership mechanics!).

Bill, yours is the first case of a cracked head I've run into myself, so I
am curious.  When you pulled the cam cover off, did you see coolant in the
head?  How noticable was the crack?

Kevin Gross

Porschephiles #1501                         Sat Jun 24 01:37:30 CDT 1995
Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 13:07:09 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Sensors to 944 DME

>I am still having trouble with my 944.  I need to now how to check the
>sensors into the DME and what process the DME looks at them in.  I thought
>it was a bad DME at first but I got another one and it still won't start.
>I have no spark at the coil.  The local shop said they could check the
>sensors that feed info to the DME, but at $55 an hour I want to try first
>since he said he couldn't give me any estimate on how long it would take.
>Also, does any one know of a good shop south of Washington DC, I live 5
>miles from Quantico.

Well, Joe, 

The proper way to diagnose this problem is to follow the diagnostic 
procedure given in Section 28 of the Factory Service Manual.

The short version for ignition problems:

1) make sure that the sensors are putting out the proper signal at the 
proper levels.

2) Check the cap, rotor, wires and coil for proper condition.

3) Replace the DME if necessary.

Sounds like you've done #3, now it's time to do #1 and #2...

Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net
Purveyors of Used 944 Parts and Services to "Her Majesty"
Orders: 800-all-p944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
83 944, 87 944S (SOLD!), 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 80 GMC Pickup

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 95 10:45:52 -0700
From: selfridg@encoreengineering.com (Mike Selfridge)
Subject: Re: Speeding

Like most laws made to protect people from themselves, speed
limits are made to fit the lowest common denominator (you know,
that guy in the Yugo with the bouncing rear tire, who's always
looking lost).  It is possible to drive faster, and still be
safe.  I'm not sure why anyone would spend the kind of money
we spend on such incredibly fast cars, if they never intended
to use them beyond the capabilities of a Yugo.  Furthermore,
driving under the speed limit does not automatically make you
safe, and driving over the speed limit does not automatically
make you unsafe.

Yes, I speed.  Here is my strategy for safe, ticket free (I
have had NO tickets at all for the past 6 years of living in
Orange County, CA) speeding:

(1) If you can't do it safely, don't.
(2) Avoid displays of excess ("exhibition of speed").
(3) Limit your speeding to rapid accelerations with minimal tire
    squealing (another "exhibition of speed").
(4) Limit your speeding, for the most part, to no more than 15%
    over the posted limit (I was told by a police officer that
    they ignore up to 10 or 15% excess speed because equipment
    errors can mount up to that--such as their radar guns and
    speedometers).
(5) Keep with the flow of traffic (don't be conspicuous).

Like many of you (and you know who you are--don't try to deny it),
I have pushed the limits, just to see what the limits are.  I had
my 928 up to 148mph on the 15 freeway, in the middle of a weekday,
with no traffic in sight.  I would have gone faster, but I caught
up to another car, and chickened out.  I did it only once, and
have never encountered conditions safe enough to do it again (like
no other cars in sight).  Since I am a new member of PCA, I look
forward to pushing the limit on the track at events.


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 95 11:46:00 PDT
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Re: New paint job; what do I need to know?


Hi Steve,

You've already gotten some good responses from Dennis and Jim, so I'll just 
add that attending a local PCA concours is a great way to find out about 
local painters.  Owners are generally eager to talk about their cars, and 
you'll get a first hand look at the results.

I'm doing my '73 Targa presently, and will use Glaurit paint in the original 
color. I was going to use PPG Deltron because I've painted with it before, 
but the original Gemini Blue isn't available.  The Glasurit will end up 
costing me and extra $150, but everyone tells me it's the best and a dream 
to squirt.  I believe the factory uses Glasurit, and possibly Sikkens, which 
is another good company.

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu
>---------------------------------------------------------------------------  
 ---
>I am contemplating getting my 82 SC repainted.  I realized that I know so
>little about this that I dont even know what questions to ask the various
>paint shops when I interview them.  This is a lot of bucks to spend and I
>would like to know how to separate the wheat from the chaff when I talk
>to body and paint shops about their quality.
>
>Every shop will tell you they do a perfect job.  How do I find out who is
>good and who is not?
>
>Thanks fellow p-filers

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 14:55:53 -0400
From: bktech@ot.com
Subject: Re:944s cracked head

>Bill, yours is the first case of a cracked head I've run into myself, so I
>am curious.  When you pulled the cam cover off, did you see coolant in the
>head?  How noticable was the crack?

>Kevin Gross

Hi Kevin,

	The coolant loss in my engine was slight and only showed up at the oil 
fill cap (looked like white grease). We only saw coolant leaking when the 
cooling 
system was being pressure tested. Originally we thought that the coolant was 
running up the stud and that the head gasket was leaking. Only after the head 
was cleaned in a cold process cleaner could the crack be seen. The crack was 
hard to see and was not noticed for several hours (the head dried and the 
crack appeared as a damp line between head bolt holes).
                                                         -Bill Maroun
                                                          bktech@ot.com
