Date: 23 Jun 1995 12:10:02 U
From: "John Lucas GRC" <John_Lucas_GRC@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re:   Steering Wheel Removal

                      Subject:                              Time:  11:58 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         RE>  Steering Wheel Removal           Date:  6/23/95

Max writes....

>I'm going to recover and re-align the steering
> wheel on my 928.  It has the factory three spoke
> steering wheel.  

>To remove the steering wheel, do I simply have to
> pull off the horn pad and remove a nut......or will I
> need a special tool.

This is an easy one!

First, disconnect the battery by undoing the ground strap in the rear of the
hatch, just underneath the tool kit.

Second, pull the horn cover off the steering wheel.  Brute force will do
nicely.

Third, get a 1/2 inch socket set and the appropriate socket to take off the
nut holding the wheel on.

Fourth, BEFORE removing the wheel, mark the wheel and the shaft so you can put
it back on in the same position.  Use a center punch and a hammer to make some
dots.

Question:  you're going to "re-align" the steering wheel?
Say what?

If you mean that the steering wheel is off center when you're going down the
road, first have a front end alignment done and specify that you want them to
check the center point steering.  That is to say, when the wheels are pointed
straight, the steering gear should be in the exact middle of its travel range.
 

If this is OK and the steering wheel still is off-center, then yes, you can
take it off and put it back on so it is "straight".

BTW, I need to have my steering wheel restitched.  I would like some feedback
from you regarding where you are getting this done, how much it costs, how
long it takes, etc.

Thanks and good luck!

John
'84 928S

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 15:43:41 -0500 (CDT)

Subject: Re: Sensors to 944 DME


The DME relay aka Fuel pump relay is a common problem.
I suggest swaping it or jumping it so that you know and can hear the 
fuel pump running.
Its a first step....

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 16:05:46 -0500 (CDT)
From: Paul Christopher Schlesselman <pcs0001@jove.acs.unt.edu>
Subject: Re: 944 wtr pump: how to?



I find it hard to imagine the original pump lasting this long pat!
my 86' 951 is on its third vasser pump (hopefully last)

it is a hell of a job to change the pump (relative to most cars)
you have to pull all sorts off stuff off just to get at it.
	underbody plastic stuff
	air box, breather lines ect...
	radiator fans
	a/c p/s belts and misc...
	cam and countershaft belts and pullies ecetetra
	hoses and h20 mix
	oil, dirt, grease
	more stuff
finally there is the pump!  held on with some bolts of various lenghts.
Remove pump bolts (including the bolts you dont see) and pop it loose.
clean up area
install new pump and all that other sh*t, including update kit for cam belt.
Have the balance and cam belt properly tentioned (I due the 'feal' method
until i get it too a shop whith $400 tension tool)

On Fri, 23 Jun 1995, Pat Norris wrote:
>-snip- waterpump 
on my '86 with about 96K miles.  So, what's it going to take to change
> this, or should my mechanic get this job?  BTW, I've done just about
> everything that's been done on the car except the belts and some seals.
> '86 944 (in need of a water pump)
>

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 16:28:46 +0800
From: losciuto@news1.mnsinc.com (losciuto)
Subject: Sensors to 944 DME

I was having a problem with my 944. It would not start/run,  I asked for
help and Paul supplied the following advice which was the solution:

>The DME relay aka Fuel pump relay is a common problem.
>I suggest swaping it or jumping it so that you know and can hear the
>fuel pump running.
>Its a first step....
>
Thanks,
This was the answer.  I actually was out looking at the relay board when I
was the DME relay.  If I had only asked the right question three months ago
before I almost went crazy trying to solve this.
I jumpered the input to the output pins and wellah my baby started up
again.  The only problem is my A/C doesn't work now probably because I
pulled something out while I had the fuse/relay panels down.
Anyway thanks for all the help.  I knew I wouldn't have to go to a shop
with all the help I got here. Thanks again.

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 20:23:54 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Should I Air Condition My 912?

> I live in College Station Texas where the weather is hot and the humidity is
> hotter, and it all is worse when you own a Porsche with black interior.  My
> question is whether I should put air into my car or not.  I have had some
> ideas about rigging up an air compressor from a latemodel econobox, and
> cutting my own hoses, and finding all of the rest of the stuff to make the
> '12 look stock from an interior point of view.  I have a 911 with air on it,
> so I have something to base my placement of equipment.  Will it run too hot?
>  Will there be no power?  I just need air to run around in, not perform, that
> is during the weekends, autocrossing......

Oh boy... 

Let me preface this appropriately: I'm a native Texican, grew up in the 
sands of far west Texas, have been in Houston for the last well, nearly
20 years. I have owned over 25 Porsches. Two had A/C. I'm currently driving
a '64 356SC, about 1500 miles a month. No A/C. 

I'm also a, ummm, how to put this most modestly, *HIGHLY* experienced
architect and implementer of air cooled engines requiring extremes of 
power. And have spent a ton of time just generally fooling around with
both the P-cars and their close bretheren, the air-cooled VWs (and Isettas,
just to get them all in...)

You *MOST EMPHATICLY* **DO NOT** want to add A/C to this particular car.

1) it's hard. You can casually add A/C to almost any 911 because for almost
   any model year, most of the 911s had A/C and both the dealer conversion
   kits and the factory parts (for the later years) are readily available.
   912 did not offer A/C as an option. You'll have to use 911 parts which 
   is fine and good until you get to the engine compartment when you find
   that you don't have anything *LIKE* the brackets you need, and that there's
   already something in the way at all of the logical places to put the
   unit. Plus

2) the engine is NOT designed to pull a compressor. It's not even designed
   to *SURVIVE* pulling a compressor. You have three main bearings. You're
   pulling on the end of the crank with a high torque moment. Go back to
   Physics 101 (maybe that's Physics 430, you did say College Station.. 8{) )
   and think about what that means. No, don't bother -- I'll *TELL* you:
   it means you're gonna bend the crank.

   Now go price 912 cranks. That should leave you pretty cold. But not
   for long because

3) the resulting loss in air flow through the engine deck lid is also 
   catastrophic and will result in engine overheating. The 911 moves a TON
   of air with that big fan, and it's also a dry-sump engine with the oil
   lines serving to radiate a lot of the heat away from the engine OUTSIDE
   of the engine compartment.  The 912 uses an oil cooler sized for operation
   in Der Fatherland, *NOT* South Texas. Any impediment is not good.

4) Finally, it's just Bad Car-ma. There are damn few decent 912s out there.
   There are a TON of clapped out late 70s Toyotas with GREAT A/C that
   you can buy for under $1200. You'd spend nearly that putting the A/C in
   the 912, so why not buy a car that HAS the A/C if you gotta have it,
   and leave the 912 alone for the next owner???

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 19:19:36 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: 914 Aerodynamics

Gary Helbig (gary@superior.ucsf.EDU) wrote:

>I'll comprimise to "streamlined brick".  That's it.

True, but put a Chalon 2 slantnose body on a 914, push the wheels out 
to the fender lips, add 911 boxed rockers, and lower the thing a few 
inches, and you get a car with exceptional aerodynamic performance.

I've got a model of my 914 (modified as described above) running in 
Algor's fluid-dynamics simulator, and it performs pretty well.  Cd is 
nothing like that of a modern passenger car (although it's 
significantly better than that of a stock-bodied 914), but it's 
respectable for such a wide-bodied car.  The center of pressure is in a 
good spot, and the body doesn't generate lift until the angle of attack 
gets really high (e.g., rear springs at full compression and front 
wheels completely off the ground).

There's still a problem with the relatively-upright windshield, but 
even that can be fixed by changing the angle of the windshield (if 
you're willing to source new vent and side glass and cut down the targa 
top so it fits into, instead of on top of, the roll bar).

The biggest problem is the low-pressure area behind the rear window.  
Bob Norwood solved this on his Can-Am Chevy-powered Ferrari GTO (in his 
case, the problem was so bad at 200 MPH that the engine was being 
starved for air) by building a giant scoop that covered the engine lid 
and extended up over the roof of the car, but that solution has obvious 
negative implications for rearward vision.  I have no idea what to do 
about this.
 
I'm thinking of cutting louvers in the front fenders to release the 
high pressure that forms there (a la the factory 911 slantnose 
fenders)... Gotta modify the model and run more simulations, I guess.

Does anyone know whether Alex Cross's shop (Swift Engineering, in San 
Clemente, CA) rents out their new wind tunnel?

 -Andy

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

shields too (just use some tape) and leave your windows cracked a little.

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 23:54:48 -0400
From: Phyl346@aol.com
Subject: Re: Sensors to 944 DME

Greetings, 
I just recently had my reference sensor go south on me.

 There are two (at least on the L-jetronic of my '83 944) sensors at the bell
housing. One is for RPM and one is for TDC.  If either is gone the engine
will not fire.  They are identical and should have three wires: one shield
and two for resistance/reluctance.  Connect a VOM between the middle wire and
the other two, checking resistance.  You should get  ~1000 ohms between one
and >1meg at the other.  sorry for the cryptic instructions but it's late.  A
new one is ~100 Dollars.  I could give you more info later if this is not
clear.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 22 Jun 1995 22:38:52 -0200
From: dhagood@henge.com (Dave Hagood)
Subject: My First Year of Porschedom

Pfellow Pfilers:

        I am rapidly approaching the end of my first year of Porsche
ownership.  I decided to
write down some of my impressions and share them with all of you.  This
will probably
be rather long, so delete it now if'n you ain't interested.

        I purchased an '84 911 Carrera Targa in early July of last year.  I
had wanted a coupe, but
I'm 6'4" tall, with a long torso, and there wasn't any way a sunroof coupe
would fit me.  Since
911s imported to the US came with a sunroof as part of the package, I would
have to find a 911
where the owner special ordered it without a sunroof, or buy a Euro-spec
car.  Since I was
wary of new smog laws, I wanted a US-spec car.  I still think a coupe looks
better, but the
Targa is a reasonable compromise.  I rejected cabs for safety reasons.

        So I have a targa.  My wife and kids love it.  I have gotten real
used to the wind in my
hair, and my colleagues at work have grown used to me walking around with
mussed hair.
I originally sort of wanted ice green paint, but wasn't that firm on it.
Ice green is gorgeous,
but the platinum color on my car keeps growing on me.

        For the most part, my 911 has been pretty reliable.  I had to
replace the ignition key,
since mine wore to the point that my key wouldn't start it.  This was
rather expensive for
the parts, but it wasn't hard to repair.  It needs a new clutch, and while
I'm in there (gulp)
I'm going to have the gearbox rebuilt, install new rear shocks, fix the
lowering job that
the PO did, adjust the valves, etc.

LIKES:

        Looks.  It's gorgeous.  It's still one of the high points of my day
to walk up to my
car.

        Huge brakes.  Monster brakes.  Brakes without end.  No muss, no
fuss, just an easily
controlled stop.  My biggest surprise, and brakes on every other vehicle
I've ever driven
*suck* in comparison.

        Power.  Tractible, easily controlled, always there.  At 100 mph at
6000 feet altitude in
4th gear, flooring the throttle provides acceleration that can be felt.
It's bone stock, too.

        Reliability.  I don't drive it hard, but then I'm not easy on it
either.  No failures, and
at 95,000 miles, the compression and leakdown are well within spec values.

        Satisfaction.  I'm sure most people have had the situation where
something long wanted
has finally been obtained, and the reality doesn't much up with the desire.
My 911 is
*better* then I'd every imagined.  I hope never to be Porscheless again.

        Porschephiles.  This list is unique in both content and general
manners.  My hat is off
to Stan and all participatory Nazi Sheep.

DISLIKES

        The hood shocks are lame.  They wear out easily and often, and
aren't cheap to replace.
I gave up in disgust and bought a cool, collapsible prop from Griot's
Garage.  Works great,
the pox on shocks.

        The cheap plastic internal door handles suck.  My driver's side
handle just broke.  Everybody
I know has handles that have broken or are breaking.  I know the car is 10
years old, but jeez...

        The door pockets split and squeak and rattle over bumps.  What do
you do with the$e
other than replace them?

        And there you have it.  One very satisfied new owner.  The only
thing I wish was different
is that my wife won't let put her half of the 911 on the track for driver's
ed events.  Oh, well...

Dave

P.S.    Arggggggggghhhhhhh!  I just limped home after clouting a curb in
the middle of a
classic half turn spin while accelerating out of a third gear corner.  The
left front is noticeably
off-(camber? caster?  The $*%&$&*%$ wheel isn't straight up and down
anymore).  The
pox on wet streets.  The pox on idiot drivers who don't adjust for weather
conditions, and
any didn't realize they were that close to the car's limit in the first place.

Unka Bart, I need some of those big one with purple spots! (sound of
repeated head banging...)

*
* David M. Hagood                       Speakin' for nobody   *
*                                                     but myself!

Date: Sat, 24 Jun 1995 01:29:02 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: 944 Idle when Cold

At 11:55 PM 6/23/95 -0400, User Dgarner wrote:
>
>My 1984 944 idles a little rough when its cold, I noticed
>that the car's idle speed is the same hot or cold (aprox. 900 RPM).
>Is there any type of choke, or is this normal?
>Could it be that I need to play with the fuel mixture? 

More likely that you have a collapsed motor mount.

Kevin Gross


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 1995 23:41:04 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Craig B. Grivette" <sac62235@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: OJ Simpson of Porschephiles


I guess the "Speeding 100+ on a 45mph country road" guy has had his 
fifteen minutes of fame.  At least he's seemed to captivate a number of 
us the way the double-murder trial has so many of my fellow Sacramento, 
California neighbors.

On task...

The issue is not speeding.  It's reality.  He wrote back to a mild 
"flame" of mine by asking (paraphrased) "How could it be showing off 
when no one was around?  "Well, basically by telling us.  You're showing 
off after the fact.  Some call it bragging boasting or blowing hot air.  
You give the impression that you are somehow proud of your act, having done
it and having been validated by being let go by the officer.

I too have broken a few similar speed laws in equally flagrant ways, but
I'm a bit embarrassed.  Not, because I'm some kind of "Casper Milktoast,"
but because I was being a "hotdog" (alone) pushing the envelope in places it 
shouldn't have been done.  I almost killed a little country boy on a 
little (45mph) country road when he and a friend were running accross the 
road.  That wasn't cool and I don't want to see someone else take my near 
fatal mishap to the next step.  

Country roads are much less deserted than one thinks.  While you may only 
see one house every mile or so, you can suddenly run into a crowded 
environment.  I know, I live in such an area and have seen it happen many 
times.

Now, on a secluded section of the Interstate, go for it if you feel 
confident of your solitude.  The open highway is much much much much much 
safer and more practical (and more fun) than a rolling country road.  
Besides, you are much less likely to put yourself in the pokey when a 
state trooper or highway patrol spot you.

Basically, the speed isn't the problem & we're not just jelous because 
that cop didn't let us off--it is just a matter of knowing when and how 
to explore the uncharted horsepower found only at the floorboard.  

I don't want to see this mailing list go limp, but there can be a 
performance skewed medium that we can all find palatable.




------------------------------

Date: Sat, 24 Jun 1995 13:05:45 +0200
From: Trond Vidar Olsen <Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no>
Subject: Making somebodys day,.....dream on!

Hiall,

Have to get my 0.02 in before this 'speeding; story gets banned.

Unfortunately(?) it is only the odd few of us that never did break the speeding limits. Most of us surely pushed our cars to the limit sometime back in our younger days.

When you get older, perhaps get a kid or so, you start to think about 'what if this/what if that happens...'. It is part of maturing.

Being a sinner (former sinner that is) on 2 or 4 wheels I understand the need and urge for younger chaps (I'm 31) to show off either by having friends in the car, or brawling wild afterwards. But I can sure tell you that noone remembers what you have 'accomplished' in this 'sport' when the years go by,...actually you hardly remember it yourself.

If I lived in the USA, where cars are looked upon as an important part of life, and not taxed to death, I would rig a race car and take it to the track as often as possible, stretching the combination of car driver as far as possible,...and have GREAT fun. This you will remember,....and look back upon with joy.

And if you're real good you don't have to brawl either, it will be official, they might even decide to give you some 'buckets' too.....!


My advice is,...if you want to play with your own *and others* lives, ...............join the UN peace corps and *protect* civilians....contrary to threathening them!


Trond V.

>

>from the 944 that I found when I got out to the car.  Checked everything,
>and under the car, and then drove home.  Pulled the cover and looked for
>the leak.  Sure looks like it's the water pump - also, it's the original
>on my '86 with about 96K miles.  So, what's it going to take to change
>this, or should my mechanic get this job?  BTW, I've done just about
>everything that's been done on the car except the belts and some seals.

Pat,

Hidden in the ftp.tta.com archives, there is a file called george.txt

Inside this file is an article I wrote for our region newsletter some time 
ago about replacing a waterpump.

It is definitely a do-it yourself job for the mechanically inclined.  Buy 
the cam belt tension gauge, the balance shaft sprocket tool and you take 
another step towards freeing yourself from the tyranny of the $50 per hour 
mechanic...
Good Luck!

From: Melissa <hongth@singnet.com.sg>
Subject: 964 wheels for 911SC

I would like to know if it is possible to fit 964 wheels 6x16" and 8x16" 
to a 911SC. From what I know, the 964 wheels have an offset of 52mm front 
and rear. This translates to a backspace of 129.1mm and 153.6mm 
respectively. The 911SC wheels have a backspace of 125mm front and rear.

Does this mean that I can fit a 4mm spacer to the front and a 28mm spacer 
to the rear? From my calculations, these spacers do not change the track 
of the vehicle.

Subject: WWW New News

Well... This certainly has been a full week in terms of WWW stuff... I 
have been struggling to stay ahead of all the new stuff to take care 
of... Kinda like when I was a sysop a while back. I've had pretty good 
results with the whoswho search form, with many requests for me to 
develop a new search program... yeah, well, maybe not today. :) It did 
however, turn out good for the most part, although it is not well 
designed enough to put out to public yet.

I have been getting enormous amounts of mail, but I do reply personally 
to all of them, so that takes a little while. Since the logs do not get 
cleared out daily, and I have not seriously looked at creating a status 
page, I have no clue whether or not hordes of people are storming the 
site, or a few are just walking in. However, from the number of mails 
straight from the page, I must assume it is doing okay. Check out 
http://tta.com/Porschephiles/OtherPages.html
This is one of Porschephiles latest services being offered. It started 
out as something to give people a few other places to visit, but has 
since its introduction (a mere week ago) grown to 22 links. All Porsche 
or car related (most Porsche/exotic car).

I've also FINALLY gotten the new TechTips logo installed, Thanks go out 
to Leonard Zech who I will properly credit on the page tomorrow. I 
haven't seen the page myself yet, due to the fact that I'm trying out 
Netscape 1.2b1, and it crashes every... 2 seconds if it's having a good 
day. :) I think I'm going to go back to 1.1N

To all those sending replies to this message and other web related stuff, 
please excuse the time I'm taking to get back. My poor computer is 
stressed just to get on the internet, and then I go and pile on graphics, 
FTP, Telnet everywhere, and more, and sometimes... well, it just can't 
take it... so, I'm trying to stay within a 2 day reply time, but then, I 
am on the Porschephiles and Air-Cooled and VintagVW lists, so by the time 
I get done reading and replying to 125 pieces of mail, I usually get 25 
more during that time...

 -Derek


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 24 Jun 1995 09:57:02 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914/6 with a 3.2 questions

Robert, 

You said:

>Just picked up my 3.2, trying to find a cheap way to hook up the pull
>clutch on the motor to my push/clutch 914 trans; anyone ever done this?

There is an article by Chuck Stoddard on this in one of the old UpFixin' der
Porsche's published by PCA.  With the orginal  914 gearbox, you use a '71 911
throwout arm and pivot (you have to drill and tap your transaxle case for it;
the boss is cast in), use the '71 throwout bearing sleeve (part that holds
the input shaft seal), use a '72 911 clutch cable, with a '71 white plastic
cable end.  He claims everything bolts up.  But with a 3.2, the 914 gearbox
ought to last about 3 nanoseconds before something breaks unless you spend
big $$ to beef it up.  Probably ought to use a 915 gearbox. Several people
have kits to do that in Panorama.

Jon Lowe
several 914's current and past

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 24 Jun 1995 09:57:05 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: G Analyst - Where can I purchase a new one?

Melissa (?)

You said:

>A few years ago, I saw the G Analyst for sale in the magazines.  Does 
>this product really work?  Other than letting us know the amount of Gs 
>one is experiencing what else does it do.  Is it still available for sale 
>from the manufacturer? 

Valentine Research made these; same people that make the Valentine One radar
detectors. They advertise the detectors in ANY  U.S. automotive related
magazine. Use the same phone number.  Last I knew, they still had parts to
make a few on demand. Easy to use, easy to set up.  Allows you to graph out
several laps showing how well you corner, brake, etc. They also make a pc
interface kit for it that allows you to graph and print out even more
functions.

Jon Lowe

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 24 Jun 1995 09:59:29 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: Sensors to 944 DME

Joe, 

You said:

> I thought it was a bad DME at first but I got another one and it still
>won't start.

Just went thru this on an '87 Turbo.  Most likely cause is one of the two
sensors on the top of the bell housing at the rear of the engine that setect
engine speed and TDC off of the flywheel.  The sensors themselves are
identical, and can go bad without warning, or a small pebble or something can
get in the housing a hit one of them. Lack of spark is a sure sign.  Remove
them one at a time and substitute known good ones. Be VERY carefull removing
them; one of ours came apart and we spent the goo dpart of a day getting the
pieces parts out.  The are a snug fit in thier holding bracket.  And no, you
can't remove the bracket with the sensors in ti because of a damn roll pin
that won't let the bracket come out without both sensors being removed.

Or you MIGHT luck out and it is the DME relay on the relay board. Obviously,
I did NOT luck out!

I now carry a spare with me to the track...

Jon Lowe
'87 944T Escort Series car

Date: Sat, 24 Jun 1995 07:47:31 -0700
From: "Jim Bauman  jbauman@btr.com" <jbauman@btr.btr.com>
Subject: Re:  Your assistance please

 
Well, you did't really say what your budget is....is it 11K or 17K?
Or more? Figure THAT out first, then start looking.  I looked for 4
months before I found the right 911. It was REALLY tough.....but I
knew I was spending hard earned cash, and did not want to make
a mistake.  It IS very easy to overlook flaws when you've got
money burning a hole in your pocket.
 
As for the car you are looking at, it's a 1979 all right, but
the 5th digit, a 3, indicates it was made for the Japanese
market! I'd say sayonara to that one....

Because this is your first 911, I'd follow Bruce Anderson's
advice and get the newest one you can afford, with the lowest
miles and fewest problems. The fact that you're looking at late
70's/early 80's is a good sign.  You don't need to settle for
lousy body work. To me, that would be an indication of the shape
of the engine too.

Good luck...

Jim Bauman
'86 Carrera Cab
GETA911

Date: 24 Jun 95 13:10:53 EDT
From: Dennis Winter <71334.2372@compuserve.com>
Subject: Auto Body Shops in MtnView CA

>>   Does anyone know of a few absolute top notch body shops in the Mountain
View, Sunnyvale ... Bay Area of California?  I'll be getting insurance quotes
next week.  I want my baby repaired as soon as possible (without sacrificing any
quality). <<

Wayne,

Del's in San Jose. Top notch, but lacking in the 'soon as possible' department.
Also, your insurance company will most likely refuse to pay his hourly rates.
Mine did. He had my SC for 3-6 months. $10,000+ of repairs and paint. Car was
rear ended, and he got the insurance company to re-paint everything but the hood
and front bumper. At their rates of course, I covered the difference. The car is
gorgeous.

	D.	23-Jun-95 at 22:54:06 PT


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 24 Jun 1995 12:34:58 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Autocrossers 911 How much gas in the tank?

> I have a question for you experienced Porsche autocrossers.  Do you 
> have a full tank of gas when you autocross, or empty?  What do you gain 

I run (ran, actually -- haven't had time to autox in a while) with a full
tank. I also ran with the spare tire, and a ton crap in the front trunk.
Here's why:

1) extra weight over front wheels helped reduce understeer 

2) that's the way I drive it on the street, and how it handles on the
   street is what I'm used to

3) it *REALLY* pisses the "I'm a totally serious autocross guy, don't
   breath on my car it might screw up the alignment" crowd off when I
   beat them (and beat them and beat them....) and then don't even have 
   to re-pack the car to go home...

If, as you say, the car handles better than you drive, what the hell are
you worried about micro-optimizations like THIS for?? Lighten up, get some
seat time with a minimum of fuss and when you get to the point that
you start winning, please note that you didn't have to do anything special
but show up and drive!

Stan

------------------------------

Date: 24 Jun 95 16:57:15 EDT
From: "Steven Z. Albert" <102074.2052@compuserve.com>
Subject: Wandering C2 (long winded story)

	After years of driving a 944 and then a 928, I just got a hold of my
first 911. It's a beautifull 1990 C2, and I couldn't wait to get it on a good
northern Arizona mountain highway to see how it compared with the other two
Porsches I had driven for so many years. It didn't take long to realize that the
911 was (for me) the best of the bunch. The road holding abilities of this car
just blew me away. The high speed stability  was absolutely wonderful. By the
time I got home, the only thing I felt the car needed was a new set of tires on
the rear. 
	The previous owner had the following setup of wheels/tires:
		OZ 17" wheels
		Dunlop D40 M2 215/45ZR17 tires up front
		Dunlop D40 M2 235/45ZR17 tires on the rear
	When replacing the rear tires, I kept the same size but upgraded to the
Dunlop SP8000 model because of its better quality. As I drove away from the tire
shop, I quickly noticed that at 40-50 mph the car started to wander left and
right as if a strong cross wind was tossing me around. The nearby Porsche dealer
later told me that you can't mix tire models or this very thing would happen.
Back to the tire shop I go, this time to replace the front tires with the same
Dunlop SP8000 (215/45ZR17).  As I drive away from the tire shop for the second
time and hit 40 mph, all seems to be back to normal. Unfortuanately, as I
approach 70-80 mph the car starts wandering from side to side again.
	Frustrated (and quickly running out of money) I go to the Porsche dealer
and have them do a front-end alignment. Results: no difference !!!!!
	Has anyone out there in Porschephile land ever run into this kind of
gremlin ?

		Thanks, Steve

Date: Sat, 24 Jun 1995 15:56:37 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: Solution to Michell's Valentine Problems

> > 
> > The RJ-11 phone jack has two very large advantages:
> > 
> >     1.  It's the only 4-wire connector in real common use, so it's
> >         cheap.
> >     2.  When a user needs a custom-length power cord, he can get one at
> >         any hardware or electronics store.  This is much nicer than
> >         having to cut the old connectors off the power cord, buy wire,
> >         solder the new wire to the old connectors, etc.
> > 
> > I can't think of another 4-wire connector, as commonly-available as 
> > RJ-11,  that would be more reliable.  Do you have any ideas?
> >   
> > 
> Dear Andy:
> I don't know much about connectors, but I have to believe that there is a 
> better solution somewhere!
> 
> Mitch
> 

I do know something about connectors.  I dropped Andy an idea or two,
but once *all* the requirements are known, the choice stays RJ-11.

Major requirements:

	Consumer application (Can find at radio shack)

	4 wires (rules out traditional power jacks)

	Easy application (rules out "molex" style)

	Affordable (NASA has better connectors, but.....)

Besides, the gold-plated RJ's are *surprisingly* durable.

Gary.

> shop, I quickly noticed that at 40-50 mph the car started to wander left and
> right as if a strong cross wind was tossing me around. The nearby Porsche dealer
> later told me that you can't mix tire models or this very thing would happen.
> Back to the tire shop I go, this time to replace the front tires with the same
> Dunlop SP8000 (215/45ZR17).  As I drive away from the tire shop for the second

> approach 70-80 mph the car starts wandering from side to side again.

Yup. I've just changed my rear tyres to a new set of 315/35 and afterwards
the rear end was all over the road. I'm using Yoko AVS's _both_ from and 
rear, but the front tyres were OK so they weren't changed.

My dealer said it was because the tyres haven't "settled" (in lack of a 
better word) yet - and I believe him, because after half a day of track 
driving it went away. I just needed to wear the tyres a bit.

Christian

Date: Sat, 24 Jun 1995 08:40:30 -0700

Date: Sat, 24 Jun 1995 18:23:15 -0700
From: mloomis@ccnet.com (marc loomis)
Subject: Altenators

Hey all again,
This is just a note of a reputable alternator source in the SF Bay area.
About a year ago my altenator went out on my 65 911. After calling all the
usual places for parts the chapest I could find a rebuilt unit was in the
250 to 300 range. I looked in the yellow pages and found a place called ASE
(Altenator Starter Exchange) in San Franciso. They mainly sell to
dealerships and shops but quoted me 135 for a rebuilt Bosch. I went down
and exchanged the alternator and promptly came home and installed it.
Unfortunately I hooked it up wrong and immediatly burnt it up. Dejected I
took it back ready to shell out another 135 but instead they gave me a
replacement, free! Just last week the altenator light came on in my 73.5 T
and stayed on with the key out. I knew the altenator had been replaced in
March by the PO but the receipt was from a BMW dealer where he worked. The
dealer would not replace it due to the fact it was a Porsche part and not
BMW. Once again I removed my alt and went to ASE where they checked both
the alt and regulator. I returned in 30 minutes ready to shell out another
135 for my 14 volt Marchal when they told me it was one of their rebuilds
and fixed it on the spot for free!  The alternator had been bought from
them via the BMW dealer. I found the honesty remarlable refreshing. They
had the opportunity to screw my twice but instead fixed the part. The shop
is ASE in San Francisco and anyone needing the number can e-mail me.

The usual disclaimers....just a HAPPY customer :-)

Marc Loomis
73 T CIS

Date: Sat, 24 Jun 1995 20:53:55 -0600
From: dkelly@iquest.com (David Kelly)
Subject: Re:   Steering Wheel Removal

"John Lucas GRC" <John_Lucas_GRC@cpqm.saic.com> said:
>BTW, I need to have my steering wheel restitched.  I would like some feedback
>from you regarding where you are getting this done, how much it costs, how
>long it takes, etc.

I took my 928's steering wheel to a local shoe repair place. They did
better than I could have done but only the top half needed restitching. It
is easy to tell the restitched work is not factory. But at least I can hold
the steering wheel now. Think $20 might have been too much but it was done
while I waited, 10 or 15 minutes.

And now a friendly QuickMail hint for John: Type command-I to install a
copy of the form used by the QMSMTP mail gateway to forward this message to
you. Name it something like "QMSMTP Form" and use it for messages that
route to the rest of the world. That form has some advantages, as I recall
its locked at 80 columns wide (at its narrowest), outgoing messages will be
formatted with extra newlines if needed, and it doesn't include the
following header in outgoing mail:

>                      Subject:                              Time:  11:58 AM
>  OFFICE MEMO         RE>  Steering Wheel Removal           Date:  6/23/95

'83 928S
Mac Eudora 1.5.1
6 cats

David Kelly N4HHE,   n4hhe@amsat.org,    dkelly@iquest.com

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 24 Jun 1995 23:49:02 -0400
From: TC911@aol.com
Subject: Alt problem sounds familiar

The alternator problem Armand was describing sounds all to familiar to me. My
85 911 had the same symptoms shortly after I purchased it. It had 56k on the
clock when it started to have dimmed lights at idle but ok at higher revs.
 Some 400 miles from home the car failed to crank over after stopping for
fuel. After recharging the battery and getting to my destination I removed
the alternator and pulled the brushes out and found one of them was alot
shorter than the other. The communtater (wasn't in Websters) was delaminating
and tore up the brush. Stuttgart Service of Williamsburg Va. helped me locate
a replacement unit.  It was delivered the next day and I had my Porsche back
on the road again. I missed Porsche in Flight at Williamsburg but enjoyed
driving my 911 around Williamsburg the rest of the week.

85 911- Carrera Slate Blue
94 Nissan 4x- Emerald Green
90 Nissan Maxima- Pearlized White 
Lab - Yellow

into the air box?  Or what?

Date: Sun, 25 Jun 1995 00:24:50 -0400 (EDT)
From: Matt Clement <mclement@access.digex.net>
Subject: Re: Your assistance please



On Sat, 24 Jun 1995, Jim Bauman jbauman@btr.com wrote:

> Because this is your first 911, I'd follow Bruce Anderson's
> advice and get the newest one you can afford, with the lowest
> miles and fewest problems. The fact that you're looking at late
> 70's/early 80's is a good sign.  You don't need to settle for
> lousy body work. To me, that would be an indication of the shape
> of the engine too.

A bit of advice, if I may.  When buying older Porsche's (I'm a 914 freak 
myself) I always budget $500 for a short trip to the West Coast -- spend 
a four day weekend with your cash-in-hand.  You can be assured of getting 
a rust-free, clean car, and as the Californians are more car-crazy than 
we out East are, you tend to get a fairly well maintained car.

- -- Matt

Porschephiles #1503                         Sun Jun 25 02:00:08 CDT 1995
Date: Sat, 24 Jun 1995 22:44:45 -0700
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: 914/6 with a 3.2 questions

Jon Lowe (JonLowe@aol.com) wrote:

>with a 3.2, the 914 gearbox ought to last about 3 nanoseconds before 
>something breaks unless you spend big $$ to beef it up.  Probably 
>ought to use a 915 gearbox. Several people have kits to do that in 
>Panorama.

A stock 3.2 makes... what?  About 210 HP?  The 901 gearbox is more than 
adequate for this type of duty, unless you're planning on drag-racing 
your car or something (the 901's first gear is a pretty weak design 
even for a stock 2-liter 914/6).

You may want to add a transmission oil cooler, but even without it, the 
901 should be just fine.

Besides, the 901 has a larger selection of gear sets, doesn't require 
questionable third-party adapters to make it work in a 914, and is 
pretty cheap to rebuild if it ever does develop a problem.

Personal testimonial:  My car, with more horsepower than that 3.2, has 
a 901 with about 30K miles since it was regeared (AA-F-L-S-X, by the 
way... Seems to be the hot ticket for Weber-carbed 2.7 Carrera RS 
motors in street cars), and it's as good as new.  Also -- although I 
know it may have little to do with street-car reliability -- all the 
successful 914/6 racers I know use 901s (with coolers).

As usual, this is just my opinion... If you have money burning a hole 
in your pocket, and you want it to burn in George Vellios' instead, buy 
his 916 kit and drop a 915 tranny into your car.

 -Andy

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Porschephiles #1504                         Mon Jun 26 02:00:17 CDT 1995
Date: Sun, 25 Jun 95 04:12 EST
From: Jay Ellis <0007142347@mcimail.com>
Subject: 951 valve job cost

Now that I've got the head off on my badly sputtering 951, it looks like I
need a valve job instead of just a head gasket.  The reason for my lack of
compression for cylinder #2 is a rather crispy and half-moon shaped exhaust
valve. 

The rest of the head looks pretty good from the outside, so what is a
reasonable cost for replacing 1 exhaust valve and machining the rest? I
gather this should be possible as long as the other valves are OK.  Also,
I'll be replacing the valve guides and seals - anything else that should be
replaced to freshen it up?

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 25 Jun 1995 08:15:58 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 951 valve job cost

>Now that I've got the head off on my badly sputtering 951, it looks like I
>need a valve job instead of just a head gasket.  The reason for my lack of
>compression for cylinder #2 is a rather crispy and half-moon shaped exhaust
>valve. 
>
>The rest of the head looks pretty good from the outside, so what is a
>reasonable cost for replacing 1 exhaust valve and machining the rest? I
>gather this should be possible as long as the other valves are OK.  Also,
>I'll be replacing the valve guides and seals - anything else that should be
>replaced to freshen it up?  

Jay,

You didn't mention your mileage, but if you're in this far, I would recommend
that you have the head reconditioned...

1) check for warpage and resurface as necessary.

2) new guides and seals

3) regrind valves and seats as necessary

4) zyglo for cracks, etc...

Also, on the 944 Turbo heads, make sure that the ceramic inserts in the 
exhaust ports have
not come loose...

This should run you about $500 plus parts...
Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net
Purveyors of Used 944 Parts and Services to "Her Majesty"
Orders: 800-all-p944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
83 944, 87 944S (SOLD!), 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 80 GMC Pickup


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 25 Jun 1995 09:41:28 -0400
From: AllPorsche@aol.com
Subject: R-12 Replacement Approved

P-Filers,

Picked this up on the net:

"As per 9/18/95 R-406A has been approved as a replacement for R-12 in
automotive applications."
As you may know, this compound is more eficient than R-12 and fullly
compatible. It was invented @ People's Welding Supplies and approved for all
applications except automotive. The only requirement seems to be a strong
suggestion to change to barrier hoses as R-406A will leak out a little faster
than R-12. The same regulations as for R-12 may apply. This may be a better
route to go than R-134A retrofitting.
They even have a homepage: http://worldserver.com/R-406A

Bart (AllPorsche@aol.com)

Date: Sun, 25 Jun 1995 12:32:36 -0400
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re: Advise on 911 buying

Hi Suzanne,

You wrote -
>
 I am limiting myself to 20,000 clams towards my 
purchase.I am looking for wide-spread advice on my options.  So far, I am
keen on a 83 911SC.
<

I like my SC despite the high miles, but my suggestion would be, if you have
$20k to spend, look at 3.2L Carreras and, as usual, buy the newest, lowest
miles one you can get with your available funds. When you first look at
Carrera prices they seem high, but keep looking, there are good cars out
there well under $20k.

Good luck,

Phil Van Buskirk, PMLetter@aol.com

Date: Sun, 25 Jun 1995 16:14:17 -0400
From: Skater44@aol.com
Subject: Re:Euro Taillight Lenses

 Mike

  I have a 1969 911S that is completely Euro.  The car came into the States
about 1970.  I have never had a problem with Legality in the 20 years I have
been driving.  Although I have not checked with anyone.

  The only problems have been that the len seals on the Euro units are
different than the US units.  So after 20 years I donot have good seals.

  Walt Chapman
 69 911S

Date: Sun, 25 Jun 1995 17:14:28 -0400
From: Bpenteco@aol.com
Subject: 944 oil changes

A few days ago a p-phile suggested for 944 oil changing: 

>helpful hint-using a punch or a drift,  knock a hole in the top
>of the filter prior to draining the oil.  after the crankcase had
>been drained, the oil in the filter has drained also.  removing
>the filter doesn't make that mess then ;->
>didn't see this in faq's, did everyone know but me?
>

And then George B. added:

> Yeah, but before you punch that hole, better make sure that your filter
> is not frozen to the flange... It makes it really tough to drive into town
and
> get the proper tool to remove it...

But I don't understand the following that George wrote (so maybe he
will explain it to me):

> Even better tip is to remove the filter first, so that when you drop it
down
> to the drain pan, it doesn't splash dirty oil all over your clean garage
floor.

And then a final question about having the oil in the filter drain back 
through the engine. This sounds like a good solution but is it the clean 
or dirty side of the oil filter that is draining back through the engine?

Bob Pentecost
'83 944

Date: Sun, 25 Jun 1995 19:35:23 -0400 (EDT)
From: Scot Alan Douglas <scootman@engin.umich.edu>
Subject: 914 intermittent miss

Hey everybody!  Got a question about my '74 914 1.8L.  I just got back 
from a 300 mile trip to my parent's home this weekend when my car 
developed some interesting problems.
1.  The engine started to randomly cut out(like the ignition was being 
switched off) and then would come back as fast as it went away.  This 
happened on the way out of Ann Arbor on Friday night so I checked all of 
the electrical connections and found a real loose coil wire.  I crimped 
the connector to tighten it up and continued the trip with no problems.
Today the car started to pull the same crap on the way home coming 
through the irish hills, but had modified itself.
2.  Now, the car misfires above 4000 rpm consistently.

I don't have time to look it over tonight, but I am hoping that someone 
can give me a suggestion where to look first when I tear into it tomorrow 
after work.  Thank you for any help you can give!
Scot

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 25 Jun 1995 21:22:06 -0500
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: Re: Sensors to 944 DME

At 11:54pm 23.6.95, Phyl346@aol.com wrote:
> There are two (at least on the L-jetronic of my '83 944) sensors at the bell
>housing. One is for RPM and one is for TDC.  If either is gone the engine
>will not fire.

I may be wrong, but I thought that the engine would run if it was missing
the speed sensor - the only problem is that the DME defaults to the idle
program. It is the TDC sensor that needs to be in place for the engine to
run ...

>They are identical and should have three wires: one shield
>and two for resistance/reluctance.  Connect a VOM between the middle wire and
>the other two, checking resistance.  You should get  ~1000 ohms between one
>and >1meg at the other.

The sensors actually produce a voltage, and are best measured on a scope
where the waveform can be observed. The factory manuals have specific
instructions about how to do this.

regards,
trev.


===============================
Trevor Sadler
Recording Engineer/Producer

While surfing, stop at:
http://www.io.org/~cme/MIC/mic.html
and look for trev ...



------------------------------

Date: Sun, 25 Jun 1995 21:43:10 -0500
From: Johnny.Miller@i-link.net (Johnny Miller)
Subject: shaky wheel

I have a 1971 911T with a problem that is getting on my nerves.
When I get it up to 65+ MPH the steering wheel starts to shimmy.
It has about a 1" travel that makes you want to slow down.
The strange thing is that it comes and goes.  About 10 seconds of violent
shaking then 10 seconds of smooth bliss then back to shaking again.

What could be causing this?  I spoke to a friend with a 71 911T Targa and his
does the same thing.   Please help. I want to go faster.

                Thanks,  Johnny Miller

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 25 Jun 95 23:11:42 PST
From: "Don Schmidek" <dis@metricom.com>
Subject: 912E questions - bucking and fuel pump location

     
     The fuel pump of the 912E is above the plate, which is under the car, 
     just under the driver side footwell.  You will find the master 
     cylinder and the reset switch there too.  The plate is removed by 
     removing a few screws which hold the plate.
     
     As to the bucking bronco 912E, you did not state at what RPM the 
     bucking started -- my did the same at 5600 (?) RPM -- the limiter 
     switch cut off the ignition. Maybe yours is loose!!!  Does it do it 
     with the car stopped and the engine speeded up the  same RPM??  If it 
     does, use a timing light to see if the  spark goes away when the 
     bucking starts.
     
     I would also check for loose wires at the coil connections.
     
     It could also be fuel problems -- change the fuel filter in the engine 
     compartment -- left side.  Finally put a pressure gauge in fuel line, 
     and watch the pressure -- I believe it has to be 24 lbs.  This is a 
     tricky test, and you better assure that the connections are tight, 
     otherwise you will have a flame-up, and you will have to get the 
     insurance to buy your wife a new car!!!  If your car bucks standing 
     still at some RPM, and you observe the fuel pressure, and it does not 
     drop, it has to be the ignition.
     
     Good luck
     
     Don


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 03:03:10 -0400
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: Air Conditioning a 912

    The Factory DID Air Condition 912's- usually for Texas and Arizona. The
kit was,  as I understand it, a Dealer-installed Option which required a
massive bracket on the left-hand side of the engine (replacing the left-hand
intermediate motor mount). It also required that a second pulley be added to
the crank pulley (and in the case of the '68 912 with already had  a 2-pulley
pulley, required a THREE pulley-pulley. One for the generator belt, one for
the air pump belt and one for the compressor. 
     The compressor also make access to the distributor, coil, oil filter,
etc difficult. Needless to say, this was not a popular option from the
mechanic's point of view- or anyone  who worked on the car.
    I've  seen several 912's with the remains of the A/C system (notably the
huge left-hand motor mount), but only a couple working examples.  Despite
Stan's claim of imminent motor demise, the 912's I've seen with working A/C
systems suffered no crankshaft failures from the compressor mounting. (Those
two middle mains in a 912 are Steel-backed- just like 'Merican cars).
    And yes, you WILL get poorer performance with A/C and though YOU may be
cooler, the engine will run hotter!
    All in all, I'd forget about putting A/C into a 912. Open the windows or
pour water over yourself- ala the "swamp cooler" technique- one which I used
 again today when coming back from the Sacramento Swap Meet in 107 degree
temperatures down I-5 at 80mph (average traffic speed) in my non-Air
Conditioned '69 Chevy Peek-up Truck, loaded with complete Super-90 Engine
 and enough parts  to build  a second 356 engine. God, it was hot!  But a
cup-full  of ice water liberally applied to one's t-shirt at 10 minute
intervals made the trip survivable.
   KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!
    The Maestro
P.S. The Swap Meet sucked- everyone left by 11 AM 'cause of  the heat.

------------------------------

From: patmor@utu.fi (Patrick Joel Morton)
Subject: 9 1 4  Audio Improvements


To put it bluntly, the stereo system in my 914 is less than adequate.
However, this is actually my fault, as I have spent time attending to other
more important areas of the car (mechanics).  Now that some of those items
have been improved somewhat, I started to think about a sound system.

The interior possibilities for some type of stereo upgrade seem to me to be
rather lackluster and limited, IMHO.  Now I do not want to push so much air
inside of the car that I can blow out the windows, rather do some smart
things that will allow me to have some nice music on, as well as perhaps
lessen road noise.

Thus, without anyone getting too specific, are there any suggestions -
i.e., speaker types and placement, sound proofing or otherwise - for
improving my 914's sound system?

I appreciate any advice!

Patrick Morton

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 09:54:03 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdbg.suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 914 specs (British)

On Fri, 23 Jun 1995, Gary Helbig wrote:

> Subject: Re: 914 specs (British)
> 
> > 
> > See the remark about the aerodynamics?  Brick, my ass.  :-)
> > Scot
> > 

ref 914s
I don't think there was ever a uk spec 914 ?? I may be wrong but I have 
never seen one - there may be a couple of conversions running around

ref cd numbers

just because you can light a cig at 70 doesn't mean it is slick, it just 
means that you are sitting in dead air.

In fact slab fronted motors often have better cd figs than sleak roadsters

the UK ford transit van had a better cd than a ford mustang

long cars always have better cd figs than short cars

the alfa romeo guilietta of 1995 and the citroen ds both had cds around .22 

formula 1 cars are generally > .50 

finally refember you must multiply the cd by the cross sectional area to 
get the drag, and big cars with low cds will still have more drag than 
914s with high cds

pete

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 11:17:03 +0200
From: Trond Vidar Olsen <Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no>
Subject: 356 restoration progress!!!!

Hi all,

Mid-spring I reported my 356 to be finished welded and complete body
restored,...somewhere along the road I changed opinion and decided to
replace the rocker panels too.

This showed up to be a wise move,...when I started drilling out the
spot welds the assembly revealed smaller rust holes between the spot
welds. I ended up using a 0.5" x 0.5" 90 degree angled piece of
sheetmetal, welding it onto the sill to get an edge for the rocker
panel.

The rocker panels goes far up on both front and rear fender, and these
areas improved a lot with the new rockers.

The job itself was very easy and I will write it down and include
photos in the DIY 356 manual I'm happy enough to set up at tta.com.

cheers,
Trond V.

Subject: Mid-Ohio Porsche weekend!

Just a quick note to highlight an incredible weekend at Mid-Ohio 
racecourse this past weekend.  The SVRA Sprint historic races were being 
held and Porsche was the featured marque. I'm not a very religious 
person, but as my girlfriend put it, "This is as close to heaven as I 
think were going to get!"  Everything from an Abarth Carrera to a 917 
were represented in the all-Porsche race on Sunday with Vic Elford doing 
analysis and giving his two cents at the end concerning all those cars 
he once drove and thier characteristics.  My hats off to event 
organizers!

Dion Dunn

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 08:33:09 -0500
From: mac3d@superlink.net (Ed Dougherty)

Johnny Miller wrote
>I have a 1971 911T with a problem that is getting on my nerves.
>When I get it up to 65+ MPH the steering wheel starts to shimmy.
>It has about a 1" travel that makes you want to slow down.
>The strange thing is that it comes and goes.  About 10 seconds of violent
>shaking then 10 seconds of smooth bliss then back to shaking again.
>
>What could be causing this?  I spoke to a friend with a 71 911T Targa and his
>does the same thing.   Please help. I want to go faster.

I had the same problem with my 951. Turned out to be a (very slightly) bent
front wheel. I described the exact same symptoms to my local Porsche tech
(unsoliced testimonial: the guys @ Princeton Porsche are some of the very
best!) and he knew right away. It was a small enough ding that I would
never have noticed it had I not gone looking for it.
Hope this helps.
 -ed
87 951, Guards red
89 Doberman, Dobe red

Subject: Problem with 5th Gear

Folks,

I am having what I think is a problem with 5th gear on my '85 911.
Whenever I try to go to 5th, the stick seems to get stuck on the
way into 5th. Then if I push harder, it seems to "click" past
something and then smoothly completes going into 5th. I don't have
a problem with any of the other gears. It seems to happen at any speed.
It gets stuck just past neutral, then the rest of the throw is OK.

Could this be a clutch problem? A transmission problem?

Any ideas would be appreciated?

Thanks,

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 09:40:04 -0400
From: Barry Chapin (chapin@draper.com) <bwc2809@support7.draper.com>
Subject: 911SC idle fluctuating/stalling

Hello,

Sometimes, after driving for a while, my 1981 911SC idle fluctuates up 
and down and sometimes even down so low it stalls, apparently only after 
the engine is hot, and I have been driving it for a while.   

For instance, after driving on a highway for a while, and then when
I pull onto the exit ramp, and put it in netutral, the engine will
stall out, or the idle will begin going up and down as if a ghost
is revving the accelerator up to maybe 3000-3500 RPM, and then down to
below normal idle, to about 500 RPM's.  Up and down, up and down, etc.

It keeps bobbing up and down unless I hold the accelerator pedal down 
slighty and keep it at maybe 2000 RPM.  Many times it stalls after a 
few of these fluctuations up and down if I do nothing.  This does not 
always happen either, only a few times in the past week, and there are
no problems under acceleration or normal driving in gear, only at idle.
What shall I look at to figure this one out?  Thanks.

 -Barry Chapin	chapin@draper.com
1981 Euro-911SC Targa.  Northeast PCA.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 11:17:05 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Help with 911 rear quarter window seals!

Dennis,

You put the seal onto the quarter glass, then lay a thin rope into the
seal.  And then you push the window into position and gradually pull the
rope out, which as it comes out flips the seal into position.

Sound confusing?  Yep.  Tricky?  Yep.  It's one of those things which
an experience body shop guy can do in a snap, while mere mortals curse
and swear for the better part of an hour!  Get someone to show you.

Kevin Gross

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 11:23:51 -0400
From: kgross@centra.net (Kevin Gross)
Subject: Re: Do I have bad clutch?

Ray,

If your clutch has blown its rubber centre, you will feel a single thunk
as you come off idle and onto the gas, and you will feel the same thunk
in the opposite transition.

If you feel a lot of bucking any time you get on the gas, it's probably
something else.  I'd look at the air flow meter, throttle switch (idle
and WOT switches), fuel filter/pressure, and for vacuum leaks.

Hope this helps.

Kevin Gross

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 08:39:50 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: 914 intermittent miss

> 
> Hey everybody!  Got a question about my '74 914 1.8L.  I just got back 
> from a 300 mile trip to my parent's home this weekend when my car 
> developed some interesting problems.
> 1.  The engine started to randomly cut out(like the ignition was being 
> switched off) and then would come back as fast as it went away.  This 
> happened on the way out of Ann Arbor on Friday night so I checked all of 
> the electrical connections and found a real loose coil wire.  I crimped 
> the connector to tighten it up and continued the trip with no problems.
> Today the car started to pull the same crap on the way home coming 
> through the irish hills, but had modified itself.

The "classic" cause of this it the throttle switch.  (flat black thing
on the side of the throttle body.)  They respond well to a good cleaning,
but be careful not to move the adjustment.

> 2.  Now, the car misfires above 4000 rpm consistently.

This sounds more like a distributor problem.  Either there is a lot
of shaft-wobble, or the injection points are starting to go.

Or it could need a *really* good tune-up.


Gary.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 95 11:50:14 EDT
From: weltyc@cs.vassar.edu (Chris Welty)
Subject: July Porsching Column


Permission is given to use this material in any publication as long
as my name and affiliation are left intact.  If you can, send me the
issue.  Previous Porsching columns are available at
http://www.cs.vassar.edu/faculty/welty/porsching

PORSCHING  by Chris Welty
Hudson-Champlain Region, PCA

When You Wish Upon A Star - Part VII

The funny thing about hearing my own voice from across the span of
time was that it was very clear.  Not only that, but while my voice
did change during puberty, I was never a soprano.  "Huh?" I said,
awakened from my revelry. 

The waitress motioned with her head towards the Porsche that had just
pulled into the parking lot.  "I just said that I wish I had a
Porsche.  Doesn't everyone?"  She deposited the check on the table and
left. 

Sometimes the deepest wisdom can be found in the most unexpected
places.  I am quite sure there are little kids in Japan who grow up
hoping one day to own a Nissan, but from my slanted view of the world,
most people dream about Porsches, and the 911 is the most eminently
recognizable car on the planet.  Everyone who sees one either says,
"Hey, nice car!" or pretends not to be impressed.  Before I had one, I
was in the latter category... 

The next morning we awoke bright and early to the sound of Steve
yelling at his girlfriend.  I stumbled around in a stupor for a while,
trying to remember what debauchery we had engaged in the previous night
that had caused me to pass out on the floor.   My memory returned in
stages, as happens when I am suddenly yanked to consciousness in
strange surroundings.   Steve yelling at someone was such a familiar
stimulus from college that my mind had grasped onto that.  Eventually
I remembered that I wasn't in college anymore, and that I was supposed
to be sleeping on the floor, though I was never able to explain why I
was wearing a grass skirt. 

Steve's girlfriend's addiction to game shows and her fascination with
the pilot light on the stove were a constant source of amusement for
us.  When Steve came out of the bedroom that morning, it was clear
that after some time living with her these endearing qualities had
lost their initial charm.  He was becoming especially frustrated with
the fact that she had graduated law school a year ago and still
thought she could make big bucks as a contestant on game shows rather
than getting a job as a lawyer.  This had, in fact, been the subject
of the morning's fracas, and Steve asked, in that "She made me ask you
this question and I really hope you say no" kind of voice, whether we
could give her a ride to Hollywood to try out as a contestant on
Jeopardy.  We somehow felt guilty about the friction, so we agreed,
though on the drive over we all felt very uncomfortable.  We were
quite relieved to resume our quest.   

We must have seen another ten cars that day, and each one in my
category made it even more clear that the car John had said I would
buy was the one for me.  Karl however, was starting to feel lonely. 

It was sometime after lunch that we visited a `78 SC at a location
near the beach.  The owner was young, younger than us, with long hair
and met us wearing a bathing suit.  We really thought he was the most
stereotypically Californian person we'd met until his friend showed
up.  This guy had bleached blond hair and a very dark tan, and at
first when he spoke we thought he was joking.  I suppose in order for
someone to make fun of that speech pattern there has to be a few
people who actually talk that way, dude.  I am telling the absolute
truth when I say he was carrying a surfboard.

The car was a dark greenish blue.  To me it was more green, but I seem
to be alone in the world in that opinion, everyone else said blue.  It
had enormous tires on color matched 15" BBS rims.  Many people update
their SCs to "sevens and eights", but this car had eights and nines,
and the 15" rims made them look all the wider.  Karl was in love.  He
was all over the car, and though he found several problems with it,
including a pretty nice sized transmission oil leak, he wanted the
car.  Karl knew a lot about cars, and a lot about Porsches, but there
was no question he was seduced by the big fat tires.  Once in a bar a
group of us college guys had been talking about favorite body parts,
and I distinctly remember being confused by his statement, "I like
them BIG but low profile." 

"That car has bitchin' tires," observed Mr. California.

My jaw dropped, and I noted John also wore an expression of shocked
surprise.  This was more than I could take.   

"Bitchin?  Did you actually say `Bitchin'? " I stammered. 

"Yaa, "  he looked momentarily confused, even in pain.  "You, like,
you don't think so?" 

"Definitely," said John. "Bitchin.  Totally bitchin.  Awesome."

A wave of relief passed over the guys face, and he began to nod with a
bobbing motion.  "Yaaaaa," he said, with feeling.  Then his face
changed again, this time to wonderment.  "Whooaaaa." 

We followed his gaze and discovered that Karl had just put on the
stethescope.  The two natives watched in awe. Flies eventually began
to dart in and out of their gaping mouths.  The owner looked nervous.
"I drive it out on the beach sometimes," he managed, spitting out a
stray insect. 

Karl's total infatuation with the tires was revealed at that moment to
the qualified observer - he was trying to listen to them.  John and I
stood back because we were now more interested, in an anthropological
sort of way, in the bitchin' friend.  The two of us were trying our
best to shatter what we firmly believed was a charade.  Our study,
unfortunately, was ended prematurely when I mistakenly uttered,
"Surf's up!" and our subject darted off to the nearby beach. 

"Had to be an act," John said, watching him disappear over a dune.

"Probably just some actor practising for a part in a B beach movie," I
offered. 

"Had to be.  Did you notice the makeup job?"

"Yes, very realistic, I wonder who did it."  I believe that John was
as deeply disturbed by the experience as I was, and through some
unspoken sympathy we never spoke of the incident again.  We turned our
attention back to Karl's newfound love.  That is, his newfound loves.

Karl had begun negotiating and it looked as if, once again, he would
need our help.  I like to share with my readers bits of the wisdom I
have gathered over my many years, and here's a particular little gem:
If you're emotionally involved in something you shouldn't be
negotiating about it.  Karl was clearly in violation of this rule.
The owner had started off at $14K and Karl had already haggled it up
to $16K.  

I was just about to step in when John, who had gone over to inspect
the car for himself, called us over.  He was knelt beside the right
rear tire, and for a moment I though perhaps he had succumbed to the
madness that was clearly possessing Karl.  Thankfully, this was not
the case, and he pointed at the tread when he said, "The tire's
rubbing."   

Karl and I bent over to look at what John was pointing at.  About two
centimeters in from the outside of the tire was a gouge about half a
centimeter deep that went all around the tire.  Karl straightened up
suddenly and let out a wail that would have impressed any banshees
surfing nearby.  The sonic blast loosened about a ton of sand which
spilled onto the ground like some bizarre hourglass.  It would be
difficult to exaggerate the amount of sand stuck in this car.  My
first impression was that the guy carried a beach around with him in
case he ever needed one. 

It was clear that the tires were too big for the car, and that
whenever it hit a bump they would rub against the underside of the
fender.  "I wonder how long it's been doing that?" wondered the owner,
in that innocent, "gee, I never noticed THAT before,"  kind of voice
that is so common in these circumstances.  John pointed out that the
contact point on the underside of the fender was worn down to bare
metal, indicating that it hadn't "just started." 

I stood up and made to leave, but to my surprise, it seemed that this
incident had not deterred Karl from his desire to own the car.  At the
very least there was a positive effect: he was negotiating in the
correct direction.  The owner was holding firm, however.  Ultimately
he was unimpressed by our knowledge of what was wrong with the car,
claiming that if he just waited around, eventually, "some guy would
come along who didn't know better and buy it for his wife." 

Hey, if someone did that for me, I'd marry him.

We started to leave. Karl, with tears in his eyes, had to be dragged
from the tires.  We drove away to our next appointment. 

"Do you think they were worth $13.5?" he asked.

"I don't know, Karl," I said.  "That was a pretty big transmission
leak.  Do you think it will make it across the country like that?" 

Karl shrugged.  "Ja.  Ja, I drove a car clear across Germany once with
no clutch and only fourth gear."  It was repeated stories like these
that had built my confidence over the course of our adventure that the
choice to drive the cars back hadn't been, as I had originally feared,
a mistake of a magnitude that would have motivated the ancient Greeks
to write a play.  

"What about the tires?  At that rate they'll wear through to the belts
before you get halfway there."  John, always the voice of reason, had
also decided he would not accompany us on the Odessian drive back,
preferring to use all three return flight tickets for himself. 

Karl remained silent, sullen.  His repertoire of stories about the
automotive obstacles he'd overcome did not seem to cover this.  It was
one of the few situations that Speed Racer had seen and Karl hadn't.
After a long silence, he spoke.  "Ja.  I will buy that car.  Do you
think they will be allright tonite?  Do you think he will drive them?"

When we returned that night to Steve's house I called Chuck, the owner
of the blue '71T we had looked at the previous day.  He accepted my
offer of $6500.  Jubilant, Karl and I could think of little else.
For the first time that trip, the three of us stayed at Steve's
apartment for the evening, but neither Karl nor I were much company.
We spent the time poring over maps trying to pick the best route home.
This suited Steve well, he loved talking about highways, almost as
much as the British. 

That night I was too excited to sleep, though I tried to look drowsy
in the hope that Steve would stop talking about the relative merits of
Interstate 40.  He finally retired to his bedroom, and we tried to get
some rest.  A cloud of doubt crossed my mind - there was still the
open question of money.   Money, money, money.  Doubt turned to
anxiety - would the stars see to it that no snags showed up in the two
rather bizarre mechanisms Karl and I had used to get our money from
New York to L.A.?  What about our safety? We would be carrying between
the two of us well over $20K in CASH. I lay awake most of the night
imagining all the possible complications, and then all the things
that might go wrong in driving two old cars 3000 miles across the
country. 


=====

Christopher Welty                        Vassar College Computer Science Dept
SIGART Information Director                            Poughkeepsie, NY 12601
weltyc@sigart.acm.org                                    weltyc@cs.vassar.edu

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1506                         Mon Jun 26 15:57:38 CDT 1995
Date: Mon, 26 Jun 95 09:07:00 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Non-starting  DMEs


George,

You know, a few years back, when I was fooling around with a non-
starting 944, I discovered that our German friends routed the 12Volt 
line from the ignition switch to the coil, then back to the DME. 

The DME has one board (most do, 944S does not) that switches the 12V to 
ground. The trigger signal comes from the Computer itself, it is delayed
or advanced as the MAP directs.

Anyway, the point is that anyone that is experiencing a non-start with 
no fire from the ignition should first check to see if there is 12V at
the coil with the ignition switch on. The problem with the car in 
question was traced to an aftermarket alarm system that broke the power 
to the coil. A good idea, very poorly executed. Removel of the alarm
circuitry and reconnection of the wires to their normal configuration
allowed this car to start and run correctly.

Jim Pasha

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 12:10:14 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re[2]: Winshield antennas

the wire was routed along with the antenna coax, and heat-shrinked to the
end. the wire was black, which confused the hell out of me. I was loath to
put 12 V on it. I convinced myself that it was the right wire by checking
the wiring diagram. I don't know where the actual amp might be.

The antenna coax comes out behind the radio, and this other wire is
attached to it.
A brown wire might be a ground. try orming it out. the power amp lead
appears to be an open.

good luck.

doug



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 12:23:18 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Translation of Paul Foster's post

     Why I got this uuencoded, I don't know. I've translated it, so
everyone might see:



     I did my first PCA track event this weekend at Bridgehampton on Long

     Island. It was a three day event with 4 sessions per day of about 20

     minutes per session.



     The first session, the instructor took it out first for two relatively

     slow laps to show me the track (Chip Brown, 944 Turbo pilot

     extraordinare). When it was my turn, I was all over the place, and he

     almost grabbed the steering wheel. Afterwards, I wasn't sure I wanted

     to be there. The front straight is really scary. It is about 3800 ft.

     long, and it goes steeply downhill the last 400-500 feet before

     sweeping to the right and going even more downhill. Cohoneville, USA.



     It all clicked in the second session once I go familiar with the track

     and the speed (2.8 miles and 13 turns). In the third session, I passed

     2 930s, 1 Testarossa, and 1 308 (My car has 145HP on a good day). In

     the fifth session, the instructor "signed me off", and I changed run

     groups and "soloed" in the seventh session (it was raining during the

     sixth session, and I wanted another set of eyes). In the eighth

     session, I must have passed everybody in the group!



     The Blue Laws don't allow anybody to have fun on Sunday until 1 PM, So

     they had a track walk that was very informative. It's amazing what you

     don't see at 120+ (the front AND back straights). When I went through

     tech, the Safety Nazi didn't like the feel of the left front when he

     was checking the lug nut tightness. I jacked it up, and sure enough,

     the rear bushing on the LF A-arm was shot. The A-arm rattled with

     moderate hand pressure. What a bummer. Being relatively adult, I

     managed to walk away with no acrimony or crying. However the mechanic

     who did the four-wheel alignment and pretrack tech inspection is going

     to have some explaining to do...



     I am well and truly hooked. Now all I have to do is come up with a way

     to get my hands on a lot of money. I think any proficient autocrosser

     is going have a relatively easy transition to the OTHER auto sport. I

     also think some proficiency at autocrossing should be required. The

     instructors are incredibly brave (stupid?) to get into the passenger

     seat with a complete stranger.



     This was a joint event with the Ferrari and BMW clubs. There were 2

     F40s in attendance. All the Ferrari drivers were slow. The F40s ran in

     the instructors group (I guess so they wouldn't get punted off). They

     were very slow in the corners, and the guys would punch it down the

     straights & not let the Porsches pass them. There was a modified 914

     in that group that sticked to an F40's tail down the front straight,

     which caused one of the pit wall wags to comment: "That sure would

     make a good picture. A 914 eating up an F40!" I was wearing a Ferrari

     hat most of the weekend, so most everybody thought I was one of them,

     instead of actually piloting a beaten-up '84 944 with 135K miles.



     Paul Foster

     pbf@tdc.com

on a 928?  It has 95K miles and the guy wants $9,000 for it.  My roommate

out for a turbo S?  Although, he really doesn't want to spend more than $9K.

normally aspirated 944/24 and tweek it(they are about half the price).

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 09:11 -0800 (PST)
From: Robert_Yasek@NOTES.YMP.GOV
Subject: Nuts!


  Hey P-filers,

  This weekend, I was replacing my transmission gear oil with nice new
  Swepco, when upon removing the magnetic drain plug I had one of those
  moments that sends shivers up one's spine. There, clinginging to the
  plug, was a nut, slightly gnawed on one side. Upon seeing this, I
  proceeded in a semi-trancelike state into the house, my jaw still
  dragging behind me. I showed it to Shelle, amidst mumblings to the effect
  that this was Not A Good Thing. She recommended that I have a beer and
  relax, which was actually very good advice, which I dutifully followed.
  After sitting down with a Hank's (Henry Weinharts Private Reserve, for
  all those non-western cheap beer connoisseurs) and poring over my brand
  new factory manuals (thanks dear, great birthday present! I swear my wife
  is psychic), I could not figure out where in the hell this nut came from.
  Having reached the limits of my knowledge, I am asking for any help
  available from you folks.

  Here is what I know:      915 transmission. 73 911T with '83 SC engine.
  The nut is the same exact one that is used to keep the differential cover
  on ( self-locking nut, M8 X 1.25 thread). There doesn't appear to be
  significant damage to the differential or case (some scratches, no
  chipped teeth on ring/pinion or others on diff). I know that there is no
  nut like this in the differential, and I don't see how it could have
  gotten there from another part of the transmission.

  Could the nut in fact have gotten to the differential from another part
  of the transmission, or was it likely left by a careless mechanic
  sometime in the cars recent past?

  Any and all help on this matter will be profoundly appreciated.

  Regards,

  Rob Yasek
  '73 911T
  '91 Bixby Noodlehead

  P.S. Hey Bruce, any room in your September transmission class!! <vbg>

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 10:36:03 -0700
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: 914/6 Fuel Pump Needed

     
     I fired up my newly rebuilt 914/6 engine this weekend.  The Bosch fuel 
     pump leaks profusely around the electrical connector!  To continue the 
     checkout of the engine, I picked up a generic fuel pump with the 
     correct pressure/flow ratings.  This will do for now, but I would like 
     to get a good used Bosch pump.  I don't want to seem cheap, but they 
     are very expensive new.  The pump has 3 fuel line connections 
     (IN/OUT/PRESSURE RELIEF).  This is the same pump as used on early 
     911Ts w/Zenith carbs.
     
     BOSCH PART # 580.960.009
     PORSCE #     911.608.107.00
     
     TIA
     
     Dan Swiger
     
     70 914/6
