Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 13:51:44 -0400 (EDT)
From: Lon Herman <loherman@magnus.acs.ohio-state.edu>
Subject: 912 Purchase; Road Trip

Well, I can say safely that if it were not for the people who make up this 
list, I would not be the very happy, new owner of a very clean '67 912, 
purchased 2,500 miles from home! My list-supporting check will go out to Bart 
Chambers by Friday. Although there are numerous posters who helped further my 
p-car technical education (and helped me determine the right car for my desires
and budget) I would like to say special thanks to the following people who 
helped guide me through the three-month consideration, inspection, and purchase
of this auto:

To Ted Smith, for graciously providing me with a thorough, thoughtful, and 
dead-accurate appraisal of the car overall;

To Harry Pellow, for checking the engine, and for writing highly entertaining 
understand it/fit it literature;

To Stan Hanks for his committment, and most recently for the brief treatise on 
Solex vs. Weber carbs (my car has the original Solex carbs; I had an 
opportunity to purchase Webers; decided to pass on them);

To Ted Rogers, Bill Hutton, Sean Steinmann, Scott Berry, Michael Hodos, and 
Matt Safranski for willingness to help, words of advice, and of caution;

....And to the 912's 2 PO's who did what was needed to keep the car this good 
after 28 years.

With the assistance of those mentioned above, several pictures, and lots of 
E-Mail between me and the PO, I arranged to purchase the car in Berkeley, 
California from my home in Granville, Ohio - flew out there to 
sightsee/visit/pick it up, and (drumroll, please....) drove it 2,500 miles back
to Ohio without major incident (and WITH lots of fun)! A special pitch for 
Dieter Mees of D+M motors in Channing, who I have never met, but who maintained
the car regularly and prepped it for the trip. The only problem I had was a 
recalcitrant starter when warm (sticky brushes, I expect - will replace it this
week, probably); otherwise, NO hassles! Engine ran smoothly, only used 1/2 
quart of oil the entire trip; even made it throug the Longest Day (16 hours/900
miles continuous running) without missing a beat! Try that in your 28 year old 
(insert name other than well-cared for Porsche)!

If there is interest I may add details of the trip in a future post; now on to 
a couple of questions for the group:

1) Can anybody transfer to me the relevant files from the FAQ? Please, just let
me know if you can do this, rather than doing it, so I only end up with one set
of FAQ's. I don't have the capability to browse, use WWB, or HMTL(?) yet.

2) I plan on doing as much of the routine tuning and repair as I can (it is a 
pleasure to have a real, mechanical machine to work on for a change); I have a 
few questions on carb tools:

a) to Synch the carbs, I'm thinking of picking up a unisyn, or should I invest 
in something different/fancier? If so, what? from where?

b) is it worth my while to track down a float level gauge and accelerator pump
vial (if I can?) The settings seem fine for now, though - how often should I
check? Recommendations on best literature to learn about ajusting the soli's?

c) Anybody with a personal recommendation re: a shop to rebuild the solex's?
It's been suggested that I probably have worn throttle shafts, butterflies; not
too bad for now, more likely a winter project.

The car is virtually rust-free (and is definately so in all the "important" 
places); later this summer I'll see about removing peeling original 
undercoating from the upper areas of the rear quarters; any recommendations on 
emulsifier/treatments (was thinking about POR 15 or wurths as treatment) would 
also be appreciated.

BTW, when I got the car home (did the trip SOLO) my 2yr old daughter 
immediately claimed the car as her own....and even my wife likes it!

Thanks, everybody. Look forward to talking with you regularly.

Lon Herman (Herman.40@osu.edu)

'67 912, '81 Vanagon Westie, 2 SAABS (now I'm thinking about selling the 
SPG.....)

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 12:50:50 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re: Headlights

The designation H4, H5 etc refers to the bulb standard, not the lens and 
reflector assembly. So a H4 light for a BMW is really a BMW reflector/lens which 
takes a standard H4 two filament replaceable bulb as its light source. Similarly 
the H4 for a 911 is a big bloody light, 9" across which uses a H4. 

I ahve the H4 lights on my 911, they are good, but my bet is that they are not 
as good as the H1 lights which have a separate bulb and reflector for low and 
high beam instead of the single light bulb in the H4/H5. Price is a factor 
though, and  I am not too sure on availability.

My advice....get rid of those sealed beams and enjoy an enlightened world, exact 
type is not supercritical....


Dennis Kalma
'75 911S with Kremer 3.2

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 11:59:38 -0800 (PST)
From: BMESSINGER@ewu.edu
Subject: RE>914 sound system



In responce to Patrick's quest for a 914 sound system I have a few
suggestions.  The best system I've seen in a 914 (according to my judgement)
was done as follows.
                    1>a new center console was made which looked just like
                      the original, but was actualy a sealed housing for a
                      'Kicker'solo-baric 8''subwoofer (designed for small
                      enclosures) which faced toward the passenger side.

                    2>carpeted enclosures housing 6.5'' component sets were
                      constructed and placed in the factory speaker locations
                      and are only slightly more obtrusive than the factory
                      plastic housings.

                    3>a cd player resides in the factory dash location
                      (only slightly closer to the driver than the passenger
                      side window crank, ha ha.)

                    4>an amp and cross-over hide in the console/enclosure.

I am more into driving than I am into stereos, so I like this set-up because
it is simple, discrete and yet it sounds wonderful. The only thing it lacks
 is a dash control for the sub-woofer, since lows are more pronounced when
 the top is off the car.

            Hope this gives you some ideas.

Ben Messinger
'72 914-4

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 95 12:32:22 PDT
From: Henrik Eriksson <henrik@chronologic.com>
Subject: C2 Running HOT

I have a '90 C2, this weekend I took it for a drive up to Napa Valley.
This saturday it was about 105 degreees up there.... I didn't use the A/C at
all because the car was getting hot, pinned as close to the red zone as it could.
Anyway finally the red light came on(overheated), but luckily I was
very close to the first wineyard. 20 minutes later the engine had cooled
down a bit and I went to the next place. The engine got up to the red again,
and I just turned in to the next place..... After this the car never got up
in the red zone again, but were as close as it could be all the way home.


My question is: is this normal with the C2?, I thought that this was more of
a problem with the older 911.

Everything in the engine compartment looked fine, is there anything special
to check?, or improve to cool it down?

What driving style cools it down best? 3000rpm in 5th?, 2500rpm in 5th?,
3000rpm in 4:th?.

How much impact do the A/C have on overheating? I mean the only time you want to
use it is when it's very warm outside, and then the car might overheat.....

Anyway I'm glad I put in the Mobil-1 synthetic oil last week.

Thanks!

henrik@chronologic.com

ps.

I saw about a dozen stranded cars on the way home, a few air-cooled VW,
VW busses, I guess this kind of heat was new.
Everything else was a success.....

- ----- Begin Included Message -----

Porsche Supercup Returns to U.S. Television in 1995

RENO, NEVADA, May 10, 1995 --- Porsche Cars North America today announced
the 1995 Porsche Supercup Championship will be televised in the U.S. over
the ESPN cable sports television network. It marks the second-straight year
ESPN has telecast the Porsche Supercup to U.S. households.

Lingner Group Productions of Indianapolis will again produce each of the
nine race broadcasts plus a season wrap-up program. All of these half-hour
telecasts will be seen once on ESPN and at least twice on ESPN 2. Veteran
motor sports announcer Marty Reid returns as the Championship host.

Now in its third year, the Porsche Supercup Championship is run in
conjunction with nine European World Championship Formula One Grand Prixs
 - -- San Marino, Spain, Monaco, France, Great Britain, Germany, Hungary,
Belgium and Europe (Nurburgring). Drivers from seven European countries
will contest the entire 1995 series in cars fielded by some of that
continent's top sports car racing teams. In addition, several well-known
North American drivers are expected to compete in individual races at the
controls of Porsche factory "guest" cars.

All cars entered in the Supercup Championship are identically equipped and
based on the highly popular 1995 Porsche 911 Carrera. Changes in the
race-prepared Carreras for the 1995 Championship include the addition of a
huge fixed rear wing and new front spoiler, enhanced suspension and a
shortened sixth gear for added performance at very high speeds. These
modifications have resulted in a car that is faster yet easier to drive
than last year's version.

1995 Porsche Supercup  U.S. Television Schedule

San Marino
ESPN - Sun., May 28, 3: 30 pm EDT
ESPN 2 - Sat., July 1, 3: 00 pm EDT
ESPN 2 - Thurs., Oct. 5, 4:30 pm EDT

Spain

ESPN 2 - Sun., Aug. 13, 12:00 pm EDT
ESPN 2 - Thurs., Nov. 9, 4:30 pm EST

Hungary
ESPN - Fr i ., Sept. 22, 1:00 am EDT
ESPN 2 - Sun., Sept. 10, 6:30 pm EDT

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 95 15:59:21 EDT
From: "Wayne G. Namerow" <itsmagic@VNET.IBM.COM>
Subject: 9 1 4 Audio Improvements

On Mon, 26 Jun 1995, Patrick Joel Morton wrote:

> Subject: 9 1 4 Audio Improvements


>To put it bluntly, the stereo system in my 914 is less than adequate.

Agreed, and there isn't much room for improvements without major surgery
to the car.

>The interior possibilities for some type of stereo upgrade seem to be
>rather lackluster and limited, IMHO....

Patrick,
     When I adressed this problem, my first rule was that I was not going
to seriously modify the 914 for a better stereo. I quickly realized that
some type of compromise would be needed for decent sound. In my case, I
chose a little less leg room. What I did was to place two, box three way
speakers with honeycomb woofers (for space conservation, yet still able
to move air), horn midrange and piezo tweeters behind each seat. Thus,
the seats are moved forward about 6 inch's (I'm 6' and really notice it,
but the tradeoff was worth it). I then installed a 50 watt per channel
amp under the dash on the passengers side and connected it to a decent
receiver/cd player in the dash. All pretty non intrusive and it sounds
good even with the top off!
This setup won't win your local distorted rap thump thump contests, but
it gives the 914 good sound with minimal tradeoff.   Good luck.
                                                    -Wayne

------------------------------

Date: 26 Jun 1995 13:06:28 U
From: "Soren LaForce" <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re- fuel level autocrossing

Peter writes:

> Do you 
>have a full tank of gas when you autocross, or empty?  What do you gain 
>I have a 1974 911 Targa Carrera (RS I wish).

I don't think it makes any significant difference.

I generally figure that any loss in acceleration is offset by 
the gains in braking and turn-in.

I don't go out with less than half a tank because sometimes I'll 
use a quarter tank during the event ('80 'sc) and then I want to 
get home...


- --Soren
soren_laforce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 13:33:48 -0700 (MST)
From: Scott D Ellingsen <sde@GAS.UUG.Arizona.EDU>
Subject: Re: 944 turbo help



On Mon, 26 Jun 1995, Sean P. Simmen wrote:

> My roommate has cought Porsche fever(I think my 928 is extremely contagious)
> and has been looking at a couple of cars this weekend.  The one he is leaning
> towards is a '96 944 turbo that is supposedly in great condition and has all
> service records.  The guy says that everything is working fine, but that it
> is about time to replace the water pump.  Does this cost as much as it does
> on a 928?  It has 95K miles and the guy wants $9,000 for it.  My roommate
> says that he really justs wants it to take to the track- so should he hold
> out for a turbo S?  Although, he really doesn't want to spend more than $9K.
> Is the 944 turbo the worst older Porsche to insure?  Should he just get a
> normally aspirated 944/24 and tweek it(they are about half the price).
> Thanks for any help!  Sean  '80 928
> PS. I have printed out the FAQ for 944/24's so please don't just tell me to
>     read them, because I have!
> 


My experience is that the water-pump is inexpensive compared to the cost
of getting at the thing to replace it (unless of course, you do it
yourself).  Your friend might consider replacing the timing/balance belts
while he's in there...seems to me you have to go through this stuff to get
at the pump...? 

Anyway, several design changes were implemented beginning in 1987, so I 
would encourage your friend to find an '87+ 944 Turbo.

That's my $0.02 on the matter.


Scott
'87 944T

Date: 26 Jun 1995 13:14:55 U

Marc writes:


Hey all again,
This is just a note of a reputable alternator source in the SF Bay area.
About a year ago my alternator went out on my 65 911. After calling all the
usual places for parts the chapest I could find a rebuilt unit was in the
250 to 300 range. I looked in the yellow pages and found a place called 

   snip

***************


Maybe I'm the only one to think of this so I'll post it.

I just get out the yellow pages and call an alternator shop
and ask "how much to rebuild my alternator?"

Last time it was Pacific Auto Electric in Sunnyvale.  $77 to 
rebuild.

They'll generally test your voltage regulator at the same time.

must reach 130 degrees. A mess. The hot air blast continues even if the 
a/c compressor is shut off. Even worse, even when the fan is set to zero,

check the relays.

any & all advice is greatly appreciated! (as there is no way i'm driving 
cross-country in this mobile oven.)  thanks!

adam

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 17:36:01 -0500 (EST)
From: NFENNESS@PEARL.TUFTS.EDU
Subject: Public Garages

Dear P-Phillers
  FYI, National Public Radio's Click and Clack the Tappet brother's "Good 
News Garage" used to be a fee-for-space facility back in the late '70s.  
You'd pay $4.00 per hour for a dry, heated (as necessary) space and 
loaner tools.  A driver's lisence was exchanged for a tool cart, floor 
jack, etc.  It beat the hell out of fixing your heap on the streets of 
the Republic of Cambridge, especially in winter.
   I left town for about three years and upon my return in 1983 called to 
see if they had a dummy load to test my heap's charging system.  When 
I asked what the hourly rate was, foolishly thinking Reganomics had 
driven their fee to $5.00 / hour, Ray replied that they were now at $35.00 
/ hour.  To make a long story short, all the groovey guys and gals who 
worked for the Good News Garage "advising" the shadetree clientel, stole 
them blind (at least tool wise).  It WASN'T the CUSTOMERS.
   So, for those of you interested in such a venture, give Tom and Ray a 
call some Saturday morning.  I'd bet they have some more interesting 
stories to tell.

	- Neil
	'67 912 (sporting a new but WAY CHEAP windshield)

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 17:59:12 -0400 (EDT)

Check the TurboS prices out. I think your friend will find a good TurboS to be
$6K - $9K over his $9K budget.
>
> Is the 944 turbo the worst older Porsche to insure?  Should he just get a
> normally aspirated 944/24 and tweek it(they are about half the price).

Some companies refused to quote me insurance on the 951. Shop around. It's
not too bad. Tweeking of the 944 has been discussed here at length and the
general tone of that particular thread was that there is no way you will
come close to 951 performance for the difference in price between a 951
and a 944 of like years and condition.

Good Luck,

Doug Donsbach - dld@symtec.com - Knoxville, TN
'88 951 - '88 735i (with new Moda M1's and Yoko A509's)

Date: 26 Jun 1995 15:17:21 U
From: "John Lucas GRC" <john_lucas_grc@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re:  944 a/c emergency

Mail*Link(r) SMTP               RE> 944 a/c emergency

Adam writes...
>i'm about to embark on a 2000-mile trip tomorrow, so of course, 
>this had to happen....

>My a/c has stopped working. The compressor engages & spins, but no matter 
>what temperature is selected, it BLASTS full heat -- the air temperature 
>must reach 130 degrees. A mess. The hot air blast continues even if the 
 <<  snip  >>

Adam, I have a 928, but I'll betcha that the a/c logic is the same in your
car.  On my car this is a symptom of a broken outside temperature sensor wire
(or a dead sensor).  If you're handy and have the trouble shooting bulletin
from Porsche, you can track it down yourself.  But you sound like you need a
fix TODAY.

If you can find the temp sensor, check the continuity of the wires from the
sensor to the plug near your a/c controller.  If one of the lines is open, you
can jury rig a temporary wire to get you through your trip.  I have no idea
what happens if you short out the connector in the car and simply remove the
outside temp sensor from the circuit, but it's worth a try.

I hope a 944-knowledgeable p-philer gives you better advice!

Good luck (I know all about this problem -- BTDT, in the desert, on a very hot
day!)

John
'84 928S



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 17:26:15 -0500 (CDT)
From: Menelaos Karamichalis <mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu>
Subject: Rev Limiters, fuel and auto-x

I finally managed to participate in an auto-x event last Sunday organized 
by the St. Louis Region chapter of SCCA.  I was a bit worried about 
trying this given it was my first event and I have not participated in any 
driving schools.

I raced my 944S in B Stock with my street tires (the only ones I own) 
which are Pirrelli P500.  Basically, my car is completely stock, which 
lend me a serious handicap as every one else was racing with BFG R1 
tires(including my competition in BS, which was 5 seconds faster than 
me).  However, it was a great experience full of fun and I feel as if I 
learned a lot.  Here is what I learned:
a) Smoothness is the key.  I never tete-a-que-ed due to spinning the rear 
end out, whereas lots of other drivers did in corners that I found easy, 
some that even had front wheel drive models.  (a CRX almost rolled)  Sure, I 
was going slow given I have not done this before, but not that slow that 
I did not have my chances to royally mess up.
b) It is good to turn in way before the cones in the slalom so that the 
chassis has time to set (give time for the weight transfer to occur).
c) I take my curves way to tight, thus my tires have to work extra hard.  
I need to increase the radius when I turn.  
d) Sheesh, I have never smoked the wheels while shifting to second gear 
before.  The car has more power that I thought.  I need to harness it better.
e) Walk the course more than once, so you can learn it before you drive 
and also plan how you should negotiate it. I walked it only once and as a 
result, I did not know it well and DNF-ed one of my runs as I missed one 
of the gates.  Also, I had lot of problems with a seemingly easy curve 
because I did not plan well.

My auto-x experience also generated questions that I was hoping someone 
in this list may have an answer for.
a) I noticed that a lot of cars were bumping their rev limiters.  The end 
of the auto-x track had a straight run where everyone just floored it on 
second gear.  I am very hesitant to hit the red line.  Should I be?  Or is 
the rev limiter something I should use from time to time?  I feel that my 
fear to mash the pedal on the floor costs me time.
b) How much fuel should I have in the tank?  Should I have little fuel so 
the car can be light or does the extra weight aid in rear whell traction?

The bottom line:  This is FUN, I want MORE.  

'85 Burgundy Ice Mazda 626LX			mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu
'87 Guard's Red Porsche 944S
'93 Red-White Miyata Five-12

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 18:34:49 -0400 (EDT)
From: Tomkow <tomkow@nando.net>
Subject: Re: Power Box Fuel System



On Sat, 24 Jun 1995, Michael Lo wrote:

> Anyone experienced with the Power Box Fuel Management System ?  How much
> should I expect to pay ?  I am considering buying one and I have a 86 Carrera.
> 
> Michael Lo
> 86 Carrera Coupe
> 
> 
Hi,
   Well, I bit.  Richard, the owner I suppose, was very convincing on the 
phone.  I had condidered the chipping option and we discussed that.  I 
had also considered the supercharging idea.  But, after talking with 
Richard twice, decided to take the plunge.  It was more (claimed) bang 
for the buck.  Installation was easy.  The short "programming" session 
for the motronic unit to adapt to the powerbox was also easy enough.  
Adjustment of the unit after installation is a breeze.  I just had the 
car "sniffed" for the state inspection and blew a 0.02% CO with about 230 
ppm HC.  Well within the legal limits for NC.
   My impressions:
	1)  While I have not timed or dyno'ed the car, I find it 
            difficult to believe that I have removed 9/10th's of a second 
            from my 0-60 times.  That kind of power increase  should not 
            be so subtle that it takes a machine to tell me that I made a 
            performance improvement.  I'm not saying that it didn't, I 
	    just have not verified it.
	2)  The engine does pull more strongly below 3500 rpm's.  That 
	    part I can tell.  No real rush or anything, I just don't find   
	    myself down-shifting as much.  Drivability has been improved 
	    in that respect.
	3)  I believe, again there's no hard data, that the car runs 
 	    cooler. I am not having to turn the A/C off in stop & go 
	    traffic like last summer.
	4)  I have not noticed any major drop in fuel consumption.  I 
	    figured that the extra fuel pressure should use more fuel.  
            Isn't that the premise of this device in the first place?
   Would I recommend it?  I don't know, certainly not for the price I 
paid: $695.00.  The mfr. realises this as well.  He has dropped the price 
by $200.00.  Against a high performance chip for the same price, I 
suppose that I would opt for this again, but at the $495.00 price.  I do 
not have problems with detonation or hard starts or flat spots and  I can 
dial the pressure up or down as necessary.  I don't have to buy premium 
fuel, though I always do.  If necessary, I can get by on regular in a 
pinch and not worry about potential damage.
   I suppose that I'll have to drive a stock 911 to see (if there's) a real 
difference.  Until then I'll just enjoy my perceived improvements.

 -Bill Tomko
 '84 911 3.2 Carrera

My '84 Carrera came with relatively new Goodyear GA's: 215/60/15 front

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 19:20:25 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: Autocrossers 911 How much gas in the tank?

>> I have a question for you experienced Porsche autocrossers.  Do you
>> have a full tank of gas when you autocross, or empty?  What do you gain
>
>I run (ran, actually -- haven't had time to autox in a while) with a full
>tank. I also ran with the spare tire, and a ton crap in the front trunk.

        As Soren noted earlier, there are trade-offs.  The main thing is
you don't want to run out of fuel.
        As for running with "a ton of crap", you will fail tech locally
if you have *any* loose "crap" hanging around in your trunk.  If you put
stuff up there (including the spare tire!), make sure that it's securely
fastened down.  I think Stan is assuming that everything's secure, but I
personally don't take the time to tie my autoX box and tool boxes down
in my trunk.
        I know people locally who drive the course with their windows
halfway rolled down because they think it's aerodynamically cleaner than
all the way down.  (Our rules specify that the window not be up.)  At
typical autoX speeds, the advantage has got to be un-measurable.  But it's
what they believe in, so they do it.  A full tank vs. an empty tank is
probably not going to have any measurable effect on how you drive until
you've been doing it for a while.  And by the time you can notice it, you
will probably have formed an opinion of the way that *you* like it.

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 19:23:08 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914/6 with a 3.2 questions

>A stock 3.2 makes... what?  About 210 HP?  The 901 gearbox is more than
>adequate for this type of duty, unless you're planning on drag-racing
>your car or something (the 901's first gear is a pretty weak design
>even for a stock 2-liter 914/6).                 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

        If you go with a 901, you'll want to baby the 1st gear even if
you *don't* go drag-racing.  I know of someone with a 3.0/901 combo that
launches their car in 2nd gear.  Hard on the clutch, of course...

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 95 20:26:42 -0500
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William Marten)
Subject: June Sprints (Porsche) results

     ******************************************************
     ***       The Porsche-related news from the        *** 
     ***  40th Annual Chicago Region SCCA June Sprints  *** 
     ***       @ Road America in Elkhart Lake, WI       *** 
     ******************************************************
 
I only spotted 3 Porsches on the race course on Saturday and 
Sunday {I didn't attend Friday's qualifying sessions} all of which 
did quite well. 
 
The best result came in the E-Production final where the 
Quicksilver-sponsored 914-4 of Robert Kirby {Oceanside, CA} took 
top honors in class while placing 3rd overall with a best lap of 
2:38.506 and a speed of 90.848 mph.  Also on the podium for E-Prod 
was Reid Vann {St. Louis, MO} for his 3rd place finish in the Reid 
Vann Luxury Imports-sponsored 356 Speedster. 
 
In the post-race interview, Mr. Kirby said that the MGs in the 
race were all over him in the corners, but he had been able to 
pull away with superior horsepower.  I would concur with his 
assessment.  From my vantage point watching turn 5, the MGs seemed 
to have the better of him, but mid-race an incident elsewhere on 
the track tore the right-rear fender off of his fiercest 
competitor and the Porsche pulled away from then on.  Earlier, he 
and his crew had been forced to swap engines before the final 
after suffering a "slightly bent valve from a slightly missed 
shift" in qualifying. 
 
The 356 ran a consistent and uneventful race dicing primarily with 
competitors of other classes. 
 
The remaining Porsche was the Red Carpet Car Wash GT-2 914-6 of 
Jim Blakewell {Oklahoma City, OK} which finished {unofficially -- 
I didn't hang around for the official results} in second behind 
the Sunbeam Tiger of Tom Patton {Fairfield, OH}.  The race took 
place with GT-1 and GT-3 competitors on the track as well and the 
distance between the Tiger and the 914-6 remained consistent until 
the last couple of laps when Blakewell seemed to make a final push 
only to run out of time. 
 
Maybe next year I can get a press pass as a reporter for 'Porschephiles'.
 
Bill Marten 
wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu 
Madison, WI, USA 


------------------------------

I once painted the insides of my faded orange BMW turn signals with
Tamiya model paint, color X-26, Clear Orange and it worked great. The
paint is acrylic and is waterproof when dry. I wouldn't try it on the outside
though.

>
>Has anyone ever seen a product, some sort of paint, I guess, that will
>restore the translucent orange color to turn signal lenses?
>

Ken '86 944

Date: 26 Jun 95 21:39:07 EDT
From: <Bill_Histed.ASM@notes.compuserve.com>
Subject: Re:  Fw: waaay stupid tricks

           Hey Percey, check  this out!


  _____ Reply Separator _____
  Author:   INTERNET:aek @ netcom.com@CISHUB
  Received: 05/22/95 08:34:00 PM
  Subject:   Fw: waaay stupid tricks

  I just got this from a friend ... enjoy!




  >Stupid Human Trick ...
  >
  >OUCH!  don't try this one at home, now, kiddies!
  >
  >"Darwin award" Nominee: You all know about the Darwin awards -- it's
  >an annual honor given to the person who did the gene pool the biggest
  >service by killing themselves in the most extraordinarily stupid way.
  >Last year's winner was the fellow who was killed by a Coke (tm)
  >machine, which toppled over on top of him as he was attempting to tip
  >a free soda out of it.
  >
  >And the nominee is:
  >
  >The Arizona (U.S.) Highway Patrol came upon a pile of smoldering metal
  >imbedded into the side of a cliff rising above the road, at the apex
  >of a curve.
  >
  >The wreckage resembled the site of an airplane crash, but it was a
  >car.  The type of car was unidentifiable at the scene.  The boys in
  >the lab finally figured out what it was, and what had happened.
  >
  >It seems that a guy had somehow got hold of a JATO unit, (Jet Assisted
  >Take Off, actually a solid-fuel rocket) that is used to give heavy
  >military transport planes an extra `push' for taking off from short
  >airfields.  He had driven his Chevy Impala out into the desert, and
  >found a long, straight stretch of road.  Then he attached the JATO
  >unit to his car, jumped in, got up some speed, and fired off the
  >JATO!!  Best as they could determine, he was doing somewhere between
  >250 and 300 mph (350-420kph) when he came to that curve....  The
  >brakes were completely burned away, apparently from trying to slow the
  >car.
  >
  >(NOTE: Solid-fuel rockets don't have an 'off'... once started, they
  >burn at full thrust 'till the fuel is all gone.)
  >
  >


  ___________________________________________
  | Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  |
  |___________________________________________|
  | "Freedom of the press is not an end in    |
  |   itself but a means to the end of a free |
  |   society."    Felix Frankfurter          |

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 17:29:51 -0700
From: kkan@Direct.CA
Subject: Metallic grinding on 944

I think I first heard this today after I hit a small 'speed' bump at 
moderate speed. The sound came from the passenger side
and sounded like a squeaking, metallic, grinding sound which
seemed to pulse (the sound, not the pedal) at a rate dependent
on how fast the wheels were turning. The sound was about 2-3 times
louder than a regular brake squeal, with more emphasis on grinding.
 
The best way I can describe it was that it sounded as though the 
metal backing plate behind the brake disk was rubbing against the
disk (though I know this was not the case).  This continued for about
3 blocks while I drove slowly in 1st gear pressing the brake
intermittently after which it seemed to go away completely.

Any ideas what this might have been??
 
Guesses:

 - Hitting the bump in the road cause the brake pads to go off alignment
  a bit, resulting in the pad rubbing against a high spot on the disk?

 - After hitting the bump, a small pebble or rock got in between the pad
 and disk, causing the grinding sound until the pebble fell out or was worn
 down?
 
These seem kind of improbable to me.

Ken '86 944

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 22:24:50 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : Autocross 911 How much gas?

Peter Kauffman kaufpw@ix.netcom.com asked about fuel level in his
'75 Carrera for autocross.

I have always run almost empty (but keep the "empty" idiot light off).
But like Stan I keep the spare in for some low stable weight, and
used to run a huge Gates sealed battery on the passengers side to 
offset the driver's side weight (but now need stock batteries in SCCA).

I think the extra fuel weight may help the front stick, but I'd rather
try to adjust the balance with sway bars and run lighter for acceleration.
I've used supertrap mufflers to reduce the rear weight, although power
may not be as good as a stock muffler (!).

But you may want to try a full tank at the end of the day after you have
fugured out the course and see how it works anyway.

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S A-Stock 
AnalogMike@aol.com

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 22:48:23 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Power Box Fuel System

> Anyone experienced with the Power Box Fuel Management System ?  How much
> should I expect to pay ?  I am considering buying one and I have a 86 Carrera.

Having never taken one apart, from the descriptions I get I believe them to
be something called a Rising Rate Regulator, that causes the fuel
pressure to go up as the engine goes under load. This delivers more gas
and hence the opportunity for more performance.  Adding these beasties
to DME engiens is sort of iffy, but it's a great win on CIS and L-jet
engines. If I'm right, there's nothing further magic about these
units except watching your money -- nothing up the vendor's sleeve,
PRESTO! It's gone....

See also "Cash Flow Device"

Stan

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 06:45:42 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 unstable/shaky after tire replacement

>Hi all,
>
>Have any of you experienced shaky/unstable 944 above 
>~60 mph ? What is going on ?
>This past weekend I had my front tires replaced and
>rear ones (old) moved to front. They also aligned the
>front end. After that the car has been very uncomfortable
>to drive, it shakes back and forth when passed over even
>small bumps/holes. It is also difficult to keep straight.
>
>I was having the same shaking problem before too, but now
>it is unbearable. 

Sound like the tires you have on your front are out of balance or
out of round.  You can check for out of round by jacking the front
wheels up so that the tires are about one quarter inch above 
your garage floor and rotating the wheel at about 20 rpm. If your 
tires/wheels are round, you will see no variance in the gap (it should
stay at 1/4 inch)...

944s are notorious for shaking with the slightest imperfection in the 
wheel/tire balance/roundness/trueness combinations.
Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net
Purveyors of Used 944 Parts and Services to "Her Majesty"
Orders: 800-all-p944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
83 944, 87 944S (SOLD!), 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 80 GMC Pickup

944 turbo fuel economy (my experience in a 944turbo):

	CIty (behaving) ~20
	City (spirited)  ~18
	Highway		~25

	Track	2.5 sessions (1/2 hour each) per tank

As always, your mileage may vary. Hopefully your lap times are consistent!

out of my wifes 325i when I drive it than when she drives it, and 
I generally drive it in much the same manner as I drive my 951...

   If anyone has tried this or has an opinion to offer, please let me know.

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 09:08:41 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Questions 914 Race Car

> I need to run fuel lines thru my 914s chassis, some people had mentioned
> using electrical conduit for the fuel, if i use that what do i put on each
> end for the carbs/fuel cell?
> Or do i just run rubber lines thru the conduit?

Well, you said "carbs" so there are two answers here:

1) full race to SCCA rules spec, etc. Use conduit in a size something like
   1/2", and cut 1/2NPT threads on the outside. Buy some 1/2NPT to AN-8
   female fittings, then make up hoses out of AQP to mate with the similar
   fittings that should already be on the fuel cell. You'll have to find
   similar fittings that fit into the carb body -- SCCA requires that
   the carb fittings be threaded rather than press-in. The one big variable
   is the fuel pump, but electric pumps for racing purposes are routinely
   available in AN or 1/2NPT threaded fittings. You'll also need a fuel
   pressure regulator, adjustble.

2) street (less than full race). I still vote for the above solution, but
   you *DO* have other options. You can get 1/2NPT to 1/2 ID rubber hose 
   (the "barbed" fittings for press-on hose) which you can use in conjuction
   with good grade of 1/2" ID rubber fuel line and hose clamps. This is
   also what you do if you're keeping the stock EFI, but the fitting
   sizes are different -- that 9mm Wurth line you need to use requires
   a 3/8" barbed fitting.

The *HARDEST* part is if you try to use the stock fuel pump. Give it up.
It doesn't work right for the application and it's really hard to get the
right hose setup to work... the Bosch pump really REALLY wants press-on
rubber hose, and that's not part of the program with the fuel cells. Plus
if you try to use AQP as press-on hose, you discover that there is NO WAY
to get enough compression on it from a hose clamp to keep it from popping
off when that's what you least need...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 23 Jun 95 15:46:56 
From: da@airsoft.com
Subject: Re: New paint job


Steve,

ask them about *everything*.  It could mean the difference between being 
satisfied and being totally bummed about a poor job.  For eg. ask the 
following:

* are they going to remove all the windows?
* are they goind to replace all the seals?
* are they going to paint inside the door jambs?
* are they going to re-paint the matt black border on the *inside* of the 
doors?
* are they going to disassemble the car. i.e. remove the doors, hood, 
decklid.
* are they going to paint the back of the decklid and under the hood?
* who's going to re-assemble the car?  These cars are *not* forgiving for 
guys who have'nt taken them apart and put them back together before.
* are they going to remove and re-paint the black trim and emblems?  If
so, what materials or paint will they use?  How well will this paint stand 
being out in the sun without oxidizing or flaking off?
* are they going to re-use the old fasteners when re-assembling the car?  
This is a complete waste if for example they intended to put your corroded 
old allen bolt back in your side mirrors.  New paint with old fasteners = 
does'nt look good...
* if your car is silver, ask them if they're any good at shooting silver.  
It is a bitch to get it right.  Many times even experienced painters will 
have silver coming out blotchy.
* what brand of paint are they going to use?  (I can't recommend any except 
Glasurit cause I've had two cars done in it - its good)
* how far down are they going to strip your original paint?  There's no 
need to go to bare metal if the factory paint is good (especially since 
your body panels are galvanized - you don't want to remove the galvanizing)
* BEWARE if your car is a targa and you're going to have the top seal that 
goes on the windshield frame replaced!  The factory replacement seal DOES 
NOT FIT without some modification.  The new part appears to be made for the 
later Carreras, which is fine because it seals the wing windows against 
water better but they seem to be a different shape (thicker) at the 
windshield corners than the original seal, and will require manual trimming 
of seal to make it work on an SC.  Make sure the guy who replaces this seal 
is an old hand at making the new factory part fit on your car!  This is 
time consuming to do and the seal fairly expensive too at around $160.


Hope this helps, and good luck!

Derek Au

P.S.  If you decide not to paint your car, you can buy my SC.  I've done 
all the above already!

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 09:30:05 -0500
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@medtronic.com>
Subject:  914 shift knob Question

P-Philes,

Last night I tried to replace the aftermarket shift knob
on my 914 with an original knob, but I couldn't figure out
how it is supposed to attach to the shift lever.

The end of the shift lever is just a smooth chromed tube -
I believe it is stock.  Looking inside the shift knob, I see what
looks like a ribbed metal sleeve deep inside.  Is this sleeve
supposed to grip the shift lever, or am I missing some other
piece?  I couldn't get the knob to seat fully on the shift lever,
and was afraid to try anything more forceful than pushing for
fear of damaging the knob.

Any suggestions?

Pete Klager
'75 914  1.8L

I'll send him.

races, anti-fire or air conditioned or radio);

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 08:11:35 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Washing Car (&wax)

Hi Darren. Re:

>        Whenever I wash my car, I always notice lots of tiny scratch-like
>marks left afterwards. I figure it's the dirt which is scraping against the
>paint when I scrub it with >>> my wash mitt. <<< 

Ouch! Don't use a wash mitt. Use a horse-hair brush (_very soft, long
bristles_) and apply it lightly on a very wet car with a swirling action. 
Eastwood sells such brushes. The idea is (as long as everything's wet
enough) that the ends of the bristles "lift" the grime off the car.

 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  |
|        standard disclaimers apply         | 
|___________________________________________|

>supposed to grip the shift lever, or am I missing some other

>fear of damaging the knob.

Yep, that crush ring is in there between the knob and the lever - you just
have to press real hard.

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 08:03:25 -0700

>how it is supposed to attach to the shift lever.

>I believe it is stock.  Looking inside the shift knob, I see what
>looks like a ribbed metal sleeve deep inside.  Is this sleeve
>supposed to grip the shift lever, or am I missing some other
>piece?  I couldn't get the knob to seat fully on the shift lever,
>and was afraid to try anything more forceful than pushing for
>fear of damaging the knob.
>

The sleeve is suppose to hold the knob on take the sleeve out and put at the
bottom of the knob.Bottom is def as the opening so when you push the knob on
the shaft the sleeve will grip and slide toward the top of the knob and if
not worn out will hold the knob in place.

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 12:39:10 -0300
From: cpaine@fox.nstn.ca (Christopher Paine)
Subject: 914 End play

Here's a straight forward but, it seems, uncommon question. Can you use more 
than three shims on the end of a 914 crank? In my attempts to check end-play 
this weekend, I discovered that the Scat crank has a total end-play of 55 
thou. and needs to be shimmed (theoretically with three shims) to between 3 
and 5 thou. Shims come in thicknesses ranging from 10 thou to 15 thou. As 
you can see, this presents a problem, mathematically,[ (3 x 15) + 4 = 49] 
Anybody have any experience with this?
TIA

__________________________________________________________________________
Christopher Paine 
cpaine@fox.nstn.ca                        "Technology is like a steamroller,
Metropolis Pictures, Director              if you're not on it, you become
Editor,Der Auspuff,Rennsport Region PCA    part of the road"

my 83 944 had a wobble at speed (50 -70 mph, I forget exactly) due to the

balanced-wobble. I just got the tires re-balanced once a year.

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 10:52:43 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: The Weekend from Hell

Last Thursday night my wife and I left Cedar Rapids, Iowa to travel
to the Minneapolis area to look for a place to live.  Btw, could you
Twin Citians please contact me so I can ask some questions about 
places to live and such.  Anyhow, we took the Porsche since her
BMW was still up on jackstands waiting for new rotors to arrive
in the mail.  That afternoon I filled up with gas and shortly 
afterwords had some hesitation in acceleration.  After pulling 
over and looking things over, I decided I must have gotten some bad
gas and that it would have to work its way through.  

During the trip the car lost power two different times.  Each time
I would loose power the car would loose rpms and I would pull over.
It never died.  After a minute or two everything would return to 
normal and we'd be on our way.  We had reserved a motel room in
Albert Lea since we couldn't find anything vacant in the Twin Cities
area over the weekend.  When we were about 10 miles south of Albert
Lea I lost power again.  This time the car died and wouldn't restart.
When I turn it on it would idle fine for a second or so.  Then it 
would idle roughly at 400-800 rpm and die.  I tried this about 10 times
with the same results.  

When it was clear that my car wasn't going to start we walked to the nearest
town.  Luckily we were only a half mile out.  The small town (I don't know
it's name) was shut down for the night.  Even the convience store was
close at 10:15, but luckily it had a pay phone.  We called the local 
dispatcher and a sheriff stopped by.  He seemed somewhat knowledgable
about cars and looked at it with me.  We gave it another 10 tries or so
with identical results.  He called a local towing company that offered
flatbed trailoring.  The sheriff gave us a lift to our motel room and
we called it a night.

The next morning I stopped by the local Ford/VW/Mazda dealership and 
asked if they would look at it.  After I described the problem, they 
told me that they had seen a lot of problems with gas lately and that
the cars would restart after cooling down.  Figuring it wouldn't hurt
to try, I start the car up and it idled fine.  I paid the towing bill
and drove out of the lot.  I got it just down the street when the
problems started again.  This time I kept it going but it was running
very roughly and wouldn't get above 2000 rpm.  I got it on a frontage
road and back to the dealership.  We still suspected gas problems, so 
they called around town look for a fuel filter.  No filters compatible
with a 944 Turbo could be found in Albert Lea, MN. 

I was at a loss at this point.  My worst nightmare had come true - my
Porsche was broken down in the middle of nowhere.  I didn't know where
to have it hauled in the Twin Cities area - this seemed like the only 
option at this point.  Of course, I hadn't bothered to bring my CRAP
list along.  This was only a five hour trip, nothing serious would 
happen in that time - yeah, right!  I had luck on my side again.  One
of the salespeaople at the Ford dealership had an '83 944 and they 
refered me to Carousel Porsche.  I called the towing company again and
had them flatbed it to Carousel.

We rented a car at a different dealership in Albert Lea (the Ford 
dealership was out of rentals) and drove to Bloomington to meet the
realitor.  The car got to Carousel at about noon on Friday and they
started looking at it at 2:00 or so.  I called and talked to the 
service manager that afternoon and he told me they had determined
that it was nothing simple and that it would be Monday at the soonest.
He said that he could make no promises about that.

We finished our business in Minneapolis Saturday afternoon.  We tried to 
find a one-way rental to get us home, since the rental we had needed to 
be returned to Albert Lea.  We check with all of the major rental companies
and none of them had anything available in the Twin Cities area for the
weekend!  I called one of my friends in Iowa City and had him meet us in
Albert Lea and give us a lift home.

Last night (Monday) I called to find out the status of my car.  The service
manager said it needs a new air box.  I guess in the end it had nothing
to do with bad gas.  The really depressing news is that supposedly there
are no air boxes in the US and they will have to order one from Germany.
Does anyone know what he means by air box?  Is this the air flow sensor?
I plan to talk to the actual mechanic (he was gone last night when I called)
later today to figure out what's going on.

I'll keep you posted on what developes.  This is only the second time since
I've owned the car that anyone except me has touched the car so I'm a bit
apprehensive at this point.  Thanks for listening.

Ross Stites
'87 951

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 95 09:02:00 PST
From: "Don Schmidek" <dis@metricom.com>
Subject: '91 911 C-2 Mistery wire

     Two questions:
     
     1.   Mystery wire
     
     I have found a loose wire in my 1991 911 C-2, behind the diagnostics 
     plug, not connected to anything.  The diagnostics plug is in the 
     passenger footwell -- on the right side, and is about 3" in diameter.
     The wire can be seen "behind" the plug, once the cover is removed.
     
     The wire is really two wires, connected together into a push on 
     connector.  Both wires are brown, with some color stripes.  The wires 
     are always hot (12 VDC).
     
     The dealer told me that that this is used to power up the diagnostics 
     meter/analyzer.  But that does not compute.  If Porsche needed to 
     deliver 12VDC to the diagnostics tool, it would come out of a pin in 
     the main diagnostics plug.
     
     2.   Second question -- the user manual states that after hot run, the 
     engine electric cooling fan will come on, if the engine is overly hot, 
     after shutting down the engine.  Even in the last hot spell in CA, the 
     fan did not come one.  Does anyone have a C-2/4 which has a fan which 
     does come-on after a hot run on a hot day?
     I just went through the fan resistor recall, and they replaced the 
     resistor in the hot air duct.  I believe that this is the same fan.
     
     Does anyone have a clue on either questions?
     
     Thanks
     
     Don
     
     DIS@Metricom.com

Just to add to the confusion, I just diagnosed a similar problem on my 535.

off scale. same symptoms: loss of idle, won't start without right foot
intervention, was intermittent at first.

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 11:08:20 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 End play

> Here's a straight forward but, it seems, uncommon question. Can you use more 
> than three shims on the end of a 914 crank? 

Well, it depends: do you want it to work and continue working for a long
time, or do you just want it to have the right end-play?? The basic
answer is NO. 

> In my attempts to check end-play 
> this weekend, I discovered that the Scat crank has a total end-play of 55 
> thou. and needs to be shimmed (theoretically with three shims) to between 3 
> and 5 thou. Shims come in thicknesses ranging from 10 thou to 15 thou. As 
> you can see, this presents a problem, mathematically,[ (3 x 15) + 4 = 49] 
> Anybody have any experience with this?

Experience with oddly made parts and quality control problems from SCAT?
You bet. Enough to have involved the CA AG office a time or two, and to have
ceased doing all business with them.

Experience with needing more shim than I have allowance for? Yup, that too.
Means that something is WAY out of spec. Could be the flywheel, could be
the crank.

BTW, I *THINK* that FAT has a special extra-thick shim in their catalog.
That's not where I am at the moment, so I can't check. But you might call
and ask anyway.

Stan

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 09:26:35 -0600 (MDT)
From: "Byron D. Short / AFS Inc." <bshort@usa.net>
Subject: RE:  Rev Limiters, fuel and autocross

Menelaos Karamichalis <mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu> sez...

> I raced my 944S in B Stock with my street tires (the only ones I own) 
> which are Pirrelli P500.  Basically, my car is completely stock, which 
> lend me a serious handicap as every one else was racing with BFG R1 
> tires(including my competition in BS, which was 5 seconds faster than 

Yeah man!  BFG's are worth 2-3 seconds on a typical 60 second course.  
You should be very encouraged to be that close at your first event ever!

> me).  However, it was a great experience full of fun and I feel as if I 
> learned a lot.  Here is what I learned:
> a) Smoothness is the key.  I never tete-a-que-ed due to spinning the rear 

Starting out smooth (even if somewhat slow) allows you to take the time 
to learn the right line.  Speed comes to those with the right line, but 
not always the other way around...

> b) It is good to turn in way before the cones in the slalom so that the 
> chassis has time to set (give time for the weight transfer to occur).

The 944 is, um, er, "transitionally challenged".  You must anticipate all 
turns, but especially those in a slalom.

> c) I take my curves way to tight, thus my tires have to work extra hard.  
> I need to increase the radius when I turn.  

Be careful here.  It's a very popular thing to drive larger arcs (a la 
roadracing) in autocross events.  Keep in mind however that physics 
dictate that you will be slower _through the turn_ when you increase the 
size of the arc.  The benefit is that you have a higher exit speed for 
the next straight.  This works great in road racing, but in autocrosses, 
there usually is not enough straight after a turn to matter.  I'd 
encourage you to drive the largest radius you can that has you finishing 
on the inside edge of the turn (late apexing) but (almost) never add 
distance just for the sake of increasing exit speed in an autocross.

> of the gates.  Also, I had lot of problems with a seemingly easy curve 
> because I did not plan well.

As someone put it eloquently, planning your run (via numerous walk thrus) 
allows you to "think" your way through the course instead of merely 
"reacting".

> My auto-x experience also generated questions that I was hoping someone 
> in this list may have an answer for.
> a) I noticed that a lot of cars were bumping their rev limiters.  The end 
> of the auto-x track had a straight run where everyone just floored it on 
> second gear.  I am very hesitant to hit the red line.  Should I be?  Or is 
> the rev limiter something I should use from time to time?  I feel that my 
> fear to mash the pedal on the floor costs me time.

Don't be afraid to use the full designed range of engine operation 
allowed by Porsche!  OTOH, don't ride the rev limiter for more than a 
second either.  At that point, you'd have been faster (and somewhat 
easier on the car) to shift to the next gear.

> b) How much fuel should I have in the tank?  Should I have little fuel so 
> the car can be light or does the extra weight aid in rear whell traction?

I like to run near empty, but Mike Piera said it best in his post on the 
same topic yesterday: Start out near empty and run that way until you 
know what it feels like.  Then try running full and see which YOU like 
better.  

Enjoyed a PCA autocross this weekend.  Took FTD.  It's fun to (flame bait 
alert) explain to all those 911s that they may be slow if they're low on 
antifreeze.  ;-)  

- -- 
[]  []  []      []                []              []       Byron D. Short
  []  []   []        []                        []       bshort@AFSinc.com
[]  []  []     []             []                           (719) 531-9511
  []  []   []       []                 []                     1990 944 S2
[]  []  []    []         []     (They're supposed to be flying checkers.)

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 12:25:06 -0400 (EDT)

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 14:03:03 -0400 (EDT)

Subject: introducing Nate's Ballistic Machine Shop and Garage

    I just got an idea the other day that came dangerously close to
making me aroused...  check this out and see if you find any flaws with
this reasoning.

    Take one fiberglass 550 Spyder replica.  Reinforce chassis.  Install
full 911 suspension and big brakes.  Add 3.6 Turbo motor.  Tune if
desired.  Make some flares and add big wheels and tires.  Go really
fast.  Smile a lot.

    Other than the fact that a 550 would definitely require some sorts
of aerodynamic add-ons (some kind of chin spoiler, rear underbody air
channels, plus some side intakes to keep the motor cool...) can anyone
see why this couldn't be done?  Would a 914 be a better platform to
start from, even though it might be heavier?
    The recent trend toward really ridiculously fast road cars (Bugatti,
McLaren, etc.) has gotten me wondering if the intelligent enthusiast
couldn't come up with something equally fast (if not as refined) for a
lot less $ and a little ingenuity.

    Anyone want to fund this project?  Think CMU would give me a
research grant for it?  (yeah right...)

later,

Nate

Subject: Re: 944 a/c emergency

So...I went and bought a new heater valve.  Of course, when I went to put 
it in, I realized the problem was not the valve, but that the valve was 
receiving no vacuum.

For the temp fix, I've disconnected the controlling arm, and moved the 
valve into the full closed (a/c) position.  Any problems with this?

I drove the car around town, and with the a/c working, the car was fine 
(temperature-wise).  Fingers crossed for my trip.

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 11:10:22 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: RE:  Rev Limiters, fuel and autocross

>> a) Smoothness is the key.  I never tete-a-que-ed due to spinning the rear
>
>Starting out smooth (even if somewhat slow) allows you to take the time
>to learn the right line.  Speed comes to those with the right line, but
>not always the other way around...

Being smooth is not nearly as important on an autox course as it is on a
big track. Considering you have so little time to learn (i.e. so few runs)
the correct line, it is imperative to be aggressive and to find your cars
limits on the course. Obviously it is important to find the right line, but
you cannot afford the time to go slow while doing it.

>> c) I take my curves way to tight, thus my tires have to work extra hard.
>> I need to increase the radius when I turn.
>
>Be careful here.  It's a very popular thing to drive larger arcs (a la
>roadracing) in autocross events.  Keep in mind however that physics
>dictate that you will be slower _through the turn_ when you increase the
>size of the arc.  The benefit is that you have a higher exit speed for
>the next straight.  This works great in road racing, but in autocrosses,
>there usually is not enough straight after a turn to matter.  I'd
>encourage you to drive the largest radius you can that has you finishing
>on the inside edge of the turn (late apexing) but (almost) never add
>distance just for the sake of increasing exit speed in an autocross.

Physics dictates that you will be slower through the turn when you increase
the size of the arc ONLY if you maintain the same speed. Just because you
are on an autox course does not change the fact that the fastest way through
a turn is not the shortest way. 99% of the time a corner in an autocross
should be late apexed. Rarely do you have a straight that is long enough
to justify an early apex at the corner at the end of the straight.

Increased exit speed is EXACTLY what you are looking for. The key is finding
the line that allows a decent entrance speed and allows a fast exit speed.

>> b) How much fuel should I have in the tank?  Should I have little fuel so
>> the car can be light or does the extra weight aid in rear whell traction?
>
>I like to run near empty, but Mike Piera said it best in his post on the
>same topic yesterday: Start out near empty and run that way until you
>know what it feels like.  Then try running full and see which YOU like
>better.

I like to run with a half a tank of gas. Why? My car was setup (suspension
settings and corner balanced) with that much fuel and it feels right.
I do not know what the issues are with 944's, but the 911 can use the
weight over the front wheels. Especially those that understeer in any case.

>Enjoyed a PCA autocross this weekend.  Took FTD.  It's fun to (flame bait
>alert) explain to all those 911s that they may be slow if they're low on
>antifreeze.  ;-)

What kind of 911's and 914's are racing against? Out here in the San
Francisco Bay Area, I have not seen a water pumper in the top 10!! ;-)

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 14:22:01 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Subject: Rev Limiters in auto-x 944

Menelaos Karamichalis <mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu> asked :

>>a) I noticed that a lot of cars were bumping their rev limiters.  The end 
of the auto-x track had a straight run where everyone just floored it on 
second gear.  I am very hesitant to hit the red line.  Should I be?  Or is 
the rev limiter something I should use from time to time?  I feel that my 
fear to mash the pedal on the floor costs me time. <<

Yes, this fear is costing you time. You should have your pedal floored
whenever possible (with a few exceptions when going slower can help).

Don't worry about using the rev limiter, that's why it's there. It is usually
faster to "ride the limiter" for a second than to upshift and then downshift
for the next corner. But if the "straight run" was at the end of the course
with no later downshift needed, then you SHOULD upshift if you can hold
the higher gear for a second or so to get a higher finishing speed.

>>b) How much fuel should I have in the tank?  Should I have little fuel so 
the car can be light or does the extra weight aid in rear whell traction? <<

I answered this for 911's yesterday. For a 944 the answer is similar.
VERY powerful RWD cars (Vettes and Camaros) can go faster with full
tanks because they can put the power down better with weight over
their light rear ends. But a 944 (with better weight distribution and 
less power) with a good limited slip (you really need one for
serious autocrossing) should not need a full tank, as the tradeoff in 
weight will offset any small traction gains.

Of course you need enough gas so as not to starve in long corners.

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S AnalogMike@aol.com
"Help the home-pageless"

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 14:22:02 -0400
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : more "crap" in the trunk for competition

Ed asked :

> Stan, your reply to autocrossers 911 how much gas in the tank has me
curious.
> I have spent quite a bit of time at PCA and SCCA events and every one of
the
> tech inspections required the removal of all the "crap" in the trunk
> including the spare. Are the events you are running sanctioned and by whom?
> As I said I am just curious. Ed

Of course all loose items must be removed, but anything the factory
included which is not loose can remain inside (MUST remain inside
in SCCA Stock classes).

In the Connecticut Valley region of PCA, the spare tire must be
installed in the front of a 911/914 for track events. They believe it 
helps to absorb impact in a crash. SCCA also allows the spare in 
autocrossing.

But my '72 911S full-size spare has no tie down that I can find. Does
anyone know if these cars had some type of securing mechanism?

Regards, Mike Piera '72S and '73E targas, '73 914/2.0

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 18:21:05 +0000 (GMT)
From: wayne@aprf.arl.mil
Subject: Re: Grade markings


Most US bolts have slashes on the bolt head to indicate Grade (tensile
strength) - no slashes - Grade 2  (commercial grade)
	    2  slashes - Grade 4  (most stainless)
	    3  slashes - Grade 5  (most automotive)
	    4  slashes - Grade 6  (some aircraft)
	    5  slashes - Grade 7  (occasionally, say main cap bolts)
	    6  slashes - Grade 8  ('hi strength', or aircraft bolts)

Metric bolts have the DIN rating stamped on the head - 8.8 is about a Grade 5,
and 10.9 is about a Grade 8.

US cap screws (Allen heads) are Grade 8, metric cap screws can be either 8.8
or 10.9 and are stamped accordingly.

US fasteners meeting NAS (National Aerospace Standards) are sometimes marked
with a series specification, usually not tho.  If they are red on top, they have
been Zyglo tested.  Must admit I'm not sure what the DIN equivalent to these
might be.
- -- 
Wayne Flowers                 Voice:  505-678-8303
Senior Scientist              Fax:    505-678-6049
Science & Technology Corp.    E-mail: wayne@aprf.arl.mil
White Sands, New Mexico       URL:    http://aprf.arl.mil/

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 11:34:42 -0700
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: 914/6 Fresh engin,oil leak

     
     I am soliciting advice!
     
     I just got my 2.2E motor for 914/6 running.  I did this on a stand 
     outside of the car to observe things more easily, like leaks!
     
     I have two small "weeping" type oil leaks.  The first one is at the 
     lower oil cooler mounting (about 1 drop/10 minutes). This one doesn't 
     bother me as I can remove cooler with minimal work.  
     
     The second leak has me concerned.  It is on the bottom of the cases, 
     at the seam, just forward of the flywheel end.  I have pretty much 
     ruled out the rear main seal, as there is no oil on the vertical of 
     the cases below it.  I have pretty much ruled out the strainer plate 
     too as I have wiped the area dry several times and it seems to be 
     "weeping" at the last 2-3" of the case seam.  In about 10-15 minutes 
     of running I get 1-2 drips. Problem doesn't get any worse when running 
     and actually drips slighty more after shutoff and engine hot.  When 
     cold it almost stops!
     
     After spending about $3500 and two months, I am not in the state of 
     mind to completely disassemble the engine to diagnose/fix.  I am 
     seriously considering degreasing the case split area to the rear of 
     the strainer and applying a good epoxy... And crossing my fingers.
     
     Other than the leak, the engine runs great, oil pressure is fine and 
     steady, even the carbs were synced!
     
     BTW, when assembling engine cases I must have checked those oil 
     passage seals for positioning about 10 times. 
     
     Stan/Bruce . . . Help!
     
     Dan Swiger
     70 914/6 (The heart is beating now!)

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 11:38:09 -0700 (MST)
From: Tim Jones <timjones@indirect.com>
Subject: Re: 9 1 4 Audio Improvements

On Mon, 26 Jun 1995, Patrick Joel Morton wrote:

> Thus, without anyone getting too specific, are there any suggestions -
> i.e., speaker types and placement, sound proofing or otherwise - for
> improving my 914's sound system?

I installed the Craig autoreverse pullout unit into both of mine ($98 with 
throw-away speakers).  The units offer 25 watts RMS per side.  I then put 
a pair of Radio Shack Minimus 7's behind the seats with the speakers 
facing up.  Wiring goes under the carpet in the middle then splits the 
the speakers in the back on the seats.  Totally clean, totally hidden, 
rocks the stop light with the lid off (though I tend to keep it down 
way below THAT level).  Total investment - under $250 per car and NO dash 
destruction!

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 95 15:36:52 EDT
From: BlaineDeLancey <Blaine.Delancey@lambada.oit.unc.edu>
Subject: Re: Temperature gauges

> I have read recommendations about proper operating temperature for air 
> cooled 911 etc engines, 190 degrees etc.  But, my stock gauge doesn't 
> read degrees so it seems that some people have installed oil temperature 
> gauges that read in degrees.  Can someone who has done that tell me about it.
> 

Hi Wayne,
If you look along the inner rim of the gauge, you will see some fine
lines, like tick marks, along the edge.  I think there are 3 or 4, but the
critical one is about 1/2 way up the left side.  That is the 'you'd better
cool off or check your wallet' point, I think around 220 or so.  Not
immediate destruction, but don't run it at that level.  Don't know if this
applies to all year/models.

Blaine
'One step closer to getting the Carolinas PCA page back online'

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 14:34:13 -0500 (CDT)
From: Paul Christopher Schlesselman <pcs0001@jove.acs.unt.edu>
Subject: Re: 944 a/c emergency!


This sounds to me like the heater valve is not closing.

the heater valve on 944 is up agianst fire wall and controls
the flow of heated water to the heater core.

it is vacuum operated.  a small vacuum hose is connected to
the end of the valve.  

I suggest applying a vacuum from known source to the valve
(manifold suplu near brake booster or vaccuum pump)
and feel fo heated air coming out of ducts.

most likely its the valve not closing. it could also be vacuum suply 
system or control system.

On Mon, 26 Jun 1995, Adam Wolf Farkas wrote:
> help!
> My a/c has stopped working. The compressor engages & spins, but no matter 
> what temperature is selected, it BLASTS full heat -- the air temperature 
> must reach 130 degrees. A mess. The hot air blast continues even if the 
> a/c compressor is shut off. Even worse, even when the fan is set to zero, 
> some air still circulates thru the cabin, and is scorching.
- ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
schless@jove.acs.unt.edu **Perfection is Acceptable** schless@cyberspace.com
http://www.unt.edu/~schless *Porsche 951* http://www.cyberspace.com/~schless

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 14:44:18 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: The Weekend from Hell

Naresh,

>As you all may know, I'm considering buying a 85.5 944 located in 
>Mountain View, CA and driving it back to New York City.
>
>When I read Ross's story it scared the cr*p out of me. I'm 19, looking 
>for my first Porsche, and considering driving it cross-country.
>
>My worst nightmare is it breaking down in nowheresville without a 
>competent mechanic to work on it. Remember this is my first Porsche, so I 
>sure as heck wouldn't know what to do!
>
>Am I crazy, should I have it trucked (if I end up buying it). That should 
>run $800-$1000 right?

How much do you know about the 944?  Any maintenance you plan to do
immediately after purchase (timing belts, tune up, etc.) I would have
done before leaving CA.  What happened to me this last weekend certainly
isn't going to stop me from taking long trips in my Porsche.  What's the
point of having it if I can't take it out and enjoy it?  I've put over
20k miles on it before this happened.  This is the first time it has 
even hesitated to start or run.  For $1k you can have a lot of towing 
and repairs done to your car and think of all the fun you will have
missed.  My major concern is time.  I couldn't stay until it was fixed.
If you're a college student (I assume from you address) and you have
some free time this summer be sure to budget extra time in case anything 
happens.

The only thing I would do different is I would take the CRAP list (very
stupid move on my part) and a copy of Excellence and Pano.  They both 
have advertisements from companies throughout the US.  Even if those
companies can't directly help you, they can point you in the right
direction for the region of the country that they are in.

>Have any Porschephiles successfully driven a car from the left coast back 
>to the East? If so, let me know what it cost: gas, motel, tolls, etc, etc..

This all depends on how you go and how you drive.  Are you going to
make any unnecessary stops along the way (ie. tourism to stops)?
The more you decide to do besides drive, the longer it will take
you and the more money it will cost you.  Figure you can stay for
$30-40 a night at decent low priced motels such as Super 8, etc.
You can cover 500-600 miles on a decent day.  You should be able to 
make 25 mpg on the highway fairly easily.  You'll also spend $15-20
a day on fast food/pizza/etc type places.

I haven't driven from one coast to the other since I live in the middle,
but I have driven several long trips in my Porsche.  If you do decide to 
do the cross-country tour let me know.  I'd be interested to know how it
goes.

Ross Stites
'87 951

for a few years because it is very inexpensive and I don't
drive my car on the street often.

American Insurance Group to American Modern
Home Insurance Group in Ohio. I am on the extremely
limited CLASSIC plan (<2500 miles per year, must be garaged, 
can't be left parked in public parking for shopping trips, can't be
driven to work, etc etc).

The cost was $177 per year for an agreed value of $17,500.
Now it will be $291 per year, with the only benefit an increase
in mileage to 3,000 miles (big deal - I put about 250 miles on 
my car in each of the last 3 years).

Did anyone else see this huge increase? I am thinking of adding
the 911 to my normal GEICO policy, but don't want them to
get worried about me driving a "performance car" so I'll probably
just pay the extra and keep this insurance.

Anyone else find a good classic insurance that will insure
a '72 911S (not yet 25 years old). I tried some that advertise
in Hemmings a few years back but none would take me.

Subject:      Best P.car Insurance

because I'm on USAA(my Dad was in the military and works for them still,
me & my Mom still get the benifits) and they seem to have the best rates.
Anyway, my question is for my roommate, the one who wants to buy a 944/24/
28.  He doesn't know where to start looking for insurance quotes and he
can't do one of the special Porsche insurances because he doesn't own a
house, garage, etc. that they require.  So, can anyone give a top three
list of the cheapest/good service insurance companies?  The only prejudice
that I have is against GEICO, for they distribute radar guns to police
stations that can't afford them, allowing them(GEICO) to raise premiums
on their customers who get trapped by these guns.  But, if people have
found GEICO to be fair and cheap, I guess I will pass the info on to my
roommate and let him decide for himself...  Thanks for any help!

Sean  '80 928  Washington, DC

Porschephiles #1511                         Tue Jun 27 20:58:31 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 15:10:37 -0600 (MDT)
From: "Byron D. Short / AFS Inc." <bshort@usa.net>
Subject: Re: Rev Limiters, fuel and autocross

Scott Winders opines...

> Being smooth is not nearly as important on an autox course as it is on a
> big track. Considering you have so little time to learn (i.e. so few runs)
> the correct line, it is imperative to be aggressive and to find your cars
> limits on the course. Obviously it is important to find the right line, but
> you cannot afford the time to go slow while doing it.

Very well put and very true...when taken in the context of a beginner, 
however, teach line first.  Speed will take care of itself.  If the 
beginner is a VERY timid driver you may be better teaching 
aggressiveness, but when dealing with the testasterone set...

> >Be careful here.  It's a very popular thing to drive larger arcs (a la
> >roadracing) in autocross events.  Keep in mind however that physics
> >dictate that you will be slower _through the turn_ when you increase the
> >size of the arc.  The benefit is that you have a higher exit speed for
> >the next straight.  This works great in road racing, but in autocrosses,
> >there usually is not enough straight after a turn to matter.  I'd
> >encourage you to drive the largest radius you can that has you finishing
> >on the inside edge of the turn (late apexing) but (almost) never add
> >distance just for the sake of increasing exit speed in an autocross.
> 
> Physics dictates that you will be slower through the turn when you increase
> the size of the arc ONLY if you maintain the same speed. Just because you
> are on an autox course does not change the fact that the fastest way through
> a turn is not the shortest way. 99% of the time a corner in an autocross
> should be late apexed. 

I disagree.  Here's the physics.  Speed^2 / radius = GForce.  If I'm on a
100 foot radius going 40 mph I'm pulling 1.07 G.  Let's say you are
running parallel to me on a 200 foot radius (to use simple numbers). 
You'll need to go twice as fast as me to complete the same arc in the same
amount of time.  The only problem with that is that to do so you'll need
to pull 2.14 G's!  If I have my car at the limit, you can't keep up on a
larger arc unless you somehow are capable of pulling higher G's as your
speed increases--you didn't mention that your 911 carries a wing the size
of a 747, so I'm guessing you can't pull 2+ G's.  ;-)

Scott's opinion is the popular one, mine is the minority.  But Sir Isaac 
doesn't care whether you agree with him or not, he's still going to apply 
the law to you equally.  And G's being equal, you'll never be faster IN THE 
TURN by traveling a larger arc.

> Increased exit speed is EXACTLY what you are looking for. 

True in roadracing, usually not in autocross.  Now comes the tricky part. 
How do you balance exit speed, which DOES go up when you run the bigger
arc, against corner time which is better with a smaller arc.  On a typical
autocross with say 150 feet of acceleration after a turn before you have
to lift (and brake) for the next one, how much faster would you have to be
at exit to overcome the time lost on the bigger arc?  If you're
interested, Scott, I'd be glad to do the math.  Only problem is, it'll
probably bore the heck out of the rest of the list, AND it might convince
you to drive my line!  And the last thing I want to do is give you the
tools you need to beat me when we meet on the autocross course! ;-)

 -- 
[]  []  []      []                []              []       Byron D. Short
  []  []   []        []                        []       bshort@AFSinc.com
[]  []  []     []             []                           (719) 531-9511
  []  []   []       []                 []                     1990 944 S2
[]  []  []    []   A thousand thank-you's to my competitor's instructors!
