Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 16:48:59 -0500 (CDT)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: The Weekend From Hell part II

Well I heard back from the dealership this afternoon.  They say
it is the air flow meter.  The diagnosis labor, part price, and
labor totals to $750 - Ouch!  I was told that there are no new
air flow meters in the US.  I assume this means in the dealership
network.  But, they did find a rebuilt one at another dealer.
The part had been ordered, but never opened.  The sevice manager
told me that this isn't a real common failure, but that he has
seen a couple of these.  I'd be very interested to hear of 
anyone else experience with failed air flow meters.

Ross Stites
'87 951 (very sick)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 95 14:49:21 PDT
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re: The Weekend from Hell

>> >As you all may know, I'm considering buying a 85.5 944 located in 
>> >Mountain View, CA and driving it back to New York City.
>> >
>> >When I read Ross's story it scared the cr*p out of me. I'm 19, looking 
>> >for my first Porsche, and considering driving it cross-country.
>> >
>> >My worst nightmare is it breaking down in nowheresville without a 
>> >competent mechanic to work on it. Remember this is my first Porsche, so I 
>> >sure as heck wouldn't know what to do!
>> >
>> >Am I crazy, should I have it trucked (if I end up buying it). That should 
>> >run $800-$1000 right?

Well, I've done the cross country trip in my 914 and in my 944.  The
first trip was in the 914.  We left the Monterey Parade and drove to
PA. for a 50th anniversery, then drove home after that.  No a/c, in a
black 914.  I do the driving, and my wife navigates.  Long days, but
not that bad.  We had a problem with bad fuel, but got answers/help
from a shop that Tweeks told us to call (we were outside Indy.) and
some other problems from driving a 18 year old car cross country, but
nothing that stopped us.

The next year, we picked up the 944 for the Boston Parade, and drove
to Boston by way of visiting FL. and then drove home by way of Mt.
Rushmore.  Over 10,000 miles that trip.  The only problem we had was a
sticking idle stabilizer - which we drove through Denver and had
checked out at the dealer (it was fine to drive home, just might not
idle well sometimes).  Otherwise, it was a fantastic trip!  

Like Ross said, do the belts and oil and any other work done before
you leave CA.  Then, take the CRAP list, the Pano (March issue, I
think) and Excellence, and any numbers you might need.  Plan on stops
just to move your legs around (I've seen 600+ mile range on my 944).
The 944 is a great car for long trips.  

For keeping costs down, we usually camp.  A tent, sleeping bag and a
small cooler do the job.  This keeps the costs down.  For gas, if you
keep to "normal" days, about a tank a day is reasonable.  For speeds,
after getting East of NV., I keep the speeds down so I don't have to
budget a lot for tickets.  And for food, remeber you won't eat as much
because a) you get less activity while driving, and b) you will love
driving your Porsche so much you won't want to stop.

Like Ross said, take the extra time and make the trip!

Pat
pat@ixi.saic.com

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 16:56:27 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 shift knob Question

>The end of the shift lever is just a smooth chromed tube -
>I believe it is stock.  Looking inside the shift knob, I see what
>looks like a ribbed metal sleeve deep inside.

        That's it.  The sleeve is just a ribbed piece of sheetmetal
that's bent around into a cylinder shape.  You can probably pull it
out of the knob with a paperclip or some such.  Then wrap it around
the top of the lever, maybe sticking partway off, and push the knob
down onto it.  Twisting may also help.  I had no problem with mine.

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 15:05:11 -0700
From: wilson@ns.net (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Subject: Rev Limiters in auto-x 944

>Don't worry about using the rev limiter, that's why it's there. It is usually
>faster to "ride the limiter" for a second than to upshift and then downshift
>for the next corner. But if the "straight run" was at the end of the course
>with no later downshift needed, then you SHOULD upshift if you can hold
>the higher gear for a second or so to get a higher finishing speed.

Thought I'd add my 2 cents to the good advice already given on this thread.

Sometimes, depending on the car and engine torque-curve, it is beneficial
to shift rather than run on or near the redline. I always thought my former
914-4 2L went faster when I short-shifted from second (maybe 500-1000 rpm
early) to third if the length of the straight would give me two or more
seconds of running time in third. I thought the engine pumped out more
torque (and speed) running at lower rpms in third than at redline in
second.

Plus, it gives you lots of opportunities to practice your heel-and-toe
downshifting/trail-braking manoeuver.

I have no idea about 944 engine characteristics at an autocross, however.

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 95 15:22:02 -0700
From: keith_watson@MENTORG.COM (Keith Watson)
Subject: Re: introducing Nate's Ballistic Machine Shop and Garage

On Jun 27, 14:03, Nathan J. Nagel wrote:
>     Take one fiberglass 550 Spyder replica.  Reinforce chassis.  Install
> full 911 suspension and big brakes.  Add 3.6 Turbo motor.  Tune if
> desired.  Make some flares and add big wheels and tires.  Go really
> fast.  Smile a lot.
>
>     Other than the fact that a 550 would definitely require some sorts
> of aerodynamic add-ons (some kind of chin spoiler, rear underbody air
> channels, plus some side intakes to keep the motor cool...) can anyone
> see why this couldn't be done?

I was just thinking along those lines last night as I was reading
the Autoweek article on the 550.  The 550A was about 1200 lbs,
150hp and did 150mph!  A 3.6 turbo might be way scary.  A 3.2
would be less expensive and less scary. ;-)  You would need to
figure out if any front and rear spoilers are needed to keep the
car on the ground.  I thought about how often I would be able to
drive such a car up here in Oregon and decided a hard top would
need to be developed so I could drive it in the rain (or not get
my head ripped off above 150mph).  The suspension and chassis would
need to be strengthened because we would want to use race rubber
and big brakes. :-)

Sounds like fun!

Keith Watson

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 17:43:20 -0500 (CDT)
From: Menelaos Karamichalis <mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu>
Subject: Thanks: Re: Rev Limiters, fuel and auto-x

I wanted to thank the following people for taking the time to respond to 
my question:
Dave Darling    <darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov>
Mike Piera      <AnalogMike@aol.com>
Sean P. Simmen  <SS8299A@american.edu>
Brian?? Short   <bshort@usa.net> (I hope I got the first name right) 
Scott Winders   <winders@apple.com>

A lot of good points were made.  These included:
a) I may be faster to shift up if there is time rather than bump the rev 
limiter.  Given that the power/torque curves go down past a certain 
engine speed, it may be advantageous to go up a gear and may actually finish 
faster.
b) Taking a curve wide is not necessarily better than finding the "line" 
which takes you through the curve with the highest exit speed.  In my 
original post, the curve I was revering to was an approximately constant 
radius curve (slightly straight in the middle), so there is probably a 
better line than to simply take the curve wide.

Nobody mentioned a case of fuel starvation for the 944.  I know from 
talking to other autocrossers last weekend that some cars to starve for 
fuel when running with less than half full a tank and if you have a turbo in 
such a car it _really_ hurts.  So it is a matter to play with for the 944 
as its balance is not affected that greatly by variations in fuel weight.
 
Thank you very much gentlemen!  I will try to apply these next time I am 
out in the course.

'85 Burgundy Ice Mazda 626LX	
'87 Guard's Red Porsche 944S				mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu
'93 Red-White Miyata Five-12	http://wuerlim.wustl.edu/users/mnk/mnk.html

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 19:30:33 -0500
From: mac3d@superlink.net (Ed Dougherty)
Subject: Field Guide

A 911-driving friend sent me this. I think p-philes will get a kick out of it...
- ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

                        A Field Guide to Cars
                          and their Drivers

When you're driving, you know that there are some cars you just don't want
to be behind. Here is a list of them, ranked from least to most offensive.

Ferraris being driven by anyone over the age of 80.
These drivers have always wanted a Ferrari and now that they are going to
die soon, they've got one. Unfortunately, the spirit is willing but the
flesh is weak. They don't have the leg strength to push in the clutch,
so must drive around in 1st. Fortunately, this still amounts to 60 MPH.

Corvettes driven by middle-aged men.
Something of a mystery. Why buy a sports car, even if it's only a 'vette,
if you won't exceed the speed limit?

Volvos.
Volvo drivers are not actively obnoxious, but it's real hard to get something
with a power-to-weight ratio approaching 0 to move.

Dodge Omnis with large, turbocharged engines.
These drivers don't quite see how 'weight transfer' and 'front wheel drive'
are related. When the light changes they briskly apply all 500 HP, burning
the rubber off the front tires within 15 feet, thereby blocking the
intersection.

Plymouth Reliants.
These are only driven by people with a mental age exceeding 70. They know
that somewhere in the Bible it says 'Thou Shalt Not Exceed 40 MPH.'
Most annoyingly, they also remember something about 'Be Thy Brother's Keeper'
and so will do anything possible to keep you from passing them. Fortunately,
this isn't much, unless you are driving a Volvo.

Subarus.
Subarus are owned only by radical eco-freaks who are convinced that the
gas pedal is a plot hatched by the oil companies and the military-industrial
complex and thus refuse to use it. Many go so far as to have it removed.
Knowing that truth and justice is on their side, they feel no guilt in
taking 5 minutes to accelerate to 30 MPH and will scream obscenities
and make rude gestures when passed.

Similarly, there are some cars you definitely want to stay behind.

Toyota pickups.
These are owned by only by yuppie cowboys who don't realize that no
real cowboy would own a Jap truck. Secretly embarrassed by all of their
friends that can afford BMWs, they try to drive like they owned a
Bimmer, too. You can usually find these vehicles firmly attached to telephone
poles.

Japanese 'sports cars'.
These silly people actually believe the advertising that they see on TV,
and think that the Japanese have a long history of fine sports car development.
These people also think that since their car is so wonderful, they must be
too. You will frequently see these cars applied as thin films to the
rear of Toyota pickups, or caught in the grilles of semis.

Porsches.
Well, you sure as hell won't be able to get in front of them.

- ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

 -ed
87 951, Guards red
89 Doberman, Dobe red

"The freedom of speech may be taken away, and dumb and silent we may be led,
like sheep to the slaughter."
 - George Washington



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 19:55:11 -0400
From: Phyl346@aol.com
Subject: 944 Tensioning Gauge Instructions

Greetings All,

Would some kind soul(s) share the secrets of using the tensioning tool?  My
budget allowed me to purchase the gauge but I'm going to have to wait a bit
before I get the manuals.  

Seems to me that you pull the pin out to allow the slider to drop, insert the
calibration bar, snap the slider back in place and adjust the dial indicator
 (via the outer ring) to read *zero*.   Pull the pin, remove the calibrator,
and you're ready for business.

1) Does the tell-tale needle on the indicator serve any special purpose?

2) Is this the setting that you then tension both belts to? in other words,
tension the belts until the gauge reads zero? 

3) For the cam belt, does the roller contact the *smooth* or *toothed* side
of the belt? 

4) For both belts is there any *wrong* location to place the gauge? or is any
location with enough room to accomodate the gauge acceptable?

TIA for all responses

BTW, if anyone is interested in renting this gauge please email me.


Phil Carr
Austin, Tx
'83 944
'65 M.G. Midget
'70 BMW R60/5

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 17:32:09 -0700 (PDT)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: Field Guide

To cars you don't want to be behind, I'd add:

Anyone whose head doesn't show above the seat back.

Anyone wearing a straw hat.

Any car full of heads of large, gray hair.

Any older car, particularly a large, older car, retrofitted with a
third brake light.

Any car with a license frame that reads "Happiness is Being a
Grandparent."

Any camper, particularly with the bumper sticker "We're Spending Our
Children's Inheritance."

As for cars I don't want to be behind me, there are times when I'd
like to have a bumper sticker reading, "Watch Out--I Drive Like You Do."

I post this in hesitation--could start an epidemic.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 16:14:01 -0700
From: kkan@Direct.CA
Subject: Re: Washing Car (&wax)


>
>What about high pressure water?

Not recommended. My lowly 1100 psi pressure washer was powerful enough
to cut the skin on the back of my thumb. Also, I believe Karcher (pressure
washer
maker) warns against using it on the tires.

Ken '86 944


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 16:33:12 -0700
From: kkan@Direct.CA
Subject: Washing Car (&wax)

>        Whenever I wash my car, I always notice lots of tiny scratch-like
>marks left afterwards. I figure it's the dirt which is scraping against the
>paint when I scrub it with my wash mitt. Is there any way this can be
>avoided? 

This seems to work for me:

 - Thoroughly hose down the car first, preferably using a garden spray
  gun at it's highest pressure (do not use high pressure washer!) This
  is critical to remove as much dirt as possible without touching the paint.
 
 - Make sure the soap water is really sudsy. Wash the car from top to bottom,
 ie. windshield, roof, hood, fenders, lower body. If necessary, use a different
 sponge/mitt for the cleaner top part than for the lower body. Wipe in straight
 lines (not swirls) in the direction from front to rear (or vice versa).
This way
 any scratches inevitably created will be harder to see. May sure the sponge/
 mitt is always loaded full of water.
 
 - When drying the car (with cotton towels/diapers), I tend to blot rather than
  wipe.
 
For removing swirl marks and fine scratches, I use Meguiar's #9 Swirl Remover.
For waxing, I use Meguiar's #26 Yellow paste wax. I'd recommend using the
#9 once and #26 thereafter.
 
Ken '86 944 Crystal Metallic Green


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 17:52:45 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Rev Limiters, fuel and autocross

>> >Be careful here.  It's a very popular thing to drive larger arcs (a la
>> >roadracing) in autocross events.  Keep in mind however that physics
>> >dictate that you will be slower _through the turn_ when you increase the
>> >size of the arc.  The benefit is that you have a higher exit speed for
>> >the next straight.  This works great in road racing, but in autocrosses,
>> >there usually is not enough straight after a turn to matter.  I'd
>> >encourage you to drive the largest radius you can that has you finishing
>> >on the inside edge of the turn (late apexing) but (almost) never add
>> >distance just for the sake of increasing exit speed in an autocross.
>>
>> Physics dictates that you will be slower through the turn when you increase
>> the size of the arc ONLY if you maintain the same speed. Just because you
>> are on an autox course does not change the fact that the fastest way through
>> a turn is not the shortest way. 99% of the time a corner in an autocross
>> should be late apexed.
>
>I disagree.  Here's the physics.  Speed^2 / radius = GForce.  If I'm on a
>100 foot radius going 40 mph I'm pulling 1.07 G.  Let's say you are
>running parallel to me on a 200 foot radius (to use simple numbers).
>You'll need to go twice as fast as me to complete the same arc in the same
>amount of time.  The only problem with that is that to do so you'll need
>to pull 2.14 G's!  If I have my car at the limit, you can't keep up on a
>larger arc unless you somehow are capable of pulling higher G's as your
>speed increases--you didn't mention that your 911 carries a wing the size
>of a 747, so I'm guessing you can't pull 2+ G's.  ;-)
>
>Scott's opinion is the popular one, mine is the minority.  But Sir Isaac
>doesn't care whether you agree with him or not, he's still going to apply
>the law to you equally.  And G's being equal, you'll never be faster IN THE
>TURN by traveling a larger arc.

Byron, you are making an assumption in your calculations that just is not
true. You are assuming we are traveling in constant radius to get around
that corner. If that is how you are driving the corners (in a constant
radius) then you are not the faster car!! I try to spend as little time
as possible turning the car. A late apex is the best way to do this and
maintain momentum.

Obviously you must hit the apex of the turn fairly closely or you are
wasting valuable space and time.

My opinion is not only the popular one, it is the fastest one as well. I
have proven it to my self on the autox course and all the truly fast
autocrossers I know do this as well. I really can't stand it when people
misapply physics to a problem and do not take into account the variables.

>> Increased exit speed is EXACTLY what you are looking for.
>
>True in roadracing, usually not in autocross.  Now comes the tricky part.
>How do you balance exit speed, which DOES go up when you run the bigger
>arc, against corner time which is better with a smaller arc.  On a typical
>autocross with say 150 feet of acceleration after a turn before you have
>to lift (and brake) for the next one, how much faster would you have to be
>at exit to overcome the time lost on the bigger arc?  If you're
>interested, Scott, I'd be glad to do the math.  Only problem is, it'll
>probably bore the heck out of the rest of the list, AND it might convince
>you to drive my line!  And the last thing I want to do is give you the
>tools you need to beat me when we meet on the autocross course! ;-)

Like I said before, we are not going around the corner in a constant radius
arc. So please tell me how you are going to to do the math. Plus, you have
no way to calculate entrance and exit speeds or the varying g forces
applied.
There is no way for you to calculate this without full telemetry and many
runs to gather data. I have empirical data (faster times) to back up my
claims.

Please, by all means come out to the Bay Area so we can see these "minority"
techniques. It would really be fun to see how you do compared to us folks
in the incorrect majority. Like I said before, I have not seen a 944 (any
version) in the top ten since I started autocrossing. I really would like to
see it happen!!

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 21:34:52 -0400
From: TC911@aol.com
Subject: re: Problem with 5th gear.

Date: Mon, 26 Jun 1995 08:43:02 -0400
>From: rouse@jazzy.bellcore.com (Darryl Rouse)
Subject: Problem with 5th Gear

Folks,

I am having what I think is a problem with 5th gear on my '85 911.
Whenever I try to go to 5th, the stick seems to get stuck on the
way into 5th. Then if I push harder, it seems to "click" past
something and then smoothly completes going into 5th. I don't have
a problem with any of the other gears. It seems to happen at any speed.
It gets stuck just past neutral, then the rest of the throw is OK.

Could this be a clutch problem? A transmission problem?

Any ideas would be appreciated?

Thanks,
Darryl
'85 911 Turbo-Look

Darryl,
Your shifter has a lockout device that prevents you from reaching reverse
once 4 th gear has been selected. To reach 5th gear you go through this
device on the right side of the pivot point and it moves out of the way. If
the lever is too far to the right it stops the shift lever from coming
anyfurther back. This device is spring loaded and somethiong may have
happened to it or your shifter may just need to be reset. I would pull the
console and rubber boot off and have a look at the locout system befor
getting too radical with anything else.

Tom Cadwalader 
85 911 Carrera
TC 911@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 21:47:25 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Tensioning Gauge Instructions

>Greetings All,
>
>Would some kind soul(s) share the secrets of using the tensioning tool?  My
>budget allowed me to purchase the gauge but I'm going to have to wait a bit
>before I get the manuals.  
>
Get the manuals...they are easily as valuable as the tools specified in them...
If you can't afford paper, get the fiche.  

>Seems to me that you pull the pin out to allow the slider to drop, insert the
>calibration bar, snap the slider back in place and adjust the dial indicator
> (via the outer ring) to read *zero*.   Pull the pin, remove the calibrator,
>and you're ready for business.

Completely wrong:

The correct sequence:

1) using the calibration gage, adjust the tension tool so that the gage's 
tension reads 4.0 plus/minus
0.0 and with no tension, the too reads 0.0 plus/minus 0.0.  For the sake of this
demonstration, assume that your new (undropped, undamaged) tool is 
in calibration...

2) Hand crank the engine forward to TDC (#1 Cylinder). Now, reverse the 
engine about 1 and a
half teeth of the camshaft sprocket. This will put all of the tension on the 
lower side of the timing
and the balance shaft belts.


3) With the tool scale dial now set to zero, pull the pin and attempt to 
place the gauge on 
the cam belt. The roller should be on the toothed side of the belt.  Push 
the moving 
arm up and lock it in place. Rotate the tell-tail so that it is at rest 
against the dial
pointer.  Pull the pin, releasing the tension on the dial pointer.  The 
reading is now
preserved by the tell tail.


>
>1) Does the tell-tale needle on the indicator serve any special purpose?

Yes, see above...
>
>2) Is this the setting that you then tension both belts to? in other words,
>tension the belts until the gauge reads zero? 
>

No, see above.


>3) For the cam belt, does the roller contact the *smooth* or *toothed* side
>of the belt? 

Toothed, see above.

>
>4) For both belts is there any *wrong* location to place the gauge? or is any
>location with enough room to accomodate the gauge acceptable?

The proper location is on the side of the crankshaft that has no tension.  
See above.


Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net
Purveyors of Used 944 Parts and Services to "Her Majesty"
Orders: 800-all-p944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
83 944, 87 944S (SOLD!), 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 80 GMC Pickup

Rob,
Zerex Extreme in the Silver bottle is phosphate free; has a label on the
front of the bottle that says so.  Bought some today at AutoZone for about
$4.79 a gallon. Normal Zerex in the white bottle contains phosphates.

If it doen't say it is phosphate free, trust me, it isn't!

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 19:41:16 -0700
From: wilson@ns.net (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: Rev Limiters, fuel and autocross

>> >Be careful here.  It's a very popular thing to drive larger arcs (a la
>> >roadracing) in autocross events.  Keep in mind however that physics
>> >dictate that you will be slower _through the turn_ when you increase the
>> >size of the arc.  The benefit is that you have a higher exit speed for
>> >the next straight.  This works great in road racing, but in autocrosses,
>> >there usually is not enough straight after a turn to matter.  I'd
>> >encourage you to drive the largest radius you can that has you finishing
>> >on the inside edge of the turn (late apexing) but (almost) never add
>> >distance just for the sake of increasing exit speed in an autocross.
>>
>> Physics dictates that you will be slower through the turn when you increase
>> the size of the arc ONLY if you maintain the same speed. Just because you
>> are on an autox course does not change the fact that the fastest way through
>> a turn is not the shortest way. 99% of the time a corner in an autocross
>> should be late apexed.

And then, Byron D. Short opines. . .

>I disagree.  Here's the physics.  Speed^2 / radius = GForce.  If I'm on a
>100 foot radius going 40 mph I'm pulling 1.07 G.  Let's say you are
>running parallel to me on a 200 foot radius (to use simple numbers).
>You'll need to go twice as fast as me to complete the same arc in the same
>amount of time.  The only problem with that is that to do so you'll need
>to pull 2.14 G's!  If I have my car at the limit, you can't keep up on a
>larger arc unless you somehow are capable of pulling higher G's as your
>speed increases--you didn't mention that your 911 carries a wing the size
>of a 747, so I'm guessing you can't pull 2+ G's.  ;-)
>
>Scott's opinion is the popular one, mine is the minority.  But Sir Isaac
>doesn't care whether you agree with him or not, he's still going to apply
>the law to you equally.  And G's being equal, you'll never be faster IN THE
>TURN by traveling a larger arc.

Ah, but Sir Isaac never met Richard Petty. In his day, did you ever see Sir
Richard take the high line and run aroud the rim? Did you ever wonder why?

>> Increased exit speed is EXACTLY what you are looking for.
>
>True in roadracing, usually not in autocross.

Do you want increased exit speed? Always. Anywhere, including an autocross.

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 20:24:59 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Craig B. Grivette" <sac62235@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: Re: Flood Damage Sale

I haven't any experience with flood damage damaged 911s, but on salvage 
papers in general:

They shouldn't actually be "salvaged" since it is really tough to "total" 
a 60K Porsche.  So, if they are able to be fixed and you intend to sell 
them--you won't have to list them with salvage papers--though for 
integrity sake, I recommend you notify the buyers of the damage and of 
the superior repair job you did.

best of luck.  Sounds like a great opportunity.

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 20:43:33 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Washing Car (&wax)

I wrote

>> Ouch! Don't use a wash mitt. Use a horse-hair brush (_very soft, long
>> bristles_) and apply it lightly on a very wet car with a swirling action.
>
and Dave Watters asked

>What about high pressure water?

"High pressure" is a relative term -- coin-op washers probably can't hurt
your car's body (from a pressure standpoint), but the kind you might use to
clean a sidewalk or take serious grime of an old engine can definitely mess
up your bodywork and tear the skin off your body. Regardless, they're not
really suited for cleaning cars - they don't deliver enough water, and the
pressure will not dislodge a lot of things that might adhere to your paint.
You can spray at mud thrown up by the rear wheels all day and it won't go
away, but a quick stroke with a brush will probably dislodge all of it.

The bottom line is you needs lots and lots of water with a sudsing agent,
and it needn't (shouldn't?) be steaming hot.  This avalanche of water,
coupled with a very light mechanical means of cleaning the surface (e.g.
the horsehair brush) is a safe and effective means of getting the dirt and
grime off your car.   For tough stains (e.g.  road tar) I use Goo-Gone with
great success.

HTH,

 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  |
|        standard disclaimers apply         | 
|___________________________________________|         


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 20:43:49 -0700
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: The Weekend from Hell

Doug wrote:

>Just to add to the confusion, I just diagnosed a similar problem on my 535.
>turns out the fuel pressure regulator went bad. The pressure reading was
>off scale. same symptoms: loss of idle, won't start without right foot
>intervention, was intermittent at first.

This happens to my 530i every once in a while (twice so far).  The fix was
super-easy -- pinch the return hose to watch the pressure go sky high (just
a second or so), then let go ... after that, everything returns to normal. 
 I think the regulator gets slightly "cocked" (i.e. not sealed) internally
and the valve inside doesn't seat correctly.  Raising it off its seat (via
the pinching) and letting it return solves it every time.

 ___________________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman, Ph.D.   aek@netcom.com  |
|        standard disclaimers apply         | 
|___________________________________________|

though ...

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 22:05:51 -0600 (MDT)
From: "Byron D. Short / AFS Inc." <bshort@usa.net>
Subject: Re: Rev Limiters, fuel and autocross

Scott Winders continues...

> Byron, you are making an assumption in your calculations that just is not
> true. You are assuming we are traveling in constant radius to get around
> that corner. If that is how you are driving the corners (in a constant
> radius) then you are not the faster car!! I try to spend as little time
> as possible turning the car. A late apex is the best way to do this and
> maintain momentum.

Scott, you continues to miss the point.  Smaller arcs are absolutely,
positively 100% faster than larger arcs 100% of the time when traversing a
set angle, such as 180 degrees.  Or for clarity, consider a full 360
degrees.  You can go around a smaller circle in less time than it takes to
go around a larger one.  (This is a re-statement of my original thought
that you found so objectional.) That's NOT to say that smaller arcs are
always, 100% of the time, absolutely the fastest way to get around the
entire autocross course.  Absolutes like that don't work.  I concede that
late apexes are faster in some situations, but IMHO they are generally 
overused in autocrosses. 

> My opinion is not only the popular one, it is the fastest one as well.

Hmmmm.  Is that an absolute?  

> I
> have proven it to my self on the autox course and all the truly fast
> autocrossers I know do this as well. 

I'm not sure who you're speaking for exactly, but ok, I'll bite...

> I really can't stand it when people
> misapply physics to a problem and do not take into account the variables.

It's entirely possible that the laws of motion of been repealed while 
I've been whiling away the hours at my computer, I guess.  

> Like I said before, we are not going around the corner in a constant radius
> arc. So please tell me how you are going to to do the math. Plus, you have
> no way to calculate entrance and exit speeds or the varying g forces
> applied.

Trigonometry maybe?

> There is no way for you to calculate this without full telemetry and many
> runs to gather data. 

Or at least a calculator.  If it'll make you happier we can use my
G.Analyst, but it's not necessary.   

> I have empirical data (faster times) to back up my claims.

Faster than whom?  Scott, you're really starting to scare me now...

> Please, by all means come out to the Bay Area so we can see these "minority" 
> techniques. 

As a matter of fact, we (my teammates--my wife Yvonne, and Steve Compton)
studied very closely a couple of Bay Area 914 drivers who were the best in
the Nation at the time.  We were constantly amazed at their line choices,
and only numerous reviews of the tape convinced our brains of what our
eyes saw.  We began adopting their lines and I'll be darned if it didn't
work.  That year the Bay Area drivers (a husband a wife team who lurk here
often) both won National Championships, and just for good measure his
sister won as well.  The next year, using the techniques we'd learned from
these Bay area drivers, my wife took second at the Nats, while Steve and I
each won our first National Championships.  In my class I was campaigning
an 80 hp 914 1.7 against cars with as much as 140 hp, and I won with the
5th biggest winning margin in SCCA history for a class of this size.  Some
of my competitor's noticed my bizarre line in one particular turn and
tried to figure out why I was going so fast.  A stop watch showed that I
was over 1/2 second faster in that ONE TURN.  I led on that course by only
about .3 seconds, so without that edge, I would not have led that day
(though I still would have won--I had a great first day...)

Currently I'm spending entirely too much time screwing around with a
program which takes my downloaded information from my G.Analyst and turns
it into course maps.  Along the way I'm doing more Trig than anybody
should ever have to, and I'm studying what works and what doesn't work
behind the wheel.  I'm thrilled that you're happy with your driving style. 
I'm not happy with mine, and I'm continually pushing myself to learn
better ways.  My work behind the wheel and in the office makes me fairly
confident of what I'm saying, but hey, that's not to say it's 100% correct
100% of the time! 

> It would really be fun to see how you do compared to us folks 
> in the incorrect majority. Like I said before, I have not seen a 944 (any 
> version) in the top ten since I started autocrossing. I really would like to 
> see it happen!! 

Well, I'd be glad to oblige you...

In the interest of keeping the conversation light, let me just say I'd be
glad to meet you halfway (I'm in Colorado)--how about the Wendover UT Pro
Solo later in July?  If your car fits the stock category in SCCA you're
supposed to be just slightly faster than me.  Forget that, I'll run you
even up.  If you're beyond stock class, no worries, we'll apply the
published NCF factors after properly classing your car.  I'm easy!  And of
course, in the interest of fairness, I should be willing to pay for your
trip, once you've enlightened me of course.  So how about this...loser
pays the winner's costs.  You just let me know what you'd like included,
gas, hotel, entry fee.  I'm open.  Just let me know. 

Are we on?

Pilltender, I'd like some of those lovely yellow ones, and bring my friend 
here some more of whatever he's having!

like electrics anyway. Also, when my headlights are on, they always stay
on "bright".

up. Any help??? I'm getting tired of pulling the battery out to charge it
every time I drive the car!!  I carry 2 batteries(one for reserve), and

pull the alternator out to check it. I've got too much other work to do on

Date: Tue, 27 Jun 95 21:47:46 PST
From: "Don Schmidek" <dis@metricom.com>
Subject: Leland West -- Insurance - 1991 911 C-2

     Some more about insurance.  
     
     Some time back, upon reading in the Digest about insurance, I noted 
     the one message from M.Willis, about the Leland-West insurance.
     
     At that time I was in the market for a ~91 911 C-2 Targa.  After 
     purchasing the car, I contacted my old insurance - Nationwide - with 
     which I had my 912E insured with (for ~ $340 per year).  
     
     I obtained a quote from Nationwide - about $850/year - which is about 
     $300 above the Leland-West quote ($580). Naturally with Leland I am 
     limited to 2500 miles per year, $1000 deductible, but that is about 
     all I plan to drive.
     
     
     If anyone finds a better deal, pass the info along.
     
     Regards
     Don
     DIS@Metricom.com

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 10:24:19 +0200
From: Kevin.Holden@met.fr (Kevin Holden)
Subject: Re: introducing Nate's Ballistic Machine Shop and Garage

> Date: Tue, 27 Jun 95 15:22:02 -0700
> From: keith_watson@MENTORG.COM (Keith Watson)
> Subject: Re: introducing Nate's Ballistic Machine Shop and Garage
> 
> On Jun 27, 14:03, Nathan J. Nagel wrote:
> >     Take one fiberglass 550 Spyder replica.  Reinforce chassis.  Install
> > full 911 suspension and big brakes.  Add 3.6 Turbo motor.  Tune if
> > desired.  Make some flares and add big wheels and tires.  Go really
> > fast.  Smile a lot.

> would be less expensive and less scary. ;-)

with an inadequate chassis, inadequate/poorly balanced brakes etc etc yet
you can't import a 959 into the US legally...

..do I really need to ask stupid questions :-)

Kevin.

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 09:41:51 +0100
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: Porsche Sightings - Advert.


Lee C. Jacobs writes:

<ad. for Japanese car featuring a Porsche snipped>

This reminds me of the ad for some kind of Volvo family
barge running in the UK Sundays.

The scenario is this picture of a Volvo streaking ahead
of a rather nice Ferrari, with banner headline saying
"Volvo beats Ferrari and Porsche" or words to that effect.

The text of the ad goes on to say that this particular
Volvo out accelerates both a Porsche 911 and a Ferrari 512
*in top gear between 50 and 70 MPH*. Bwhahahahahahaha...

I really can't imagine the scenario where any respectable
Porsche or Ferrari driver would ever accelerate between
50 and 70 MPH in *top* gear, what an absurd idea. I know
in my 911, the rather excellent howl of the flat six,
the roaring induction noise, and the general eyeball squashing
acceleration and horizon rushing towards effect you are at their
most delightful in third. If you are in a hurry you might
want to use second.

Cheers

Ben





------------------------------

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 06:34:17 -0400
From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Tensioning Gauge Instructions

>George,
>
>Many thanks for the info.  I do have a few more questions just to make sure I
>fully understand:
>
>1) I seem to remember that the tensioning exercise is to be done with the
>engine cold.  True?
>

Yes.

>2) As far as the calibration goes, the gauge should read zero in the free
>state and 4 with the calibration bar in place?  If not exactly 4 , how
>exactly does one go about adjusting the gauge? Is it with the two screws to
>the right of the dial face?
>

You should see a small hole at the top of the tool. I believe that a 1.5 mm
allen wrench will make the adjustment. It may also be a tiny flathead screw.

>3) Once in calibration, is the correct tension setting 2 (which  seems
>logical to me as it puts the correct setting in the center of the calibration
>range)?  Is this the same for both belts?  If not what is?

The correct tension setting for a new timing belt is 4.0 plus/minus 0.3.
For a previously used timing belt 2.7 plus/minus 0.3.
For a balance shaft belt 2.7 plus/minus 0.3.

>
>4) What is the stated tolerance for the setting?

As above

>
>5) After rotating the engine forward and backward as you directed, is it
>correct to locate the gauge between the cam sprocket and the small idler
>opposite the water pump for the cam belt.  And for the balance shaft belt
>between the upper sprocket and the large idler?  These seem to be the most
>reasonably accessible locations to me.

Yes, those are the best locations.

>
>Thanks again, I really appreciate the benefit of your experience.
>
>
>
Good Luck!

George Beuselinck, 944 Ecology, georgeb@mhv.net
Purveyors of Used 944 Parts and Services to "Her Majesty"
Orders: 800-all-p944  Advice/Info: 914-658-9593
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
83 944, 87 944S (SOLD!), 86 Audi 5000 Wagon, 80 GMC Pickup

From: georgeb@mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Flood Damage Sale

The only thing worse than flood cars are fire cars.

Flood cars will drive you nuts for years with electrical problems.

Unless you are buying them for scrap metal, be aware of 
what you're getting into...

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 95 08:55:37 EDT
From: scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com (Scott Humphreys)
Subject: Re: The Weekend from Hell


Somebody wrote:

>> >As you all may know, I'm considering buying a 85.5 944 located in 
>> >Mountain View, CA and driving it back to New York City.
>> >
>> >When I read Ross's story it scared the cr*p out of me. I'm 19, looking 
>> >for my first Porsche, and considering driving it cross-country.
>> >
>> >My worst nightmare is it breaking down in nowheresville without a 
>> >competent mechanic to work on it. Remember this is my first Porsche, so I 
>> >sure as heck wouldn't know what to do!

Pat Norris writes:

>The 944 is a great car for long trips.

Amen.  The car is great on the highway, and a blast when 
you break off onto the twisty mountain roads. 
It's easy to tell the car was designed and built by
dedicated and talented people.

>Like Ross said, do the belts and oil and any other work done before
>you leave CA. 

Be very careful with a used 944.  There is a very wide
range of cars out there from "cherry" to "ragged out."
The suggestion to always have a Porsche checked out by
a Porsche mechanic is a VERY good one.  I didn't and
probably paid $1,000 more than I should have.

I bought the best 87 944 I could find (in south Florida)
two years ago.  The car was owned by three different
German engineers with Siemens (they sold it to each other
when they each left the US).  The paint is flawless and it has all
maintenance records.  The clutch had been replaced at 20K mi.
It had one known problem:  the front seals were leaking.  It turned 
out that the water pump, oil cooler seals, and the front seals were 
all having problems, and the repair bills were alot more than you 
might expect due to the amount of labor these replacements involve.
The maintenance costs can be very high unless you do the work yourself, 
and that can take some time - 944's aren't the most easily serviced 
cars.

That said, I applaud anyone's decision to purchase a 944.
They are GREAT cars.  And being on Porschephiles means you're
ahead already.  The cars aren't that expensive to maintain
if you do your own work.

Read the 944 FAQ (at ftp.tta.com, or through the WWW page).
Good luck with the car.

 -Scott

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 07:08:57 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re: Experience with Short Shifter kits in 911 ?

Boy you are a braver man than I, I look at the cash invested in that engine and 
wouldn't dream of brazing up my own lines....hopefully it will all work well for 
you!!

On the short shift stuff, there have been a couple of articles in Panorama 
(which ended up in Upfix'ins) on the various kits. I have installed the Porsche 
short shift kit, complete with new housing and all....really good stuff. THe 
throws and effort are acceptable and much better, the quality was as usual very 
good and it all fit well.

Not trying to be too much of an advert for the folks from Stuttgart, but I 
really think their stuff works best in almost all cases....I'd highly recommend 
it.

Only concern I have is that the shift quality is still not great, not yet at a 
par with my Nissan pick up......(very much tongue in cheek...)

Dennis Kalma

'75 911S with Kremer 3.2

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 09:41:12 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: 944 ball joint: observed!

I'm in the process of swapping out the suspension, replacing it with the
bilstein turbo cup (group A) set up. I've now started on the struts. the
new shock is not an insert, and has a shaft which is 40 mm in diameter.
Meanwhile, at the bottom, the control arm is attached to a 30 mm (tubular,
man) Andial sway bar. What is connecting all this up you ask? There is a
ball joint buried in the control arm, which has a shaft going into the hub
carrier. It can't be more than about 1/2 " in diameter. >YUK!<

I am amazed that with all the development in the 944 series, what looks
like the original rabbit part is still there. Are these the same folks who
changed the door skins with every model designation change?

Are any of the "updated" control arms using a larger diameter ball
joint/shaft? Do I HAVE to change them out for driving schools (mostly the
glen)? I don't see any obvious damage (I'm working on the right side).
Would secondary creep be observable from the surface?

What about weight? Are the steel arms a LOT heavier than the Aluminum ones?
The front end is now carrying 255/40-17 tires on HRE rims, AND 12.75"
coleman rotors with the red (C2-turbo/RSR) calipers. I'd like to keep the
unsprung weight to a minimum.


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951 (Red Calipers, 255/40, 275/40-17s, turbo-cup suspension in process)
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
94 child
Groucho the cat (meow)

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 95 8:44:54 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; water damaged 911s and titles


> P-filers,
> 
>> Does anyone have any experience with flooded cars ? I am offered two 1995
>> 911s that went through the New Orleans flood. Both cars had water inside 
>> but just covering the floor board. One's red with black leather and has  
>> 500 miles - offered for "low thirties". The other a cabriolet with 1,000
>> miles. I have no further info and haven't gotten an opportunity to inspect.
>> George (Beuselinck), did you ever salvage any ?
>> Suggestions & opinions welcome !
> 
>> Bart (AllPorsche@aol.com)


>I haven't any experience with flood damage damaged 911s, but on salvage
>papers in general:
>They shouldn't actually be "salvaged" since it is really tough to "total"
>a 60K Porsche.  So, if they are able to be fixed and you intend to sell
>them--you won't have to list them with salvage papers--though for
>integrity sake, I recommend you notify the buyers of the damage and of
>the superior repair job you did.


     Bart, in Texas a water-damaged car (totaled by the insurance company)
 will print "Water Damaged" on the title. It may be the only stain you
 can't remove from the car. We've had a bunch of water damaged cars, they
 are the best totals you'll ever get.

      Luckily when it floods, it floods water and not some noxious chemical...
 If the car was running or hot when or it ingested water, you may have a
 real problem. If the car stalled out and then water rose above it (usually
 what happens) or just sat while they got wet I wouldn't blink twice about the
 car.

      Virtually every flood-damaged car returns to the road. You'll spend
  forever cleaning it and spraying WD-40 in the electricals, but gauge your
  repair expenses by what obvious cosmetic problems you have and add a change
  of all fluids. Make sure the motor turns (even if it won't start).

      Also, a buyer of a '95 Porsche expects a new car. You'll have to
  seriously discount the sale. Don't even imagine not telling the buyer
  as you'll get sued and end up giving the car away for free (anybody buying
  a car for $50k has money and friends for lawyers...).

           -Lee A.


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 11:01:26 -0300
From: rosvall@itchy.mi.net (Peter & Julie Rosvall)
Subject: Re: 73 911 alt/elec problem

>Still having trouble with my alternator??? My light is dim ALL the time.
>The light does not glow bright when ignition turned on- - -nor does it go
>out when car is started. It just sits there and dimmly shines. As the bat
>starts loosing it's juice, the light seems to grow brighter!! The other
>evening I was out on my nightly beat-in cruise, as I turned back onto the
>highway I turned on my lights and the engine died!! I turned them off and
>it came back to life. I think this was caused by the low battery, right?
>
>I,ve cleaned all the ground connections(5),cables, and fuse holders. I
>keep blowing the #1 in the 2nd box and can't figure out why. I'm don't
>like electrics anyway. Also, when my headlights are on, they always stay
>on "bright".    
>
>I don't know if I've just got a bad alt, or the whole wiring is screwed
>up. Any help??? I'm getting tired of pulling the battery out to charge it
>every time I drive the car!!  I carry 2 batteries(one for reserve), and
>change them as necessary. I'd like to get as many miles as I can before I
>pull the alternator out to check it. I've got too much other work to do on
>the car to let it sit!
>If anyone can help me with this , it will really be appreciated.
>
>                                           Thanks,
>
>                               Paul Zwerner
>              zwerner@rosevc.rose-hulman.edu

Paul,

I don't know if this will help but I recently had a similar problem with my
'68 911L. My alt light was always on just ever so dim. The alt light would
only get brighter as the load on the alt was greater ie. fan, lights,
wipers. I had my motor and trans out of the car this winter so everything
was disconnected and then reconnected.

I'll do my best to explain how my problem was fixed in layman terms (the
only terms that I know....) there are a group of wirs that come from the
alt. There should be one big one that goes directly to the ground, there
should be another group of wires thgat go to a plug which plugs to the
regulator. The last wire, a red with white stripe, goes to a "block" under
the coil and screws in. On this block there are two spots where wires can be
screwed in. In my situation the wire was bolted to the wrong screw on the
block and has worked ever since.....

I don't know if this made any sense or not it just that I was so happy to
have the problem corrected without the expense of a rebuilt alt that I
thought I would forward this info on......

Peter

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 09:15:32 -0500
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Re: Experience with Short Shifter kits in 911 ?

>
>Now I'm considering to install a short shifter kit in the same car.
>
>The only one that I know of is the Weltmeister kit listed in the
>Automotion catalog. In the catalog it says 'This is the only kit that
>comes ready to install without welding or epoxying!'.
>
>Has anyone on the list any experience of installing this
>kit? Is it as easy as it seems?
>
>Are there any other kits on the market that might be better?

 I used a factory short shift kit on a 73.5 we had for a bit. Instalation
was not a big deal. I did read somewhere about the actual reduction in
throw with all the kits available. If I remember correctly the OEM kit
was the best to use with the most reduction in throw (not to mention being
correct!). I also recall taking part of the assembly to a machine shop for
pressing. The job took about 3 hrs and the owner is more than satisfied with
the work. Oh yea... I do remember having to get a couple of shims to make the
shifter center properly. My recomemdation is to go with the OEM where available.


Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1966 911 cpe

>     Some more about insurance.  
>     
>     Some time back, upon reading in the Digest about insurance, I noted 
>     the one message from M.Willis, about the Leland-West insurance.
>     
>     At that time I was in the market for a ~91 911 C-2 Targa.  After 
>     purchasing the car, I contacted my old insurance - Nationwide - with 
>     which I had my 912E insured with (for ~ $340 per year).  
>     
>     I obtained a quote from Nationwide - about $850/year - which is about 
>     $300 above the Leland-West quote ($580). Naturally with Leland I am 
>     limited to 2500 miles per year, $1000 deductible, but that is about 
>     all I plan to drive.
>     
>     
>     If anyone finds a better deal, pass the info along.
>     
>     Regards
>     Don
>     DIS@Metricom.com
>
>
Leland-west also offers a not so limited policy with a 5000 mile cap. This
is the policy that is on my carrera. The 914 is on the 2500 miles policy.
Both run $450 annual total. But, I have not got my August renewal yet and
with the change in insurance cos by leland I may go back to Nationwide.

mike

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 07:57:33 -0700
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Mike Willis)
Subject: Re: Conversion to '76 GT/934

The parts to convert mine came from AIR in So calif. They adv in all the
porsche mags.

I bought the car already done so do not know the price. Do not use
fiberglass for the fender stay with steel and find a good body shop that has
done this before. Mine from nose has had an inch +/- sectioned out of it
that way don't keep hitting drivways and curbs.

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 95 09:28:44 PDT

Johan,
I have installed the weltmeister kit in my 912. It was a straight forward
bolt in installation. I didn't buy it from Automotion and saved a few bucks.
It seems to work well as I have had no problems with it since the install. 
The one thing I don't like about it is that it is a bit shorter in height
than the original, i.e. it's alittle further away from you. Got used to that
fast though. 
Sean
69 912
Zero & Maddog: 8 Legs of Terror!

------------------------------

Date: 28 Jun 1995 09:49:02 U
From: "Soren LaForce" <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: None

Byron writes:

>Scott Winders opines...
>

snip

>
>I disagree.  Here's the physics.  Speed^2 / radius = GForce.  If I'm on a
>100 foot radius going 40 mph I'm pulling 1.07 G.  Let's say you are
>running parallel to me on a 200 foot radius (to use simple numbers). 
>You'll need to go twice as fast as me to complete the same arc in the same
>amount of time.  The only problem with that is that to do so you'll need
>to pull 2.14 G's!  If I have my car at the limit, you can't keep up on a
>larger arc unless you somehow are capable of pulling higher G's as your
>speed increases--you didn't mention that your 911 carries a wing the size
>of a 747, so I'm guessing you can't pull 2+ G's.  ;-)

While your example is correct it's irrelevant.

When you increase the arc, it's not going from a circular arc a one 
radius to a circular arc at another radius.  It's generally going 
from a geometric apex to a late apex.

>
>Scott's opinion is the popular one, mine is the minority.  But Sir Isaac 
>doesn't care whether you agree with him or not, he's still going to apply 
>the law to you equally.  And G's being equal, you'll never be faster IN THE 
>TURN by traveling a larger arc.

There are two main reasons for a late apex:  exit speed and correct 
line.

You will be fastest through the turn with a geometric apex.  I'm sure 
Scott knows this.  However, the point is not to be fastest through the
turn.  The point is to be fastest around the course.  To be fastest 
around the course *rarely* calls for a geometric apex.

Also, G's are not equal.  With a 911 they are a function of 
acceleration.

For example, 911's will sustain more lateral G when one is on the 
throttle than when one is not on the throttle.  Thus, a 911 driver
has to choose a line that allows him (or her) to stay on the throttle
during the turn, particularly during the exit.  This generally dictates
a late apex.

By the way, if your opinion is the minority *and* your are not fastest 
in class, that's natures way of telling you something...

>> Increased exit speed is EXACTLY what you are looking for. 
>
>True in roadracing, usually not in autocross.  

Also true in at least one place on most autocross courses.

>Now comes the tricky part. 
>How do you balance exit speed, which DOES go up when you run the bigger
>arc, against corner time which is better with a smaller arc.  

How do you balance the incorrect line you achieve during linked turns
if you drive a geometric apex?

You balance it turn-by-turn, course-by-course, car-by-car, and driver-
by-driver!  See the 911 specifics above if this is unclear.

>On a typical
>autocross with say 150 feet of acceleration after a turn before you have
>to lift (and brake) for the next one, how much faster would you have to be
>at exit to overcome the time lost on the bigger arc?  If you're
>interested, Scott, I'd be glad to do the math.  

You can't do the math; it's specific to the course driven and that's 
*never* circular sections, constant speed, and constant sustainable G.

>Only problem is, it'll
>probably bore the heck out of the rest of the list, AND it might convince
>you to drive my line!  And the last thing I want to do is give you the
>tools you need to beat me when we meet on the autocross course! ;-)
>
>


- --Soren
soren_laforce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov

Porschephiles #1514                         Wed Jun 28 16:35:20 CDT 1995
Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 13:06:30 -0400
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Racing / AutoX lines

Hello All,

This is getting very interesting! Will Scott accept "The Challenge?" Will
Byran  teach us trigonometry (please no)? Who will win the Porschephiles Cup?
Will King Richard explain his technique? Stay tuned for further episodes of
"As the Wheels Turn."

Seriously, I think people are missing the point here. Everyone has valid
data, but in racing and autocrossing it is impossible to speak in absolutes.
Too much depends on the course, the day, the car, and the driver to say what
is faster ALL of the time.

All of the books I have read on competition driving (the red book, something
like "Secrets of Solo Driving" by Hank Watts, "High Performance Porsche
Driving" by Vic Elford, Bob B's book, and some other books on racing) say the
same things. You will have a higher exit speed if you drive the proper line
through a turn. They ALL also say that this may not be what you want. One
book talks about "Throw away" turns. These are turns that usually occur right
before another turn that exits onto a long straight. The "Throw Away" turn is
usually not driven in the classic "proper" line if the exit from that line
would leave you out of position to enter the next turn. 

An example of this is turn four at Lime Rock. This is the start of the Esses.
There is a quick left turn followed immediatly by a right turn that leads
onto No Name straight (the back straight). The traditional line for the left
turn (if taken only by itself) would be to stay wide before the turn, turn in
to the apex, and then track out to the right edge of the track. While this
would make you fast through the left turn, it would leave you in the
completely wrong position for the next turn, a 90 degree right onto No Name
straight. Since you will be spending much more of your time on the straight
than in the turns, having the higher speed getting onto the straight will let
you have the benefit of this higher speed for the entire length of the
straight. The REAL line for the left turn is to track in towards the apex,
and then hold the car on the left side of the track and NOT let the car drift
to the right edge. This has you in the perfect position to enter the right
turn, and go quickly down the straight.

Watt's book also describes the different lines taken due to car differences.
He uses a big block Corvette vs. a 911S as a good example. The nose heavy,
high powered, understeering Corvette needs to drive a much different line
than the lighter, less powered, oversteering 911. The Corvette is going to
have to use trail brake to get the car to turn in. The 911 has to keep the
momentum up in order to overcome the HP advantage of the Corvette.

What was my point again? Oh yeah, I remember now. Since autocross courses
appear and disappear so quicky, it is very difficult to argue over a computer
screen about the proper line. I would say that if the turn leads onto a long
straight, then late apex, etc. If the turn leads immediatly into another turn
(as MANY turns in an autox do) you are probably better off staying towards
the inside of the turn, and minimizing your time in the turn.

I'll be autocrossing july 22 and 23 with the Metro NY PCA. I'll try some
different lines, and let everyone know how it turns out.

Barry Lenoble
BLenoble@aol.com
89 944 Turbo, Alpine White

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 10:40:31 -0700
From: ehab@cisco.com (Ehab Aljandali)
Subject: Re: Experience with Short Shifter kits in 911 ?

I have a Factory short shift installed in my 84 911. It is a quality kit as
to be expected from Porsche. I opted for this one after seeing the Welt
kit. It is fairly easy to install but requires some muscle power to install
the springs. The Welt kit is much more easy to install, but I think is not
as well designed.
I personally recommend the factory kit, but you can go either way. I also
installed a Turbo knob and boot and it looks and feels very nice.
Stay away from any kit that requires YOU to weld or epoxy.


Hope this helps....

Ehab 84 911 Euro

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 18:26:44 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdbg.suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: cornering



>For example, 911's will sustain more lateral G when one is on the 
throttle than when one is not on the throttle.  Thus, a 911 driver
ha....

This doesn't equate to what I know about slip angles!!

the slip angle is a vector and if you are on the throttle, the slip angle 
is the vector of the cornering force and the acceleration

as the slip angle determines the max amount of acceleration you can 
apply, you will drift wide as you apply power and/or tend to spin the 
wheels - talking about spinning wheels, I have never been a great 
believer in brains and maths helping you get round a course quickly, its 
always the ballsiest drivers who win.

Pete

| From   : Peter Diffey         |

right above the exhaust pipe coming out of cylinder  #4.  Right now I do not 
have the heater hose connected.  Now here's my problem.  The two holes in my

exhaust pipes from cylinders #2 and #4.  I have no way to connect the two holes 
in the rear engine shield to the flapper boxes because the exhaust pipes are in

this figured out.  As usual TIA!

All the physics/differential equations in the world are just groovy, but
don't do sh*t unless you have some kind of car which you can #define these
values (or pass them in on the command line) and then go.  My car won't even 
compile :)

Fastest guy wins.  Period.  All the CPU cycles of all the CRAYS aren't going
to help you one bit.  All the pontification and verbal (literary) masturbation
are useless.  I'm sure they guys and gals that are out there wiping the track
with your face are _not_ plotting 3-d vectors and calculating their G-force
when they are shaving seconds off their time again and again!

Get yer butt out there and drive, dammit!

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 14:48:51 -0400
From: Eezibleed@aol.com
Subject: Re: EZ Bleed vs Eezibleed

EZ BLeed is a one-way valve. You still need someone to pump the brakes. My
experience with one-way valves is that they take some time to bleed the brake
system. Eezibleed is a pressure bleeder that uses air from the tire or an air
tank so you don't need an assistant. Eezibleed is great when you want to
change out the brake fluid because hte job  takes about 10 minutes. I
advertise Eezibleed in Pano so look for my ad. I have several articles about
Eezibleed from the Star, Roundel, Performance Reports, etc. and if you
contact me I'll be glad to send you a copy. There is confusion over the name.
Eezibleed is made by Gunson Ltd. in the U.K. EZ Bleed is made in the US by
Waekon (I think that's the speliing) Industires.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 12:45:24 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: 911 brake light adj question

> 
> Hey guys;
> 
> Where is the adjustment for the brake light switch. After changing my brake
> fluid and bleeding the system, the pedal now is high and the brake lights
> come on when I hard brake only not with a light touch as it used to be.
> This is concerning since I like to warn drivers behind me that I am lightly
> braking... you got the idea? Anyway, I looked at the pedal area and did not
> find the switch...soooo?
> (BTW, the brakes now feel very positive even thu I used mighty vac!! no
> flames please. I used MOTUL fluid)
> 
> Also, my throttle cable has run out of adjustment and I still can NOT get
> full throttle, only about 70%... any ideas you P-nuts out there?
> 
> TIA, Ehab
> 
> San Jose, CA, 84 911 Euro.
> 

On cars I'm familar with:  The switch is on a plate attached to the pedal
cluster.  The brake pedal pushes on a rod, the rod hits the master cylinder
plunger.  On the rod is a disk, which holds the switch off when the pedal is
not pressed.  The switch is mounted with two screws, and can be twisted
slightly to adjust.

While you're doing this, you aren't too far away from the gas pedal.  You
might want to check out all the connections in there to make sure that
everything is proper.

Gary.


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 14:36:44 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: Rev Limiters, fuel and autocross

        Oh, man!  I was honestly trying to stay out of this!

>Do you want increased exit speed? Always. Anywhere, including an autocross.

        I think I'd like to disagree.  In a 914 in particular, there are
occasions when you simply want to drive the shortest path through a corner.
I have been told this about several particular corners by some very exper-
ienced 914 pilots--including at least one national champion.  ("Dave, get
off of that 911 line!  You need to be over on the inside--it's shorter!")
        It does not happen all that often (here I disagree with Byron), but
it does happen (here I disagree with Scott and Larry).  The low power/high
stability nature of the 914 probably has something to do with why that was
the appropriate 914 line.
        Also, note that Byron has an evenly-balanced car, while Scott has
a tail-heavy car.  What is right for the one is not *necessarily* what is
right for the other.  Further, Byron mentions that the straights on the
courses he drives on are typically 250 feet.  Most of the events here in
Zone 7 (where Scott drives) tend to have longer straights.  I managed to go
about 60-65 MPH at the end of one of 'em--and a stock 914 does *NOT* do
that in 250 feet!
        I think one of the reasons for the disagreement are that Byron and
Scott are talking about different cars, different courses, and different
driving styles.  I'd *love* to see both out on the same course!  If I could
get within ten minutes of their times, I'd be doing well.    8)

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"

Subject: 911SC/Carrera specs
Content-Length: 1012

Hi,

A couple of questions regarding late 70s - early 80s 911 specs (as taken
from the 911 FAQ)...

For the '78 to '83 SCs, horsepower seems to range from a low of 180
to a high of 204 (for the '81). Can someone explain where the differences
come from? eg. is it easy to upgrade a '78 SC to '81 specs? Is there
anything (other than HP) to chose from between the SCs (eg. are any more
reliable than others, etc)?

And, for the '84 to '87 Carreras, the specs show different HP specs
for the US and 'elsewhere' - Question: does 'elsewhere' in this
context include Canada (for many vehicles, the Canadian market receives
what are essentially US market vehicles with slight mods)?

Thanks!

Ross (hoping to add a vehicle to my .sig!)

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 13:58:31 -0700
From: hairpin@ix.netcom.com (Dion Dunn )
Subject: 914 engine problems - HELP!!!

OK, here goes again. A while back I asked this question, but 
unfortunately, although good, the answers I got were not the answers I 
needed.

I have a 1972 914-4 1.7 L.  I have slightly modified the engine with a 
new mild cam, new lifters and new heavier valve springs, all from Weber. 
 I did the rebuild myself, following all specs to the 'T'.  When I turn 
the engine over without the rocker assemblies on the heads, it spins 
like it should by hand and with the starter.  When I put the assemblies 
back on, it gets very tight, almost too tight to turn by hand.  A brand 
new Bosch starter and fresh battery only turns it past 2 cyclinders and 
stops.  I am not binding the rocker springs, the valves aren't touching 
the pistons, and the timing is right on.  I even went as far as pulling 
the engine back out of the car and taking the heads back off.  I put the 
old lifters and old rocker springs back on, still tight.  Weber says the 
Cam was designed to work with the stock valve train.

The engine ran ok when I started all this.  The car is now completed, 
waiting for a beating heart!  I am so frustrated with this problem, as 
are others who have seen what I've done, that If I don't get it resolved 
soon I'm going to break down and either sell the car or buy a new engine 
(depending on what kind of mood I'm in!)  Please help, as this is my 
last resort. (Or, does anyone have a nice-used, turn-key 1.7L for sale?)

Dion
72 914

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 95 14:03:06 PDT
From: Jeff Munsey <jmunsey@hpcvicae.cv.hp.com>
Subject: Re: 914 shift knob Question

|
|Date: Tue, 27 Jun 1995 16:56:27 -0500
|From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
|Subject: Re: 914 shift knob Question
|
|>The end of the shift lever is just a smooth chromed tube -
|>I believe it is stock.  Looking inside the shift knob, I see what
|>looks like a ribbed metal sleeve deep inside.
|
|        That's it.  The sleeve is just a ribbed piece of sheetmetal
|that's bent around into a cylinder shape.  You can probably pull it
|out of the knob with a paperclip or some such.  Then wrap it around
|the top of the lever, maybe sticking partway off, and push the knob
|down onto it.  Twisting may also help.  I had no problem with mine.
|
|- --DD
|
|Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
|darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
|        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"

Mine was missing the spacer sleeve.  The fine folks at German Parts & 
Restorations were able to fix me up with a new one.  I also installed
the "no buck" short shift kit by cutting 1 1/2" off of the lever.
The shifts are nice and tight plus now there is room for my knee. 8v)

Jeff Munsey  (jmunsey@cv.hp.com)
74' 914 1.8 (916 wanna be, I guess that's a 916/4)

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 95 14:35:24 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Exit Speed


What Larry Wilson failed to tell everyone is that his exit speed is 
usually calculated from the sideways position, that is , he usually is 
driving by seeing the road ahead through the passenger window. It makes 
course and coner workers scatter when he exits.

We have it on film.

Byron, that was a good, simple explaination of how magazines arrive
at the cornering force during testing. Peter Albrecht does this on a
regular basis, perhaps he could explain a little of the process used
for slalom and lane change info. His stuff is *very* accurate.

BTW, if you want to do this test for yourself, find the levelest site
possible with a GOOD surface, asphalt only. Be sure to run BOTH 
directions on the circle. I usually use a chalker and a 100 foot cord
as a concentric tether to set the circle up. The trick is to be as 
steady on throttle as possible when running. I use a timer to ensure 
that the reading is accurate by converting elapsed time to speed then 
cornering force. Works great, doesn't lie.

Roger Kraus and I did this with my 914/6 in 1979 and discovered that 
we had broken 1G on street (P6) tires. This was one of the first 
recorded instances of that feat. We later learned that Goodyear had
done the same with a 1978 Corvette with some very radical changes.
My car was being set up for the SCCA A/S class.

Jim Pasha

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 14:38:38 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Rev Limiters, fuel and autocross

>Scott Winders continues...
>
>> Byron, you are making an assumption in your calculations that just is not
>> true. You are assuming we are traveling in constant radius to get around
>> that corner. If that is how you are driving the corners (in a constant
>> radius) then you are not the faster car!! I try to spend as little time
>> as possible turning the car. A late apex is the best way to do this and
>> maintain momentum.
>
>Scott, you continues to miss the point.  Smaller arcs are absolutely,
>positively 100% faster than larger arcs 100% of the time when traversing a
>set angle, such as 180 degrees.  Or for clarity, consider a full 360
>degrees.  You can go around a smaller circle in less time than it takes to
>go around a larger one.  (This is a re-statement of my original thought
>that you found so objectional.) That's NOT to say that smaller arcs are
>always, 100% of the time, absolutely the fastest way to get around the
>entire autocross course.  Absolutes like that don't work.  I concede that
>late apexes are faster in some situations, but IMHO they are generally
>overused in autocrosses.

Traversing a set angle of 180 degrees is not very hard considering it is a
straight line. Or did you mean a 180 degree turn?

What kind of autox courses are we talking about here? I don't see many
that have a bunch of constant radius turns greater than 90 degrees. In
fact, most turns on autocross courses I have driven on are full of 90
degree turns. Most of these turns are best taken using a late apex. It is
obvious that not all 90 degree turns can be taken with a late apex due
to the fact that you have to set yourself up to be in the right place
when exiting the turn. The "right place" will vary depending on what follows.
If it is a  straight, the "right place" is arrived at via an early apex.

When I late apex a turn, I spend very little time in an arc and a whole
bunch of time in a straight line accelerating. Draw a 90 degree corner
on a piece of paper and draw an early apex line and a late apex line.
Which line has the longer arc? Which line spends more time in a straight
line? Which line has more time on the the throttle?

>> My opinion is not only the popular one, it is the fastest one as well.
>
>Hmmmm.  Is that an absolute?
>
>> I
>> have proven it to my self on the autox course and all the truly fast
>> autocrossers I know do this as well.

Every book I have read and every truly fast autocrosser I know says that
late apexes are the way to go.

>I'm not sure who you're speaking for exactly, but ok, I'll bite...
>
>> I really can't stand it when people
>> misapply physics to a problem and do not take into account the variables.
>
>It's entirely possible that the laws of motion of been repealed while
>I've been whiling away the hours at my computer, I guess.
>
>> Like I said before, we are not going around the corner in a constant radius
>> arc. So please tell me how you are going to to do the math. Plus, you have
>> no way to calculate entrance and exit speeds or the varying g forces
>> applied.
>
>Trigonometry maybe?

How is trig going to give the entrance and exit speeds? How is trig going to
account for slip? How is trig going to account for the variable radius when
you have no way to measure it?

>> There is no way for you to calculate this without full telemetry and many
>> runs to gather data.
>
>Or at least a calculator.  If it'll make you happier we can use my
>G.Analyst, but it's not necessary.

All the G-Analyst is going to give you is g-force. What does that tell you?

>
>> I have empirical data (faster times) to back up my claims.
>
>Faster than whom?  Scott, you're really starting to scare me now...

Faster than myself, that's whom. I have tried late and early apexing many
times and have found that 95% of the time, the late apex is much faster. I
am not saying I am faster or slower than anyone else. That is not relavent
to this discussion anyway.

>
>> Please, by all means come out to the Bay Area so we can see these "minority"
>> techniques.
>
>As a matter of fact, we (my teammates--my wife Yvonne, and Steve Compton)
>studied very closely a couple of Bay Area 914 drivers who were the best in
>the Nation at the time.  We were constantly amazed at their line choices,
>and only numerous reviews of the tape convinced our brains of what our
>eyes saw.  We began adopting their lines and I'll be darned if it didn't
>work.  That year the Bay Area drivers (a husband a wife team who lurk here
>often) both won National Championships, and just for good measure his
>sister won as well.  The next year, using the techniques we'd learned from
>these Bay area drivers, my wife took second at the Nats, while Steve and I
>each won our first National Championships.  In my class I was campaigning
>an 80 hp 914 1.7 against cars with as much as 140 hp, and I won with the
>5th biggest winning margin in SCCA history for a class of this size.  Some
>of my competitor's noticed my bizarre line in one particular turn and
>tried to figure out why I was going so fast.  A stop watch showed that I
>was over 1/2 second faster in that ONE TURN.  I led on that course by only
>about .3 seconds, so without that edge, I would not have led that day
>(though I still would have won--I had a great first day...)

Please describe this turn in detail. Over "1/2 second faster" in one turn
is significant. Don't tell us the line you took though....

>Currently I'm spending entirely too much time screwing around with a
>program which takes my downloaded information from my G.Analyst and turns
>it into course maps.  Along the way I'm doing more Trig than anybody
>should ever have to, and I'm studying what works and what doesn't work
>behind the wheel.  I'm thrilled that you're happy with your driving style.
>I'm not happy with mine, and I'm continually pushing myself to learn
>better ways.  My work behind the wheel and in the office makes me fairly
>confident of what I'm saying, but hey, that's not to say it's 100% correct
>100% of the time!

No, I am not happy with my current skill level. I am constantly trying
new things and taking instruction from the fastest drivers (914 and 911)
that I can find. These "people" include Henry Watts, Tom Provasi, and Galen
Bieker. I let these people drive my car so I can see what they do with it.
This is where I learn the most.

It is quite possible that the 911 is so different than a 914 or 944 that
we are both right. Hell, maybe the 914 and the 944 need completely different
lines all the time or part of the time. I am certainly coming from a 911
perspective on this.

>> It would really be fun to see how you do compared to us folks
>> in the incorrect majority. Like I said before, I have not seen a 944 (any
>> version) in the top ten since I started autocrossing. I really would like to
>> see it happen!!
>
>Well, I'd be glad to oblige you...
>
>In the interest of keeping the conversation light, let me just say I'd be
>glad to meet you halfway (I'm in Colorado)--how about the Wendover UT Pro
>Solo later in July?  If your car fits the stock category in SCCA you're
>supposed to be just slightly faster than me.  Forget that, I'll run you

>pays the winner's costs.  You just let me know what you'd like included,
>gas, hotel, entry fee.  I'm open.  Just let me know.
>
>Are we on?

I am not challenging you to anything. I would love to see your techniques
in action though. It would certainly be a chance to see if it was faster
or not. I would be willing to have you go out with me on a course and see
how I do it and then have you tell me how to do it your way. Then we can
compare the times and see how we faired.

Date:          Wed, 28 Jun 1995 14:47:25 +0000
