Yes indeed, birls and goys, we have another useful web page:

http://ram.chem.tulane.edu:8080/f-body/trivia/trivia.html

The guys with the backwards baseball hats driving Camaros have their own 
list and website, and they've put up a page of gearhead info.  Some of 
this stuff is of interest only to a Firebird owner, but much of it is 
applicable to all:

+ A Roadrider article on oil additive (Snake Oil!)

+ The Gasoline FAQ -- what's in yer gas, and why

+ Articles on synthetic lubes

+ What's in Octane Boost

+ Your O2 sensor, and how to test it.

Give it a shot.  I learned a good deal from some of this stuff.

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 15:29:52 -0800
From: gwilensky@gryphonsw.com (Gabriel Wilensky)
Subject: Experience with Short Shifter kits in 911 ?

Johan, I installed the Quick Shift part sold by Perfomance Products in my
'77 911S. It's the kind you epoxy, but that's not a problem at all (the
original shifter is also glued with epoxy, and in my car lasted for 17
years without problem). The installation is easy (but you need some tools
and a torch) and the result is great. It has to be among the best things
you can do to your car for $60!


Gabriel

Date: 28 Jun 1995 16:48:27 U
From: "Soren LaForce" <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re-re-cornering

Pete writes:



>For example, 911's will sustain more lateral G when one is on the 
>throttle than when one is not on the throttle.  Thus, a 911 driver
>ha....

This doesn't equate to what I know about slip angles!!

the slip angle is a vector and if you are on the throttle, the slip angle 
is the vector of the cornering force and the acceleration

as the slip angle determines the max amount of acceleration you can 
apply, you will drift wide as you apply power and/or tend to spin the 
wheels - talking about spinning wheels, I have never been a great 
believer in brains and maths helping you get round a course quickly, its 
always the ballsiest drivers who win.

********************

I respond:

Actually, the slip angle is an angle, not a vector.  Angles are not 
vectors.  Ever.  Period.

The slip angle is the difference between the orientation of the 
car and its heading, e.g. slip angle is zero when car is moving 
the same direction it's pointing (going straight); it's 90 
degrees when you aren't moving and get 't-boned.'

Typically, one achieves maximum tire adhesion at a particular slip
angle (generally around 8-10 degrees) for a given normal force.

Tire adhesion may be approximated by the product of the "coefficient" 
of friction and the normal force on the tire.  The problem is that the 
"coefficient" is really a function (yes Virginia, they lied to you in 
freshman physics).

The "coefficient" of friction is determined by a number of factors 
including tire temp, slip angle, inflation, road surface, tire 
loading, and so on.

Since the adhesion is the product of the "coefficient" of friction
and normal force, increasing normal force generally increases the 
adhesion of a given tire; the friction circle increases in diameter.

When you are accelerating, the car experiences a weight shift from 
front axle to rear axle.  In other words if you are on the throttle, 
the normal force on the rear tires increases and the adhesion of the
rear tires increase at the expense of front tire adhesion.

If a car tends to oversteer (can you say 911?), you generally want to 
transfer weight to the rear wheels during the exit of a turn.

As far as brains getting you around a course, let's just say that if 
you don't understand what the car is doing and why, you generally 
wind up sacrificing chickens (or spare 'vette drivers) to the tire 
gods when you make changes in your setup.

Stupid ballsy drivers go sideways nicely, but they aren't very fast.



- --Soren
soren_laforce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov

p.s.  
I consider the above generally correct, but it's definitely the Reader's
Digest version.  Critique it as such.

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 18:12:01 -0600 (MDT)
From: "Byron D. Short / AFS Inc." <bshort@usa.net>
Subject: Re: Rev Limiters, fuel and autocross

Lot's of interesting and thoughtful feedback on this thread.  Here's my 
favorite snippets:

Larry Wilson asks (I paraphrase here and elsewhere for brevity) if Isaac
Newton applies his laws to all equally, what kind of a deal did he strike
with King Richard (Petty) that allows him to run those NASCAR races on the
high line, passing folks like crazy?  Simple.  The bank increases in slope
as you approach the top.  This allows you to pull more G's.  (Technically,
the car is still pulling the same amount, but the banking imparts an
opposite g force which counteracts a portion of the g's produced by the
car, but let's not get too technical.) Anyway, if the banking at the top
is sufficiently steeper enough (what sentence structure!) to compensate
for the required increase in speed, the car could be faster in the top
groove. 

Barry Lenobe summarizes the place of exit speed very nicely.  Remember my 
original post?  It didn't deal with exit speed or fastest times for the 
full run, but rather emphasized that you will always be faster on a 
tighter arc for the duration of the turn only.  This was emphasized with 
_underlines_ once and with UPPER CASE a second time.  Still, most seem to 
go right by that point--Barry didn't.  Barry understands the trade off 
between corner time and exit speed.  Barry and I could still disagree on 
a particular corner or two, but at least we'd be considering the same 
factors.

Pete Diffey disagrees that 911's pull more g's when on the throttle.  
(I'm trying to remember who said that was true in the first place.)  
Well, Pete, put me on record with whoever it is that you're disputing.  
Everything I've ever raced shows higher g-analyst readings when you're on 
the throttle--trick is staying at that proper slip angle for long enough 
to be useful without going too far, exceedint the tire's limits, and 
slowing down.  This is even more remarkable when you consider that a 
G-Analyst will show falsely low lateral readings and falsely high 
accelerative readings as slipangle goes up.  But I digress...

Of course, Thom Fitzgerald puts it all in perspective when he says "my 
car doesn't even compile!...Get yer butt out there and drive, dammit!"  
Well put!  (Although I do think that math has a place in examining ways 
to go faster, but hey, I'm more geeky than the average software 
developer, I guess.)

And Scott Winders takes an easy kill-shot here...

> Traversing a set angle of 180 degrees is not very hard considering it is a
> straight line. Or did you mean a 180 degree turn?

ZAP!  No disputing that one.  BTW, I bet we take about the same line on 
180 degree angles...

> What kind of autox courses are we talking about here? I don't see many
> that have a bunch of constant radius turns greater than 90 degrees. In
> fact, most turns on autocross courses I have driven on are full of 90
> degree turns. Most of these turns are best taken using a late apex. It is
> obvious that not all 90 degree turns can be taken with a late apex due
> to the fact that you have to set yourself up to be in the right place
> when exiting the turn. The "right place" will vary depending on what follows.
> If it is a  straight, the "right place" is arrived at via an early apex.

Oh no.  Now we're starting to agree!  Damn, it was just getting interesting!

> When I late apex a turn, I spend very little time in an arc and a whole
> bunch of time in a straight line accelerating. Draw a 90 degree corner
> on a piece of paper and draw an early apex line and a late apex line.
> Which line has the longer arc? Which line spends more time in a straight
> line? Which line has more time on the the throttle?

Well I differ a bit, but conceptually, we're trying to do the same thing
in MANY corners.  There are times to early apex, though not as many as
there are to late apex.  Still, a nuetral apex (what I like to call the
asymmetrical line) will produce a faster time _through the corner_.  (Uh
oh, I'm doing it again.) The decision that must be reached is will that
time savings exceed the time lost down the next straight?  In autocross,
it's my opinion that the answer is YES more times than most drivers think. 

> Every book I have read and every truly fast autocrosser I know says that
> late apexes are the way to go.
                 ^
               often

I hope you don't mind, but I've just added one teensy word to your 
statement to make it more palatable to those with different experiences.

> How is trig going to give the entrance and exit speeds? How is trig going to
> account for slip? How is trig going to account for the variable radius when
> you have no way to measure it?

Actually, in our example we were trying to prove one line over another.  
In this case we can set the speed to anything we want.  The trig is used 
to plot various points along the ever changing arc.  It's real easy when 
you do it on paper.  It's tougher when you do it on the course, then you 
need some instrumentation...

> All the G-Analyst is going to give you is g-force. What does that tell you?

A run of G-Analyst data can be used to compute speed.  This speed is then 
used to calculate the radius of the arc at any instant via the G-Analyst 
lateral readings.  This arc can then be plotted using a little trig.  
Along the way, it's neato to devise a correction factor for slip angle.  
More trig.  But hey, we're boring the masses.

> Please describe this turn in detail. Over "1/2 second faster" in one turn
> is significant. Don't tell us the line you took though....

Cruddy ascii art follows:

           o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o
                
           o
                                                                    o 

           o                                o                       o
                                       o
                                   o            o                   o
           o                    o            
                             o                      o               o
  - - - - -o - - - - - - -o- - - - - - - - - - - - - o - - - - - -  o
                  ^                                         |
           o      |       o                          o      V       o

The dotted line represents a crown, you start down a slope as soon as
crossing it.  Although the slope isn't steep, the crown is abrupt and a
great number of cars lift the fronts slightly as they cross it.  The turn
is followed by one of the longest straights on the course, probably 250'. 
BTW, the venue was 1993 Solo 2 Nationals South Course.  If you find that
map, it's the corner in the opposite corner of the course from the start
line.  Through 4 days of walking the course, I NEVER saw ANYONE ELSE walk
my line.  And everyone looked at me like I was nuts when I walked mine. 
And, I have to admit, that while I think many didn't run the best line for
their cars, the extreme line I drove was probably only advisable because
of the car I was driving. 

Show me your line, I but it's the popular one.  Then I'll show you mine, 
and why it works even though I had to have given up some exit speed.  Be 
prepared for some (horrors!) math.

> I am not challenging you to anything. I would love to see your techniques
> in action though. It would certainly be a chance to see if it was faster
> or not. I would be willing to have you go out with me on a course and see
> how I do it and then have you tell me how to do it your way. Then we can
> compare the times and see how we faired.

That sounds great!  More course has been very California-light this 
year.  But if next year is more normal, I'll be in your neck of the woods 
at least once.  Let's try to get together!  And seriously, if you would 
be interested in trying a really fun event, come on out to the Wendover 
Pro Solo!  It's really a lot of fun.  Minimum 12 runs over 2 days; if you 
do well you can get up to 10 more runs in the Challenge, wherein they 
name an overall champ.  Or maybe next year the Parade will fit my 
schedule better and we could meet there!

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 20:50:58 -0400
From: DMoore356@aol.com
Subject: Re: re-re-cornering

I have made it a policy to stay out of these things but this time I cannot
resist.  Here goes.  Understanding Gs, slip angles and the like will not make
you go fast.  It might help you understand why you are slower than others.
 What will make you fast is to watch what the fast guys do and do that.  What
will make you fast is practice, train and drill and practice (seat time) and
more practice and experience.

Autocrossing and track events are not an intellectual activity.  It is a
sport that involves all the things usually associated with a sport ie
experience, training and hand /eye coordination.  If it were an intelectual
activity all the fast people would be mathmeticians and phyicists.  In my
experience that is not the case.
Thank you for your indulgence.  The end.
Denis Moore

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 95 21:19:11 EST
From: mark_salvetti@ABBSMTP.abb.com (mark salvetti)
Subject: Re: Phosphate-Free Antifreeze

          People have been recommending a Zerex product which I
          admittedly know nothing about, but I was wondering if it's
          ethylene glycol (EG) or propylene glycol (PG) based?

          There's a PG-based brand (who's name escapes me) that has
          been advertised as environmentally friendly because it isn't
          as toxic as EG.  It also has no phosphates, but
          it's heat transfer and lubricating properties are different
          than EG.  I think the Big Three have warned against the use
          of PG-based antifreeze in cars not designed for it.

          Just my $0.02.

          Mark_Salvetti@abbsmtp.abb.com
          1979 911SC Targa

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 95 17:09:49 EDT
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: Racing / AutoX lines

>All the physics/differential equations in the world are just groovy, but
>don't do sh*t unless you have some kind of car which you can #define these
>values (or pass them in on the command line) and then go.  My car won't even 
>compile :)
>
>Fastest guy wins.  Period.  All the CPU cycles of all the CRAYS aren't going
>to help you one bit.  All the pontification and verbal (literary) masturbation
>are useless.  I'm sure they guys and gals that are out there wiping the track
>with your face are _not_ plotting 3-d vectors and calculating their G-force
>when they are shaving seconds off their time again and again!
>
>Get yer butt out there and drive, dammit!

>From what I have seen there are two general classes of fast drivers. Some of
them are very intuitive. They try things until they find something which
works, and then they keep doing it. They in general don't know why their
particular technique works in a given situation, they just know it works.
In some cases they can't even describe quantitatively what they do. For 
instance, you ask them if they turn in to corner X before or after the
doohickey on the track surface, and they don't know. They just somehow
turn in at the optimum point for that corner, every time.

Other fast drivers approach the problem more analytically. They tend to
try to think through what ought to work before they start experimenting,
and they tend to be interested in understanding why a given technique works
so well after they have found the best choice by experiment. The latter type
of driver is frequently just as fast in the end as the former. Surprisingly
enough, this forum seems to have many technically oriented people in it
which approach problems the latter way. I therefore disagree with wou that
all of this discussion is worthless. If the combatants were both "armchair
racers" who had no significant actual experience, I would agree with your
comment. However, both of the primary contributors seem to be successful
autocrossers who in fact have "gotten their butts out and driven", and
I, for one, find the discussions interesting as an ex-road racer who
only very occasionally autocrosses, but who likes to understand why a
particular technique works or doesn't.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 18:44:39 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Rev Limiters, fuel and autocross

>Cruddy ascii art follows:

           o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o

           o
                                                                    o

           o                                o                       o
                                       o
                                   o            o                   o
           o                    o
                             o                      o               o
  - - - - -o - - - - - - -o- - - - - - - - - - - - - o - - - - - -  o
                  ^                                         |
           o      |       o                          o      V       o

Before I say what my line would be (I often change them based on what
happens my first time around a turn), what kind of dimensions do we have
here and how much speed am I carrying into the turn (how long is the
straight before it)?

How much much run out room do I have on the exit (how wide id the track
there)? If I have a lot, I take an earlier apex (still a late one though).

Also, you say you were about .5 seconds faster through the turn than
other people. How much did they make up on that straight? Did you time
the difference? This is an important piece of information!!

However, with the data I have now, I would probably try something like this:

           o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o
                                      ---> 1 <---
           o                               V
                                           *                        o
                                       *      *
           o                        *       o   *                   o
                                 *     o          *
                              *    o            o   *               o
           o               *    o                     *
                        *    o                      o   *           o
  - - - - -o - - - - -*- -o- - - - - - - - - - - - - o - * - - - -  o
                  ^ *                                     * |
           o      |       o                          o     *V       o
                 *                                          *
                *                                            *
               *                                              *
               *                                               *
               *                                               *
                                                               *
                                                               *

This line would require significant breaking (at point number one) to
slow down the car and to get it rotated then floor the sucker. There
appears to be plenty of runout on the turn so I could drift the car to
the edge of the track  under full acceleration from point 1 and carry
good speed down the  straight. This is an example of a turn heading
onto a long straight that you can start with a late apex and end with
early apex and still  carry speed down the straight.

You have picked a very good turn to prove your point. It is not common
to have a decreasing radius turn with so much room to the outside.

Before I am crucified, please provide the requested data.....

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

"BAD DREAM.  Brad Windle of Salt Lake City was so nervous about denting the
mint-condition black Porsche he just purchased that he refused to take it
cruising Friday and parked it in front of a friend's house.  Big mistake.

Around 2 a.m. while the group drank cocktails on the friend's deck, the heard
a loud crash.  A sailboat had drifted down the street on its trailer and
docked against the Porsche, smashing the car.

Salt Lake City police are in search of the missing sailor."

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 28 Jun 1995 23:36:29 -0400
From: DH993@aol.com
Subject: 993 Experience

You said:

<Date: Tue, 27 Jun 95 12:03:46 PDT
>From: Derek Chan <dchan@cisco.com>
Subject: 993 troublefree?

Hi,

I posted earlier a question to 993 owners about how troublefree the car is
so far. I got no response. Are all the 993s on this list perfect? I don't
believe it.

It may be hard to admit a car worth that much is far from perfect. Send me
private e-mail if you wish. 

Thanks.
Derek>

Our only troubles so far (Oct-June 95) and 4000 miles & 3 days at Lime Rock
was the air compressor & water in the passenger side front and rear footwells
under the rubberised sound-proofing. The air compressor wiring pulled out of
the cigarette lighter adapter plug on first use - dealer replaced
immediately. After several hours of searching for the source of water
intrusion at the dealership, they found that the factory had burnt thru a
hole at one of the spot welds in the rear of the passenger side wheel well
behind all the plastic enclosure stuff. Seems that at speed in the rain the
water gets thrown up and around and weeped in. If it hadn't been that the
wife was cleaning the car out from the crap accumulated at the 3 days of Lime
Rock and a piece of the rubber underlayment was turned up under the carpet we
probably never would have found it. (Pays to have a PCA national concours
judge for a wife sometimes.) The water did not smell especially fresh.
Recollection was that we drove in rain some during our use of car in Germany
when we took delivery in October, again on way back from Charleston when I
picked it up from shipment in early December as well as 2 of the 3 days at
Limerock in April. Problem was fixed by insertion of silicon sealant in hole.
Covered under warranty. Definitely going to keep record of that for future
and periodically check under mats after out in rain. Suggest everyone do this
periodically cause you won't get a clue thru the carpet cause the rubberized
coating on the soundproofing is a solid barrier to moisture escaping from
between the sheet metal and it.

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 01:10:07 -0400
From: HHeath3@aol.com
Subject: Cars not to be behind

The thread on cars not to be caught behind reminds me of the day I was
following (in my 944-- obligatory P-content) a red full-sized Ford pickup
that clearly was very low to the ground, jazzed up with pinstripes, etc.   I
was curious, thinking this was an F-150 Lightning, a pretty speedy truck, so
I pulled alongside.  The pilot had a full shock of white hair,  looked about
70, and seated beside was the frau, another head of white, hands primly
crossed in her lap.  What cracked me up as he pulled briskly away at the next
stoplight was the custom ring around the rear license plate that read: "It's
red, it's fast, and it's MINE."  Adolescent fantasies *can* last forever!

Hunter

Porschephiles #1516                         Thu Jun 29 11:56:43 CDT 1995
Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 03:15:59 -0400
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: #1(2) Porschephiles #1514...

>From your description, you have a VERY BAD MISMATCH! You apparently have a
European Fan Shroud (with open air outlet hole for the Euro heaters), but you
have the  American  style "Flapper Boxes"! The air bleed off the fan shroud
is really needed to cool the 5' of exhaust pipe inside each  Euro heater box.
The Euro heater is always "on", with  a deflector valve on the body under
ther car either sending hot air to you inside or to the  atmosphere outside,
depending on what position your heater control is in. 
    In your case, having the flapper boxes,  what  you should do is BLOCK OFF
the air bleed hole on the right hand side of the fan shroud. Cut a piece of
sheet metal to fit, and use the existing bolt holes/weld nuts to attach. If
 you really need something to block this off, let me know at (408) 727-1864,
as I have a few of them around the  Shop. A Better Solution (at least a more
visually appealing solution) would be either to replace the  Euro fan shroud
 with an American one, or convert the engine  to the Euro heater boxes. If
your  engine number is 830,000 to 836,xxx it was Originally a Euro model.
Unfortunately, to convert to Euro you need some expensive parts- like the
heater boxes, muffler, muffler supports, etc. I have them in stock in case
you want to  go that way. If you want more info, give me a call at (408)
727-1864.
KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!
The Maestro

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 07:38:34 -0400
From: JWilli911@aol.com
Subject: Re: RE: Wandering C2

I've been reading the comments about wandering C-2s and thought I'd include
my observations: I purchased a 91 C-2 turbo about 3 months ago and believe
that the car exhibits symptoms I would describe as wandering.  I have driven
the car only about 300 miles, all in town.  I have been telling myself that I
need to get the alignment checked, but at this posting, am still
procrastinating, against my better judgement, as I* know* what excessive
toe-in (or out) can do to tires.

The car has only 24k miles, and I'm embarrased to say that without going to
the garage to check, I don't know what the tires are other than that they are
Goodyears.

I will keep following the thread and also still have good intentions of
having the alignment checked, and will report the findings.

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 08:38:59 -0400 (EDT)
From: Gary Cuozzo <cuozzo@pb.com>
Subject: Hot 911SC

I have a 1980 911SC that has been running hot the last two times I have driven 
it.  The first time it happened, I was close to home and noticed that the temp 
gauge was between the top of normal and the bottom of hot.  In the past, the 
gauge has never read past the top of the normal range, except for very hot days
or during a track event.  Even then, it only went slightly past the line.  I 
pulled over and shut the car off and looked for anything that could be wrong. 
The engine runs perfectly and does not make any unusual noises.  When I started
it back up to continue home, the temp began to come back down towards the 
normal.

Today, on my way to work, the temp climbed again.  It never went past the 
halfway point on the gauge, but still made me nervous, since it was fairly cool
out this morning (60's).

Any clues as to what this might be?  Could it be a faulty sender?  Is there 
some kind of thermostat that could be sticking?  Also, how hot do other SC's 
tend to run?

Any help is appreciated.

Gary.
Red Hot '80 SC

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 09:25:59 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Driving Courses

don't know what your ride is, but the bmw club runs schools at virtually
every major track in the country, and they don't require you to drive a
bmw, the way pca requires a porsche. The prices are lower, as they aren't
in it for the money, and they get subsidized by the national club. I've
been going for 10 years, (both here and at mosport via bmwccc) and while
I'm not fast, I'm smooth, and never bent anything but the ol' ego.


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories

94 850 turbo wagon

Groucho the cat (meow)



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 09:31:07 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: re-re-cornering

I once got a ride with an instructor at the glen. Going into the turn at
the end of the back straight (before the chicane was installed), this guy
dives for the inside, and hangs there all the way around this major
sweeper. We'd been sweating the late apex, exit speeds, setting up for the
turn, balancing the car, you get the idea. This guy had a simple answer, "
if the inside was left open, someone else would try to pass me there".
THAT, boys and girls, is the difference between the driving line they teach
us (or try to), and the racing line, where it only matters that you come in
first.


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951 (Red Calipers, 255/40, 275/40-17s, turbo-cup suspension in process)
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
94 child
Groucho the cat (meow)

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 09:36:39 -0400
From: pigozzi@pilot.msu.edu (Bruce Wm. Pigozzi)
Subject: re:field guide

I take umbrage at the broad inclusion of SUBARUs as cars to stay away from.
My SVX (daily driver) is a truly civilized car for a relatively small price.
Its 3.3 ltr horizontally opposed flat six (water cooled) has a distinct
design resemblance to the 911, and sounds like recent vintage 911s  when
pushed. (The fact that it's water cooled and rumor says that the next new
911 will need to be watercooled ... maybe Porsche will imitate Subaru!
Seriously, though, one wonders why, when Porsche, Ferrari, and yes even
Subaru can squeeze so much out of such an engine that others don't follow?)
And, sure it's heavier than your SCs, RSs, my 944, and even a C4;  but it
will easily keep up on any interstate around. The SVX is only "good" through
corners, can't hold a candle to my 944 but  I wish Porsche could do a
climate control system like my SVX.
Bruce Wm. Pigozzi
Associate Professor of Geography
Michigan State University
Email:pigozzi@pilot.msu.edu
517-355-4652

Subject: wheel locks



i am searching for a source of wheel lock covers.  local dealer, 
and the aftermarket seem to be oblivious to my needs.  for some
reason i can't seem to keep them!  please let me know if they 
are available from anywhere, anyone.
i have an 87 944s with phone-dial wheels.  when i purchased the 
car not only were a couple of covers missing, the key to the 
locks were missing also.  local dealer wanted $180 to drill 
the old locks and to replace! :-<  found tri-color locksmith in 
urbana, illinois.  owner, rich, picked a lock, dismantled it and
made me 3 keys in 30 minutes for $32! ;->  i hope he doesn't 
live in my neighborhood!

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 16:16:10 -0400
From: lucat@galactica.it (Luca Cattaneo)
Subject: CARRERA C2-RS

For Everybody in the world: please help me.

Hello, I'm an Italian with this intention: I'm trying to organize a list of
all the models of Carrera C2 RS 3.6 Liters made in 1991 and 1992 in about
2200 pieces.
There is something egual for the model 911 RS of 1972 (in a grat big book),
but nothing for the 3.6 Liters.
So, from every part of the world, please write an e-mail to this address:
lucat@galactica.it  
and in the subject write:
CARRERA C2-RS
If someone will be interested in the list, contact me and every 100 models
I'll send him.

In Your reply You have to write the following things:

1) date when You saw the RS (mounth and year- if You are not the owner);
2) nation where You saw the RS (or if You are the owner, nation where the
car was for the first time matriculated;
3) kind of RS (there are: BASE, TOURING-maybe just for Japan, LIGHT-maybe no
more then 100 models with the packet M003);
4) number of chassis (just the last four numbers);
5) colour of the body(if is the original or not, and please even the number
of color);
6) color of the safety bells and the write Carrera Rs inside the back cockpit;
7) if the chassis number is also on a small plate on the left side of the
vertical rod of the windscreen;
8) if the model is right or left way;
9) the capacity of the petrol tank (77 or 92 liters);
10) other extras not included in the series RS model (like Roll-bar for
races, anti-fire or air conditioned or radio);
11) mechanical modifications: like engine increased at 3.8 Liters, or breaks
of the RSR model, or other;
12) every other interesting new about the specified model.

I'll send this request every mounth in Porschephiles mailing list until the
end of 1995. I hope that You can help me; for the moment I have the
caracteristics of about 50 cars (most in Italy).

Sorry for my non perfect english, I wait Your reply.
Many thanks.
 

Luca Cattaneo-Milano-Italy

E-MAIL: lucat@galactica.it

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 10:31:06 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Kenneth D. Grimm" <GRIMM@alison.sbc.edu>
Subject: Re: Phosphate-Free Antifreeze

Mark Salvetti wrote expressing concern that the Zerex antifreeze might
contain propylene glycol that would be bad for our beloved Porsches.
It does not contain the bad stuff.  It is based on the familiar
ethylene glycol.  The label specifically mentions that it protects
aluminum engines and is phosphate free...Zerex Extreme 4/50.
The 4/50 refers to the 4 year, 50,000 mile guarantee.

Ken
'83 944 Platin (with Zerex Extreme 4/50 in the cooling system)

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 07:22:22 -0700
From: "Jim Bauman  jbauman@btr.com" <jbauman@btr.btr.com>
Subject: Re:  Check Engine Light

I have a check engine light on my Chrysler minivan,
and have the same recurring problem. I connected
a computer to the data port, and found out that
it was tripping when the oxygen sensor in the emission
controls hit a certain peak value.  It's probably
something similar in your C2. I had the sensor replaced
once, but the problem cropped up again. I just ignore it.

Jim Bauman
'86 Carrera Cab
GETA911.

Sorry about that prior message. I have been in the middle of a large
conversation about the surging problems I have been having and thought that
was what you were talking about. should have read your whole message and
noticed the referance at the bottom. I have yet to have any good answers
back and am thinking that my original idea was correct. Either replace the
dash (if I can find a tan one available) or there are a couple of outfits in
Kelowna that do vinyl repair. The vinyl repair places do good work but your
cracks have to be fairly narrow. If they are like mine and have spred and
started to curl they cannot do a good job of fixing them. Th preccedure
takes about a day for them to get a good job out of it. The shortest I have
heard of is 6 hours so anyone that says they can do it quicker is likely as
not to do a poor job.
Ideally, the new dash is where its at but I don't have a clue as to the price.
Another option would be to have the dash redone from one side to the other.
All these options other than the fill job are a bit pricey.
the fill job will run me about 150.00 can. (about 50 cent usd ;+} ).

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 12:05:15 -0400 (EDT)
From: Doug Donsbach <dld@Symtec.com>
Subject: Re: Life Expectancy

> Can anybody out there give me an idea as to how long a reasonably cared for 944
> turbo's turbo will actually last. I would like to know if I am looking at one of
> these cars to purchase, how long I can expect to drive it before it will need to
> be replaced. Also, can somebody give me a ball park figure as to total cost to
> replace the turbo. Lastly, does anyone have an idea as to the difference in
> insurance cost of a 944 turbo, to a 944S2.
> 
There are lots of things that can and do fail on 951's but the turbo is probably
not one of the more frequent items. It would probably be a mistake to purchase an
S2 because you're worried about turbo failure. You should drive both cars and see
which one you like the most. The turbo is about 600 lbs. lighter than the S2 and
and has about 5% more HP so it should feel more agile.

Good Luck,

Doug Donsbach - dld@symtec.com - Knoxville, TN
'88 951 - '88 735i

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 09:09:10 -0700 (PDT)
From: Mujahid Mahmood <mmmahmood@ucdavis.edu>
Subject: Re:(William Cianco)Cracked vinyl

hod,
	concerning cracked cash repair, i know the cost of a new dash can 
be prohibitive and i just don't like those covers so i'm living wth my 
poor craking dash for now.  but i read in european car mag a few months 
back about a company in van nuys, ca that would basically rebuild your 
dash foam, recover it in vinyl, and dye it to the proper color.  the best 
part i thought was that they warrantied it for as long as you own the 
car.  the price for a 944 was about $500  I believe, i don't recall the 
price for the 911s.  the obvious down side is that youu have to remove 
the dash and send it to them.  i don't have the mag with me, but i 
remember the company was called Just Dashes.  if you would like any more 
info, let me know and if anyone has some experience with them, please share!

good luck    mujahid mahmood   mmmahmood@ucdavis.edu

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 95 09:24:06 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Handling/Driving Style


I've gotten a hoot outta the current thread. No issues here, but I KNOW
who I can beat just buy listening to what they say. The Reitmeier kids
use to watch all of us when we thrashed our stuff 20 years ago.

Maybe they saw something we didn't pay attention to. Larry Wong and I 
started beating Larry Wilson after we studied his Speedster and our 914 
2.0s. we were giving him a 400 pound advantage. We also weren't paying 
attention to our cars and it's features. Once we disconnected the rear 
bar and used the higher cornering speeds to our advantage, the Speedster
was history in autocrossing. Larry then bought a 914.

When I was learning to roadrace in the 60s, a friend and instructor 
gave me some good advice. If the corner is 45 degrees or less, late 
apex and drift it. If it is between 45 and 90 degrees, study the 
surface, the approaching corner and the corner following to see if 
drifting will help or hinder your exit/approach. If it's over 90 degrees,
study the corner for the smoothest way in and out, practice the corner
to get the best feel. Use the minimum brake necessary as late as 
possible, smoothly reapply the throttle.

It's wonderful that everyone talks about slip angles, etc., but the
big issue is whether you can step up and make it all work at critical
mass. Not all of us that are capable still compete. I get a kick out of 
Jeff and his wife and sister doing well. I remember that competing 
against their father was no picnic. 

On the other hand, it use to be fun watching a whole group of people 
tail Dwight Mitchell as he did his course walk. Dwight was (and still is)
one of the most articulate instructors on the sport of autocrossing.
His patience and willingness to show as he walked the course where the 
most likely line and method of driving the line has helped many novices
become excellent competitors.

Jim Pasha


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 10:59:31 -0600 (MDT)
From: "Byron D. Short / AFS Inc." <bshort@usa.net>
Subject: Re: Rev Limiters, fuel and autocross

Here's the PLAY AT HOME version of the "Pick your Line" game...  Play 
fair, and draw out your own line before looking at Scott's answer or my 
answer.  For those with nothing but time on their hands, a mathematical 
explanation follows.  The turn starts on the left, ends on the right.

> >Cruddy ascii art follows:
> 
>            o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o
> 
>            o
>                                                                     o
> 
>            o                                o                       o
>                                        o
>                                    o            o                   o
>            o                    o
>                              o                      o               o
>   - - - - -o - - - - - - -o- - - - - - - - - - - - - o - - - - - -  o
>                                                             
>            o    ENTER     o                          o     EXIT     o
> 
> Before I say what my line would be (I often change them based on what
> happens my first time around a turn), what kind of dimensions do we have
> here and how much speed am I carrying into the turn (how long is the
> straight before it)?

The entry "straight" is a series of lane change manuevers, allowing most 
street tire cars to enter around the same speed 50-55mph, regardless of 
horsepower.  The inside diameter, measured across the dotted line (which 
represents a crown line) was about 100 feet, the lanes were, say, 30 feet 
on each side, so the outside diameter is around 160 feet.

> How much much run out room do I have on the exit (how wide id the track
> there)? If I have a lot, I take an earlier apex (still a late one though).

The next element down is way down there, probably 250 feet to the next 
braking point, so you should definitely use all the track width.

> Also, you say you were about .5 seconds faster through the turn than
> other people. How much did they make up on that straight? Did you time
> the difference? This is an important piece of information!!

Absolutely right!  Nobody measured the next straight, and there's no doubt
that most everybody in the class was faster than me down that straight. 
(BTW, the folks that timed me said I was around .7 faster--remember I said
I was "more than 1/2 sec" faster.) Of course, this may have more to do
with horsepower than exit speed, in my case--remember I was in a 80 hp
914, versus 110 hp CRX's (almost as light as me) and 140 hp Sentra SE-R's
and NX-2000's, and even an older 240Z.  My point in all of this has been
(and continues to be) that I'll be faster "in the turn", and that often
(not always) my competitors with more exit speed won't be able to overcome
the deficit in the next straight...math follows for this example to
estimate that answer. 

> However, with the data I have now, I would probably try something like this:
> 
>            o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o  o
>                                  +    ---> 1 <---
>            o                  +        +   V
>                         +                  * +                      o
>                       +                *      *+
>            o       +                *       o   *+                  o
>                   +              *     o          *+
>                  +            *    o            o   *               o
>            o    +          *    o                     *
>                 +       *    o                      o  +*           o
>   - - - - -o - + - - -*- -o- - - - - - - - - - - - - o + * - - - -  o
>                +    *                                   + *  
>            o   +          o                          o    +*        o
>                + *                                         +*
>                +*                                           +*
>                *                                              *
>                *                                               *
>                *                                               *
>                                                                *

  LEGEND:  *** = Scott (and Byron--yep, the "Minority view")
           +++ = the classic late apex, the Majority view.

Scott explains his line...
 
> This line would require significant breaking (at point number one) to
> slow down the car and to get it rotated then floor the sucker. There
> appears to be plenty of runout on the turn so I could drift the car to
> the edge of the track  under full acceleration from point 1 and carry
> good speed down the  straight. This is an example of a turn heading
> onto a long straight that you can start with a late apex and end with
> early apex and still  carry speed down the straight.

Scott, Scott, Scott...what fun is this going to be if we suddenly find 
ourselves in agreement?  The classic late apex, which I thought you would 
endorse, starts with a more sweeping, wider arc.  This allows a faster 
speed at point 1, which then translates to a faster exit speed and a 
faster straight.  The trade off is that the extra distance traveled from 
the start of the turn to point 1 is about 50 feet!  

Here's some math:  The "classic" line is traveling on an arc of about a 70
foot radius, for a speed of 32 mph @ 1 g, while Scott and I are going
faster at entry, only breaking after we've pitched it over the crest. 
Scott and I are both probably counting on throwing the rear end out in
order to get back on line (and on power) quickly.  At 1, we are slower,
since we're running a tighter radius, probably something closer to 40
feet.  That means we're going about 27 mph at point 1 (all things being
equal I'm assuming we are pulling 1 g as well).  However, at that point we
join the "majority" line, and accelerate just as hard.  We remain 5 mph
slower all the way down the next straight.  My calculations show that in
the first part of the corner, from the start of the turn to point 1, we
went 86 feet at an average speed of about 35 mph, taking 1.68 seconds. 
The majority went 137 feet at 32 mph, using up 2.92 seconds.  We are (at
point 1) 1.24 seconds ahead!  However, starting from point 1 and going to
the end of the turn both lines take us about 64 feet.  The majority, use
up only 1.36 seconds.  We use up 1.61 seconds, so we lose 0.25 seconds
here.  The total is that we were about 1 second faster IN THE TURN. 

What about the straight?  Assuming equal acceleration between the two 
examples, we'll always be 5 mph slower.  At that rate, we lose 0.18 
seconds for every second of acceleration.  So how long does the straight 
have to be for us to lose all of our advantage?  About 6 seconds (for the 
majority car--that's going to be 7.08 seconds for us), or, 
assuming constant acceleration of 0.3 g's (pretty good second gear street 
car acceleration), about 484 feet!  To put this in perspective, the 
classic line guys will be going 71 mph, we'll be going 66 mph.  Remember, 
484 foot straights are easy to find in roadracing, but are not the usual 
fare in autocrosses.  In my example the braking point was 250 feet away, 
so by then we've only given up about 0.65 seconds, so we're still ahead 
by 0.34 seconds. 

Interesting that Scott went to the shortest (and tightest) line possible
in this example.  How often do we give in to peer pressure and run the
sweeping late apex (larger arc) at the event, but only because we haven't
had a chance to consider the turn at length, as we have here?  Once again,
late apexes are a wonderful thing, but apply much less in autocrossing
then roadracing.  Be careful when you add distance for the sake of a late
apex (and faster exit speed) in an autocross--it doesn't always work. 

I would offer this rule of thumb.  In roadracing (or events with straights 
over 60 mph), when in doubt, late apex.  In autocrossing (or events with 
straights below 60), when in doubt, run the shortest line possible.  In 
both cases, you should finish the turn the same, that is, use all the 
track that's available without throwing your horribly offline for the 
next line.  Scott?  How do you feel about this rule of thumb?  Seem 
pretty close to you?

- --

  []  []   []        []                        []       bshort@AFSinc.com
[]  []  []     []             []                           (719) 531-9511
  []  []   []       []                 []                     1990 944 S2
[]  []  []    []         []         New sig--equally un-appealing to all.

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 09:08:34 -0700
From: peterg@airdata.com (Peter Gregory)
Subject: Re: 912 history

> did the 912 preceed the 911, or what is the big difference

The 912 was introduced in 1965 - the same year as the 911.  The 912
was produced from 1965 to 1969.

The 912 was the "entry level" Porsche, costing about $1500 (25%) less than
a 911 of the same year.

The 912 was basically a 911 (same body, tranny, suspension, etc.), but with
a 616/36 engine from a 356SC (but with a different clutch/flywheel to mate
with the 901 transmission, and different sheet metal to mate up with the
911 engine compartment).

Hope this helps,

Peter Gregory
1969 912, polo red, blown engine, for sale
1973-1/2 911T, oxford blue
1982 tabby cat
1963 spouse
1957 body

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 02:09:00 -0700
From: hod@cns.bc.ca (Hod Pharis)
Subject: RE: 912 history



>did the 912 preceed the 911, or what is the big difference
>
>Pete

With the demise of the 356 in March 1965 there was a need to fill in the
space untill the 911 was established. Porsche took the 911 body & running
gear, but used the 356 1600cc flat four with either four or five speed tranny.
1st year 6440 were made against 4865 911's. The next year 8700 were made and
all in all when they quit making the 912 in '69 30,300 were made. It was
replaced by the 914.
It was reintroduced in 1975 for the '76 production, and sold only in the us
as a buffer if you like, until the 924 was ready. The engine this time was a
1971cc flat four vw developed by porsche, like the last of the 914/4s. 90bhp
at 4900rpm and according to my book, 2099 were made, mine is #472. 

Hod.
.

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 12:30:29 -0600
From: kalmad@cadvision.com
Subject: Re: Query on rebuilt 911 calipe

I have rebuilt my type M calipers and so far they seem to be just fine. 

Process I followed was to strip the caliper, cut some wood discs (using a hole 
saw) to fill the cylinders, seal the gap between the wood and the caliper (it 
was a tight fit), seal teh brake fluid line and then bead blast the rust off of 
them. I then painted the outside of the caliper using a Sikkens 15/50 blackwash, 
which according to them is good for high temperature and has truly awesome 
adhesion to  steel as it was designed for truck frames. From that point on it 
was straight forward, take out the wood blocks, clean, clean and clean the 
passages and cylinders just in case any dust or grit got inside, refit the 
pistons and seals and you're done. 

Mine were in quite good shape, no pits or corrosion on the inside, if I would 
have found a pit I would have turfed the caliper. The pistons had a very small 
amount of corrosion, I used a very fine emery cloth on the small spots and again 
no problems....


Dennis Kalma

'75 911 S with Kremer 3.2 and nice tidy black calipers


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 13:38:30 -0500
From: Brian Scudder <bscudder@spdmail.spd.dsccc.com>
Subject: Re: Do I have Limited Slip?

Sean asks:
>How do I tell if my '80 928 has a limited slip differential that everyone
>says is necessary for a competative car?  What does it do exactly, anyway?
>Sean

One way to tell is to rev the engine to 5000 rpm, drop the clutch, then
count the number of burnout marks: 1 = non-lsd, 2 = lsd. :^) Another way
is to jackup the rear of the car (both tires off of the ground) then
turn one of the wheels. If they turn in the same way then you have the
LSD.

The LSD "senses" the speed differential between the two rear wheels. If
the difference is too great then it applies torque to the wheel which
has the slower speed.

Basically, what a LSD gives you is higher exit speeds out of a turn. If
you nail the thottle during a turn you will spin the inside rear
wheel. The LSD will apply torque to the outside rear where all of the
weight is anyway. Maybe someone will add/clarify my explanation if this
is not clear.

Adding a LSD to a 928 is not a trivial deal. A used LSD unit for a
'78-'82 from 928 International is about $500. Plan on 9 hrs (shop time)
to R&R the transmission, 10 hrs to rebuild, 5 hrs to set up the
differential, plus parts and anything else "while you're in there" (this
is for a manual).

I've just got my tranny back from the shop and had the LSD
installed. Whenever I get some time I'll finish putting it together. I'm
having serious p-car withdrawls.

Brian Scudder
'83 928S (almost back on the road)
'70 old blue truck
'93 Redi (the cat and purring machine) 

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 13:41:02 -0600
From: esherte@sandia.gov (Eugene S. Hertel)
Subject: Just Dashes

Just Dashes
5941 Lemona Avenue
Van Nuys, Ca. 91411
(800) 247 3274
(818) 780 9005

I talked to them a few months ago about dashes for my Opel and the Porsche.
They strip the old unit and apply new foam and then shrink fit vinyl.  The match
colors by dying.  A 911 dash is ~350$.  I have heard (third hand only) that they
do excellant work.

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 15:51:56 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Do I trade my Audi for a 944

I sold my 77 audi fox in 1983 and bought a 944. Back then the hosepower
difference was a factor of two (76 vs 143)! I got tired of having the
porsche/audi dealer charge me porsche prices for an audi. I went through
several winters in Rochester NY with the 944, before I embraced the idea of
a "winter rat". I guess if you get snows on wheels you should be ok, except
for major snow on sidestreets, where the low ground clearance makes the car
into a poor snowplow. I remember crawling home late at night in the snow
and being blown off by a civic.

good luck,

doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951 (Red Calipers, 255/40, 275/40-17s, turbo-cup suspension in process)
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
94 child
Groucho the cat (meow)



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 16:04:52 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: 944 Steel A-Arms: Translation

     Doug Dykaar writes:



     >Are the steel arms a LOT heavier than the Aluminum ones?



     No. They are relatively lightweight, and you can easily swap the

     balljoint and bushings. They are from the VW Rabbit, so go to a VW

     parts department and save big bucks.



     However, I have had some TERRIBLE experiences with them. The SCCA Solo

     II stock class allows you to exchange the front swaybar. The only

     adjustable one I know of is the Weltmeister bar from Automotion. It

     mounts in the normal position on the aluminum a-arms, but you must

     drill a hole through the middle of the steel a-arms to mount it.



     Accident #1: I was autocrossing at Sacramento about 2 1/2 hrs from

     home. I was going around a 20-25 mph right corner when the a-arm

     snapped in half, right through the drilled mounting hole. Carroll

     Smith would say "stress riser". I would say SH*T.



     At the time I blamed my lack of mechanical aptitude. Since I was so

     far from home, I had the car towed to Dwight Mitchell's shop

     (Autosport Technology). $1200 and one week later, I had 2 new steel

     a-arms, a four-wheel alignment, and a crumpled left fender.



     Accident #2: About one year later, I was autocrossing at Pleasanton

     about 1/2 hour from home. I was going around a left-hand corner about

     30-40 mph when the a-arm once again breaks, right through the drilled

     mounting hole.



     Ken Mitchell (ex-GGR PCA member), bless his heart, helped me put my

     car on his trailer and towed me home.



     Now, I had matching crumpled fenders.



     If you want to go to another vendor, I understand somebody (Racefab?)

     makes competition a-arms. This month's Pano has an interesting warning

     from the factory concerning aluminum a-arms. Porsche is recommending

     the Club Sport arms for heavy competitive uses. They have a 951 part

     number instead of a 944 number.



     In the Northeast, there are a lot of stories about balljoint failures

     at speed on cars that have been lowered too much. The July 1 Driver Ed

     at Watkins Glen won't allow lowered 944s with aluminum arms to run.



Paul,
I have the 951, with the aluminum arms, AND mounting for the sway bar.
Given the warnings from alwyn springer (PCNA) in pano, I'm considering one
of the "race" arms you mentioned. His letter mentions that one of the
problems occurred on a car with stock suspension, and big sway bars. Well I
have the factory sport suspension (adjustible konis) and BIG (Tubular-30
mm) sway bars, but stock ride height.

Soooooo,

Am I in trouble? Will I go spinning down the back straight on three wheels?
No offence, but I don't want a paul foster autograph fender. I was
wondering about the various after market arms...I already have so much
beefier-than-stock stuff in there, I was hoping I could either, avoid, or
minimize the penalty of new arms.

thanks for the reply,

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 95 13:16:14 PDT
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Driving Style


- ----- Begin Included Message -----

>From bshort@usa.net Thu Jun 29 11:37:08 1995

Hi Jim--

> I've gotten a hoot outta the current thread. No issues here, but I KNOW
> who I can beat just buy listening to what they say. The Reitmeier kids
> use to watch all of us when we thrashed our stuff 20 years ago.

Did I mention the Reitmeir kids?  (I knew those in the know would know...)

> When I was learning to roadrace in the 60s, a friend and instructor 
> gave me some good advice. If the corner is 45 degrees or less, late 
> apex and drift it. If it is between 45 and 90 degrees, study the 
> surface, the approaching corner and the corner following to see if 
> drifting will help or hinder your exit/approach. If it's over 90 degrees,
> study the corner for the smoothest way in and out, practice the corner
> to get the best feel. Use the minimum brake necessary as late as 
> possible, smoothly reapply the throttle.
> 
> It's wonderful that everyone talks about slip angles, etc., but the
> big issue is whether you can step up and make it all work at critical
> mass. Not all of us that are capable still compete. I get a kick out of 
> Jeff and his wife and sister doing well. I remember that competing 
> against their father was no picnic. 

I like these generalizations, not because they're always accurate (we both
know they're not) but because they give you the basis of a PLAN.  I like
to drift the car on exit to most any turn.  Studying my and my wife's
G.Analyst traces (with the software I'm developing giving graphic
representations) we discovered that I'm always on the gas about a second
sooner than she is.  She complains that if she gets on that early, she
pushes.  The difference, we discovered, was that I drift the car early, so
that when I get back on it I'm inducing power on oversteer instead of mere
understeer.  That's a neato lesson and I hope she'll be able to apply it. 
OTOH, we examined our slaloms and found that Yvonne's more precise driving
was much faster than mine.  I like slip angle too much, and persisted in
throwing the car into the slalom, when a "carve" like Yvonne uses would
have been faster... 

> 
> On the other hand, it use to be fun watching a whole group of people 
> tail Dwight Mitchell as he did his course walk. Dwight was (and still is)
> one of the most articulate instructors on the sport of autocrossing.
> His patience and willingness to show as he walked the course where the 
> most likely line and method of driving the line has helped many novices
> become excellent competitors.

Indeed--I've spent my share of time doing course walks behind Dwight as 
well!  A very good instructor with a terrific grasp of the machanics of 
the game.

- ----- Begin 2nd Included Message -----

them?  Remember when I flamed you on the list for a post you had sent me 
privately?  I was REAL embarrassed.  Since then I've gotten better at 
replying in private when mailed in private.  Sometimes I forget to check 
the header before I hit the "Reply" key to see if I should be copying the 
list.

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 13:22:14 -0700 (PDT)
From: scokelly@netcom.com (Scott Kelly)
Subject: 911 1990 C4 Resolved studdering

Just an update...
I few weeks ago I posted a message regarding my 90 C4s problem of 
studdering, poor acceleration, lack of power.  I got a few responses and 
I have since had the problem repaired.  Wanted to bring ya' up to date.

RedNineCo suggested it could be the belt between the two distributors
and that was exactly what it was.  This was causing only one plug per 
cylinder to fire.  BTW, there were not any dash lights to indicate there 
was actually a problem.

I took the car to the local Porsche Dealer (Jim Ellis) in the hopes that 
the problem was a warranty issue.  The car has 48k miles so the emissions 
warranty (5yrs,50k miles) still applies.  And low and behold - it was 
covered.  Jim Ellis said it would be a $600 repair otherwise.  Probably 
could have been done cheaper if you just replaced the belt - but they 
replaced the whole distributor.

They also installed the vent hose to prevent this from happening.  They 
charged 1/2 hr ($29) labor and $9.14 for parts to install.

One other note - it took them 2 weeks to get the distributor in.
Car us back running great.

Thanks,
Scott
(scokelly@netcom.com)

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 17:46:08 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: 912 history

On Thu, 29 Jun 1995, Peter Diffey wrote:

> did the 912 preceed the 911, or what is the big difference
The 911 came was introduced as a '65 model. The 912 didn't come out until 
'66. Because the 911 replaced the 356 as Porsche's flagship, it left 
sales lagging due to the high cost. Porsche thought and quickly decided 
to offer a more basic version that was basically a 356 that looked like a 
911 (gauges, VW engine pumped up, metal dash) and the 912 was born. While 
it was not cheap, it was relatively affordable compared to the 911.
The Boxter is Porsche's latest rendition of this old idea. Take a low 
cost 4 cylinder engine and put it in a nice car, and voila, you have 
yourself a 'low-cost' Porsche. Porsche's 'low-end' models have been the 
912, 914/4, 912E (a different 912 'round 1976, this time using a Type IV 
(914) engine), 924, 944, 968, 986. While these are low in cost, they are 
still clearly Porsche performance cars.
Oh, the E in 912E is injection (in German injection is spelled with an e)
 -Derek
 

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 17:50:51 -0400
From: Mrbill456@aol.com
Subject: Re: shaky wheel

My 71E had wheel shakes too. Mine were not as large in amplitude as yours but
they did kick in at about the same speed.

In this case the shakes were due to front wheel bearings that were slightly
loose. When they were readjusted to their proper torque the shakes went away.

Best of luck at getting this resolved.

Bill Hutton
1971 911E Coupe

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 17:56:51 -0500

>believe it.

No car is perfect. I've mentioned this story before... At our dealership we
had a '95 911 Carrera (sorry, I'm one of those "call 'em by their name"
folks) that was a demo of some sort... We were selling it as used, it had a
little over 5,000 miles on it. So it was DAMN close to being a new car.

A customer went for a test drive, during which the car stopped going into
gear. I helped tow it back, and believe me, that shifter wasn't doing ANYTHING.

Our Porsche tech dropped the engine and tranny, took the trans apart, and
discovered a shift fork shattered into three pieces. With less that 6,000
miles on the car!

Keep this in mind, any '95 911 drivers who like driving like Don Garlits. :)

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 20:04:42 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: ?? about porsche magazines

Andrew, 

You said:

>Does anyone know of an issue of panorama or another reputable magazine,
>that has an article on how to do a 914 - 914/6 conversion?  Or how to put
>a chevy 350 in a 914?  What is the G-50 tranny?

Upfixin' der Prosche, available thru PCA national, Vol V, Page 300 has a
reprint of an article from Panorama, Nov 78, on converting a 4 to a 6.
 George Hussey of Automobile Atlanta also wrote a pamphlet on the same
subject that he seels for a few bucks.  AA is at 404-427-2844. Order Upfixin
from the PCA national office; call 703-922-9300 and they'll tell you the
price and how to order. Renegade Hybrids who I THINK advertises in Excellence
makes conversions to Chevys if you REALLY want to devalue a nice 914 to near
zero :). 

914/6 conversions will increase the value of certain, less desireable, models
of 914/4's IF DONE RIGHT. If you find a nice 2.0 914, leave it alone. If you
have a 70-72 1.7 with a bad engine or a 1.8, those would be reasonable
candidates for a conversion. Figure on $3000 for a decent used 911 engine
with Weber carbs, hopefully with a compatible flywheel and pressure plate,
(figure $450 more if without), $500 for engine sheet metal, $500 for an oil
tank, $300 for the oil lines and associated parts for the tank, $350 for the
engine oil cooler (less if you have the existing one modified), $300 for the
motor mount, $200 for necessary bits and pieces for the transaxle shift
linkage (less if you fabricate or mod some of the existing parts), $500-1000
for upgrading brakes/hubs to 911/914/6 parts, $100 to get the tach converted
to 6 cyl., $100 for a fuel pump, $500 for 5 bolt wheels to match the new
hubs, $500 for headers ($2000 if you want original heat exchangers), $300 for
a muffler, and another $300 to $500 for misc. parts.  Oh, and $100 for new
rear springs to support the added weight, and why go to all of this bother if
you don't make it handle with $500 in sway bars and $500 in shocks? You can
beat some of these prices by careful shopping at swap meets. You will NEVER
get your money back out of any conversion, and it may ultimately be cheaper
to search for a nice 6. 

If you think converting to a Chevy will be significantly cheaper, think again
about radiators, hoses, heaters, transmission beefups,brakes, mounts,
clutches, etc, etc.

G-50 tranny's were used in late model Carrera's and C2's and maybe the 993
(?).

Jon Lowe
Numerous 914's of all types past and present

never seen a C2's fenders perched so high ( 3 inches) above the tops of the

pair of shorter springs on the front to lower the nose an inch or so. Sounds
logical to me.......I'll keep you posted

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 21:06:15 -0400 (EDT)
From: Scot Alan Douglas <scootman@engin.umich.edu>
Subject: its alive...ITS ALIVE!!!

In follow up to my story of my ill running 914 1.8L;  its fixed (I hope)
I replaced the cap, rotor, wires, and coil (Bosch Blue) tonight.  
Afterwards, I took it for a test drive and was really surprised!  The 
difference in power is amazing!  The only other mod that would give this 
much of an increase would be splitfires (ack pblthht).  Seriously, the 
car runs much better than before-allthough it looked like the original 
coil and wires were on the car.  I don't know if it will still 
mysteriously cut out on me since I didn't have the chance to drive it 
very far tonight.  I guarantee I will tomorrow.  Thanks to all that 
replied to my cry for help!
Scot

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 18:48:26 -0700
From: "Wayne Michelsen" <wayne@darien.arc.nasa.gov>

I posted about 5 days ago, crying because a woman backed into me, and requesting
recommendations for "top notch" body shops in the Bay Area.  Well, the votes
are in, "..And The Survey Says..." Cecil Beech's BodyStyles.

Seriously...Thanks to everyone (about 15+ responses) who gave me
recommendations for top notch body shops in South Bay Area.  The votes came in
as follows:

6 for Cecil Beech's Bodystyles
3 for Del's Porsche Auto Body
2 for Anderson-Beihl
and single votes for: Images, A&B, Yeaman, L&M, T&D, James Brooks, and
Cavallino

I could not check out all of them, but I did go by several.  All of them did
seem to do very good work.  Of course each had his own particular opinions of
my needs.  I think I will go with Cecil Beech's Bodystyles.  I was very
impressed with the extent of his estimate and the other cars in the shop.  His
finished repairs were nearly undetectable.  "Nearly" only because the repaired
parts had no chips or scratches and fresh undercoating.

So, for my car, Cecil is planning to completely disassemble the passenger side.
 Remove the front bumper, headlight and fender to take out a slight impression
where the damage started (about 4 inches from the door), and repaint the entire
quarter off the car.  Remove the door, and all extremity pieces, to take out
the damage along its length and repaint it.  Remove the Targa glass, engine
lid, and rear bumper so he can replace the rear quarter panel with a new one.
 Then top it off with a 4 wheel align (my wheel was bumped).

As I said, the repair estimate seems very detailed.  In total, it comes to over
$6000 including 75 hours of labor.  I'm sure glad it's not my money.  And to
think...the accident happened while neither of us were travelling more than 2
mph.

I'll keep everyone posted.

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 20:27:09 -0600
From: qmoolla@gpu3.srv.ualberta.ca (Qassim Moolla)
Subject: Re: Do I trade my Audi for a 944


>	I own a 1990 Audi 90 Quattro that I am considering trading for a
>944.  The Audi is worth about $13,500 if I sell it myself and has about
>65,000 miles.  It's very comfortable, great in the snow, and has terrible
>performance (it weighs way too much for its 5 cylinders).
>
>	If I was to buy a newer 944 (say 87 and up), these questions are
>needing to be answered:

>	1)  Maintenance costs - the Audi is not cheap to maintain and only
>the dealer can do A lot of stuff on it.  How is maintenance on 944 - both
>big and small problems?  Are there any real problems to look out for (I
>would really like a turbo if you guys think it's good - great to drive!!)?

Hi Darrin,
The big problems (or normal maintenance items) are (a) clutch replacement 
about $450 parts and 9hrs labour  (b) timing/cam and balance shaft belt 
replacement with rollers about $140 parts and 4hrs labour.  You should 
consult the 944 FAQs for more info on these.  Other than that I have had no 
big expenses on my two 944s (over 5 years ownership)  My 5000 Audi turbo and 
turbo Quattro on the other hand was a heck of a lot more trouble, constant 
minor electrical problems and major ones with the steering racks, power 
steering pumps (seals always went) heater fans, leaky heater cores etc.  It 
drove me nuts - I believe Audi should have replaced their trouble light "!" 
with a "$" symbol which more accurately reflected what was in store for the 
owner when it came on.

Audi parts were another sore spot with me, $200 rubber bushings and the like 
for the quattro control arms.  You have a tremendous advantage on parts 
availability and choice of vendors/prices on the 944.  I will never buy 
another Audi for that reason.
  
>	2)  Comfort - the Audi is very comfortable - I don't need a couch, but
>would like something reasonably comfortable - I'm 6' 4" tall so I have tons
>of height to pack into any vehicle.
>
Cannot comment on comfort I am 5.11 so my musings on comfort will not help. 
 
>	3)  Snow - how is a 944 in the winter?  This car will be driven every
>day in the winter and has to get through a souther New ENgland Winter.
>
I live in Edmonton Alberta (substitute Siberia) with Jan/Feb temps 
frequently in the minus 30-35 Celcius range (minus 22-31 Fahrenheit) and 
snow/ice on the ground from Nov. to early May. The 944 with good Yoko snows 
(studded last winter) were fine.  Summer and All Season tires even with full 
tread depth are useless however.  I do have heated parking though.  Power 
steering starts complaining if you leave the car out in the cold at these 
temperatures.
    
	4)  Parts availability - It seems that there are lots of 944s on
>the road so parts shouls
>not be stupidly expensive like a 928  (true or false).

True

>	5)  How long do they last?  My Audis and Saab have always had great
>relaibility well over 100,000 miles - how about 944 (assuming PO took good
>care and changed the oil at least once every 50,000 miles or so  :)   )
>
I change oil every 3000 miles (5000kms).- I'm sure you don't really mean 
"50,000" miles-, antifreeze every year, brake fluid every second year. Both 
cars are near the 100000 mile mark and the compressions great. I expect to 
get at least another 100000 miles (touch wood).  
>
>	My budget will be 12,000 to 15,000 if I sell my Audi.  Any years
>to avoid or years to look at in that range?
>
>$15000 transalates to $21000 CDN, it will buy you an 88 944S-89 944S2 or 88 
944 turbo in my part of the world, if you negotiate hard enough.  I don't 
know what your local market is like. 
 Happy 944 hunting.
Ike Moolla
1984 944
1987 944S
qmoolla@pop.srv.ualberta.ca

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 21:59:57 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: solex carb re-bush

> i've been referred to a company in santa anna ca. called "rimco" for 
> rebushing my solex (40 p-ii) lower carb bodies. the price is right 
> ($30 ea.). turnaround quoted @ 2 days. i've heard some pretty scary
> things price-wise for the same job ($175 ea.?) from other sources.
> any feedback / experience. TIA

RIMCO has a very good rep in the VW market for doing high quality engine
machine work at a reasonable price. I have *NO IDEA* if they have the 
stuff to do this, but I'd bet that they do. And if you send them a fully
stripped carb lower body with just the shafts installed (nothing else) so that
all they have to do is pull the shafte, re-bush, and hone to fit the shaft,
they *MIGHT* be able to actually do it for $30. If you send them the whole
carb intact, don't bet on it for microsecond...

*HOWEVER* the real problem is that you also may need to have the throttle 
bores honed or rebored to a uniform size, and larger butterflies installed.
Not to mention all the twisty little passages filled with crap and corrosion.
There's much more to making a 30 year old carb run like new than just
the rebushing... I think that this is the source of the $175 each sorts
of numbers you've seen. 

Stan

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 95 21:36:16 MDT
From: hrubin@nyx10.cs.du.edu (Howard Rubin)
Subject: Experience with Short Shifter kits in 911

When I bought my 911SC a few years ago it had a Weltmeister
short shifter installed. It worked fine but was too short shifting
for my tastes. I removed it and put the stock shifter in which I
found to have very l-o-n-g throws. I finally settled on the factory
short shifter which is somewhere between the W and the stock one.
All of them are very easy to install. BTW I still have the Weltmeister
shifter which I'd sell for a substantial discount.
Howard Rubin - hrubin@nyx.cs.du.edu

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 23:54:02 -0400
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re: 912 history

Peter,
You wrote,
>did the 912 preceed the 911, or what is the big difference<

The 911 actually preceeds the 912 slightly, there were prototypes in 1963 and
production 911s in 1964, but the 912 appeared in production during 1965.
Obviously, the 912 engine(other than the 912E), being based on the 356 4 cyl
design, preceeds the 911 6 cyl design. There are differences other than the
engines, but in general the two cars are quite similar in other respects.

Phil Van Buskirk, PMLetter@aol.com
67 912, 67 911S, and now a 914 1.8L from Thom Kuby!



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 95 12:10:32 SST
From: Lawrence Leong <lawrence@hpsgsi3.sgp.hp.com>
Subject: Re: Any Experience With Defrost Repair Adhesive?

Andrew E. Kalman asked:

>The rear window defroster "tabs" on my car are no longer attached to the
>glass and are pretty bent out of shape.  I would like to fix the defroster,
>though.
>
>I remember (vaguely) once seeing a Permatex or Loctite product for
>re-bonding (directly to the glass) such tabs to the "pads" of the defrost
>wires. Does anyone have experience with this product, and what's it called,
>exactly? 

Andrew, I believe the Permetex/Loctite adhesives are insulating (correct me
if i'm wrong -- there might be something new I have not come across).  I 
used conductive epoxy, used by PCB manufacturing shops for touchup.  
Very low resistance, very high cost.  Approx $20 for a 10g tube.
If you know anyone inthe PCB business, you can scrounge a dollop for free.

Lawrence

that happen. Hope that helps, Ed

Porschephiles #1519                         Fri Jun 30 11:44:32 CDT 1995
Date: Tue, 27 Jun 95 11:13:46 
From: da@airsoft.com
Subject: Re: How tight is too tight?


Rob,

you want to be careful or else a burned wheel bearing can result.  You want 
to tighten the wheel bearing retaining nut so that you can just move the 
big flat washer under it with a screwdriver.  You can also test for a 
minute amount of play by grabbing and moving the wheel once you've bolted 
it back on.

Derek Au

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 29 Jun 95 12:01:00 ADT
From: "Southard, Keith" <KSOUTHAR@atu.com>
Subject: RE: Do I trade my Audi for a 944


Two totally different worlds. The 944 will be more fun to drive
snappier handling and acceleration. I drive mine all year
(live in Anchorage, Alaska) and generally only have a
problem after a heavy snowfall. Can't get out of my
neighborhood if we get more than 8 inches or so of snow.
Buy good winter tires. Don't try to drive the same ones
all year. You'll end up in a ditch!

I don't know about your Audi but maintenance costs for
a late 944 are not inexpensive. We're not talking' your
basic Chevy Cavilier here. These cars were expensive
when new (my 89 was $36k) and the care and upkeep
is going to be higher, particularly if you want to get
long life from the car. I spend about $1200 a year at
the dealer, do minor maintenance like oil changes
myself. Some maintenance is done more frequently
than the service book requires.

Comfort - Go sit in one. I like mine fine, but I'm only 5'8"
Forget the back seat. Kids only.

Have no trouble getting parts. If the dealer doesn't
have it in stock, they air-freight it & have it within 2
days (their cost).

Have seen lots of 944s with over 75k. Don't know any
one with one over 100. Don't seem to have any
particular problems in cars that are well maintained.

You should be able to find a good post-87 for that
kind of change.  Look for things like ABS, 16" wheels.
Make sure to check when the cam/balance shaft belts
were changed!  Very bad (read expensive) results
when these puppies break. Change it before you
start autocrossing if it hasn't been replaced and the
car has more than 30k miles. It's expensive but
cheaper than bent valves and broken pistons.

 ----------
>From: porschephiles-request
To: porschephiles

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 95 14:53:43 CET
From: "Robert Dru Martin" <rmartin@sgit.iaea.or.at>
Subject: re:Re: 911: Fram oild filter, Help!

The biggest reason is that the Fram filter sacks a pressure relief valve 
inside the filter like the OEM-styles do.  I think Fram assumes that if you 
can screw it on, it must be OK, never mind the guts of the thing.

THere have been articles in Pano and Excellence discussing this same 
topic.  Any help from the list in tracking those down?

Dru Martin
rmartin@sgit.iaea.or.at

looked at about 12  944s in the last 3 weeks.

and alloys (928 type)  /  very good interior (not perfect)  /  dealer will
replace timing belt at no charge  /  guards red  : )   /  drives  great  /
quickest of the 944s I've driven thus far.

	Asking $12,750.


	How's the price - seems reasonable to me  -  there are some minor
scratches in the paint, but that's OK since it will be a daily driver
anyway.  Keep in mind I live in Fairfield County,  Connecticut, where 
everything is slightly overpriced.
