Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 09:56:05 -0400 (EDT)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: 911: Fram oild filter, Help!

On 29 Jun 1995, Chris Bennet wrote:

>  A fellow here at work is going to get a Fram oil filter
> for his 911 and this strikes me as a Really Bad Idea.
> Could someone help me articulate why he shouldn't ?
Well, now, if he's the religous, stop by the road with the drain pan at 
exactly 3,000 miles or 3 months, it probably won't be a problem, but tell 
him to realize that in a 911 engine (you didn't say what year, so) there 
can be anywhere between 2 and 3 times as much oil as in a waterbox (9 
quarts to 13? quarts), and that the temperature of the oil is not 
significantly (it won't melt the thing down at it's post) hotter, it is 
hotter than waterboxes.

> P.S.  The fact that I lost a 944 Turbo engine to a Fram filter
>       didn't impress him. (Frambought me another car.)
Hm... I've never had this experience, but then I have no Turbos. And for 
those of you wondering, there has never been anything but Porsche 
filters in our car ('cept for the air which is K&N). I do use Fram on the 
Toyota, and have had no problems, but then, on that car, I'm the 
religious 2,999 miles or 3 months type (more or less because it is a 
leased car)
 -Derek

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 95 9:20:10 CDT
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; just dashes

Subject: Re:(William Cianco)Cracked vinyl

>    If I'm not mistaken, that company is called the "new dash group"... 
>I've never dealt with them personally but I do know that all the hot
>rod/resto guys are raving over them (because of their ability to repair
>irreplaceable stuff...)  If I remember right, their average charge was
>$150 a couple of years ago, and their work was supposed to be pretty
>good (from memory/ a Hot Rod article)
>
>later,
>
>Nate
>
       
      I think "New Dash Group" is a different company than Just Dashes.
      The prices are not cheap, and the grain of the vinyl does NOT match
      OEM. But they are attractive for;
       1. Guys who CAN NOT get a replacement dash. You can still get OEM
           for a 911 and it is the "right" look.
       2. Guys who own Porsches (!) as they guarantee the dash for life
           and a Porsche dash will last no more than 10 or 15 years.

        You can probably get New Dash Group's phone number out of a 
       Hemmings.  I haven't used either but a friend was quite pleased
       with his Trans Am re-dash. Don't get the hard-plastic coverall; 
       my experience on a 924 and 911 was -horrible-. The fabric covers
       are an improvement over a warped leather dash, IMHO they look
       okay and are much cheaper than a new dash.
                                                 
              -Lee A.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 09:20:05 -0500 (CDT)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 911: Fram oild filter, Help!

>  A fellow here at work is going to get a Fram oil filter
> for his 911 and this strikes me as a Really Bad Idea.
> Could someone help me articulate why he shouldn't ?

There is a HUGE volume of discussion of this in Pano starting from
about 1967 and going up until  oh I'd say the early '80s. Mainly
it goes like this:

CB:	"I'm a cheap bastard and can buy Fram filters for 1/2 what
	 the Mahle/Mann/German Purolator filters that Porsche sells
	 me. Fram says it'll work, so I'm gonna do it!"

VoW (Voice of Wisdom): "That's not such a bad idea. After all, oil
 	 filter are oil filters, and the factory didn't do such a
	 great job on the 356 oil filter, and Fram *IS* a name brand..."

CB (later): "Ummm. There was more to this than met the eye. Like now
	 the factory says they won't honor your engine warranty if you
	 don't use their filter. What gives? Aren't oil filters just
	 oil filters?"

VoW (somewhat chastened): "Seems we got it wrong -- the factory filter
	 *IS* much better than expected. There's a pressure relief system
	 incorporated into the filter. There's a significant amount MORE
	 filter area with different porosity. And it's rated for higher
	 internal pressures than other filters. Guess we'd better stick
	 with the factory filter."

CB: 	"But it's too expensive! I'm gonna save that $2.50 and buy the
	 Fram filter because Fram says it's OK!!!"

VoW:	"Not such a good idea. The filter area thing is probably a wash,		but that pressure relief and rated pressure for the filter assembly
	has GOT to be there for a reason... Don't do it. If you're really
	that cheap, buy a case of the OE filters from Zim's or something
	instead of buying from the dealer."

CB:	"My oil filter blew up all over the engine compartment when I started		 the car cold one morning. Anyone know why? Anyone still listening		 to me? Hello?? Hell-OOO??"

My own experience: I've blown up even the hyper-expensive Fram HP-1 racing
oil filters on more or less stock *VW Beetles* with large capacity oil
pumps. These air-cooled engines are really *OIL COOLED* and as a result
move a hellishly large volume of oil at surprisingly high pressures.

Use the factory filter.  Or the OE equivalent purchased from a reputable
source.

> P.S.  The fact that I lost a 944 Turbo engine to a Fram filter 
>       didn't impress him. (Frambought me another car.)

The fact that they bought you another car impresses ME. They usually
find some way to weasel out of that sort of thing...

Stan

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 10:28:32 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Do I trade my Audi for a 944

Darrin asks a number of questions, among them, "2)  Comfort - the Audi is
very comfortable - I don't need a couch, but would like something reasonably
comfortable - I'm 6' 4" tall so I have tons of height to pack into any
vehicle."

Before buying the 944, Darrin, borrow it for an afternoon of driving to see
just how comfortable you may (or may not) be in it.  I'm also 6'4" tall and
find the usual 944 to be too cramped for my preference (limited headroom with
the sunroof and power seats, and limited elbow room with the power windows et
al).  On the other hand, if you can find one without a sunroof and the power
features, it may very well be acceptable.  A couple of months before buying a
new 924S (which is ALL manual and acceptably comfortable), I turned down a
great deal on a friend's almost-new 944 (usual equipment) because of the
cramped cockpit.  I also owned Audis continuously between 1972 and 1990, and
am enthusiastic about them...they're certainly among the best of the road
cars (they track like an arrow, are comfortable, quiet, reliable, and have
tremendous luggage capacity), they handle very well, have reasonable
performance, and (at least here) have outstanding dealer support...but I can
relate to the comments about pricey minor parts.  However, my 1980 5000S had
195,000 miles on the odometer when I traded it, and it still had the original
clutch (and all the other major parts)!

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 10:31:45 -0400
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: 912 History

Peter says, "The 912 was introduced in 1965 - the same year as the 911.  The
912 was produced from 1965 to 1969."

The 911 was actually introduced in 1964.

And, "The 912 was the "entry level" Porsche, costing about $1500 (25%) less
than a 911 of the same year."

Interesting comment.  While I don't recall 912 prices, I do remember the
difference between my 1965 356SC and a 1965 911 was closer to $500 ($5500 vs
$6000, approximately) so I would seriously doubt a 25% difference between a
1911 and a 912, even by 1969.

Derek says, "...a more basic version that was basically a 356 that looked
like a 
911 (gauges, VW engine pumped up, metal dash) and the 912 was born."

It would be more correct to say the 912 was basically a 911 with the 356SC
engine and a few minor interior changes.  And, by 1965 the 1600SC Porsche
engine was certainly not a "pumped-up" VW engine!

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 08:47:06 -0600
From: Bdale Garbee <bdale@gag.com>
Subject: Re: Do I trade my Audi for a 944

In article <950629152638.20238742@WCSUB.CTSTATEU.EDU> you wrote:

: 	1)  Maintenance costs - the Audi is not cheap to maintain and only
: the dealer can do A lot of stuff on it.

I suspect a 944 would be in the same maintenance price league as your Audi.

: Are there any real problems to look out for (I
: would really like a turbo if you guys think it's good - great to drive!!)?

I have an 87 944S, which is the 16-valve non-turbo flavor.  I like it, haven't
driven a turbo.  On all of the 944 family, don't skimp on the suggested
maintenance intervals on the timing belt/balance shaft belt/rollers stuff on
the front end of the engine.  If you do, you could suffer valve/piston impact,
which is way expensive to deal with.  The belts are cheap, the tensioning tool
is not.  See the faq for a few other standard things to have checked before
you buy.

: 	2)  Comfort - the Audi is very comfortable - I don't need a couch, but
: would like something reasonably comfortable - I'm 6' 4" tall so I have tons
: of height to pack into any vehicle.

I'm 6' 6.5".  The 944, and the 924 it replaced, are the only vehicles I've
ever owned that I drive with the seat *not* all the way back!  It's quite
reasonable/comfortable to tilt the driver's seat back a bit and balance my
desire to be fairly verticle against headroom.  Even with the motorized roof
tilt, there's no significant reduction in headroom.

: 	3)  Snow - how is a 944 in the winter?  This car will be driven every
: day in the winter and has to get through a souther New ENgland Winter.

I haven't been through a winter with the 944 yet, but the 924 was fun in the
snow if I could get out of my driveway (sharp turn, steep hill, gotta have
4WD in winter to get out for long periods of time - I'm in Colorado).  I drove
from Colorado Springs south across Raton Pass into New Mexico in February on
packed snow and ice, knowing that once I crossed the pass heading for Tucson
I'd quickly be into weather where I'd pop the roof panel and switch to short
pants... :-)  The only heart-stoppers on that trip involved dancing with
semi's on the ice in the pass, which had nothing to do with what I was
driving!

Driving the 944S back across country from purchase in North Carolina, I spent
a solid day in near-blizzard conditions in Kansas, and other than being 
really nervous about bending my new toy, and having near-worthless tires for
snow, it wasn't bad at all.  The car has wonderful weight balance and overall
handling, so I had no trouble feeling when it started to get loose on the
snow/slush, and kept my speed "right on the edge" all day.  Actually, was
pretty fun in hindsight.  I won't be able to get it out of my driveway for
much of the winter, but if I get caught out somewhere, I won't dread getting
home in snow.  I'm sure the choice of tires plays a really big role here. 

: 	4)  Parts availability - It seems that there are lots of 944s on
: the road so parts shouls not be stupidly expensive like a 928 

Dunno.  The part's aren't cheap, but I suspect it'll be more like your Audi
and less like a 928.

: 	5)  How long do they last?  My Audis and Saab have always had great
: relaibility well over 100,000 miles - how about 944 (assuming PO took good
: care and changed the oil at least once every 50,000 miles or so  :)   )

I bought mine around 72k miles, now have about 77k, I see no reason not to get
to at least 150k with it, unless I do something really stupid.

: 	My budget will be 12,000 to 15,000 if I sell my Audi.  Any years
: to avoid or years to look at in that range?

My 87 944S was less than 10k, with fresh brake pads before driving cross-
country, and fresh belts/rollers in response to the bearings in one of the
belt sprockets squealing to signify imminent death, I'm still under $11k total
after the first 5k miles I've put on the car, which feels really good. 

: Sorry I'm considering a water pumper

Don't be.  I haven't driven anything made by our favorite marque that I didn't
think was a nice car.  The 4-cylinder water pumpers are a class of their own,
and I suspect if you find a recent vintage model in good condition, you'll
enjoy it a lot!  Very comfortable for long trips...

Bdale

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 95 07:50:01 PDT
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re:Query on rebuilt 911 calipe


Soren-

>Are rebuild kits available?

Yes.  From just about every place that advertises in Pano or Excellence.  You can also  get them from your local autoparts store.

>Is the process generally successful? 

Yes.  Rebuilding a caliper is a pretty simple operation.  All you do is replace an inner O-ring type seal, and the outer dustcover.  The latter
is what is evidently torn on yours.

>Are third party (e.g. Vertex) rebuilt calipers trustworthy?

Don't know, but can't imagine why not.  Like I said, rebuilding is
pretty simple and straightforward.  By the way, a rebuild kit costs about $10.  How much does Vertex charge for a rebuilt caliper?

Have fun.

Bob Spindel
spindel@apl.washington.edu

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 07:51:56 -0700

Tell him the oil holes in the filter are fewer and small than the holes in a
Mahn Which measns less oil flow, cooling and lubrication. If that doesn't
convince him tell him it costs $10-15,000 to rebuild a 911 engine. If he
still doesn't get it give up it is his money.

mike

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 95 08:42:17 PDT
From: Scott=D=Berry%MfgEng%GPID@banyan.BV.TEK.COM
Subject: Overheating 912

I posted this a couple of days ago and I want to thank you  that replied, but 
so far I am still stumped.  I have some additional information that might help 
out.

Now that the temperature is hitting 90 degrees here in Oregon my 912 is starting 
to complain.  If the temperature is above 80 I can only drive for about 25 
minutes before my temperature gauge is horizontal and I notice a loss of power. 
 (I will eventually install a oil temp gauge, I promise!).  I think I know why 
the car is overheating but I do not know how to fix it.  I have a 1966 912 with 
an the air blower on the right rear side of the engine that splits into two 
vents approximately 3 inches in diameter.  One of the vents goes 
straight down into the rear engine shield above the exhaust pipe coming out of 
cylinder # 2.  The other vent is suppose to have a large (approx. 3 inch heater 
hose) connect to it and the heater hose should connect to a matching hole in the 
rear engine shield right above the exhaust pipe coming out of cylinder  #4.  
Right now I do not have the heater hose connected.  Now here's my problem.  The 
two holes in my rear engine shield for connecting the heater hose to are 
centered right over the exhaust pipes from cylinders #2 and #4.  I have no way 
to connect the two holes in the rear engine shield to the flapper boxes because 
the exhaust pipes are in the way.  I believe my engine is a European one  (the 
engine  Serial number is 832574), but the heating system is U.S. (I think?)  I 
would think that the additional air would help cool the cylinders but I can't 
see how to hook it up.  Do I have the incorrect rear engine shield?  All my 
other engine shields are in place except for the small one that goes under the 
fuel pump. (I'm painting it)  Is this missing heater hose my problem or could it 
be something else?  

Some additional information:

>From what I have read in Harry Pellow's books my car is suppose to be a European 
912.  I think someone at sometime tried to convert the heating system over to 
US???  Does anyone know of a good book that shows US heater systems versus 
European Systems on early 912's?  In my 912 if the temp gauge is horizontal it 
is in the middle of the range, halfway to the red.  The "red" zone is straight 
up top.  The car runs poorly once I enter the middle of the temp. gauge.  I have 
never had the temp. gauge read more then horizontal. At this point the oil 
filter canister is quite hot. The calibration of the temp. gauge may be way off? 
 My car has webers and there are no horns that connect to the carbs for cold 
starting.  I have the "Porsche 912 Handbook" (a orange cover published by Lash 
International) and the pictures on page 184 & 190 look exactly like my engine 
except for the air cleaners and the preheat hoses connected to the air cleaners. 
 The valves are properly adjusted, timing is at 31 degrees BTDC at 3000 rpm, 
Penzoil 20-50W and the engine runs strong on cooler days.  I have owned the car 
for about a year and the engine was spotless when I bought it and is still 
spotless.  Could someone explain the easiest way to get a good look at the oil 
cooler without pulling the engine?  It could be all clogged up, but I doubt it. 
 I appreciate your help!  TIA

Scott
66 912

Thanks, I was kinda feeling bad afterwards because on e-mail you don't really
get much positive feedback, mostly because people only feel compelled to reply
if they dissagree with something.  When I checked my mail again a couple of
days later I had received a couple of positive e-mails to the same effect as
yours, so I feel better.  The thing that made me flame was the rhetoric and
instant blame that these people were spouting without knowing the circumstances
, etc..  It kinda reminded me of the stuff the hardcore religious right say.
And I couldn't just laugh and hit the delete key like I have on other topics.
I am a starving college student and purchasing a 928 has sort of dictated this
lifestyle.  So, my only extra curricular fun(unless a friend is treating!) is
my car.  When people tell me that I cannot drive it the way I want(fast) on
back roads that I know like the back of my hand, I get a little mad.  I do not
agree with the speed limits on most of these roads, and feel that they should
be a suggested speed, and not a law.  God, I sound like a card carying NRA
member arguing for gun rights!  But, I suppose I fell as strongly about my
right to drive my car at speed after I have learned it's limits on the
racetrack(of course taking into account conditions, surroundings, traffic, etc)
 Why can't we organize ourselves to be as powerful a lobbying group as the NRA?
 We could make everyone take a driving school and raise the limits, like in
 Europe!  Oh, I'd better calm down...  How was that for a thanks reply?!

Sean  '80 928

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 09:52:32 -0700 (PDT)
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: Re: 914 Two Questions

> 
> The following questions are about my 1973 914 1.7 which is a limited use
> street only car with the occasional TSD rallys.
> 1. Since this is limited use about once a week if I'm lucky....how often
>    should I start it and are there any tips for keeping a limited use P-car
>    in good condition?

Depending on my work schedule, I either drive mine every day, or
every other week.  It doesn't seem to mind.

I think the important thing here is to *drive* it, not just start it.

You want to run it long enough to recharge the battery, and let it get
hot enough to get rid of all the condensed moisture.

Change the oil based on TIME, not miles.

> 2. Shocks..it now has 59K miles and the shocks are weak...especially the
>    rear...I have removed them to check...the springs are still in spec at
>    471mm length.....for a street only car what are the best shocks?
>    Koni/Bilstein/Boge....as usual I want it all by having good handling
>    and a good street ride....it doesn't have sway bars...
> Thanks....John
> 

"good street ride": Get adjustable shocks.  Koni's are good, KYB's
are almost as good.  Bilsteins are NOT adjustable.  Stock shocks
*are* weak.

Sway bars:  Get a front one.  It's not *that* expensive to have
the front transom opened up and the mounts installed.  (1.5 hours
shop time.)  If the mounts are there, you have *no* excuse.

Gary.

Bruce,

As a matter of fact, I did just change the oil.  How can I tell if the 
sump plate/scavenge tubes are installed correctly or misaligned?  It 
seemed that the sump plate only goes on one way (at least easily).  Is it 
possible for the positioning of the scavenge tube to change unknowingly 
as the sump plate is removed/replaced?

This has to be the problem since it has only occurred since changing the 
oil (I hope).
**********************************

I knew this problem sounded familiar!

The pickup tube goes through the hole, not the other way.

The screen will go on 2 (two) ways.

With my car, it ran okay until I got on the power, at which time
it got hot.

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 10:26:47 -0700
From: winders@apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Rev Limiters, fuel and autocross

It would appear that Byron and I agree much more than we disagree!!
Probably because I took the "always late apex unless it sets you up wrong"
approach and Byron takes the "examine the corner thoroughly then decide
what is fastest" approach.

Byron's approach ultimately is better but I am not sure that many of us
have the time to analyse every corner on the course to determine whether
or not an earlier apex through a turn costs us time or saves us time.

I still believe that over 90% of the turns I see on autocross courses
should be late apexed. Based on that, it is certainly better to err
on less than 10% of the turns than to confuse your self trying to figure
out every turn.

The good news is that as you autocross more, you get better and better
at recognizing what to do with each turn.

That is why I say: "When in doubt, late apex".

Scott Winders
winders@apple.com

P.S. I forgot to "cc" the list on my response and Byron asked that I
forward this along:

>From: "Byron D. Short / AFS Inc." <bshort@usa.net>
>Reply-To: "Byron D. Short / AFS Inc." <bshort@usa.net>
>Subject: Re: Rev Limiters, fuel and autocross
>To: winders@apple.com
>Date: Thu, 29 Jun 1995 13:15:30 -0600 (MDT)
>Mime-Version: 1.0
>
>Hi Again, Scott--
>
>> It figures we would end up agreeing on that damn turn. But like I said,
>> you picked a very good one to illustrate your point. The turn has some
>> unique aspects to it that make the traditional late apex not such a good
>> idea.
>
>It's probably the most clear-cut example I could think of.  I believe
>there are many more subtle examples that would have been harder to make
>the point.  As the differences become more slight, my view becomes even
>more minority...and the math has to be a lot more exact to show any
>appreciable difference.
>
>> Also, I am not convinced that someone would have a 5 MPH advantage using
>> the traditional late apex line. Especially with me in a 911 that will
>> rotate on command.
>
>Keep in mind that I applied the same g force to both lines.  The fact that
>you rotate the car (a trait that my FWD competitor's simply didn't have
>available) doesn't [significantly] change your g's and the radius that
>you're traveling. (And in my example I kept it simple by applying the same
>1 g max to both traces, without regard to pitching the car.)  Using my
>basic assumptions, 1 g for each car (regardless of rotation) and radii of
>70' and 40', 5mph is the difference.  In the real world lots of other
>factors can adjust that amount, but the principles remain true.
>
>The instant rotation (which I always used in the 914) does keep you from
>wasting additional time re-aiming the car down the straight.  In that
>regard it's needed to generate the extremely large difference this one
>corner example produced.  If we couldn't rotate the car, we'd probably
>have lost another 1/2 second (no math on this one--just a wild-assed
>guess) because we'd have had to stay on that 40' radius longer to bring
>the car around.  And when you subtract 1/2 second from our advantage, we
>lose our edge in only about 180 feet!
>
>> It is very
>> hard to tell without being able to walk it and then drive it.
>
>Truer words ain't never been spoke.
>
>> I still don't like your rule of thumb. I think late apexes are the way to
>> go in most situations. The way most autox courses are setup you have 90
>> degree turns linked like this:
>>
>>
>>        -----------------
>>                         |
>>                         |
>>                         |
>>                         |
>>         -------         |
>>                |        |
>>                |        |
>>                |        |
>>                |         -----------------
>>                |
>>                |
>>                |
>>                 --------------------------
>>
>>
>> The ONLY way to drive these turns is to late apex them. Turns with an inside
>> radius are casue for thought and experimentation.
>
>I bet we'd do the same thing here...late apex the first one (in fact, REAL
>late) to allow a good fast exit on the second one.  If the straight
>following is real long I'll late apex the second as well.  If it's shorter
>I'll concentrate on getting out of the corner on the shortest line
>possible, even if that meant an early apex (although usually it's just
>about nuetral).
>
>
>--
>[]  []  []      []                []              []       Byron D. Short
>  []  []   []        []                        []       bshort@AFSinc.com
>[]  []  []     []             []                           (719) 531-9511
>  []  []   []       []                 []                     1990 944 S2
>[]  []  []    []         []         New sig--equally un-appealing to all.

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 14:06:30 -0400 (EDT)
From: Mark D Wemple <mwemple@acsu.buffalo.edu>
Subject: Re: Distilled or Non-Distilled H2O?

I just purchased a Vanagon with a water boxer after doing some research 
on them. What i leasrned is that, yes do use distilled water to help 
inhibit corosion. You will also find that using phosphate free 
anti-freeze is a good idea especially for those of you with any aluminum 
engine components(everyone).
address:
mwemple through pine

>

> eliminate corrosion and the precipitation of minerals that reduce radiator
> efficiency.

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 14:03:51 -0400 (EDT)
From: Bill Byrne <byrne@cspjhu.ece.jhu.edu>
Subject: Re: Wandering C-2

I'm also following the accounts of the wandering C-2s.

I've hesitated posting what fixed my 85 911 from wandering
because I didn't want to risk offending anyone.  But I don't
think anyone's suggested this yet so ... did you check 
that the tires are pointing in the right direction?  

I had some work done on my wheels and
suspension last fall and, when I got it back from the shop,
the car was all over the road.  It was kind of fun, but not
quite what I was looking for.  Turns out the right
rear tire was installed backwards so the tread was pointing
the wrong way.  

Bill

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 14:32:52 -0400 (EDT)
From: Mark D Wemple <mwemple@acsu.buffalo.edu>
Subject: Re: early vs. late 911s

why aren't you looking at the 74-77 911s. I know, their bad reputation. 
Well, screw Bruce he isn't god you know. What you want is a well 
maintained car for reliability. I am guessing that you want CIS for its 
ease of opperation compared to carbs or MFI- good thought. Also consider 
76 or later for their galvanizing. Remember the later S models may not 
have been the track cars that the earlier ones were but they have a great 
deal more torque, are less finiky and will cost you less to buy and 
maintain. Oh and by the way, a properly rebuilt 2.7 is good for an easy 
200K. Good luck!

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 14:22:47 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: 914 Exhaust Nuts (NUTS!)

        Well, I must say that after trying the 40-cent 12mm exhaust
nuts that I got from GPR--"THEY SUCK!"
        These nuts have a hole through the center that is round at
the bottom (the way nuts are supposed to be), but is oval at the top.
The threads on the ovaled part do not mate with the threads on the
stud.  Wound up pulling an exhaust stud with it.   B^P
        If you have ordered these nuts, check them carefully.  You may
see some marks at the top of two faces of the nut where it seems to
have been squeezed.  If it has, it won't work correctly.
        I am going to re-use the four Factory nuts that came off the
car, and buy four more of the $11 list ($8.40 at cost+20%) 13 mm nuts.
Anyone have any other suggestions?
        I think I'll call up GPR and ask if I can have a $6.40 credit
on my next order with them...

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 12:44:50 -0700
From: wilson@ns.net (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Re: Wandering C-2

Regarding the wandering C-2, didn't see the original post, but perchance
were the rear tires replaced and the fronts still originals?

My genius son, the mechanic, tells me original tires on C-2/4 cars came
"matched" and replacing only the rears (even with the same type) may create
weird handling.

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 95 13:05:46 PDT
From: Miq Millman <mmillman@ptdcs2.intel.com>
Subject: Re: Early 911S serial number

Peter Barlow says:
>      Who keeps a serial number list on their desk?  Is 302403
> a valid 911S serial number, and is that 66 or 67?  There is one for
> sale here, pretty ratty but solid where it counts.  Runs OK too.  Good
> restoration candidate.

This is an early 1966 model 911. "S" models should have an S at the end. 1967
models started at around 307xxx.  There were a handful of 1966 911S, euro
market cars, built near the end of the year, serial numbers were in the
306xxxS to 307xxxS range.

Mine is 306745S

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 13:10:33 -0700
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Mike Willis)
Subject: Re: Where is the Mather AFB autox?

Mater field is off hwy 50 at Mather field blvd offramp. Those going east
will turn right at the end of the ramp. and proceed as straight as possible
after you pass the first signal. mather field is on right so you will bear
right before the next light. go through the gate and proceed to stratoliner
and turn left. after you go around the end of the runway and about one
quarter mile after the golf course entrance there will a "road" to the
right. We should have a sign up there for this weekends zone autox. follow
that road and enter through the gate keep right and park. And now it is time
for some third gear autoxing.

mike

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 17:57:59 -0400 (EDT)
From: Richard Hollander <ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us>
Subject: Re: Do I trade my Audi for a 944

I've an '87 951 and it's much better than any Audi product, in my 
professional (as a car writer) opinion--except for the Audi V8. Anyway, 
go for the 951 and not the 944S. The S has little low-end torque, when 
compared to the 951, and is not the "bahn stormer" either. 

I've driven my 951 in the snow often, and it ain't bad. Then again, I've 
ABS and LSD on the car, so they help. Also, I used P-Zero's; with 
dedicated M&S tires, I imagine the car would be twice as tractable. 
Getting to the point--it's good in the winter. Mind you, it has a 50-50% 
distribution of weight. 

Go for a 951! Good luck.


RickSH
ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us

Chris, have your friend cut open a Fram filter and look inside, it will  do all
of the talking.  Be sure its a Ford FL 1A (I think PH8A).  These  filter look
horrible when opened up.

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 18:27:49 -0400
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: Wandering C2.....ain't fixed but got a hunch

Steve said:

> Well, after 4 new tires and two front-end alignments (one at the dealer
>and the other at an independant garage) the 'ol C2 still starts to wander
>at 70-80 mph.

To coin one of Stan's favorite phrases, "Sigh....."

You missed the single most likely cause of wandering, weight balance.  If you
have not had the car weght balanced, PRIOR to alignment, the car is most
likely acting like a teeter totter with the weight jacked between two wheels
diagonal to each other.  Get to a high performance alignment center, or a
major Porsche dealer that has the proper scales and get the car weight
balanced to within about 15 lbs. or so side to side with the drivers weight
in the front seat. That is the weight on the two front tires ought to be
within 15 lbs. of each other, as should the two rear tires. If the places you
took the car to be aligned look at you like you are from Mars when you talk
weight balancing, run like hell. I've transformed several cars from beasts
into lambs by proper balancing and alignment.  The idiot that told you that
air getting under the front of the car at 70 -80 mph is the cause of your
problems doesn't know his A-- from a hole in the ground. (Excuse my
french..., I just get pi--ed off about people that waste other people's money
because they don't have a clue).

I really hope this helps. I don't know where you live, but if you are within
200 miles of Cincinnati, OH, go to Bill Braucksick at Performance Alignment.
 I go there and I'm from Alabama...

Jon Lowe
Heart O' Dixie Region, PCA

>200K. Good luck!

Date: 30 Jun 95 18:44:42 EDT
From: Chris Werle <74537.554@compuserve.com>
Subject: 1989 Speedster Info.


>Date: 26 Jun 1995 10:21:29 U
>From: Steve Poole <stevep@wrq.com>
>Subject: Any '89 911 Speedster savvy?
>
>I'm toying with the notion of making a 1989 911 Speedster my next P-car. I've
>seen virtually nothing about these in print; all I know is that I experience
>what some would term an unnatural urge when I see pictures of these cars.
>There don't seem to be many for sale, and the three in the most recent Pano
>were all in the $60K neighborhood (admittedly for very low mile, flawless
>cars). Owie!
>
>Can someone tell me a bit about these? Are there severely limited numbers?
>Where can I read more about them? Is there any reason to not purchase one?
>
>Steve Poole
>stevep@wrq.com
>1979 911SC

Steve,

The '89 Speedster is a pretty rare care, only made in 1989 and in limited
quantities (I think about 1,000 world-wide).  That's probably the reason you
haven't seen many for sale.

The '89 Speedster has a turbo-like wide-body with a cropped windshield, and
therefore is a very distinctive Porsche.  The "new" (1994) Speedster does not
have the wide-body and looks totally different.  I like the 1989 model MUCH
better.  The 1989 also has the Carerra 3.3 engine.

I think it's a beautiful car and a great investment which can be found for about
$50k (see below).  Check Hemmings Motor News, the Porsche Market Letter, or
duPont Registry.

"1989 911 Speedster, red/black, 3400 miles $49,900 (417) 886-3200"

Chris Werle
scwerle@aol.com
1989 911 Turbo Cabriolet

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 19:22:22 -0400 (EDT)
From: Tomkow <tomkow@nando.net>
Subject: re:Re: 911: Fram oild filter, Help!


Hi P-Philers,

Back in the stone age when I was a BMW wrench and then service manager, 
we had some pennywise customers who would screw on anything that would 
fit.  The most amusing cases were the colder mornings when they would 
start their car and immediately drive off.  The oil filters without the 
pressure reliefs would then blow open at high rpm's and empty all of the 
oil out in short order.  The less intelligent customers would try to 
drive to the shop...

Still Laughing about the money they saved!
 -Bill Tomko
  '84 Carrera

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 18:15:49 -0500
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 Exhaust Nuts (NUTS!)

>           These nuts have a hole through the center that is round at
>   the bottom (the way nuts are supposed to be), but is oval at the top.

        From several people on the list, and one of "the guys" here at
work, I have found out that these are *lock-nuts* and that is the way
that they lock.
        I'm still not that pleased with them.  Also, the factory nuts
that I took off the car did not appear to be locknuts.  Anyway, I wound
up with some "other" copper-coated nuts to do the job.  They went on
quite a bit easier--though the anti-sieze may have had something to do
with that.  (DUH!  I *knew* I'd forgotten *something*!)
        Thanks!

- --DD

Dave Darling                                  + Two 914 "projects"
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov
        "I have an opinion, and everyone's entitled to it!"

Date: Fri, 30 Jun 1995 20:56:12 -0400
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: 911 Ride Height Adjust. Question

Hey,

I adjusted the rear ride height of my 911 as a result of
putting some Koni shocks on a few weeks ago.  The Konis
actually lifted the rear of my car about 14mm (hence the
need for adjustment).  Anyway, the whole task was pretty
easy (thanks to a comment Mike Piera(?) made).  I 
needed to rotate the torsion bar relative to the spring
plate, but since I have the Sway-a-way adjustable spring
plates, I only took the "outer" part off and left the main
part of it bolted to the banana arm.  My quandary is that
due to the way the thing came apart, I rotated the inner
end of the torsion bar on one side and the outer end on
the other.  If I'm not mistaken this results in a difference
side to side of about 0 degrees 50 minutes.  I was able
to easily level the car using the spring plate adjustment
screws, and it seems that ride height is a function of
"torque" on the torsion bar, so even though I have this
slight initial difference in geometry, everything should
be OK, right?

What do you guys think?  Luckily, this whole job only took
me about 1 hour and 45 minutes, but I don't want to make a 
habit out of it.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911
